故事

S·T·O·R·Y

故事

STORY

故事



S·T·O·R·Y



内容、结构、风格

和剧本创作原则





Substance, Structure, Style,

and the Principles of Screenwriting





罗伯特·麦基





R  O  B  E  R  T    M  c  K  E  E





我将这本书献给我父母的美好回忆，他们以不同的方式教会了我对故事的热爱。

I dedicate this book to the happy memory of my parents who, in their very different ways, taught me the love of story.

当我刚开始学习阅读，但行为举止并不总是得体时，父亲就向我介绍了伊索寓言，希望这些古老的警世故事能改善我的举止。每天晚上，在我读完《狐狸和葡萄》之类的故事后，他都会点头并问：“罗伯特，这个故事对你来说意味着什么？”当我盯着这些文本和它们漂亮的彩色插图，努力寻找自己的解读时，我慢慢意识到故事的意义远不止文字和漂亮的图片。

When I was first learning to read, but not always behaving appropriately, my father introduced me to the fables of Aesop in the hope that these ancient cautionary tales might improve my deportment. Each evening, after working my way through the likes of “The Fox and the Grapes,” he would nod and ask, “And what does this story mean to you, Robert?” As I stared at these texts and their handsome color illustrations, struggling to find my interpretations, I slowly came to realize that stories mean much more than words and pretty pictures.

后来，在进入大学之前，我推断出最好的生活就是尽可能多地打高尔夫球，因此，我会成为一名牙医。“牙医？！”我妈妈笑道。“你不是认真的吧。当他们治愈了所有牙齿问题时会发生什么？到那时牙医会在哪里？不，鲍比，人们总是需要娱乐。我在为你的未来着想。你要进入演艺界。”

Later, before entering the university, I deduced that the best possible life includes as many rounds of golf as possible, and therefore, I would become a dentist. “Dentist?!” my mother laughed. “You can’t be serious. What happens when they cure all teeth problems? Where will dentists be then? No, Bobby, people will always need entertainment. I’m looking out for your future. You’re going into show business.”

经文注释

NOTES ON THE TEXT

《故事》中的数百个例子取材于一个世纪以来全球的电影写作和电影制作。只要有可能，我就会提供不止一部我所知道的最新和广为人知的作品。因为不可能选出每个人都看过并记得细节的电影，所以我倾向于选择那些随时可观看的视频。但最重要的是，每部电影之所以被选中，是因为它清楚地说明了文中的观点。

The hundreds of examples in Story are drawn from a century of film writing and filmmaking around the world. Whenever possible, I offer more than one title of the most recent and widely seen works I know. Because it’s impossible to select films everyone has seen and remembers in detail, I’ve leaned toward those readily available on video. But first and foremost, each film has been chosen because it is a clear illustration of the point made in the text.

为了解决代词问题，我避免使用分散读者注意力的结构，例如令人讨厌的“她”和“她”与“他”和“他”的交替，重复的“他和她”和“他和她”，尴尬的“他/她”和“她/我”，以及不合语法的“他们”和“他们”作为中性单数。相反，我使用非排他性的“他”和“他”来表示“作家”。

To deal with the pronoun problem I have avoided constructions that distract the reader’s eye, such as the annoying alternation of “she” and “her” with “he” and “him,” the repetitious “he and she” and “him and her,” the awkward “s/he” and “her/im,” and the ungrammatical “they” and “them” as neuter singulars. Rather, I use the nonexclusive “he” and “him” to mean “writer.”

第一部分

作家

与故事

艺术



PART 1

THE

WRITER

AND THE

ART OF

STORY

故事是生活的装备。

Stories are equipment for living.

—肯尼思·伯克

— KENNETH BURKE

介绍

INTRODUCTION

故事讲的是原则，而不是规则。

Story is about principles, not rules.

规则说：“你必须这样做。 ”原则说：“这有效……并且历久弥新。”两者的区别至关重要。你的作品不必模仿“制作精良”的剧本；相反，它必须符合塑造我们艺术的原则。焦虑、缺乏经验的作家遵守规则。叛逆、未受过教育的作家打破规则。艺术家掌握形式。

A rule says, “You must do it this way.” A principle says, “This works … and has through all remembered time.” The difference is crucial. Your work needn’t be modeled after the “well-made” play; rather, it must be well made within the principles that shape our art. Anxious, inexperienced writers obey rules. Rebellious, unschooled writers break rules. Artists master the form.

故事是关于永恒的、普遍的形式，而不是公式。

Story is about eternal, universal forms, not formulas.

所有关于商业成功的范式和万无一失的故事模型都是胡说八道。尽管有潮流、翻拍和续集，但当我们纵观好莱坞电影的整体时，我们发现故事设计种类繁多，但没有原型。《虎胆龙威》并不比《为人父母》、《边缘明信片》、《狮子王》、《摇滚万岁》、《命运的逆转》、《危险关系》、《土拨鼠日》、《离开拉斯维加斯》或从闹剧到悲剧的数十种类型和子类型的数千部其他优秀电影更能代表好莱坞。

All notions of paradigms and foolproof story models for commercial success are nonsense. Despite trends, remakes, and sequels, when we survey the totality of Hollywood film, we find an astounding variety of story designs, but no prototype. DIE HARD is no more typical of Hollywood than are PARENTHOOD, POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE, THE LION KING, THIS IS SPINAL TAP, REVERSAL OF FORTUNE, DANGEROUS LIAISONS, GROUNDHOG DAY, LEAVING LAS VEGAS, or thousands of other excellent films in dozens of genres and subgenres from farce to tragedy.

Story鼓励创作出让六大洲观众激动不已、几十年后仍能复兴的作品。没人需要另一本关于如何重新加热好莱坞剩菜剩饭的食谱。我们需要重新发现我们艺术的基本原则，即解放人才的指导原则。无论电影在哪里制作——好莱坞、巴黎、香港——如果它具有原型品质，它就会引发全球和永久的连锁反应，让观众从一家电影院流传到另一家电影院，一代又一代地观看。

Story urges the creation of works that will excite audiences on the six continents and live in revival for decades. No one needs yet another recipe book on how to reheat Hollywood leftovers. We need a rediscovery of the underlying tenets of our art, the guiding principles that liberate talent. No matter where a film is made—Hollywood, Paris, Hong Kong—if it’s of archetypal quality, it triggers a global and perpetual chain reaction of pleasure that carries it from cinema to cinema, generation to generation.

故事是关于原型，而不是刻板印象。

Story is about archetypes, not stereotypes.

原型故事发掘出普遍的人类体验，然后将自己包裹在独特的、特定文化的表达方式中。刻板故事则颠倒了这种模式：它的内容和形式都很贫乏。它将自己限制在狭隘的、特定文化的体验中，并披上了陈腐的、不具体的泛泛之谈。

The archetypal story unearths a universally human experience, then wraps itself inside a unique, culture-specific expression. A stereotypical story reverses this pattern: It suffers a poverty of both content and form. It confines itself to a narrow, culture-specific experience and dresses in stale, nonspecific generalities.

例如，西班牙的习俗曾经规定，女儿必须按照从大到小的顺序出嫁。在西班牙文化中，一部关于 19 世纪一个由严厉的家长、无能的母亲、嫁不出去的大女儿和长期受苦的小女儿组成的家庭的电影可能会打动那些记得这一习俗的人，但在西班牙文化之外，观众不太可能产生共鸣。作家担心他的故事吸引力有限，于是诉诸过去让观众感到愉悦的熟悉场景、人物和动作。结果呢？世界对这些陈词滥调的兴趣更小了。

For example, Spanish custom once dictated that daughters must be married off in order from oldest to youngest. Inside Spanish culture, a film about the nineteenth-century family of a strict patriarch, a powerless mother, an unmarriageable oldest daughter, and a long-suffering youngest daughter may move those who remember this practice, but outside Spanish culture audiences are unlikely to empathize. The writer, fearing his story’s limited appeal, resorts to the familiar settings, characters, and actions that have pleased audiences in the past. The result? The world is even less interested in these clichés.

另一方面，如果艺术家撸起袖子寻找原型，这种压抑的习俗可能会成为全球性成功的素材。原型故事创造了如此罕见的背景和人物，让我们的眼睛饱览每一个细节，而它的讲述方式揭示了如此真实的人类冲突，以至于它在不同的文化中传播开来。

On the other hand, this repressive custom could become material for a worldwide success if the artist were to roll up his sleeves and search for an archetype. An archetypal story creates settings and characters so rare that our eyes feast on every detail, while its telling illuminates conflicts so true to humankind that it journeys from culture to culture.

在劳拉·埃斯基维尔 (Laura Esquivel) 的《巧克力情人》 (LIKE WATER FOR CHOCOLATE) 中，母亲和女儿在依赖与独立、持久与变化、自我与他人的需求之间发生冲突——每个家庭都知道这样的冲突。然而，埃斯基维尔对家庭和社会、人际关系和行为的观察是如此丰富，充满了前所未见的细节，我们无法抗拒地被这些人物所吸引，并被一个我们从未了解或无法想象的领域所吸引。

In Laura Esquivel’s LIKE WATER FOR CHOCOLATE, mother and daughter clash over the demands of dependence versus independence, permanence versus change, self versus others—conflicts every family knows. Yet Esquivel’s observation of home and society, of relationship and behavior is so rich in never-before-seen detail, we’re drawn irresistibly to these characters and fascinated by a realm we’ve never known, nor could imagine.

刻板故事留在家里，原型故事四处传播。从查理·卓别林到英格玛·伯格曼，从萨蒂亚吉特·雷伊到伍迪·艾伦，电影大师的故事讲述者给我们带来了我们渴望的双重体验。首先，发现一个我们不知道的世界。无论多么亲密或史诗般，当代或历史，具体或幻想，一位杰出艺术家的世界总是令人震撼我们觉得有些异国情调或奇怪。就像探险家拨开森林的树叶一样，我们睁大眼睛走进一个未被触及的社会，一个没有陈词滥调的区域，在这里平凡变得非凡。

Stereotypical stories stay at home, archetypal stories travel. From Charlie Chaplin to Ingmar Bergman, from Satyajit Ray to Woody Allen, the cinema’s master storytellers give us the double-edged encounter we crave. First, the discovery of a world we do not know. No matter how intimate or epic, contemporary or historical, concrete or fantasized, the world of an eminent artist always strikes us as somewhat exotic or strange. Like an explorer parting forest leaves, we step wide-eyed into an untouched society, a cliché-free zone where the ordinary becomes extraordinary.

其次，一旦进入这个陌生的世界，我们就会发现自己。在这些角色和他们的冲突中，我们发现了我们自己的人性。我们去看电影是为了进入一个全新的、迷人的世界，间接地融入另一个人，他乍一看与我们完全不同，但内心却与我们一样，生活在一个照亮我们日常现实的虚构现实中。我们不想逃避生活，而是想寻找生活，以新鲜、实验的方式运用我们的思想，表达我们的情感，享受生活，学习生活，为我们的生活增添深度。故事的创作是为了培养具有典型力量和美感的电影，让世界享受这种双重乐趣。

Second, once inside this alien world, we find ourselves. Deep within these characters and their conflicts we discover our own humanity. We go to the movies to enter a new, fascinating world, to inhabit vicariously another human being who at first seems so unlike us and yet at heart is like us, to live in a fictional reality that illuminates our daily reality. We do not wish to escape life but to find life, to use our minds in fresh, experimental ways, to flex our emotions, to enjoy, to learn, to add depth to our days. Story was written to foster films of archetypal power and beauty that will give the world this dual pleasure.

故事讲究彻底性，而非捷径。

Story is about thoroughness, not shortcuts.

从灵感迸发到最终定稿，编写剧本所需的时间可能与编写小说所需的时间一样多。电影和散文作家创造的世界、人物和故事的密度相同，但由于剧本页面上有太多空白，我们常常误以为剧本比小说更快更容易。但是，尽管抄写狂们以打字的速度填满页面，但电影编剧却不断删减，他们无情地希望用尽可能少的词语表达出最大限度的内容。帕斯卡曾经给一位朋友写了一封冗长的信，然后在后记中为自己没有时间写一封短信而道歉。像帕斯卡一样，编剧们也明白节约是关键，简洁需要时间，卓越意味着坚持不懈。

From inspiration to last draft you may need as much time to write a screenplay as to write a novel. Screen and prose writers create the same density of world, character, and story, but because screenplay pages have so much white on them, we’re often mislead into thinking that a screenplay is quicker and easier than a novel. But while scribomaniacs fill pages as fast as they can type, film writers cut and cut again, ruthless in their desire to express the absolute maximum in the fewest possible words. Pascal once wrote a long, drawn-out letter to a friend, then apologized in the postscript that he didn’t have time to write a short one. Like Pascal, screenwriters learn that economy is key, that brevity takes time, that excellence means perseverance.

故事讲述的是现实，而不是写作的奥秘。

Story is about the realities, not the mysteries of writing.

没有任何阴谋来隐瞒我们艺术的真相。自亚里士多德写下《诗学》以来的二十三个世纪里，故事的“秘密”一直像街对面的图书馆一样公开。讲故事的技巧中没有什么是深奥的。事实上，乍一看，在屏幕上讲故事似乎很容易。但我们越来越接近中心，尝试一幕一幕地让故事发挥作用，任务变得越来越困难，因为我们意识到在屏幕上没有地方可以隐藏。

There’s been no conspiracy to keep secret the truths of our art. In the twenty-three centuries since Aristotle wrote The Poetics, the “secrets” of story have been as public as the library down the street. Nothing in the craft of storytelling is abstruse. In fact, at first glance telling story for the screen looks deceptively easy. But moving closer and closer to the center, trying scene by scene to make the story work, the task becomes increasingly difficult, as we realize that on the screen there’s no place to hide.

如果编剧不能用戏剧场景的纯粹性打动我们，他就不能像小说家用作者的口吻或剧作家用独白那样，隐藏在文字背后。他不能用解释性或情感性的语言掩盖逻辑上的漏洞、不明确的动机或无色彩的情感，只是告诉我们该想什么或该如何感受。

If a screenwriter fails to move us with the purity of a dramatized scene, he cannot, like a novelist in authorial voice, or the playwright in soliloquy, hide behind his words. He cannot smooth a coating of explanatory or emotive language over cracks in logic, blotchy motivation, or colorless emotion and simply tell us what to think or how to feel.

相机是可怕的X光机，可以检测一切虚假。它多次放大生活，然后剥去故事中每个虚弱或虚假的转折，直到我们感到困惑和沮丧，想要放弃。然而，只要下定决心并深入研究，谜题就会解开。剧本创作充满奇迹，但没有无法解决的谜题。

The camera is the dread X-ray machine of all things false. It magnifies life many times over, then strips naked every weak or phony story turn, until in confusion and frustration we’re tempted to quit. Yet, given determination and study, the puzzle yields. Screenwriting is full of wonders but no unsolvable mysteries.

故事在于掌握艺术，而不是猜测市场。

Story is about mastering the art, not second-guessing the marketplace.

没人能教什么会卖，什么不会卖，什么会大获成功或惨败，因为没人知道。好莱坞的烂片和热门片一样，都是出于同样的商业考量，而那些读起来像是金钱智慧告诉你绝对不能做的事情的清单的黑暗剧——《普通人》、《意外的旅客》、《猜火车》——却悄然征服了国内和国际票房。我们的艺术没有任何东西是可以保证的。这就是为什么这么多人为“闯入”、“成功”和“创意干预”而苦恼。

No one can teach what will sell, what won’t, what will be a smash or a fiasco, because no one knows. Hollywood’s bombs are made with the same commercial calculation as its hits, whereas darkish dramas that read like a checklist of everything moneyed wisdom says you must never do—ORDINARY PEOPLE, THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, TRAINSPOTTING—quietly conquer the domestic and international box office. Nothing in our art is guaranteed. That’s why so many agonize over “breaking in,” “making it,” and “creative interference.”

大城市对所有这些担忧的诚实回答是，当你写出质量卓越的作品时，你会得到一个经纪人，出售你的作品，并看到它如实地在屏幕上实现……但直到你。如果你能复制去年夏天的热门作品，你就会加入那些每年向好莱坞推出成千上万个陈词滥调故事的低才华行列。与其为成功而苦恼，不如把精力投入到追求卓越上。如果你向经纪人展示一个精彩的原创剧本，他们会争取代表你的权利。你雇佣的经纪人会在缺乏故事的制片人之间挑起一场竞价战，获胜者将支付给你一笔令人尴尬的金钱。

The honest, big-city answer to all these fears is that you’ll get an agent, sell your work, and see it realized faithfully on screen when you write with surpassing quality … and not until. If you knock out a knockoff of last summer’s hit, you’ll join the ranks of lesser talents who each year flood Hollywood with thousands of cliché-ridden stories. Rather than agonizing over the odds, put your energies into achieving excellence. If you show a brilliant, original screenplay to agents, they’ll fight for the right to represent you. The agent you hire will incite a bidding war among story-starved producers, and the winner will pay you an embarrassing amount of money.

更重要的是，一旦投入制作，完成的剧本几乎不会受到干扰。没有人能保证不幸的个性结合不会破坏好的作品，但可以肯定的是，好莱坞最优秀的演员和导演人才都敏锐地意识到，他们的职业生涯取决于高质量的剧本。然而，由于好莱坞对故事的渴求，剧本往往在成熟之前就被选中，迫使片场进行修改。稳妥的作家不会出售初稿。他们会耐心地重写剧本，直到剧本尽可能适合导演和演员。未完成的作品容易被篡改，而经过打磨的成熟作品则能保证其完整性。

What’s more, once in production, your finished screenplay will meet with surprisingly little interference. No one can promise that unfortunate conjunctions of personalities won’t spoil good work, but be certain that Hollywood’s best acting and directing talents are acutely aware that their careers depend on working within quality writing. Yet because of Hollywood’s ravenous appetite for story, scripts are often picked before they’re ripe, forcing changes on the set. Secure writers don’t sell first drafts. They patiently rewrite until the script is as director-ready, as actor-ready as possible. Unfinished work invites tampering, while polished, mature work seals its integrity.

故事是对观众的尊重，而不是蔑视。

Story is about respect, not disdain, for the audience.

有才华的人写得不好通常是出于以下两个原因：要么他们被一个他们觉得必须证明的想法蒙蔽了双眼，要么他们被一种必须表达的情感所驱使。有才华的人写得好通常是出于这个原因：他们被一种想要打动观众的欲望所感动。

When talented people write badly it’s generally for one of two reasons: Either they’re blinded by an idea they feel compelled to prove or they’re driven by an emotion they must express. When talented people write well, it is generally for this reason: They’re moved by a desire to touch the audience.

多年来，在表演和导演生涯中，我夜复一夜地敬畏观众，敬畏他们的反应能力。仿佛被施了魔法，观众的面具脱落，脸上变得脆弱、善于接受。电影观众不会保护自己的情绪，而是以连他们的爱人都不知道的方式向讲故事的人敞开心扉，欢迎欢笑、泪水、恐惧、愤怒、同情、激情、爱、恨——这种仪式常常让他们精疲力竭。

Night after night, through years of performing and directing, I’ve stood in awe of the audience, of its capacity for response. As if by magic, masks fall away, faces become vulnerable, receptive. Filmgoers do not defend their emotions, rather they open to the storyteller in ways even their lovers never know, welcoming laughter, tears, terror, rage, compassion, passion, love, hate—the ritual often exhausts them.

观众不仅异常敏感，而且当他们坐进漆黑的影院时，他们的集体智商会上升 25 点。当你去看电影时，你是不是常常觉得自己比你看的电影更聪明？你知道角色在做什么之前会做什么？你在结局到来之前就知道结局？观众不仅聪明，而且比大多数电影都聪明，而且当你移到屏幕的另一边时，这一事实也不会改变。这就是作家所能做的，利用每一点他所掌握的技巧，能够领先于专注的观众的敏锐洞察力。

The audience is not only amazingly sensitive, but as it settles into a darkened theatre its collective IQ jumps twenty-five points. When you go to the movies, don’t you often feel you’re more intelligent than what you’re watching? That you know what characters are going to do before they do it? That you see the ending coming long before it arrives? The audience is not only smart, it’s smarter than most films, and that fact won’t change when you move to the other side of the screen. It’s all a writer can do, using every bit of craft he’s mastered, to keep ahead of the sharp perceptions of a focused audience.

如果不了解观众的反应和期望，任何电影都无法成功。你必须以一种既能表达你的愿景又能满足观众愿望的方式来塑造你的故事。观众是决定故事设计的力量，就像任何其他因素一样。因为没有它，创作就毫无意义。

No film can be made to work without an understanding of the reactions and anticipations of the audience. You must shape your story in a way that both expresses your vision and satisfies the audience’s desires. The audience is a force as determining of story design as any other element. For without it, the creative act is pointless.

故事讲求原创，而非复制。

Story is about originality, not duplication.

原创性是内容和形式的融合——独特的主题选择加上独特的叙事方式。内容（背景、人物、想法）和形式（事件的选择和安排）相互需要、相互启发、相互影响。作家一手掌握内容，一手掌握形式，就可以塑造故事。当你重新加工故事的内容时，叙事方式也会重新塑造。当你玩弄故事的形式时，它的智力和情感精神就会不断发展。

Originality is the confluence of content and form—distinctive choices of subject plus a unique shaping of the telling. Content (setting, characters, ideas) and form (selection and arrangement of events) require, inspire, and mutually influence one another. With content in one hand and a mastery of form in the other, a writer sculpts story. As you rework a story’s substance, the telling reshapes itself. As you play with a story’s shape, its intellectual and emotional spirit evolves.

故事不仅关乎你要讲什么，还关乎你如何讲。如果内容陈词滥调，讲述方式也会陈词滥调。但如果你的愿景深刻而新颖，你的故事设计就会独一无二。相反，如果讲述方式传统而可预测，就需要刻板的角色来演绎陈词滥调。但如果故事设计具有创新性，那么设置、角色和想法必须同样新颖才能实现它。我们塑造讲述方式以适应内容，重新加工内容以支持设计。

A story is not only what you have to say but how you say it. If content is cliché, the telling will be cliché. But if your vision is deep and original, your story design will be unique. Conversely, if the telling is conventional and predictable, it will demand stereotypical roles to act out well-worn behaviors. But if the story design is innovative, then settings, characters, and ideas must be equally fresh to fulfill it. We shape the telling to fit the substance, rework the substance to support the design.

然而，千万不要把怪异误认为是原创。为了差异而差异，就像盲目遵循商业规则一样空洞。经过数月甚至数年的努力，将事实、记忆和想象收集成故事素材宝库后，没有一位严肃的作家会将自己的视野禁锢在公式中，或将其琐碎化为前卫的碎片。“制作精良”的公式可能会扼杀故事的声音，但“艺术电影”的怪异会给它带来语言障碍。就像孩子们为了好玩而破坏东西或发脾气以吸引注意力一样，太多的电影制作人用幼稚的花招在屏幕上大喊：“看我能做什么！”成熟的艺术家永远不会引人注目，明智的艺术家永远不会仅仅因为打破常规而做任何事情。

Never, however, mistake eccentricity for originality. Difference for the sake of difference is as empty as slavishly following commercial imperatives. After working for months, perhaps years, to gather facts, memories, and imagination into a treasury of story material, no serious writer would cage his vision inside a formula, or trivialize it into avant-garde fragmentations. The “well-made” formula may choke a story’s voice, but “art movie” quirkiness will give it a speech impediment. Just as children break things for fun or throw tantrums to force attention on themselves, too many film-makers use infantile gimmicks on screen to shout, “Look what I can do!” A mature artist never calls attention to himself, and a wise artist never does anything merely because it breaks convention.

霍顿·福特、罗伯特·奥特曼、约翰·卡萨维蒂、普雷斯顿·斯特吉斯、弗朗索瓦·特吕弗和英格玛·伯格曼等大师的电影都独具特色，三页的简介就能像识别出艺术家的 DNA 一样准确无误。伟大的编剧以个人的叙事风格而著称，这种风格不仅与他们的视野密不可分，而且从深层次上来说就是他们的视野。他们的形式选择——主角数量、进展节奏、冲突程度、时间安排等——与内容的实质性选择——背景、角色、想法——相互影响，直到所有元素融合成一个独特的剧本。

Films by masters such as Horton Foote, Robert Altman, John Cassavetes, Preston Sturges, François Truffaut, and Ingmar Bergman are so idiosyncratic that a three-page synopsis identifies the artist as surely as his DNA. Great screenwriters are distinguished by a personal storytelling style, a style that’s not only inseparable from their vision, but in a profound way is their vision. Their formal choices—number of protagonists, rhythm of progressions, levels of conflict, temporal arrangements, and the like—play with and against substantive choices of content—setting, character, idea—until all elements meld into a unique screenplay.

然而，如果我们暂时将他们电影的内容放在一边，研究他们事件的纯粹模式，我们就会发现，就像没有歌词的旋律，没有矩阵的轮廓，他们的故事设计充满了强烈的意义。讲故事的人对事件的选择和安排是他对现实各个层面相互联系的巧妙隐喻——个人、政治、环境、精神。故事结构剥去表面的人物和地点，揭示了他的个人宇宙观，他对这个世界上事情发生的方式和原因的最深层模式和动机的洞察——他绘制的生活隐秘秩序地图。

If, however, we were to put the content of their films aside for the moment, and study the pure patterning of their events, we’d see that, like a melody without a lyric, like a silhouette without a matrix, their story designs are powerfully charged with meaning. The storyteller’s selection and arrangement of events is his master metaphor for the interconnectedness of all the levels of reality—personal, political, environmental, spiritual. Stripped of its surface of characterization and location, story structure reveals his personal cosmology, his insight into the deepest patterns and motivations for how and why things happen in this world—his map of life’s hidden order.

无论你的偶像是谁——伍迪·艾伦、大卫·马梅、昆汀·塔伦蒂诺、露丝·普劳尔·贾布瓦拉、奥利弗·斯通、威廉·戈德曼、张艺谋、诺拉·艾芙隆、斯派克·李、斯坦利·库布里克——你都钦佩他们，因为他们独一无二。他们每个人都脱颖而出，因为他们选择了与众不同的内容，设计了与众不同的形式，将两者融合成一种独特的风格。我希望你也能如此。

No matter who your heroes may be—Woody Allen, David Mamet, Quentin Tarantino, Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, Oliver Stone, William Goldman, Zhang Yimou, Nora Ephron, Spike Lee, Stanley Kubrick—you admire them because they’re unique. Each has stepped out of the crowd because each selects a content like no one else, designs a form like no one else, combining the two into a style unmistakably his own. I want the same for you.

但我对你的期望不仅仅在于能力和技巧。我渴望看到伟大的电影。在过去的二十年里，我看过好电影和几部非常好的电影，但很少，很少看到一部具有惊人力量和美感的电影。也许是我的问题；也许我已经厌倦了。但我我不这么认为。还没有。我仍然相信艺术可以改变生活。但我知道，如果你不能演奏故事管弦乐队中的所有乐器，那么无论你的想象中有什么音乐，你都注定要哼着老调。我写《故事》是为了增强你对这门手艺的掌握，让你自由地表达对生活的独到见解，让你的才华超越传统，创造出具有独特内容、结构和风格的电影。

But my hope for you goes beyond competence and skill. I’m starved for great films. Over the last two decades I’ve seen good films and a few very good films, but rarely, rarely a film of staggering power and beauty. Maybe it’s me; maybe I’m jaded. But I don’t think so. Not yet. I still believe that art transforms life. But I know that if you can’t play all the instruments in the orchestra of story, no matter what music may be in your imagination, you’re condemned to hum the same old tune. I’ve written Story to empower your command of the craft, to free you to express an original vision of life, to lift your talent beyond convention to create films of distinctive substance, structure, and style.

1

故事问题

1

THE STORY PROBLEM

故事的衰落

THE DECLINE OF STORY

想象一下，在一天的时间里，人们翻阅散文、表演戏剧、放映电影、源源不断的电视喜剧和戏剧、24 小时的印刷和广播新闻、给孩子们讲的睡前故事、酒吧里的吹牛、网上的闲聊，以及人类对故事的无限渴望。故事不仅是我们最丰富的艺术形式，而且在我们清醒的时间里，它与所有活动（工作、娱乐、饮食、锻炼）相媲美。我们讲故事和听故事的时间和我们睡觉的时间一样多，甚至在睡觉时，我们也会做梦。为什么？为什么我们的生命中有这么多的时间是在故事中度过的？因为正如评论家肯尼斯·伯克所说，故事是生活的工具。

Imagine, in one global day, the pages of prose turned, plays performed, films screened, the unending stream of television comedy and drama, twenty-four-hour print and broadcast news, bedtime tales told to children, barroom bragging, back-fence Internet gossip, humankind’s insatiable appetite for stories. Story is not only our most prolific art form but rivals all activities—work, play, eating, exercise—for our waking hours. We tell and take in stories as much as we sleep—and even then we dream. Why? Why is so much of our life spent inside stories? Because as critic Kenneth Burke tells us, stories are equipment for living.

日复一日，我们寻求亚里士多德在《伦理学》中提出的永恒问题的答案：人应该如何生活？但答案却躲藏在匆匆流逝的时光中，我们努力实现梦想，将想法与激情融合，将愿望变为现实。我们被卷入充满风险的时间穿梭中。如果我们退后一步去把握模式和意义，生活就像格式塔一样，不断翻转：先是严肃，然后是滑稽；静止，疯狂；有意义，毫无意义。重大的世界事件是我们无法控制的，而个人事件，尽管我们竭尽全力控制着方向盘，却往往控制着我们。

Day after day we seek an answer to the ageless question Aristotle posed in Ethics: How should a human being lead his life? But the answer eludes us, hiding behind a blur of racing hours as we struggle to fit our means to our dreams, fuse idea with passion, turn desire into reality. We’re swept along on a risk-ridden shuttle through time. If we pull back to grasp pattern and meaning, life, like a Gestalt, does flips: first serious, then comic; static, frantic; meaningful, meaningless. Momentous world events are beyond our control while personal events, despite all effort to keep our hands on the wheel, more often than not control us.

传统上，人类从四大智慧——哲学、科学、宗教、艺术——中寻找亚里士多德问题的答案，从每一种智慧中汲取洞察力，将之整合成一种可行的意义。但如今谁会不通过考试就读黑格尔或康德的作品呢？科学曾经是解释的伟大工具，但现在却将生活复杂而令人困惑。谁能不带任何愤世嫉俗的态度听经济学家、社会学家和政治家的言论呢？对许多人来说，宗教已经成为一种掩盖虚伪的空洞仪式。随着我们对传统意识形态的信仰逐渐减弱，我们转向我们仍然相信的源头：故事艺术。

Traditionally humankind has sought the answer to Aristotle’s question from the four wisdoms—philosophy, science, religion, art—taking insight from each to bolt together a livable meaning. But today who reads Hegel or Kant without an exam to pass? Science, once the great explicator, garbles life with complexity and perplexity. Who can listen without cynicism to economists, sociologists, politicians? Religion, for many, has become an empty ritual that masks hypocrisy. As our faith in traditional ideologies diminishes, we turn to the source we still believe in: the art of story.

如今，全世界对电影、小说、戏剧和电视的消费量如此之大，如此渴望，以至于故事艺术已成为人类的主要灵感来源，因为它试图理清混乱，洞察生活。我们对故事的渴望反映了人类对掌握生活模式的深刻需求，这不仅仅是一种智力活动，而是一种非常个人的情感体验。用剧作家让·阿努伊的话来说，“小说赋予了生活形式。”

The world now consumes films, novels, theatre, and television in such quantities and with such ravenous hunger that the story arts have become humanity’s prime source of inspiration, as it seeks to order chaos and gain insight into life. Our appetite for story is a reflection of the profound human need to grasp the patterns of living, not merely as an intellectual exercise, but within a very personal, emotional experience. In the words of playwright Jean Anouilh, “Fiction gives life its form.”

有些人认为，对故事的这种渴望只是一种简单的娱乐，是一种逃避生活，而不是对生活的探索。但娱乐到底是什么呢？娱乐就是沉浸在故事的仪式中，以达到智力和情感上的满足。对于电影观众来说，娱乐是一种仪式，他们坐在黑暗中，全神贯注地看着屏幕，体验故事的意义，并凭借这种领悟，唤起强烈的、有时甚至是痛苦的情感，随着意义的加深，最终获得这些情感的满足。

Some see this craving for story as simple entertainment, an escape from life rather than an exploration of it. But what, after all, is entertainment? To be entertained is to be immersed in the ceremony of story to an intellectually and emotionally satisfying end. To the film audience, entertainment is the ritual of sitting in the dark, concentrating on a screen in order to experience the story’s meaning and, with that insight, the arousal of strong, at times even painful emotions, and as the meaning deepens, to be carried to the ultimate satisfaction of those emotions.

无论是《捉鬼敢死队》中疯狂企业家战胜赫梯恶魔，还是《闪亮的风采》中内心恶魔的复杂解决方案；《红色沙漠》中人物的融合，还是《窃听大阴谋》中人物的瓦解，所有优秀的电影、小说和戏剧，无论喜剧还是悲剧，只要能给观众一种充满情感意义的全新生活模式，就能带来娱乐。如果认为观众只是想把烦恼抛在门外，逃避现实，那么就懦弱地放弃了艺术家的责任。故事不是逃避现实，而是载着我们寻找现实的工具，是我们尽最大努力从存在的混乱中寻找意义的工具。

Whether it’s the triumph of crazed entrepreneurs over Hittite demons in GHOSTBUSTERS or the complex resolution of inner demons in SHINE; the integration of character in THE RED DESERT or its disintegration in THE CONVERSATION, all fine films, novels, and plays, through all shades of the comic and tragic, entertain when they give the audience a fresh model of life empowered with an affective meaning. To retreat behind the notion that the audience simply wants to dump its troubles at the door and escape reality is a cowardly abandonment of the artist’s responsibility. Story isn’t a flight from reality but a vehicle that carries us on our search for reality, our best effort to make sense out of the anarchy of existence.

然而，尽管媒体的影响力不断扩大，让我们有机会跨越国界和语言，向数百数百万人中，讲故事的整体质量正在下降。我们偶尔会读到或看到优秀的作品，但大多数时候，我们厌倦了在报纸广告、录像店和电视节目单上寻找优质作品，厌倦了放下读了一半的小说，厌倦了在中场休息时溜出剧院，厌倦了走出电影院，用“但拍摄得很漂亮……”来安慰我们的失望。故事艺术正在衰落，正如亚里士多德在两千三百年前观察到的那样，当讲故事变坏时，结果就是颓废。

Yet, while the ever-expanding reach of the media now gives us the opportunity to send stories beyond borders and languages to hundreds of millions, the overall quality of storytelling is eroding. On occasion we read or see works of excellence, but for the most part we weary of searching newspaper ads, video shops, and TV listings for something of quality, of putting down novels half-read, of slipping out of plays at the intermission, of walking out of films soothing our disappointment with “But it was beautifully photographed …” The art of story is in decay, and as Aristotle observed twenty-three hundred years ago, when storytelling goes bad, the result is decadence.

有缺陷和虚假的故事叙述被迫以奇观取代实质，以诡计取代真相。为了吸引观众的注意力，乏味的故事沦为耗资数百万美元的花哨演示片。好莱坞的形象越来越奢华，欧洲的形象越来越花哨。演员的行为越来越夸张、越来越淫秽、越来越暴力。音乐和音效变得越来越喧嚣。整体效果变得怪诞。没有诚实、有力的故事叙述，文化就无法发展。当社会一再经历浮华、空洞、伪造的故事时，它就会堕落。我们需要真正的讽刺和悲剧、戏剧和喜剧，它们能将一束干净的光芒照进人类心灵和社会的阴暗角落。否则，正如叶芝所警告的那样，“……中心就无法维持。”

Flawed and false storytelling is forced to substitute spectacle for substance, trickery for truth. Weak stories, desperate to hold audience attention, degenerate into multimillion-dollar razzle-dazzle demo reels. In Hollywood imagery becomes more and more extravagant, in Europe more and more decorative. The behavior of actors becomes more and more histrionic, more and more lewd, more and more violent. Music and sound effects become increasingly tumultuous. The total effect transudes into the grotesque. A culture cannot evolve without honest, powerful storytelling. When society repeatedly experiences glossy, hollowed-out, pseudo-stories, it degenerates. We need true satires and tragedies, dramas and comedies that shine a clean light into the dingy corners of the human psyche and society. If not, as Yeats warned, “… the centre can not hold.”

好莱坞每年制作和/或发行四五百部电影，几乎每天一部。其中有几部很出色，但大多数都平庸或更糟。人们很容易将这种平庸之作归咎于那些批准制作的巴比特式人物。但回想一下《大玩家》中的一幕：蒂姆罗宾斯的年轻好莱坞高管解释说，他有很多敌人，因为他的工作室每年收到两万多个故事投稿，但只制作十二部电影。这是准确的对话。各大电影公司的故事部门仔细研究了成千上万的剧本、剧本、小说和戏剧，寻找一个伟大的银幕故事。或者，更有可能的是，一个半好半坏的故事，他们可以把它发展成比平均水平更好的故事。

Each year, Hollywood produces and/or distributes four hundred to five hundred films, virtually a film per day. A few are excellent, but the majority are mediocre or worse. The temptation is to blame this glut of banality on the Babbitt-like figures who approve productions. But recall a moment from THE PLAYER: Tim Robbins’s young Hollywood executive explains that he has many enemies because each year his studio accepts over twenty thousand story submissions but only makes twelve films. This is accurate dialogue. The story departments of the major studios pore through thousands upon thousands of scripts, treatments, novels, and plays searching for a great screen story. Or, more likely, something halfway to good that they could develop to better-than-average.

到了 20 世纪 90 年代，好莱坞的剧本开发费用每年攀升至 5 亿美元以上，其中四分之三是支付给编剧的，用于选择和重写那些永远不会被制作的电影。尽管尽管耗资五亿美元，开发人员不遗余力，好莱坞还是无法找到比它制作的更好的素材。令人难以置信的事实是，我们每年在银幕上看到的作品都是过去几年最佳剧本的合理反映。

By the 1990s script development in Hollywood climbed to over $500 million per annum, three quarters of which is paid to writers for options and rewrites on films that will never be made. Despite a half-billion dollars and the exhaustive efforts of development personnel, Hollywood cannot find better material than it produces. The hard-to-believe truth is that what we see on the screen each year is a reasonable reflection of the best writing of the last few years.

然而，许多编剧无法面对这个现实，生活在虚幻的郊区，坚信好莱坞对他们的才华视而不见。除了极少数例外，未被认可的天才只是一个神话。一流的剧本即使没有被制作出来，至少也是有选择的。对于能讲出优质故事的作家来说，这是一个卖方市场——过去如此，将来也永远如此。好莱坞每年有数百部电影在国际上稳操胜券，而且这些电影一定会被制作出来。大多数电影都会上映，放映几周，然后停播，最后被人遗忘。

Many screenwriters, however, cannot face this downtown fact and live in the exurbs of illusion, convinced that Hollywood is blind to their talent. With rare exceptions, unrecognized genius is a myth. First-rate screenplays are at least optioned if not made. For writers who can tell a quality story, it’s a seller’s market—always has been, always will be. Hollywood has a secure international business for hundreds of films each year, and they will be made. Most will open, run a few weeks, close, and be mercifully forgotten.

然而，好莱坞不仅幸存了下来，而且还蓬勃发展，因为它几乎没有竞争对手。情况并非总是如此。从新现实主义的兴起到新浪潮的高潮，北美电影院挤满了才华横溢的欧洲电影人的作品，这些作品挑战了好莱坞的主导地位。但随着这些大师的去世或退休，过去 25 年来，欧洲电影的质量逐渐下降。

Yet Hollywood not only survives, it thrives, because it has virtually no competition. This wasn’t always the case. From the rise of Neo-realism to the high tide of the New Wave, North American cinemas were crowded with works by brilliant Continental filmmakers that challenged Hollywood’s dominance. But with the death or retirement of these masters, the last twenty-five years have seen a slow decay in the quality of European films.

如今，欧洲电影人将吸引观众的失败归咎于发行商的阴谋。然而，他们的前辈——雷诺阿、伯格曼、费里尼、布努埃尔、瓦依达、克鲁佐、安东尼奥尼、雷乃——的电影却在世界各地放映。体制并没有改变。非好莱坞电影的观众仍然庞大而忠诚。发行商现在的动机和过去一样：金钱。改变的是，当代“作者”无法用上一代的力量来讲述故事。就像自命不凡的室内装饰师一样，他们制作的电影只吸引眼球，仅此而已。结果，欧洲天才的风暴变成了一片枯燥的电影泥沼，留下了好莱坞来填补的真空。

Today European filmmakers blame their failure to attract audience on a conspiracy of distributors. Yet the films of their predecessors—Renoir, Bergman, Fellini, Buñuel, Wajda, Clouzot, Antonioni, Resnais—were screened throughout the world. The system hasn’t changed. The audience for non-Hollywood film is still vast and loyal. Distributors have the same motivation now they had then: money. What’s changed is that contemporary “auteurs” cannot tell story with the power of the previous generation. Like pretentious interior decorators, they make films that strike the eye, and nothing more. As a result, the storm of European genius has become a slough of arid films that leave a vacuum for Hollywood to fill.

然而，亚洲电影如今已在北美和世界各地上映，感动了数百万人，并让他们欣喜若狂，轻松吸引了国际关注，原因只有一个：亚洲电影人的故事精彩绝伦。非好莱坞电影人与其将发行商当做替罪羊，不如将目光投向东方，那里的艺术家有讲故事的热情，也有讲故事的技巧，把故事讲得美轮美奂。

Asian works, however, now travel throughout North America and the world, moving and delighting millions, seizing the international spotlight with ease for one reason: Asian filmmakers tell superb stories. Rather than scapegoating distributors, non-Hollywood filmmakers would do well to look to the East, where artists have the passion to tell stories and the craft to tell them beautifully.

工艺的丧失

THE LOSS OF CRAFT

故事艺术是世界上占主导地位的文化力量，而电影艺术则是这一伟大事业的主导媒介。全世界的观众都对故事充满热情，但又渴望得到它。为什么呢？原因并非如此。美国作家协会剧本登记服务每年登记超过三万五千部作品。这些只是登记的作品。每年全美有数十万部剧本被尝试创作，但只有极少数是优质剧本，原因有很多，但最重要的是：今天有志于成为作家的人在没有先学习手艺的情况下就匆忙地拿起打字机。

The art of story is the dominant cultural force in the world, and the art of film is the dominant medium of this grand enterprise. The world audience is devoted but thirsting for story. Why? Not from a poverty of effort. The Writers Guild of America script registration service logs over thirty-five thousand titles yearly. These are only those that are registered. Across America hundreds of thousands of screenplays are attempted each year, but only a handful are quality screenplays, for many reasons but this above all: Today’s would-be writers rush to the typewriter without first learning their craft.

如果你的梦想是作曲，你会对自己说：“我听过很多交响乐……我还会弹钢琴……我想这个周末我会弹完一架钢琴”吗？不会。但许多编剧的开头都是这样的：“我看过很多电影，有好的，也有坏的……我的英语成绩是 A……假期快到了……”

If your dream were to compose music, would you say to yourself: “I’ve heard a lot of symphonies … I can also play the piano … I think I’ll knock one out this weekend”? No. But that’s exactly how many screenwriters begin: “I’ve seen a lot of flicks, some good and some bad … I got A’s in English … vacation time’s coming …”

如果你希望作曲，你会去音乐学校学习理论和实践，专注于交响乐。经过多年的努力，你会将知识与创造力相结合，发挥你的勇气，大胆创作。太多苦苦挣扎的作家从未想到，创作一部优秀的剧本和创作一首交响乐一样困难，甚至在某些方面更难。因为虽然作曲家用音符的数学纯度来作曲，但我们却深入研究被称为人性的混乱事物。

If you hoped to compose, you’d head for music school to study both theory and practice, focusing on the genre of symphony. After years of diligence, you’d merge your knowledge with your creativity, flex your courage, and venture to compose. Too many struggling writers never suspect that the creation of a fine screenplay is as difficult as the creation of a symphony, and in some ways more so. For while the composer scores with the mathematical purity of notes, we dip into the messy stuff known as human nature.

新手一头扎进去，只依赖经验，以为他所经历的生活和看过的电影给了他要说的东西和表达的方式。然而，经验被高估了。当然，我们希望作家不逃避生活，生活深刻，观察仔细。这很重要，但永远不够。对于大多数作家来说，他们从阅读和学习中获得的知识等于或超过经验，特别是如果经验未经检验的话。自我认知是关键——生活加上对我们对生活的反应的深刻反思。

The novice plunges ahead, counting solely on experience, thinking that the life he’s lived and the films he’s seen give him something to say and the way to say it. Experience, however, is overrated. Of course we want writers who don’t hide from life, who live deeply, observe closely. This is vital but never enough. For most writers, the knowledge they gain from reading and study equals or outweighs experience, especially if that experience goes unexamined. Self-knowledge is the key—life plus deep reflection on our reactions to life.

至于技巧，新手误认为是技巧，其实只是他无意识地吸收了他所读过的每一部小说、电影或戏剧中的故事元素。在写作时，他会将自己的通过反复试验，根据通过不断阅读和观察而建立起来的模型进行创作。没有受过教育的作家称之为“本能”，但这只是习惯，而且有严格的限制。他要么模仿自己心理原型，要么想象自己是先锋派，并反抗它。但随意摸索或反抗无意识根深蒂固的重复总和，在任何意义上都不是技巧，这会导致剧本充斥着商业或艺术电影的陈词滥调。

As for technique, what the novice mistakes for craft is simply his unconscious absorption of story elements from every novel, film, or play he’s ever encountered. As he writes, he matches his work by trial and error against a model built up from accumulated reading and watching. The unschooled writer calls this “instinct,” but it’s merely habit and it’s rigidly limiting. He either imitates his mental prototype or imagines himself in the avant-garde and rebels against it. But the haphazard groping toward or revolt against the sum of unconsciously ingrained repetitions is not, in any sense, technique, and leads to screenplays clogged with clichés of either the commercial or the art house variety.

这种碰运气的挣扎并不总是如此。几十年前，编剧要么通过大学学习，要么自学图书馆知识，要么通过剧院经验或小说写作，要么通过好莱坞制片厂系统的学徒，要么通过这些方式的组合来学习。

This hit-or-miss struggle wasn’t always the case. In decades past screenwriters learned their craft either through university study or on their own in a library, through experience in the theatre or in writing novels, through apprenticeship to the Hollywood studio system, or through a combination of these means.

本世纪初，许多美国大学开始相信，作家和音乐家、画家一样，需要音乐或艺术学校等同等的教育来学习其手艺的原理。为此，威廉·阿彻、肯尼斯·罗和约翰·霍华德·劳森等学者撰写了关于戏剧和散文艺术的优秀书籍。他们的方法是内在的，从欲望的肌肉运动、对抗力量、转折点、脊柱、进展、危机、高潮中汲取力量——从内到外的故事。无论是否受过正规教育，在职作家都利用这些文本来发展他们的艺术，将咆哮的二十年代到抗议的六十年代的半个世纪变成了美国故事在银幕、书页和舞台上的黄金时代。

Early in this century a number of American universities came to believe that, like musicians and painters, writers need the equivalent of music or art school to learn the principles of their craft. To that end scholars such as William Archer, Kenneth Rowe, and John Howard Lawson wrote excellent books on dramaturgy and the prose arts. Their method was intrinsic, drawing strength from the big-muscle movements of desire, forces of antagonism, turning points, spine, progression, crisis, climax—story seen from the inside out. Working writers, with or without formal educations, used these texts to develop their art, turning the half-century from the Roaring Twenties through the protesting sixties into a golden age of the American story on screen, page, and stage.

然而，在过去的二十五年里，美国大学教授创意写作的方法已经从内在转向外在。文学理论的趋势让教授们远离故事的深层来源，转向语言、代码、文本——从外部看故事。因此，除了一些明显的例外，当代作家对故事的基本原理缺乏了解。

Over the last twenty-five years, however, the method of teaching creative writing in American universities has shifted from the intrinsic to the extrinsic. Trends in literary theory have drawn professors away from the deep sources of story toward language, codes, text—story seen from the outside. As a result, with some notable exceptions, the current generation of writers has been undereducated in the prime principles of story.

国外的编剧学习机会更少。欧洲学术界普遍否认写作可以教授，因此，创意写作课程从未被纳入欧洲大陆大学的课程体系。当然，欧洲确实培养了许多世界上最出色的艺术和音乐学院。为什么人们觉得一种艺术可以教，而另一种艺术则不行，这很难说清楚。更糟糕的是，直到最近，除了莫斯科和华沙，所有欧洲电影学校都对编剧不屑一顾，将其排除在了学习范围之外。

Screenwriters abroad have had even less opportunity to study their craft. European academics generally deny that writing can, in any sense, be taught, and as a result, courses in Creative Writing have never been included in the curriculum of Continental universities. Europe does, of course, foster many of the world’s most brilliant art and music academies. Why it’s felt that one art is teachable, another not, is impossible to say. What’s worse, disdain for screenwriting has, until recently, excluded it from study in all European film schools save Moscow and Warsaw.

好莱坞旧制片厂制度有很多缺点，但值得称赞的是，它是一种由经验丰富的故事编辑监督的学徒制。那个时代已经一去不复返了。时不时地，制片厂会重新发现学徒制，但在热衷于重现黄金时代的同时，它忘记了学徒需要师傅。今天的高管可能会认可能力，但很少有人有技能或耐心将人才培养成艺术家。

Much can be said against the old Hollywood studio system, but to its credit it was a system of apprenticeship overseen by seasoned story editors. That day is gone. Every now and then a studio rediscovers apprenticeship, but in its zeal to bring back the golden days it forgets that an apprentice needs a master. Today’s executives may recognize ability, but few have the skill or patience to turn a talent into an artist.

故事衰落的最后一个原因非常深刻。价值观，即生活中的积极/消极因素，是我们艺术的灵魂。作家围绕对什么值得为之而生、什么值得为之而死、追求什么是愚蠢的、正义的意义、真理——基本价值观——的理解来塑造故事。在过去的几十年里，作家和社会或多或少在这些问题上达成了共识，但我们的时代越来越成为一个道德和伦理玩世不恭、相对主义和主观主义的时代——价值观大混乱。随着家庭解体和两性对立加剧，谁会觉得自己理解了爱的本质？如果你确实有信念，你会如何向越来越怀疑的观众表达它？

The final cause for the decline of story runs very deep. Values, the positive/negative charges of life, are at the soul of our art. The writer shapes story around a perception of what’s worth living for, what’s worth dying for, what’s foolish to pursue, the meaning of justice, truth—the essential values. In decades past, writer and society more or less agreed on these questions, but more and more ours has become an age of moral and ethical cynicism, relativism, and subjectivism—a great confusion of values. As the family disintegrates and sexual antagonisms rise, who, for example, feels he understands the nature of love? And how, if you do have a conviction, do you express it to an ever-more skeptical audience?

价值观的侵蚀也带来了故事的侵蚀。与过去的作家不同，我们不能假设任何事情。首先，我们必须深入挖掘生活，发现新的见解、新的价值观和意义的精炼，然后创造一个故事载体，表达我们对日益不可知论的世界的解读。这不是一件容易的事。

This erosion of values has brought with it a corresponding erosion of story. Unlike writers in the past, we can assume nothing. First we must dig deeply into life to uncover new insights, new refinements of value and meaning, then create a story vehicle that expresses our interpretation to an increasingly agnostic world. No small task.

故事的必要性

THE STORY IMPERATIVE

当我搬到洛杉矶时，我做了许多人为了继续吃饭和写作所做的事——阅读。我为 UA 和 NBC 工作。分析电影和电视剧稿。在做了最初几百篇分析之后，我觉得我可以提前写出一份万能的好莱坞故事分析员的报道内容，只需填写标题和作者。我反复写的报道是这样的：

When I moved to Los Angeles, I did what many do to keep eating and writing—I read. I worked for UA and NBC. analyzing screen and teleplay submissions. After the first couple hundred analyses, I felt I could write up in advance an all-purpose Hollywood story analyst’s coverage and just fill in title and writer. The report I wrote over and over again went like this:

描述不错，对话可演。有些时刻很有趣；有些时刻很敏感。总而言之，剧本措辞精妙。但是故事很烂。前三十页充斥着大量的说明；其余部分则毫无进展。主线情节充斥着巧合和薄弱的动机。没有明显的主角。可以形成次要情节的无关紧张关系从未形成。人物从未展现出比他们看起来更深刻的一面。没有一刻洞察这些人或他们所在社会的内心生活。这是一本毫无生气的可预测、讲述不当和陈词滥调的情节合集，最终陷入毫无意义的迷雾中。别看了。

Nice description, actable dialogue. Some amusing moments; some sensitive moments. All in all, a script of well-chosen words. The story, however, sucks. The first thirty pages crawl on a fat belly of exposition; the rest never get to their feet. The main plot, what there is of it, is riddled with convenient coincidence and weak motivation. No discernible protagonist. Unrelated tensions that could shape into subplots never do. Characters are never revealed to be more than they seem. Not a moment’s insight into the inner lives of these people or their society. It’s a lifeless collection of predictable, ill-told, and clichéd episodes that wander off into a pointless haze. PASS ON IT.

但我从来没有写过这份报告：

But I never wrote this report:

很棒的故事！第一页就抓住了我，让我无法自拔。第一幕突然达到高潮，然后发展成情节和次要情节的完美交织。深刻人物的崇高启示。对这个社会的惊人洞察。让我笑，让我哭。第二幕的高潮如此感人，我以为故事结束了。然而，在第二幕的废墟中，这位作家创造了如此强大、如此美丽、如此壮丽的第三幕，我正躺在地板上写这篇报告。然而，这个剧本是一场 270 页的语法噩梦，每五个单词就有一个拼写错误。对话如此复杂，奥利维尔无法理解。描述中充斥着镜头指示、潜台词解释和哲学评论。它甚至没有用正确的格式打字。显然不是专业作家。放弃它。

Great story! Grabbed me on page one and held me in its embrace. The first act builds to a sudden climax that spins off into a superb weave of plot and subplot. Sublime revelations of deep character. Amazing insight into this society. Made me laugh, made me cry. Drove to an Act Two climax so moving that I thought the story was over. And yet, out of the ashes of the second act, this writer created a third act of such power, such beauty, such magnificence I’m writing this report from the floor. However, this script is a 270-page grammatical nightmare with every fifth word misspelled. Dialogue’s so tangled Olivier couldn’t get his tongue around it. Descriptions are stuffed with camera directions, subtextural explanations, and philosophical commentary. It’s not even typed in the proper format. Obviously not a professional writer. PASS ON IT.

如果我写了这份报告，我就会丢掉工作。

If I’d written this report, I’d have lost my job.

门上的标牌上没有写着“对话部”或“描述部”，而是“故事部”。好故事是好电影的可能，而故事情节不合理几乎注定是灾难。读者如果不能理解这一基本原则，就应该被解雇。事实上，很少人会找到一个精心制作的故事，但对话糟糕或描述乏味。通常情况下，故事讲述得越好，画面越生动，对话越犀利。但缺乏进展、动机虚假、人物冗余、潜台词空洞、漏洞百出等故事问题是文本平淡无趣的根本原因。

The sign on the door doesn’t read “Dialogue Department” or “Description Department.” It reads “Story Department.” A good story makes a good film possible, while failure to make the story work virtually guarantees disaster. A reader who can’t grasp this fundamental deserves to be fired. It’s surprisingly rare, in fact, to find a beautifully crafted story with bad dialogue or dull description. More often than not, the better the storytelling, the more vivid the images, the sharper the dialogue. But lack of progression, false motivation, redundant characters, empty subtext, holes, and other such story problems are the root causes of a bland, boring text.

文学天赋是不够的。如果你不能讲好一个故事，你花了几个月时间完善的那些美丽的画面和对话的微妙之处就白白浪费了。我们为世界创造的，世界对我们的要求，就是故事。现在和永远。无数作家在无聊的故事中大肆渲染华丽的对话和精心修饰的描述，并想知道为什么他们的剧本从未投入制作，而其他文学天赋平平但讲故事能力很强的人则非常高兴地看着他们的梦想在银幕上活灵活现。

Literary talent is not enough. If you cannot tell a story, all those beautiful images and subtleties of dialogue that you spent months and months perfecting waste the paper they’re written on. What we create for the world, what it demands of us, is story. Now and forever. Countless writers lavish dressy dialogue and manicured descriptions on anorexic yarns and wonder why their scripts never see production, while others with modest literary talent but great storytelling power have the deep pleasure of watching their dreams living in the light of the screen.

在一部完成的作品中，作家 75% 或更多的创作精力都用于设计故事。这些角色是谁？他们想要什么？他们为什么想要？他们如何得到它？是什么阻止了他们？后果是什么？找到这些重大问题的答案并将它们塑造成故事是我们艰巨的创作任务。

Of the total creative effort represented in a finished work, 75 percent or more of a writer’s labor goes into designing story. Who are these characters? What do they want? Why do they want it? How do they go about getting it? What stops them? What are the consequences? Finding the answers to these grand questions and shaping them into story is our overwhelming creative task.

设计故事考验作家的成熟度和洞察力，以及他对社会、自然和人心的了解。故事需要生动的想象力和强大的分析思维。自我表达从来都不是问题，因为，无论有意还是无意，所有故事，无论是诚实的还是不诚实的，聪明的还是愚蠢的，都忠实地反映了作者的本性，暴露了他的人性……或缺乏人性。与这种恐惧相比，写对话是一种甜蜜的消遣。

Designing story tests the maturity and insight of the writer, his knowledge of society, nature, and the human heart. Story demands both vivid imagination and powerful analytic thought. Self-expression is never an issue, for, wittingly or unwittingly, all stories, honest and dishonest, wise and foolish, faithfully mirror their maker, exposing his humanity … or lack of it. Compared to this terror, writing dialogue is a sweet diversion.

因此，作家接受了“讲故事”的原则……然后就愣住了。故事是什么？故事的概念就像音乐的概念。我们一生都在听曲调。我们可以跟着跳舞唱歌。我们以为自己懂音乐，直到我们尝试创作音乐，钢琴演奏出来的音乐吓坏了猫。

So the writer embraces the principle, Tell Story … then freezes. For what is story? The idea of story is like the idea of music. We’ve heard tunes all our lives. We can dance and sing along. We think we understand music until we try to compose it and what comes out of the piano scares the cat.

如果《温柔的怜悯》和《夺宝奇兵》都是为银幕而精心讲述的精彩故事——而且确实如此——那么它们到底有什么共同之处呢？如果《汉娜姐妹》和《巨蟒与圣杯》都是精彩的喜剧故事讲述得非常愉快，而且确实如此，它们有什么相似之处？比较一下《哭泣游戏》和《为人父母》，《终结者》和《命运的逆转》，《不可饶恕》和《吃喝男人女人》。或者比较一下《一条叫旺达的鱼》和《陷害兔子罗杰的人咬狗》和《落水狗》。回溯到几十年前，比较一下《迷魂记》和《八部半》和《假面人》和《罗生门》和《卡萨布兰卡》和《贪婪》和《摩登时代》和《战舰波将金号》——所有都是精彩的银幕故事，虽然有很大的不同，但都产生了同样的效果：观众离开剧院时惊呼：“真是一个伟大的故事！”

If both TENDER MERCIES and RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK are wonderful stories beautifully told for the screen—and they are—what on earth do they have in common? If HANNAH AND HER SISTERS and MONTY PYTHON AND THE HOLY GRAIL are both brilliant comic stories delightfully told, and they are, where do they touch? Compare THE CRYING GAME to PARENTHOOD, TERMINATOR to REVERSAL OF FORTUNE, UNFORGIVEN to EAT DRINK MAN WOMAN. Or A FISH CALLED WANDA to MAN BITES DOG, WHO FRAMED ROGER RABBIT to RESERVOIR DOGS. Moving back through the decades, compare VERTIGO to 8 1/2 to PERSONA to RASHOMON to CASABLANCA to GREED to MODERN TIMES to THE BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN—all superb screen stories, all vastly different, yet all produce the same result: an audience leaving the theatre exclaiming, “What a great story!”

淹没在流派和风格的海洋中，作家可能会认为，如果所有这些电影都在讲述故事，那么任何东西都可以成为故事。但如果我们深入观察，如果我们剥去表面，我们会发现，从本质上讲，所有电影都是一样的。每部电影都是故事的普遍形式的体现。每部电影都以独特的方式在银幕上表达这种形式，但每部电影的本质形式都是相同的，观众在回应“多么好的故事！”时，就是对这种深层形式的回应。

Drowning in a sea of genres and styles, the writer may come to believe that if all these films tell story, then anything can be a story. But if we look deeply, if we strip away the surface, we find that at heart all are the same thing. Each is an embodiment of the universal form of story. Each articulates this form to the screen in a unique way, but in each the essential form is identical, and it is to this deep form that the audience is responding when it reacts with, “What a good story!”

每种艺术都由其基本形式定义。从交响乐到嘻哈音乐，音乐的基本形式使作品成为音乐而不是噪音。无论是具象还是抽象，视觉艺术的基本原则使画布成为一幅画，而不是一幅涂鸦。同样，从荷马到英格玛·伯格曼，故事的普遍形式将作品塑造成故事，而不是肖像画或拼贴画。在所有文化和所有时代，这种固有形式一直在不断变化但始终不变。

Each of the arts is defined by its essential form. From symphony to hip-hop, the underlying form of music makes a piece music and not noise. Whether representational or abstract, the cardinal principles of visual art make a canvas a painting, not a doodle. Equally, from Homer to Ingmar Bergman, the universal form of story shapes a work into story, not portraiture or collage. Across all cultures and through all ages, this innate form has been endlessly variable but changeless.

然而形式并不意味着“公式”。没有剧本写作秘诀可以保证你的剧本成功。故事充满了神秘感、复杂性和灵活性，不可能被简化为公式。只有傻瓜才会尝试。相反，作家必须掌握故事形式。这是不可避免的。

Yet form does not mean “formula.” There is no screenplay-writing recipe that guarantees your cake will rise. Story is far too rich in mystery, complexity, and flexibility to be reduced to a formula. Only a fool would try. Rather, a writer must grasp story form. This is inescapable.

好故事讲得好

GOOD STORY WELL TOLD

“好故事”意味着值得讲述、全世界都想听的故事。找到这个是你孤独的任务。它始于天赋。你必须天生具有创造力，能够以前所未有的方式将事物组合在一起。然后，你必须为作品注入一种愿景，这种愿景由对人性和社会的全新见解以及对角色和世界的深入了解所驱动。所有这些……以及，正如 Hallie 和 Whit Burnett 在他们出色的小书中所揭示的那样，大量的爱。

“Good story” means something worth telling that the world wants to hear. Finding this is your lonely task. It begins with talent. You must be born with the creative power to put things together in a way no one has ever dreamed. Then you must bring to the work a vision that’s driven by fresh insights into human nature and society, coupled with in-depth knowledge of your characters and your world. All that … and, as Hallie and Whit Burnett reveal in their excellent little book, a lot of love.

对故事的热爱——相信你的想法只能通过故事来表达，相信角色比人更“真实”，相信虚构的世界比现实更深刻。对戏剧的热爱——着迷于突然的惊喜和启示，它们给生活带来了翻天覆地的变化。对真理的热爱——相信谎言会削弱艺术家的才能，相信生活中的每一个真理都必须受到质疑，甚至包括一个人自己的秘密动机。对人性的热爱——愿意同情受苦的灵魂，钻进他们的内心，通过他们的眼睛看世界。对感觉的热爱——不仅想放纵身体，还想放纵内心的感觉。对梦想的热爱——乐于悠闲地驾驭你的想象力，看看它会把我们引向何方。对幽默的热爱——为恢复生活平衡的救赎而感到高兴。对语言的热爱——对声音和意义、句法和语义的愉悦。对二元性的热爱——对生活中隐藏矛盾的感受，对事物并非表面所见的合理怀疑。对完美的热爱——为了追求完美时刻而不断写作和重写的激情。对独特的热爱——大胆的刺激和遭到嘲笑时的镇定。对美的热爱——一种与生俱来的感觉，珍视好作品，讨厌坏作品，并知道其中的区别。对自我的爱——一种不需要不断安慰的力量，永远不会怀疑你确实是一名作家。你必须热爱写作并忍受孤独。

The love of story—the belief that your vision can be expressed only through story, that characters can be more “real” than people, that the fictional world is more profound than the concrete. The love of the dramatic—a fascination with the sudden surprises and revelations that bring sea-changes in life. The love of truth—the belief that lies cripple the artist, that every truth in life must be questioned, down to one’s own secret motives. The love of humanity—a willingness to empathize with suffering souls, to crawl inside their skins and see the world through their eyes. The love of sensation—the desire to indulge not only the physical but the inner senses. The love of dreaming—the pleasure in taking leisurely rides on your imagination just to see where it leads. The love of humor—a joy in the saving grace that restores the balance of life. The love of language—the delight in sound and sense, syntax and semantics. The love of duality—a feel for life’s hidden contradictions, a healthy suspicion that things are not what they seem. The love of perfection—the passion to write and rewrite in pursuit of the perfect moment. The love of uniqueness—the thrill of audacity and a stone-faced calm when it is met by ridicule. The love of beauty—an innate sense that treasures good writing, hates bad writing, and knows the difference. The love of self—a strength that doesn’t need to be constantly reassured, that never doubts that you are indeed a writer. You must love to write and bear the loneliness.

但仅仅热爱一个好故事、一个了不起的人物和一个由你的热情、勇气和创造性天赋驱动的世界还不够。你的目标必须是讲述一个好故事。

But the love of a good story, of terrific characters and a world driven by your passion, courage, and creative gifts is still not enough. Your goal must be a good story well told.

正如作曲家必须精通音乐创作原则一样，你必须掌握相应的故事创作原则。这种技艺既不是机械的，也不是花招。它是技术的协奏曲，我们通过它创造了一个阴谋我们与观众之间会产生怎样的互动关系？艺术是吸引观众深度参与、保持这种参与感、并最终以动人而有意义的体验回报观众的所有手段的总和。

Just as a composer must excel in the principles of musical composition, so you must master the corresponding principles of story composition. This craft is neither mechanics nor gimmicks. It is the concert of techniques by which we create a conspiracy of interest between ourselves and the audience. Craft is the sum total of all means used to draw the audience into deep involvement, to hold that involvement, and ultimately to reward it with a moving and meaningful experience.

如果没有写作技巧，作家所能做的最好的事情就是抓住脑海中的第一个想法，然后无助地坐在自己的作品前，无法回答那些可怕的问题：这是好作品吗？还是说是污秽之作？如果是污秽之作，我该怎么办？意识会纠结于这些可怕的问题，从而阻碍潜意识。但是，当意识开始致力于完成写作技巧的客观任务时，自发性就会浮现出来。掌握写作技巧可以释放潜意识。

Without craft, the best a writer can do is snatch the first idea off the top of his head, then sit helpless in front of his own work, unable to answer the dreaded questions: Is it good? Or is it sewage? If sewage, what do I do? The conscious mind, fixated on these terrible questions, blocks the subconscious. But when the conscious mind is put to work on the objective task of executing the craft, the spontaneous surfaces. Mastery of craft frees the subconscious.

作家一天的节奏是怎样的？首先，你进入想象的世界。当角色说话和行动时，你开始写作。接下来做什么？走出幻想，阅读自己写的东西。阅读时你做什么？分析。“写得好吗？有用吗？为什么不行？我应该删减、添加还是重新排序？”你写作、阅读；创造、批评；冲动、逻辑；右脑、左脑；重新想象、重写。重写的质量、完美的可能性取决于你对技巧的掌握，这种技巧可以指导你纠正不完美之处。艺术家永远不会受冲动的摆布；他会有意识地运用自己的技巧，创造出本能和想法的和谐。

What is the rhythm of a writer’s day? First, you enter your imagined world. As characters speak and act, you write. What’s the next thing you do? You step out of your fantasy and read what you’ve written. And what do you do as you read? You analyze. “Is it good? Does it work? Why not? Should I cut? Add? Reorder?” You write, you read; create, critique; impulse, logic; right brain, left brain; re-imagine, rewrite. And the quality of your rewriting, the possibility of perfection, depends on a command of the craft that guides you to correct imperfection. An artist is never at the mercy of the whims of impulse; he willfully exercises his craft to create harmonies of instinct and idea.

故事与生活

STORY AND LIFE

多年来，我观察到两种典型且持续存在的失败剧本。第一种是“个人故事”烂剧本：

Over the years I’ve observed two typical and persistent kinds of failed screenplay. The first is the “personal story” bad script:

在办公室里，我们遇到了一个有问题的主人公：她应该升职，但却被忽视了。她生气地回到父母家，发现爸爸已经老糊涂了，妈妈无法应付。回到公寓后，她和邋遢、阴险的室友吵了一架。现在出去约会，却陷入了沟通失败：她那麻木不仁的情人带她去了一家昂贵的法国餐厅，完全忘记了她在节食。回到办公室，令人惊讶的是，她得到了晋升……但新的压力回到父母家，就在她解决完爸爸的问题后，妈妈却情绪失控。回家后，她发现室友偷了她的电视机，没有付房租就消失了。她与情人分手，翻遍了冰箱，胖了五磅。但她振作起来，把升职变成了一场胜利。与父母共进晚餐时，一场怀旧的推心置腹的谈话治愈了妈妈的痛苦。她的新室友不仅是一个用银行本票提前几周付房租的娇生惯养的宝贝，还把她介绍给了新人。我们现在到了第 95 页。在最后 25 页，她坚持减肥，看起来很棒，这相当于在文学上慢动作穿过雏菊，与新人的恋情正在绽放。最后，她面临着危机决定：是否要承诺？剧本以一个令人泪流满面的高潮结束，因为她决定她需要自己的空间。

In an office setting we meet a protagonist with a problem: She deserves a promotion but she’s being passed over. Angry, she heads for her parents’ home to discover that Dad’s gone senile and Mom can’t cope. Home to her apartment and a fight with her slobbish, conniving roommate. Now out on a date and smack into a failure to communicate: Her insensitive lover takes her to an expensive French restaurant, completely forgetting that she’s on a diet. Back to the office where, amazingly, she gets her promotion … but new pressures arise. Back at her parents’ place, where just as she solves Dad’s problem, Mom goes over the edge. Coming home she discovers that her roommate has stolen her TV and vanished without paying the rent. She breaks up with her lover, raids the refrigerator, and gains five pounds. But chin up, she turns her promotion into a triumph. A nostalgic heart-to-heart over a dinner with her folks cures Mom’s woes. Her new roommate not only turns out to be an anal-retentive gem who pays the rent weeks ahead with cashier’s checks, but introduces her to Someone New. We’re now on page ninety-five. She sticks to her diet and looks great for the last twenty-five pages, which are the literary equivalent of running in slow-mo through daisies as the romance with Someone New blossoms. At last she confronts her Crisis Decision: whether or not to commit? The screenplay ends on a tearful Climax as she decides she needs her space.

第二是“保证商业成功”的糟糕剧本：

Second is the “guaranteed commercial success” bad script:

在机场行李弄错后，一名软件销售员得到了“将终结当今文明的东西”。这个“将终结当今文明的东西”很小。事实上，它藏在这位倒霉的主角口袋里的一支圆珠笔里，主角成了三十多个角色的目标，这些角色都有双重或三重身份，都在铁幕的两边工作过，自冷战以来就彼此认识，他们都想杀死这个家伙。剧本充斥着汽车追逐、枪战、惊心动魄的逃跑和爆炸。除了炸毁东西或射杀人员之外，剧本还暂停，出现大量对话场景，主角试图筛选这些表里不一的人，找出他可以信任的人。影片在暴力的喧嚣和耗资数百万美元的特效下结束，在此期间，英雄成功摧毁了将终结当今文明的东西，从而拯救了人类。

Through a luggage mix-up at the airport, a software salesman comes into possession of the-thing-that-will-end-civilization-as-we-know-it-today. The-thing-that-will-end-civilization-as-we-know-it-today is quite small. In fact, it’s concealed inside a ballpoint pen unwittingly in the pocket of this hapless protagonist, who becomes the target of a cast of three dozen characters, all of whom have double or triple identities, all of whom have worked on both sides of the Iron Curtain, all of whom have known one another since the Cold War, all of whom are trying to kill the guy. This script is stuffed with car chases, shoot-outs, hair-raising escapes, and explosions. When not blowing things up or shooting folks down, it halts for dialogue-thick scenes as the hero tries to sort through these duplicitous people and find out just whom he can trust. It ends with a cacophony of violence and multimillion-dollar effects, during which the hero manages to destroy the-thing-that-will-end-civilization-as-we-know-it-today and thus save humanity.

“个人故事”是结构不严谨的、生活片段式的描绘，误把逼真当作真实。笔者认为，他对日常事实的观察越精确，他对实际发生的事情的报道就越准确，他讲的就越真实。但事实，无论观察得多么细致，都是小写的真理。大写的真理位于事物的背后、之外、内部、表面之下，将现实联系在一起或将其撕裂，无法直接观察到。因为这位作家只看到可见的事实，所以他对生活的真相视而不见。

The “personal story” is understructured, slice-of-life portraiture that mistakes verisimilitude for truth. This writer believes that the more precise his observation of day-to-day facts, the more accurate his reportage of what actually happens, the more truth he tells. But fact, no matter how minutely observed, is truth with a small “t.” Big “T” Truth is located behind, beyond, inside, below the surface of things, holding reality together or tearing it apart, and cannot be directly observed. Because this writer sees only what is visible and factual, he is blind to the truth of life.

另一方面，“保证商业成功”是一种结构过于复杂、内容过于密集的对身体感官的攻击，与生活毫无关系。这位作家误以为动感就是娱乐。他希望，无论故事如何，如果他要求足够多的高速动作和令人眼花缭乱的视觉效果，观众就会兴奋。考虑到计算机生成图像现象推动了如此多的夏季上映，他的说法并非完全错误。

The “guaranteed commercial success,” on the other hand, is an overstructured, overcomplicated, overpopulated assault on the physical senses that bears no relationship to life whatsoever. This writer is mistaking kinesis for entertainment. He hopes that, regardless of story, if he calls for enough high-speed action and dazzling visuals, the audience will be excited. And given the Computer Generated Image phenomenon that drives so many summer releases, he would not be altogether wrong.

这种奇观用模拟现实取代了想象。它们以故事为借口，制造出前所未有的效果，将我们带入龙卷风、恐龙的嘴巴或未来的大屠杀。毫无疑问，这些令人眼花缭乱的奇观可以带来一场刺激的马戏表演。但就像游乐园的游乐设施一样，它们的乐趣是短暂的。因为电影制作的历史一次又一次地表明，随着新的动感刺激越来越受欢迎，它们很快就会沉没在“去过那里，做过那事”的冷漠之中。

Spectacles of this kind replace imagination with simulated actuality. They use story as an excuse for heretofore unseen effects that carry us into a tornado, the jaws of a dinosaur, or futuristic holocausts. And make no mistake, these razzle-dazzle spectacles can deliver a circus of excitement. But like amusement park rides, their pleasures are short-lived. For the history of filmmaking has shown again and again that as fast as new kinetic thrills rise to popularity, they sink under a “been there, done that” apathy.

每隔十年左右，技术创新就会催生出一大批叙事拙劣的电影，其唯一目的是利用奇观。电影本身的发明，是对现实的惊人模拟，引起了公众的极大兴奋，随后几年，故事变得乏味无趣。然而，随着时间的推移，无声电影发展成为一种宏伟的艺术形式，却被声音的出现所摧毁，声音是对现实的更逼真的模拟。20 世纪 30 年代早期的电影倒退了一步，因为观众愿意忍受平淡无奇的故事，以享受听演员说话的乐趣。随后，有声电影的力量和美感不断增强，却被彩色、3D、宽屏以及现在的计算机生成图像 (CGI) 的发明所击败。

Every decade or so technical innovation spawns a swarm of ill-told movies, for the sole purpose of exploiting spectacle. The invention of film itself, a startling simulation of actuality, caused great public excitement, followed by years of vapid stories. In time, however, the silent film evolved into a magnificent art form, only to be destroyed by the advent of sound, a yet more realistic simulation of actuality. Films of the early 1930s took a step backward as audiences willingly suffered bland stories for the pleasure of hearing actors talk. The talkie then grew in power and beauty, only to be knocked off stride by the inventions of color, 3-D, wide-screen, and now Computer Generated Images, or CGI.

CGI 既不是诅咒也不是灵丹妙药。它只是给故事增添了新鲜的色彩。多亏了 CGI，我们能想象到的任何东西都可以变成现实完成，并带着微妙的满足感。当 CGI 受到强大故事的启发时，例如《阿甘正传》或《黑衣人》，其效果消失在故事背后，丰富了情节，却没有引起人们的注意。然而，“商业”作家经常被奇观的光芒所迷惑，看不到持久的娱乐性只有在图像背后充满人性的真相中才能找到。

CGI is neither a curse nor a panacea. It simply adds fresh hues to the story pallet. Thanks to CGI, anything we can imagine can be done, and done with subtle satisfaction. When CGIs are motivated by a strong story, such as FORREST GUMP or MEN IN BLACK, the effect vanishes behind the story it’s telling, enriching the moment without calling attention to itself. The “commercial” writer, however, is often dazzled by the glare of spectacle and cannot see that lasting entertainment is found only in the charged human truths beneath the image.

肖像画和奇观画的作家，事实上所有的作家，都必须理解故事与生活的关系：故事是生活的隐喻。

The writers of portraiture and spectacle, indeed all writers, must come to understand the relationship of story to life: Story is metaphor for life.

讲故事的人是生活诗人，是将日常生活、内在生活和外在生活、梦想和现实转化为诗歌的艺术家，诗歌的韵律是事件而不是文字——一个长达两小时的比喻，说：生活就是这样！因此，故事必须从生活中抽象出来，才能发现它的本质，但不能成为一种抽象的东西，失去所有生活的意义。故事必须像生活一样，但不能一字不差，以至于除了街上每个人都能看出来的东西之外，它没有任何深度或意义。

A storyteller is a life poet, an artist who transforms day-to-day living, inner life and outer life, dream and actuality into a poem whose rhyme scheme is events rather than words—a two-hour metaphor that says: Life is like this! Therefore, a story must abstract from life to discover its essences, but not become an abstraction that loses all sense of life-as-lived. A story must be like life, but not so verbatim that it has no depth or meaning beyond what’s obvious to everyone on the street.

肖像作家必须认识到事实是中立的。将任何内容纳入故事的最薄弱的借口是：“但它确实发生了。”一切都会发生；所有可以想象到的事情都会发生。事实上，难以想象的事情也会发生。但故事不是现实生活。单纯的发生并不能让我们接近真相。发生的事情是事实，而不是真相。真相是我们对发生的事情的看法。

Writers of portraiture must realize that facts are neutral. The weakest possible excuse to include anything in a story is: “But it actually happened.” Everything happens; everything imaginable happens. Indeed, the unimaginable happens. But story is not life in actuality. Mere occurrence brings us nowhere near the truth. What happens is fact, not truth. Truth is what we think about what happens.

考虑一组被称为“圣女贞德的一生”的事实。几个世纪以来，著名作家将这个女人搬上了舞台、书页和银幕，每个贞德都是独一无二的——阿努伊笔下的精神贞德、萧伯纳笔下的机智贞德、布莱希特笔下的政治贞德、德莱叶笔下的受苦贞德、好莱坞的浪漫战士。在莎士比亚笔下，她变成了疯子贞德，这是典型的英国观点。每个贞德都受到神的启发，组建了一支军队，打败了英国人，被烧死在火刑柱上。贞德的事实总是一样的，但整个流派都在变化，而她生活的“真相”等待着作家去寻找它的意义。

Consider a set of facts known as “The Life of Joan of Arc.” For centuries celebrated writers have brought this woman to the stage, page, and screen, and each Joan is unique—Anouilh’s spiritual Joan, Shaw’s witty Joan, Brecht’s political Joan, Dreyer’s suffering Joan, Hollywood’s romantic warrior. In Shakespeare’s hands she became the lunatic Joan, a distinctly British point of view. Each Joan is divinely inspired, raises an army, defeats the English, burns at the stake. Joan’s facts are always the same, but whole genres shift while the “truth” of her life waits for the writer to find its meaning.

同样，景观作家必须意识到抽象是中性的。我所说的抽象是指平面设计策略、视觉效果、色彩饱和度、声音透视、剪辑节奏等，这些本身没有任何意义，同样的剪辑模式应用于六个不同的场景，会产生六种截然不同的解读。电影美学是表达故事鲜活内容的手段，但绝不能成为其本身的目的。

Likewise, writers of spectacle must realize that abstractions are neutral. By abstractions I mean strategies of graphic design, visual effects, color saturation, sound perspective, editing rhythm, and the like. These have no meaning in and of themselves. The identical editing pattern applied to six different scenes results in six distinctively different interpretations. The aesthetics of film are the means to express the living content of story, but must never become an end in themselves.

能力与才干

POWERS AND TALENTS

尽管写肖像或大场面的作者在故事方面很弱，但他们可能拥有两种基本能力中的一种。倾向于报道的作家往往具有感官能力，能够将肉体感觉传递给读者。他们以敏锐和敏感的态度看待和聆听，以至于读者在被他们清晰美丽的画面所震撼时，心会怦怦乱跳。另一方面，写动作大片的作家往往拥有想象力，能够让观众超越现实，达到可能达到的境界。他们可以把假定的不可能变成令人震惊的确定。他们也能让人心动不已。感官知觉和丰富的想象力都是令人羡慕的天赋，但就像美满的婚姻一样，两者相辅相成。如果两者单独存在，就会失去意义。

Although the authors of portraiture or spectacle are weak in story, they may be blessed with one of two essential powers. Writers who lean toward reportage often have the power of the senses, the power to transport corporal sensations into the reader. They see and hear with such acuity and sensitivity that the reader’s heart jumps when struck by the lucid beauty of their images. Writers of action extravaganzas, on the other hand, often have the imaginative power to lift audiences beyond what is to what could be. They can take presumed impossibilities and turn them into shocking certainties. They also make hearts jump. Both sensory perception and a lively imagination are enviable gifts, but, like a good marriage, one complements the other. Alone they are diminished.

现实的一端是纯粹的事实，另一端是纯粹的想象。横跨这两极的是小说的无限变化范围。精彩的故事叙述在这个范围内取得平衡。如果你的写作偏向一个极端，你必须学会​​将人性的各个方面协调起来。你必须把自己置于创造性的范围内：对视觉、声音和感觉敏感，但要平衡这些与想象的力量。用双手挖掘，用你的洞察力和直觉来感动我们，表达你对人类如何以及为什么做他们所做的事情的看法。

At one end of reality is pure fact; at the other end, pure imagination. Spanning these two poles is the infinitely varied spectrum of fiction. Strong storytelling strikes a balance along this spectrum. If your writing drifts to one extreme or the other, you must learn to draw all aspects of your humanity into harmony. You must place yourself along the creative spectrum: sensitive to sight, sound, and feeling, yet balancing that with the power to imagine. Dig in a two-handed way, using your insight and instinct to move us, to express your vision of how and why human beings do the things they do.

最后，感知力和想象力不仅是创造力的先决条件，写作还需要两种独特而必不可少的才能。然而，这两种才能并无必然联系。一种才能的丰富并不意味着另一种才能的匮乏。

Last, not only are sensory and imaginative powers prerequisite to creativity, writing also demands two singular and essential talents. These talents, however, have no necessary connection. A mountain of one does not mean a grain of the other.

第一是文学天赋——创造性地将普通语言转化为更高级、更富有表现力的形式，生动地描述文学是人类的本能，它影响着世界，捕捉人类的声音。然而，文学天赋却很普遍。在世界上每一个有文化的社区里，数百甚至数千人都可以在某种程度上从他们文化的普通语言开始，最终写出一些非凡的作品。从文学的角度来看，他们写得非常优美，少数人写得非常出色。

The first is literary talent—the creative conversion of ordinary language into a higher, more expressive form, vividly describing the world and capturing its human voices. Literary talent is, however, common. In every literate community in the world, hundreds, if not thousands of people can, to one degree or another, begin with the ordinary language of their culture and end with something extraordinary. They write beautifully, a few magnificently, in the literary sense.

第二个是故事天赋——创造性地将生活本身转化为一种更有力、更清晰、更有意义的体验。它寻找我们生活的本质，并将其重塑为丰富生活的故事。纯粹的故事天赋很少见。哪个作家仅凭直觉就能年复一年地创作出精彩的故事，却从不考虑自己是如何做到的，或者可以做得更好？天生的天才可能会创作出一部高质量的作品，但完美和多产并不是自发和未经训练的人所为。

The second is story talent—the creative conversion of life itself to a more powerful, clearer, more meaningful experience. It seeks out the inscape of our days and reshapes it into a telling that enriches life. Pure story talent is rare. What writer, on instinct alone, creates brilliantly told stories year after year and never gives a moment’s thought to how he does what he does or could do it better? Instinctive genius may produce a work of quality once, but perfection and prolificness do not flow from the spontaneous and untutored.

文学天赋和故事天赋不仅截然不同，而且毫无关联，因为故事不需要书写才能讲述。故事可以用人类能够交流的任何方式来表达。戏剧、散文、电影、歌剧、哑剧、诗歌、舞蹈都是讲故事仪式的宏伟形式，每种形式都有自己的乐趣。然而，在历史的不同时期，这些形式中的一种会脱颖而出。在十六世纪是戏剧；在十九世纪是小说；在二十世纪是电影，这是所有艺术的盛大音乐会。银幕上最有力、最雄辩的时刻不需要口头描述来创造，也不需要对话来表演。它们是纯粹而无声的形象。文学天赋的材料是文字；故事天赋的材料是生活本身。

Literary and story talent are not only distinctively different but are unrelated, for stories do not need to be written to be told. Stories can be expressed any way human beings can communicate. Theatre, prose, film, opera, mime, poetry, dance are all magnificent forms of the story ritual, each with its own delights. At different times in history, however, one of these steps to the fore. In the sixteenth century it was the theatre; in the nineteenth century, the novel; in the twentieth century, the cinema, the grand concert of all the arts. The most powerful, eloquent moments on screen require no verbal description to create them, no dialogue to act them. They are image, pure and silent. The material of literary talent is words; the material of story talent is life itself.

工艺让天赋发挥到极致

CRAFT MAXIMIZES TALENT

虽然讲故事的天赋很少见，但我们经常会遇到似乎天生就有这种天赋的人，这些街头说书人讲故事就像微笑一样容易。例如，当同事们围坐在咖啡机旁时，讲故事就开始了。这是人际交往的货币。每当有六个人聚在一起进行上午的例行活动时，总会至少有一个人有这种天赋。

Rare as story talent is, we often meet people who seem to have it by nature, those street-corner raconteurs for whom storytelling is as easy as a smile. When, for example, coworkers gather around the coffee machine, the storytelling begins. It’s the currency of human contact. And whenever a half-dozen souls gather for this mid-morning ritual, there will always be at least one who has the gift.

假设今天早上，我们的讲故事者向朋友们讲述了“我如何把孩子们送上校车”的故事。就像柯勒律治的《古舟子咏》中那样，她吸引了所有人的注意力。她把他们吸引到她的魔力中，让他们目瞪口呆地喝着咖啡。她讲故事，让他们兴奋，让他们放松，让他们笑，甚至哭，让他们保持高度的悬念，直到她用一个精彩的结尾结束故事：“这就是我今天早上把那些小挖鼻孔的人带上校车的原因。”她的同事们心满意足地向后靠着，喃喃自语：“天哪，是的，海伦，我的孩子就是这样的。”

Let’s say that this morning our storyteller tells her friends the story of “How I Put My Kids on the School Bus.” Like Coleridge’s Ancient Mariner, she hooks everyone’s attention. She draws them into her spell, holding them slack-jawed over their coffee cups. She spins her tale, building them up, easing them down, making them laugh, maybe cry, holding all in high suspense until she pays it off with a dynamite last scene: “And that’s how I got the little nosepickers on the bus this morning.” Her coworkers lean back satisfied, muttering, “God, yes, Helen, my kids are just like that.”

现在，我们假设故事讲到了她旁边的那个男人身上，他向其他人讲述了他母亲上周末去世的令人心碎的故事……让每个人都感到厌烦。他的故事都是浮于表面的，从琐碎的细节到陈词滥调，一再​​重复：“她在棺材里看起来真好。”当他讲到一半时，其他人又回到咖啡壶旁喝了一杯，对他的悲伤故事充耳不闻。

Now let’s say the storytelling passes to the guy next to her who tells the others the heartrending tale of how his mother died over the weekend … and bores the hell out of everyone. His story is all on the surface, repetitious rambling from trivial detail to cliché: “She looked so good in her coffin.” Halfway through his rendition, the rest head back to the coffee pot for another cup, turning a deaf ear to his tale of grief.

如果要选择精彩讲述的琐碎内容和拙劣讲述的深刻内容，观众总是会选择精彩讲述的琐碎内容。讲故事高手知道如何从最微不足道的事情中挖掘出生命力，而拙劣的故事讲述者则会将深刻的内容简化为平庸之作。您可能拥有佛陀的洞察力，但如果您不会讲故事，您的想法就会变得枯燥无味。

Given the choice between trivial material brilliantly told versus profound material badly told, an audience will always choose the trivial told brilliantly. Master storytellers know how to squeeze life out of the least of things, while poor storytellers reduce the profound to the banal. You may have the insight of a Buddha, but if you cannot tell story, your ideas turn dry as chalk.

故事天赋是首要的，文学天赋是次要的，但必不可少。这一原则在电影和电视中是绝对正确的，在舞台和书本中比大多数剧作家和小说家愿意承认的更为真实。故事天赋虽然罕见，但你必须有，否则你就不会渴望写作。你的任务是从中榨取所有可能的创造力。只有利用你所知道的关于讲故事技巧的一切，你才能让你的天赋铸就故事。因为没有技巧的天赋就像没有引擎的燃料。它燃烧得很猛，却一无所获。

Story talent is primary, literary talent secondary but essential. This principle is absolute in film and television, and truer for stage and page than most playwrights and novelists wish to admit. Rare as story talent is, you must have some or you wouldn’t be itching to write. Your task is to wring from it all possible creativity. Only by using everything and anything you know about the craft of story-telling can you make your talent forge story. For talent without craft is like fuel without an engine. It burns wildly but accomplishes nothing.

第二部分故事的

要素



PART 2

THE

ELEMENTS

OF STORY

一个讲述得美的故事就像一个交响乐的整体，结构、背景、人物、类型和思想天衣无缝地融为一体。为了找到它们的和谐，作家必须研究故事的元素，就像它们是管弦乐队的乐器一样——先是单独研究，然后是协奏曲。

A beautifully told story is a symphonic unity in which structure, setting, character, genre, and idea meld seamlessly. To find their harmony, the writer must study the elements of story as if they were instruments of an orchestra—first separately, then in concert.

2

结构谱

2

THE STRUCTURE SPECTRUM

故事设计术语

THE TERMINOLOGY OF STORY DESIGN

当一个角色进入你的想象时，他会带来丰富的故事可能性。如果你愿意，你可以在角色出生前开始讲述，然后日复一日、数十年地跟随他，直到他死去。一个角色的一生包含数十万个生活小时，这些小时既复杂又多层次。

When a character steps into your imagination, he brings an abundance of story possibilities. If you wish, you could start the telling before the character is born, then follow him day after day, decade after decade until dead and gone. A character’s life encompasses hundreds of thousands of living hours, hours both complex and multileveled.

从一瞬间到永恒，从颅内到星际，每个人物的人生故事都提供了百科全书式的可能性。大师的标志是只选择几个瞬间，却给我们一生。

From an instant to eternity, from the intracranial to the intergalactic, the life story of each and every character offers encyclopedic possibilities. The mark of a master is to select only a few moments but give us a lifetime.

从最深层次开始，你可以将故事设定在主人公的内心世界，讲述他清醒或做梦时的思想和感受。或者你可以将故事提升到主人公与家人、朋友、爱人之间的个人冲突。或者扩展到社会机构，让角色与学校、职业、教堂、司法系统发生冲突。或者更广泛地说，你可以让角色与环境对抗——危险的城市街道、致命的疾病、无法启动的汽车、时间耗尽。或者所有这些层次的任意组合。

Starting at the deepest level, you might set the story within the protagonist’s inner life and tell the whole tale inside his thoughts and feelings, awake or dreaming. Or you could shift up to the level of personal conflict between protagonist and family, friends, lovers. Or expand into social institutions, setting the character at odds with school, career, church, the justice system. Or wider still, you could pit the character against the environment—dangerous city streets, lethal diseases, the car that won’t start, time running out. Or any combination of all these levels.

但这个复杂的人生故事必须成为讲述的故事。要设计一部故事片，你必须减少故事的沸腾和匆忙。短短两个小时里，你就可以讲出你人生故事的全部内容，或者多或少，这些内容表达了你遗漏的所有内容。如果故事讲得好，效果不就是这样吗？当朋友看完电影回来，你问他们电影讲的是什么，你有没有注意到他们经常把讲的故事放在人生故事里？

But this complex expanse of life story must become the story told. To design a feature film, you must reduce the seething mass and rush of life story to just two little hours, more or less, that somehow express everything you left out. And when a story is well told, isn’t that the effect? When friends come back from a film and you ask them what it was about, have you noticed they often put the story told inside life story?

“太棒了！这个故事讲的是一个在佃农农场长大的男孩。小时候，他和家人在烈日下辛苦劳作。他上学，但成绩并不好，因为他必须在黎明起床，除草锄地。但有人给了他一把吉他，他学会了弹吉他，写自己的歌……最后，他厌倦了这种艰苦的生活，离家出走，在廉价酒吧里演奏，勉强糊口。后来，他遇到了一位声音优美的美丽女孩。他们相爱了，组了队，然后，砰的一声，他们的事业一飞冲天。但问题是，人们总是把注意力集中在她身上。他为他们写歌，编曲，为她伴奏，但人们只来看她。生活在她的阴影下，他开始酗酒。最后，她把他赶了出去，他又重新踏上街头，直到他跌入谷底。他醒来时发现自己身处中西部一个尘土飞扬的小镇的廉价汽车旅馆，地处偏僻，身无分文，举目无亲，是个彻头彻尾的酒鬼，身无分文，打电话也无人可打电话。”

“Great! About a guy raised on a sharecropper’s farm. As a kid he toiled with his family under the hot sun. He went to school but didn’t do too well because he had to get up at dawn, all that weeding and hoeing. But somebody gave him a guitar and he learned to play, write his own songs … finally, fed up with this backbreaking life, he ran away, living hand to mouth playing in honky-tonk bars. Then he met a beautiful gal with a great voice. They fell in love, teamed up, and, bang, their careers skyrocketed. But the trouble was the spotlight was always on her. He wrote their songs, arranged, backed her up, but people only came to see her. Living in her shadow, he turned to drink. Finally she throws him out, and there he is back on the road again, until he hits rock bottom. He wakes up in a cheap motel in a dusty Midwest town, middle of nowhere, penniless, friendless, a hopeless drunk, not a dime for the phone and no one to call if he had one.”

换句话说，《温柔的怜悯》从出生开始讲述。但以上内容都不在电影中。《温柔的怜悯》从罗伯特·杜瓦尔饰演的麦克·斯莱奇在人生低谷醒来的早晨开始。接下来的两个小时涵盖了斯莱奇生命中的第二年。然而，在场景中和场景之间，我们了解了他的所有过去，了解了斯莱奇在那一年发生的所有重要事情，直到最后一张图片让我们看到了他的未来。一个人的一生，从出生到死亡，都在霍顿·福特的奥斯卡获奖剧本的淡入淡出之间被捕捉下来。

In other words, TENDER MERCIES told from birth. But nothing of the above is in the film. TENDER MERCIES begins the morning Robert Duvall’s Mac Sledge wakes up at rock bottom. The next two hours cover the next year in Sledge’s life. Yet, in and between scenes, we come to know all of his past, everything of significance that happens to Sledge in that year, until the last image gives us a vision of his future. A man’s life, virtually from birth to death, is captured between the FADE IN and FADE OUT of Horton Foote’s Oscar-winning screenplay.

结构

Structure

作家必须从纷繁复杂的人生故事中做出选择。虚构的世界不是白日梦，而是血汗工厂，我们在那里辛苦寻找素材来制作电影。然而，当被问到“你选择什么？”时，没有两位作家意见一致。有些人寻找人物，有些人寻找行动或冲突，也许是情绪、图像、对话。但没有一个元素本身能够构成一个故事。一部电影不仅仅是冲突或活动的时刻，个性或情感、妙语或象征。作家寻求的是事件，因为事件包含以上所有，甚至更多。

From the vast flux of life story the writer must make choices. Fictional worlds are not daydreams but sweatshops where we labor in search of material to tailor a film. Yet when asked “What do you choose?” no two writers agree. Some look for character, others for action or strife, perhaps mood, images, dialogue. But no one element, in and of itself, will build a story. A film isn’t just moments of conflict or activity, personality or emotionality, witty talk or symbols. What the writer seeks are events, for an event contains all the above and more.

结构是从人物生活故事中选择出的事件，按照战略顺序组合成一个整体，以唤起特定的情感并表达特定的人生观。

STRUCTURE is a selection of events from the characters’ life stories that is composed into a strategic sequence to arouse specific emotions and to express a specific view of life.

事件是由人引起的或影响人的，从而塑造人物；它发生在一个场景中，产生形象、动作和对话；它从冲突中汲取能量，在人物和观众中产生情感。但事件的选择不能随意或漠不关心地展示；它们必须被组合起来，故事中的“组合”与音乐中的含义大致相同。要包括什么？要排除什么？在什么之前和之后放什么？

An event is caused by or affects people, thus delineating characters; it takes place in a setting, generating image, action, and dialogue; it draws energy from conflict producing emotion in characters and audience alike. But event choices cannot be displayed randomly or indifferently; they must be composed, and “to compose” in story means much the same thing it does in music. What to include? To exclude? To put before and after what?

要回答这些问题，你必须知道你的目的。活动是为了什么而举办的？一个目的可能是表达你的感受，但如果它不能激起观众的情绪，那就变成了自我放纵。第二个目的可能是表达思想，但如果观众无法理解，这就有唯我论的风险。因此，活动的设计需要双重策略。

To answer these questions you must know your purpose. Events composed to do what? One purpose may be to express your feelings, but this becomes self-indulgence if it doesn’t result in arousing emotions in the audience. A second purpose may be to express ideas, but this risks solipsism if the audience cannot follow. So the design of events needs a dual strategy.

事件

Event

“事件”意味着变化。如果你窗外的街道是干燥的，但午睡后你发现它们湿了，你就会认为发生了一个事件，叫做下雨。世界从干燥变成了潮湿。然而，你不能只靠天气变化来制作一部电影——尽管有些人尝试过。故事事件是有意义的，而不是微不足道的。要使变化有意义，它必须首先发生在一个角色身上。如果你看到有人在倾盆大雨中浑身湿透，这比一条潮湿的街道更有意义。

“Event” means change. If the streets outside your window are dry, but after a nap you see they’re wet, you assume an event has taken place, called rain. The world’s changed from dry to wet.
