Fellini made I VITIONI and LA STRADA before he risked the Miniplot of AMARCORD or the Antiplot of 81/2. Godard made BREATHLESS before WEEKEND. Robert Altman perfected his story talents in the TV series Bonanza and Alfred Hitchcock Presents. First, the masters mastered the Archplot.

我同情年轻人想让第一部剧本读起来像《假面》的愿望。但加入先锋派的梦想必须等待，就像你之前的艺术家一样，你也掌握了古典形式。不要自欺欺人地认为你看过电影就理解了大情节。当你能做到的时候，你就会知道你理解了它。作家努力磨练他的技巧，直到知识从大脑的左侧转移到右侧，直到智力意识成为活生生的技艺。

I sympathize with the youthful desire to make a first screenplay read like PERSONA. But the dream of joining the avant-garde must wait while, like the artists before you, you too gain mastery of Classical form. Don’t kid yourself into thinking that you understand Archplot because you’ve seen the movies. You’ll know you understand it when you can do it. The writer works at his skills until knowledge shifts from the left side of the brain to the right, until intellectual awareness becomes living craft.

作家必须相信自己所写的东西

The Writer Must Believe in What He Writes

斯坦尼斯拉夫斯基问他的演员们：你们是爱上了自己身上的艺术，还是爱上了艺术中的自己？你们也必须审视自己想要以自己的方式写作的动机。为什么你的剧本总是落在三角形的一角或另一角？你的愿景是什么？

Stanislavski asked his actors: Are you in love with the art in yourself or yourself in the art? You too must examine your motives for wanting to write the way you write. Why do your screenplays find their way to one corner of the triangle or the other? What is your vision?

你创作的每一个故事都在向观众说：“我相信生活就是这样。 ”每一刻都必须充满你热情的信念，否则我们就会闻到虚假的味道。如果你写极简主义，你相信这种形式的含义吗？经验是否让你相信生活带来很少或根本没有变化？如果你的志向是反古典主义，你是否相信生活毫无意义？如果你的答案是肯定的，那么就写下你的小情节或反情节，并尽一切可能让它实现。

Each tale you create says to the audience: “I believe life is like this.” Every moment must be filled with your passionate conviction or we smell a phony. If you write minimalism, do you believe in the meanings of this form? Has experience convinced you that life brings little or no change? If your ambition is anticlassicism, are you convinced of the random meaninglessness of life? If your answer is a passionate yes, then write your Miniplot or Antiplot and do everything possible to see it made.

然而，对于绝大多数人来说，这些问题的诚实答案是否定的。然而，反结构，尤其是极简主义仍然像魔笛手一样吸引着年轻作家。为什么？我怀疑，对于许多人来说，引起他们兴趣的并不是这些形式的内在意义。相反，是这些形式外在所代表的东西。换句话说，就是政治。反情节和小情节并不是什么，而是它们不是什么：它们不是好莱坞。

For the vast majority, however, the honest answer to these questions is no. Yet antistructure and, in particular, minimalism still attract young writers like a Pied Piper. Why? I suspect that for many it isn’t the intrinsic meanings of such forms that draw their interest. Rather, it’s what these forms represent extrinsically. In other words, politics. It isn’t what Antiplot and Miniplot are, it’s what they’re not: They’re not Hollywood.

年轻人被教导好莱坞和艺术是对立的。因此，新手想要被认可为艺术家，就会陷入这样的陷阱：写剧本不是为了剧本是什么，而是为了剧本不是什么。他避免结局、活跃的角色、时间顺序和因果关系，以避免商业主义的污点。结果，自命不凡毒害了他的作品。

The young are taught that Hollywood and art are antithetical. The novice, therefore, wanting to be recognized as an artist, falls into the trap of writing a screenplay not for what it is, but for what it’s not. He avoids closure, active characters, chronology, and causality to avoid the taint of commercialism. As a result, pretentiousness poisons his work.

用埃德蒙德·胡塞尔的话来说，故事是我们思想和激情的体现，是我们希望灌输给观众的感受和见解的“客观对应物”。当你一边关注剧本，一边关注好莱坞，做出古怪的选择以避免商业主义的污点时，你就产生了文学上相当于发脾气的行为。就像一个生活在强大父亲阴影下的孩子，你打破好莱坞的“规则”，因为这会让你感到自由。但愤怒地反对家长并不是创造力；这是引起注意的违法行为。为了差异而差异，就像盲目地遵循商业命令一样，是一种空洞的成就。只写你相信的东西。

A story is the embodiment of our ideas and passions in Edmund Husserl’s phrase, “an objective correlative” for the feelings and insights we wish to instill in the audience. When you work with one eye on your script and the other on Hollywood, making eccentric choices to avoid the taint of commercialism, you produce the literary equivalent of a temper tantrum. Like a child living in the shadow of a powerful father, you break Hollywood’s “rules” because it makes you feel free. But angry contradiction of the patriarch is not creativity; it’s delinquency calling for attention. Difference for the sake of difference is as empty an achievement as slavishly following the commercial imperative. Write only what you believe.

3

结构与设置

3

STRUCTURE AND SETTING

反对陈词滥调的战争

THE WAR ON CLICHÈ

这可能是历史上对作家来说最艰难的时期。将今天沉迷于故事的观众与过去几个世纪的观众进行比较。受过教育的维多利亚时代人每年去剧院几次？在大家庭和没有自动洗碗机的时代，他们有多少时间阅读小说？在一个典型的星期里，我们的曾曾祖父母可能已经阅读或观看了五六个小时的故事——而我们许多人现在每天的阅读时间也差不多。当现代电影观众坐下来观看您的作品时，他们已经吸收了数万小时的电视、电影、散文和戏剧。您将创作什么他们从未见过的作品？您将在哪里找到真正原创的故事？您将如何赢得对陈词滥调的战争？

This may be the most demanding time in history to be a writer. Compare the story-saturated audience of today to that of centuries past. How many times a year did educated Victorians go to the theatre? In a era of huge families and no automatic dishwashers, how much time did they have for fiction? In a typical week our great-great-grandparents may have read or seen five or six hours of story—what many of us now consume per day. By the time modern filmgoers sit down to your work, they’ve absorbed tens of thousands of hours of TV, movies, prose, and theatre. What will you create that they haven’t seen before? Where will you find a truly original story? How will you win the war on cliche?

陈词滥调是观众不满的根源，就像一场因无知而传播的瘟疫，如今它感染了所有故事媒体。我们常常对从一开始就很明显的结局感到厌烦，然后合上小说或离开影院，因为这些陈词滥调的场景和人物我们已经看过太多次了，所以感到不满。这种全球流行病的原因很简单也很清楚；所有陈词滥调的根源都可以追溯到一件事，而且只有一件事：作家不了解他的故事世界。

Cliché is at the root of audience dissatisfaction, and like a plague spread through ignorance, it now infects all story media. Too often we close novels or exit theatres bored by an ending that was obvious from the beginning, disgruntled because we’ve seen these clichéd scenes and characters too many times before. The cause of this worldwide epidemic is simple and clear; the source of all clichés can be traced to one thing and one thing alone: The writer does not know the world of his story.

这类作家在选择背景并开始创作剧本时，假设自己对虚构世界有所了解，而实际上他们并不具备这种知识。当他们在脑海中寻找素材时，却一无所获。那么他们该去哪里呢？去寻找具有类似背景的电影、电视、小说和戏剧。从他们抄袭其他作家的作品，抄袭我们以前看过的场景，改写我们以前听过的对话，伪装我们以前见过的人物，并把他们当作自己的作品。他们重新加热文学残羹剩饭，端上一盘无聊的菜肴，因为无论他们有多有才华，他们都缺乏对故事背景及其内容的深入了解。了解和洞察故事的世界是实现原创和卓越的基础。

Such writers select a setting and launch a screenplay assuming a knowledge of their fictional world that they don’t have. As they reach into their minds for material, they come up empty. So where do they run? To films and TV, novels and plays with similar settings. From the works of other writers they crib scenes we’ve seen before, paraphrase dialogue we’ve heard before, disguise characters we’ve met before, and pass them off as their own. They reheat literary leftovers and serve up plates of boredom because, regardless of their talents, they lack an in-depth understanding of their story’s setting and all it contains. Knowledge of and insight into the world of your story is fundamental to the achievement of originality and excellence.

环境

SETTING

故事的背景是四维的——时期、持续时间、地点、冲突程度。

A story’s SETTING is four-dimensional—Period, Duration, Location, Level of Conflict.

时间的第一个维度是时期。故事背景是当代世界？还是历史？还是假设的未来？还是像《动物庄园》或《沃特希普荒原》等罕见的奇幻小说，其中的时间位置是不可知且无关紧要的？

The first dimension of time is Period. Is the story set in the contemporary world? In history? A hypothetical future? Or is it that rare fantasy, such as ANIMAL FARM or WATERSHIP DOWN, in which location in time is unknowable and irrelevant?

PERIOD 是故事在时间中的位置。

PERIOD is a story’s place in time.

持续时间是时间的第二个维度。故事在人物的一生中跨越了多少时间？几十年？几年？几个月？几天？是否有罕见的作品，故事时间等于放映时间，例如《我与安德烈的晚餐》，一部讲述两小时晚餐的两小时电影？

Duration is the second dimension of time. How much time does the story span within the lives of your characters? Decades? Years? Months? Days? Is it that rare work in which storytime equals screentime, such as MY DINNER WITH ANDRE, a two-hour movie about a two-hour dinner?

或者更罕见的是《去年在马里恩巴德》，一部将时间融化为永恒的电影？通过交叉剪辑、重叠、重复和/或慢动作，可以想象屏幕时间超越故事时间。虽然没有一部长篇电影尝试过这一点，但有几个片段做得非常出色——最著名的是《战舰波将金号》中的“敖德萨台阶”片段。沙皇军队对敖德萨抗议者的实际攻击不超过两三分钟，这是穿着长筒靴的脚从上到下走下台阶所需的时间。屏幕上的恐怖扩展到这个长度的五倍。

Or rarer still, LAST YEAR AT MARIENBAD, a film that liquefies time into timelessness? It’s conceivable, through cross-cutting, overlap, repetition, and/or slow motion, for screentime to surpass storytime. Although no feature-length film has attempted this, a few sequences have done it brilliantly—most famous of all, the “Odessa Steps” sequence of THE BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN. The actual assault by the Tsar’s army on the Odessa protesters took no more than two or three minutes, the time needed for jack-booted feet to march down the steps from top to bottom. Onscreen the terror expands to five times this length.

DURATION 是故事随时间的长度。

DURATION is a story’s length through time.

地点是故事的物理维度。故事的具体地理位置是什么？在哪个城镇？在哪条街道上？街道上有哪些建筑？建筑内有哪些房间？爬上哪座山？穿过哪片沙漠？前往哪个星球？

Location is the story’s physical dimension. What is the story’s specific geography? In what town? On what streets? What buildings on those streets? What rooms inside those buildings? Up what mountain? Across what desert? A voyage to what planet?

地点是故事在空间中的位置。

LOCATION is a story’s place in space.

冲突层次是人性维度。背景不仅包括物理和时间领域，还包括社会领域。从这个意义上说，这个维度是垂直的：你的故事讲述的冲突层次是怎样的？无论在机构中外化还是在个人中内化，社会的政治、经济、意识形态、生物和心理力量都会像时期、风景或服装一样影响事件。因此，包含各种冲突层次的角色阵容是故事背景的一部分。

Level of Conflict is the human dimension. A setting includes not only itsphysical and temporal domain, but social as well. This dimension becomes vertical in this sense: At what Level of Conflict do you pitch your telling? No matter how externalized in institutions or internalized in individuals, the political, economic, ideological, biological, and psychological forces of society shape events as much as period, landscape, or costume. Therefore, the cast of characters, containing its various levels of conflict, is part of a story’s setting.

你的故事是否聚焦于人物内心的、甚至是潜意识的冲突？还是上升到某个层次，聚焦于个人冲突？还是更高更广义的，聚焦于与社会制度的斗争？再广义一点，聚焦于与环境力量的斗争？从潜意识到星空，贯穿人生的所有多层次体验，你的故事可以设定在任何一个层次，也可以设定在这些层次的任意组合中。

Does your story focus on the inner, even unconscious conflicts within your characters? Or coming up a level, on personal conflicts? Or higher and wider, on battles with institutions in society? Wider still, on struggles against forces of the environment? From the subconscious to the stars, through all the multilayered experiences of life, your story may be set at any one or any combination of these levels.

冲突级别是故事在人类斗争等级中的位置。

LEVEL OF CONFLICT is the story’s position on the hierarchy of human struggles.

结构与背景的关系

The Relationship Between Structure and Setting

故事的背景明确地定义并限制了其可能性。

A story’s setting sharply defines and confines its possibilities.

尽管你的设定是虚构的，但并非所有想到的事情都可能在里面发生。在任何世界里，无论多么虚构，只有某些事件是可能或很可能发生的。

Although your setting is a fiction, not everything that comes to mind may be allowed to happen in it. Within any world, no matter how imaginary, only certain events are possible or probable.

如果你的剧情发生在洛杉矶西部的封闭式住宅区，我们不会看到房主在绿树成荫的街道上骚乱，抗议社会不公，尽管他们可能会举办一场每张餐盘上千美元的募捐活动。如果你的剧情发生在洛杉矶东部的住宅区，洛杉矶的贫民区，这些公民不会参加每张盘子价值数千美元的晚宴，但他们可能会走上街头要求改变。

If your drama is set among the gated estates of West L.A., we won’t see homeowners protesting social injustice by rioting in their tree-lined streets, although they might throw a thousand-dollar-a-plate fund-raiser. If your setting is the housing projects of East L.A.’s ghetto, these citizens won’t dine at thousand-dollar-a-plate galas, but they might hit the streets to demand change.

故事必须遵循其自身的概率法则。因此，作家对事件的选择受限于他所创造的世界的可能性和概率。

A STORY must obey its own internal laws of probability. The event choices of the writer, therefore, are limited to the possibilities and probabilities within the world he creates.

每个虚构世界都创造了一个独特的宇宙观，并制定了其内部事物发生方式和原因的“规则”。无论场景多么现实或离奇，一旦其因果原则确立，它们就无法改变。事实上，在所有体裁中，奇幻是最严格和结构最传统的。我们让奇幻作家远离现实，然后要求严密的概率和没有巧合——例如《绿野仙踪》的严格大情节。另一方面，坚韧不拔的现实主义往往允许逻辑上的飞跃。例如，在《非常嫌疑犯》中，编剧克里斯托弗·麦夸里将他疯狂的不切实际的情节限制在自由联想的“法则”之内。

Each fictional world creates a unique cosmology and makes its own “rules” for how and why things happen within it. No matter how realistic or bizarre the setting, once its causal principles are established, they cannot change. In fact, of all genres Fantasy is the most rigid and structurally conventional. We give the fantasy writer one great leap away from reality, then demand tight-knit probabilities and no coincidence—the strict Archplot of THE WIZARD OF OZ, for example. On the other hand, a gritty realism often allows leaps in logic. In THE USUAL SUSPECTS, for example, screenwriter Christopher McQuarrie arrests his wild improbabilities inside the “law” of free association.

故事并非凭空而来，而是从历史和人类经验中已有的材料中生长出来。从第一眼看到第一幅图像开始，观众就会审视你的虚构世界，将可能与不可能、可能与不可能区分开来。观众有意无意地想知道你的“法则”，了解事情在你的特定世界中如何发生以及为什么发生。你通过个人选择的背景和在其中工作的方式来创造这些可能性和局限性。在发明了这些限制之后，你就必须遵守合同。因为一旦观众掌握了你的现实法则，如果你打破这些法则，他们就会感到被侵犯，并认为你的作品不合逻辑、难以信服而拒绝接受。

Stories do not materialize from a void but grow out of materials already in history and human experience. From its first glimpse of the first image, the audience inspects your fictional universe, sorting the possible from the impossible, the likely from the unlikely. Consciously and unconsciously, it wants to know your “laws,” to learn how and why things happen in your specific world. You create these possibilities and limitations through your personal choice of setting and the way you work within it. Having invented these strictures, you’re bound to a contract you must keep. For once the audience grasps the laws of your reality, it feels violated if you break them and rejects your work as illogical and unconvincing.

从这个角度看，背景可能感觉像是想象力的束缚。在开发过程中，我经常被作家们试图通过拒绝具体化来摆脱束缚所震惊。“你的背景是什么？”我会问。“美国，”作家兴高采烈地回答。“听起来有点大。有想到哪个特定的社区吗？”“鲍勃，没关系。这是你典型的美国故事。这是关于离婚的故事。还有什么比这更美国化呢？我们可以把故事背景设置在路易斯安那州、纽约州或爱达荷州。没关系。”但这绝对重要。在 Bayou 发生的分手与数百万美元的 Park Avenue 诉讼案毫无相似之处，而且两者都不像土豆农场里的不忠行为。没有随身携带的故事。一个诚实的故事只适合一个地方和时间。

Seen this way, the setting may feel like a straitjacket to the imagination. When working in development, I’m often struck by how writers try to wriggle out of its restraints by refusing to be specific. “What’s your setting?” I’ll ask. “America,” the writer cheerfully answers. “Sounds a bit vast. Got any particular neighborhood in mind?” “Bob, it won’t matter. This is your quintessential American story. It’s about divorce. What could be more American? We can set it in Louisiana, New York, or Idaho. Won’t matter.” But it matters absolutely. Breakup in the Bayou bears little resemblance to a multimillion-dollar Park Avenue litigation, and neither looks like infidelity on a potato farm. There is no such thing as a portable story. An honest story is at home in one, and only one, place and time.

创作限制原则

THE PRINCIPLE OF CREATIVE LIMITATION

限制至关重要。要写出一个精彩的故事，第一步就是创造一个小而可知的世界。艺术家天生渴望自由，因此结构/背景关系限制创作选择的原则可能会激起你内心的反叛。然而，仔细观察，你会发现这种关系再积极不过了。背景对故事设计的限制并不会抑制创造力；它反而会激发创造力。

Limitation is vital. The first step toward a well-told story is to create a small, knowable world. Artists by nature crave freedom, so the principle that the structure/setting relationship restricts creative choices may stir the rebel in you. With a closer look, however, you’ll see that this relationship couldn’t be more positive. The constraint that setting imposes on story design doesn’t inhibit creativity; it inspires it.

所有精彩的故事都发生在一个有限的、可知的世界中。无论虚构的世界看起来多么宏伟，只要仔细观察就会发现它非常小。《罪与罚》是微观的。《战争与和平》虽然以动荡的俄罗斯为背景，但集中讲述了几个人物及其相互关联的家庭的故事。《奇爱博士》以杰克·D·里珀将军的办公室、飞往俄罗斯的飞行堡垒和五角大楼的作战室为背景。它的高潮是行星核毁灭，但故事仅限于三个场景和八个主要人物。

All fine stories take place within a limited, knowable world. No matter how grand a fictional world may seem, with a close look you’ll discover that it’s remarkably small. CRIME AND PUNISHMENT is microscopic. WAR AND PEACE, although played against a landscape of Russia in turmoil, is the focused tale of a handful of characters and their interrelated families. DR. STRANGELOVE is set in the office of General Jack D. Ripper, a Flying Fortress heading for Russia, and the War Room of the Pentagon. It climaxes in planetary nuclear annihilation, but the telling is limited to three sets and eight principal characters.

故事的世界必须足够小，以至于单个艺术家的头脑可以理解它所创造的虚构世界，并像上帝了解他所创造的世界一样深入细致地了解它。正如我母亲常说的，“上帝不会不知道一只麻雀掉下来。” 作家的世界里不应该有一只麻雀掉下来，他不会不知道。当你完成最后一稿时，你必须对故事的背景有深入细致的了解，以至于没有人会对你的世界提出任何你无法立即回答的问题——从人物的饮食习惯到九月的天气。

The world of a story must be small enough that the mind of a single artist can surround the fictional universe it creates and come to know it in the same depth and detail that God knows the one He created. As my mother used to say, “Not a sparrow falls that God does not know.” Not a sparrow should fall in the world of a writer that he wouldn’t know. By the time you finish your last draft, you must possess a commanding knowledge of your setting in such depth and detail that no one could raise a question about your world—from the eating habits of your characters to the weather in September—that you couldn’t answer instantly.

然而，“小”世界并不意味着微不足道。艺术就是从宇宙中分离出一小块，并以某种方式将它举起来，让它看起来是此刻最重要、最迷人的东西。在这种情况下，“小”意味着可知。

A “small” world, however, does not mean a trivial world. Art consists of separating one tiny piece from the rest of the universe and holding it up in such a way that it appears to be the most important, fascinating thing of this moment. “Small,” in this case, means knowable.

“掌握知识”并不意味着对存在的每一个缝隙都具有广泛的认识。它意味着对所有相关事物的了解。这似乎是一个不可能实现的理想，但最好的作家每天都在实现它。英格玛·伯格曼会不明白《呼喊与细语》的时间、地点和人物的哪些相关问题？大卫·马梅特会不明白《拜金一族》的哪些相关问题？约翰·克里斯会不明白《一条叫旺达的鱼》的哪些相关问题？这并不是说优秀的艺术家会对他们的故事所暗示的每一个生活方面进行深思熟虑、有意识的思考，而是在某种程度上他们会吸收一切。伟大的作家知道一切。因此，要在可知的范围内写作。一个广阔而拥挤的世界会把人的心智拉得太窄，知识必定是肤浅的。一个有限的世界和有限的演员阵容提供了深度和广度知识的可能性。

“Commanding knowledge” does not mean an extended awareness into every crevice of existence. It means knowledge of all that’s germane. This may seem an impossible ideal, but the best writers attain it every day. What relevant question about the time, place, and characters of CRIES AND WHISPERS would elude Ingmar Bergman? Or David Mamet of GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS? Or John Cleese of A FISH CALLED WANDA? It’s not that fine artists give deliberate, conscious thought to each and every aspect of life implied by their stories, but at some level they absorb it all. Great writers know. Therefore, work within what’s knowable. A vast, populous world stretches the mind so thinly that knowledge must be superficial. A limited world and restricted cast offer the possibility of knowledge in depth and breadth.

设定与故事之间的讽刺之处在于：世界越大，作家的知识就越稀薄，因此他的创作选择就越少，故事就越陈词滥调。世界越小，作家的知识就越完整，因此他的创作选择就越多。结果：一个完全原创的故事和对陈词滥调的战争的胜利。

The irony of setting versus story is this: The larger the world, the more diluted the knowledge of the writer, therefore the fewer his creative choices and the more clichéd the story. The smaller the world, the more complete the knowledge of the writer, therefore the greater his creative choices. Result: a fully original story and victory in the war on cliché.

研究

RESEARCH

赢得这场战争的关键是研究，花时间和精力去获取知识。我建议采用以下具体方法：研究记忆、研究想象、研究事实。一般来说，一个故事需要这三种方法。

The key to winning this war is research, taking the time and effort to acquire knowledge. I suggest these specific methods: research of memory, research of imagination, research of fact. Generally, a story needs all three.

记忆

Memory

靠在办公桌前，问问自己：“我从个人经历中了解到了什么，可以影响我笔下人物的生活？”

Lean back from your desk and ask, “What do I know from personal experience that touches on my characters’ lives?”

假设你写的是一位中年高管，他面临着一场成就职业生涯或毁掉职业生涯的演讲。他的个人和职业生涯岌岌可危。他很害怕。害怕是什么感觉？慢慢地，记忆把你带回到那天，你妈妈出于你永远无法理解的原因，把你锁在壁橱里，离开了家，直到第二天才回来。回忆一下黑暗笼罩着你那漫长而充满恐惧的时光。你的角色有同样的感受吗？如果是这样，生动地描述你在壁橱里的白天和黑夜。你可能认为你知道，但你不知道你知道，直到你能写下来。研究不是白日梦。探索你的过去，重温它，然后写下来。在你的脑海里它只是记忆，但写下来它就变成了实用知识。现在，带着你腹中的恐惧之怒，写一个真实的、独一无二的场景。

You’re writing, let’s say, about a middle-aged executive who faces a career-making/career-destroying presentation. His personal and professional life hangs in the balance. He’s afraid. How does fear feel? Slowly, memory takes you back to the day your mother, for reasons you’ll never understand, locked you in a closet, left the house, and didn’t come back until the next day. Bring back those long, fright-filled hours when the dark smothered you. Could your character feel the same? If so, vividly describe your day and night in the closet. You may think you know, but you don’t know you know until you can write it down. Research is not daydreaming. Explore your past, relive it, then write it down. In your head it’s only memory, but written down it becomes working knowledge. Now with the bile of fear in your belly, write an honest, one-of-a-kind scene.

想像力

Imagination

向后靠，问自己：“每天、每小时过着我笔下角色的生活会是什么样的？”

Lean back and ask, “What would it be like to live my character’s life hour by hour, day by day?”

生动地描绘出你的人物如何购物、做爱、祈祷——这些场景可能会出现在你的故事中，也可能不会，但会把你带入你想象的世界，直到感觉似曾相识。记忆给了我们整个生活，而想象力则把看似毫无关联的碎片、梦的碎片和经验碎片，寻找它们隐藏的联系，将它们融合成一个整体。找到这些联系并设想出这些场景后，把它们写下来。有效的想象力就是研究。

In vivid detail sketch how your characters shop, make love, pray—scenes that may or may not find their way into your story, but draw you into your imagined world until it feels like déja vu. While memory gives us whole chunks of life, imagination takes fragments, slivers of dream, and chips of experience that seem unrelated, then seeks their hidden connections and merges them into a whole. Having found these links and envisioned the scenes, write them down. A working imagination is research.

事实

Fact

你曾经有过写作瓶颈吗？很可怕，不是吗？日子一天天过去，什么也没写出来。打扫车库看起来很有趣。你一遍又一遍地重新整理你的桌子，直到你觉得自己疯了。我知道一种治疗方法，但这不是去看心理医生。而是去图书馆。

Have you ever had writer’s block? Scary, isn’t it? Days drag by and nothing gets written. Cleaning the garage looks like fun. You rearrange your desk over and over and over until you think you’re losing your mind. I know a cure, but it isn’t a trip to your psychiatrist. It’s a trip to the library.

你被困住是因为你无话可说。你的才华并没有抛弃你。如果你有话要说，你就无法阻止自己写作。你不能扼杀你的才华，但你可以因无知而使它陷入昏迷。因为无论你多么有才华，无知者无法写作。事实和想法必须激发才华。做研究。培养你的才华。研究不仅能打赢陈词滥调之战，也是战胜恐惧及其表亲抑郁的关键。

You’re blocked because you have nothing to say. Your talent didn’t abandon you. If you had something to say, you couldn’t stop yourself from writing. You can’t kill your talent, but you can starve it into a coma through ignorance. For no matter how talented, the ignorant cannot write. Talent must be stimulated by facts and ideas. Do research. Feed your talent. Research not only wins the war on cliché, it’s the key to victory over fear and its cousin, depression.

假设你正在写家庭剧。你在一个家庭中长大，也许你养育过一个家庭，你见过家庭，你可以想象家庭。但如果你去图书馆阅读有关家庭生活动态的受人尊敬的著作，就会发生两件非常重要的事情：

Suppose, for example, you’re writing in the genre of Domestic Drama. You were raised in a family, perhaps you’ve raised a family, you’ve seen families, you can imagine families. But if you were go to the library and read respected works on the dynamics of family life, two very important things would happen:

  1. 生活教给你的一切都将得到有力的证实。在一页又一页的书里，你会认出自己的家庭。这一发现至关重要，即你的个人经历具有普遍性。这意味着你将拥有一个读者群。你的写作方式独一无二，但世界各地的读者都会理解，因为家庭的模式无处不在。你在家庭生活中所经历的一切与其他人的经历相似——竞争与联盟、忠诚与背叛、痛苦与欢乐。当你表达出你认为只属于你自己的情感时，每个读者都会认识到这是他自己的，也是他自己的。

  2. Everything life has taught you would be powerfully confirmed. On page after page you’ll recognize your own family. This discovery, that your personal experience is universal, is critical. It means you’ll have an audience. You’ll write in a singular way, but audiences everywhere will understand because the patterns of family are ubiquitous. What you’ve experienced in your domestic life is analogous to all others—the rivalries and alliances, loyalties and betrayals, pains and joys. As you express emotions you feel are yours and yours alone, each member of the audience will recognize them as his and his alone.

  3. 无论你生活在多少个家庭中，观察过多少个家庭，或者你的想象力多么丰富，你对家庭本质的了解都仅限于你有限的经验范围。但是当你在图书馆做笔记时，你扎实、真实的研究将把这个范围扩大到全球。你会突然被强大的洞察力所震撼，并达到你无法通过其他方式获得的深刻理解。

  4. No matter how many families you live in, how many you observe, or how vivid your imagination, your knowledge of the nature of family is limited to the finite circle of your experience. But as you take notes in the library, your solid, factual research will expand that circle globally. You’ll be struck by sudden and powerful insights and reach a depth of understanding you couldn’t have gained any other way.

通过对记忆、想象和事实的研究，往往会出现一种作者喜欢用神秘术语描述的现象：人物突然活了过来，他们自愿做出选择并采取行动，创造出转折点，这些转折点不断扭曲、构建和转变，直到作者打字速度快到跟不上这些倾泻而下的情节。

Research from memory, imagination, and fact is often followed by a phenomenon that authors love to describe in mystical terms: Characters suddenly spring to life and of their own free will make choices and take actions that create Turning Points that twist, build, and turn again until the writer can hardly type fast enough to keep up with the outpourings.

这种“处女生子”是作家们喜欢沉迷的一种迷人的自我欺骗，但突然间，故事正在写作写作本身只是标志着作家对某一主题的了解达到饱和点的时刻。作家成为他小宇宙的神，对看似自发的创作感到惊讶，但事实上这是努力工作的回报。

This “virgin birth” is a charming self-deception writers love to indulge in, but the sudden impression that the story is writing itself simply marks the moment when a writer’s knowledge of the subject has reached the saturation point. The writer becomes the god of his little universe and is amazed by what seems to be spontaneous creation, but is in fact the reward for hard work.

但请注意。虽然研究提供了素材，但它不能代替创造力。对背景和演员的传记、心理、身体、政治和历史研究是必不可少的，但如果它不能导致事件的创作，那就毫无意义了。故事不是将信息串联成叙述的积累，而是将我们带到有意义的高潮的事件设计。

Be warned, however. While research provides material, it’s no substitute for creativity. Biographical, psychological, physical, political, and historical research of the setting and cast is essential but pointless if it doesn’t lead to the creation of events. A story is not an accumulation of information strung into a narrative, but a design of events to carry us to a meaningful climax.

此外，研究绝不能成为拖延症。太多缺乏安全感的人才花费数年时间进行研究，却从未真正写出任何东西。研究只是喂养想象力和发明力的肉食，而不是最终目的。研究也没有必要的顺序。我们不会先在笔记本上写满社会、传记和历史研究，等到所有这些工作完成后，才开始创作故事。创造力很少如此理性。创作和探索交替进行。

What’s more, research must not become procrastination. Too many insecure talents spend years in study and never actually write anything. Research is meat to feed the beasts of imagination and invention, never an end in itself. Nor is there a necessary sequence to research. We do not first fill notebooks full of social, biographical, and historical studies, and once all this work is done, begin to compose a story. Creativity is rarely so rational. Origination and exploration go on alternatively.

想象一下写一部心理惊悚小说。你也许会以“如果……”开头。如果一名精神科医生违背职业道德，与她的病人发生婚外情，会发生什么？你好奇地想知道，这位医生是谁？病人是谁？也许他是一名士兵，患有精神错乱症，精神失常。她为什么会爱上他？你分析和探索，直到越来越多的知识导致疯狂的猜测：假设她爱上了他，因为她的治疗似乎创造了奇迹：在催眠状态下，他睁大眼睛的麻痹消失了，露出了一个美丽的、几乎天使般的个性。

Imagine writing a Psycho-Thriller. You begin perhaps with a “What if…” What would happen if a psychiatrist violated her professional ethics and began an affair with her patient? Intrigued, you wonder, Who is this doctor? Patient? Perhaps he’s a soldier, shell-shocked, catatonic. Why does she fall for him? You analyze and explore until growing knowledge leads to wild speculation: Suppose she falls when her treatment seems to work a miracle: Under hypnosis his wide-eyed paralysis melts away to reveal a beautiful, almost angelic personality.

这种转变似乎太甜蜜了，让人难以置信，所以你开始朝另一个方向寻找，在深入研究中，你遇到了成功精神分裂症的概念：一些精神病患者拥有如此极端的智慧和意志力，他们可以很容易地向周围的每个人隐藏他们的疯狂，甚至是他们的精神科医生。你的病人会是其中之一吗？你的医生会爱上一个她认为已经治愈的疯子吗？

That turn seems too sweet to be true, so you go on a hunt in the other direction, and deep in your studies you come across the concept of successful schizophrenia: Some psychotics possess such extreme intelligence and willpower they can easily hide their madness from everyone around them, even their psychiatrists. Could your patient be one of these? Could your doctor be in love with a madman she thinks she’s cured?

随着新想法的出现，你的故事和人物也会不断成长；随着你的故事不断发展，问题也随之产生，你也会渴望更多研究。创作和调查来来回回，互相提出要求，以这样或那样的方式推拉，直到故事本身完整而生动。

As new ideas seed your story, story and characters grow; as your story grows, questions are raised and it hungers for more research. Creation and investigation go back and forth, making demands on each other, pushing and pulling this way or that until the story shakes itself out, complete and alive.

创意选择

CREATIVE CHOICES

优秀的写作从来不是一对一的，从来不是设计出故事所需的确切事件数量，然后用铅笔写下对话。创造力是五比一，也许是十比一或二十比一。这种手艺要求发明远超你所能使用的材料，然后从这些高质量的事件、忠于角色和世界的原创时刻中精明地挑选。例如，当演员们互相称赞时，他们经常说：“我喜欢你的选择。”他们知道，如果同事找到了一个美妙的时刻，那是因为演员在排练时尝试了二十种不同的方式，然后选择了一个完美的时刻。我们也是如此。

Fine writing is never one to one, never a matter of devising the exact number of events necessary to fill a story, then penciling in dialogue. Creativity is five to one, perhaps ten or twenty to one. The craft demands the invention of far more material than you can possibly use, then the astute selection from this quantity of quality events, moments of originality that are true to character and true to world. When actors compliment each other, for example, they often say, “I like your choices.” They know that if a colleague has arrived at a beautiful moment, it’s because in rehearsal the actor tried it twenty different ways, then chose the one perfect moment. The same is true for us.

创造力意味着包容和排斥的创造性选择。

CREATIVITY means creative choices of inclusion and exclusion.

想象一下，你正在写一部以曼哈顿东区为背景的浪漫喜剧。你的思绪在角色们各自的生活中来回穿梭，寻找恋人相遇的完美时刻。然后突然灵感迸发：“单身酒吧！就是它！他们在 PJ Clarke's 相遇！”为什么不呢？考虑到你想象中的富裕纽约人，在单身酒吧相遇当然是可能的。为什么不呢？因为这是一个可怕的陈词滥调。当达斯汀·霍夫曼在《约翰与玛丽》中遇到米亚·法罗时，这是一个新鲜的想法，但自那以后，雅皮士恋人在一部又一部电影、肥皂剧和情景喜剧中都在单身酒吧相遇。

Imagine writing a romantic comedy set on the East Side of Manhattan. Your thoughts meander back and forth between the separate lives of your characters, searching for that perfect moment when the lovers meet. Then sudden inspiration: “A singles bar! That’s it! They meet at P. J. Clarke’s!” And why not? Given the affluent New Yorkers of your imagining, meeting in a singles bar is certainly possible. Why not? Because it’s a dreadful cliche. It was a fresh idea when Dustin Hoffman met Mia Farrow in JOHN AND MARY, but since then, yuppie lovers have bumped into each other in a singles bar in film after film, soap operas, and sitcoms.

但如果你懂这门手艺，你就会知道如何治愈陈词滥调：列出五、十、十五个不同的“东区恋人相遇”场景。为什么？因为经验丰富的作家从不相信所谓的灵感。灵感往往是你脑海中浮现的第一个想法，而你脑海里浮现的是你看过的每一部电影、读过的每一本小说，它们为陈词滥调提供了灵感。勇气。这就是为什么我们周一爱上了一个想法，睡了一觉，周二又厌恶地重读它，因为我们意识到我们已经在其他十几部作品中看到过这种陈词滥调。真正的灵感来自更深层次的源泉，所以释放你的想象力并进行实验：

But if you know the craft, you know how to cure clichés: Sketch a list of five, ten, fifteen different “East Side lovers meet” scenes. Why? Because experienced writers never trust so-called inspiration. More often than not, inspiration is the first idea picked off the top of your head, and sitting on the top of your head is every film you’ve ever seen, every novel you’ve ever read, offering clichés to pluck. This is why we fall in love with an idea on Monday, sleep on it, then reread it with disgust on Tuesday as we realize we’ve seen this cliche in a dozen other works. True inspiration comes from a deeper source, so let loose your imagination and experiment:

  1. 单身酒吧。虽然俗气，但是一种选择。不要急着把它扔掉。

  2. Singles Bar. Cliché, but a choice. Don’t throw it away yet.

  3. 帕克大道。他的宝马爆胎了。他站在路边，穿着三件套西装，无助无助。她骑着摩托车过来，对他表示同情。她拿出备用轮胎，在她修理汽车的同时，他扮演护士的角色，递给她千斤顶手柄、螺母、车轮罩……直到突然目光相遇，火花四溅。

  4. Park Avenue. A tire blows out on his BMW. He stands at the curb, helpless in his three-piece suit. She comes along on her motorcycle and takes pity on him. She gets out the spare, and as she doctors the car, he plays nurse, handing her jack handle, lug nuts, wheel cover … until suddenly eyes meet and sparks fly.

  5. 厕所。她在办公室圣诞派对上喝得酩酊大醉，跌跌撞撞地走进男厕所呕吐。他发现她倒在地板上。在其他人进来之前，他迅速锁上了隔间的门，帮助她缓解病情。等一切都恢复正常后，他偷偷带她出去，让她免于尴尬。

  6. Toilet. She’s so drunk at the office Christmas party that she stumbles into the men’s room to throw up. He finds her collapsed on the floor. Quickly, before others enter, he locks the stall door and helps her through her illness. When the coast is clear he sneaks her out, saving her embarrassment.

列表越来越长。你不必把这些场景全部写出来。你正在寻找想法，所以只需粗略地勾勒出发生的事情。如果你深入了解你的角色和世界，那么十几个或更多这样的场景就不是什么难事了。一旦你用尽了最好的想法，就检查一下你的列表，问这些问题：哪个场景对我的角色最真实？对他们的世界最真实？而且以前从未以这种方式出现在屏幕上？这就是你写进剧本的场景。

On and on the list grows. You needn’t write out these scenes in full. You’re on a search for ideas, so simply sketch the bold strokes of what happens. If you know your characters and world in depth, a dozen or more such scenes won’t be a difficult task. Once you’ve exhausted your best ideas, survey your list, asking these questions: Which scene is truest to my characters? Truest to their world? And has never been on the screen quite this way before? This is the one you write into the screenplay.

然而，假设当你质疑清单上的邂逅场景时，你内心深处意识到，虽然所有场景都有其优点，但你的第一印象是正确的。不管是否是陈词滥调，这些恋人都会在单身酒吧相遇；没有什么比这更能表达他们的天性和环境了。现在你该怎么做？跟随你的直觉，开始一份新清单：在单身酒吧相遇的十几种不同方式。研究这个世界，闲逛，观察人群，参与其中，直到你比之前的作家更了解单身酒吧的场景。

Suppose, however, as you question the meeting-cute scenes on your list, deep in your gut you realize that, while all have their virtues, your first impression was right. Cliché or not, these lovers would meet in a singles bar; nothing could be more expressive of their natures and milieu. Now what do you do? Follow your instincts and start a new list: a dozen different ways to meet in a singles bar. Research this world, hang out, observe the crowd, get involved, until you know the singles bar scene like no writer before you.

浏览你的新列表时，你会问同样的问题：哪种变体最真实地反映了人物和世界？哪种变体从未被描述过？以前在银幕上出现过这样的场景吗？当你的剧本拍成电影，摄影机推向单身酒吧时，观众的第一反应可能是，“天哪，又不是单身酒吧的场景。”但当你把他们带进门，向他们展示那些肉架上真正发生的事情时。如果你做得好，观众会惊讶得合不拢嘴，点头称是：“没错！这不是‘你的星座是什么？最近读了什么好书？’的问题。这很尴尬，很危险。这是事实。”

Scanning your new list you ask the same questions: Which variation is truest to character and world? Which has never been onscreen before? When your script becomes a film and the camera dollies toward a singles bar, the audience’s first reaction may be, “Oh man, not another singles bar scene.” But then you take them through the door, show them what really goes on in those meat racks. If you’ve done your task well, jaws will drop and heads will nod: “That’s right! It’s not ‘What’s your astrological sign? Read any good books lately?’ That’s the embarrassment, danger. That’s the truth.”

如果你完成的剧本包含了你写过的每一个场景，如果你从未抛弃过任何想法，如果你的重写只是对对话进行修改，那么你的作品几乎肯定会失败。无论我们的才华如何，我们都知道，我们所做的 90% 都不是最佳水平。然而，如果研究能以十比一甚至二十比一的速度激励你，如果你做出明智的选择，找到那 10% 的优秀之处，并烧掉其余部分，那么每个场景都会令人着迷，全世界都会对你的天才感到敬畏。

If your finished screenplay contains every scene you’ve ever written, if you’ve never thrown an idea away, if your rewriting is little more than tinkering with dialogue, your work will almost certainly fail. No matter our talent, we all know in the midnight of our souls that 90 percent of what we do is less than our best. If, however, research inspires a pace of ten to one, even twenty to one, and if you then make brilliant choices to find that 10 percent of excellence and burn the rest, every scene will fascinate and the world will sit in awe of your genius.

没有人会注意到你的失败，除非你愚蠢地加上虚荣心并把它们展现出来。天才不仅包括创造富有表现力的节奏和场景的能力，还包括品味、判断力和意志，以清除和摧毁平庸、自负、虚假和谎言。

No one has to see your failures unless you add vanity to folly and exhibit them. Genius consists not only of the power to create expressive beats and scenes, but of the taste, judgment, and will to weed out and destroy banalities, conceits, false notes, and lies.

4

结构与体裁

4

STRUCTURE AND GENRE

电影类型

THE FILM GENRES

数万年来，人们在炉边讲述着各种故事，四千年来，人们用文字书写着各种文字，两千五百年来，戏剧、电影、广播等形式层出不穷，一代又一代的讲故事者将故事编织成千姿百态、令人称奇的故事。为了理解这些故事，人们设计了各种系统，根据故事的共同元素对故事进行分类，并按类型进行分类。然而，没有两个系统能够就分类时应使用哪些故事元素达成一致，因此，也没有两个系统能够就类型的数量和种类达成一致。

Through tens of thousands of years of tales told at fireside, four millennia of the written word, twenty-five hundred years of theatre, a century of film, and eight decades of broadcasting, countless generations of storytellers have spun story into an astonishing diversity of patterns. To make sense of this outpouring, various systems have been devised to sort stories according to shared elements, classifying them by genre. No two systems, however, have ever agreed on which story elements to use in the sorting, and, therefore, no two agree on the number and kind of genres.

亚里士多德根据结局的价值负荷和故事设计对戏剧进行划分，为我们提供了第一种类型。他指出，一个故事的结局可以是正面的，也可以是负面的。那么这两种类型中的每一种都可以是简单设计（结局平淡，没有转折点或惊喜）或复杂设计（高潮围绕主角生活中的重大逆转）。结果就是他的四种基本类型：简单悲剧、简单幸运、复杂悲剧、复杂幸运。

Aristotle gave us the first genres by dividing dramas according to the value-charge of their ending versus their story design. A story, he noted, could end on either a positive or a negative charge. Then each of these two types could be either a Simple design (ending flat with no turning point or surprise) or a Complex design (climaxing around a major reversal in the protagonist’s life). The result is his four basic genres: Simple Tragic, Simple Fortunate, Complex Tragic, Complex Fortunate.

然而，几个世纪以来，随着体裁体系变得越来越模糊和臃肿，亚里士多德的清晰性也逐渐消失。歌德根据主题列出了七种类型——爱情、复仇等等。席勒认为肯定还有更多，但他无法一一列举。波尔蒂列举了至少三十种不同的情绪，并从中推导出“三十六种戏剧性情景​​”，但他的分类诸如“为爱而犯下的不自觉罪行”或“为理想而自我牺牲”等概念模糊得无法使用。符号学家梅茨将所有电影剪辑缩减为八种可能性，他称之为“语法”，然后试图将所有电影图式化为“大语法”，但他将艺术转化为科学的努力却像巴别塔一样崩溃了。

Over the centuries, however, the lucidity of Aristotle was lost as genre systems became more and more blurred and bloated. Goethe listed seven types by subject matter—love, revenge, and so on. Schiller argued that there must be more but couldn’t name them. Polti inventoried no less than three dozen different emotions from which he deduced “Thirty-Six Dramatic Situations,” but his categories such as “An Involuntary Crime Committed for Love” or “Self-Sacrifice for an Ideal” are vague beyond use. The semiologist Metz reduced all film edits to eight possibilities he called “syntagmas,” then tried to schematize all of cinema inside “La Gran Syntagma,” but his effort to turn art into science crumbled like the Tower of Babel.

另一方面，新亚里士多德主义批评家诺曼·弗里德曼则开发了一个系统，该系统再次通过结构和价值观来划分流派。弗里德曼对教育情节、救赎情节和幻灭情节等进行了区分，这些情节微妙地以内心冲突为层次，从而给主人公的思想或道德本质带来深刻的变化。

The neo-Aristotelian critic Norman Friedman, on the other hand, developed a system that once again delineates genres by structure and values. We’re indebted to Friedman for distinctions such as the Education Plot, Redemption Plot, and Disillusionment Plot—subtle forms in which story arcs at the level of inner conflict to bring about deep changes within the mind or moral nature of the protagonist.

虽然学者们对定义和体系存在争议，但观众已经是电影类型的专家。观众在观看每部电影时，都带着通过一生的观影经历所学到的一套复杂的预期。电影观众对电影类型的了解给作家带来了这一关键挑战：他不仅必须满足观众的预期，否则可能会让他们感到困惑和失望，还必须将他们的预期引向新鲜、意想不到的时刻，否则可能会让他们感到无聊。如果没有超越观众对电影类型的了解，这种双管齐下的技巧是不可能实现的。

While scholars dispute definitions and systems, the audience is already a genre expert. It enters each film armed with a complex set of anticipations learned through a lifetime of moviegoing. The genre sophistication of filmgoers presents the writer with this critical challenge: He must not only fulfill audience anticipations, or risk their confusion and disappointment, but he must lead their expectations to fresh, unexpected moments, or risk boring them. This two-handed trick is impossible without a knowledge of genre that surpasses the audience’s.

以下是编剧使用的类型和子类型系统——该系统是从实践而非理论发展而来的，它取决于主题、背景、角色、事件和价值观的差异。

Below is the genre and subgenre system used by screen-writers—a system that’s evolved from practice, not theory, and that turns on differences of subject, setting, role, event, and values.

  1. 爱情故事。其子类型《好友救赎》用友情取代了浪漫爱情：《穷街陋巷》、《激情鱼》、《罗密欧与朱丽的高中同学聚会》。

  2. LOVE STORY. Its subgenre, Buddy Salvation, substitutes friendship for romantic love: MEAN STREETS, PASSION FISH, ROMY AND MICHELE’S HIGH SCHOOL REUNION.

  3. 恐怖片。恐怖片又分为三个子类型：恐怖片，恐怖的来源令人震惊，但可以得到“理性”的解释，比如来自外太空的生物、科学制造的怪物或疯子；超自然片，恐怖的来源是来自精神领域的“非理性”现象；超级恐怖片，观众只能在另外两种可能性之间猜测——《怪房客》、《狼时》、《闪灵》。

  4. HORROR FILM. This genre divides into three subgenres: the Uncanny, in which the source of horror is astounding but subject to “rational” explanation, such as beings from outer space, science-made monsters, or a maniac; the Supernatural, in which the source of horror is an “irrational” phenomenon from the spirit realm; and the Super-Uncanny, in which the audience is kept guessing between the other two possibilities—THE TENANT, HOUR OF THE WOLF, THE SHINING.

  5. 现代史诗（个人与国家）：《斯巴达克斯》、《史密斯先生到华盛顿》、《萨帕塔万岁！》、《1984》、《人民与拉里·弗林特》。

  6. MODERN EPIC (the individual versus the state): SPAR-TACUS, MR. SMITH GOES TO WASHINGTON, VIVA ZAPATA!, 1984, THE PEOPLE VS. LARRY FLINT.

  7. 西部片。威尔·赖特的《六支枪与社会》精彩地描述了这一类型及其子类型的演变。

  8. WESTERN. The evolution of this genre and its subgenres is brilliantly traced in Will Wright’s Six Guns and Society.

  9. 战争题材。虽然战争通常是其他题材（如爱情故事）的背景，但战争题材专门讲述战斗。支持战争与反对战争是其主要子题材。当代电影一般反对战争，但几十年来，大多数电影暗中赞美战争，即使是最可怕的战争形式。

  10. WAR GENRE. Although war is often the setting for another genre, such as the Love Story, the WAR GENRE is specifically about combat. Pro-war versus Antiwar are its primary subgenres. Contemporary films generally oppose war, but for decades the majority covertly glorified it, even in its most grisly form.

  11. 成熟情节或成长故事：《伴我同行》、《周末夜狂热》、《冒险乐园》、《飞越未来》、《小鹿斑比》、《穆里尔的婚礼》。

  12. MATURATION PLOT or the coming-of-age story: STAND BY ME, SATURDAY NIGHT FEVER, RISKY BUSINESS, BIG, BAMBI, MURIEL’S WEDDING.

  13. 救赎情节。影片在这里讲述了主人公从坏到好的道德转变：《骗子》、《吉姆爵士》、《药店牛仔》、《辛德勒的名单》、《承诺》。

  14. REDEMPTION PLOT. Here the film arcs on a moral change within the protagonist from bad to good: THE HUSTLER, LORD JIM, DRUGSTORE COWBOY, SCHINDLER’S LIST, LA PROMESSE.

  15. 惩罚性情节。在这些情节中，好人变坏并受到惩罚：《贪婪》、《碧血金沙》、《梅菲斯特》、《华尔街》、《崩溃》。

  16. PUNITIVE PLOT. In these the good guy turns bad and is punished: GREED, THE TREASURE OF THE SIERRA MADRE, MEPHISTO, WALL STREET, FALLING DOWN.

  17. 测试情节。意志力与屈服诱惑的故事：《老人与海》、《铁窗喋血》、《陆战队》、《阿甘正传》。

  18. TESTING PLOT. Stories of willpower versus temptation to surrender: THE OLD MAN AND THE SEA, COOL HAND LUKE, FITZCARRALDO, FORREST GUMP.

  19. 教育情节。这种类型围绕主人公对生活、他人或自我的看法的深刻变化展开，从消极（天真、多疑、宿命论、自我憎恨）转变为积极（明智、信任、乐观、泰然自若）：《哈罗德与莫德》、《温柔的怜悯》、《冬日之光》、《邮差》、《大白鲨》、《我最好朋友的婚礼》、《我们跳舞吧》。

  20. EDUCATION PLOT. This genre arcs on a deep change within the protagonist’s view of life, people, or self from the negative (naive, distrustful, fatalistic, self-hating) to the positive (wise, trusting, optimistic, self-possessed): HAROLD AND MAUDE, TENDER MERCIES, WINTER LIGHT, IL POSTINO, GROSS POINTE BLANK, MY BEST FRIEND’S WEDDING, SHALL WE DANCE.

  21. 幻灭情节。世界观从正面到负面的深刻转变：《帕克夫人与恶性循环》、《蚀》、《火之歌》、《了不起的盖茨比》、《麦克白》。

  22. DISILLUSIONMENT PLOT. A deep change of worldview from the positive to the negative: MRS. PARKER AND THE VICIOUS CIRCLE, L’ECLISSE, LE FEU FOLLET, THE GREAT GATSBY, MACBETH.

有些流派是超级流派，非常庞大和复杂，以至于它们充满了无数的子流派变体：

Some genres are mega-genres, so large and complex that they’re filled with numerous subgenre variations:

12.喜剧。喜剧的子类型包括戏仿、讽刺、情景喜剧、浪漫喜剧、脱口秀喜剧、闹剧和黑色喜剧，所有喜剧类型都因喜剧攻击的重点（官僚愚蠢、上流社会礼仪、青少年求爱等）和嘲讽程度（温和、尖刻、致命）而有所不同。

12. COMEDY. Subgenres range from Parody to Satire to Sitcom to Romantic to Screwball to Farce to Black Comedy, all differing by the focus of comic attack (bureaucratic folly, upper-class manners, teenage courtship, etc.) and the degree of ridicule (gentle, caustic, lethal).

13.犯罪。子类型主要根据对这个问题的回答而有所不同：我们从谁的角度看待犯罪？谋杀悬疑（侦探大师的视角）；犯罪团伙（犯罪大师的视角）；侦探（警察的视角）；黑帮（骗子的视角）；惊悚片或复仇故事（受害者的视角）；法庭（律师的视角）；报纸（记者的视角）；间谍（间谍的视角）；监狱剧（囚犯的视角）；黑色电影（主角的视角可能是部分是罪犯，部分是侦探，部分是蛇蝎美人的受害者）。

13. CRIME. Subgenres vary chiefly by the answer to this question: From whose point of view do we regard the crime? Murder Mystery (master detective’s POV); Caper (master criminal’s POV); Detective (cop’s POV); Gangster (crook’s POV); Thriller or Revenge Tale (victim’s POV); Courtroom (lawyer’s POV); Newspaper (reporter’s POV); Espionage (spy’s POV); Prison Drama (inmate’s POV); Film Noir (POV of a protagonist who may be part criminal, part detective, part victim of a femme fatale).

14.社会剧。这种题材会找出社会中的问题——贫困、教育制度、传染病、弱势群体、反社会叛乱等——然后构建一个展示治愈方法的故事。它有许多重点突出的子类型：家庭剧（家庭内部问题）、女性电影（事业与家庭、情人与孩子之间的两难困境）、政治剧（政治腐败）、生态剧（拯救环境的斗争）、医疗剧（与身体疾病的斗争）和心理剧（与精神疾病的斗争）。

14. SOCIAL DRAMA. This genre identifies problems in society—poverty, the education system, communicable diseases, the disadvantaged, antisocial rebellion, and the like—then constructs a story demonstrating a cure. It has a number of sharply focused subgenres: Domestic Drama (problems within the family), the Woman’s Film (dilemmas such as career versus family, lover versus children), Political Drama (corruption in politics), Eco-Drama (battles to save the environment), Medical Drama (struggles with physical illness), and Psycho-Drama (struggles with mental illness).

15.动作/冒险。这类电影经常借用战争或政治剧等其他题材的元素，以此作为爆发性动作和勇敢行为的动机。如果动作/冒险电影融入了命运、傲慢或精神等概念，它就变成了高冒险的子类型：《王者之战》。如果大自然是对抗的根源，那么它就是一部灾难/生存电影：《生死边缘》、《海神号遇险记》。

15. ACTION/ADVENTURE. This often borrows aspects from other genres such as War or Political Drama to use as motivation for explosive action and derring-do. If ACTION/ADVENTURE incorporates ideas such as destiny, hubris, or the spiritual, it becomes the subgenre High Adventure: THE MAN WHO WOULD BE KING. If Mother Nature is the source of antagonism, it’s a Disaster/Survival Film: ALIVE, THE POSEIDON ADVENTURE.

从更广泛的角度来看，超流派是由包含大量自主流派的场景、表演风格或电影制作技术所创造的。它们就像有许多房间的豪宅，其中一种基本流派、子流派或任何组合都可能在其中找到住所：

Taking a still wider view, supra-genres are created out of settings, performance styles, or filmmaking techniques that contain a host of autonomous genres. They are like mansions of many rooms where one of the basic genres, subgenres, or any combination might find a home:

16.历史剧。历史是故事素材的取之不尽的源泉，涵盖了所有可以想象到的故事类型。然而，历史的宝库却被这样一条警示封住了：过去的事情必须存在于现在。编剧不是希望死后才被发现的诗人。他必须找到今天的观众。因此，历史的最佳利用，以及将电影设定在过去并因此增加数百万美元预算的唯一合法借口，就是时代错误——用过去作为一面透明的镜子，透过它向我们展示现在。

16. HISTORICAL DRAMA. History is an inexhaustible source of story material and embraces every type of story imaginable. The treasure chest of history, however, is sealed with this warning: What is past must be present. A screenwriter isn’t a poet hoping to be discovered after he’s dead. He must find an audience today. Therefore, the best use of history, and the only legitimate excuse to set a film in the past and thereby add untold millions to the budget, is anachronism—to use the past as a clear glass through which you show us the present.

许多当代的对立是如此令人痛苦或充满争议，以至于很难在不疏远观众的情况下在当今的背景下将它们戏剧化。这种困境通常最好在安全的时间距离内观看。历史剧将过去打磨成现在的镜子，清晰而可以忍受《光荣》中的种族主义痛苦问题、《迈克尔·柯林斯》中的宗教冲突或《不可饶恕》中各种暴力行为，尤其是针对妇女的暴力行为。

Many contemporary antagonisms are so distressing or loaded with controversy that it’s difficult to dramatize them in a present-day setting without alienating the audience. Such dilemmas are often best viewed at a safe distance in time. HISTORICAL DRAMA polishes the past into a mirror of the present, making clear and bearable the painful problems of racism in GLORY, religious strife in MICHAEL COLLINS, or violence of all kinds, especially against women, in UNFORGIVEN.

克里斯托弗·汉普顿的《危险关系》：在法国蕾丝袖口和尖刻的俏皮话中设定一个悲观的结局、爱恨交织的故事，这似乎是商业灾难的惯例。但这部电影通过对现代敌对模式的尖锐批评，吸引了大批观众：求爱就像一场战斗，政治上过于敏感，无法直接解决。汉普顿将镜头拉回了两个世纪前的那个时代，在那个时代，性政治爆发为一场争夺性霸权的战争，当时占主导地位的情绪不是爱，而是对异性的恐惧和怀疑。尽管背景陈旧，但几分钟内观众就对腐败的贵族产生了亲密的感觉——他们就是我们。

Christopher Hampton’s DANGEROUS LIAISONS: Setting a down ending, love/hate story in the France of lace cuffs and piquant repartee seemed like protocol for commercial disaster. But the film found a huge audience by turning a scalding light on a mode of modern hostility too politically sensitive to be addressed directly: courtship as combat. Hampton stepped back two centuries to an age in which sexual politics exploded into a war for sexual supremacy, where the ascendant emotion was not love but fear and suspicion of the opposite sex. Despite the antiquated setting, within minutes the audience felt intimately at home with its corrupted aristocrats—they are us.

17.传记。这部历史剧的近亲关注的是人物而非时代。然而，传记绝不能成为简单的编年史。某人的生平、死亡以及其间做过的有趣事情仅具有学术意义，仅此而已。传记作者必须将事实解释为虚构，找到主人公生活的意义，然后把他塑造成他一生流派的主角：年轻的林肯先生在法庭剧中为无辜者辩护；甘地成为现代史诗中的英雄；伊莎多拉屈服于幻灭情节；尼克松在惩罚情节中受苦。

17. BIOGRAPHY. This cousin to Historical Drama focuses on a person rather than an era. BIOGRAPHY, however, must never become a simple chronicle. That someone lived, died, and did interesting things in between is of scholarly interest and no more. The biographer must interpret facts as if they were fiction, find the meaning of the subject’s life, and then cast him as the protagonist of his life’s genre: YOUNG MR. LINCOLN defends the innocent in a Courtroom Drama; GANDHI becomes the hero of a Modern Epic; ISADORA succumbs to a Disillusionment Plot; NIXON suffers in a Punitive Plot.

这些警告同样适用于子类型“自传”。这种习语在那些认为自己应该写一部关于自己熟悉主题的电影的制片人中很流行。这是理所当然的。但自传电影往往缺乏它们所承诺的美德：自我认知。​​因为虽然未经审视的生活不值得过，但同样，没有经历过的生活也不值得审视。例如《大星期三》。

These caveats apply equally to the subgenre Autobiography. This idiom is popular with filmmakers who feel that they should write a film about a subject they know. And rightly so. But autobiographical films often lack the very virtue they promise: self-knowledge. For while it’s true that the unexamined life is not worth living, it’s also the case that the unlived life isn’t worth examining. BIG WEDNESDAY, for example.

18.纪录片。纪录片是历史剧的近亲，它关注的是近期事件而非过去事件。它曾受到真实电影《阿尔及尔之战》的启发，现在已成为一种流行的电视类型，有时很有影响力，但往往缺乏纪实价值。

18. DOCU-DRAMA. A second cousin to Historical Drama, DOCU-DRAMA centers on recent rather than past events. Once invigorated by cinema verite—BATTLE OF ALGIERS—it’s become a popular TV genre, sometimes powerful, but often with little documentary value.

19.伪纪录片。这种类型假装根植于现实或记忆，表现得像纪录片或自传，但其实是彻头彻尾的虚构。它颠覆了基于事实的电影制作，讽刺虚伪的机构：《摇滚万岁》中的摇滚幕后世界；《罗马》中的天主教会；《泽利格》中的中产阶级习俗；《人咬狗》中的电视新闻；《鲍勃·罗伯茨》中的政治；《不惜代价》中的粗俗美国价值观。

19. MOCKUMENTARY. This genre pretends to be rooted in actuality or memory, behaves like documentary or autobiography, but is utter fiction. It subverts fact-based filmmaking to satirize hypocritical institutions: the backstage world of rock ‘n’ roll in THIS IS SPINAL TAP; the Catholic Church in ROMA; middle-class mores in ZELIG; TV journalism in MAN BITES DOG; politics in BOB ROBERTS; crass American values in TO DIE FOR.

20.音乐剧。这种类型源自歌剧，呈现了一种“现实”，剧中人物通过唱歌和跳舞讲述自己的故事。音乐剧通常是爱情故事，但也可以是黑色电影：《日落大道》的舞台改编版；社会剧： 《西区故事》；惩罚性情节：爵士乐；传记：埃维塔。事实上，任何类型的音乐都可以以音乐形式呈现，并且都可以在音乐喜剧中进行讽刺。

20. MUSICAL. Descended from opera, this genre presents a “reality” in which characters sing and dance their stories. It’s often a Love Story, but it can be Film Noir: the stage adaptation of SUNSET BOULEVARD; Social Drama: WEST SIDE STORY; Punitive Plot: ALL THAT JAZZ; Biography: EVITA. Indeed, any genre can work in musical form and all can be satirized in Musical Comedy.

21.科幻小说。科幻小说作家经常将人类对抗国家的现代史诗与动作/冒险结合在一起，这些假想的未来通常是暴政和混乱的技术反乌托邦， 《星球大战》三部曲和《全面回忆》。但是，就像历史一样，未来是任何类型都可以发挥作用的背景。例如，在《SOLARIS》中，安德烈·塔可夫斯基用科幻来演绎幻灭情节的内心冲突。

21. SCIENCE FICTION. In hypothetical futures that are typically technological dystopias of tyranny and chaos, the SCIENCE FICTION writer often marries the man-against-state Modern Epic with Action/Adventure: the STAR WARS trilogy and TOTAL RECALL. But, like history, the future is a setting in which any genre may play. In SOLARIS, for example, Andrei Tarkovsky used sci-fi to act out the inner conflicts of a Disillusionment Plot.

22.体育类型。体育是角色改变的熔炉。这种类型是成熟情节的天然家园：《北达拉斯四十》；救赎情节：《有人喜欢我》；教育情节：《公牛达勒姆》；惩罚情节： 《愤怒的公牛》；测试情节：《烈火战车》；幻灭情节：《长跑者的孤独》；伙伴救赎：《白人不能跳》；社会剧：《红粉联盟》。

22. SPORTS GENRE. Sport is a crucible for character change. This genre is a natural home for the Maturation Plot: NORTH DALLAS FORTY; the Redemption Plot: SOMEBODY UP THERE LIKES ME; the Education Plot: BULL DURHAM; the Punitive Plot: RAGING BULL; the Testing Plot: CHARIOTS OF FIRE; the Disillusionment Plot: THE LONELINESS OF THE LONG DISTANCE RUNNER; Buddy Salvation: WHITE MEN CAN’T JUMP; Social Drama: A LEAGUE OF THEIR OWN.

23.奇幻。作家在这里玩弄时间、空间和物理，扭曲和混合自然法则和超自然现象。奇幻的超现实主义吸引了动作类型，但也欢迎其他类型，例如爱情故事：《时光倒流》；政治剧/寓言：《动物农场》；社会剧：《如果……》；成熟情节：《爱丽丝梦游仙境》。

23. FANTASY. Here the writer plays with time, space, and the physical, bending and mixing the laws of nature and the supernatural. The extra-realities of FANTASY attract the Action genres but also welcome others such as the Love Story: SOMEWHERE IN TIME; Political Drama/Allegory: ANIMAL FARM; Social Drama: IF …; Maturation Plot: ALICE IN WONDERLAND.

24.动画。这里适用普遍变形定律：任何事物都可以变成其他事物。与奇幻和科幻一样，动画倾向于卡通闹剧的动作类型：《兔八哥》；或《冒险奇遇记》：《石中剑》、《黄色潜水艇》；由于青年观众是其天然市场，因此有许多成熟情节：《狮子王》、《小美人鱼》；但正如东欧和日本的动画师所展示的那样，没有任何限制。

24. ANIMATION. Here the law of universal metamorphism rules: Anything can become something else. Like Fantasy and Science Fiction, ANIMATION leans toward the Action genres of cartoon Farce: BUGS BUNNY; or High Adventure: THE SWORD IN THE STONE, THE YELLOW SUBMARINE; and because the youth audience is its natural market, many Maturation Plots: THE LION KING, THE LITTLE MERMAID; but as the animators of Eastern Europe and Japan have shown, there are no restraints.

最后，对于那些认为流派及其惯例只是“商业”作家关注的问题，而严肃艺术是非流派的人们，请允许我在名单上加上一个名字：

Lastly, for those who believe that genres and their conventions are concerns of “commercial” writers only, and that serious art is nongeneric, let me add one last name to the list:

25.艺术电影。先锋派认为，在流派之外写作是幼稚的。没有人在真空中写作。经过数千年的叙事，没有一个故事是如此不同，以至于它与任何其他作品都毫无相似之处。艺术电影已成为一种传统流派，可分为两个子流派，即极简主义和反结构，每个子流派都有自己的结构和宇宙观的形式惯例。与历史剧一样，艺术电影是一种超流派，它涵盖了其他基本流派：爱情故事、政治剧等。

25. ART FILM. The avant-garde notion of writing outside the genres is naive. No one writes in a vacuum. After thousands of years of storytelling no story is so different that it has no similarity to anything else ever written. The ART FILM has become a traditional genre, divisible into two subgenres, Minimalism and Antistructure, each with its own complex of formal conventions of structure and cosmology. Like Historical Drama, the ART FILM is a supra-genre that embraces other basic genres: Love Story, Political Drama, and the like.

虽然这份名单相当全面，但没有任何一份名单是明确或详尽的，因为流派之间的界限经常重叠，因为它们相互影响和融合。流派不是静态或僵化的，而是不断发展和灵活的，但又足够坚固和稳定，可以被识别和使用，就像作曲家演奏音乐流派的可塑性运动一样。

Although this slate is reasonably comprehensive, no list can ever be definitive or exhaustive because the lines between genres often overlap as they influence and merge with one another. Genres are not static or rigid, but evolving and flexible, yet firm and stable enough to be identified and worked with, much as a composer plays with the malleable movements of musical genres.

每位作家的功课都是先确定自己的体裁，然后研究其统治实践。这些任务是无法逃避的。我们都是体裁作家。

Each writer’s homework is first to identify his genre, then research its governing practices. And there’s no escaping these tasks. We’re all genre writers.

结构与体裁的关系

THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN STRUCTURE AND GENRE

每种类型都对故事设计施加了惯例：高潮时的传统价值观念，例如幻灭情节的低谷结局；传统背景，例如西部片；传统事件，例如爱情故事中的男孩遇见女孩；传统角色，例如犯罪故事中的罪犯。观众了解这些惯例并期望看到它们得到实现。因此，类型的选择严格决定并限制了故事中可能发生的事情，因为故事的设计必须预见观众的知识和期望。

Each genre imposes conventions on story design: conventional value-charges at climax such as the down-ending of the Disillusionment Plot; conventional settings such as the Western; conventional events such as boy-meets-girl in the Love Story; conventional roles such as the criminal in a Crime Story. The audience knows these conventions and expects to see them fulfilled. Consequently, the choice of genre sharply determines and limits what’s possible within a story, as its design must envision the audience’s knowledge and anticipations.

流派惯例是定义单个流派及其子流派的特定设置、角色、事件和价值观。

GENRE CONVENTIONS are specific settings, roles, events, and values that define individual genres and their subgenres.

每种类型都有独特的惯例，但有些惯例相对简单易行。幻灭情节的主要惯例是主角在故事开始时充满乐观，抱有崇高的理想或信念，对生活持积极态度。它的第二个惯例是反复出现负面故事转折，这些转折起初可能会激发他的希望，但最终会毒害他的梦想和价值观，使他变得非常愤世嫉俗和幻灭。例如，《窃听大阴谋》的主角一开始生活井然有序，安稳无忧，最后却陷入偏执的噩梦中。这套简单的惯例提供了无数的可能性，因为生活有成千上万条通往绝望的道路。这一类型中许多令人难忘的电影包括《不合群的人》、《甜蜜的生活》和《莱尼》。

Each genre has unique conventions, but in some these are relatively uncomplicated and pliable. The primary convention of the Disillusionment Plot is a protagonist who opens the story filled with optimism, who holds high ideals or beliefs, whose view of life is positive. Its second convention is a pattern of repeatedly negative story turns that may at first raise his hopes, but ultimately poison his dreams and values, leaving him deeply cynical and disillusioned. The protagonist of THE CONVERSATION, for example, begins with an orderly, secure hold on life and ends in a paranoid nightmare. This simple set of conventions offers uncountable possibilities, for life knows a thousand paths to hopelessness. Among the many memorable films in this genre are THE MISFITS, LA DOLCE VITA, and LENNY.

其他类型的电影相对缺乏灵活性，充满了一整套严格的惯例。犯罪类型电影必须有犯罪情节，而且必须在故事叙述的早期就发生。必须有一个侦探角色，无论是专业侦探还是业余侦探，来发现线索和嫌疑人。惊悚片中的罪犯必须“个人化”。尽管故事可能以一个为薪水工作的警察开始，但为了加深戏剧性，在某个时候，罪犯会越界。围绕这一惯例，陈词滥调如真菌般滋生：罪犯威胁警察的家人，或将警察本人变成嫌疑人；或者，像《马耳他之鹰》中陈词滥调一样，他杀死了侦探的搭档。最终，警察必须识别、逮捕并惩罚罪犯。

Other genres are relatively inflexible and filled with a complex of rigid conventions. In the Crime Genre there must be a crime; it must happen early in the telling. There must be a detective character, professional or amateur, who discovers clues and suspects. In the Thriller the criminal must “make it personal.” Although the story may start with a cop who works for a paycheck, to deepen the drama, at some point, the criminal goes over the line. Clichés grow like fungus around this convention: The criminal menaces the family of the cop or turns the cop himself into a suspect; or, cliché of clichés with roots back to THE MALTESE FALCON, he kills the detective’s partner. Ultimately, the cop must identify, apprehend, and punish the criminal.

喜剧也包含无数的子流派，每个子流派都有自己的惯例，但有一个压倒性的惯例将这一巨型流派统一起来，并将其与戏剧区分开来：没有人受伤。在喜剧中，观众必须感觉到，无论角色如何从墙上弹起，无论他们在生活的鞭策下如何尖叫和扭动，都不会真正受到伤害。建筑物可能会倒塌在劳莱和哈代身上，但他们会从废墟中爬起来，拍拍身上的灰尘，喃喃自语，“现在，真是一团糟……”然后他们继续前进。

Comedy contains myriad subgenres as well, each with its own conventions, but one overriding convention unites this mega-genre and distinguishes it from drama: Nobody gets hurt. In Comedy, the audience must feel that no matter how characters bounce off walls, no matter how they scream and writhe under the whips of life, it doesn’t really hurt. Buildings may fall on Laurel and Hardy, but they get up out of the rubble, dust themselves off, mutter, “Now, what a fine mess …” and on they go.

在《一条叫旺达的鱼》中，肯（迈克尔·帕林饰）这个角色对动物有着痴迷，他试图杀死一位老太太，却意外杀死了她养的梗犬。最后一只狗死在一块巨大的建筑砖块下，小爪子还露在外面。导演查尔斯·克莱顿拍摄了这一场景的两个版本：一个版本只显示爪子，而对于第二个版本，他让屠夫去肉店拿了一袋内脏，并添加了一条血迹，血从被压扁的梗犬身上流出。当这一血腥画面在试映观众面前闪过时，影院一片死寂。血和内脏在说：“好痛。”在公映时，克莱顿切换到了经过净化的镜头，引人发笑。按照类型片的惯例，喜剧作家在让角色经历地狱般的折磨与向观众保证火焰不会真正燃烧之间寻找平衡。

In A FISH CALLED WANDA Ken (Michael Palin), a character with an obsessive love of animals, tries to kill an old lady but accidentally kills her pet terriers instead. The last dog dies under a massive construction block with his little paw left sticking out. Charles Crichton, the director, shot two versions of this moment: one showing only the paw, but for the second he sent to a butcher’s shop for a bag of entrails and added a trail of gore draining away from the squashed terrier. When this gory image flashed in front of preview audiences, the theatre fell dead quiet. The blood and guts said: “It hurt.” For general release Crichton switched to the sanitized shot and got his laugh. By genre convention, the comedy writer walks the line between putting characters through the torments of hell while safely reassuring the audience that the flames don’t really burn.

这条线的另一边是黑色喜剧这一分支。在这里，作家打破了喜剧惯例，让观众感受到尖锐但并非无法忍受的痛苦：《挚爱》、《玫瑰战争》、《普里兹的荣誉》——这些电影常常让我们笑得喘不过气来。

Across that line waits the subgenre of Black Comedy. Here the writer bends comic convention and allows his audience to feel sharp, but not unbearable, pain: THE LOVED ONE, THE WAR OF THE ROSES, PRIZZI’S HONOR—films in which laughter often chokes us.

艺术电影因一系列外部惯例而变得传统，例如没有明星（或明星的薪水）、好莱坞体系之外的制作、通常使用英语以外的语言——所有这些都成为卖点，因为营销团队鼓励评论家将电影视为失败者。其主要内部惯例首先是理智的颂扬。艺术电影通过将强烈的情感抑制在情绪之下来偏爱智力，同时通过谜团、象征主义或未解决的紧张关系，它邀请人们在电影结束后的咖啡馆批评仪式中进行解释和分析。其次，也是最根本的，艺术电影的故事设计取决于一个大惯例：非传统性。极简主义和/或反结构的非传统性是艺术电影的特色惯例。

Art Films are conventionalized by a number of external practices such as the absence of stars (or stars’ salaries), production outside the Hollywood system, generally in a language other than English—all of which become sales points as the marketing team encourages critics to champion the film as an underdog. Its primary internal conventions are, first, a celebration of the cerebral. The Art Film favors the intellect by smothering strong emotion under a blanket of mood, while through enigma, symbolism, or unresolved tensions it invites interpretation and analysis in the postfilm ritual of cafe criticism. Secondly and essentially, the story design of an Art Film depends on one grand convention: unconventionality. Minimalist and/or Antistructure unconventionality is the Art Film’s distinguishing convention.

艺术电影类型的成功通常会立即（尽管往往是暂时的）使艺术家获得认可。另一方面，经久不衰的阿尔弗雷德·希区柯克只在大情节和类型惯例内工作，始终以大众观众为目标，并且习惯性地实现了这一目标。然而，今天他站在电影制作人的万神殿之巅，被全世界崇拜为本世纪的主要艺术家之一，电影诗人，其作品以崇高的性意象、宗教信仰和微妙的观点引起共鸣。希区柯克知道艺术与大众成功之间没有必然的矛盾，艺术与艺术电影之间也没有必然的联系。

Success in the Art Film genre usually results in instant, though often temporary, recognition as an artist. On the other hand, the durable Alfred Hitchcock worked solely within the Archplot and genre convention, always aimed for a mass audience, and habitually found it. Yet today he stands atop the pantheon of filmmakers, worshipped worldwide as one of the century’s major artists, a film poet whose works resonate with sublime images of sexuality, religiosity, and subtleties of point of view. Hitchcock knew that there is no necessary contradiction between art and popular success, nor a necessary connection between art and Art Film.

精通流派

MASTERY OF GENRE

我们每个人都对伟大的故事传统心存感激。你不仅要尊重你的流派及其惯例，还要精通它。不要以为你看过你类型的电影就了解它。这就像以为你听过贝多芬的九首交响曲就能谱写交响曲一样。你必须研究这种形式。流派批评的书籍可能会有所帮助，但很少有最新的，也没有一本是完整的。尽管如此，还是要读一切，因为我们需要从任何可能的地方获得帮助。然而，最有价值的见解来自自我发现；没有什么比挖掘宝藏更能激发想象力了。

Each of us owes an enormous debt to the great story traditions. You must not only respect but master your genre and its conventions. Never assume that because you’ve seen films in your genre you know it. This is like assuming you could compose a symphony because you have heard all nine of Beethoven’s. You must study the form. Books of genre criticism may help, but few are current and none is complete. Read everything, nonetheless, for we need all possible help from wherever we can get it. The most valuable insights, however, come from self-discovery; nothing ignites the imagination like the unearthing of buried treasure.

类型研究最好按照以下方式进行：首先，列出所有你认为与你的作品相似的作品，包括成功的和失败的。（对失败的研究很有启发性……也让人谦卑。）接下来，租借视频电影，如果可能的话购买剧本。然后，断断续续地研究电影，随着屏幕翻页，将每部电影分解为背景、角色、事件和价值等元素。最后，将这些分析堆叠在一起，然后仔细查看它们，并问自己：我这个类型的故事总是做什么？它的时间、地点、人物和动作惯例是什么？在你找到答案之前，观众总是走在你前面。

Genre study is best done in this fashion: First, list all those works you feel are like yours, both successes and failures. (The study of failures is illuminating … and humbling.) Next, rent the films on video and purchase the screenplays if possible. Then study the films stop and go, turning pages with the screen, breaking each film down into elements of setting, role, event, and value. Lastly, stack, so to speak, these analyses one atop the other and look down through them all asking: What do the stories in my genre always do? What are its conventions of time, place, character, and action? Until you discover answers, the audience will always be ahead of you.

要预测观众的期待，你必须掌握你的体裁及其惯例。

To anticipate the anticipations of the audience you must master your genre and its conventions.

如果一部电影得到了适当的宣传，观众就会满怀期待地来到影院。用营销专家的行话来说，这部电影已经“定位”了。“定位观众”的意思是：我们不希望观众带着冷漠和模糊的情绪来到我们的作品前，不知道会发生什么，迫使我们花上前二十分钟的屏幕时间向他们提供必要的故事态度。我们希望他们安坐在座位上，热情而专注，并带着我们想要满足的胃口。

If a film has been properly promoted, the audience arrives filled with expectancy. In the jargon of marketing pros, it’s been “positioned.” “Positioning the audience” means this: We don’t want people coming to our work cold and vague, not knowing what to expect, forcing us to spend the first twenty minutes of screen-time clueing them toward the necessary story attitude. We want them to settle into their seats, warm and focused with an appetite we intend to satisfy.

观众定位并不是什么新鲜事。莎士比亚没有将自己的剧作命名为《哈姆雷特》，而是将其命名为《丹麦王子哈姆雷特的悲剧》。他​​给喜剧起名为《无事生非》和《终成眷属》，这样每天下午在环球剧院上演的伊丽莎白时代的观众在心理上都会被设定为哭或笑。

Positioning of the audience is nothing new. Shakespeare didn’t call his play Hamlet; he called it The Tragedy of Hamlet, Prince of Denmark. He gave comedies titles such as Much Ado About Nothing and All’s Well That Ends Well, so that each afternoon at the Globe Theatre his Elizabethan audience was psychologically set to cry or laugh.

巧妙的营销能创造类型期待。从片名到海报，再到印刷品和电视广告，营销旨在将故事类型牢牢地刻在观众的脑海中。在告诉电影观众会期待最喜欢的形式后，我们必须信守承诺。如果我们因忽略或滥用惯例而破坏了类型，观众会立即知道并对我们的作品恶语相向。

Skillful marketing creates genre expectation. From the title to the poster through print and TV ads, promotion seeks to fix the type of story in the mind of the audience. Having told our film-goers to expect a favorite form, we must deliver as promised. If we botch genre by omitting or misusing conventions, the audience knows instantly and badmouths our work.

例如，不幸的标题为《迈克谋杀案》（美国/1984）的营销将观众定位为谋杀悬疑片。然而，这部电影属于另一种类型，观众坐在那里一个多小时都在想，“这部电影里到底是谁死了？”剧本对成熟情节进行了全新的诠释，将德布拉·温格饰演的银行出纳员从依赖和不成熟转变为沉着冷静和成熟。但是，定位错误、困惑的观众的负面口碑让这部原本不错的电影失去了“立足点”。

For example, the marketing of the unfortunately titled MIKE’S MURDER (USA/1984) positioned the audience to a Murder Mystery. The film, however, is in another genre, and for over an hour the audience sat wondering, “Who the hell dies in this movie?” The screenplay is a fresh take on the Maturation Plot as it arcs Debra Winger’s bank teller from dependency and immaturity to self-possession and maturity. But the sour word-of-mouth of a mispositioned and confused audience cut the “legs” out from under an otherwise good film.

创意限制

CREATIVE LIMITATIONS

罗伯特·弗罗斯特曾说过，写自由诗就像打网球，因为诗歌惯例的自我强加、甚至是人为的要求激发了想象力。假设一位诗人任意设定了这个限制：他决定写六行诗节，每隔一行押韵。在第四行与第二行押韵后，他就写完了一节。在逼入困境后，他努力将第六行与第四行和第二行押韵，这可能会激发他想象一个与他的诗毫无关系的词——它恰好押韵——但这个随机的词会突然冒出一个短语，反过来又会让人想起一个画面，一个形象反过来又在前五行中产生共鸣，引发一种全新的感觉和感受，扭曲并推动诗歌产生更丰富的意义和情感。由于诗人对这种押韵方案的创造性限制，这首诗达到了一种强度，如果诗人允许自己自由选择他想要的任何单词，它就会缺乏这种强度。

Robert Frost said that writing free verse is like playing tennis with the net down, for it’s the self-imposed, indeed artificial demands of poetic conventions that stir the imagination. Let’s say a poet arbitrarily imposes this limit: He decides to write in six-line stanzas, rhyming every other line. After rhyming the fourth line with the second line he reaches the end of a stanza. Backed into this corner, his struggle to rhyme the sixth line with the fourth and second may inspire him to imagine a word that has no relationship to his poem whatsoever—it just happens to rhyme—but this random word then springs loose a phrase that in turn brings an image to mind, an image that in turn resonates back through the first five lines, triggering a whole new sense and feeling, twisting and driving the poem to a richer meaning and emotion. Thanks to the poet’s Creative Limitation of this rhyme scheme, the poem achieves an intensity it would have lacked had the poet allowed himself the freedom to choose any word he wished.

创造性限制原则要求在障碍圈内自由发挥。天赋就像肌肉：没有东西可以推动，它就会萎缩。所以我们故意在路上放石头，这些障碍会激发我们的灵感。我们约束自己要做什么，但如何去做却没有限制。因此，我们的第一步是确定支配我们工作的流派或流派组合，因为最富有成效的想法生长的岩石土壤就是流派惯例。

The principle of Creative Limitation calls for freedom within a circle of obstacles. Talent is like a muscle: without something to push against, it atrophies. So we deliberately put rocks in our path, barriers that inspire. We discipline ourselves as to what to do, while we’re boundless as to how to do it. One of our first steps, therefore, is to identify the genre or combination of genres that govern our work, for the stony ground that grows the most fruitful ideas is genre convention.

体裁惯例是讲故事的人的“诗”的押韵方案。它们不会抑制创造力，而是激发创造力。挑战在于保持惯例但避免陈词滥调。爱情故事中男孩与女孩相遇不是陈词滥调，而是形式的必要元素——惯例。陈词滥调是他们相遇的方式就像爱情故事中的恋人相遇的方式一样：两个充满活力的个人主义者被迫一起冒险，似乎一见面就互相憎恨；或者两个害羞的人，每个人都为一个不愿意花时间与他们在一起的人而心生爱意，发现自己被排挤到派对的边缘，没有其他人可以交谈，等等。

Genre conventions are the rhyme scheme of a storyteller’s “poem.” They do not inhibit creativity, they inspire it. The challenge is to keep convention but avoid cliché. That boy meets girl in a Love Story is not a cliché but a necessary element of form—a convention. The cliché is that they meet as Love Story lovers have always met: Two dynamic individualists are forced to share an adventure and seem to hate each other on sight; or two shy souls, each carrying the torch for someone who won’t give them the time of day, find themselves shunted to the edge of a party with no one else to talk to, and so on.

类型惯例是一种创造性限制，它迫使作家的想象力与时俱进。优秀的作家不会否认惯例，让故事变得平淡无奇，而是像老朋友一样利用惯例，他知道，在努力以独特的方式实现惯例的过程中，他可能会找到灵感，创造出超越平凡的场景。通过掌握类型，我们可以引导观众通过丰富、富有创意的惯例变化来重塑和超越期望，不仅给观众他们所希望的东西，如果我们非常优秀的话，还会给观众超出他们想象的东西。

Genre convention is a Creative Limitation that forces the writer’s imagination to rise to the occasion. Rather than deny convention and flatten the story, the fine writer calls on conventions like old friends, knowing that in the struggle to fulfill them in a unique way, he may find inspiration for the scene that will lift his story above the ordinary. With mastery of genre we can guide audiences through rich, creative variations on convention to reshape and exceed expectations by giving the audience not only what it had hoped for but, if we’re very good, more than it could have imagined.

以动作/冒险类小说为例。它常常被认为是无聊的题材，但事实上，它是当今最难写的题材……因为它已经被写烂了。什么是动作类作家观众从未见过的场景？例如，在众多惯例中，最主要的是这一幕：英雄任由坏人摆布。英雄在无助的情况下，必须扭转局势，打败坏人。这一幕是必不可少的。它绝对考验并表达了主角的聪明才智、意志力和在压力下的冷静。没有它，主角和他的故事都会被削弱；观众会不满意地离开。陈词滥调在这个惯例上生长，就像面包上的霉菌一样，但当它的解决方案新颖时，故事会大大增强。

Consider Action/Adventure. Often dismissed as mindless fare, it is in fact the single most difficult genre in which to write today … simply because it’s been done to death. What is an Action writer to do that the audience hasn’t seen a thousand times before? For example, chief among its many conventions is this scene: The hero is at the mercy of the villain. The hero, from a position of helplessness, must turn the tables on the villain. This scene is imperative. It tests and expresses in absolute terms the protagonist’s ingenuity, strength of will, and cool under pressure. Without it both the protagonist and his story are diminished; the audience leaves dissatisfied. Clichés grow on this convention like mold on bread, but when its solution is fresh, the telling is much enhanced.

在《夺宝奇兵》中，印第安纳·琼斯与手持巨大弯刀的埃及巨人面对面。琼斯露出恐惧的表情，然后耸耸肩，迅速射出一颗子弹，因为琼斯想起自己带了枪。幕后传说是哈里森·福特提出了这个广受欢迎的解决方案，因为他患了痢疾，无法参加劳伦斯·卡斯丹编写的杂技打斗。

In RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK, Indiana Jones comes face to face with an Egyptian giant wielding a massive scimitar. A look of terror, then a shrug and a quick bullet as Jones remembers he is carrying a gun. The behind-the-screen legend is that Harrison Ford suggested this much-loved solution because he was too sick with dysentery to take on the acrobatic fight Lawrence Kasdan had scripted.

《虎胆龙威》以这种优雅的惯例演绎达到高潮：约翰·麦克莱恩（布鲁斯·威利斯饰）赤裸上身，手无寸铁，双手高举，与全副武装的虐待狂汉斯·格鲁伯（艾伦·瑞克曼饰）面对面。然而，当镜头慢慢跟踪麦克莱恩时，我们发现他赤裸的后背上绑着一把枪。他用一个笑话分散了格鲁伯的注意力，从他背上夺过枪，杀死了他。

DIE HARD climaxes around this graceful execution of the convention: John McClane (Bruce Willis), stripped to the waist, weaponless, his hands in the air, is face to face with the sadistic and well-armed Hans Gruber (Alan Rickman). Slowly, however, as the camera tracks around McClane we discover that he’s duct-taped a gun to his naked back. He distracts Gruber with a joke, snatches the gun from his back, and kills him.

在所有英雄任由恶棍摆布的陈词滥调中，“小心！有人在你身后！”是最古老的。但在《午夜狂奔》中，编剧乔治·加洛通过一幕又一幕的疯狂变奏赋予了它新的生命和乐趣。

Of all the hero-at-the-mercy-of-the-villain clichés, “Look out! There’s somebody behind you!” is the most archaic. But in MIDNIGHT RUN screenwriter George Gallo gave it new life and delight by riffing lunatic variations in scene after scene.

混合风格

MIXING GENRES

各种类型经常结合在一起，产生共鸣，丰富人物性格，创造各种情绪和情感。例如，爱情故事的次要情节几乎出现在任何犯罪故事中。《渔王》将五条线索——救赎情节、心理剧、爱情故事、社会剧、喜剧——编织成了一部优秀的电影。音乐恐怖片是一项美妙的发明。考虑到二十多种主要类型，创造性的可能性杂交是无穷无尽的。这样，掌握流派的编剧就可能创作出世界上从未见过的电影类型。

Genres are frequently combined to resonate with meaning, to enrich character, and to create varieties of mood and emotion. A Love Story subplot, for example, finds its way inside almost any Crime Story. THE FISHER KING wove five threads—Redemption Plot, Psycho-Drama, Love Story, Social Drama, Comedy—into an excellent film. The Musical Horror Film was a delicious invention. Given over two dozen principal genres, possibilities for inventive cross-breeding are endless. In this way the writer in command of genre may create a type of film the world has never seen.

重塑流派

REINVENTING GENRES

同样，精通流派可以让编剧与时俱进。因为流派惯例并非一成不变，它们会随着社会的变化而发展、成长、适应、修改和突破。社会变化缓慢，但确实在变化，随着社会进入每个新阶段，流派也会随之改变。因为流派只是现实的窗口，是作家看待生活的各种方式。当窗口外的现实发生变化时，流派也会随之改变。否则，如果一种流派变得僵化，无法随着世界的变化而改变，它就会僵化。以下是流派演变的三个例子。

Equally, mastery of genre keeps the screenwriter contemporary. For the genre conventions are not carved in stone; they evolve, grow, adapt, modify, and break apace with the changes in society. Society changes slowly, but it does change, and as society enters each new phase, the genres transform with it. For genres are simply windows on reality, various ways for the writer to look at life. When the reality outside the window undergoes change, the genres alter with it. If not, if a genre becomes inflexible and cannot bend with the changing world, it petrifies. Below are three examples of genre evolution.

西部

The Western

西部片最初是一部以“旧西部”为背景的道德剧，这是一个神话般的黄金时代，善恶对立的寓言。但在 20 世纪 70 年代愤世嫉俗的氛围中，这种类型变得过时和陈旧。当梅尔布鲁克斯的《闪亮的马鞍》揭露了西部片的法西斯主义本质时，这种类型实际上进入了休眠状态二十年，直到通过改变其惯例才卷土重来。在 20 世纪 80 年代，西部片被改编为准社会剧，是对种族主义和暴力的纠正：《与狼共舞》、《不可饶恕》、《团伙》。

The Western began as morality plays set in the “Old West,” a mythical golden age for allegories of good versus evil. But in the cynical atmosphere of the 1970s the genre became dated and stale. When Mel Brooks’s BLAZING SADDLES exposed the Western’s fascist heart, the genre went into virtual hibernation for twenty years before making a comeback by altering its conventions. In the 1980s the Western modulated into quasi-Social Drama, a corrective to racism and violence: DANCES WITH WOLVES, UNFORGIVEN, POSSE.

心理剧

The Psycho-Drama

临床精神病首次被改编为乌发无声电影《卡里加里博士的小屋》（德国/1919 年）。随着精神分析学名声大噪，心理剧逐渐发展成为一种弗洛伊德式的侦探故事。在心理剧的第一阶段，精神科医生扮演“侦探”的角色，调查一桩隐藏的“罪行”，即他的病人过去遭受的深深压抑的创伤。一旦精神科医生揭露了这一“罪行”，受害者要么恢复理智，要么朝着理智迈出了重要一步：《西比尔》、《蛇坑》、《夏娃的三面》、《我从未承诺给你一座玫瑰园、马克、大卫和丽莎、雅科仕。

Clinical insanity was first dramatized in the UFA silent THE CABINET OF DR. CALIGARI (Germany/1919). As psychoanalysis grew in reputation, Psycho-Drama developed as a kind of a Freudian detective story. In its first stage, a psychiatrist played “detective” to investigate a hidden “crime,” a deeply repressed trauma his patient has suffered in the past. Once the psychiatrist exposed this “crime,” the victim was either restored to sanity or took a major step toward it: SYBIL, THE SNAKE PIT, THE THREE FACES OF EVE, I NEVER PROMISED YOU A ROSE GARDEN, THE MARK, DAVID AND LISA, EQUUS.

然而，随着连环杀手开始困扰社会的噩梦，类型演化将心理剧带入了第二阶段，将其与侦探类型合并为被称为心理惊悚片的子类型。在这些类型中，警察变成了追捕精神病患者的普通精神病医生，而逮捕取决于侦探对疯子的心理分析：《第一宗罪》、《人神共愤》、《警察》，以及最近的《七宗罪》。

However, as the serial killer began to haunt society’s nightmares, genre evolution took Psycho-Drama to its second stage, merging it with the Detective Genre into the subgenre known as the Psycho-Thriller. In these cops became lay psychiatrists to hunt down psychopaths, and apprehension hinged on the detective’s psychoanalysis of the madman: THE FIRST DEADLY SIN, MAN-HUNTER, COP, and, recently, SEVEN.

20 世纪 80 年代，心理惊悚片第三次进化。在《走钢丝》、《致命武器》、《天使之心》和《黎明前的早晨》等电影中，侦探本人也变成了精神病患者，患有各种现代疾病——性痴迷、自杀冲动、创伤性失忆症、酗酒。在这些电影中，正义的关键变成了警察对自己的心理分析。一旦侦探接受了内心的恶魔，抓捕罪犯几乎就成了事后的想法。

In the 1980s the Psycho-Thriller evolved a third time. In films such as TIGHTROPE, LETHAL WEAPON, ANGEL HEART, and THE MORNING AFTER, the detective himself became the psycho, suffering from a wide variety of modern maladies—sexual obsession, suicidal impulse, traumatic amnesia, alcoholism. In these films the key to justice became the cop’s psychoanalysis of himself. Once the detective came to terms with his inner demons, apprehending the criminal was almost an afterthought.

这种演变是我们社会变化的有力证明。我们不再能用“所有疯子都被关起来，而我们这些理智的人安全地待在精神病院墙外”这样的想法来安慰自己。如今我们中很少有人如此天真。我们知道，如果发生某些事件，我们也可能与现实背道而驰。这些心理惊悚片讲述了这种威胁，让我们意识到，我们生活中最艰巨的任务是自我分析，因为我们试图理解我们的人性，并为内心的战争带来和平。

This evolution was a telling statement about our changing society. Gone was the day when we could comfort ourselves with the notion that all the crazy people were locked up, while we sane people were safely outside the asylum walls. Few of us are so naive today. We know that, given a certain conjunction of events, we too could part company with reality. These Psycho-Thrillers spoke to this threat, to our realization that our toughest task in life is self-analysis as we try to fathom our humanity and bring peace to the wars within.

到 1990 年，该类型电影进入了第四阶段，再次将精神病患者定位为配偶、精神病医生、外科医生、孩子、保姆、室友、邻里警察。这些电影触及了社会偏执狂，我们发现，我们生活中最亲密的人、我们必须信任的人、我们希望保护我们的人都是疯子：《摇篮之手》、《与敌同眠》、《强行闯入》、《黑暗中的低语》、《单身白人女性》和《好儿子》。也许最能说明问题的是《孽扣》，这是一部关于终极恐惧的电影：对最亲近的人——你自己的恐惧。什么样的恐怖会从你的潜意识中爬出并窃取你的理智？

By 1990 the genre reached its fourth stage by relocating the psychopath once again, now placing him in your spouse, psychiatrist, surgeon, child, nanny, roommate, neighborhood cop. These films tap communal paranoia, as we discover that the people most intimate in our lives, people we must trust, those we hope will protect us, are maniacs: THE HAND THAT ROCKS THE CRADLE, SLEEPING WITH THE ENEMY, FORCED ENTRY, WHISPERS IN THE DARK, SINGLE WHITE FEMALE, and THE GOOD SON. Most telling of all perhaps is DEAD RINGERS, a film about the ultimate fear: the fear of the person closest to you—yourself. What horror will crawl up from your unconscious to steal your sanity?

爱情故事

The Love Story

在写爱情故事时，我们问的最重要的问题是：“是什么阻止了他们？”因为爱情故事中的故事在哪里？两个人相遇、相爱、结婚、组建家庭、互相支持，直到死亡将他们分开……还有什么比这更无聊的呢？因此，自希腊剧作家米南德以来的两千多年来，作家们一直用“女孩的父母”来回答这个问题。女孩的父母认为这个年轻人不合适，并成为所谓的阻碍人物或“反对爱情的力量”的惯例。莎士比亚在《罗密欧与朱丽叶》中将其扩展到双方父母。从公元前2300 年开始，这一基本惯例一直没有改变……直到二十世纪浪漫主义革命爆发。

The most important question we ask when writing a Love Story is: “What’s to stop them?” For where’s the story in a Love Story? Two people meet, fall in love, marry, raise a family, support each other till death do them part … what could be more boring than that? So, for over two thousand years, since the Greek dramatist Menander, writers answered the question with “the parents of the girl.” Her parents find the young man unsuitable and become the convention known as Blocking Characters or “the force opposed to love.” Shakespeare expanded it to both sets of parents in Romeo and Juliet. From 2300 B.C. this essential convention went unchanged … until the twentieth century launched the romantic revolution.

二十世纪是一个前所未有的浪漫时代。浪漫爱情（以性作为其隐含的伴侣）的观念主宰着流行音乐、广告和整个西方文化。几十年来，汽车、电话和其他上千种解放因素让年轻情侣越来越不受父母的控制。与此同时，由于通奸、离婚和再婚的猖獗，父母将浪漫从青春期的放纵延伸到终身追求。年轻人总是不听父母的话，但今天，如果电影中的父母反对，而青少年情侣们真的听从他们的话，观众就会对着银幕大肆嘲笑。因此，随着女方父母的传统和包办婚姻的消失，足智多谋的作家们发现了一系列新的、令人惊叹的反对爱情的力量。

The twentieth century has been an Age of Romance like no other. The idea of romantic love (with sex as its implicit partner) dominates popular music, advertising, and Western culture in general. Over the decades, the automobile, telephone, and a thousand other liberating factors have given young lovers greater and greater freedom from parental control. Meanwhile, parents, thanks to the rampant rise in adultery, divorce, and remarriage, have extended romance from a youthful fling to a lifelong pursuit. It’s always been the case that young people don’t listen to their parents, but today, if a movie Mom and Dad were to object, and the teenage lovers were actually to obey them, the audience would blister the screen with jeers. So, as the-parents-of-the-girl convention faded along with arranged marriages, resourceful writers unearthed a new and amazing array of forces that oppose love.

在《毕业生》中，阻碍角色是女孩的传统父母，但原因却非常不寻常。在《证人》中，阻碍爱情的力量是她的文化——她是阿米什人，几乎来自另一个世界。在《索菲尔太太》中，梅尔·吉布森扮演一名被判绞刑的囚犯杀人犯，黛安·基顿扮演监狱长妻子。是什么阻止了他们？所有成员思想正确”的社会。在《当哈利遇见莎莉》中，恋人们被荒谬的信念所困扰，认为友谊和爱情是不相容的。在《孤星》中，阻碍力量是种族主义；在《哭泣游戏》中，阻碍力量是性别认同；在《幽灵》中，阻碍力量是死亡。

In THE GRADUATE the Blocking Characters were the conventional parents of the girl but for a very unconventional reason. In WITNESS the force that opposes love is her culture—she’s Amish, virtually from another world. In MRS. SOFFEL, Mel Gibson plays an imprisoned murderer condemned to hang and Diane Keaton is the wife of the prison’s warden. What is to stop them? All members of “right-thinking” society. In WHEN HARRY MET SALLY, the lovers suffer from the absurd belief that friendship and love are incompatible. In LONE STAR, the blocking force is racism; in THE CRYING GAME, sexual identity; in GHOST, death.

本世纪初人们对浪漫的热情在接近尾声时已转变为深深的忧郁，随之而来的是人们对爱情的黑暗、怀疑态度。作为回应，我们看到了令人意外的失败结局的兴起和流行：《危险关系》、《廊桥遗梦》、《长日留痕》、《丈夫与妻子》。在《离开拉斯维加斯》中，本是一个有自杀倾向的酒鬼，塞拉是一个受虐狂妓女，他们的爱情“命运多舛”。这些电影表明，人们越来越意识到持久的爱情是无望的，甚至是不可能实现的。

The enthusiasm for romance that opened this century has turned at its close to deep malaise that brings with it a dark, skeptical attitude toward love. In response, we’ve seen the rise and surprising popularity of down-endings: DANGEROUS LIAISONS, THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, THE REMAINS OF THE DAY, HUSBANDS AND WIVES.
