In LEAVING LAS VEGAS, Ben’s a suicidal alcoholic, Sera’s a masochistic prostitute, and their love is “star-crossed.” These films speak to a growing sense of the hopelessness, if not impossibility, of a lasting love.

为了达到颠覆性的结局，一些近期的电影将这一类型改编为渴望故事。男孩遇见女孩一直是电影讲述开头不可或缺的惯例，随后是爱情的考验、磨难和胜利。但《西雅图不眠夜》和《红色》以男孩遇见女孩结束。观众等着看这对恋人的“命运”将如何掌握在机会的手中。通过巧妙地将恋人的相遇推迟到高潮，这些电影用相遇的困难取代了爱情的困难，从而避免了现代爱情的棘手问题。这些不是爱情故事，而是渴望的故事，因为对爱情的谈论和渴望充斥着整个场景，将真正的爱情行为及其往往令人不安的后果留在了屏幕外的未来。也许二十世纪诞生了浪漫时代，然后又埋葬了它。

To achieve an up-ending some recent films have retooled the genre into the Longing Story. Boy-meets-girl has always been an irreducible convention that occurs early in the telling, to be followed by the trials, tribulations, and triumphs of love. But SLEEPLESS IN SEATTLE and RED end on boy-meets-girl. The audience waits to see how the lovers’ “fate” will be shaped in the hands of chance. By cleverly delaying the lovers’ meeting to climax, these films avoid the prickly issues of modern love by replacing the difficulty of love with the difficulty of meeting. These aren’t love stories but stories of longing, as talk about and desire for love fills the scenes, leaving genuine acts of love and their often troubling consequences to happen in an offscreen future. It may be that the twentieth century gave birth to, then buried, the Age of Romance.

教训是：社会态度在变化。作家的文化触角必须对这些变化保持警惕，否则就有写出老套作品的风险。例如：在《坠入爱河》中，阻碍爱情的力量是恋人各自嫁给了别人。观众唯一的眼泪来自打哈欠太厉害。人们几乎可以听到他们的思想在尖叫：“你有什么问题？你嫁给了死板的人。甩掉他们。‘离婚’这个词对你们来说意味着什么吗？”

The lesson is this: Social attitudes change. The cultural antenna of the writer must be alert to these movements or risk writing an antique. For example: In FALLING IN LOVE the force that opposes love is that the lovers are each married to someone else. The only tears in the audience came from yawning too hard. One could almost hear their thoughts screaming, “What’s your problem? You’re married to stiffs. Dump them. Does the word ‘divorce’ mean anything to you people?”

然而，在 20 世纪 50 年代，跨婚姻的爱情被视为痛苦的背叛。许多感人的电影——《陌生人》《相见恨晚》的创作灵感来源于社会对通奸的敌意。但到了 20 世纪 80 年代，人们的态度发生了变化，人们认为爱情如此珍贵，生命如此短暂，如果两个已婚人士想有外遇，那就让他们去做吧。无论对错，这就是当时的风气，因此一部带有 20 世纪 50 年代陈旧价值观的电影让 20 世纪 80 年代的观众感到无聊透顶。观众想知道活在当下的刀刃上是什么感觉。今天做人意味着什么？

Through the 1950s, however, a love affair across marriages was seen as a painful betrayal. Many poignant films—STRANGERS WHEN WE MEET, BRIEF ENCOUNTER—drew their energy from society’s antagonism to adultery. But by the 1980s attitudes had shifted, giving rise to the feeling that romance is so precious and life so short, if two married people want to have an affair, let them. Right or wrong, that was the temperament of the time, so that a film with antiquated 1950s values brutally bored the 1980s audience. The audience wants to know how it feels to be alive on the knife edge of the now. What does it mean to be a human being today?

创新型作家不仅与时代同步，而且富有远见。他们时刻关注历史，随着事物的变化，他们能够感知社会走向未来的方式。然后，他们创作出打破传统的作品，并将这些体裁带入下一代。

Innovative writers are not only contemporary, they are visionary. They have their ear to the wall of history, and as things change, they can sense the way society is leaning toward the future. They then produce works that break convention and take the genres into their next generation.

例如，这是《唐人街》的众多精彩之处之一。在之前所有谋杀悬疑片的高潮中，侦探都会抓获并惩罚罪犯，但《唐人街》中富有且政治上强大的凶手却逍遥法外，打破了一项受人尊敬的惯例。然而，直到 20 世纪 70 年代，民权运动、水门事件和越南战争才使美国意识到其腐败的深度，国家意识到富人确实可以逍遥法外……甚至更多。《唐人街》改写了这一类型，为结局悲观的犯罪故事打开了大门，例如《体热》、《罪与错》、《问答》、《本能》、《最后的诱惑》和《七宗罪》。

This, for example, is one of the many beauties of CHINATOWN. In the climax of all previous Murder Mysteries the detective apprehends and punishes the criminal, but CHINATOWN’s wealthy and politically powerful killer gets away with it, breaking an honored convention. This film could not have been made, however, until the 1970s when the civil rights movement, Watergate, and the Vietnam War woke America up to the depth of its corruption and the nation realized that indeed the rich were getting away with murder … and much more. CHINATOWN rewrote the genre, opening the door to down-ending crime stories such as BODY HEAT, CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS, Q & A, BASIC INSTINCT, THE LAST SEDUCTION, and SEVEN.

最优秀的作家不仅有远见，他们还创作经典。每个流派都涉及重要的人类价值观：爱/恨、和平/战争、正义/非正义、成就/失败、善/恶等等。这些价值观都是永恒的主题，自故事诞生以来就一直激励着伟大的写作。这些价值观必须年复一年地重新塑造，以保持其对当代观众的活力和意义。然而，最伟大的故事总是当代的。它们是经典。经典之所以令人愉悦，是因为它可以在几十年后被重新诠释，因为其中蕴含着如此丰富的真理和人性，每一代新人都能找到自己故事中反映出这一点。《唐人街》就是这样一部作品。汤恩和波兰斯基对这种类型的把握非常到位，他们的才华达到了前所未有的高度。

The finest writers are not only visionary, they create classics. Each genre involves crucial human values: love/hate, peace/war, justice/injustice, achievement/failure, good/evil, and the like. Each of these values is an ageless theme that has inspired great writing since the dawn of story. From year to year these values must be reworked to keep them alive and meaningful for the contemporary audience. Yet the greatest stories are always contemporary. They are classics. A classic is reexperienced with pleasure because it can be reinterpreted through the decades, because in it truth and humanity are so abundant that each new generation finds itself mirrored in the story. CHINATOWN is such a work. With an absolute command of genre Towne and Polanski took their talents to a height few have reached before or since.

忍耐的恩赐

THE GIFT OF ENDURANCE

掌握体裁至关重要，还有一个原因：编剧不是短跑运动员的工作，而是长跑运动员的工作。无论你听说过周末在泳池边匆匆写出的剧本，从最初的灵感到最后的润色稿，一部高质量的剧本需要六个月、九个月、一年甚至更长时间。写一部电影在世界、人物和故事方面需要的创造性劳动与写一部四百页的小说相同。唯一的实质性区别是讲述时使用的单词数量。剧本对语言的精心节俭需要汗水和时间，而用散文填满页面的自由通常会使任务更容易，甚至更快。所有的写作都是纪律，但编剧是一名训练军士。因此，问问自己，是什么会让你的欲望在这几个月里一直燃烧？

Mastery of genre is essential for yet one more reason: Screen-writing is not for sprinters, but for long-distance runners. No matter what you’ve heard about scripts dashed off over a weekend at poolside, from first inspiration to last polished draft, a quality screenplay consumes six months, nine months, a year, or more. Writing a film demands the same creative labor in terms of world, character, and story as a four-hundred-page novel. The only substantive difference is the number of words used in the telling. A screenplay’s painstaking economy of language demands sweat and time, while the freedom to fill pages with prose often makes the task easier, even faster. All writing is discipline, but screenwriting is a drill sergeant. Ask yourself, therefore, what will keep your desire burning over those many months?

一般来说，伟大的作家都不是折衷主义者。他们每个人都把自己的作品紧紧聚焦于一个想法，一个点燃他激情的主题，一个他用一生的时间去追求的主题。例如，海明威就对如何面对死亡这个问题很着迷。在目睹父亲自杀之后，死亡成为了他作品和生活的中心主题。他在战争、体育、狩猎中追逐死亡，直到最后，他把猎枪放进嘴里，找到了死亡。查尔斯·狄更斯的父亲因债务入狱，他在《大卫·科波菲尔》、《雾都孤儿》和《远大前程》中反复描写了孤独的孩子寻找失踪的父亲。莫里哀批判地批判了十七世纪法国的愚蠢和堕落，他以写作为职业，这些剧本的标题读起来就像是人类恶习的清单：《吝啬鬼》、《愤世嫉俗者》、《疑病症患者》。每一位作家都找到了自己的主题，并以此支撑着他漫长的写作历程。

Generally, great writers are not eclectic. Each tightly focuses his oeuvre on one idea, a single subject that ignites his passion, a subject he pursues with beautiful variation through a lifetime of work. Hemingway, for example, was fascinated with the question of how to face death. After he witnessed the suicide of his father, it became the central theme, not only of his writing, but of his life. He chased death in war, in sport, on safari, until finally, putting a shotgun in his mouth, he found it. Charles Dickens, whose father was imprisoned for debt, wrote of the lonely child searching for the lost father over and over in David Copperfield, Oliver Twist, and Great Expectations. Molière turned a critical eye on the idiocy and depravity of seventeenth-century France and made a career writing plays whose titles read like a checklist of human vices: The Miser, The Misanthrope, The Hypochondriac. Each of these authors found his subject and it sustained him over the long journey of the writer.

你的创作风格是什么？你是像海明威和狄更斯一样，直接从自己的生活经历中汲取灵感吗？还是像莫里哀一样，直接写作？您对社会和人性的看法如何？无论您的灵感来源是什么，请留意这一点：在您完成之前，对自我的爱就会腐烂和死亡，对思想的爱就会病态和消亡。您会对写自己或您的想法感到厌倦和厌烦，您可能无法完成比赛。

What is yours? Do you, like Hemingway and Dickens, work directly from the life you’ve lived? Or, like Molière, do you write about your ideas of society and human nature? Whatever your source of inspiration, beware of this: Long before you finish, the love of self will rot and die, the love of ideas sicken and perish. You’ll become so tired and bored with writing about yourself or your ideas, you may not finish the race.

所以，另外，问问自己：我最喜欢的类型是什么？然后写下你喜欢的类型。因为尽管对一个想法或经历的热情可能会消退，但对电影的热爱却是永恒的。类型应该是不断重新激发灵感的源泉。每次重读剧本时，它都应该让你兴奋不已，因为这是你喜欢的故事，是那种你愿意在雨中排队观看的电影。不要因为知识分子朋友认为它具有社会重要性而写一些东西。不要写你认为会激发《电影季刊》批评赞誉的东西。在选择类型时要诚实，因为在所有想要写作的原因中，唯一能长久滋养我们的是对作品本身的热爱。

So, in addition, ask: What’s my favorite genre? Then write in the genre you love. For although the passion for an idea or experience may wither, the love of the movies is forever. Genre should be a constant source of reinspiration. Every time you reread your script, it should excite you, for this is your kind of story, the kind of film you’d stand in line in the rain to see. Do not write something because intellectual friends think it’s socially important. Do not write something you think will inspire critical praise in Film Quarterly. Be honest in your choice of genre, for of all the reasons for wanting to write, the only one that nurtures us through time is love of the work itself.

5

结构与特征

5

STRUCTURE AND CHARACTER

情节还是人物？哪个更重要？这场争论和艺术一样古老。亚里士多德权衡了双方的观点，得出结论：故事是主要的，人物是次要的。他的观点一直占据主导地位，直到小说的发展，舆论的钟摆才摆到了另一边。到了十九世纪，许多人认为结构只是一种用来展示个性的手段，读者想要的是迷人而复杂的人物。今天，双方仍在继续争论，没有定论。陪审团悬而未决的原因很简单：论点似是而非。

Plot or character? Which is more important? This debate is as old as the art. Aristotle weighed each side and concluded that story is primary, character secondary. His view held sway until, with the evolution of the novel, the pendulum of opinion swung the other way. By the nineteenth century many held that structure is merely an appliance designed to display personality, that what the reader wants is fascinating, complex characters. Today both sides continue the debate without a verdict. The reason for the hung jury is simple: The argument is specious.

我们不能问结构和人物哪个更重要，因为结构就是人物，人物就是结构。它们是同一回事，因此一个不可能比另一个更重要。然而，争论仍在继续，因为人们普遍混淆了虚构角色的两个关键方面——人物和人物塑造之间的区别。

We cannot ask which is more important, structure or character, because structure is character; character is structure. They’re the same thing, and therefore one cannot be more important than the other. Yet the argument goes on because of a widely held confusion over two crucial aspects of the fictional role—the difference between Character and Characterization.

性格与人物塑造

CHARACTER VERSUS CHARACTERIZATION

性格是一个人所有可观察品质的总和，所有通过仔细观察就能了解的品质：年龄和智商；性别和性欲；说话和手势的风格；住房、汽车和着装的选择；教育和职业；个性和紧张程度；价值观和态度——我们可以通过日复一日地记录某人来了解人性的所有方面。这些特征的总和每个人都是独一无二的，因为我们每个人都是独一无二的遗传基因和积累的经验的组合。这些独特的特征组合是性格特征……但不是性格。

Characterization is the sum of all observable qualities of a human being, everything knowable through careful scrutiny: age and IQ; sex and sexuality; style of speech and gesture; choices of home, car, and dress; education and occupation; personality and nervosity; values and attitudes—all aspects of humanity we could know by taking notes on someone day in and day out. The totality of these traits makes each person unique because each of us is a one-of-a-kind combination of genetic givens and accumulated experience. This singular assemblage of traits is characterization … but it is not character.

人的本性是在压力之下做出的选择中显露出来的——压力越大，显露得越深刻，选择越符合人物的本质。

TRUE CHARACTER is revealed in the choices a human being makes under pressure—the greater the pressure, the deeper the revelation, the truer the choice to the character’s essential nature.

无论外表如何，在人物塑造的表面之下，这个人究竟是谁？在他的人性深处，我们会发现什么？他是慈爱的还是残忍的？慷慨的还是自私的？坚强的还是软弱的？诚实的还是撒谎的？勇敢的还是懦弱的？了解真相的唯一方法就是亲眼目睹他在压力下做出选择，在追求自己的欲望的过程中采取这样或那样的行动。他选择什么，他就做什么。

Beneath the surface of characterization, regardless of appearances, who is this person? At the heart of his humanity, what will we find? Is he loving or cruel? Generous or selfish? Strong or weak? Truthful or a liar? Courageous or cowardly? The only way to know the truth is to witness him make choices under pressure to take one action or another in the pursuit of his desire. As he chooses, he is.

压力是必不可少的。在没有危险的情况下做出的选择意义不大。如果一个角色在说谎不会给他带来任何好处的情况下选择说实话，那么这个选择就微不足道，那一刻没有任何意义。但如果同一个角色在说谎可以挽救他的生命时坚持说实话，那么我们就会感觉到诚实是他本性的核心。

Pressure is essential. Choices made when nothing is at risk mean little. If a character chooses to tell the truth in a situation where telling a lie would gain him nothing, the choice is trivial, the moment expresses nothing. But if the same character insists on telling the truth when a lie would save his life, then we sense that honesty is at the core of his nature.

想象一下这样的场景：两辆汽车在高速公路上疾驰。一辆是锈迹斑斑的旅行车，车后座放着水桶、拖把和扫帚。开车的是一名非法移民——一个沉默寡言、害羞的女人，靠做佣人赚取私房钱养家糊口。她旁边是一辆崭新的保时捷，车主是一位才华横溢、富有的神经外科医生。这两个人的背景、信仰、性格、语言都截然不同——从各个方面来看，他们的性格特征都截然相反。

Consider this scene: Two cars motor down a highway. One is a rusted-out station wagon with buckets, mops, and brooms in the back. Driving it is an illegal alien—a quiet, shy woman working as a domestic for under-the-table cash, sole support of her family. Alongside her is a glistening new Porsche driven by a brilliant and wealthy neurosurgeon. Two people who have utterly different backgrounds, beliefs, personalities, languages—in every way imaginable their characterizations are the opposite of each other.

突然，在他们面前，一辆载满孩子的校车失控翻滚，撞上地下通道，起火燃烧，困住了车内的孩子。现在，在这种可怕的压力下，我们将发现这两个人的真实身份。

Suddenly, in front of them, a school bus full of children flips out of control, smashes against an underpass, bursting into flames, trapping the children inside. Now, under this terrible pressure, we’ll find out who these two people really are.

谁会选择停车？谁会选择开车经过？每个人都有自己开车经过的理由。女佣担心，如果她如果卷入其中，警察可能会质问她，发现她是非法移民，将她遣返回国，她的家人将挨饿。外科医生担心，如果他受伤，他的手被烧伤，他那双能进行神奇显微手术的手，成千上万的未来患者的生命将因此丧命。但假设他们都踩了刹车，停了下来。

Who chooses to stop? Who chooses to drive by? Each has rationalizations for driving by. The domestic worries that if she gets caught up in this, the police might question her, find out she’s an illegal, throw her back across the border, and her family will starve. The surgeon fears that if he’s injured and his hands burned, hands that perform miraculous microsurgeries, the lives of thousands of future patients will be lost. But let’s say they both hit the brakes and stop.

这个选择给了我们一个关于人物性格的线索，但是谁停下来帮忙，谁又歇斯底里得不敢再开车了？假设他们都选择帮忙。这告诉我们更多信息。但是谁选择通过叫救护车并等待来帮忙？谁选择通过冲进燃烧的公共汽车来帮忙？假设他们都冲向公共汽车——这个选择更深入地揭示了人物性格。

This choice gives us a clue to character, but who’s stopping to help, and who’s become too hysterical to drive any farther? Let’s say they both choose to help. This tells us more. But who chooses to help by calling for an ambulance and waiting? Who chooses to help by dashing into the burning bus? Let’s say they both rush for the bus—a choice that reveals character in even greater depth.

现在，医生和女管家砸碎窗户，爬进燃烧的校车，抓住尖叫的孩子们，并将他们推到安全的地方。但他们的选择还没有结束。很快，火焰就变成了熊熊烈火，他们的脸上皮肤脱落。他们再也呼吸不到空气，否则肺部就会灼伤。在这种恐惧之中，他们意识到只剩下一秒钟来救出车内众多孩子中的一个。医生会如何反应？突然下意识地伸手去救白人孩子还是靠近他的黑人孩子？女管家的本能会带她往哪个方向走？她会救小男孩？还是救跪在她脚下的小女孩？她会如何做出“苏菲的选择”？

Now doctor and housekeeper smash windows, crawl inside the blazing bus, grab screaming children, and push them to safety. But their choices aren’t over. Soon the flames surge into a blistering inferno, skin peels from their faces. They can’t take another breath without searing their lungs. In the midst of this horror each realizes there’s only a second left to rescue one of the many children still inside. How does the doctor react? In a sudden reflex does he reach for a white child or the black child closer to him? Which way do the housekeeper’s instincts take her? Does she save the little boy? Or the little girl cowering at her feet? How does she make “Sophie’s choice”?

我们或许会发现，在这些截然不同的人物性格中，隐藏着相同的人性——他们都愿意为陌生人献出生命。或者，我们原本认为会英勇行事的人其实是个懦夫。或者，我们原本认为会懦弱行事的人其实是个英雄。或者，在最深层次的思考中，我们或许会发现，无私的英雄主义并不是他们两人真正性格的极限。因为他们文化适应的无形力量可能会迫使他们做出自发的选择，从而暴露出他们无意识的性别或种族偏见……即使他们正在做出圣人般的勇敢行为。无论场景如何写，压力之下的选择都会剥去人物塑造的面具，我们将窥视他们的内在本性，并在瞬间洞察到他们真正的性格。

We may discover that deep within these utterly different characterizations is an identical humanity—both willing to give their lives in a heartbeat for strangers. Or it may turn out that the person we thought would act heroically is a coward. Or the one we thought would act cowardly is a hero. Or at rock bottom, we may discover that selfless heroism is not the limit of true character in either of them. For the unseen power of their acculturation may force each to a spontaneous choice that exposes unconscious prejudices of gender or ethnicity … even while they are performing acts of saintlike courage. Whichever way the scene’s written, choice under pressure will strip away the mask of characterization, we’ll peer into their inner natures and with a flash of insight grasp their true characters.

性格揭示

CHARACTER REVELATION

揭示真实性格，与人物塑造形成对比或矛盾，是所有优秀故事叙述的基础。生活教会我们这个伟大的原则：表象并非如此。人并不像他们表面上表现的那样。隐藏在性格特征的背后隐藏着一种隐藏的本性。无论他们说什么，无论他们如何表现自己，我们唯一能够深入了解人物的方式是通过他们在压力下做出的选择。

The revelation of true character in contrast or contradiction to characterization is fundamental to all fine storytelling. Life teaches this grand principle: What seems is not what is. People are not what they appear to be. A hidden nature waits concealed behind a facade of traits. No matter what they say, no matter how they comport themselves, the only way we ever come to know characters in depth is through their choices under pressure.

如果我们被介绍给一个行为举止像“慈爱丈夫”的角色，而故事结束时他仍然像他最初表现的那样，一个没有秘密、没有未实现的梦想、没有隐藏激情的慈爱丈夫，我们会非常失望。当人物塑造和真实人物相匹配时，当内心生活和外表像一块水泥一样，是同一物质时，角色就变成了一串重复的、可预测的行为。并不是说这样的角色不可信。肤浅、没有维度的人是存在的……但他们很无聊。

If we’re introduced to a character whose demeanor is “loving husband,” and by the end of the tale he’s still what he first appeared to be, a loving husband with no secrets, no unfulfilled dreams, no hidden passions, we’ll be very disappointed. When characterization and true character match, when inner life and outer appearance are, like a block of cement, of one substance, the role becomes a list of repetitious, predictable behaviors. It’s not as if such a character isn’t credible. Shallow, nondimensional people exist… but they are boring.

例如：兰博到底出了什么问题？在《第一滴血》中，他是一个引人注目的角色——一个在越南战争中筋疲力尽的孤独者，一个在山间徒步旅行、寻求孤独的人（人物塑造）。后来，一位警长，仅仅因为体内睾丸激素水平极高而激怒了他，于是兰博就出现了，他是一个冷酷无情、势不可挡的杀手（真实人物）。但兰博一旦出现，就不会再回来了。在续集中，他将子弹带绑在涂满油的肌肉上，用红色头巾束起头发，直到超级英雄的人物塑造和真实人物融合成一个比周六早上的卡通片还要缺乏立体感的人物。

For example: What went wrong with Rambo? In FIRST BLOOD he was a compelling character—a Vietnam burnout, a loner hiking through the mountains, seeking solitude (characterization). Then a sheriff, for no reason other than wickedly high levels of testosterone, provoked him, and out came Rambo, a ruthless and unstoppable killer (true character). But once Rambo came out, he wouldn’t go back in. For the sequels, he strapped bandoleers of bullets across his oiled, pumped muscles, coiffed his locks with a red bandanna until super-hero characterization and true character merged into a figure with less dimension than a Saturday morning cartoon.

将这种扁平模式与詹姆斯·邦德进行比较。三部似乎是兰博的极限，但邦德电影已经有近二十部了。邦德不断出现，因为世界喜欢反复揭示与人物性格相矛盾的深刻人物。邦德喜欢扮演花花公子：穿着燕尾服，他出席豪华派对，指尖挂着鸡尾酒杯，和美女聊天。但随后故事压力增大，邦德的选择揭示出在他花花公子外表下是一位有思想的兰博。这部揭露诙谐超级英雄与花花公子性格的影片似乎带来了无穷的乐趣。

Compare that flat pattern to James Bond. Three seems to be the limit on Rambos, but there have been nearly twenty Bond films. Bond goes on and on because the world delights in the repeated revelation of a deep character that contradicts characterization. Bond enjoys playing the lounge lizard: Dressed in a tuxedo, he graces posh parties, a cocktail glass dangling from his fingertips as he chats up beautiful women. But then story pressure builds and Bond’s choices reveal that underneath his lounge lizard exterior is a thinking man’s Rambo. This exposé of witty super-hero in contradiction to playboy characterization has become a seemingly endless pleasure.

进一步阐述这一原则：与人物塑造形成对比或矛盾的是，揭示深层性格是主要角色的根本。次要角色可能需要隐藏的维度，也可能不需要，但主要角色必须深入刻画——他们内心的本质不能和表面上的一样。

Taking the principle further: The revelation of deep character in contrast or contradiction to characterization is fundamental in major characters. Minor roles may or may not need hidden dimensions, but principals must be written in depth—they cannot be at heart what they seem to be at face.

角色弧

CHARACTER ARC

进一步阐述这一原则：最好的写作不仅能揭示真实的性格，而且能在讲述的过程中塑造或改变性格的内在本质，无论好坏。

Taking the principle further yet: The finest writing not only reveals true character, but arcs or changes that inner nature, for better or worse, over the course of the telling.

在《判决》中，男主角弗兰克·加尔文首次以波士顿律师的身份出现，身着三件套西装，看起来像保罗·纽曼……英俊得令人难以置信。大卫·马梅特的剧本随后揭开了这一人物的面纱，揭露了一个腐败、破产、自我毁灭、无可救药的酒鬼，多年来从未打过一场官司。离婚和耻辱摧毁了他的精神。我们看到他在讣告中寻找死于车祸或工伤的人，然后去参加这些不幸者的葬礼，向悲痛的亲属分发他的名片，希望能促成一些保险诉讼。这一幕以醉酒的自我厌恶而达到高潮，他把办公室弄得一团糟，从墙上撕下文凭，摔碎，然后倒在一堆。但接下来是案件。

In THE VERDICT, protagonist Frank Galvin first appears as a Boston attorney, dressed in a three-piece suit and looking like Paul Newman … unfairly handsome. David Mamet’s screenplay then peels back this characterization to reveal a corrupt, bankrupt, self-destructive, irretrievable drunk who hasn’t won a case for years. Divorce and disgrace have broken his spirit. We see him searching obituaries for people who have died in automobile or industrial accidents, then going to the funerals of these unfortunates to pass out his business card to grieving relatives, hoping to drum up some insurance litigation. This sequence culminates in a rage of drunken self-loathing as he trashes his office, rips the diplomas off the walls, and smashes them before collapsing in a heap. But then comes the case.

他提起医疗事故诉讼，为一名昏迷中的女性辩护。如果能尽快和解，他将获得七万美元。但当他看到客户无助的样子时，他意识到这个案子带给他的不是一笔丰厚的轻松费用，而是他最后的救赎机会。他选择与天主教会和政治机构对抗，不仅为客户而战，也为自己的灵魂而战。胜利带来重生。这场法律斗争使他变成了一个清醒、有道德、优秀的律师——就像他失去生存意志之前的那种人一样。

He’s offered a medical malpractice suit to defend a woman lost in a coma. With a quick settlement, he’d make seventy thousand dollars. But as he looks at his client in her helpless state, he senses that what this case offers is not a fat, easy fee, but his last chance for salvation. He chooses to take on the Catholic Church and the political establishment, fighting not only for his client but for his own soul. With victory comes resurrection. The legal battle changes him into a sober, ethical, and excellent attorney—the kind of man he once was before he lost his will to live.

这是小说史上常见的人物与结构之间的博弈。首先，故事展现了主人公的性格特征：哈姆雷特从大学回家参加父亲的葬礼，心情忧郁而困惑，希望父亲死去：“哦，但愿这太过坚实的肉体融化……”

This is the play between character and structure seen throughout the history of fiction. First, the story lays out the protagonist’s characterization: Home from the university for the funeral of his father, Hamlet is melancholy and confused, wishing he were dead: “Oh, that this too too solid flesh would melt…”

其次，我们很快就被引向了人物的内心。当他选择采取一项行动而不是另一项行动时，他的真实本性就显露出来了：哈姆雷特父亲的鬼魂声称他是被哈姆雷特的叔叔克劳迪斯谋杀的，而克劳迪斯现在已经成为了国王。哈姆雷特的选择暴露了他非常聪明和谨慎的性格，他努力抑制自己鲁莽、热情的幼稚。他决定寻求报复，但要等到他能证明国王有罪后才会这么做：“我会说出尖刻的话……但不会用。”

Second, we’re soon led into the heart of the character. His true nature is revealed as he chooses to take one action over another: The ghost of Hamlet’s father claims he was murdered by Hamlet’s uncle, Claudius, who has now become king. Hamlet’s choices expose a highly intelligent and cautious nature battling to restrain his rash, passionate immaturity. He decides to seek revenge, but not until he can prove the King’s guilt: “I will speak daggers … but use none.”

第三，这种深沉的性格与人物的外表不符，与其形成对比，甚至相互矛盾。我们感觉到他并不像他表面上表现的那样。他不仅仅是悲伤、敏感和谨慎。他的性格下还隐藏着其他品质。哈姆雷特：“我只是一个疯狂的西北人；当风吹向南方时，我能分辨出鹰和手锯。”

Third, this deep nature is at odds with the outer countenance of the character, contrasting with it, if not contradicting it. We sense that he is not what he appears to be. He’s not merely sad, sensitive, and cautious. Other qualities wait hidden beneath his persona. Hamlet: “I am but mad north-north-west; when the wind is southerly I know a hawk from a handsaw.”

第四，在揭露了人物的内心本质后，故事给他施加了越来越大的压力，迫使他做出越来越艰难的选择：哈姆雷特追捕杀害他父亲的凶手，发现他跪在地上祈祷。他可以轻易杀死国王，但哈姆雷特意识到，如果克劳迪斯在祈祷中死去，他的灵魂可能会升入天堂。因此，哈姆雷特强迫自己等到国王的灵魂“像地狱一样邪恶黑暗”时再杀死克劳迪斯。

Fourth, having exposed the character’s inner nature, the story puts greater and greater pressure on him to make more and more difficult choices: Hamlet hunts for his father’s killer and finds him on his knees in prayer. He could easily kill the King, but Hamlet realizes that if Claudius dies in prayer, his soul might go to heaven. So Hamlet forces himself to wait and kill Claudius when the King’s soul is “as damned and black as Hell whereto it goes.”

第五，到了故事的高潮，这些选择深刻地改变了人物的人性：哈姆雷特的战争，无论是已知的还是未知的，都结束了。随着他活泼的才智逐渐成熟为智慧，他达到了平静的成熟：“剩下的就是沉默。”

Fifth, by the climax of the story, these choices have profoundly changed the humanity of the character: Hamlet’s wars, known and unknown, come to an end. He reaches a peaceful maturity as his lively intelligence ripens into wisdom: “The rest is silence.”

结构和角色功能

STRUCTURE AND CHARACTER FUNCTIONS

结构的作用是提供逐渐增强的压力，迫使角色陷入越来越困难的困境，他们必须做出越来越困难的冒险选择和行动，逐渐揭示他们的本性，甚至深入到潜意识中。

The function of STRUCTURE is to provide progressively building pressures that force characters into more and more difficult dilemmas where they must make more and more difficult risk-taking choices and actions, gradually revealing their true natures, even down to the unconscious self.

人物的作用是为故事赋予人物塑造的品质，以便令人信服地演绎出人物的选择。简而言之，人物必须可信：足够年轻或足够年老、强大或软弱、世故或天真、受过教育或无知、慷慨或自私、机智或愚笨，比例恰当。每个人物都必须为故事赋予各种品质，让观众相信该人物能够并且会做他所做的事情。

The function of CHARACTER is to bring to the story the qualities of characterization necessary to convincingly act out choices. Put simply, a character must be credible: young enough or old enough, strong or weak, worldly or naive, educated or ignorant, generous or selfish, witty or dull, in the right proportions. Each must bring to the story the combination of qualities that allows an audience to believe that the character could and would do what he does.

结构和角色是相互关联的。故事的事件结构是由角色在压力下做出的选择和他们选择采取的行动所创造的，而角色则是通过他们在压力下选择如何行动而展现和改变的生物。如果你改变一个，你就会改变另一个。如果你改变事件设计，你也会改变角色；如果你改变深层角色，你必须重新设计结构来表达角色改变的性质。

Structure and character are interlocked. The event structure of a story is created out of the choices that characters make under pressure and the actions they choose to take, while characters are the creatures who are revealed and changed by how they choose to act under pressure. If you change one, you change the other. If you change event design, you have also changed character; if you change deep character, you must reinvent the structure to express the character’s changed nature.

假设一个故事包含一个关键事件，主人公冒着极大的风险选择说实话。但作者觉得初稿不行。在重写时研究这个场景时，他决定让角色撒谎，并通过反转该动作来改变故事设计。从一稿到下一稿，主人公的性格特征保持不变——他穿着相同的衣服，做着相同的工作，对相同的笑话大笑。但在第一稿中，他是一个诚实的人。在第二稿中，他是一个骗子。通过反转事件，作者创造了一个全新的角色。

Suppose a story contains a pivotal event in which the protagonist, at serious risk, chooses to tell the truth. But the writer feels the first draft doesn’t work. While studying this scene in the rewrite, he decides that his character would lie and changes his story design by reversing that action. From one draft to the next the protagonist’s characterization remains intact—he dresses the same, works the same job, laughs at the same jokes. But in the first draft he’s an honest man. In the second, a liar. With the inversion of an event the writer creates a wholly new character.

另一方面，假设这个过程是这样的：作家突然洞察到主人公的性格，启发他勾勒出一个全新的心理轮廓，把一个诚实的人变成一个骗子。为了表达一个完全改变的性格，作家要做的远不止重新塑造角色的性格。黑色幽默可能会增加质感，但会永远不够。如果故事保持不变，人物也保持不变。如果作家重塑人物，他就必须重塑故事。改变的人物必须做出新的选择，采取不同的行动，并经历另一个故事——他的故事。无论我们的直觉是通过人物还是结构发挥作用，它们最终都会在同一个地方相遇。

Suppose, on the other hand, the process takes this path: The writer has a sudden insight into his protagonist’s nature, inspiring him to sketch out a radically new psychological profile, transforming an honest man into a liar. To express a wholly changed nature the writer will have to do far more than rework the character’s traits. A dark sense of humor might add texture but would never be enough. If story stays the same, character stays the same. If the writer reinvents character, he must reinvent story. A changed character must make new choices, take different actions, and live another story—his story. Whether our instincts work through character or structure, they ultimately meet at the same place.

因此，“角色驱动的故事”这一短语是多余的。所有的故事都是“角色驱动的”。事件设计和角色设计是相互映照的。角色无法通过故事设计来深入表达。

For this reason the phrase “character-driven story” is redundant. All stories are “character-driven.” Event design and character design mirror each other. Character cannot be expressed in depth except through the design of story.

关键在于适当性。

The key is appropriateness.

人物的相对复杂性必须与类型相适应。动作/冒险和闹剧要求人物简单，因为复杂性会分散我们对这些类型必不可少的勇敢行为或失误的注意力。诸如教育和救赎情节之类的个人和内心冲突的故事要求人物复杂，因为简单会剥夺我们对这些类型所必需的人性的洞察力。这是常识。那么“人物驱动”到底是什么意思呢？对于太多作家来说，它意味着“人物塑造驱动”，薄如纸的肖像画，其中面具可能刻画得很好，但深层人物却没有得到充分发展和表达。

The relative complexity of character must be adjusted to genre. Action/Adventure and Farce demand simplicity of character because complexity would distract us from the derring-do or pratfalls indispensable to those genres. Stories of personal and inner conflict, such as Education and Redemption Plots, demand complexity of character because simplicity would rob us of the insight into human nature requisite to those genres. This is common sense. So what does “character-driven” really mean? For too many writers it means “characterization driven,” tissue-thin portraiture in which the mask may be well drawn but deep character is left underdeveloped and unexpressed.

高潮与人物

CLIMAX AND CHARACTER

结构和人物的交织似乎是对称的，直到我们遇到结局问题。好莱坞有一句备受推崇的格言警告说：“电影是关于最后二十分钟的。”换句话说，一部电影要想在世界上有一席之地，最后一幕和高潮必须是最令人满意的体验。因为无论前九十分钟取得了什么成就，如果最后一幕失败了，这部电影就会在首映周末就夭折。

The interlock of structure and character seems neatly symmetrical until we come to the problem of endings. A revered Hollywood axiom warns: “Movies are about their last twenty minutes.” In other words, for a film to have a chance in the world, the last act and its climax must be the most satisfying experience of all. For no matter what the first ninety minutes have achieved, if the final movement fails, the film will die over its opening weekend.

比较两部电影：在《盲目约会》的前 80 分钟里，金·贝辛格和布鲁斯·威利斯在这场闹剧中大展身手，引得观众笑声不断。但随着第二幕的高潮，所有的笑声都消失了，第三幕也变得平淡无奇，原本应该大获成功的东西却落空了。另一方面，《蜘蛛女之吻》影片以乏味的三四十分钟开场，但逐渐地，影片将我们深深地吸引进去，节奏也逐渐加快，直到故事高潮打动了我们，很少有戏剧能做到这一点。八点钟时感到无聊的观众在十点钟时却兴高采烈。口碑让这部电影有了立足之地；美国电影艺术与科学学院将奥斯卡奖颁给了威廉·赫特。

Compare two films: For the first eighty minutes of BLIND DATE Kim Basinger and Bruce Willis careened through this farce, exploding laugh after laugh. But with the Act Two climax all laughter ceased, Act Three fell flat, and what should have been a hit went south. KISS OF THE SPIDER WOMAN, on the other hand, opened with a tedious thirty or forty minutes, but gradually the film drew us into deep involvement and built pace until the Story Cimax moved us as few dramas do. Audiences who were bored at eight o’clock were elated at ten o’clock. Word-of-mouth gave the film legs; the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences voted William Hurt an Oscar.

故事是生活的隐喻，而生活是在时间中度过的。因此，电影是时间艺术，而不是造型艺术。我们的表亲不是绘画、雕塑、建筑或静态摄影的空间媒介，而是音乐、舞蹈、诗歌和歌曲的时间形式。所有时间艺术的第一条戒律是：你应该把最好的留到最后。芭蕾舞的最后一乐章、交响乐的尾声、十四行诗的对句、最后一幕及其故事高潮——这些高潮时刻一定是最令人满意、最有意义的体验。

Story is metaphor for life and life is lived in time. Film, therefore, is temporal art, not plastic art. Our cousins are not the spacial media of painting, sculpture, architecture, or still photography, but the temporal forms of music, dance, poetry, and song. And the first commandment of all temporal art is: Thou shalt save the best for last. The final movement of a ballet, the coda of a symphony, the couplet of a sonnet, the last act and its Story Climax—these culminating moments must be the most gratifying, meaningful experiences of all.

显然，一部完成的剧本代表了作者 100% 的创作劳动。这项工作的绝大部分，也就是我们 75% 或更多的努力，都用于设计深刻人物与事件的构思和安排之间的联系。对话和描述的写作消耗了剩下的时间。在设计故事所投入的巨大努力中，75% 都集中在创造最后一幕的高潮上。故事的最终事件是作家的最终任务。

A finished screenplay represents, obviously, 100 percent of its author’s creative labor. The vast majority of this work, 75 percent or more of our struggles, goes into designing the interlock of deep character to the invention and arrangement of events. The writing of dialogue and description consumes what’s left. And of the overwhelming effort that goes into designing story, 75 percent of that is focused on creating the climax of the last act. The story’s ultimate event is the writer’s ultimate task.

吉恩·福勒曾经说过，写作很简单，只要盯着空白的纸张，直到额头流血即可。如果有什么能让你额头流血的话，那就是创造最后一幕的高潮——所有意义和情感的顶峰和集中，所有其他准备工作都是为了实现这一目标，是观众满意度的决定性中心。如果这一幕失败了，故事就失败了。在你创造它之前，你没有故事。如果你未能诗意地跃升到辉煌的高潮，所有之前的场景、人物、对话和描述都将成为复杂的打字练习。

Gene Fowler once said that writing is easy, just a matter of staring at the blank page until your forehead bleeds. And if anything will draw blood from your forehead, it’s creating the climax of the last act—the pinnacle and concentration of all meaning and emotion, the fulfillment for which all else is preparation, the decisive center of audience satisfaction. If this scene fails, the story fails. Until you have created it, you don’t have a story. If you fail to make the poetic leap to a brilliant culminating climax, all previous scenes, characters, dialogue, and description become an elaborate typing exercise.

假设你某天早上醒来，突然有灵感写下这个故事的高潮：“英雄和恶棍在莫哈维沙漠徒步追逐对方三天三夜。脱水、疲惫和精神错乱的边缘，距离最近的水源有一百英里，他们打斗起来，一个杀死了另一个。”这很刺激……直到你回头看你的主角，想起他是一个 75 岁的退休会计师，拄着拐杖，对灰尘过敏。他会把你的悲剧高潮变成一个笑话。更糟糕的是，你的经纪人告诉你，沃尔特·马修想在你把结局整理好后立即扮演他。你会怎么做？

Suppose you were to wake up one morning with the inspiration to write this Story Climax: “Hero and villain pursue each other on foot for three days and three nights across the Mojave Desert. On the brink of dehydration, exhaustion, and delirium, a hundred miles from the nearest water, they fight it out and one kills the other.” It’s thrilling … until you look back at your protagonist and remember that he’s a seventy-five-year-old retired accountant, hobbled on crutches and allergic to dust. He’d turn your tragic climax into a joke. What’s worse, your agent tells you Walter Matthau wants to play him as soon as you get the ending sorted out. What do you do?

找到介绍主角的那一页，在上面找到描述短语“杰克（75）”，然后删除 7，插入 3。换句话说，重新塑造人物。深刻的人物性格保持不变，因为无论杰克是三十五岁还是七十五岁，他仍然有意志和毅力在莫哈韦沙漠中挑战极限。但你必须让他可信。

Find the page where the protagonist is introduced, on it locate the phrase of description that reads “Jake (75)”, then delete 7, insert 3. In other words, rework characterization. Deep character remains unchanged because whether Jake is thirty-five or seventy-five, he still has the will and tenacity to go to the limit in the Mojave. But you must make him credible.

1924 年，埃里希·冯·施特罗海姆拍摄了《贪婪》。影片的高潮部分在莫哈维沙漠上演了三天三夜，英雄与反派的对决由此展开。冯·施特罗海姆在盛夏的莫哈维沙漠拍摄了这个片段，当时气温高达 130 华氏度以上。他差点杀死了所有演员和工作人员，但他得到了他想要的：一片白茫茫的盐碱地延伸到地平线。在烈日下，英雄和反派扭打在一起，皮肤干裂，如同沙漠地面。在搏斗中，反派抓起一块石头砸进了英雄的头骨。但当英雄死去时，在他意识的最后一刻，他设法伸出手将自己铐在了杀手身上。在最后的画面中，反派倒在尘土中，被锁在他刚刚杀死的尸体上。

In 1924 Erich von Stroheim made GREED. Its climax plays out over three days and three nights, hero and villain, across the Mojave Desert. Von Stroheim shot this sequence in the Mojave in high summer with temperatures rising to over 130 degrees Fahrenheit. He almost killed his cast and crew, but he got what he wanted: a white-on-white landscape of vast salt wastes extending to the horizon. Under the scorching sun, hero and villain, skin cracked and parched like the desert floor, grapple. In the struggle the villain grabs a rock and smashes in the skull of the hero. But as the hero dies, in his last moment of consciousness, he manages to reach up and handcuff himself to his killer. In the final image the villain collapses in the dust chained to the corpse he just killed.

《贪婪》的精彩结局是由深刻刻画人物的终极选择所创造的。任何破坏这种行为可信度的人物塑造方面都必须牺牲。正如亚里士多德所说，情节比人物塑造更重要，但故事结构和真实人物是从两个角度看待的一种现象。人物在外在面具后面做出的选择同时塑造了他们的内在本质并推动了故事的发展。从俄狄浦斯王到福斯塔夫，从安娜卡列尼娜到吉姆老爷，从希腊人佐巴到塞尔玛和路易丝，这就是完美故事讲述的人物/结构动态。

GREED’s brilliant ending is created out of ultimate choices that profoundly delineate its characters. Any aspect of characterization that undermines the credibility of such an action must be sacrificed. Plot, as Aristotle noted, is more important than characterization, but story structure and true character are one phenomenon seen from two points of view. The choices that characters make from behind their outer masks simultaneously shape their inner natures and propel the story. From Oedipus Rex to Falstaff, from Anna Karenina to Lord Jim, from Zorba the Greek to Thelma and Louise, this is the character/structure dynamic of consummate storytelling.

6

结构和含义

6

STRUCTURE AND MEANING

审美情感

AESTHETIC EMOTION

亚里士多德是这样看待故事和意义的：他问道，为什么我们在街上看到一具尸体时会有一种反应，而当我们在荷马史诗中读到死亡或在剧院看到死亡时，我们却有另一种反应？因为在生活中，思想和情感是分开出现的。思想和激情在我们人类的不同领域中运转，很少协调，通常相互矛盾。

Aristotle approached the question of story and meaning in this way: Why is it, he asked, when we see a dead body in the street we have one reaction, but when we read of death in Homer, or see it in the theatre, we have another? Because in life idea and emotion come separately. Mind and passions revolve in different spheres of our humanity, rarely coordinated, usually at odds.

生活中，如果你在街上看到一具尸体，你会感到肾上腺素激增：“天哪，他死了！”也许你会害怕地开车离开。后来，在冷静下来之后，你可能会反思这个陌生人死亡的意义，反思你自己的死亡，反思在死亡阴影下的生活。这种沉思可能会改变你的内心，这样当你下次面对死亡时，你就会有一个全新的、也许更富有同情心的反应。或者，反过来说，你可能在年轻时对爱情进行了深刻但不明智的思考，怀抱一种理想主义的幻想，让你陷入一段凄美而痛苦的爱情。这可能会使你的心变得冷酷，成为一个愤世嫉俗的人，在晚年会发现年轻人仍然认为甜蜜的东西是苦涩的。

In life, if you see a dead body in the street, you’re struck by a rush of adrenaline: “My God, he’s dead!” Perhaps you drive away in fear. Later, in the coolness of time, you may reflect on the meaning of this stranger’s demise, on your own mortality, on life in the shadow of death. This contemplation may change you within so that the next time you are confronted with death, you have a new, perhaps more compassionate reaction. Or, reversing the pattern, you may, in youth, think deeply but not wisely about love, embracing an idealistic vision that trips you into a poignant but very painful romance. This may harden the heart, creating a cynic who in later years finds bitter what the young still think sweet.

你的智力生活让你做好了应对情感体验的准备，而情感体验会促使你产生新的感知，进而重新融合新遭遇的化学反应。这两个领域相互影响，但先影响一个，然后影响另一个。事实上，在生活中，思想和情感融合在一起的时刻非常罕见，当它们发生时你认为自己正在经历一种宗教体验。但生活将意义与情感分开，而艺术将它们统一起来。故事是一种工具，你可以利用它随心所欲地创造这种顿悟，这种现象被称为审美情感。

Your intellectual life prepares you for emotional experiences that then urge you toward fresh perceptions that in turn remix the chemistry of new encounters. The two realms influence each other, but first one, then the other. In fact, in life, moments that blaze with a fusion of idea and emotion are so rare, when they happen you think you’re having a religious experience. But whereas life separates meaning from emotion, art unites them. Story is an instrument by which you create such epiphanies at will, the phenomenon known as aesthetic emotion.

所有艺术的源头都是人类心灵的原始需求，即通过美与和谐解决压力与不和谐，利用创造力来重振因循守旧而麻木的生活，通过本能的感官感受与现实建立联系。就像音乐和舞蹈、绘画和雕塑、诗歌和歌曲一样，故事是审美情感的体验，是思想与情感同时相遇。

The source of all art is the human psyche’s primal, prelinguistic need for the resolution of stress and discord through beauty and harmony, for the use of creativity to revive a life deadened by routine, for a link to reality through our instinctive, sensory feel for the truth. Like music and dance, painting and sculpture, poetry and song, story is first, last, and always the experience of aesthetic emotion—the simultaneous encounter of thought and feeling.

当一个想法包裹着一种情感冲击时，它会变得更加强大、更加深刻、更加令人难忘。你可能会忘记在街上看到一具尸体的那一天，但哈姆雷特的死会永远困扰着你。如果没有艺术来塑造它，生活本身会让你陷入困惑和混乱，但审美情感会将你所知道的与你所感受到的相协调，让你提高意识，确定你在现实中的位置。简而言之，一个讲得好的故事会给你生活中无法得到的东西：有意义的情感体验。在生活中，经历随着时间的反思而变得有意义。在艺术中，它们现在就有意义，在它们发生的那一刻。

When an idea wraps itself around an emotional charge, it becomes all the more powerful, all the more profound, all the more memorable. You might forget the day you saw a dead body in the street, but the death of Hamlet haunts you forever. Life on its own, without art to shape it, leaves you in confusion and chaos, but aesthetic emotion harmonizes what you know with what you feel to give you a heightened awareness and a sureness of your place in reality. In short, a story well told gives you the very thing you cannot get from life: meaningful emotional experience. In life, experiences become meaningful with reflection in time. In art, they are meaningful now, at the instant they happen.

从这个意义上说，故事本质上是非智力的。它不会以枯燥、智力的论文论证来表达思想。但这并不是说故事是反智力的。我们祈祷作家有重要和深刻的思想。相反，艺术家和观众之间的交流直接通过感官和知觉、直觉和情感来表达思想。它不需要中介，不需要批评家来合理化交易，用解释和抽象来取代不可言喻和有知觉的东西。学术敏锐性可以提高品味和判断力，但我们绝不能把批评误认为是艺术。智力分析，无论多么令人兴奋，都不会滋养灵魂。

In this sense, story is, at heart, nonintellectual. It does not express ideas in the dry, intellectual arguments of an essay. But this is not to say story is anti-intellectual. We pray that the writer has ideas of import and insight. Rather, the exchange between artist and audience expresses idea directly through the senses and perceptions, intuition and emotion. It requires no mediator, no critic to rationalize the transaction, to replace the ineffable and the sentient with explanation and abstraction. Scholarly acumen sharpens taste and judgment, but we must never mistake criticism for art. Intellectual analysis, however heady, will not nourish the soul.

一个讲得好的故事既不会表达论点的机械推理，也不会发泄愤怒的初生情感。它成功地将理性与非理性结合在一起。因为一部本质上是情感的或本质上是智力的作品不可能具有它激发我们的同情心、同理心、预感、洞察力......以及我们对真理的天生敏感性。

A well-told story neither expresses the clockwork reasonings of a thesis nor vents raging inchoate emotions. It triumphs in the marriage of the rational with the irrational. For a work that’s either essentially emotional or essentially intellectual cannot have the validity of one that calls upon our subtler faculties of sympathy, empathy, premonition, discernment … our innate sensitivity to the truth.

前提

PREMISE

两个思想组成了创作过程：前提，即激发作者创作故事欲望的思想；主控思想，即通过最后一幕高潮的动作和审美情感表达出的故事的最终意义。然而，前提与主控思想不同，它很少是一个封闭的陈述。更可能是一个开放式的问题：如果……会发生什么？如果鲨鱼游进海滩度假村并吞噬了度假者，会发生什么？大白鲨。如果妻子抛弃丈夫和孩子，会发生什么？克莱默夫妇。斯坦尼斯拉夫斯基称之为“魔力如果……”，这种白日梦般的假设浮现在脑海中，打开了想象之门，在那里一切皆有可能。

Two ideas bracket the creative process: Premise, the idea that inspires the writer’s desire to create a story, and Controlling Idea, the story’s ultimate meaning expressed through the action and aesthetic emotion of the last act’s climax. A Premise, however, unlike a Controlling Idea, is rarely a closed statement. More likely, it’s an open-ended question: What would happen if … ? What would happen if a shark swam into a beach resort and devoured a vacationer? JAWS. What would happen if a wife walked out on her husband and child? KRAMER VS. KRAMER. Stanislavski called this the “Magic if …,” the daydreamy hypothetical that floats through the mind, opening the door to the imagination where everything and anything seems possible.

但“如果……会发生什么”只是前提的一种。作家们可以从任何地方找到灵感——朋友对黑暗欲望的轻松告白、无腿乞丐的嘲讽、噩梦或白日梦、报纸上的事实、孩子的幻想。甚至写作技巧本身也可能激发灵感。纯粹的技术练习，例如将一个场景与下一个场景流畅地衔接起来或编辑对话以避免重复，可能会引发想象力的爆发。任何事情都可能成为写作的前提，例如，向窗外瞥一眼。

But “What would happen if …” is only one kind of Premise. Writers find inspiration wherever they turn—in a friend’s light-hearted confession of a dark desire, the jibe of a legless beggar, a nightmare or daydream, a newspaper fact, a child’s fantasy. Even the craft itself may inspire. Purely technical exercises, such as linking a smooth transition from one scene to the next or editing dialogue to avoid repetition, may trigger a burst of imagination. Anything may premise the writing, even, for example, a glance out a window.

1965 年，英格玛·伯格曼患上了迷路炎，这是一种病毒性内耳感染，患者即使在睡觉时也会持续感到眩晕。数周以来，伯格曼卧床不起，头部戴着支架，他一直盯着医生在天花板上画的一个点，试图控制眩晕，但每次他把目光移开，房间就会像陀螺一样旋转。他把注意力集中在那个点上，开始想象两张脸交织在一起。几天后，当他康复时，他透过窗户瞥了一眼，看到一名护士和一名病人坐在一起比较手。这些画面、护士/病人的关系和交织的面孔，是伯格曼杰作《假面》的灵感来源。

In 1965 Ingmar Bergman contracted labyrinthitis, a viral infection of the inner ear that keeps its victims in a ceaselessly swirling vertigo, even while sleeping. For weeks Bergman was bedridden, his head in a brace, trying to keep vertigo at bay by staring at a spot his doctor had painted on the ceiling, but with each glance away the room spun like a whirligig. Concentrating on the spot, he began to imagine two faces intermingled. Days later, as he recovered, he glanced through a window and saw a nurse and a patient sitting comparing hands. Those images, the nurse/patient relationship and merging faces, were the genesis for Bergman’s masterpiece PERSONA.

灵感或直觉的闪现看似随机而自发，其实是偶然的。因为可能激发一个人灵感的东西作家将被他人忽视。前提唤醒了作家内心的等待，唤醒了作家心中萌芽的愿景或信念。他的所有经历都为这一刻做好了准备，他对此做出了只有他才会做出的反应。现在工作开始了。一路上，他解释、选择并做出判断。如果对某些人来说，作家对生活的最终陈述显得教条和固执己见，那就这样吧。平淡无奇、令人安心的作家令人厌烦。我们需要无拘无束的灵魂，有勇气采取自己的观点，需要洞察力令人震惊和兴奋的艺术家。

Flashes of inspiration or intuition that seem so random and spontaneous are in fact serendipitous. For what may inspire one writer will be ignored by another. The Premise awakens what waits within, the visions or convictions nascent in the writer. The sum total of his experience has prepared him for this moment and he reacts to it as only he would. Now the work begins. Along the way he interprets, chooses, and makes judgments. If, to some people, a writer’s final statement about life appears dogmatic and opinionated, so be it. Bland and pacifying writers are a bore. We want unfettered souls with the courage to take a point of view, artists whose insights startle and excite.

最后，重要的是要意识到，激发写作灵感的东西不必留在写作中。前提并不珍贵。只要它有助于故事的发展，就保留它，但如果讲述方式发生了变化，就放弃最初的灵感，去追随不断发展的故事。问题不在于开始写作，而在于继续写作和更新灵感。我们很少知道我们要去哪里；写作就是发现。

Finally, it’s important to realize that whatever inspires the writing need not stay in the writing. A Premise is not precious. As long as it contributes to the growth of story, keep it, but should the telling take a left turn, abandon the original inspiration to follow the evolving story. The problem is not to start writing, but to keep writing and renewing inspiration. We rarely know where we’re going; writing is discovery.

结构作为修辞

STRUCTURE AS RHETORIC

别误会：虽然故事的灵感可能来自梦境，最终效果可能是审美情感，但只有当作家经过严肃思考时，作品才能从开放的前提走向令人满意的高潮。因为艺术家不仅要表达想法，还要证明想法。表达想法，也就是揭露想法，永远不够。观众不能只是理解，他们必须相信。你希望全世界在听完你的故事后，相信你的故事是对生活的真实隐喻。而让观众接受你的观点的方法，就在于你为故事设计的构思。当你创作故事时，你也在创造证据；想法和结构在修辞关系中交织在一起。

Make no mistake: While a story’s inspiration may be a dream and its final effect aesthetic emotion, a work moves from an open premise to a fulfilling climax only when the writer is possessed by serious thought. For an artist must have not only ideas to express, but ideas to prove. Expressing an idea, in the sense of exposing it, is never enough. The audience must not just understand; it must believe. You want the world to leave your story convinced that yours is a truthful metaphor for life. And the means by which you bring the audience to your point of view resides in the very design you give your telling. As you create your story, you create your proof; idea and structure intertwine in a rhetorical relationship.

讲故事是真理的创造性展示。故事是思想的活生生的证明，是思想转化为行动的过程。故事的事件结构是你首先表达然后证明你的想法的手段……无需解释。

STORYTELLING is the creative demonstration of truth. A story is the living proof of an idea, the conversion of idea to action. A story’s event structure is the means by which you first express, then prove your idea … without explanation.

大师级的讲故事者从不解释。他们做艰难而痛苦的创造性工作——他们戏剧化。当观众被迫聆听思想讨论时，他们很少感兴趣，当然也永远不会被说服。对话，即人物追求欲望的自然对话，不是电影制作人哲学的平台。对作者思想的解释，无论是对话还是旁白，都会严重降低电影的质量。一个伟大的故事只能在其事件的动态中验证其思想；无法通过人类选择和行动的纯粹、诚实的后果来表达生活观，这是一种创造性的失败，无论多少巧妙的语言都无法挽救。

Master storytellers never explain. They do the hard, painfully creative thing—they dramatize. Audiences are rarely interested, and certainly never convinced, when forced to listen to the discussion of ideas. Dialogue, the natural talk of characters pursuing desire, is not a platform for the filmmaker’s philosophy. Explanations of authorial ideas, whether in dialogue or narration, seriously diminish a film’s quality. A great story authenticates its ideas solely within the dynamics of its events; failure to express a view of life through the pure, honest consequences of human choice and action is a creative defeat no amount of clever language can salvage.

举例来说，以犯罪这一多产的题材为例。几乎所有侦探小说都表达了什么思想？“犯罪不会有好下场”。我们如何理解这一点？希望不要让一个角色对另一个角色沉思，“瞧！我告诉你什么了？犯罪不会有好下场。不，看起来他们会逃脱惩罚，但正义之轮无情地转动着……”不，我们看到这个想法在我们面前上演：犯罪发生；一段时间内罪犯逍遥法外；最终他被逮捕并受到惩罚。在惩罚的过程中——终身监禁或在街上枪杀他——一个情绪激动的想法在观众心中流淌。如果我们可以用语言来表达这个想法，他们不会像“犯罪不会有好下场”那么礼貌。而是：“他们抓住了这个混蛋！”这是正义和社会复仇的激动人心的胜利。

To illustrate, consider that prolific genre, Crime. What idea is expressed by virtually all detective fiction? “Crime doesn’t pay.” How do we come to understand that? Hopefully without one character musing to another, “There! What’d I tell ya? Crime doesn’t pay. Nope, it looked like they’d get away with it, but the wheels of justice turned unrelentingly …” No, we see the idea acted out in front of us: A crime is committed; for a while the criminal goes free; eventually he’s apprehended and punished. In the act of punishment—imprisoning him for life or shooting him dead on the street—an emotionally charged idea runs through the audience. And if we could put words to this idea, they wouldn’t be as polite as “Crime does not pay.” Rather: “They got the bastard!” An electrifying triumph of justice and social revenge.

审美情感的种类和质量是相对的。心理惊悚片力求达到非常强烈的效果；其他形式，如幻灭情节或爱情故事，则需要更柔和的情感，例如悲伤或同情。但无论类型如何，原则都是普遍的：故事的意义，无论是喜剧还是悲剧，都必须在情感表达的故事高潮中戏剧化地表达出来，而无需借助解释性对话。

The kind and quality of aesthetic emotion is relative. The Psycho-Thriller strives for very strong effects; other forms, like the Disillusionment plot or the Love Story, want the softer emotions of perhaps sadness or compassion. But regardless of genre, the principle is universal: the story’s meaning, whether comic or tragic, must be dramatized in an emotionally expressive Story Climax without the aid of explanatory dialogue.

中心思想

CONTROLLING IDEA

主题在作家的词汇中已成为一个相当模糊的术语。例如，“贫穷”、“战争”和“爱情”都不是主题；它们与背景或类型有关。真正的主题不是一个词，而是一个句子——一个清晰、连贯的句子，表达故事不可简化的意义。我更喜欢“主控思想”这个短语，因为它像主题一样，指出了故事的根源或中心思想，但它也暗示了功能：主控思想塑造了作家的战略选择。这是另一种创造性学科，可以指导您的审美选择，确定故事中什么是合适的，什么是不合适的，什么是可以表达您的主控思想的，可以保留，什么是与之无关的，必须删除。

Theme has become a rather vague term in the writer’s vocabulary. “Poverty,” “war,” and “love,” for example, are not themes; they relate to setting or genre. A true theme is not a word but a sentence—one clear, coherent sentence that expresses a story’s irreducible meaning. I prefer the phrase Controlling Idea, for like theme, it names a story’s root or central idea, but it also implies function: The Controlling Idea shapes the writer’s strategic choices. It’s yet another Creative Discipline to guide your aesthetic choices toward what is appropriate or inappropriate in your story, toward what is expressive of your Controlling Idea and may be kept versus what is irrelevant to it and must be cut.

一个完整故事的主旨必须能用一句话表达出来。在构思好前提、开始创作之后，探索一切能想到的东西。但最终，电影必须围绕一个想法来塑造。这并不是说故事可以简化为一个规则。故事的网络中包含着更多的东西，这些是无法用语言表达的——微妙之处、潜台词、构思、双重含义、各种丰富性。故事成为一种活生生的哲学，观众可以在一瞬间、不经意间掌握它——这是一种与他们的生活经历相结合的感知。但讽刺的是：

The Controlling Idea of a completed story must be expressible in a single sentence. After the Premise is first imagined and the work is evolving, explore everything and anything that comes to mind. Ultimately, however, the film must be molded around one idea. This is not to say that a story can be reduced to a rubric. Far more is captured within the web of a story that can ever be stated in words—subtleties, subtexts, conceits, double meanings, richness of all kinds. A story becomes a kind of living philosophy that the audience members grasp as a whole, in a flash, without conscious thought—a perception married to their life experiences. But the irony is this:

你越能将作品完美地围绕一个清晰的理念展开，观众就越能从你的电影中发现更多意义，因为他们会接受你的想法，并将其影响融入到他们生活的方方面面。相反，你试图将越多的想法塞进一个故事中，它们就会越自相矛盾，直到电影崩塌成一堆无关紧要的想法，毫无意义。

The more beautifully you shape your work around one clear idea, the more meanings audiences will discover in your film as they take your idea and follow its implications into every aspect of their lives. Conversely, the more ideas you try to pack into a story, the more they implode upon themselves, until the film collapses into a rubble of tangential notions, saying nothing.

控制思想可以用一句话来表达，描述生命如何以及为何从开始时的一种生存状态转变为结束时的另一种生存状态。

A CONTROLLING IDEA may be expressed in a single sentence describing how and why life undergoes change from one condition of existence at the beginning to another at the end.

主控思想由两个部分组成：价值加原因。它确定了故事在最后一幕高潮时的关键价值的正向或负向作用，并确定了这种价值转变为最终状态的主要原因。由价值加原因这两个元素组成的句子表达了故事的核心含义。

The Controlling Idea has two components: Value plus Cause. It identifies the positive or negative charge of the story’s critical value at the last act’s climax, and it identifies the chief reason that this value has changed to its final state. The sentence composed from these two elements, Value plus Cause, expresses the core meaning of the story.

价值是指故事的最终行动为角色的世界或生活带来的积极或消极影响的主要价值。例如：一个结局向上的犯罪故事（《炎热的夜晚》）将不公正的世界（消极）带回正义（积极），让人联想到“正义得到恢复……”这样的句子。在一个结局向下的政治惊悚片（《失踪》）中，军事独裁统治在高潮时控制着故事的世界，引发了“暴政盛行……”这样的消极句子。一个结局积极的教育情节（《土拨鼠日》）将主人公从一个玩世不恭、自私自利的人转变成一个真正无私、充满爱心的人，导致“幸福充满了我们的生活……”一个结局消极的爱情故事（《危险关系》）将激情变成了自我厌恶，让人联想到“仇恨摧毁了……”

Value means the primary value in its positive or negative charge that comes into the world or life of your character as a result of the final action of the story. For example: An up-ending Crime Story (IN THE HEAT OF THE NIGHT) returns an unjust world (negative) to justice (positive), suggesting a phrase such as “Justice is restored …” In a down-ending Political Thriller (MISSING), the military dictatorship commands the story’s world at climax, prompting a negative phrase such as “Tyranny prevails …” A positive-ending Education Plot (GROUNDHOG DAY) arcs the protagonist from a cynical, self-serving man to someone who’s genuinely selfless and loving, leading to “Happiness fills our lives …” A negative-ending Love Story (DANGEROUS LIAISONS) turns passion into self-loathing, evoking “Hatred destroys …”

原因是指主角的生活或世界转向其正面或负面价值的主要原因。从结尾回溯到开头，我们可以追溯到人物、社会或环境深处产生这种价值的主要原因。一个复杂的故事可能包含许多改变的力量，但通常一个原因主导着其他原因。因此，在犯罪故事中，“犯罪没有回报……”（正义胜利了……）和“犯罪有回报……”（不公正胜利了……）都不能成为完整的主控思想，因为它们都只给了我们一半的意义——结局价值。一个有实质内容的故事还会表达为什么它的世界或主角会以它的特定价值结束。

Cause refers to the primary reason that the life or world of the protagonist has turned to its positive or negative value. Working back from the ending to the beginning, we trace the chief cause deep within the character, society, or environment that has brought this value into existence. A complex story may contain many forces for change, but generally one cause dominates the others. Therefore, in a Crime Story, neither “Crime doesn’t pay …” (justice triumphs …) nor “Crime pays …” (injustice triumphs …) could stand as a full Controlling Idea because each gives us only half a meaning—the ending value. A story of substance also expresses why its world or protagonist has ended on its specific value.

例如，如果你在为克林特·伊斯特伍德的《肮脏的哈利》写作，你完整的价值主控思想加上原因应该是：“正​​义胜利，因为主角比罪犯更暴力。”肮脏的哈利偶尔会做一些小侦探工作，但他的暴力行为是改变的主要原因。然后，这种洞察力会引导你了解什么是合适的，什么是不合适的。它告诉你，写这样一个场景是不合适的：肮脏的哈利遇到了谋杀受害者，发现了逃跑的杀手留下的滑雪帽，拿出放大镜，仔细检查，然后得出结论，“嗯……这个人大约三十五岁；他有一头红发；他来自煤矿宾夕法尼亚州的一些地区——注意那些无烟煤粉尘。”这是夏洛克·福尔摩斯，不是肮脏的哈利。

If, for example, you were writing for Clint Eastwood’s Dirty Harry, your full Controlling Idea of Value plus Cause would be: “Justice triumphs because the protagonist is more violent than the criminals.” Dirty Harry manages some minor detective work here and there, but his violence is the dominant cause for change. This insight then guides you to what’s appropriate and inappropriate. It tells you it would be inappropriate to write a scene in which Dirty Harry comes upon the murder victim, discovers a ski cap left behind by the fleeing killer, takes out a magnifying glass, examines it, and concludes, “Hmm … this man’s approximately thirty-five years of age; he has reddish hair; and he comes from the coal-mining regions of Pennsylvania—notice the anthracitic dust.” This is Sherlock Holmes, not Dirty Harry.

但是，如果你为彼得·福尔克的《神探可伦坡》写作，你的主控思想应该是：“正​​义得以恢复，因为主角比罪犯更聪明。”滑雪帽法医可能适合《神探可伦坡》，因为《神探可伦坡》系列中变化的主要原因是福尔摩斯式的推理。然而，如果让《神探可伦坡》从皱巴巴的雨衣里掏出一把 .44 马格南手枪，然后开始射杀人们，那就不合适了。

If, however, you were writing for Peter Falk’s Columbo, your Controlling Idea would be: “Justice is restored because the protagonist is more clever than the criminal.” The ski cap forensics might be appropriate for Columbo because the dominant cause for change in the Columbo series is Sherlock Holmesian deduction. It would be inappropriate, however, for Columbo to reach under his wrinkled raincoat, come up with a.44 Magnum, and start blowing people away.

补充前面的例子：《夜色正浓》——正义得以恢复，因为一个敏锐的黑人局外人看到了白人变态的真相。《土拨鼠日》——当我们学会无条件地去爱时，我们的生活充满了幸福。《失踪》——暴政盛行，因为它得到了腐败的中央情报局的支持。《危险关系》——当我们害怕异性时，仇恨会摧毁我们。主控思想是故事意义的最纯粹形式，是改变的方式和原因，是观众带入生活的人生愿景。

To complete the previous examples: IN THE HEAT OF THE NIGHT—justice is restored because a perceptive black outsider sees the truth of white perversion. GROUNDHOG DAY—happiness fills our lives when we learn to love unconditionally. MISSING—tyranny prevails because it’s supported by a corrupt CIA. DANGEROUS LIAISONS—hatred destroys us when we fear the opposite sex. The Controlling Idea is the purest form of a story’s meaning, the how and why of change, the vision of life the audience members carry away into their lives.

意义和创作过程

Meaning and the Creative Process

如何找到故事的主控思想？创作过程可以从任何地方开始。你可能会被一个前提、一个“如果……会发生什么”、一个人物或一个形象所激发。你可能从中间、开头或接近结尾的地方开始。随着虚构世界和人物的成长，事件相互联系，故事也逐渐成型。然后就是那个关键时刻，你迈出这一步，创造出故事高潮。最后一幕的高潮是让你兴奋和感动的最终行动，让你感到完整和满足。主控思想现在就在眼前。

How do you find your story’s Controlling Idea? The creative process may begin anywhere. You might be prompted by a Premise, a “What would happen if…,” or a bit of character, or an image. You might start in the middle, the beginning, near the end. As your fictional world and characters grow, events interlink and the story builds. Then comes that crucial moment when you take the leap and create the Story Climax. This climax of the last act is a final action that excites and moves you, that feels complete and satisfying. The Controlling Idea is now at hand.

看看你的结局，问问自己：由于这个高潮，什么价值观（正面或负面）被带入了主人公的世界？接下来，从这个高潮回溯，深入到基石，问问自己：这个价值观被带入主人公的世界的主要原因、力量或手段是什么？你根据这两个问题的答案所写的句子将成为你的主控思想。

Looking at your ending, ask: As a result of this climatic action, what value, positively or negatively charged, is brought into the world of my protagonist? Next, tracing backward from this climax, digging to the bedrock, ask: What is the chief cause, force, or means by which this value is brought into his world? The sentence you compose from the answers to those two questions becomes your Controlling Idea.

换句话说，故事会告诉你它的意义；你不会为故事规定意义。你不会从想法中得出行动，而是从行动中得出想法。无论你的灵感是什么，故事最终都会将其主宰思想嵌入到最后的高潮中，当这个事件说出它的意义时，你将体验到写作生涯中最强大的时刻之一——自我认知：故事高潮反映了你的内心，如果你的故事来自你内心最好的来源，你往往会对你在其中看到的东西感到震惊。

In other words, the story tells you its meaning; you do not dictate meaning to the story. You do not draw action from idea, rather idea from action. For no matter your inspiration, ultimately the story embeds its Controlling Idea within the final climax, and when this event speaks its meaning, you will experience one of the most powerful moments in the writing life—Self-Recognition: The Story Climax mirrors your inner self, and if your story is from the very best sources within you, more often than not you’ll be shocked by what you see reflected in it.

你可能认为自己是一个热情、有爱心的人，直到你发现自己写的故事充满了黑暗、愤世嫉俗的后果。或者你可能认为自己是一个街头智慧的人，在街头摸爬滚打了好几次，直到你发现自己写的故事结局温暖、富有同情心。你以为你知道自己是谁，但你常常对自己内心深处需要表达的东西感到惊讶。换句话说，如果情节完全按照你最初的计划进行，那么你就没有足够松散地工作，没有给你的想象力和直觉留出空间。你的故事应该一次又一次地让你感到惊讶。美丽的故事设计是发现的主题、发挥想象力和头脑松散但明智地执行工艺的结合。

You may think you’re a warm, loving human being until you find yourself writing tales of dark, cynical consequence. Or you may think you’re a street-wise guy who’s been around the block a few times until you find yourself writing warm, compassionate endings. You think you know who you are, but often you’re amazed by what’s skulking inside in need of expression. In other words, if a plot works out exactly as you first planned, you’re not working loosely enough to give room to your imagination and instincts. Your story should surprise you again and again. Beautiful story design is a combination of the subject found, the imagination at work, and the mind loosely but wisely executing the craft.

理念与反理念

Idea Versus Counter-Idea

帕迪·查耶夫斯基曾告诉我，当他终于发现了故事的意义时，他会把它写在一张纸上，然后用胶带把它粘在打字机上，这样机器打出的任何内容都会以某种方式表达出故事的中心主题。有了清晰的价值加原因陈述，他就能抵制那些引人入胜的无关紧要的东西，集中精力围绕故事的核心意义统一叙事。查耶夫斯基所说的“不管怎样”，是指他会动态地编造故事，在主要价值观的对立方面来回移动。他的即兴创作会如此形成，一个又一个的序列交替表达了他主宰思想的积极维度和消极维度。换句话说，他通过让思想与反思想对抗来塑造他的故事。

Paddy Chayefsky once told me that when he finally discovered his story’s meaning, he’d scratch it out on a scrap of paper and tape it to his typewriter, so that nothing going through the machine wouldn’t in one way or another express his central theme. With a clear statement of Value plus Cause staring him in the eye, he could resist intriguing irrelevancies and concentrate on unifying the telling around the story’s core meaning. By “one way or another,” Chayefsky meant he’d forge the story dynamically, moving it back and forth across the opposing charges of its primary values. His improvisations would be so shaped that sequence after sequence alternately expressed the positive, then negative dimension of his Controlling Idea. In other words, he fashioned his stories by playing Idea against Counter-Idea.

通过在故事中所涉及的价值观的正负之间动态移动来建立进展。

PROGRESSIONS build by moving dynamically between the positive and negative charges of the values at stake in the story.

从灵感迸发的那一刻起，您便进入虚构世界寻找设计。您必须从开头到结尾搭建故事的桥梁，从前提到主控思想，一系列事件接踵而至。这些事件呼应着一个主题的矛盾声音。一个接一个的场景，积极的思想和消极的反思想不断地来回争论，形成一场戏剧化的辩证辩论。在高潮时，这两种声音中的一种获胜，成为故事的主控思想。

From the moment of inspiration you reach into your fictional world in search of a design. You have to build a bridge of story from the opening to the ending, a progression of events that spans from Premise to Controlling Idea. These events echo the contradictory voices of one theme. Sequence by sequence, often scene by scene, the positive Idea and its negative Counter-Idea argue, so to speak, back and forth, creating a dramatized dialectical debate. At climax one of these two voices wins and becomes the story’s Controlling Idea.

借用犯罪故事中熟悉的节奏来说明：典型的开场序列表达了消极的反观念，“犯罪是有好处的，因为罪犯非常聪明并且/或者冷酷无情”，因为它将一桩神秘莫测的罪行（《迷魂记》）或由凶恶的罪犯（《虎胆龙威》）犯下罪行戏剧化，令观众震惊：“他们会逃脱惩罚的！”但是，当一位经验丰富的侦探发现逃亡杀手留下的线索（《夜长梦多》）时，下一个序列用积极观念来反驳这种恐惧，“犯罪没有好处，因为主角更加聪明并且/或者冷酷无情。”然后，也许警察被误导怀疑了错误的人（《再见，我的爱人》）：“犯罪有好处。”但是很快主角就发现了坏人的真实身份（《亡命天涯》）：“犯罪没有好处。”接下来，罪犯抓获了主角，甚至可能杀死了主角（《机械战警》）： “犯罪是有回报的。” 但警察实际上死而复生（《突如其来》）并重新开始追捕：“犯罪没有回报。”

To illustrate with the familiar cadences of the Crime Story: A typical opening sequence expresses the negative Counter-Idea, “Crime pays because the criminals are brilliant and/or ruthless” as it dramatizes a crime so enigmatic (VERTIGO) or committed by such diabolical criminals (DIE HARD) that the audience is stunned: “They’re going to get away with it!” But as a veteran detective discovers a clue left by the fleeing killer (THE BIG SLEEP), the next sequence contradicts this fear with the positive Idea, “Crime doesn’t pay because the protagonist is even more brilliant and/or ruthless.” Then perhaps the cop is misled into suspecting the wrong person (FAREWELL, MY LOVELY): “Crime pays.” But soon the protagonist uncovers the real identity of the villain (THE FUGITIVE): “Crime doesn’t pay.” Next the criminal captures, may even seem to kill, the protagonist (ROBOCOP): “Crime pays.” But the cop virtually resurrects from the dead (SUDDEN IMPACT) and goes back on the hunt: “Crime doesn’t pay.”

同一思想的正面和负面断言在整部电影中来回交锋，强度不断增加，直到危机时刻，它们正面碰撞，陷入最后的僵局。由此产生故事高潮，其中一个或另一个思想获得成功。这可能是正面思想：“正义胜利，因为主角顽强、机智、勇敢”（《黑岩惨案》、《生死时速》、《沉默的羔羊》），也可能是负面反思想：“不公正盛行，因为反派无情、强大”（《七宗罪》、《问答》、《唐人街》）。无论哪种两者中的一个在最后的高潮行动中被戏剧化，成为价值加原因的控制思想，这是故事的决定性和决定性意义的最纯粹的陈述。

The positive and negative assertions of the same idea contest back and forth through the film, building in intensity, until at Crisis they collide head-on in a last impasse. Out of this rises the Story Climax, in which one or the other idea succeeds. This may be the positive Idea: “Justice triumphs because the protagonist is tenaciously resourceful and courageous” (BAD DAY AT BLACK ROCK, SPEED, THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS), or the negative Counter-Idea: “Injustice prevails because the antagonist is overwhelmingly ruthless and powerful” (SEVEN, Q & A, CHINATOWN). Whichever of the two is dramatized in the final climatic action becomes the Controlling Idea of Value plus Cause, the purest statement of the story’s conclusive and decisive meaning.

这种理念与反理念的节奏是我们艺术的基础和本质。它在所有精彩故事的核心中脉动，无论情节如何内化。更重要的是，这种简单的动态可以变得非常复杂、微妙和讽刺。

This rhythm of Idea versus Counter-Idea is fundamental and essential to our art. It pulses at the heart of all fine stories, no matter how internalized the action. What’s more, this simple dynamic can become very complex, subtle, and ironic.

在《爱之海》中，侦探凯勒（阿尔·帕西诺饰）爱上了他的主要嫌疑人（艾伦·巴金饰）。结果，每个指向她罪行的场景都带有讽刺意味：对正义的价值持积极态度，对爱情的价值持消极态度。在成熟情节《闪亮的风采》中，大卫（诺亚·泰勒饰）的音乐胜利（积极）激起了他父亲（阿明·穆勒-斯塔尔饰）的嫉妒和残酷的压抑（消极），使这位钢琴家陷入病态的不成熟（双重消极），这使他最终的成功成为艺术和精神成熟的胜利（双重积极）。

In SEA OF LOVE detective Keller (Al Pacino) falls in love with his chief suspect (Ellen Barkin). As a result, each scene that points toward her guilt turns with irony: positive on the value of justice, negative on the value of love. In the maturation plot SHINE, David’s (Noah Taylor) musical victories (positive) provoke his father’s (Armin Mueller-Stahl) envy and brutal repression (negative), driving the pianist into a pathological immaturity (doubly negative), which makes his final success a triumph of maturity in both art and spirit (doubly positive).

说教主义

DIDACTICISM

需要注意的是：在创建故事“论点”的维度时，要非常小心地建立双方的力量。在创作与你的最终陈述相矛盾的场景和序列时，要像创作那些支持它的内容一样，尽可能真实和有力。如果你的电影以反面观点结尾，比如“犯罪是有代价的，因为……”，那么就放大那些让观众觉得正义会胜利的序列。如果你的电影以正面观点结尾，比如“正义会胜利，因为……”，那么就增强那些表达“犯罪是有代价的，而且代价巨大”的序列。换句话说，不要歪曲你的“论点”。

A note of caution: In creating the dimensions of your story’s “argument,” take great care to build the power of both sides. Compose the scenes and sequences that contradict your final statement with as much truth and energy as those that reinforce it. If your film ends on the Counter-Idea, such as “Crime pays because…,” then amplify the sequences that lead the audience to feel justice will win out. If your film ends on the Idea, such as “Justice triumphs because…,” then enhance the sequences expressing “Crime pays and pays big.” In other words, do not slant your “argument.”

如果在道德故事中，你把反派写成一个无知的傻瓜，或多或少会自我毁灭，我们能相信善良终将获胜吗？但是，如果你像古代神话创造者一样，创造一个几乎无所不能、即将取得成功的反派，你就会强迫自己创造一个能够迎难而上、变得更加强大、更加聪明的主角。在这种平衡的叙述中，你对邪恶的胜利现在听起来很有道理。

If, in a morality tale, you were to write your antagonist as an ignorant fool who more or less destroys himself, are we persuaded that good will prevail? But if, like an ancient myth-maker, you were to create an antagonist of virtual omnipotence who reaches the brink of success, you would force yourself to create a protagonist who will rise to the occasion and become even more powerful, more brilliant. In this balanced telling your victory of good over evil now rings with validity.

危险在于：当你的前提是你觉得必须向世界证明的想法，而你把你的故事设计成这个想法的不可否认的证明时，你就走上了说教主义的道路。在你热衷于说服的过程中，你会扼杀对方的声音。误用和滥用艺术来说教，你的剧本将成为一部论文电影，一场伪装的布道，而你却试图一举改变世界。说教主义源于一种天真的热情，即小说可以像手术刀一样用来切除社会的癌症。

The danger is this: When your Premise is an idea you feel you must prove to the world, and you design your story as an undeniable certification of that idea, you set yourself on the road to didacticism. In your zeal to persuade, you will stifle the voice of the other side. Misusing and abusing art to preach, your screenplay will become a thesis film, a thinly disguised sermon as you strive in a single stroke to convert the world. Didacticism results from the naive enthusiasm that fiction can be used like a scalpel to cut out the cancers of society.

这类故事往往以社会剧的形式出现，这是一种拘谨的体裁，具有两项定义惯例：发现社会弊病；戏剧化地描述其解决办法。例如，作者可能认为战争是人类的祸害，而和平主义则是解药。他热衷于让我们相信，他笔下的所有好人都是非常非常好的人，而所有坏人都是非常非常坏的人。所有的对话都是对战争的徒劳和疯狂的“直白”哀叹，由衷宣称战争的起因是“当权者”。从提纲到最终稿，他把令人反胃的画面填满屏幕，确保每一个场景都响亮而清晰地表明：“战争是一种祸害，但和平主义可以治愈……战争是和平主义可以治愈的祸害……战争是和平主义可以治愈的祸害……”直到你想拿起枪。

More often than not, such stories take the form of Social Drama, a lead-handed genre with two defining conventions: Identify a social ill; dramatize its remedy. The writer, for example, may decide that war is the scourge of humanity, and pacifism is the cure. In his zeal to convince us all his good people are very, very good people, and all his bad people are very, very bad people. All the dialogue is “on the nose” laments about the futility and insanity of war, heartfelt declarations that the cause of war is the “establishment.” From outline to last draft, he fills the screen with stomach-turning images, making certain that each and every scene says loud and clear: “War is a scourge, but it can be cured by pacifism… war is a scourge cured by pacifism… war is a scourge cured by pacifism…” until you want to pick up a gun.

但反战电影（《哦！多么可爱的战争》、《现代启示录》、《加利波利》、《汉堡山》）的和平主义呼吁很少能让我们意识到战争。我们之所以不相信，是因为作者急于证明自己有答案，却忽视了一个我们非常清楚的事实——人类热爱战争。

But the pacifist pleas of antiwar films (OH! WHAT A LOVELY WAR, APOCALYPSE NOW, GALLIPOLI, HAMBURGER HILL) rarely sensitize us to war. We’re unconvinced because in the rush to prove he has the answer, the writer is blind to a truth we know too well—men love war.

这并不意味着从一个想法开始就一定会产生说教性的作品……但这就是风险所在。随着故事的发展，你必须愿意接受相反的、甚至是令人反感的想法。最优秀的作家拥有辩证的、灵活的头脑，可以轻易地改变观点。他们看到积极的、消极的和各种讽刺的方面，诚实而令人信服地寻求这些观点的真相。这种无所不知迫使他们变​​得更有创造力、更有想象力、更有洞察力。最终，他们会表达他们深信不疑的东西，但前提是他们允许自己权衡每一个生活问题并体验其所有可能性。

This does not mean that starting with an idea is certain to produce didactic work… but that’s the risk. As a story develops, you must willingly entertain opposite, even repugnant ideas. The finest writers have dialectical, flexible minds that easily shift points of view. They see the positive, the negative, and all shades of irony, seeking the truth of these views honestly and convincingly. This omniscience forces them to become even more creative, more imaginative, and more insightful. Ultimately, they express what they deeply believe, but not until they have allowed themselves to weigh each living issue and experience all its possibilities.

别误会，没有人能在不具备哲学家和坚定信念的情况下成为优秀的作家。诀窍在于不要成为你思想的奴隶，而是让自己沉浸在生活中。因为你的远见卓识的证明不是你能多好地坚持你的主宰思想，而是它战胜了你与之对抗的强大力量。

Make no mistake, no one can achieve excellence as a writer without being something of a philosopher and holding strong convictions. The trick is not to be a slave to your ideas, but to immerse yourself in life. For the proof of your vision is not how well you can assert your Controlling Idea, but its victory over the enormously powerful forces that you array against it.

想想斯坦利·库布里克执导的三部反战电影的绝妙平衡。库布里克和他的编剧研究并探索了反战思想，深入人类心灵。他们的故事揭示了战争是人类本性中热爱战斗和杀戮的内在维度的逻辑延伸，让我们不寒而栗地意识到，人类喜欢做的事，它就会去做——正如它千百年来所做的那样，从现在到所有可预见的未来。

Consider the superb balance of three antiwar films directed by Stanley Kubrick. Kubrick and his screenwriters researched and explored the Counter-Idea to look deep within the human psyche itself. Their stories reveal war to be the logical extension of an intrinsic dimension of human nature that loves to fight and kill, chilling us with the realization that what humanity loves to do, it will do—as it has for aeons, through the now and into all foreseeable futures.

在库布里克的《光荣之路》中，法国的命运取决于不惜一切代价打赢对德战争。因此，当法国军队撤退时，一位愤怒的将军想出了一个创新的激励策略：他命令炮兵轰炸自己的部队。在《奇爱博士》中，美国和俄罗斯都意识到，在核战争中，不输比赢更重要，所以他们各自都想出了一个不输的计划，这个计划非常有效，甚至会焚烧地球上的所有生命。在《全金属外壳》中，海军陆战队面临着一项艰巨的任务：如何说服人类无视基因禁止杀死自己同类的禁令。简单的解决办法是对新兵进行洗脑，让他们相信敌人不是人类；这样杀人就变得容易了，即使他是你的教练。库布里克知道，如果他给人类足够的弹药，他们会自杀。

In Kubrick’s PATHS OF GLORY the fate of France hangs on winning the war against the Germans at any cost. So when the French army retreats from battle, an outraged general devises an innovative motivational strategy: He orders his artillery to bombard his own troops. In DR. STRANGELOVE the United States and Russia both realize that in nuclear war, not losing is more important than winning, so each concocts a scheme for not losing so effective it incinerates all life on Earth. In FULL METAL JACKET, the Marine Corps faces a tough task: how to persuade human beings to ignore the genetic prohibition against killing their own kind. The simple solution is to brainwash recruits into believing that the enemy is not human; killing a man then becomes easy, even if he’s your drill instructor. Kubrick knew that if he gave the humanity enough ammunition, it would shoot itself.

伟大的作品是一个活生生的隐喻，它告诉我们“生活就是这样。 ”古往今来的经典之作给我们的不是解决方案而是明晰，不是答案而是诗意的坦诚；它们不可避免地阐明了每一代人作为人都必须解决的问题。

A great work is a living metaphor that says, “Life is like this.” The classics, down through the ages, give us not solutions but lucidity, not answers but poetic candor; they make inescapably clear the problems all generations must solve to be human.

理想主义者、悲观主义者、讽刺主义者

IDEALIST, PESSIMIST, IRONIST

根据主控思想的情感冲击力，作家和他们讲述的故事可以分为三大类。

Writers and the stories they tell can be usefully divided into three grand categories, according to the emotional charge of their Controlling Idea.

理想主义控制思想

Idealistic Controlling Ideas

“颠覆性”故事表达了人类的乐观、希望和梦想，是人类精神的积极愿景；我们希望的生活是这样的。示例：

“Up-ending” stories expressing the optimism, hopes, and dreams of mankind, a positively charged vision of the human spirit; life as we wish it to be. Examples:

“当我们克服理智的幻想并遵循我们的本能时，爱就会充满我们的生活”：《汉娜和她的姐妹们》。在这本书中故事情节复杂，一群纽约人正在寻找爱情，但他们无法找到，因为他们不断思考、分析，试图解读事物的意义：性政治、事业、道德或永生。然而，他们一个接一个地摆脱了理智的幻想，倾听了内心的声音。他们一这样做，就找到了爱情。这是伍迪·艾伦拍过的最乐观的电影之一。

“Love fills our lives when we conquer intellectual illusions and follow our instincts”: HANNAH AND HER SISTERS. In this Multiplot story, a collection of New Yorkers are seeking love, but they’re unable to find it because they keep thinking, analyzing, trying to decipher the meaning of things: sexual politics, careers, morality or immortality. One by one, however, they cast off their intellectual illusions and listen to their hearts. The moment they do, they all find love. This is one of the most optimistic films Woody Allen has ever made.

“当我们战胜邪恶时，善良就会胜利”：《伊斯特威克的女巫》。女巫们巧妙地利用魔鬼自己的肮脏伎俩来对付他，并在三个胖乎乎的婴儿身上找到了善良和幸福。

“Goodness triumphs when we outwit evil”: THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK. The witches ingeniously turn the devil’s own dirty tricks against him and find goodness and happiness in the form of three chubby-cheeked babies.

“人类的勇气和智慧将战胜大自然的敌意。”生存电影是动作/冒险电影的一个分支，是与环境力量进行生死冲突的“颠覆性”故事。在灭绝的边缘，主角凭借意志和智慧，与大自然母亲常常残酷的性格作斗争并坚持下去：《海神号遇险记》、《大白鲨》、《寻找火种》、《蜘蛛恐惧症》、《菲茨卡拉多》、《凤凰飞翔》、《活着》。

“The courage and genius of humanity will prevail over the hostility of Nature.” Survival Films, a subgenre of Action/Adventure, are “up-ending” stories of life-and-death conflict with forces of the environment. At the brink of extinction, the protagonists, through dint of will and resourcefulness, battle the often cruel personality of Mother Nature and endure: THE POSEIDON ADVENTURE, JAWS, QUEST FOR FIRE, ARACHNOPHOBIA, FITZCAR-RALDO, FLIGHT OF THE PHOENIX, ALIVE.

悲观控制思想

Pessimistic Controlling Ideas

“悲观结局”的故事表达了我们的愤世嫉俗、失落和不幸，以及对文明衰落和人类黑暗面的消极看法；我们害怕生活，但又知道它常常如此。例子：

“Down-ending” stories expressing our cynicism, our sense of loss and misfortune, a negatively charged vision of civilization’s decline, of humanity’s dark dimensions; life as we dread it to be but know it so often is. Examples:

“当我们把别人当作享乐的对象时，激情就会变成暴力，毁掉我们的生活”：《与陌生人共舞》。这部英国作品中的情侣认为他们的问题是阶级差异，但阶级已经被无数情侣克服。最深层的冲突是，他们的恋情被欲望所毒害，欲望将对方当作神经质满足的对象，直到其中一人夺取了最终的占有物——她爱人的生命。

“Passion turns to violence and destroys our lives when we use people as objects of pleasure”: DANCE WITH A STRANGER. The lovers in this British work think their problem is a difference of class, but class has been overcome by countless couples. The deep conflict is that their affair is poisoned by desires to possess each other as objects for neurotic gratification, until one seizes the ultimate possession—the life of her lover.

“邪恶之所以胜利，是因为它是人性的一部分”：《唐人街》。从表面上看，《唐人街》暗示富人可以逍遥法外。他们确实可以逍遥法外。但更深刻的是这部电影表达了邪恶无处不在。事实上，由于善恶是人性中平等的部分，所以邪恶战胜善良的次数与善良战胜邪恶的次数一样多。我们既是天使又是魔鬼。如果我们的天性稍微偏向其中之一，所有的社会困境在几个世纪前就已经解决了。但我们是如此分裂，我们永远不知道自己会成为哪一种。今天我们建造了巴黎圣母院；明天我们建造了奥斯维辛。

“Evil triumphs because it’s part of human nature”: CHINATOWN. On a superficial level, CHINATOWN suggests that the rich get away with murder. They do indeed. But more profoundly the film expresses the ubiquity of evil. In reality, because good and evil are equal parts of human nature, evil vanquishes good as often as good conquers evil. We’re both angel and devil. If our natures leaned just slightly toward one or the other, all social dilemmas would have been solved centuries ago. But we’re so divided, we never know from day to day which we’ll be. One day we build the Cathedral of Notre Dame; the next, Auschwitz.

“自然的力量将对人类徒劳的努力拥有最终决定权。”当生存电影的反思想成为主导思想时，我们就有了那种罕见的“结局悲观”的电影，其中人类再次与自然的显现作斗争，但现在自然占了上风：《南极的斯科特》、《象人》、《地震》和《群鸟》，在这些电影中，大自然向我们发出了警告。这些电影之所以罕见，是因为悲观的愿景是一些人希望避免的残酷事实。

“The power of nature will have the final say over mankind’s futile efforts.” When the Counter-Idea of survival films becomes the Controlling Idea, we have that rare “down-ending” movie in which again human beings battle a manifestation of nature, but now nature prevails: SCOTT OF THE ANTARCTIC, THE ELEPHANT MAN, EARTHQUAKE, and THE BIRDS, in which nature lets us off with a warning. These films are rare because the pessimistic vision is a hard truth that some people wish to avoid.

讽刺控制思想

Ironic Controlling Ideas

“上/下结局”的故事表达了我们对存在的复杂性、二重性的感受，一种同时充满积极和消极的看法；最完整和最现实的生活。

“Up/down-ending” stories expressing our sense of the complex, dual nature of existence, a simultaneously charged positive and negative vision; life at its most complete and realistic.

在这里，乐观/理想主义和悲观/愤世嫉俗融合在一起。故事不是表达一个极端，而是表达了两者。理想主义的“当我们为他人牺牲自己的需要时，爱情就会胜利”，如《克莱默夫妇》中所说，与悲观主义的“当私利占主导地位时，爱情就会毁灭”，如《玫瑰战争》中所说，融合在一起，产生了一个具有讽刺意味的控制思想：“爱情既是快乐也是痛苦，是一种痛苦，一种温柔的残忍，我们追求它，因为没有它，生活就没有意义”，如《安妮霍尔》、《曼哈顿》、《爱上瘾》中所说。

Here optimism/idealism and pessimism/cynicism merge. Rather than voicing one extreme or the other, the story says both. The Idealistic “Love triumphs when we sacrifice our needs for others,” as in KRAMER VS. KRAMER, melds with the Pessimistic “Love destroys when self-interest rules,” as in THE WAR OF THE ROSES, and results in an ironic Controlling Idea: “Love is both pleasure and pain, a poignant anguish, a tender cruelty we pursue because without it life has no meaning,” as in ANNIE HALL, MANHATTAN, ADDICTED TO LOVE.

以下是两个控制思想的例子，它们的讽刺性有助于定义当代美国社会的道德和态度。首先是积极的讽刺：

What follows are two examples of Controlling Ideas whose ironies have helped define the ethics and attitudes of contemporary American society. First, the positive irony:

对当代价值观的强迫性追求——成功、财富、名望、性、权力——会毁了你，但如果你及时认清这个真理，抛弃你的执念，你就能救赎自己。

The compulsive pursuit of contemporary values—success, fortune, fame, sex, power—will destroy you, but if you see this truth in time and throw away your obsession, you can redeem yourself.

直到 20 世纪 70 年代，“逆转结局”都可以宽泛地定义为“主角得到了他想要的东西”。在高潮中，主角的欲望对象变成了某种奖杯，具体价值取决于奖杯的价值——梦中情人（爱情）、坏人的尸体（正义）、成就徽章（财富、胜利）、公众认可（权力、名望）——而主角赢得了它。

Until the 1970s an “up-ending” could be loosely defined as “The protagonist gets what he wants.” At climax the protagonist’s object of desire became a trophy of sorts, depending on the value at stake—the lover of one’s dreams (love), the dead body of the villain (justice), a badge of achievement (fortune, victory), public recognition (power, fame)—and he won it.

然而，在 20 世纪 70 年代，好莱坞演绎出了一种极具讽刺意味的成功故事版本。救赎情节，其中的主角追求曾经被尊崇的价值观 — — 金钱、名望、事业、爱情、胜利、成功 — — 但却带有一种强迫性和盲目性，将他们带到了自我毁灭的边缘。他们可能会失去生命，甚至是人性。然而，他们设法瞥见了这种痴迷的毁灭性，在超越极限之前停下来，然后扔掉了他们曾经珍视的东西。这种模式导致了一个充满讽刺意味的结局：在高潮时，主角牺牲了他的梦想（积极的），这种价值观已经成为一种腐蚀灵魂的执念（消极的），以获得诚实、理智、平衡的生活（积极的）。

In the 1970s, however, Hollywood evolved a highly ironic version of the success story. Redemption Plots, in which protagonists pursue values that were once esteemed—money, reknown, career, love, winning, success—but with a compulsiveness, a blindness that carries them to the brink of self-destruction. They stand to lose, if not their lives, their humanity. They manage, however, to glimpse the ruinous nature of their obsession, stop before they go over the edge, then throw away what they once cherished. This pattern gives rise to an ending rich in irony: At climax the protagonist sacrifices his dream (positive), a value that has become a soul-corrupting fixation (negative), to gain an honest, sane, balanced life (positive).

《纸上谈兵》、《猎鹿人》、《克莱默夫妇》、《未婚女子》、《十个孩子》、《正义与正义》、《亲密关系》、《电光骑士》、《风流老爸》、《智力竞赛》、《子弹飞过百老汇》、《渔王》、《大峡谷》、《雨人》、《汉娜姐妹》、《军官与绅士》、《窈窕淑男》、《亨利的回忆》、《普通人》、《干净清醒》、《北达拉斯四十人组》、《走出非洲》、《婴儿潮》、《医生》、《辛德勒的名单》和《甜心先生》都围绕着这种讽刺展开，每部都以独特而有力的方式表达了这种讽刺。正如这些片名所表明的那样，这个想法一直是奥斯卡的热门话题。

THE PAPER CHASE, THE DEER HUNTER, KRAMER VS.
