KRAMER, AN UNMARRIED WOMAN, 10, AND JUSTICE FOR ALL, TERMS OF ENDEARMENT, THE ELECTRIC HORSEMAN, GOING IN STYLE, QUIZ SHOW, BULLETS OVER BROADWAY, THE FISHER KING, GRAND CANYON, RAIN MAN, HANNAH AND HER SISTERS, AN OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN, TOOTSIE, REGARDING HENRY, ORDINARY PEOPLE, CLEAN AND SOBER, NORTH DALLAS FORTY, OUT OF AFRICA, BABY BOOM, THE DOCTOR, SCHINDLER’S LIST, and JERRY MAGUIRE all pivot around this irony, each expressing it in a unique and powerful way. As these titles indicate, this idea has been a magnet for Oscars.

从技术上讲，这些电影中高潮动作的执行令人着迷。从历史上看，积极的结局是主角采取行动得到他想要的东西的场景。然而，在上面提到的所有作品中，主角要么拒绝按照他的痴迷行事，要么抛弃他曾经期望。他或她通过“失败”而获胜。就像解决禅宗鼓掌之谜一样，作家在每种情况下的问题都是如何使不作为或消极的行动感觉积极。

In terms of technique, the execution of the climactic action in these films is fascinating. Historically, a positive ending is a scene in which the protagonist takes an action that gets him what he wants. Yet in all the works cited above, the protagonist either refuses to act on his obsession or throws away what he once desired. He or she wins by “losing.” Like solving the Zen riddle of the sound of one hand clapping, the writer’s problem in each case was how to make a nonaction or negative action feel positive.

在北达拉斯四十人队的高潮部分，全明星外接手菲利普·艾略特（尼克·诺尔特饰）张开双臂，让足球从他的胸前弹起，这个手势宣布他不会再玩这种幼稚的游戏了。

At the climax of NORTH DALLAS FORTY All-Star wide receiver Phillip Elliot (Nick Nolte) opens his arms and lets the football bounce off his chest, announcing in his gesture that he won’t play this childish game anymore.

《电动骑士》的结尾，昔日的牛仔竞技明星桑尼·斯蒂尔（罗伯特·雷德福饰）如今已沦落到靠贩卖早餐麦片为生，他将其赞助商的获奖种马放归野外，象征性地将自己从对名利的渴求中解放出来。

THE ELECTRIC HORSEMAN ends as the former rodeo star Sonny Steele (Robert Redford), now reduced to peddling breakfast cereal, releases his sponsor’s prize stallion into the wild, symbolically freeing himself from his need for fame.

《走出非洲》讲述了一位女性的故事，她践行着 20 世纪 80 年代“我拥有什么就是什么”的道德观。卡伦（梅丽尔·斯特里普饰）说的第一句话是：“我在非洲有一个农场。”她把家具从丹麦拖到肯尼亚，建造了一个家和种植园。她用自己的财产来定义自己，她把这些工人称为“她的人”，直到她的情人指出，她实际上并不拥有这些人。当她的丈夫把梅毒传染给她时，她没有和他离婚，因为她的身份是“妻子”，而这个身份是由她对丈夫的占有而定义的。然而，随着时间的推移，她开始意识到，你不是你所拥有的；你是你的价值观、才能和你能做的事情。当她的情人被杀时，她很悲伤，但并没有迷失，因为她不是他。她耸耸肩，放弃了丈夫、家、一切，放弃了她所拥有的一切，却获得了自我。

OUT OF AFRICA is the story of a woman living the 1980s ethic of “I am what I own.” Karen’s (Meryl Streep) first words are: “I had a farm in Africa.” She drags her furniture from Denmark to Kenya to build a home and plantation. She so defines herself by her possessions that she calls the laborers “her people” until her lover points out that she doesn’t actually own these people. When her husband infects her with syphilis, she doesn’t divorce him because her identity is “wife,” defined by her possession of a husband. In time, however, she comes to realize you are not what you own; you are your values, talents, what you can do. When her lover is killed, she grieves but is not lost because she is not he. With a shrug, she lets husband, home, everything go, surrendering all she had, but gaining herself.

《亲密的话语》讲述了一种截然不同的痴迷。奥罗拉（雪莉·麦克雷恩饰）奉行伊壁鸠鲁哲学，认为幸福意味着永不痛苦，生活的秘诀是避免一切消极情绪。她拒绝了两个众所周知的痛苦源头：事业和情人。她非常害怕变老的痛苦，所以穿得比自己年轻二十岁。她的家就像一个无人居住的娃娃屋。她唯一的生活就是通过女儿在电话里间接地了解她。但在她五十二岁生日那天，她开始意识到，你体验到的快乐深度与你愿意承受的痛苦成正比。在最后一幕中，她抛弃了无痛苦生活的空虚，拥抱孩子、情人、年龄，以及它们带来的所有快乐和悲伤。

TERMS OF ENDEARMENT tells of a very different obsession. Aurora (Shirley MacLaine) lives the Epicurean philosophy that happiness means never suffering, that the secret of life is to avoid all negative emotion. She refuses two renowned sources of misery, career and lovers. She’s so afraid of the pain of growing old, she dresses twenty years too young for herself. Her home has the unlived-in look of a doll’s house. The only life she leads is over the telephone vicariously through her daughter. But on her fifty-second birthday she begins to realize that the depth of joy you experience is in direct proportion to the pain you’re willing to bear. In the last act she throws away the emptiness of a pain-free life to embrace children, lover, age, and all the pleasure and woe they bring.

二、负面讽刺：

Second, the negative irony:

如果你执着于你的痴迷，你无情的追求将会实现你的愿望，然后毁灭你。

If you cling to your obsession, your ruthless pursuit will achieve your desire, then destroy you.

华尔街、赌场、玫瑰战争、80 年代之星、纳什维尔、电视台、他们射杀了马，对吧？——这些影片是上述救赎情节的惩罚情节对应物。在这些影片中，“结局令人沮丧”的反思想成为主控思想，因为主角仍然坚定地被对名声和成功的渴求所驱使，从未想过放弃它。在故事高潮中，主角实现了他们的愿望（积极的），却又被它摧毁（消极的）。在《尼克松》中，总统（安东尼·霍普金斯饰）对其政治权力的盲目、腐败的信任毁了他自己，也毁掉了国家对政府的信心。在《玫瑰》中，罗斯（贝特·米德勒饰）被她对毒品、性和摇滚乐的热爱所摧毁。在《爵士乐之王》中，乔·吉迪恩 (罗伊·施奈德饰) 因对毒品、性和音乐喜剧的神经质需求而堕落。

WALL STREET; CASINO; THE WAR OF THE ROSES; STAR ’80; NASHVILLE; NETWORK; THEY SHOOT HORSES, DON’T THEY?—these films are the Punitive Plot counterpart to the Redemption Plots above. In them the “down-ending” Counter-Idea becomes the Controlling Idea as protagonists remain steadfastly driven by their need to achieve fame or success, and never think to abandon it. At Story Climax the protagonists achieve their desire (positive), only to be destroyed by it (negative). In NIXON the president’s (Anthony Hopkins) blind, corrupt trust in his political power destroys him and with him the nation’s faith in government. In THE ROSE Rose (Bette Midler) is destroyed by her passion for drugs, sex, and rock ‘n’ roll. In ALL THAT JAZZ Joe Gideon (Roy Scheider) is brought down by his neurotic need for drugs, sex, and musical comedy.

论讽刺

On Irony

讽刺对观众的影响是“啊，生活就是这样”的奇妙反应。我们认识到理想主义和悲观主义是经验的极端，生活很少是阳光明媚和草莓般的，也不是全是厄运和悲观；它两者兼而有之。从最糟糕的经历中可以得到一些积极的东西；为了获得最丰富的经历，必须付出巨大的代价。无论我们如何试图规划一条笔直的人生道路，我们都在讽刺的潮流中航行。现实总是充满讽刺，这就是为什么以讽刺结尾的故事往往历久弥新，传播范围最广，并赢得观众最大的喜爱和尊重。

The effect of irony on an audience is that wonderful reaction, “Ah, life is just like that.” We recognize that idealism and pessimism are at the extremes of experience, that life is rarely all sunshine and strawberries, nor is it all doom and drek; it is both. From the worst of experiences something positive can be gained; for the richest of experiences a great price must be paid. No matter how we try to plot a straight passage through life, we sail on the tides of irony. Reality is relentlessly ironic, and this is why stories that end in irony tend to last the longest through time, travel the widest in the world, and draw the greatest love and respect from audiences.

这也是为什么在高潮时可能出现的三种情绪中，讽刺是最难写的。它需要最深的智慧和最高的技巧，原因有三。

This is also why, of the three possible emotional charges at climax, irony is by far the most difficult to write. It demands the deepest wisdom and the highest craft for three reasons.

首先，想出一个令人满意和信服的光明、理想主义的结局或一个严肃、悲观的高潮已经够难的了。但讽刺高潮是一个既有正面意义又有负面意义的单一动作。如何将两者合二为一呢？

First, it’s tough enough to come up with either a bright, idealistic ending or a sober, pessimistic climax that’s satisfying and convincing. But an ironic climax is a single action that makes both a positive and a negative statement. How to do two in one?

第二，如何把两者说清楚？讽刺并不意味着模棱两可。模棱两可是一种模糊；一件事与另一件事无法区分。但讽刺并不模棱两可；它清楚地、双重地宣告所得与所失，并列而立。讽刺也不意味着巧合。真正的讽刺是真诚地有动机的。以随机机会结束的故事，无论是否具有双重意义，都是毫无意义的，不是讽刺。

Second, how to say both clearly? Irony doesn’t mean ambiguity. Ambiguity is a blur; one thing cannot be distinguished from another. But there’s nothing ambiguous about irony; it’s a clear, double declaration of what’s gained and what’s lost, side by side. Nor does irony mean coincidence. A true irony is honestly motivated. Stories that end by random chance, doubly charged or not, are meaningless, not ironic.

第三，如果在高潮时主人公的生活状况既有积极的一面，也有消极的一面，那么该如何表达，才能让这两种情绪在观众的体验中保持分离，不至于互相抵消，最终什么也没说？

Third, if at climax the life situation of the protagonist is both positive and negative, how to express it so that the two charges remain separated in the audience’s experience and don’t cancel each other out, and you end up saying nothing?

意义与社会

MEANING AND SOCIETY

一旦你发现了你的主控思想，就尊重它。永远不要让自己奢望“这只是娱乐”。毕竟，“娱乐”是什么？娱乐是一种仪式，坐在黑暗中，盯着屏幕，投入巨大的注意力和精力，希望获得令人满意的、有意义的情感体验。任何能吸引、维持并实现故事仪式的电影都是娱乐。无论是《绿野仙踪》（美国/1939 年）还是《四百击》（法国/1959 年）、《甜蜜的生活》（意大利/1960 年）还是《白雪公主和三个臭皮匠》（美国/1961 年），没有一个故事是无辜的。所有连贯的故事都表达了隐藏在情感魔咒中的想法。

Once you discover your Controlling Idea, respect it. Never allow yourself the luxury of thinking, “It’s just entertainment.” What, after all, is “entertainment”? Entertainment is the ritual of sitting in the dark, staring at a screen, investing tremendous concentration and energy into what one hopes will be a satisfying, meaningful emotional experience. Any film that hooks, holds, and pays off the story ritual is entertainment. Whether it be THE WIZARD OF OZ (USA/1939) or THE 400 BLOWS (France/1959), LA DOLCE VITA (Italy/1960) or SNOW WHITE AND THE THREE STOOGES (USA/1961), no story is innocent. All coherent tales express an idea veiled inside an emotional spell.

公元前388 年，柏拉图敦促雅典城邦元老们流放所有诗人和讲故事的人。他认为，他们是社会的威胁。作家处理思想，但不是像哲学家那样以开放、理性的方式。相反，他们将思想隐藏在艺术的诱人情感中。然而，正如柏拉图指出的那样，感觉到的思想仍然是思想。每一个有效的故事都会向我们传达一个充满激情的思想，实际上是将这个想法强加给我们，让我们不得不相信。事实上，故事的说服力是如此之大，以至于我们可能会相信它意思是，即使我们认为它在道德上令人厌恶。柏拉图坚持认为，讲故事的人是危险的人。他是对的。

In 388 B.C. Plato urged the city fathers of Athens to exile all poets and storytellers. They are a threat to society, he argued. Writers deal with ideas, but not in the open, rational manner of philosophers. Instead, they conceal their ideas inside the seductive emotions of art. Yet felt ideas, as Plato pointed out, are ideas nonetheless. Every effective story sends a charged idea out to us, in effect compelling the idea into us, so that we must believe. In fact, the persuasive power of a story is so great that we may believe its meaning even if we find it morally repellent. Storytellers, Plato insisted, are dangerous people. He was right.

想想《死亡愿望》。它的主导思想是“当公民掌握法律并杀死需要杀死的人时，正义就会胜利。”在人类历史上所有卑鄙的想法中，这是最卑鄙的。纳粹利用它摧毁了欧洲。希特勒相信，只要杀死需要杀死的人，他就会把欧洲变成天堂……而且他有自己的名单。

Consider DEATH WISH. Its Controlling Idea is “Justice triumphs when citizens take the law into their own hands and kill the people who need killing.” Of all the vile ideas in human history, this is the vilest. Armed with it, the Nazis devastated Europe. Hitler believed he would turn Europe into a paradise once he killed the people who needed killing… and he had his list.

《死亡愿望》上映时，全国各地的报纸评论员看到查尔斯·布朗森在曼哈顿潜行，枪杀那些碰巧长得像强盗的人，都感到义愤填膺：“好莱坞认为这就是正义吗？”他们咆哮道。“正当法律程序怎么了？”但在我读到的几乎每篇评论中，评论家都会在某个地方指出：“……但观众似乎很喜欢它。”暗号：“……评论家也是如此。”评论家从不提及观众的乐趣，除非他们自己也喜欢。尽管他们有被震惊的感受，但这部电影也打动了他们。

When DEATH WISH opened, newspaper reviewers across the country were morally outraged at the sight of Charles Bronson stalking Manhattan, gunning down people if they happened to look like muggers: “Hollywood thinks this passes for justice?” they ranted. “Whatever became of due process of law?” But in nearly every review I read, at some point the critic noted: “… and yet the audience seemed to enjoy it.” A code for: “… and so did the critic.” Critics never cite the pleasure of the audience unless they share it. In spite of their scandalized sensibilities, the film got to them too.

另一方面，我不想生活在一个不能制造死亡愿望的国家。我反对一切审查制度。为了追求真理，我们必须心甘情愿地忍受最丑陋的谎言。正如霍姆斯法官所说，我们必须相信思想市场。如果每个人都有发言权，即使是非理性的激进分子或残酷的反动分子，人类也会筛选出所有可能性并做出正确的选择。包括柏拉图在内的任何文明都从未因为其公民了解了太多真理而遭到毁灭。

On the other hand, I wouldn’t want to live in a country where DEATH WISH couldn’t be made. I oppose all censorship. In pursuit of truth, we must willingly suffer the ugliest of lies. We must, as Justice Holmes argued, trust the marketplace of ideas. If everyone is given a voice, even the irrationally radical or cruelly reactionary, humanity will sort through all possibilities and make the right choice. No civilization, including Plato’s, has ever been destroyed because its citizens learned too much truth.

像柏拉图这样的权威人士所害怕的威胁不是来自思想，而是来自情感。当权者永远不想让我们感受到这种威胁。思想可以被控制和操纵，但情感是任性的、不可预测的。艺术家通过揭露谎言和激发变革的热情来威胁权威。这就是为什么当暴君夺取权力时，他们的行刑队瞄准了作家的心脏。

Authoritative personalities, like Plato, fear the threat that comes not from idea, but from emotion. Those in power never want us to feel. Thought can be controlled and manipulated, but emotion is willful and unpredictable. Artists threaten authority by exposing lies and inspiring passion for change. This is why when tyrants seize power, their firing squads aim at the heart of the writer.

最后，鉴于故事的影响力，我们需要审视艺术家的社会责任问题。我认为我们没有责任去治愈社会弊病或重振对人类的信心，没有责任去振奋社会精神，甚至没有责任去表达我们的内心。我们只有一个责任：讲真话。因此，研究你的故事达到高潮并从中提炼出你的主宰思想。但在你迈出下一步之前，先问自己这个问题：这是事实吗？我相信我的故事的意义吗？如果答案是否定的，那就把它扔掉，重新开始。如果答案是肯定的，那就尽一切可能让你的作品走向世界。因为尽管艺术家在私生活中可能会对别人撒谎，甚至对自己撒谎，但当他创作时，他说的是真话；在一个充满谎言和谎言的世界里，诚实的艺术作品永远是一种社会责任的行为。

Lastly, given story’s power to influence, we need to look at the issue of an artist’s social responsibility. I believe we have no responsibility to cure social ills or renew faith in humanity, to uplift the spirits of society or even express our inner being. We have only one responsibility: to tell the truth. Therefore, study your Story Climax and extract from it your Controlling Idea. But before you take another step, ask yourself this question: Is this the truth? Do I believe in the meaning of my story? If the answer is no, toss it and start again. If yes, do everything possible to get your work into the world. For although an artist may, in his private life, lie to others, even to himself, when he creates he tells the truth; and in a world of lies and liars, an honest work of art is always an act of social responsibility.

第三部分：故事设计的

原则





PART 3:

THE

PRINCIPLES

OF STORY

DESIGN

当被迫在严格的框架内工作时，想象力会被发挥到极致——并会产生最丰富的想法。如果完全自由，工作可能会变得杂乱无章。

When forced to work within a strict framework the imagination is taxed to its utmost—and will produce its richest ideas. Given total freedom the work is likely to sprawl.

—TS E.利奥特

—T. S. ELIOT

7

故事的实质

7

THE SUBSTANCE OF STORY

我们用什么材料创作出将来有一天会在银幕上行走和讲述的场景？我们扭曲和塑造、保留或丢弃的粘土是什么？故事的“实质”是什么？

From what material do we create the scenes that will one day walk and talk their way across the screen? What is the clay we twist and shape, keep or throw away? What is the “substance” of story?

在所有其他艺术领域，答案是不言而喻的。作曲家有他的乐器和它发出的音符。舞者称她的身体为她的乐器。雕塑家凿石头。画家搅拌颜料。所有艺术家都可以接触到他们艺术的原材料——除了作家。因为故事的核心是一种“物质”，就像原子中旋转的能量，它从未直接看到、听到或触摸过，但我们却知道并感受到它。故事的内容是活的，但又是无形的。

In all other arts the answer is self-evident. The composer has his instrument and the notes it sounds. The dancer calls her body her instrument. Sculptors chisel stone. Painters stir paint. All artists can lay hands on the raw material of their art—except the writer. For at the nucleus of a story is a “substance,” like the energy swirling in an atom, that’s never directly seen, heard, or touched, yet we know it and feel it. The stuff of story is alive but intangible.

“无形？”我听到你在想。“但我有文字。对话、描述。我可以把手放在纸上。作家的原始材料是语言。”事实上，语言不是，许多有才华的作家，尤其是那些在接受过良好的文学教育后从事编剧工作的作家，因为对这一原则的严重误解而陷入困境。因为就像玻璃是光的媒介，空气是声音的媒介一样，语言只是讲故事的一种媒介，事实上是众多媒介中的一种。故事的核心是比单纯的文字更深刻的东西。

“Intangible?” I hear you thinking. “But I have my words. Dialogue, description. I can put hands on my pages. The writer’s raw material is language.” In fact, it’s not, and the careers of many talented writers, especially those who come to screenwriting after a strong literary education, flounder because of the disastrous misunderstanding of this principle. For just as glass is a medium for light, air a medium for sound, language is only a medium, one of many, in fact, for storytelling. Something far more profound than mere words beats at the heart of a story.

故事的另一端是另一个同样深刻的现象：观众对这种物质的反应。仔细想想，去看电影是一件很奇怪的事情。数百名陌生人挤坐在一间漆黑的房间里，一坐就是两个多小时。他们不去厕所，也不抽烟。相反，他们睁大眼睛盯着屏幕，更加专注地观看电影。比他们投入到工作中更多，花钱去承受他们一生中会竭尽全力避免的情绪。从这个角度来看，第二个问题出现了：故事能量的来源是什么？它如何吸引观众如此强烈的精神和感知注意力？故事是如何运作的？

And at the opposite end of story sits another equally profound phenomenon: the audience’s reaction to this substance. When you think about it, going to the movies is bizarre. Hundreds of strangers sit in a blackened room, elbow to elbow, for two or more hours. They don’t go to the toilet or get a smoke. Instead, they stare wide-eyed at a screen, investing more uninterrupted concentration than they give to work, paying money to suffer emotions they’d do anything to avoid in life. From this perspective, a second question arises: What is the source of story energy? How does it compel such intense mental and sentient attention from the audience? How do stories work?

当艺术家主观地探索创作过程时，这些问题的答案就会出现。要理解故事的本质及其表现方式，你需要从内而外地审视你的作品，从角色的中心，通过角色的眼睛看世界，体验故事，就像你自己就是活生生的角色一样。要进入这种主观和高度富有想象力的视角，你需要仔细观察这个你打算扮演的生物，一个角色。或者更具体地说，一个主角。因为虽然主角和其他角色一样，作为中心和基本角色，他绝对体现了角色的所有方面。

The answers to these questions come when the artist explores the creative process subjectively. To understand the substance of story and how it performs, you need to view your work from the inside out, from the center of your character, looking out at the world through your character’s eyes, experiencing the story as if you were the living character yourself. To slip into this subjective and highly imaginative point of view, you need to look closely at this creature you intend to inhabit, a character. Or more specifically, a protagonist. For although the protagonist is a character like any other, as the central and essential role, he embodies all aspects of character in absolute terms.

主角

THE PROTAGONIST

一般情况下，主角都是一个角色。但是，一个故事可以由两个角色推动，比如《末路狂花》；也可以由三个角色推动，比如《东镇女巫》；甚至还有《七武士》或《十二金刚》。在《战舰波将金号》中，整个阶级，即无产阶级，创造了一个巨大的多元主角。

Generally, the protagonist is a single character. A story, however, could be driven by a duo, such as THELMA & LOUISE; a trio, THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK; more, THE SEVEN SAMURAI or THE DIRTY DOZEN. In THE BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN an entire class of people, the proletariat, create a massive Plural-Protagonist.

要让两个或多个角色组成一个复数主角，必须满足两个条件：首先，群体中的所有个体都有相同的愿望。其次，在实现这一愿望的斗争中，他们相互受益。如果一个人成功了，所有人都受益。如果一个人遭遇挫折，所有人都受苦。在复数主角中，动机、行动和后果都是共同的。

For two or more characters to form a Plural-Protagonist, two conditions must be met: First, all individuals in the group share the same desire. Second, in the struggle to achieve this desire, they mutually suffer and benefit. If one has a success, all benefit. If one has a setback, all suffer. Within a Plural-Protagonist, motivation, action, and consequence are communal.

另一方面，故事也可能是多主角的。与多主角不同，角色追求独立而个人的欲望，独立地受苦和受益：《低俗小说》、《汉娜姐妹》、《为人父母》、《小餐馆》、《为所应为》、《早餐俱乐部》、《吃喝男人女人》、《征服者佩尔》、《希望与荣耀》，寄予厚望。罗伯特·奥特曼是这个设计的大师：婚礼、纳什维尔、捷径。

A story may, on the other hand, be Multiprotagonist. Here, unlike the Plural-Protagonist, characters pursue separate and individual desires, suffering and benefiting independently: PULP FICTION, HANNAH AND HER SISTERS, PARENTHOOD, DINER, DO THE RIGHT THING, THE BREAKFAST CLUB, EAT DRINK MAN WOMAN, PELLE THE CONQUEROR, HOPE AND GLORY, HIGH HOPES. Robert Altman is the master of this design: A WEDDING, NASHVILLE, SHORT CUTS.

银幕上的多主角故事与《大饭店》一样古老；小说中的多主角故事更古老，如《战争与和平》；戏剧中的多主角故事更古老，如《仲夏夜之梦》。多主角故事成为多情节故事。这些作品不是通过主角（无论是单个还是多个）的集中欲望来推动叙述，而是编织了许多较小的故事，每个故事都有自己的主角，以创造特定社会的动态画像。

On screen the Multiprotagonist story is as old as GRAND HOTEL; in the novel older still, War and Peace; in the theatre older yet, A Midsummer Night’s Dream. Multiprotagonist stories become Multiplot stories. Rather than driving the telling through the focused desire of a protagonist, either single or plural, these works weave a number of smaller stories, each with its own protagonist, to create a dynamic portrait of a specific society.

主角不一定是人类。它可能是动物、小黄人、卡通人物、兔八哥，甚至是无生命的物体，例如儿童故事《小火车头做到了》中的主人公。任何能够被赋予自由意志和渴望、采取行动并承担后果的能力的东西都可以成为主角。

The protagonist need not be human. It may be an animal, BABE, or a cartoon, BUGS BUNNY, or even an inanimate object, such as the hero of the children’s story The Little Engine That Could. Anything that can be given a free will and the capacity to desire, take action, and suffer the consequences can be a protagonist.

在极少数情况下，故事进行到一半时主角甚至可能被更换。《惊魂记》就是这样做的，让淋浴谋杀案在情感和形式上都令人震惊。主角死后，观众一时感到困惑；这部电影是关于谁的？答案是多重主角，因为受害者的妹妹、男朋友和私家侦探接管了这个故事。但无论故事的主角是单、多还是复数，无论他如何被塑造，所有主角都具有某些标志性品质，而第一个就是意志力。

It’s even possible, in rare cases, to switch protagonists halfway through a story. PSYCHO does this, making the shower murder both an emotional and a formal jolt. With the protagonist dead, the audience is momentarily confused; whom is this movie about? The answer is a Plural-Protagonist as the victim’s sister, boyfriend, and a private detective take over the story. But no matter whether the story’s protagonist is single, multi or plural, no matter how he is characterized, all protagonists have certain hallmark qualities, and the first is willpower.

主角 (PROTAGONIST) 是一个任性的角色。

A PROTAGONIST is a willful character.

其他角色可能顽固，甚至不灵活，但主角却是一个任性的人。然而，这种意志力的确切数量可能无法衡量。一个好的故事不一定是巨大意志与绝对必然力量的斗争。意志的质量与数量同样重要。主角的意志力可能不如圣经中的约伯，但足以在冲突中保持欲望，并最终采取行动，创造有意义且不可逆转的改变。

Other characters may be dogged, even inflexible, but the protagonist in particular is a willful being. The exact quantity of this willpower, however, may not be measurable. A fine story is not necessarily the struggle of a gigantic will versus absolute forces of inevitability. Quality of will is as important as quantity. A protagonist’s willpower may be less than that of the biblical Job, but powerful enough to sustain desire through conflict and ultimately take actions that create meaningful and irreversible change.

此外，主人公意志的真正力量可能隐藏在被动的性格特征背后。想想布兰奇·杜波依斯，《欲望号街车》的女主角。乍一看，她似乎软弱、飘忽不定、意志薄弱，她说她只想活在现实中。然而，在她脆弱的性格之下，布兰奇的深沉性格拥有强大的意志，驱使着她无意识的欲望：她真正想要的是逃离现实。所以布兰奇尽其所能来保护自己免受这个丑陋世界的吞噬：她扮演贵妇，给破旧的家具铺上桌布，给裸露的灯泡戴上灯罩，试图把一个笨蛋变成白马王子。当这些都失败时，她最终逃离了现实——她疯了。

What’s more, the true strength of the protagonist’s will may hide behind a passive characterization. Consider Blanche DuBois, protagonist of A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE. At first glance she seems weak, drifting and will-less, only wanting, she says, to live in reality. Yet beneath her frail characterization, Blanche’s deep character owns a powerful will that drives her unconscious desire: What she really wants is to escape from reality. So Blanche does everything she can to buffer herself against the ugly world that engulfs her: She acts the grand dame, puts doilies on frayed furniture, lampshades on naked light bulbs, tries to make a Prince Charming out of a dullard. When none of this succeeds, she takes the final escape from reality—she goes insane.

另一方面，虽然布兰奇只是看起来很被动，但真正被动的主角却是一个令人遗憾的常见错误。一个不想要任何东西、不会做决定、其行为在任何层面上都无法产生任何改变的主角的故事是无法讲述的。

On the other hand, while Blanche only seems passive, the truly passive protagonist is a regrettably common mistake. A story cannot be told about a protagonist who doesn’t want anything, who cannot make decisions, whose actions effect no change at any level.

主角有一个有意识的愿望。

The PROTAGONIST has a conscious desire.

相反，主角的意志会驱使已知的欲望。主角有需求或目标，有欲望的对象，并且知道这一点。如果你能把主角拉到一边，在他耳边低语，“你想要什么？”他会回答：“我今天想要 X，下周想要 Y，但最终我想要 Z。”主角的欲望对象可能是外在的：《大白鲨》中鲨鱼的毁灭，或内在的：《飞越未来》中的成熟。无论哪种情况，主角都知道自己想要什么，对于许多角色来说，一个简单、清晰、有意识的欲望就足够了。

Rather, the protagonist’s will impels a known desire. The protagonist has a need or goal, an object of desire, and knows it. If you could pull your protagonist aside, whisper in his ear, “What do you want?” he would have an answer: “I’d like X today, Y next week, but in the end I want Z.” The protagonist’s object of desire may be external: the destruction of the shark in JAWS, or internal: maturity in BIG. In either case, the protagonist knows what he wants, and for many characters a simple, clear, conscious desire is sufficient.

主角也可能有自相矛盾的潜意识欲望。

The PROTAGONIST may also have a self-contradictory unconscious desire.

然而，最令人难忘、最迷人的角色往往不仅有有意识的欲望，还有无意识的欲望。尽管这些复杂的主角没有意识到他们的潜意识需求，但观众却能感觉到，在他们身上感受到一种内在矛盾。多维主角的有意识和无意识欲望相互矛盾。他认为自己想要的东西与他实际上但无意识地想要的东西是对立的。这是不言而喻的。如果角色的潜意识欲望恰好是他有意识追求的东西，那么赋予它潜意识欲望有什么意义呢？

However, the most memorable, fascinating characters tend to have not only a conscious but an unconscious desire. Although these complex protagonists are unaware of their subconscious need, the audience senses it, perceiving in them an inner contradiction. The conscious and unconscious desires of a multidimensional protagonist contradict each other. What he believes he wants is the antithesis of what he actually but unwittingly wants. This is self-evident. What would be the point of giving a character a subconscious desire if it happens to be the very thing he knowingly seeks?

主角有能力令人信服地追求欲望对象。

The PROTAGONIST has the capacities to pursue the Object of Desire convincingly.

主角的性格塑造必须恰当。他需要可信的品质组合，以恰当的平衡来追求自己的愿望。这并不意味着他会得到他想要的东西。他可能会失败。但角色的愿望必须与他的意志和能力足够现实，让观众相信他可以做他们看到他做的事情，并且他有机会实现愿望。

The protagonist’s characterization must be appropriate. He needs a believable combination of qualities in the right balance to pursue his desires. This doesn’t mean he’ll get what he wants. He may fail. But the character’s desires must be realistic enough in relationship to his will and capacities for the audience to believe that he could be doing what they see him doing and that he has a chance for fulfillment.

主角至少要有机会实现他的愿望。

The PROTAGONIST must have at least a chance to attain his desire.

观众对一个完全没有实现愿望的可能性的主角没有耐心。原因很简单：没有人相信自己的生活会这样。没有人相信他连实现愿望的最小机会都没有。但如果我们把镜头拉回到生活，宏观的概览可能会让我们得出这样的结论：用亨利·戴维·梭罗的话来说，“大多数人过着平静的绝望生活”，大多数人浪费了宝贵的时间，死时感觉自己没有实现梦想。尽管这个痛苦的见解可能是真实的，但我们不能让自己相信它。相反，我们会把希望坚持到底。

An audience has no patience for a protagonist who lacks all possibility of realizing his desire. The reason is simple: No one believes this of his own life. No one believes he doesn’t have even the smallest chance of fulfilling his wishes. But if we were to pull the camera back on life, the grand overview might lead us to conclude that, in the words of Henry David Thoreau, “The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation,” that most people waste their precious time and die with the feeling they’ve fallen short of their dreams. As honest as this painful insight may be, we cannot allow ourselves to believe it. Instead, we carry hope to the end.

毕竟，希望并非不合理。它只是假设。“如果这样……如果那样……如果我学得更多……如果我爱得更多……如果我约束自己……如果我中了彩票……如果事情有所改变，那么我就有机会从生活中得到我想要的东西。”无论我们面临的困难有多大，我们都心怀希望。因此，一个完全绝望、甚至连实现愿望的最低限度的能力都没有的主角，是无法引起我们兴趣的。

Hope, after all, is not unreasonable. It’s simply hypothetical. “If this… if that… if I learn more… if I love more… if I discipline myself… if I win the lottery… if things change, then I’ll have a chance of getting from life what I want.” We all carry hope in our hearts, no matter the odds against us. A protagonist, therefore, who’s literally hopeless, who hasn’t even the minimal capacity to achieve his desire, cannot interest us.

主角具有意志和能力去追求他有意识和/或无意识渴望的目标，直到终点，达到场景和类型所设定的人类极限。

The PROTAGONIST has the will and capacity to pursue the object of his conscious and/or unconscious desire to the end of the line, to the human limit established by setting and genre.

故事的艺术不是关于中间地带，而是关于存在钟摆摆动到极限，关于生活在最激烈的状态。我们探索体验的中间范围，但只是作为一条通往终点的路径。观众感觉到那个极限并希望达到它。因为无论背景多么亲密或史诗般，观众都会本能地在人物和他们的世界周围画一个圆圈，一个由虚构现实的性质定义的体验周长。这条线可以向内延伸到灵魂，向外延伸到宇宙，或者同时向两个方向延伸。因此，观众希望讲故事的人是一位有远见的艺术家，能够将他的故事带到遥远的深度和广度。

The art of story is not about the middle ground, but about the pendulum of existence swinging to the limits, about life lived in its most intense states. We explore the middle ranges of experience, but only as a path to the end of the line. The audience senses that limit and wants it reached. For no matter how intimate or epic the setting, instinctively the audience draws a circle around the characters and their world, a circumference of experience that’s defined by the nature of the fictional reality. This line may reach inward to the soul, outward into the universe, or in both directions at once. The audience, therefore, expects the storyteller to be an artist of vision who can take his story to those distant depths and ranges.

故事必须发展到一个观众无法想象的最终情节。

A STORY must build to a final action beyond which the audience cannot imagine another.

换句话说，电影不能让观众在街头重新改写它：“大团圆结局……但她不应该和她父亲和解吗？她不应该在和麦克同居之前和艾德分手吗？她不应该……”或者：“令人沮丧……那家伙死了，但他为什么不报警？他不是在车内放了把枪吗？他不应该……吗？”如果人们在离开时想象他们认为应该在我们给他们的结局之前或之后看到的场景，他们就不会成为快乐的电影观众。我们应该比他们更擅长写作。观众希望被带到极限，到所有问题都得到解答，所有情感都得到满足的地方——终点。

In other words, a film cannot send its audience to the street rewriting it: “Happy ending… but shouldn’t she have settled things with her father? Shouldn’t she have broken up with Ed before she moved in with Mac? Shouldn’t she have…” Or: “Downer… the guy’s dead, but why didn’t he call the cops? And didn’t he keep a gun under the dash, and shouldn’t he have…?” If people exit imagining scenes they thought they should have seen before or after the ending we give them, they will be less than happy moviegoers. We’re supposed to be better writers than they. The audience wants to be taken to the limit, to where all questions are answered, all emotion satisfied—the end of the line.

主角把我们带到了这个极限。他必须有内心去追求他的愿望，在深度、广度或两者兼而有之的范围内探索人类经验的边界，以达到绝对和不可逆转的改变。顺便说一句，这并不意味着你的电影不能有续集；主角可能还有更多故事要讲。这意味着每个故事都必须找到自己的结局。

The protagonist takes us to this limit. He must have it within himself to pursue his desire to the boundaries of human experience in depth, breadth, or both, to reach absolute and irreversible change. This, by the way, doesn’t mean your film can’t have a sequel; your protagonist may have more tales to tell. It means that each story must find closure for itself.

主角必须富有同理心；他可能有同情心，也可能没有。

The PROTAGONIST must be empathetic; he may or may not be sympathetic.

同情意味着讨人喜欢。例如汤姆·汉克斯和梅格·瑞恩，或者斯宾塞·特蕾西和凯瑟琳·赫本的典型角色：他们一出现在银幕上，我们就喜欢他们。我们希望他们成为朋友、家人或爱人。他们天生就讨人喜欢，让人产生同情。然而，同理心是一种更深刻的反应。

Sympathetic means likable. Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan, for example, or Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn in their typical roles: The moment they step onscreen, we like them. We’d want them as friends, family members, or lovers. They have an innate likability and evoke sympathy. Empathy, however, is a more profound response.

感同身受意味着“像我一样”。观众在主人公的内心深处认识到某种共同的人性。当然，角色和观众并非在各个方面都一样；他们可能只有一个共同的品质。但角色身上总有一些东西能引起共鸣。在那一刻，观众突然本能地希望主人公实现他所渴望的一切。

Empathetic means “like me.” Deep within the protagonist the audience recognizes a certain shared humanity. Character and audience are not alike in every fashion, of course; they may share only a single quality. But there’s something about the character that strikes a chord. In that moment of recognition, the audience suddenly and instinctively wants the protagonist to achieve whatever it is that he desires.

观众的潜意识逻辑是这样的：“这个角色和我一样。因此，我希望他能得到他想要的一切，因为如果我是他，在那种情况下，我也会想得到同样的东西。”好莱坞有许多同义词来表达这种联系：“有人支持”、“有人加油”。所有这些都描述了观众与主角之间产生的共情联系。如果观众被感动，可能会对电影中的每个角色产生共情，但他们必须对主角产生共情。否则，观众/故事的纽带就被打破了。

The unconscious logic of the audience runs like this: “This character is like me. Therefore, I want him to have whatever it is he wants, because if I were he in those circumstances, I’d want the same thing for myself.” Hollywood has many synonymic expressions for this connection: “somebody to get behind,” “someone to root for.” All describe the empathetic connection that the audience strikes between itself and the protagonist. An audience may, if so moved, empathize with every character in your film, but it must empathize with your protagonist. If not, the audience/story bond is broken.

观众纽带

THE AUDIENCE BOND

观众的情感投入是由同理心的粘合剂所维系的。如果编剧未能将电影观众与主角之间的纽带融合在一起，我们坐在外面什么感觉也没有。投入与唤起利他主义或同情心无关。我们出于非常个人的原因产生同理心，即使不是以自我为中心的原因。当我们认同主角和他生活中的欲望，实际上，我们也在为自己生活中的欲望加油打气。通过同理心，将自己与虚构人物联系起来，我们测试并拓展了我们的人性。故事的礼物是让我们有机会超越自我，在无数的世界和时代，在我们存在的各个深度中渴望和奋斗。

The audience’s emotional involvement is held by the glue of empathy. If the writer fails to fuse a bond between filmgoer and protagonist, we sit outside feeling nothing. Involvement has nothing to do with evoking altruism or compassion. We empathize for very personal, if not egocentric, reasons. When we identify with a protagonist and his desires in life, we are in fact rooting for our own desires in life. Through empathy, the vicarious linking of ourselves to a fictional human being, we test and stretch our humanity. The gift of story is the opportunity to live lives beyond our own, to desire and struggle in a myriad of worlds and times, at all the various depths of our being.

因此，同理心是绝对的，而同情心则是可选的。我们都遇到过讨人喜欢却不会引起我们同情的人。因此，主角可能讨人喜欢，也可能不讨人喜欢。一些作家没有意识到同情心和同理心之间的区别，他们会自动设计出好人英雄，担心如果主角不讨人喜欢，观众就不会产生共鸣。然而，无数的商业灾难都以迷人的主角为主角。讨人喜欢并不能保证观众参与其中；它只是人物塑造的一个方面。观众认同深刻的人物性格，认同在压力下通过选择而展现出的内在品质。

Empathy, therefore, is absolute, while sympathy is optional. We’ve all met likable people who don’t draw our compassion. A protagonist, accordingly, may or may not be pleasant. Unaware of the difference between sympathy and empathy, some writers automatically devise nice-guy heroes, fearing that if the star role isn’t nice, the audience won’t relate. Uncountable commercial disasters, however, have starred charming protagonists. Likability is no guarantee of audience involvement; it’s merely an aspect of characterization. The audience identifies with deep character, with innate qualities revealed through choice under pressure.

乍一看，创造同理心似乎并不难。主角是人，观众也是人。当电影观众抬头看银幕时，他认识到角色的人性，感觉到他也有这种人性，与主角产生共鸣，并沉浸在故事中。事实上，在最伟大的作家手中，即使是最冷酷无情的角色也能让人产生同理心。

At first glance creating empathy does not seem difficult. The protagonist is a human being; the audience is full of human beings. As the filmgoer looks up on the screen, he recognizes the character’s humanity, senses that he shares it, identifies with the protagonist, and dives into the story. Indeed, in the hands of the greatest writers, even the most unsympathetic character can be made empathetic.

例如，从客观的角度看，麦克白是一个恶魔。他杀死了一位慈祥的老国王，而这位国王从未伤害过麦克白——事实上，就在那天，他还给了麦克白一个王室晋升。麦克白随后谋杀了国王的两名仆人，并将此事嫁祸给他们。他杀死了他最好的朋友。最后，他下令暗杀敌人的妻子和幼子。他是一个冷酷无情的杀手；然而，在莎士比亚的笔下，他成为了一个悲剧性的、令人同情的英雄。

Macbeth, for example, viewed objectively, is monstrous. He butchers a kindly old King while the man is sleeping, a King who had never done Macbeth any harm—in fact, that very day he’d given Macbeth a royal promotion. Macbeth then murders two servants of the King to blame the deed on them. He kills his best friend. Finally he orders the assassination of the wife and infant children of his enemy. He’s a ruthless killer; yet, in Shakespeare’s hands he becomes a tragic, empathetic hero.

莎士比亚通过赋予麦克白良知来实现这一壮举。当他在独白中徘徊，苦苦思索，“我为什么要这样做？我是什么样的人？”观众听了会想，“什么样的人？充满内疚……就像我一样。当我想到要做坏事时，我会感到难过。当我做这些事时，我会感到很可怕，事后内疚感永无止境。麦克白是一个人类；他和我一样有良知。”事实上，我们被麦克白痛苦的灵魂所吸引，当麦克德夫在高潮时斩首时，我们感到一种悲剧性的失落。麦克白是作家神力的惊人展现，他在一个原本卑鄙的角色身上找到了同情的中心。

The Bard accomplished this feat by giving Macbeth a conscience. As he wanders in soliloquy, wondering, agonizing, “Why am I doing this? What kind of a man am I?” the audience listens and thinks, “What kind? Guilt-ridden… just like me. I feel bad when I’m thinking about doing bad things. I feel awful when I do them and afterward there’s no end to the guilt. Macbeth is a human being; he has a conscience just like mine.” In fact, we’re so drawn to Macbeth’s writhing soul, we feel a tragic loss when at climax Macduff decapitates him. Macbeth is a breathtaking display of the godlike power of the writer to find an empathetic center in an otherwise contemptible character.

另一方面，近年来，许多电影尽管质量上乘，却因为未能与观众建立联系而遭遇惨败。《夜访吸血鬼》就是其中一个例子。观众对布拉德·皮特饰演的路易斯的反应是：“如果我是路易斯，陷入死后地狱，我会立刻结束这一切。不幸的是，他是个吸血鬼。我不希望任何人这样。但如果他觉得吸食无辜受害者的生命是令人厌恶的，如果他讨厌自己把孩子变成魔鬼，如果他厌倦了老鼠血，他应该采取这个简单的解决办法：等到日出，然后，噗，一切都结束了。”尽管安妮·赖斯的小说引导我们了解路易斯的思想和感受，直到我们对他产生同情，但镜头冷静的眼光却看到了他的真面目，一个爱抱怨的骗子。观众总是与伪君子划清界限。

On the other hand, in recent years many films, despite otherwise splendid qualities, have crashed on these rocks because they failed to create an audience bond. Just one example of many: INTERVIEW WITH A VAMPIRE. The audience’s reaction to Brad Pitt’s Louis went like this: “If I were Louis, caught in his hell-after-death, I’d end it in a flash. Bad luck he’s a vampire. Wouldn’t wish that on anybody. But if he finds it revolting to suck the life out of innocent victims, if he hates himself for turning a child into a devil, if he’s tired of rat blood, he should take this simple solution: Wait for sunrise, and poof, it’s over.” Although Anne Rice’s novel steered us through Louis’s thoughts and feelings until we fell into empathy with him, the dispassionate eye of the camera sees him for what he is, a whining fraud. Audiences always disassociate themselves from hypocrites.

第一步

THE FIRST STEP

当你坐下来写作时，你就会开始思考：“如何开始？我的角色会做什么？”

When you sit down to write, the musing begins: “How to start? What would my character do?”

你的角色，事实上所有的角色，在故事的任何时刻，在追求任何欲望时，都会从他的角度采取最小、最保守的行动。所有人类都是如此。人类本质上是保守的，事实上自然界也是如此。没有生物会消耗超过必要范围的能量，冒不必要的风险，或者在非必要的情况下采取任何行动。为什么要这样做？如果一项任务可以轻松完成，没有损失或痛苦的风险，也不需要消耗能量，为什么任何生物会去做更困难、更危险或更耗费精力的事情？它不会。大自然不允许……而人性只是普遍自然的一个方面。

Your character, indeed all characters, in the pursuit of any desire, at any moment in story, will always take the minimum, conservative action from his point of view. All human beings always do. Humanity is fundamentally conservative, as indeed is all of nature. No organism ever expends more energy than necessary, risks anything it doesn’t have to, or takes any action unless it must. Why should it? If a task can be done in an easy way without risk of loss or pain, or the expenditure of energy, why would any creature do the more difficult, dangerous, or enervating thing? It won’t. Nature doesn’t allow it… and human nature is just an aspect of universal nature.

在生活中，我们经常看到人们，甚至是动物，做出一些看似不必要的极端行为，甚至是愚蠢的行为。但这是我们对他们处境的客观看法。主观上，从经验中就这个生物而言，这种看似过激的行为是最低限度的、保守的和必要的。毕竟，人们认为的“保守”总是与观点有关。

In life we often see people, even animals, acting with extreme behavior that seems unnecessary, if not stupid. But this is our objective view of their situation. Subjectively, from within the experience of the creature, this apparently intemperate action was minimal, conservative, and necessary. What’s thought “conservative,” after all, is always relative to point of view.

例如：如果一个普通人想进屋，他会采取最低限度和保守的行动。他会敲门，想着，“如果我敲门，门就会打开。我会被邀请进来，这将是实现我愿望的积极一步。”然而，武术英雄作为保守的第一步，可能会用空手道把门砍成碎片，觉得这是谨慎和最低限度的。

For example: If a normal person wanted to get into a house, he’d take the minimum and conservative action. He’d knock on the door, thinking, “If I knock, the door’ll be opened. I’ll be invited in and that’ll be a positive step toward my desire.” A martial arts hero, however, as a conservative first step, might karate-chop the door to splinters, feeling that this is prudent and minimal.

必要但最低限度和保守的做法是相对于每个角色在每个特定时刻的观点而言的。例如，在生活中，我对自己说：“如果我现在过马路，那辆车离我足够远，司机可以及时看到我，必要时放慢速度，然后我就能过马路了。”或者：“我找不到多洛雷斯的电话号码。但我知道我的朋友杰克在他的 Rolodex 里有这个号码。如果我在他忙碌的一天中给他打电话，因为他是我的朋友，他会停下手头的工作，把电话号码告诉我。”

What is necessary but minimal and conservative is relative to the point of view of each character at each precise moment. In life, for example, I say to myself: “If I cross the street now, that car’s far enough away for the driver to see me in time, slow down if needed, and I’ll get across.” Or: “I can’t find Dolores’s phone number. But I know that my friend Jack has it in his Rolodex. If I call him in the midst of his busy day, because he’s my friend, he’ll interrupt what he’s doing and give me the number.”

换句话说，在生活中，我们有意识或无意识地采取行动（生活中大多数时候都是自发的，就像我们张口说话或迈出一步一样），内心会这样想或感觉：“如果在这种情况下我采取这种最低限度的保守行动，世界就会对我做出积极的反应，让我能够得到我想要的东西。”在生活中，99% 的时间我们都是对的。司机及时看到你，踩下刹车，你安全到达了另一边。你打电话给杰克，为打扰他而道歉。他说：“没问题”，并给了你电话号码。这是生活中每时每刻的大量经验。但在故事中，永远、永远都不会发生。

In other words, in life we take an action consciously or unconsciously (and life is spontaneous most of the time as we open our mouths or take a step), thinking or sensing within to this effect: “If in these circumstances I take this minimum, conservative action, the world will react to me in a fashion that will be a positive step toward getting me what I want.” And in life, 99 percent of the time we are right. The driver sees you in time, taps the brakes, and you reach the other side safely. You call Jack and apologize for interrupting him. He says, “No problem,” and gives you the number. This is the great mass of experience, hour by hour, in life. BUT NEVER, EVER IN A STORY.

故事与生活之间的巨大差异在于，在故事中，我们抛弃了日常生活中的琐碎细节，人类采取行动，期望从世界获得某种有利的反应，并且或多或少地得到他们所期望的。

The grand difference between story and life is that in story we cast out the minutiae of daily existence in which human beings take actions expecting a certain enabling reaction from the world, and, more or less, get what they expect.

在故事中，我们专注于那个时刻，也只关注那个时刻，即人物采取行动并期待从他的世界得到有用的反应，但他的行动却激起了对抗力量。角色世界的反应与预期不同，比预期更强烈，或两者兼而有之。

In story, we concentrate on that moment, and only that moment, in which a character takes an action expecting a useful reaction from his world, but instead the effect of his action is to provoke forces of antagonism. The world of the character reacts differently than expected, more powerfully than expected, or both.

我拿起电话，打电话给杰克，说：“很抱歉打扰你，但我找不到多洛雷斯的电话号码。你能——”他大喊：“多洛雷斯？多洛雷斯！你怎么敢问我她的电话号码？”然后摔了电话。突然间，生活变得有趣起来。

I pick up the phone, call Jack, and say: “Sorry to bother you, but I can’t find Dolores’s phone number. Could you—” and he shouts: “Dolores? Dolores! How dare you ask me for her number?” and slams down the phone. Suddenly, life is interesting.

角色的世界

THE WORLD OF A CHARACTER

本章从一位作家的角度来探讨故事的本质，这位作家在自己的想象中将自己置于所创造角色的中心。人类的“中心”，即内心深处不可或缺​​的特殊性，是你一天 24 小时都带着的意识，它注视着你所做的一切，在你做错事时责备你，或者在你做对事时称赞你。当你经历人生中最痛苦的经历，倒在地上，痛哭流涕时，正是这位深邃的观察者来到你身边……那个小小的声音说：“你的睫毛膏在脱落。”这双内在的眼睛就是你：你的身份、你的自我、你存在的意识焦点。这个主观核心之外的一切都是一个角色的客观世界。

This chapter seeks the substance of story as seen from the perspective of a writer who in his imagination has placed himself at the very center of the character he’s creating. The “center” of a human being, that irreducible particularity of the innermost self, is the awareness you carry with you twenty-four hours a day that watches you do everything you do, that chides you when you get things wrong, or compliments you on those rare occasions when you get things right. It’s that deep observer that comes to you when you’re going through the most agonizing experience of your life, collapsed on the floor, crying your heart out… that little voice that says, “Your mascara is running.” This inner eye is you: your identity, your ego, the conscious focus of your being. Everything outside this subjective core is the objective world of a character.

角色的世界可以想象为一系列围绕原始身份或意识核心的同心圆，这些圆标志着角色生活中的冲突层次。内圈或层次是角色自身以及由其天性元素（思想、身体、情感）引起的冲突。

A character’s world can be imagined as a series of concentric circles surrounding a core of raw identity or awareness, circles that mark the levels of conflict in a character’s life. The inner circle or level is his own self and conflicts arising from the elements of his nature: mind, body, emotion.

例如，当一个角色采取行动时，他的思想可能不会像他预期的那样做出反应。他的思维可能不像他预期的那样敏捷、有洞察力、机智。他的身体可能不会像他想象的那样做出反应。它可能不够强壮或不够灵巧，无法完成某项任务。我们都知道情绪会背叛我们。因此，角色世界中最近的对抗圈就是他自己的存在：感觉和情绪、思想和身体，所有这些或任何一个都可能或可能不会按照他预期的方式在一刻到下一刻做出反应。很多时候，我们就是自己最大的敌人。

When, for example, a character takes an action, his mind may not react the way he anticipates. His thoughts may not be as quick, as insightful, as witty as he expected. His body may not react as he imagined. It may not be strong enough or deft enough for a particular task. And we all know how emotions betray us. So the closest circle of antagonism in the world of a character is his own being: feelings and emotions, mind and body, all or any of which may or may not react from one moment to the next the way he expects. As often as not, we are our own worst enemies.

冲突的三个层次

THE THREE LEVELS OF CONFLICT

第二个圆圈代表个人关系，即比社会角色更深的亲密关系。社会习俗指定了我们扮演的外在角色。例如，目前我们扮演的是老师/学生的角色。但有一天，我们可能会有交集，我们可能会决定将职业关系转变为友谊。同样，父母/子女的关系始于社会角色，可能比社会角色更深入，也可能不深入。我们中的许多人一生都在父母/子女关系中度过，这种关系从未超越社会对权威和反叛的定义。直到我们把传统的角色放在一边，我们才会找到家庭、朋友和恋人之间的真正亲密关系——他们不会像我们期望的那样做出反应，成为个人冲突的第二层。

The second circle inscribes personal relationships, unions of intimacy deeper than the social role. Social convention assigns the outer roles we play. At the moment, for example, we’re playing teacher/student. Someday, however, our paths may cross and we may decide to change our professional relationship to friendship. In the same manner, parent/child begins as social roles that may or may not go deeper than that. Many of us go through life in parent/child relationships that never deepen beyond social definitions of authority and rebellion. Not until we set the conventional role aside do we find the true intimacy of family, friends, and lovers—who then do not react the way we expect and become the second level of personal conflict.

第三个圆圈标记了个人之外的冲突水平——所有个人之外的对抗根源：与社会机构和个人的冲突——政府/公民、教会/信徒；公司/客户；与个人的冲突——警察/罪犯/受害者、老板/工人、顾客/服务员、医生/病人；与人造环境和自然环境的冲突——时间、空间及其中的每一个物体。

The third circle marks the level of extra-personal conflict—all the sources of antagonism outside the personal: conflict with social institutions and individuals—government/citizen, church/worshipper; corporation/client; conflict with individuals—cop/criminal/victim, boss/worker, customer/waiter, doctor/patient; and conflict with both man-made and natural environments—time, space, and every object in it.

差距

THE GAP

故事诞生于主观与客观领域接触的地方。

STORY is born in that place where the subjective and objective realms touch.

主角寻求一个超出他能力范围的欲望对象。他有意或无意地选择采取某种行动，其动机是认为这一行动将使世界做出反应，从而朝着实现他的欲望迈出积极的一步。从他的主观观点来看，他选择的行动似乎微不足道、保守，但足以产生他想要的反应。但当他采取这一行动时，他的内心生活、个人关系或个人以外的世界（或这些的组合）的客观领域会做出比他预期更强烈或不同的反应。

The protagonist seeks an object of desire beyond his reach. Consciously or unconsciously he chooses to take a particular action, motivated by the thought or feeling that this act will cause the world to react in a way that will be a positive step toward achieving his desire. From his subjective point of view the action he has chosen seems minimal, conservative, yet sufficient to effect the reaction he wants. But the moment he takes this action, the objective realm of his inner life, personal relationships, or extra-personal world, or a combination of these, react in a way that’s more powerful or different than he expected.

来自他世界的反应阻碍了他的欲望，使他受挫，并使他比在采取行动之前更加偏离自己的欲望。他的行动非但没有激发他世界的合作，反而激起了对抗的力量，扩大了他主观期望与客观结果之间的差距，扩大了他采取行动时认为会发生什么与事实上发生的事情之间的差距，扩大了他概率感与真正必要性之间的差距。

This reaction from his world blocks his desire, thwarting him and bending him further from his desire than he was before he took this action. Rather than evoking cooperation from his world, his action provokes forces of antagonism that open up the gap between his subjective expectation and the objective result, between what he thought would happen when he took his action and what in fact does happen between his sense of probability and true necessity.

每个人的行为都是基于他对概率的感觉，基于他采取行动时最有可能发生的事情的预期，无论是有意还是无意。我们行走在这片土地上，都认为，或者至少希望，我们了解自己、我们的亲朋好友、社会和世界。我们根据自己认为的关于自己、我们周围的人和环境的真相行事。但这是我们无法绝对知道的真相。这就是我们所相信的真相。

Every human being acts, from one moment to the next, knowingly or unknowingly, on his sense of probability, on what he expects, in all likelihood, to happen when he takes an action. We all walk this earth thinking, or at least hoping, that we understand ourselves, our intimates, society, and the world. We behave according to what we believe to be the truth of ourselves, the people around us, and the environment. But this is a truth we cannot know absolutely. It’s what we believe to be true.

我们还相信，我们可以自由地做出任何决定，采取任何行动。但我们做出和采取的每一个选择和行动，无论是自发的还是有意的，都植根于我们的全部经验，植根于当时发生在我们身上的现实、想象或梦境。然后，我们根据生活的这种聚集告诉我们的世界可能做出的反应来选择行动。只有这样，当我们采取行动时，我们才会发现必要性。

We also believe we’re free to make any decision whatsoever to take any action whatsoever. But every choice and action we make and take, spontaneous or deliberate, is rooted in the sum total of our experience, in what has happened to us in actuality, imagination, or dream to that moment. We then choose to act based on what this gathering of life tells us will be the probable reaction from our world. It’s only then, when we take action, that we discover necessity.

必然性是绝对真理。必然性就是我们行动时实际发生的事情。只有当我们深入世界并勇敢面对其反应时，我们才能知道这一真理，而且也只能知道这一真理。无论我们之前相信什么，这一反应都是我们当时存在的真相。必然性是必须发生且确实发生的事情，与概率相反，概率是我们希望或期望发生的事情。

Necessity is absolute truth. Necessity is what in fact happens when we act. This truth is known—and can only be known—when we take action into the depth and breadth of our world and brave its reaction. This reaction is the truth of our existence at that precise moment, no matter what we believed the moment before. Necessity is what must and does actually happen, as opposed to probability, which is what we hope or expect to happen.

生活如此，小说亦然。当客观必然性与人物的概率感相矛盾时，虚构现实中就会突然出现差距。这个差距是主观和客观领域的碰撞点，是预期和结果之间的差异，是人物在行动前所感知的世界与他在行动中发现的真相之间的差异。

As in life, so in fiction. When objective necessity contradicts a character’s sense of probability, a gap suddenly cracks open in the fictional reality. This gap is the point where the subjective and objective realms collide, the difference between anticipation and result, between the world as the character perceived it before acting and the truth he discovers in action.

一旦现实中的差距裂开，这个有意志力和能力的角色就会感觉到或意识到，他无法以最低限度、保守的方式得到他想要的东西。他必须振作起来，努力突破这个差距，采取第二个行动。这个下一步行动是角色在第一种情况下不想做的事情，因为它不仅需要更多的意志力，迫使他更深入地挖掘自己的人类能力，而且最重要的是，第二个行动让他处于危险之中。他现在必须失去才能获得。

Once the gap in reality splits open, the character, being willful and having capacity, senses or realizes that he cannot get what he wants in a minimal, conservative way. He must gather himself and struggle through this gap to take a second action. This next action is something the character would not have wanted to do in the first case because it not only demands more willpower and forces him to dig more deeply into his human capacity, but most important, the second action puts him at risk. He now stands to lose in order to gain.

面临风险

ON RISK

我们都想鱼与熊掌兼得。另一方面，在处于危险之中时，我们必须冒着失去想要或已经拥有的东西的风险，才能得到我们想要的其他东西或保护我们已经拥有的东西——这是我们努力避免的困境。

We’d all like to have our cake and eat it too. In a state of jeopardy, on the other hand, we must risk something that we want or have in order to gain something else that we want or to protect something we have—a dilemma we strive to avoid.

这是一个适用于任何故事的简单测试。问：风险是什么？如果主角得不到他想要的东西，他会失去什么？更具体地说，如果主角没有实现他的愿望，最糟糕的事情是什么？

Here’s a simple test to apply to any story. Ask: What is the risk? What does the protagonist stand to lose if he does not get what he wants? More specifically, what’s the worst thing that will happen to the protagonist if he does not achieve his desire?

如果不能以令人信服的方式回答这个问题，那么这个故事从本质上就是错误的。例如，如果答案是：“如果主角失败了，生活就会恢复正常”，那么这个故事就不值得讲述。主角想要的东西没有真正的价值，而追求价值不大或毫无价值的东西的故事就是无聊的定义。

If this question cannot be answered in a compelling way, the story is misconceived at its core. For example, if the answer is: “Should the protagonist fail, life would go back to normal,” this story is not worth telling. What the protagonist wants is of no real value, and a story of someone pursuing something of little or no value is the definition of boredom.

生活告诉我们，任何人类欲望的价值衡量标准都与追求它所涉及的风险成正比。价值越高，风险越大。我们赋予那些需要承担终极风险的东西终极价值——我们的自由、我们的生命、我们的灵魂。然而，这种风险的必要性远不止是一种美学原则，它植根于我们艺术的最深层源泉。因为我们不仅创造故事作为生活的隐喻，我们还创造故事作为有意义的生活的隐喻——而有意义的生活就是永远处于风险之中。

Life teaches that the measure of the value of any human desire is in direct proportion to the risk involved in its pursuit. The higher the value, the higher the risk. We give the ultimate values to those things that demand the ultimate risks—our freedom, our lives, our souls. This imperative of risk, however, is far more than an aesthetic principle, it’s rooted in the deepest source of our art. For we not only create stories as metaphors for life, we create them as metaphors for meaningful life—and to live meaningfully is to be at perpetual risk.

审视自己的欲望。对你而言是真实的，对别人而言也是真实的。你笔下的每一个角色。你希望为电影写作，因为电影是当今世界最重要的创意表达媒体；你希望给我们带来美丽而有意义的作品，帮助我们塑造对现实的看法；作为回报，你希望得到认可。这是一个崇高的抱负和一项伟大的成就。因为你是一个严肃的艺术家，所以你愿意冒着生命中至关重要的风险去实现这个梦想。

Examine your own desires. What’s true of you will be true of every character you write. You wish to write for the cinema, the foremost media of creative expression in the world today; you wish to give us works of beauty and meaning that help shape our vision of reality; in return you would like to be acknowledged. It’s a noble ambition and a grand achievement to fulfill. And because you’re a serious artist, you’re willing to risk vital aspects of your life to live that dream.

你愿意冒着时间风险。你知道，即使是最有才华的作家——奥利弗·斯通、劳伦斯·卡斯丹、露丝·普劳尔·贾布瓦拉——也要到三四十岁才能取得成功，就像要花十年或更长时间才能成为一名好医生或好老师一样，要掌握这门高难度的技艺，需要十年或更长时间，而且往往需要写出同样多的剧本，但都卖不出去。

You’re willing to risk time. You know that even the most talented writers—Oliver Stone, Lawrence Kasdan, Ruth Prawer Jhabvala—didn’t find success until they were in their thirties or forties, and just as it takes a decade or more to make a good doctor or teacher, it takes ten or more years of adult life to find something to say that tens of millions of people want to hear, and ten or more years and often as many screenplays written and unsold to master this demanding craft.

你愿意冒金钱风险。你知道，如果你把十年未售出剧本所付出的辛勤工作和创造力运用到正常的职业中，那么你可能会在看到你的第一部剧本出现在屏幕上之前就退休了。

You’re willing to risk money. You know that if you were to take the same hard work and creativity that goes into a decade of unsold screenplays and apply it to a normal profession, you could retire before you see your first script on the screen.

你愿意为他人冒险。每天早晨，你坐在书桌前，进入你笔下人物的想象世界。你梦想着、写作着，直到太阳落山，你的头开始抽痛。于是你关掉文字处理器，与你爱的人在一起。不过，虽然你可以关掉机器，但你无法关掉你的想象力。当你坐下来吃晚饭时，你的人物仍然在你的脑海里浮现，你希望你的盘子旁边有一本记事本。迟早，你爱的人会说：“你知道……你并不真的在这里。”这是真的。一半的时间你都在别的地方，没有人愿意和一个不在这里的人住在一起。

You’re willing to risk people. Each morning you go to your desk and enter the imagined world of your characters. You dream and write until the sun’s setting and your head’s throbbing. So you turn off your word processor to be with the person you love. Except that, while you can turn off your machine, you can’t turn off your imagination. As you sit at dinner, your characters are still running through your head and you’re wishing there was a notepad next to your plate. Sooner or later, the person you love will say: “You know… you’re not really here.” Which is true. Half the time you’re somewhere else, and no one wants to live with somebody who isn’t really there.

作家将时间、金钱和人置于危险之中，因为他的野心具有决定人生的力量。对作家而言，对他所创造的每个角色而言，都是如此：

The writer places time, money, and people at risk because his ambition has life-defining force. What’s true for the writer is true for every character he creates:

人物欲望的价值衡量标准与他为实现欲望愿意承担的风险成正比；价值越大，风险越大。

The measure of the value of a character’s desire is in direct proportion to the risk he’s willing to take to achieve it; the greater the value, the greater the risk.

进步的差距

THE GAP IN PROGRESSION

主人公的第一次行动激起了敌意，阻碍了他的愿望，并在预期和结果之间拉开了差距，使他对现实的认识出现偏差，使他与世界产生更大的冲突，甚至面临更大的风险。但坚韧不拔的人类心灵很快将现实重塑为一个更大的模式，将这种偏差、这种意想不到的反应纳入其中。现在，他采取了第二个更困难、更冒险的行动，这一行动符合他对现实的修正看法，基于他对世界的新期望。但他的行动再次激起了敌意，在他的现实中拉开了差距。因此，他适应了意外情况，再次加大赌注，决定采取他认为与他修正后的事物观念一致的行动。他更加深入地发挥自己的能力和意志力，将自己置于更大的风险之中，并采取了第三个行动。

The protagonist’s first action has aroused forces of antagonism that block his desire and spring open a gap between anticipation and result, disconfirming his notions of reality, putting him in greater conflict with his world, at even greater risk. But the resilient human mind quickly remakes reality into a larger pattern that incorporates this disconfirmation, this unexpected reaction. Now he takes a second, more difficult and risk-taking action, an action consistent with his revised vision of reality, an action based on his new expectations of the world. But again his action provokes forces of antagonism, splitting open a gap in his reality. So he adjusts to the unexpected, ups the ante yet again and decides to take an action that he feels is consistent with his amended sense of things. He reaches even more deeply into his capacities and willpower, puts himself at greater risk, and takes a third action.

也许这一行动取得了积极成果，他暂时向自己的愿望迈出了一步，但随着他的下一个行动，差距将再次出现。现在他必须采取更困难的行动，这需要更多的意志力、更大的能力和更大的风险。他的行为一次又一次地激起对抗力量，而不是合作，在他的现实中打开了缺口。这种模式在各个层面上重复，直到终点，直到观众无法想象的最后一个行动。

Perhaps this action achieves a positive result, and for the moment he takes a step toward his desire, but with his next action, the gap will again spring open. Now he must take an even more difficult action that demands even more willpower, more capacity, and more risk. Over and over again in a progression, rather than cooperation, his actions provoke forces of antagonism, opening gaps in his reality. This pattern repeats on various levels to the end of the line, to a final action beyond which the audience cannot imagine another.

这些瞬间现实中的裂缝标志着戏剧化和平淡化、行动和活动之间的区别。真正的行动是身体、声音或精神上的活动，它打破了预期的差距，并带来了重大变化。单纯的活动是预期发生的事情的行为，要么没有变化，要么变化微不足道。

These cracks in moment-to-moment reality mark the difference between the dramatic and the prosaic, between action and activity. True action is physical, vocal, or mental movement that opens gaps in expectation and creates significant change. Mere activity is behavior in which what is expected happens, generating either no change or trivial change.

但期望与结果之间的差距远不止是因果关系。从最深刻的意义上讲，表面上的原因与结果之间的断裂标志着人类精神与世界的交汇点。一边是我们所相信的世界，另一边是现实。在这个差距中，故事的纽带，是熔铸我们故事的熔炉。在这里，作家找到了最强大、最能改变生活的时刻。我们能够到达这个关键节点的唯一方法是从内而外地努力。

But the gap between expectation and result is far more than a matter of cause and effect. In the most profound sense, the break between the cause as it seemed and the effect as it turns out marks the point where the human spirit and the world meet. On one side is the world as we believe it to be, on the other is reality as it actually is. In this gap is the nexus of story, the caldron that cooks our tellings. Here the writer finds the most powerful, life-bending moments. The only way we can reach this crucial junction is by working from the inside out.

从内而外的写作

WRITING FROM THE INSIDE OUT

为什么我们必须这样做？为什么在创作一个场景时我们必须找到每个角色的中心并从他的角度去体验它？如果我们这样做，我们会得到什么？如果我们不这样做，我们会牺牲什么？

Why must we do this? Why during the creation of a scene must we find our way to the center of each character and experience it from his point of view? What do we gain when we do? What do we sacrifice if we don’t?

例如，我们可以像人类学家一样，通过仔细观察发现社会和环境真相。像做笔记的心理学家一样，我们可以发现行为真相。我们可以从外向内地描绘出性格的外表，让它显得真实，甚至令人着迷。但我们不会创造的一个关键维度是情感真相。

Like anthropologists, we could, for example, discover social and environmental truths through careful observations. Like note-taking psychologists, we could find behavioral truths. We could, by working from the outside in, render a surface of character that’s genuine, even fascinating. But the one crucial dimension we would not create is emotional truth.

唯一可靠的情感真相来源就是你自己。如果你置身于角色之外，你不可避免地会写出陈词滥调的情感。要创造出具有启发性的人性反应，你不仅必须进入角色，还必须进入你自己。那么，如何做到这一点？当你坐在书桌前时，你如何进入角色的头脑，感受你的心跳、手心出汗、腹部打结、眼中含泪、心中笑意、性唤起、愤怒、愤慨、同情、悲伤、快乐，或人类情感范围内无数的反应？

The only reliable source of emotional truth is yourself. If you stay outside your characters, you inevitably write emotional clichés. To create revealing human reactions, you must not only get inside your character, but get inside yourself. So, how to do this? How, as you sit at your desk, do you crawl inside the head of your character to feel your heart pounding, your palms sweating, a knot in your belly, tears in your eyes, laughter in your heart, sexual arousal, anger, outrage, compassion, sadness, joy, or any of the uncountable responses along the spectrum of human emotions?

你已经确定了故事中必须发生某个事件，某个需要发展和转变的情境。如何写出充满深刻情感的场景？你可以问：一个人应该如何采取这一行动？但这会导致陈词滥调和说教。或者你可以问：一个人怎么才能做到这一点？但这会导致写得“可爱”——聪明但不诚实。或者：“如果我的角色在这种情况下，他会怎么做？”但这会让你与故事保持距离，想象你的角色走在他的人生舞台上，猜测他的情绪，而猜测往往是陈词滥调。或者你可以问：“如果我在这种情况下，我会怎么做？”当这个问题在你的想象中发挥作用时，它可能会让你心跳加速，但显然你不是这个角色。虽然对你来说这可能是一种真实的情感，但你的角色可能会做相反的事情。那么你会怎么做呢？

You’ve determined that a certain event must take place in your story, a situation to be progressed and turned. How to write a scene of insightful emotions? You could ask: How should someone take this action? But that leads to clichés and moralizing. Or you could ask: How might someone do this? But that leads to writing “cute”—clever but dishonest. Or: “If my character were in these circumstances, what would he do?” But that puts you at a distance, picturing your character walking the stage of his life, guessing at his emotions, and guesses are invariably clichés. Or you could ask: “If I were in these circumstances, what would I do?” As this question plays on your imagination, it may start your heart pounding, but obviously you’re not the character. Although it may be an honest emotion for you, your character might do the reverse. So what do you do?

你问自己：“如果我是这个角色，在这种情况下，我会怎么做？”使用斯坦尼斯拉夫斯基的“魔法如果”，你扮演这个角色。从欧里庇得斯到莎士比亚再到品特，从 DW 格里菲斯到露丝戈登再到约翰塞尔斯，许多最伟大的剧作家都是演员，这并非偶然。作家是即兴表演者，他们坐在文字处理器前表演，在房间里踱步，扮演他们所有的角色：男人、女人、孩子、怪物。我们在想象中表演，直到诚实、具体的角色情感在我们的血液中流动。当一个场景对我们来说具有情感意义时，我们可以相信它对观众来说也具有意义。通过创作让我们感动的作品，我们感动了他们。

You ask: “If I were this character in these circumstances, what would I do?” Using Stanislavski’s “Magic if,” you act the role. It is no accident that many of the greatest playwrights from Euripides to Shakespeare to Pinter, and screenwriters from D. W. Griffith to Ruth Gordon to John Sayles were also actors. Writers are improvisationalists who perform sitting at their word processors, pacing their rooms, acting all their characters: man, woman, child, monster. We act in our imaginations until honest, character-specific emotions flow in our blood. When a scene is emotionally meaningful to us, we can trust that it’ll be meaningful to the audience. By creating work that moves us, we move them.

唐人街

CHINATOWN

为了从内到外说明写作，我将使用电影中最著名、最精彩的场景之一，即编剧罗伯特·汤恩 (Robert Towne) 的《唐人街》第二幕高潮。我将根据屏幕上的场景进行创作，但也可以在汤恩 1973 年 10 月 9 日的剧本第三稿中找到它。

To illustrate writing from the inside out, I’ll use one of the most famous and brilliantly written scenes in film, the second act climax of CHINATOWN by screenwriter Robert Towne. I’ll work from the scene as performed on screen, but it can also be found in the third draft of Towne’s screenplay, dated October 9, 1973.

概要

Synopsis

私家侦探 JJ Gittes 正在调查洛杉矶水电局局长 Hollis Mulwray 的死因。Mulwray 显然是溺水身亡，而这一犯罪行为让 Gittes 的对手、警官 Escobar 感到困惑。在第二幕的结尾，Gittes 将嫌疑人和作案动机缩小到两个：要么是一群百万富翁密谋杀害 Mulwray，而凶手是残忍的 Noah Cross，他们为获取政治权力和财富而谋杀了 Mulwray；要么是 Evelyn Mulwray 在丈夫被发现与另一名女性在一起后，出于嫉妒而杀死了他。

Private detective J. J. Gittes is investigating the death of Hollis Mulwray, commissioner of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. Mulwray has apparently drowned in a reservoir, and the crime baffles Gittes’s rival, Police Lieutenant Escobar. Near the end of the Act Two, Gittes has narrowed suspects and motives to two: either a conspiracy of millionaires led by the ruthless Noah Cross killed Mulwray for political power and riches; or Evelyn Mulwray killed her husband in a jealous rage after he was found with another woman.

吉蒂斯跟踪伊芙琳来到圣莫尼卡的一所房子。透过窗户，他看到了“另一个女人”，似乎被下了药，被关在了监狱里。当伊芙琳走到她的车旁时，他强迫她说话，她声称那个女人是她的妹妹。吉蒂斯知道她没有妹妹，但暂时什么也没说。

Gittes follows Evelyn to a house in Santa Monica. Peering through a window, he sees the “other woman,” seemingly drugged and held prisoner. When Evelyn comes out to her car, he forces her to talk and she claims that the woman is her sister. Gittes knows she doesn’t have a sister, but for the moment says nothing.

第二天早上，他在洛杉矶山上的穆尔雷家的咸水池里发现了似乎是死者的眼镜。现在他知道了该男子是如何以及在何处被杀的。有了这些证据，他回到圣莫尼卡与伊芙琳对质，并将她交给埃斯科瓦尔，后者威胁要吊销吉特斯的私人侦探执照。

The next morning he discovers what appears to be the dead man’s eyeglasses in a salt water pond at the Mulwray home in the hills above L.A. Now he knows how and where the man was killed. With this evidence he goes back to Santa Monica to confront Evelyn and turn her over to Escobar, who’s threatening to pull Gittes’s private investigator’s license.

人物

CHARACTERS

JJ GITTES 在为地方检察官工作时爱上了唐人街的一名女子，在试图帮助她时却不知何故害死了她。他辞职并成为一名私家侦探，希望逃离腐败的政治和他悲惨的过去。但现在他又被卷入了这两件事。更糟糕的是，他发现自己陷入这种困境是因为在谋杀案发生的前几天，他被骗去调查 Mulwray 的通奸行为。有人愚弄了 Gittes，他是一个过度骄傲的人。在他冷静的举止背后是一个冲动的冒险者；他讽刺的玩世不恭掩盖了一个理想主义者对正义的渴望。更复杂的是，他爱上了 Evelyn Mulwray。Gittes 的场景目标：找出真相。

J.J. GITTES, while working for the district attorney, fell in love with a woman in Chinatown and while trying to help her somehow caused her death. He resigned and became a PI, hoping to escape corrupt politics and his tragic past. But now he’s drawn back into both. What’s worse, he finds himself in this predicament because, days before the murder, he was duped into investigating Mulwray for adultery. Someone’s made a fool of Gittes and he’s a man of excessive pride. Behind his cool demeanor is an impulsive risk-taker; his sarcastic cynicism masks an idealist’s hunger for justice. To further complicate matters, he’s fallen in love with Evelyn Mulwray. Gittes’s scene objective: to find the truth.

伊芙琳·穆尔雷是受害者的妻子，也是诺亚·克罗斯的女儿。当被问及丈夫时，她很紧张，很防备；当提到父亲时，她结结巴巴。我们感觉到她是一个有隐瞒的女人。她雇佣吉蒂斯调查她丈夫的谋杀案，也许是为了掩盖自己的罪行。然而，在调查过程中，她似乎对他很感兴趣。在从暴徒手中侥幸逃脱后，他们做爱了。伊芙琳的场景目标是：隐藏她的秘密并与凯瑟琳一起逃跑。

EVELYN MULWRAY is the victim’s wife and daughter of Noah Cross. She’s nervous and defensive when questioned about her husband; she stammers when her father is mentioned. She is, we sense, a woman with something to hide. She has hired Gittes to look into the murder of her husband, perhaps to conceal her own guilt. During the investigation, however, she seems drawn to him. After a close escape from some thugs, they make love. Evelyn’s scene objective: to hide her secret and escape with Katherine.

KHAN 是 Evelyn 的仆人。现在她丧偶了，他也将自己视为她的保镖。他以自己庄重的举止和处理困难情况的能力而自豪。Khan 的场景目标：保护 Evelyn。

KHAN is Evelyn’s servant. Now that she’s widowed, he also sees himself as her bodyguard. He prides himself on his dignified manner and ability to handle difficult situations. Khan’s scene objective: to protect evelyn.

凯瑟琳是一个害羞、天真的女孩，她过着非常受保护的生活。凯瑟琳的场景目标：服从伊芙琳。

KATHERINE is a shy innocent who has lead a very protected life. Katherine’s scene objective: to obey evelyn.

现场：

THE SCENE:

内景/外景 圣莫尼卡—别克—搬家—白天

INT./ EXT. SANTA MONICA—BUICK—MOVING—DAY

吉蒂斯驾车穿过洛杉矶。

Gittes drives through Los Angeles.

要从内而外地进行，请在 Gittes 开车前往 Evelyn 的藏身处时潜入他的脑海。想象自己在 Gittes 的当街道滚动过去时，你问道：

To work from the inside out, slip in Gittes’ mind while he drives to Evelyn’s hideaway. Imagine yourself in Gittes’ pov. As the streets roll past, you ask:

“如果我现在就是吉蒂斯，我会做什么呢？”

“If I were Gittes at this moment, what would I do?”

让你的想象力飞翔，答案是：

Letting your imagination roam, the answer comes:

“排练。在面对生活中的重大挑战之前，我总是在脑海里进行排练。”

“Rehearse. I always rehearse in my head before taking on life’s big confrontations.”

现在更深入地探究吉蒂斯的情感和心理：

Now work deeper into Gittes’s emotions and psyche:

双手紧握方向盘，思绪万千：“她杀了他，然后利用我。她对我撒谎，勾引我。天哪，我爱上了她。我心如刀绞，但我会保持冷静。我会走到门口，走进去指控她。她撒谎。我叫警察来。她装无辜，流了几滴眼泪。但我保持冷静，给她看穆尔雷的眼镜，然后一步一步地说明她是如何做到的，就好像我在场一样。她坦白了。我把她交给埃斯科瓦尔；我摆脱了困境。”

Hands white-knuckled on the steering wheel, thoughts racing: “She killed him, then used me. She lied to me, came on to me. Man, I fell for her. My guts are in a knot, but I’ll be cool. I’ll stroll to the door, step in and accuse her. She lies. I send for the cops. She plays innocent, a few tears. But I stay ice cold, show her Mulwray’s glasses, then lay out how she did it, step by step, as if I was there. She confesses. I turn her over to Escobar; I’m off the hook.”

外部平房-圣莫尼卡

EXT. BUNGALOW-SANTA MONICA

吉蒂斯的车加速驶入车道。

Gittes’ car speeds into the driveway.

你继续从 Gittes 的角度思考：

You continue working from inside Gittes’ pov, thinking:

“我会冷静的，我会冷静的……”突然，看到她的房子，伊芙琳的形象闪现在你的脑海中。一阵愤怒袭来。你的冷静决心和你的愤怒之间出现了一道裂缝。

“I’ll be cool, I’ll be cool…” Suddenly, with the sight of her house, an image of Evelyn flashes in your imagination. A rush of anger. A gap cracks open between your cool resolve and your fury.

别克车猛地停了下来。吉蒂斯跳了出来。

The Buick SCREECHES to a halt. Gittes jumps out.

“让她见鬼去吧！”

“To hell with her!”

吉蒂斯“砰”的一声关上车门，冲上台阶。

Gittes SLAMS the car door and bolts up the steps.

“趁她还没跑，赶紧抓住她。”

“Grab her now, before she runs.”

他转动门把手，发现门被锁上了，然后猛地敲门。

He twists the door knob, find it locked, then BANGS on the door.

“他妈的。”

“Goddamn it.”

内部平房

INT. BUNGALOW

伊芙琳的中国仆人汗 (KHAN) 听到敲门声，便朝门口走去。

KHAN, Evelyn’s Chinese servant, hears POUNDING and heads for the door.

随着角色的出现和退出，在你的想象中来回转换，先从一个角色的角度，然后再从另一个角色的角度。转到 Khan 的角度，问问自己：

As characters enter and exit, shift back and forth in your imagination, taking the pov of one, then the other. Moving to Khan’s point of view, ask yourself:

“如果此刻我是汗，我会想什么、感受什么，会做什么？”

“If I were Khan at this moment, what would I think, feel, do?”

当你深入了解这个角色的心理时，你的想法是：

As you settle into this character’s psyche, your thoughts run to:

“那他妈是谁？”管家露出微笑。“十有八九又是那个大嘴巴侦探。我来对付他。”

“Who the hell’s that?” Paste on a butler’s smile. “Ten to one it’s that loud mouth detective again. I’ll handle him.”

汗打开门，发现吉蒂斯站在台阶上。

Khan unlocks the door and finds Gittes on the step.

汗

KHAN

      你等待。

      You wait.

回到吉蒂斯的脑海中：

Shifting back into Gittes’ mind:

“又是那个傲慢的管家。”

“That snotty butler again.”

吉蒂斯：

你等着。滚开，小混混！

（翻译：滚开

，小混混）

GITTES

You wait. Chow hoy kye dye!

(translation: Fuck

off, punk)

吉蒂斯把汗推到一边，走进了屋子。

Gittes shoves Khan aside and pushes into the house.

当你切换回 Khan 时，期望和结果之间的突然差距让你笑得前仰后合：

As you switch back to Khan, the sudden gap between expectation and result inverts your smile:

困惑，愤怒。“他不仅闯进来，还用粤语侮辱我！把他赶出去！”

Confusion, anger. “He not only barges in but insults me in Cantonese! Throw him out!”

吉蒂斯抬起头，看见伊芙琳出现在卡恩身后的楼梯上，一边走下楼梯，一边紧张地调整着她的项链。

Gittes looks up as Evelyn appears on the stairs behind Khan, nervously adjusting her necklace as she descends.

正如 Khan 所说：

As Khan:

“这是穆尔雷夫人。保护她！”

“It’s Mrs. Mulwray. Protect her!”

伊芙琳一上午都在给吉蒂斯打电话，希望得到他的帮助。收拾了几个小时的行李后，她急着赶上 5:30 去墨西哥的火车。你换到她的角度：

Evelyn has been calling Gittes all morning, hoping to get his help. After packing for hours, she’s in a hell-bent rush to catch the 5:30 train to Mexico. You shift to her pov:

“如果我是伊芙琳，处于这种情况我会怎么做？”

“If I were Evelyn in this situation, what would I do?”

现在，找到通往这位非常复杂的女人内心的途径：

Now find your way to the heart of this very complex woman:

“是杰克。感谢上帝。我知道他关心我。他会帮助我的。我看起来怎么样？”手本能地摸摸头发和脸。“可汗看起来很担心。”

“It’s Jake. Thank God. I know he cares. He’ll help me. How do I look?” Hands instinctively flutter to hair, face. “Khan looks worried.”

伊芙琳向汗安慰地笑了笑，示意他离开。

Evelyn smiles reassuringly to Khan and gestures for him to leave.

伊芙琳

EVELYN

没关系，可汗。

It’s all right, Khan.

伊芙琳转身对吉蒂斯说：

As Evelyn turning back to Gittes:

感觉更加自信了。“现在我不再孤单了。”

Feeling more confident. “Now I’m not alone.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

你好吗？我一直在

给你打电话。

How are you? I’ve been

calling you.

客厅内部——相同

INT. LIVING ROOM—SAME

吉蒂斯转身走进客厅。

Gittes turns away and steps into the living room.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“她太漂亮了。别看她。坚强点，老兄。做好准备。她会一再撒谎。”

“She’s so beautiful. Don’t look at her. Stay tough, man. Be ready. She’ll tell lie on lie.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

… 是的？

… Yeah?

伊芙琳跟在后面，观察着他的脸。

Evelyn follows, searching his face.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

“我没法看清他的表情。有什么东西在困扰着他。他看上去很疲惫……”

“I can’t get his eye. Something’s bothering him. He looks exhausted…”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

你睡着了吗？

Did you get some sleep?

吉蒂斯

GITTES

当然。

Sure.

“……而且还是饥饿的可怜的人。”

“… and hungry, poor man.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

你吃午饭了吗？Khan

可以给你做点东西。

Have you had lunch? Khan

can fix you something.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“这是什么鬼午餐？现在就吃吧。”

“What’s this lunch bullshit? Do it now.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

女孩在哪儿？

Where’s the girl?

伊芙琳的脑海中浮现出一个令人震惊的预期差距：

Back in Evelyn’s thoughts as a gap in expectation flies open with a shock:

“他为什么问这个？出了什么问题？保持冷静。假装无辜。”

“Why’s he asking that? What’s gone wrong? Keep calm. Feign innocence.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

楼上的，为什么呢？

Upstairs, why?

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“柔和的声音，天真的‘为什么？’保持冷静。”

“The soft voice, the innocent ‘why?’ Keep cool.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

我想见她。

I want to see her.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

“他想从凯瑟琳那儿得到什么？不。我现在不能让他见她。撒谎。先搞清楚。”

“What does he want with Katherine? No. I can’t let him see her now. Lie. Find out first.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

……她正在洗澡，

你干嘛要见她？

… She’s having a bath now.

Why do you want to see her?

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

讨厌她的谎言。“别让她影响到你。”

Disgusted with her lies. “Don’t let her get to ya.”

吉蒂斯环顾房间，看到半打包的行李箱。

Gittes looks around the room and sees half-packed suitcases.

“她正在逃跑。幸好我赶到了。保持警惕。她会再次撒谎。”

“She’s making a run for it. Good thing I got here. Keep sharp. She’ll lie again.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

要去某個地方嗎？

Going somewhere?

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

“应该告诉他，但没时间了。没法隐瞒。说实话。他会理解的。”

“Should have told him, but there wasn’t time. Can’t hide it. Tell the truth. He’ll understand.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

是的，我们要赶 5:30 的火车。

Yes, we have a 5:30 train to catch.

作为 Gittes，出现了一个小缺口：

As Gittes, a minor gap opens:

“你知道什么？听起来很诚实。没关系。别再跟她胡扯了。让她知道你是认真的。电话在哪儿？在那里。”

“What do ya know? Sounds honest. Doesn’t matter. Put an end to her bullshit. Let her know you mean business. Where’s the phone? There.”

吉蒂斯拿起电话。

Gittes picks up the telephone.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

困惑，窒息的恐惧。“他在给谁打电话？”

Bewilderment, choking fear. “Who’s he calling?”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

杰克……？

Jake…?

“他正在拨号。上帝啊，救救我……”

“He’s dialing. God, help me…”

吉蒂斯一边听着电话，一边说道：

As Gittes, ear to the phone:

“该死的，回答我。”听到值班警官接了电话。

“Answer, damn it.” Hearing the desk sergeant pick up.

吉蒂斯

GITTES

JJ Gittes 饰演埃斯科巴中尉。

J. J. Gittes for Lt. Escobar.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

“警察！”一阵肾上腺素的分泌袭来。一阵恐慌。“不，不。保持冷静。保持冷静。一定是霍利斯的事。但我等不及了。我们必须现在就走。”

“The police!” A rush of adrenaline hits. Panic. “No, no. Keep calm. Keep calm. It must be about Hollis. But I can’t wait. We have to leave now.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

听着，怎么了？

出了什么问题？我告诉过你

我们有 5:30 的火车——

Look, what’s the matter?

What’s wrong? I told you

we’ve got a 5:30 train—

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“够了！让她闭嘴。”

“Enough! Shut her up.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

你会错过火车的。

You’re gonna miss your train.

（接通電話）

(into phone)

卢，在 1972 Canyon

Drive 见我……是的，你尽快吧

。

Lou, meet me at 1972 Canyon

Drive… yeah, soon as you

can.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

怒火中烧。“这个傻瓜……”一丝希望。“但也许他是在报警求助。”

Anger rises. “The fool…” A shred of hope. “But maybe he’s calling the police to help me.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

你为什么这么做？

Why did you do that?

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

得意洋洋。“她想变得强硬起来，但我现在控制住了她。感觉很好。我感觉就像在家一样。”

Smug satisfaction. “She’s trying to get tough, but I’ve got her now. Feels good. I’m right at home.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

（把帽子扔到

(tossing his hat on

桌子）

the table)

您认识哪些优秀的刑事律师？

You know any good criminal lawyers?

就像伊芙琳 (Evelyn) 试图缩小不断扩大的差距一样：

As Evelyn, trying to close an ever-widening gap:

“律师？他到底是什么意思？”一种可怕的恐惧感油然而生。

“Lawyers? What the hell does he mean?” A chilling fear of something terrible about to happen.

伊芙琳

EVELYN

不。

No.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“看看她，冷静而镇定，始终装作无辜。”

“Look at her, cool and collected, playing it innocent to the end.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

（拿出一枚银币

(taking out a silver

烟盒）

cigarette case)

别担心。我可以推荐

Don’t worry. I can recommend

一对。它们很贵，

a couple. They’re expensive,

但你可以负担得起。

but you can afford it.

吉蒂斯平静地从口袋里掏出打火机，坐下来，点燃一支香烟。

Gittes calmly takes a lighter from his pocket, sits down and lights a cigarette.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

“天哪，他威胁我。我和他睡过觉。看他那架势。他以为他是谁？”喉咙因愤怒而紧绷。“别慌张。处理好。这肯定是有原因的。”

“My God, he’s threatening me. I slept with him. Look at him swagger. Who does he think he is?” Throat tightens in anger. “Don’t panic. Handle it. There must be a reason for this.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

你能告诉我这是什么吗

Will you please tell me what this

是关于什么的？

is all about?

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“生气了，是吗？好。看这个。”

“Pissed off, are ya? Good. Watch this.”

吉蒂斯把打火机放回口袋，同时掏出一条包好的手帕。他把手帕放在桌上，小心地拉开手帕的四个角，露出眼镜。

Gittes slips the cigarette lighter back into his pocket and with the same motion brings out a wrapped handkerchief. He sets it on the table and carefully pulls back the four corners of the cloth to reveal the eyeglasses.

吉蒂斯

GITTES

我在你的后院发现了这些东西

I found these in your back-yard

在池塘里。他们

in the pond. They

属于你的丈夫，

belonged to your husband,

难道他们不是……难道他们不是吗？

didn’t they… didn’t they?

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

缝隙无法弥合。头晕目眩。一切都失去了意义。恐惧感油然而生。“眼镜？在霍利斯的鱼塘里？他在找什么？”

The gap refuses to close. Dazed. Nothing makes sense. A rising dread. “Glasses? In Hollis’ fish pond? What’s he after?”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

我不知道。是的，可能吧。

I don’t know. Yes, probably.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

“一个机会。现在就抓住她。让她坦白。”

“An opening. Get her now. Make her confess.”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

（跳起）

(jumping up)

是的，肯定如此。这就是

Yes, positively. That’s where

他被淹死了。

he was drowned.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

惊呆了。“在家？！”

Stunned. “At home?!”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

什么？！

What?!

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

愤怒。“让她说话。现在！”

Fury. “Make her talk. Now!”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

没有时间感到震惊

There’s no time to be shocked

事实真相。验尸官

by the truth. The coroner’s

报告证明他有盐

report proves that he had salt

当他肺里有水的时候

water in his lungs when he

被杀了。相信我的话

was killed. Just take my word

好吗？现在我想

for it, all right? Now I want to

知道事情是怎么发生的，而且我

know how it happened, and I

想知道为什么，我

want to know why, and I

想知道埃斯科瓦尔之前

want to know before Escobar

来到这里是因为我没有

gets here because I don’t

我想失去我的执照。

want to lose my license.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

他冷笑着，铁青着脸，直视着你。混乱、令人麻木的恐惧、控制欲。

His sneering, livid face pushes into yours. Chaos, paralyzing fear, grasping for control.

伊芙琳

EVELYN

我不知道你是什么

I don’t know what you are

谈论。这是

talking about. This is the

最疯狂的，最疯狂的

craziest, the most insane

事物…

thing…

吉蒂斯

GITTES

停下来！

Stop it!

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

失去控制，双手伸出，抓住她，手指深深地插入，让她畏缩。但随后，她眼中的震惊和痛苦让她心生同情。一个缺口打开了。感受到她与愤怒的斗争。双手放下。“她很痛苦。拜托，伙计，她不是冷血的，任何人都可能发生这种事。给她一个机会。一点一点地说出来，但要让她说出真相！”

Losing control, hands shoot out, grasp her, fingers digging in, making her wince. But then the look of shock and pain in her eyes brings a stab of compassion. A gap opens. Feelings for her struggle against the rage. Hands drop. “She’s hurting. Come on, man, she didn’t do it in cold blood, could happen to anybody. Give her a chance. Lay it out, point by point, but get the truth out of her!”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

我会让

I’m gonna make it easy for

你。你嫉妒，你

you. You were jealous, you

打架时，他摔倒了，撞到了他的

had a fight, he fell, hit his

头……这是一场意外

head… it was an accident

但他的女朋友是证人。所以

… but his girl’s a witness. So

你必须让她闭嘴。你

you had to shut her up. You

没有勇气去伤害

don’t have the guts to harm

她，但你有钱

her, but you’ve got the money

让她闭嘴。是还是不是？

to shut her mouth. Yes or no?

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

缝隙轰然闭合，含义十分可怕：“天哪，他认为是我干的！”

The gap crashes shut with a horrible meaning: “My God, he thinks I did it!”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

不！

No!

吉蒂斯听到她坚定的回答：

As Gittes, hearing her emphatic answer:

“很好。终于听起来像是事实了。”冷静下来。“但到底发生了什么？”

“Good. Finally sounds like the truth.” Cooling off. “But what the hell’s going on?”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

Who is she? And don’t give

我关于姐姐的那些废话

me that crap about a sister

因为你没有

because you don’t have a

姐姐。

sister.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

最让你震惊的是，他想知道她是谁……上帝保佑我。”多年来一直保守这个秘密，你很虚弱。背井离乡。“如果我不告诉他，他会报警，但如果我告诉他……”没有地方可去……除了吉蒂斯。

The greatest shock of all splits you in two: “He wants to know who she is… God help me.” Weak with years of carrying the secret. Back to wall. “If I don’t tell him, he’ll call the police, but if I do…” No place to turn… except to Gittes.

伊芙琳

EVELYN

我会告诉你…我会告诉你

I’ll tell you… I’ll tell you the

真相。

truth.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

Good. What’s her name?

伊芙琳

吉蒂斯

凯瑟琳是谁？

Katherine who?

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

做好最坏的打算。“把一切都说出来。看看他能不能接受……我能不能接受……”

Bracing for the worst. “Tell it all. See if he can take it… if I can take it…”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

她是我的女儿。

She’s my daughter.

回到吉特斯的视角，随着终于撬开她的供词的期望爆发：

Back in Gittes pov as the expectation of finally prying loose her confession explodes:

“又是一个该死的谎言！”

“Another goddamned lie!”

吉蒂斯猛地发怒，一巴掌打在了她脸上。

Gittes lashes out and slaps her flush across the face.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

灼痛。麻木。一生的愧疚感带来的无力感。

Searing pain. Numbness. The paralysis that comes from a life time of guilt.

吉蒂斯

GITTES

我说的是实话。

I said the truth.

她被动地站着，任由自己再次遭受打击。

She stands passively, offering herself to be hit again.

伊芙琳

EVELYN

她是我的妹妹-

She’s my sister—

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

又打了她一巴掌……

slapping her again…

伊芙琳

EVELYN

—她是我的女儿—

—she’s my daughter—

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

什么感觉也没有，只是放手而已。

Feeling nothing but a letting go.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

…再次打她，看到她的眼泪……

… hitting her yet again, seeing her tears…

伊芙琳

EVELYN

-我的姐妹-

—my sister—

…更用力地打她……

… slapping her even harder…

伊芙琳

EVELYN

—我的女儿，我的姐妹—

—my daughter, my sister—

…反手，张开拳头，抓住她，把她扔到沙发上。

… backhand, open fist, grasp her, hurl her into a sofa.

吉蒂斯

GITTES

我说我想要真相。

I said I want the truth.

正如 Evelyn 所说：

As Evelyn:

一开始，他的攻击似乎离你很远，但撞到沙发上的声音让你回过神来，你尖叫出从未对任何人说过的话：

At first his assault seems miles away, but slamming against the sofa jolts you back to the now, and you scream out words you’ve never said to anyone:

伊芙琳

EVELYN

她是我的姐姐和我的女儿。

She’s my sister and my daughter.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

巨大的差距！目瞪口呆。随着差距的缩小，愤怒逐渐消退，你开始理解她话语背后的可怕含义。

A blinding gap! Dumbfounded. Fury ebbs away as the gap slowly closes and you absorb the terrible implications behind her words.

突然，Khan 从楼梯上冲下来。

Suddenly, Khan POUNDS down the stairs.

正如 Khan 所说：

As Khan:

准备战斗来保护她。

Ready to fight to protect her.

伊芙琳突然想起：

As Evelyn, suddenly remembering:

“凯瑟琳！天啊，她听到我说话了吗？”

“Katherine! Sweet Jesus, did she hear me?”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

（快速转向卡恩）

(quickly to Kahn)

汗，请回去吧。

Khan, please, go back.

看在上帝的份上，让她

For God’s sake, keep her

上楼。回去吧。

upstairs. Go back.

汗狠狠地看了吉蒂斯一眼，然后退到楼上。

Khan gives Gittes a hard look, then retreats upstairs.

伊芙琳转过身来，看到吉蒂斯脸上僵硬的表情：

As Evelyn, turning to see the frozen expression on Gittes’ face:

对他有一种奇怪的怜悯之感。“可怜的人……还是不明白。”

An odd sense of pity for him. “Poor man… still doesn’t get it.”

伊芙琳

EVELYN

我和父亲

… my father and I…

明白吗？还是太难了

understand? Or is it too tough

为你？

for you?

伊芙琳跪倒在地，哭泣起来。

Evelyn drops her head to her knees and sobs.

正如吉蒂斯所说：

As Gittes:

一阵同情。“可恶……这个变态混蛋……”

A wave of compassion. “Cross… that sick bastard…”

吉蒂斯

GITTES

（悄悄）

(quietly)

他强奸了你？
