Joanna Kramer was, in essence, raising two children, and overwhelmed by the impossibility of a mature relationship, she abandoned the marriage. What’s more, we feel she was right to do it. New direction: Kramer’s growth into manhood.

《帝国反击战》的高潮推动了人们去洞察真相的最长旅程。当达斯维达 (大卫普劳斯 / 詹姆斯厄尔琼斯 饰) 和卢克天行者 (马克哈米尔 饰) 用光剑决一死战时，维达后退一步说道：“你杀不死我，卢克，我是你父亲。”“父亲”这个词打破了电影史上最著名的空白之一，让观众仿佛回到了相隔三年的两部电影中。我们立刻明白了为什么本欧比旺克诺比 (亚历克吉尼斯 饰) 如此担心如果达斯和卢克面对面会发生什么。我们知道了为什么尤达 (弗兰克奥兹 配音) 如此渴望教卢克如何使用原力。我们意识到了为什么卢克多次死里逃生：他的父亲一直在暗中保护他。两部迄今为止完全合理的电影如今有了新的、更深层的含义。新方向：《绝地归来》。

The Climax of THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK propels the longest rush for insight I know. As Darth Vader (David Prowse/ James Earl Jones) and Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill) fight to the death with light sabers, Vader steps back and says: “You can’t kill me, Luke, I’m your father.” The word “father” explodes one of the most famous gaps in film history and hurls the audience back through two whole films separated by three years. Instantly we grasp why Ben Obi-Wan Kenobi (Alec Guinness) was so worried about what would happen if Darth and Luke ever met face to face. We know why Yoda (voice of Frank Oz) was so desperate to teach Luke command of the Force. We realize why Luke’s had so many close escapes: His father has been secretly protecting him. Two films that made perfect sense to this moment now have a new, deeper layer of meaning. New direction: RETURN OF THE JEDI.

唐人街：在第二幕高潮之前，我们认为穆尔雷要么是为了经济利益，要么是出于嫉妒而遭到谋杀。但当伊芙琳说：“她是我的妹妹，也是我的女儿……”时，我们震惊地打破了这种隔阂。为了理解她的话，我们急忙回想通过电影，我们获得了一系列深刻的见解：父女乱伦、谋杀的真正动机以及凶手的身份。新方向：第三幕的螺旋式曲折。

CHINATOWN: Before the Act Two Climax we believe that Mulwray was murdered either for financial gain or in a jealous rage. But when Evelyn says: “She’s my sister and my daughter…” the gap splits with a shock. To understand her words, we race back through the film and gain a powerful set of insights: incest between father and daughter, the real motivation for the murder, and the identity of the killer. New direction: the corkscrew twists of Act Three.

自我表达的问题

The Question of Self-Expression

一位讲故事的人友好地拥抱着观众，说道：“让我给你们看个东西。”他把我们带到一个场景，比如《唐人街》中的场景，然后说道：“看吉蒂斯开车去圣莫尼卡，打算逮捕伊芙琳。当他敲她的门时，你认为他会受到邀请吗？看这个。现在美丽的伊芙琳下楼来，很高兴见到他。你认为他会心软并放过她吗？看这个。接下来她会努力保护她的秘密。你认为她会保守秘密吗？看这个。当他听她的忏悔时，他会帮助她还是逮捕她？看这个。”

A storyteller puts a friendly arm around the audience, saying: “Let me show you something.” He takes us to a scene, such as the one in CHINATOWN, and says: “Watch Gittes drive to Santa Monica, intent on arresting Evelyn. When he knocks on her door, do you think he’ll be invited in? Watch this. Now the beautiful Evelyn comes downstairs, happy to see him. Think he’ll soften and let her off the hook? Watch this. Next she fights to protect her secret. Think she’ll keep it? Watch this. As he listens to her confession, will he help her or arrest her? Watch this.”

讲故事的人让我们充满期待，让我们以为自己已经理解了，然后打破现实，制造惊喜和好奇，让我们一遍又一遍地回顾他的故事。在每一次回顾中，我们越来越深入地了解他笔下人物的本质和他们的世界——突然意识到隐藏在电影画面之下的不可言喻的真相。然后，他以不断升级的这种时刻将故事带向新的方向。

The storyteller leads us into expectation, makes us think we understand, then cracks open reality, creating surprise and curiosity, sending us back through his story again and again. On each trip back, we gain deeper and deeper insight into the natures of his characters and their world—a sudden awareness of the ineffable truths that lie hidden beneath the film’s images. He then takes his story in a new direction in an ever-escalating progression of such moments.

讲故事就是在许下承诺：如果你全神贯注，我就会给你惊喜，然后让你在从未想象过的层面和方向上发现生活、痛苦和欢乐。最重要的是，这必须做得如此轻松自然，以至于我们让观众仿佛自发地发现这些。精彩转折的效果是，电影观众会体验到知识的冲击，就像他们自己做的一样。从某种意义上说，他们确实做到了。洞察力是观众关注的回报，而精心设计的故事一幕又一幕地传递着这种乐趣。

To tell story is to make a promise: If you give me your concentration, I’ll give you surprise followed by the pleasure of discovering life, its pains and joys, at levels and in directions you have never imagined. And most important, this must be done with such seeming ease and naturalness that we lead the audience to these discoveries as if spontaneously. The effect of a beautifully turned moment is that filmgoers experience a rush of knowledge as if they did it for themselves. In a sense they did. Insight is the audience’s reward for paying attention, and a beautifully designed story delivers this pleasure scene after scene after scene.

然而，如果我们问作家他们如何表达自己，他们往往会回答：“用我的文字，我的描述我对世界的理解和我为角色创造的对话。我是一个作家。我用语言表达自己。”但语言仅仅是我们的文本。自始至终，自我表达总是发生在转折点涌出的洞见洪流中。在这里，作家向世界张开双臂，说道：“这是我对生活的看法，对生活在我的世界中的人类的本性的看法。我认为，在这些情况下，人们会因为这些原因而发生这样的事情。我的想法，我的情感。我。”我们最有力的自我表达方式是我们讲述故事的独特方式。

Yet, if we were to ask writers how they express themselves, more often than not they’ll reply: “With my words, My descriptions of the world and the dialogue I create for my characters. I’m a writer. I express myself in language.” But language is merely our text. First, last, and always, self-expression occurs in the flood of insight that pours out of a Turning Point. Here the writer opens his arms to the world, saying: “This is my vision of life, of the nature of the human beings that inhabit my world. This is what I think happens to people in these circumstances for these reasons. My ideas, my emotions. Me.” Our most powerful means of self-expression is the unique way we turn the story.

接下来是文字。我们生动而巧妙地运用文学才华，这样当一个写得很美的场景上演时，观众就会心甘情愿地、愉快地经历我们的转折点。然而，语言虽然重要，但它只是我们吸引读者并引导他们进入故事内心生活的表面。语言是自我表达的工具，绝不能成为其自身的装饰目的。

Then come words. We apply our literary talent with vividness and skill, so that when a beautifully written scene is acted, the audience is carried willingly and pleasurably through our Turning Points. As important as language is, however, it’s only the surface by which we capture the reader to lead him to the inner life of the story. Language is a tool for self-expression and must never become a decorative end of its own.

现在想象一下，设计一个故事有多么困难，因为三十次、四十次、五十次，场景以小、中或大的方式转变，每次都表达我们视野的一个方面。这就是为什么糟糕的故事叙述会诉诸于用信息代替洞察力。为什么许多作家选择从人物的口中解释他们的意思，或者更糟的是，用画外音叙述。这样的写作总是不够充分。它迫使人物去了解一种在现实中很少发现的虚假的、自我意识的知识。更重要的是，即使是精美、敏锐的散文也无法取代当我们将自己的生活经历与艺术家精心设计的设置相匹配时，脑海中涌现的整体洞察力。

Imagine now the difficulties of designing a story so that thirty, forty, fifty times over, scenes turn in minor, moderate, or major ways, each expressing an aspect of our vision. This is why weak storytelling resorts to substituting information for insight. Why many writers choose to explain their meanings out of the mouths of their characters, or worse, in voice-over narration. Such writing is always inadequate. It forces characters to a phony, self-conscious knowledge rarely found in actuality. More important, even exquisite, perceptive prose cannot substitute for the global insight that floods the mind when we match our life experiences against an artist’s well-placed setup.

设置/收益

SETUPS/PAYOFFS

为了一幕一幕地表达我们的愿景，我们揭开了虚构现实的表面，让观众回过头来获得洞察力。因此，这些洞察力必须被塑造成设置和回报。设置意味着层层灌输知识；回报意味着通过向观众传递这些知识来缩小差距。当期望和结果之间的差距促使观众回过头来通过故事寻找答案，只有当作家在作品中准备或植入了这些见解时，才能找到答案。

To express our vision scene by scene we crack open the surface of our fictional reality and send the audience back to gain insight. These insights, therefore, must be shaped into Setups and Payoffs. To set up means to layer in knowledge; to pay off means to close the gap by delivering that knowledge to the audience. When the gap between expectation and result propels the audience back through the story seeking answers, it can only find them if the writer has prepared or planted these insights in the work.

唐人街：当伊芙琳·穆尔雷说：“她是我的妹妹，也是我的女儿”时，我们立刻想起了她父亲和吉蒂斯之间的一幕，侦探问诺亚·克罗斯，在穆尔雷被谋杀的前一天，他和他的女婿在争论什么。克罗斯回答说：“我的女儿。”我们第一次听到这句话时，以为他指的是伊芙琳。一瞬间，我们意识到他指的是凯瑟琳，他的女儿。克罗斯说这句话时知道吉蒂斯会得出错误的结论，并暗示会怀疑伊芙琳是他所犯下的谋杀罪。

CHINATOWN: When Evelyn Mulwray says: “She’s my sister and my daughter,” we instantly remember a scene between her father and Gittes in which the detective asks Noah Cross what he and his son-in-law were arguing about the day before Mulwray was murdered. Cross replies, “My daughter.” The first time we hear this, we think he means Evelyn. In a flash, we now realize he meant Katherine, his daughter by his daughter. Cross said it knowing that Gittes would draw the wrong conclusion, and, by implication, would suspect Evelyn of the murder he committed.

《帝国反击战》：当达斯·维德透露自己是卢克的父亲时，我们又回到了本·克诺比和尤达对卢克掌握原力感到十分不安的场景，我们推测他们担心这个年轻人的安全。现在我们意识到卢克的导师们其实是在担心他的灵魂，担心他的父亲会引诱他走向“黑暗面”。

THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK: When Darth Vader reveals that he’s Luke’s father, we rush back to the scenes in which Ben Kenobi and Yoda are greatly troubled over Luke’s command of the Force, fearing, we presume, for the young man’s safety. We now realize that Luke’s mentors were actually concerned for his soul, dreading that his father would seduce him to the “dark side.”

苏利文的旅行：约翰·L·苏利文是一位电影导演，执导过一系列热门影片，如《再见》、《纱笼》和1939 年的《蚂蚁进裤子里》。苏利文对世界骇人听闻的状况深感良知，他决定他的下一部电影必须具有“社会意义”。愤怒的制片厂老板指出，他来自好莱坞，因此对“社会意义”一无所知。

SULLIVAN’S TRAVELS: John L. Sullivan is a film director with a string of hits such as So Long, Sarong and Ants in Your Pants of 1939. Conscience-stricken by the appalling condition of the world, Sullivan determines that his next film must have “social significance.” Angry studio bosses point out that he’s from Hollywood and therefore doesn’t know anything about “social significance.”

于是沙利文决定进行调查。他跋涉前往美国，后面跟着一辆空调旅行车，车上还配备了他的管家、厨师、秘书、女友和一名新闻代理人，他打算把沙利文的疯狂冒险变成一场宣传噱头。然后，由于身份错误，沙利文被扔进了路易斯安那州沼泽地的劳役队。突然间，他陷入了“社会影响”的泥潭，却没有一分钱给经纪人打电话。

So Sullivan decides to do research. He trudges off into America, followed by an air-conditioned travel van, equipped with his butler, cook, secretary, girlfriend, and a press agent intent on turning Sullivan’s lunatic adventure into a publicity stunt. Then, in a case of mistaken identity, Sullivan’s thrown on a chain gang in the swamps of Louisiana. Suddenly he’s up to his nostrils in “social significance” without a dime to call his agent.

一天晚上，沙利文听到监狱大院里传来一阵哄堂大笑，发现一个临时电影院里挤满了他的狱友，他们正在看米老鼠卡通片，笑得前仰后合。他意识到这些人不需要他“发挥社会作用”，于是脸色一沉。他们他们的生活已经够多了。他们需要的是他最擅长的——好的轻松娱乐。

One evening Sullivan hears uproarious laughter coming from a building in the prison compound and discovers a makeshift movie theatre filled with his fellow prisoners laughing themselves helpless at a Mickey Mouse cartoon. His face drops as he realizes that these men do not need “social significance” from him. They have more than enough in their lives already. What they need is what he does best—good light entertainment.

随着这一精彩的逆转，我们回到电影，看到了沙利文的见解……以及更多。当我们聚集在讽刺好莱坞贵族的所有场景中时，我们意识到，那些试图指导社会如何解决其缺点的商业电影肯定是错误的。因为，除了少数例外，大多数电影制作人，比如沙利文，对受苦受难的穷人的兴趣，远不如对风景如画的穷人的兴趣。

With this brilliant reversal, we’re swept back through the film coming to Sullivan’s insight… and much more. As we gather in all the scenes that satirize Hollywood aristocracy, we realize that commercial films that presume to instruct society on how to solve its shortcomings are certain to be false. For, with few exceptions, most filmmakers, like Sullivan, are not interested in the suffering poor as much as the picturesque poor.

必须非常小心地处理设置。必须以这样的方式植入，即当观众第一次看到它们时，它们只有一个含义，但随着洞察力的提升，它们会呈现出第二个更重要的含义。事实上，单个设置可能隐藏着第三或第四层的含义。

Setups must be handled with great care. They must be planted in such a way that when the audience first sees them, they have one meaning, but with a rush of insight, they take on a second, more important meaning. It’s possible, in fact, that a single setup may have meanings hidden to a third or fourth level.

唐人街：当我们遇到诺亚·克罗斯时，他是一名谋杀嫌疑犯，但他也是一位担心女儿的父亲。当伊芙琳揭露他们的乱伦时，我们才意识到克罗斯真正关心的是凯瑟琳。在第三幕中，当克罗斯利用他的财富阻止吉蒂斯并抓获凯瑟琳时，我们意识到在克罗斯之前的场景下隐藏着第三个层次，一种由几乎无所不能的力量驱动的疯狂，这种力量在谋杀的同时逃避法律的制裁。在最后一幕中，当克罗斯把凯瑟琳拖进唐人街的阴影中时，我们意识到在所有这些可怕的腐败之下，克罗斯一直渴望与自己乱伦的后代乱伦。

CHINATOWN: When we meet Noah Cross, he’s a murder suspect, but he’s also a father worried about his daughter. When Evelyn reveals their incest, we then realize Cross’s true concern is Katherine. In Act Three, when Cross uses his wealth to block Gittes and capture Katherine, we realize that under Cross’s previous scenes lurked a third level, a madness driven by the virtually omnipotent power to escape justice while committing murder. In the final scene, when Cross draws Katherine into the shadows of Chinatown, we realize that festering under all this grotesque corruption has been Cross’s lust to have incest with the offspring of his own incest.

布景必须足够牢固，这样当观众回过神来时，他们才能记住。如果布景太微妙，观众就会错过重点。如果布景太过沉重，观众就会在很远的地方看到转折点。当我们过度准备显而易见的东西而准备不充分时，转折点就会失败。

Setups must be planted firmly enough so that when the audience’s mind hurls back, they’re remembered. If setups are too subtle, the audience will miss the point. If too heavy-handed, the audience will see the Turning Point coming a mile away. Turning Points fail when we overprepare the obvious and underprepare the unusual.

此外，电影的设置必须根据目标观众进行调整。我们更突出地针对年轻观众，因为他们不像中年电影观众那样精通故事。例如，伯格曼的电影对年轻人来说很难——不是因为即使解释，他们也无法理解他的想法，而是因为伯格曼从不解释。他巧妙地将自己的想法戏剧化，使用这些设置是为受过良好教育、具有社会经验和心理成熟的人而设计的。

Additionally, the firmness of the setup must be adjusted to the target audience. We set up more prominently for youth audiences, because they’re not as story literate as middle-aged filmgoers. Bergman, for example, is difficult for the young—not because they couldn’t grasp his ideas if they were explained, but because Bergman never explains. He dramatizes his ideas subtly, using setups intended for the well-educated, socially experienced, and psychologically sophisticated.

一旦设置弥补了差距，该收益很可能会成为未来收益的另一种设置。

Once the setup closes the gap, that payoff will, in all probability, become yet another setup for payoffs ahead.

唐人街：当伊芙琳通过乱伦将她的孩子暴露出来时，她反复警告吉蒂斯，她的父亲很危险，吉蒂斯不知道自己在面对什么。然后我们意识到克罗斯在争夺孩子所有权的斗争中杀死了穆尔雷。第二幕的结局为第三幕的高潮埋下了伏笔，吉蒂斯未能抓住克罗斯，伊芙琳被杀，父亲/祖父将惊恐的凯瑟琳拉入黑暗之中。

CHINATOWN: When Evelyn reveals her child by incest, she repeatedly warns Gittes that her father is dangerous, that Gittes doesn’t know what he’s dealing with. We then realize that Cross killed Mulwray in a fight for possession of the child. This Act Two payoff sets up an Act Three Climax in which Gittes fails to apprehend Cross, Evelyn is killed, and the father/grandfather pulls the terrified Katherine into the darkness.

《帝国反击战》：当达斯·维德向卢克表明身份时，两部电影中出现的多重设定得到了回报。然而，在一瞬间，这也成为了卢克下一步行动的设定。这位年轻的英雄会怎么做？他选择杀死父亲，但达斯·维德砍掉了儿子的手——这是为下一步行动设置的回报。现在被打败了，卢克会怎么做？他从天空之城跳下，试图光荣地自杀——这是为下一步行动设置的回报。他会死吗？不，他的朋友几乎在半空中救了他。这次幸运的举动为自杀提供了回报，并成为第三部电影解决父子冲突的设定。

THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK: When Darth Vader reveals himself to Luke, this pays off multiple setups strung back through two films. In an instant, however, this also becomes the setup for Luke’s next action. What will the young hero do? He chooses to try to kill his father, but Darth Vader cuts off his son’s hand—a payoff to set up the next action. Now defeated, what will Luke do? He hurls himself out of the sky city, trying to commit an honorable suicide—a payoff to set up the next action. Will he die? No, he’s rescued virtually in mid-air by his friends. This stroke of luck pays off the suicide and becomes the setup for a third film to resolve the conflict between father and son.

苏利文的旅行：当苏利文意识到自己是个多么自命不凡的傻瓜时，他之前所有傲慢愚蠢的行为都得到了回报。这反过来又为他的下一步行动埋下了伏笔。他将如何逃脱劳役？他发现自己的真实身份后，重新回到了好莱坞的轨道上。他意识到，就像任何好莱坞专业人士一样，出狱的办法，实际上，摆脱任何麻烦的办法，就是出名。苏利文承认了自己没有犯下的谋杀罪，以便重新回到法庭和媒体的聚光灯下，这样制片厂老板和他们强大的律师就可以拯救他了。这一回报为解决场景埋下了伏笔，我们看到苏利文回到好莱坞的束缚中，制作他一直制作的轻松娱乐电影——但现在他知道为什么了。

SULLIVAN’S TRAVELS: When Sullivan realizes what a pretentious fool he’s been, this pays off all the arrogant folly underlying the previous acts. It in turn sets up his next action. How will he escape the chain gang? His discovery of who he really is puts his head back in the Hollywood groove. He realizes, like any Hollywood pro, that the way out of prison, indeed out of any trouble, is publicity. Sullivan confesses to a murder he didn’t commit to get back into court and the limelight of the press so the studio bosses and their powerhouse attorneys can rescue him. This payoff sets up the Resolution scene where we see Sullivan back in the Hollywood harness, making the fluffy entertainment films he has always made—but now he knows why.

准备、付款、再次准备、再次付款的过程常常会激发我们最富创造力的灵感。

The juggling act of setting up, paying off, setting up again and paying off again often sparks our most creative flashes.

假设你正在创作一个关于孤儿兄弟马克和迈克尔的故事，他们从婴儿时期就被送进一个残酷的机构。兄弟俩形影不离，多年来互相保护和支持。后来他们逃出了孤儿院。现在他们在街头挣扎求生，却总是互相保护。马克和迈克尔彼此相爱，你也爱他们。但你有一个问题：没有故事。这是一幅名为“两个兄弟对抗世界”的肖像画。他们兄弟般忠诚的反复表现，唯一的变化就是地点。没有什么本质的变化。

Suppose you were developing a story about orphaned brothers, Mark and Michael, who are raised from infancy in a brutal institution. The brothers are inseparable, protecting and supporting each other through the years. Then they escape the orphanage. Now on the streets they struggle to survive while always defending each other. Mark and Michael love each other, and you love them. But you have a problem: no story. This is a portrait entitled: “Two brothers against the world.” The only variation in the repetitious demonstration of their fraternal loyalty is its location. Nothing essential changes.

但是，当你盯着开放式结局的连环情节时，你有一个疯狂的想法：“如果马克背叛了迈克尔会怎么样？骗走他的钱，抢走他的女朋友……”现在你踱步，争辩道：“这太愚蠢了！他们彼此相爱。一起对抗世界。没有道理！不过，那会很棒。算了吧。但那会是一场地狱般的场景。别这样。这不合逻辑！”

But, as you stare at your open-ended chain-link of episodes, you have a crazy idea: “What if Mark stabbed Michael in the back? Ripped him off, took his money, his girl…” Now you’re pacing, arguing: “That’s stupid! They love each other. Fought the world together. Makes no sense! Still, it’d be great. Forget it. But it’d be a hell of a scene. Cut it out. It’s not logical!”

然后我灵光一闪：“我可以让它合乎逻辑。我可以回顾一切，并把这些层层叠加。两个兄弟对抗世界？该隐和亚伯呢？兄弟姐妹之间的竞争？我可以从开头重写，在每一个场景下，都隐含着马克的嫉妒之苦，迈克尔的优越感和傲慢。在甜蜜的忠诚背后，这一切都悄无声息。如果我做得好，当马克背叛迈克时，观众就会瞥见马克压抑的嫉妒，一切都说得通了。”

Then the light goes on: “I could make it logical. I could go back through everything and layer that in. Two brothers against the world? What about Cain and Abel? Sibling rivalry? I could rewrite from the opening and under every scene slip a bitter taste of envy in Mark, superiority and arrogance in Michael. All quietly there behind the sweet loyalty. If I do it well, when Mark betrays Mike, the audience will glimpse that repressed jealousy in Mark and it’ll all make sense.”

现在，你的角色不再重复，而是不断成长。也许你意识到你终于表达了你对自己兄弟的真实感受，但又无法承认。然而，事情还没有结束。突然，出乎意料地，你又想到了第二个想法：“如果马克背叛了迈克，那可能是倒数第二个高潮。而这个高潮可能会为最后一幕的故事高潮埋下伏笔，迈克会报复……”你找到了你的故事，因为你允许自己去思考那些不可想象的事情。在讲故事时，逻辑是回溯性的。

Now your characters aren’t repeating but growing. Perhaps you realize you’re finally expressing what you really feel toward your own brother and couldn’t admit. Still, it’s not over. Suddenly, out of the blue, a second thought: “If Mark betrays Mike, that could be the Penultimate Climax. And that Climax could set up a last act Story Climax in which Mike takes his revenge and…” You’ve found your story because you’ve allowed yourself to think the unthinkable. In storytelling, logic is retroactive.

故事与生活不同，你总是可以回头去修正它。你可以设置看似荒谬的东西，并使其合理化。推理是次要的，是创造力之后的。想象力是其他一切的首要和先决条件——愿意思考任何疯狂的想法，让可能有意义也可能没有意义的图像进入你的脑海。十有八九都是无用的。然而，一个不合逻辑的想法可能会让你心跳加速，这种激动告诉你，这个疯狂的想法中隐藏着一些美妙的东西。在直觉的闪现中，你看到了其中的联系，并意识到你可以回过头来让它有意义。逻辑是小菜一碟。想象力会带你走向屏幕。

In story, unlike life, you can always go back and fix it. You can set up what may seem absurd and make it rational. Reasoning is secondary and postcreativity. Primary and preconditional to everything else is imagination—the willingness to think any crazy idea, to let images that may or may not make sense find their way to you. Nine out of ten will be useless. Yet one illogical idea may put butterflies in your belly, a flutter that’s telling you something wonderful is hidden in this mad notion. In an intuitive flash you see the connection and realize you can go back and make it make sense. Logic is child’s play. Imagination takes you to the screen.

情绪转变

EMOTIONAL TRANSITIONS

我们不会通过让角色眼中闪烁的泪光、写出让演员能够朗诵自己喜悦的热情对话、描述情色拥抱或播放愤怒的音乐来打动观众的情感。相反，我们会呈现引起情感的精确体验，然后带领观众经历这种体验。因为转折点不仅传递洞察力，还创造了情感的动态。

We do not move the emotions of an audience by putting glistening tears in a character’s eyes, by writing exuberant dialogue so an actor can recite his joy, by describing an erotic embrace, or by calling for angry music. Rather, we render the precise experience necessary to cause an emotion, then take the audience through that experience. For Turning Points not only deliver insight, they create the dynamics of emotion.

要了解如何营造观众的情感体验，首先要认识到只有两种情感——快乐和痛苦。每种情感都有其变化：一方面是喜悦、爱、幸福、狂喜、乐趣、狂喜、激动、幸福和许多其他情感，另一方面是痛苦、恐惧、焦虑、恐怖、悲伤、羞辱、不适、痛苦、压力、悔恨和许多其他情感。但从内心而言，生活只赋予我们其中一种情感。

The understanding of how we create the audience’s emotional experience begins with the realization that there are only two emotions—pleasure and pain. Each has its variations: joy, love, happiness, rapture, fun, ecstasy, thrill, bliss, and many others on one hand, and anguish, dread, anxiety, terror, grief, humiliation, malaise, misery, stress, remorse, and many others on the other hand. But at heart life gives us only one or the other.

作为观众，当故事带给我们价值观的转变时，我们会感受到一种情感。首先，我们必须同情角色。其次，我们必须知道角色想要什么，并希望角色得到它。第三，我们必须理解角色生活中的价值观。在这些条件下，价值观的改变会触动我们的情感。

As audience, we experience an emotion when the telling takes us through a transition of values. First, we must empathize with the character. Second, we must know what the character wants and want the character to have it. Third, we must understand the values at stake in the character’s life. Within these conditions, a change in values moves our emotions.

假设一部喜剧以一个穷困潦倒的主角开始，他对于财富的看法是负面的。然后，随着场景、序列或行为的演绎，他的生活发生了积极的变化，从贫穷变成了富有。当观众看着这个角色朝着他的愿望前进时，从少到多的转变将提升到积极的情感体验。

Suppose a comedy were to begin with a poverty-stricken protagonist at the negative in terms of the value of wealth. Then over scene, sequence, or act, his life undergoes change to the positive, a transition from poor to rich. As the audience watches this character move toward his desire, the transition from less to more will lift it into a positive emotional experience.

然而，一旦达到这个平台期，情绪就会迅速消散。情绪是一种相对短期的、充满活力的体验高潮过后，高潮过后，剧情结束了。现在观众在想：“太棒了。他很有钱。接下来会发生什么？”

As soon as this plateau is reached, however, emotion quickly dissipates. An emotion is a relatively short-term, energetic experience that peaks and burns and is over. Now the audience is thinking: “Terrific. He’s rich. What happens next?”

接下来，故事必须转向新的方向，塑造一个比他之前一贫如洗的状态更深刻的从正面到负面的转变。也许主角从富有沦落到欠黑帮的债，比贫穷还要糟糕。随着这种从富有到一无所有的变化，观众会产生负面的情绪反应。然而，一旦主角欠了高利贷，观众的情绪就会减弱，因为他们会想：“这招不好。他把钱挥霍一空，还欠了黑帮的钱。接下来会发生什么？”

Next, the story must turn in a new direction to shape a transition from positive to negative that’s deeper than his previous penniless state. Perhaps the protagonist falls from riches into debt to the mafia, far worse than poverty. As this transition moves from more to less than nothing, the audience will have a negative emotional response. However, once the protagonist owes all to a loan shark, the audience’s emotion wanes as it thinks: “Bad move. He blew the money and owes the mob. What’s going to happen next?”

现在故事必须转向另一个新方向。也许他通过冒充老大并接管黑帮来逃避债务。随着故事从双重消极转变为具有讽刺意味的积极，观众的积极情绪更加强烈。故事必须创造积极和消极情绪之间的动态交替，以遵守收益递减定律。

Now the story must turn in yet another new direction. Perhaps he escapes his debt by impersonating the Don and taking over the mob. As the telling makes the transition from the doubly negative to the ironically positive, the audience has an even stronger positive emotion. Story must create these dynamic alternations between positive and negative emotion in order to obey the Law of Diminishing Returns.

收益递减定律在生活中和故事中都是正确的：我们体验某件事的次数越多，它的影响就越小。换句话说，情感体验不能连续重复产生影响。第一个冰淇淋甜筒味道很好；第二个还不错；第三个会让你恶心。我们第一次体验某种情感或感觉时，它会产生全部影响。如果我们试图立即重复这种体验，它的影响将只有一半或不到一半。如果我们第三次直接体验同一种情感，它不仅不会产生原来的效果，还会产生相反的效果。

The Law of Diminishing Returns, true in life as well as in story, is this: The more often we experience something, the less effect it has. Emotional experience, in other words, cannot be repeated back-to-back with effect. The first ice cream cone tastes great; the second isn’t bad; the third makes you sick. The first time we experience an emotion or sensation it has its full effect. If we try to repeat this experience immediately, it has half or less than half of its full effect. If we go straight to the same emotion for the third time, it not only doesn’t have the original effect, it delivers the opposite effect.

假设一个故事包含三个连续的悲剧场景。效果会怎样？在第一个场景中，我们流泪；在第二个场景中，我们抽泣；在第三个场景中，我们大笑……大声笑。不是因为第三个场景不悲伤——它可能是三个场景中最悲伤的一个——而是因为前两个场景已经耗尽了我们的悲伤，我们认为讲故事的人希望我们再次哭泣是不敏感的，甚至是荒谬的。事实上，重复“严肃”的情感是一种受欢迎的喜剧手法。

Suppose a story contains three tragic scenes contiguously. What would be the effect? In the first, we shed tears; in the second, we sniffle; in the third, we laugh… loudly. Not because the third scene isn’t sad—it may be the saddest of the three—but because the previous two have drained us of grief and we find it insensitive, if not ludicrous, of the storyteller to expect us to cry yet again. The repetition of “serious” emotion is, in fact, a favorite comic device.

虽然喜剧似乎是这一原则的例外，因为我们经常会笑个不停，但事实并非如此。笑声不是情绪。喜悦是一种情绪。笑是我们对可笑或离谱的事情的批评。它可能出现在任何情绪中，从恐惧到爱。我们笑的时候也不会没有解脱。笑话有两个部分：铺垫和打击。铺垫通过危险、性、猥亵——一系列禁忌——让观众紧张起来，哪怕只有一瞬间，然后打击引爆笑声。这是喜剧时机的秘诀：什么时候铺垫成熟到可以打出笑点或笑话？喜剧演员凭直觉感觉到这一点，但他客观地学到的一件事是，他不能不停地打出打击，否则会让人厌烦。

Although comedy may seem the exception to this principle in that we often seem to laugh repeatedly, it’s not. Laughter is not an emotion. Joy is an emotion. Laughter is a criticism we hurl at something we find ridiculous or outrageous. It may occur inside any emotion, from terror to love. Nor do we laugh without relief. A joke has two parts: setup and punch. The setup raises the tension in the audience, if only for a moment, through danger, sex, the scatological—a host of taboos—then the punch explodes laughter. This is the secret to comic timing: When is the setup ripe to hit the punchline or gag? The comic senses this intuitively, but one thing he learns objectively is that he can’t deliver punch, punch, punch without wearing out his welcome.

然而，有一个例外：一个故事可以从正面转为正面，也可以从负面转为负面，如果这些事件之间的对比如此之大，回想起来，第一个事件就会呈现出相反的色彩。想想这两个事件：恋人争吵分手。负面。接下来，一个人杀死了另一个人。第二个转折是如此强烈的负面，以至于争论开始显得积极。鉴于谋杀，观众会回顾分手并想：“至少当时他们在说话。”

There is, however, one exception: a story can go from positive to positive or negative to negative, if the contrast between these events is so great, in retrospect the first takes on shades of its opposite. Consider these two events: Lovers argue and break up. Negative. Next, one kills the other. The second turn is so powerfully negative that the argument begins to seem positive. In the light of the murder, the audience will look back at the breakup and think: “At least they were talking then.”

如果情绪之间的反差很大，事情可以从积极走向积极，而不会伤感，也可以从消极走向消极，而不会显得严肃。然而，如果进展只是逐渐变化，就像通常那样，那么重复的情绪就只能产生一半的预期效果，如果再次重复，不幸的是，情绪会逆转。

If the contrast between emotional charges is great, events can move from positive to positive without sentimentality, or from negative to negative without forced seriousness. However, if the progression changes only by degree, as it normally would, then a repeated emotion has half its expected effect, and if repeated yet again, the charge unfortunately reverses itself.

收益递减规律适用于生活中的一切，但性除外，因为性似乎可以无限重复且有效。

The Law of Diminishing Returns is true of everything in life, except sex, which seems endlessly repeatable with effect.

一旦价值转变产生了情绪，感觉就会发挥作用。虽然感觉和情绪经常被混淆，但感觉并不是情绪。情绪是一种短期体验，会迅速达到顶峰并迅速燃烧。感觉是一种长期、普遍、有知觉的背景，它影响着我们整天、整周甚至整年的生活。事实上，一种特定的感觉往往主导着一个人的性格。生活中的每一种核心情绪——快乐和痛苦——都有很多变化。那么我们会体验到哪种特定的消极或积极情绪呢？答案就在它周围的感觉中。因为，就像给铅笔素描添加颜料或给旋律添加管弦乐队一样，感觉使情绪变得具体。

Once a transition of value creates an emotion, feeling comes into play. Although they’re often mistaken for each other, feeling is not emotion. Emotion is a short-term experience that peaks and burns rapidly. Feeling is a long-term, pervasive, sentient background that colors whole days, weeks, even years of our lives. Indeed, a specific feeling often dominates a personality. Each of the core emotions in life—pleasure and pain—has many variations. So which particular negative or positive emotion will we experience? The answer is found in the feeling that surrounds it. For, like adding pigment to a pencil sketch or an orchestra to a melody, feeling makes emotion specific.

假设一个男人对生活感觉良好，他的人际关系和事业都进展顺利。然后他收到一条消息，说他的爱人已经去世。他会感到悲伤，但随着时间的推移，他会恢复过来，继续生活。另一方面，假设他的生活因他所做的每件事而变得黑暗、紧张和沮丧。然后他突然收到一条消息，说他的爱人已经去世。好吧……他可能会和她在一起。

Suppose a man is feeling good about life, his relationships and career both going well. Then he receives a message that his lover has died. He’ll grieve but in time recover and go on with life. On the other hand, suppose his days are dark, stressed, and depressed by everything he tries. Then suddenly he receives a message that his lover has died. Well… he might join her.

在电影中，感觉被称为情绪。情绪是在电影文本中创造的：光线和色彩的质量、动作和剪辑的节奏、演员阵容、对话风格、制作设计和音乐配乐。所有这些结构品质的总和创造了一种特定的情绪。一般来说，情绪就像布景一样，是一种伏笔，一种准备或塑造观众期待的方式。然而，每时每刻，虽然场景的动态决定了它引起的情绪是积极的还是消极的，但情绪使这种情绪变得具体。

In film, feeling is known as mood. Mood is created in the film’s text: the quality of light and color, tempo of action and editing, casting, style of dialogue, production design, and musical score. The sum of all these textural qualities creates a particular mood. In general, mood, like setups, is a form of foreshadowing, a way of preparing or shaping the audience’s anticipations. Moment by moment, however, while the dynamic of the scene determines whether the emotion it causes is positive or negative, the mood makes this emotion specific.

例如，这个小品旨在营造一种积极情绪：疏远的恋人已经一年多没有说话了。没有了她，他的生活发生了危险的转变。绝望和破产的他来找她，希望借钱。这个场景从两个负面价值观开始：他的生存和他们的爱。

This sketch, for example, is designed to create a positive emotion: Estranged lovers haven’t spoken to each other for over a year. Without her, his life’s taken a dangerous turn. Desperate and broke, he comes to her, hoping to borrow money. The scene begins at the negative in two values: his survival and their love.

他敲了敲她的门。她看到他站在台阶上，拒绝让他进来。他发出很大的声音，吵醒了邻居，希望让她难堪，让他进来。她拿起电话，威胁要报警。他揭穿了她的虚张声势，隔着门大喊，说他麻烦大了，监狱可能是他唯一安全的地方。她大声回应说她没问题。

He knocks on her door. She sees him on the step and refuses to let him in. He makes a noise loud enough to disturb the neighbors, hoping to embarrass her into letting him in. She picks up a phone and threatens to call the police. He calls her bluff, shouting through the door that he is in such deep trouble prison may be the only safe place for him. She shouts back that that’s fine with her.

他又惊又怒，破门而入。但从她脸上的表情，他意识到这样是借不到钱的。他疯狂地解释说，高利贷者威胁要打断他的胳膊和腿。她不但不同情，反而笑着告诉他，她希望他们也打断他的头。他哭了起来，爬到她身边乞讨。他脸上的疯狂表情吓坏了她，她从抽屉里拿出一把枪吓跑了他。他笑着说，他记得一年前把枪给她，撞针坏了。她笑着说，她已经修好了，并炸毁了他旁边的灯来证明这一点。

Frightened and angry, he smashes through the door. But from the look on her face, he realizes this is no way to borrow money from anybody. He frantically explains that loan sharks are threatening to break his arms and his legs. Rather than sympathizing, she laughs and tells him she hopes they break his head as well. He bursts into tears and crawls to her, begging. The mad look on his face frightens her and she takes a gun out of a drawer to scare him off. He laughs, saying he remembers giving her the gun a year ago and the firing pin was broken. She laughs, saying she had it fixed and blows up the lamp next to him to prove it.

他抓住她的手腕，两人摔倒在地，争抢枪支，互相碾压，直到突然间，他们一年多来都没有感受到的情感被点燃，他们开始在地板上，在破碎的灯和破碎的门旁做爱。他脑海里有一个小小的声音说：“这也许可行”，但随后他和他的身体之间出现了一道缝隙。她微笑着想，这才是他真正的问题。她被怜悯和爱所感动，决定让他回到她的生活中。这一幕以积极的结局结束：他得到了她的帮助，得以生存，他们的爱情又恢复了。

He grabs her wrist and they fall to floor wrestling for the gun, rolling over each other, until suddenly an emotion they haven’t felt for over a year ignites and they start to make love on the floor next to the smashed lamp and shattered door. A little voice in his head says, “This could work,” but then a gap opens between him… and his body. That, she thinks, smiling, is his real problem. Moved to pity and affection, she decides to take him back into her life. The scene ends on the positive: He has her help to survive, their love is restored.

如果观众同情这些角色，从消极到积极的转变将产生积极情绪。但哪种积极情绪呢？有很多。

If the audience empathizes with these characters, the movement from the negative to the positive will create a positive emotion. But which? There are many.

假设编剧想在夏日里拍摄，窗台上开满了色彩鲜艳的花朵，树上开满了花朵。制片人选择了金·凯瑞和米拉·索维诺。导演则为他们安排了从头到脚的镜头。他们一起营造了一种喜剧氛围。喜剧喜欢明亮的光线和色彩。喜剧演员需要全镜头，因为他们用整个身体来表演。凯瑞和索维诺是出色的喜剧演员。当凯瑞撞破门而入、索维诺拔出枪、这两个人试图做爱时，观众会感到一阵阵恐惧和笑声。然后当她把他带回来时，观众会感到一阵欢欣鼓舞。

Suppose the writer calls for a summer’s day, brightly colored flowers in window boxes, blossoms on the trees. The producer casts Jim Carrey and Mira Sorvino. The director composes them in head-to-foot shots. Together they’ve created a comic mood. Comedy likes bright light and color. Comics need full shots because they act with their whole bodies. Carrey and Sorvino are brilliant zanies. The audience will feel tingling fear spiced with laughter as Carrey bangs through the door, as Sorvino pulls a gun, as these two try to make love. Then a burst of joy when she takes him back.

但假设场景设在深夜，房子里点缀着随风摇曳的树影、月光和路灯。导演拍摄角度紧凑，倾斜，并命令实验室将色彩调暗。制片人选择了迈克尔·马德森和琳达·费奥伦蒂诺。场景一如既往地充满了惊悚氛围。我们心惊胆战，担心这两个人中有一个无法活着离开。想象一下马德森强行闯入，费奥伦蒂诺抓起一把枪，他们两个争抢着枪。当他们终于拥抱在一起时，我们会松一口气。

But suppose the scene were set in the dead of night, the house spackled with shadows of trees blowing in the wind, moonlight, street light. The director shoots tight, canted angles and orders the lab to mute the colors. The producer casts Michael Madsen and Linda Fiorentino. Without changing a beat, the scene is now drenched in a Thriller mood. Our hearts will be in our throats as we fear that one of these two isn’t getting out of this alive. Imagine Madsen bulling his way in, Fiorentino grabbing a gun, those two fighting for it. When they’re finally in each other’s arms, we’ll breathe a sigh of relief.

场景、序列或动作的弧线决定了基本情感。情绪使它具体化。但情绪不会取代情感。当我们想要情绪体验时，我们会去音乐会或博物馆。当我们想要有意义的情感体验时，我们会去找讲故事的人。写一个没有任何变化的充满说明的场景，然后把它设置在花园里，这对作家来说是毫无用处的。日落时分，以为金色的心情将占据上风。编剧所做的只是把蹩脚的剧本扔到导演和演员的肩上。在任何情况下，没有戏剧性的阐述都是无聊的。电影不是装饰性的摄影。

The arc of the scene, sequence, or act determines the basic emotion. Mood makes it specific. But mood will not substitute for emotion. When we want mood experiences, we go to concerts or museums. When we want meaningful emotional experience, we go to the storyteller. It does the writer no good to write an exposition-filled scene in which nothing changes, then set it in a garden at sundown, thinking that a golden mood will carry the day. All the writer has done is dump weak writing on the shoulders of the director and cast. Undramatized exposition is boring in any light. Film is not about decorative photography.

选择的本质

THE NATURE OF CHOICE

转折点的核心在于人物在压力下为了追求欲望而做出的选择。人性决定了我们每个人都会根据自己对“善”或“正确”的理解选择“善”或“正确”。否则就不可能了。因此，如果一个角色被置于必须在明显的善与明显的恶、正确与错误之间做出选择的境地，观众在了解角色的观点后，就会提前知道角色会如何选择。

A Turning Point is centered in the choice a character makes under pressure to take one action or another in the pursuit of desire. Human nature dictates that each of us will always choose the “good” or the “right” as we perceive the “good” or the “right.” It is impossible to do otherwise. Therefore, if a character is put into a situation where he must choose between a clear good versus a clear evil, or right versus wrong, the audience, understanding the character’s point of view, will know in advance how the character will choose.

善与恶、对与错之间的选择根本就不是选择。

The choice between good and evil or between right and wrong is no choice at all.

想象一下，匈奴王阿提拉站在五世纪欧洲边境，审视着他的军队，自问：“我应该入侵、屠杀、强奸、劫掠、焚烧和蹂躏……还是应该回家？”对阿提拉来说，这根本就不是选择。他必须入侵、屠杀、劫掠和蹂躏。当他终于看到胜利的曙光时，他并没有带领着横跨两大洲的数万名战士掉头返回。然而，在他的受害者眼中，他的决定是邪恶的。但这是他们的观点。对阿提拉来说，他的选择不仅是正确的，而且可能是道德的。毫无疑问，像历史上许多伟大的暴君一样，他觉得自己肩负着神圣的使命。

Imagine Attila, King of the Huns poised on the borders of fifth-century Europe, surveying his hordes and asking himself: “Should I invade, murder, rape, plunder, burn, and lay waste… or should I go home?” For Attila this is no choice at all. He must invade, slay, plunder, and lay waste. He didn’t lead tens of thousands of warriors across two continents to turn around when he finally came within sight of the prize. In the eyes of his victims, however, his is an evil decision. But that’s their point of view. For Attila his choice is not only the right thing to do, but probably the moral thing to do. No doubt, like many of history’s great tyrants, he felt he was on a holy mission.

或者，更贴近现实：一个小偷在街上用棍棒殴打一名受害者，以抢走她钱包里的五美元。他可能知道这样做不道德，但道德/不道德、正确/错误、合法/非法往往没有多大关系。他可能会立刻后悔自己所做的事。但在谋杀的那一刻，从小偷的角度来看，他的手臂不会移动，除非他确信这是正确的选择。

Or, closer to home: A thief bludgeons a victim on the street for the five dollars in her purse. He may know this isn’t the moral thing to do, but moral/immoral, right/wrong, legal/illegal often have little to do with one another. He may instantly regret what he’s done. But at the moment of murder, from the thief’s point of view, his arm won’t move until he’s convinced himself that this is the right choice.

如果我们对人性了解不够——即一个人只能按照自己所相信或合理化的方式做出正确或善良的行为——那么我们理解的就太少了。善与恶、对与错的选择显而易见，而且微不足道。

If we do not understand that much about human nature—that a human being is only capable of acting toward the right or the good as he has come to believe it or rationalize it—then we understand very little. Good/evil, right/wrong choices are dramatically obvious and trivial.

真正的选择是两难境地。它发生在两种情况下。首先，在不可调和的善与恶之间做出选择：从角色的角度来看，有两件事是可取的，他想要两者，但环境迫使他只能选择其中之一。其次，在两害相权取其轻之间做出选择：从角色的角度来看，有两件事是不可取的，他都不想要，但环境迫使他选择其中之一。角色在真正的两难境地中如何做出选择，是其人性和其所处世界的有力表达。

True choice is dilemma. It occurs in two situations. First, a choice between irreconcilable goods: From the character’s view two things are desirable, he wants both, but circumstances are forcing him to choose only one. Second, a choice between the lesser of two evils: From the character’s view two things are undesirable, he wants neither, but circumstances are forcing him to choose one. How a character chooses in a true dilemma is a powerful expression of his humanity and of the world in which he lives.

自荷马以来，作家们都懂得了困境的原理，并且意识到双边关系的故事无法持续下去，人物 A 和人物 B 之间的简单冲突无法得到令人满意的讲述。

Writers since Homer have understood the principle of dilemma, and realized that the story of a two-sided relationship cannot be sustained, that the simple conflict between Character A and Character B cannot be told to satisfaction.

双面冲突不是两难，而是在正反两面之间摇摆不定。例如，“她爱我/她不爱我，她爱我/她不爱”在好与坏之间来回摇摆，故事中的问题难以解决。它不仅冗长重复，而且没有结局。

A two-sided conflict is not dilemma but vacillation between the positive and the negative. “She loves me/she loves me not, she loves me/she loves not,” for example, swings back and forth between good and bad, and presents insoluble story problems. It isn’t only tediously repetitious, but it has no ending.

如果我们尝试以正面的方式将这种模式推向高潮，让主角相信“她爱我”，观众在看完后会想，“等到明天，她就不会再爱你了。”或者，如果以负面的方式“她不爱我”，观众在看完后会想，“她会回来的。她总是回来的。”即使我们杀死了所爱的人，这也不是一个真正的结局，因为主角会疑惑，“她爱我？她不爱我？”观众在看完后会摸索一个从未提出的观点。

If we try to climax this pattern on the positive with the protagonist believing “She loves me,” the audience leaves thinking, “Wait till tomorrow when she’ll love you not again.” Or if on the negative “She loves me not,” the audience exits thinking, “She’ll come back. She always did.” Even if we kill the loved one, it’s not a true ending because the protagonist is left wondering, “She loved me? She loved me not?” and the audience exits groping for a point that was never made.

比如，这里有两个故事：一个在内心的快乐与痛苦之间摇摆不定，另一个则陷入内心的困境。将《红沙漠》与《贝蒂布鲁》进行比较。在前者中，贝蒂（比阿特丽斯·达尔饰）从痴迷到疯狂再到紧张症。她有冲动，但从未做出真正的决定。在后者中，朱丽安娜（莫妮卡·维蒂饰）面临着深刻的困境：是退缩到安慰的幻想中，还是从严酷的现实中寻找意义，是疯狂还是痛苦。贝蒂布鲁的“模仿极简主义”是一个长达两个多小时的快照，记录了一个无助的精神分裂症患者，她把痛苦误认为是戏剧。《红沙漠》是一部极简主义的杰作，描绘了一个与她本性中可怕的矛盾作斗争的人。

For example, here are two stories: one that wavers back and forth between inward states of pleasure and pain and one of inner dilemma. Compare BETTY BLUE with THE RED DESERT. In the former, Betty (Beatrice Dalle) slides from obsession to madness to catatonia. She has impulses but never makes a true decision. In the later Giuliana (Monica Vitti) faces profound dilemmas: retreat into comforting fantasies versus making meaning out of a harsh reality, madness versus pain. BETTY BLUE’S “mock-minimalism” is an over two-hour long snapshot of a helpless victim of schizophrenia that mistakes suffering for drama. IL DESERTO ROSSO is a minimalist masterpiece that delineates a human being grappling with the terrifying contradictions within her nature.

要构建和创造真正的选择，我们必须构建一个三面的局面。就像在生活中一样，有意义的决定是三角的。

To construct and create genuine choice, we must frame a three-sided situation. As in life, meaningful decisions are triangular.

在添加 C 的那一刻，我们生成了足够的材料来避免重复。首先，对于 A 和 B 之间可能存在的三种关系：积极/消极/中立、爱/恨/冷漠，例如，我们在 A 和 C 之间以及 B 和 C 之间添加相同的三种关系。这给了我们九种可能性。然后我们可以将 A 和 B 与 C 结合起来；A而 C 则对 B；B 和 C 对 A。或者让他们全都相爱，全都相恨，全都漠不关心。通过添加第三个角，三角关系产生了 20 多种变化，材料多得足以不重复地发展。第四个元素会产生复合的互锁三角关系，即变化无常的关系。

The moment we add C we generate ample material to avoid repetition. First, to the three possible relationships between A and B: positive/negative/neutral, love/hate/indifference, for example, we add the same three between A and C and between B and C. This gives us nine possibilities. Then we may join A and B against C; A and C against B; B and C against A. Or put them all in love or all in hate or all indifferent. By adding a third corner, the triangle breeds over twenty variations, more than enough material to progress without repetition. A fourth element would produce compound interlocking triangles, a virtual infinitude of changing relationships.

更重要的是，三角设计带来了结局。如果故事是双向的，A 在 B 和无 B 之间摇摆不定，结局是开放的。但如果选择是三向的，A 被夹在 B 和 C 之间，A 的选择会让结局令人满意。无论 B 和 C 代表的是两害相权取其轻还是不可调和的善，主角都无法同时拥有两者。必须付出代价。必须冒着风险或失去其中一个才能获得另一个。例如，如果 A 放弃 C 而选择 B，观众会觉得做出了真正的选择。C 被牺牲了，这种不可逆转的变化结束了故事。

What’s more, triangular design brings closure. If a telling is two-sided so that A vacillates between B and no-B, the ending is open. But if choice is three-sided so that A is caught between B and C, A’s choice of one or the other closes the ending with satisfaction. Whether B and C represent the lesser of two evils or irreconcilable goods, the protagonist can’t have both. A price must be paid. One must be risked or lost to gain the other. If, for example, A relinquishes C to have B, the audience feels a true choice has been taken. C has been sacrificed, and this irreversible change ends the story.

最令人难以抗拒的困境往往是两害相权取其轻。例如，在超自然爱情片《唐娜·弗洛尔和她的两个丈夫》中，唐娜（索尼娅·布拉加饰）面临着一个选择：一个是温暖、安全、忠诚但乏味的新丈夫；另一个是性感、刺激但已死的前夫，然而他的鬼魂却在私下里以血肉之躯出现在她面前，并且性欲旺盛。她是在产生幻觉吗？寡妇该怎么办？她陷入了两难境地：是选择平凡而愉快的生活，还是选择怪异、甚至疯狂但充满情感满足的生活。她做出了明智的决定：选择两者。

The most compelling dilemmas often combine the choice of irreconcilable goods with the lesser of two evils. In the Supernatural Romance DONA FLOR AND HER TWO HUSBANDS, for example, Dona (Sonia Braga) faces a choice between a new husband who’s warm, secure, faithful, but dull versus an ex-husband who’s sexy, exciting, but dead, yet his ghost appears to her in private as flesh and blood and sexually insatiable as ever. Is she hallucinating or not? What’s the widow to do? She’s caught in the dilemma between a boringly pleasant life of normality versus a bizarre, perhaps mad, life of emotional fulfillment. She makes the wise decision: She takes both.

原创作品提出了独特但不可调和的欲望之间的选择：可能是两个人之间的选择、一个人和一种生活方式之间的选择、两种生活方式之间的选择、两种理想之间的选择、内心深处的两个方面之间的选择——作家可以设计出任何冲突程度的任何冲突欲望，无论是真实的还是想象的。但原则是普遍的：选择不能是怀疑，而应该是两难，不是在对与错或善与恶之间，而是在同等重要和价值的积极欲望或消极欲望之间。

An original work poses choices between unique but irreconcilable desires: It may be between two persons, a person and a lifestyle, two lifestyles, two ideals, two aspects of the innermost self—between any conflicting desires at any level of conflict, real or imagined, the writer may devise. But the principle is universal: Choice must not be doubt but dilemma, not between right/wrong or good/evil, but between either positive desires or negative desires of equal weight and value.

11

场景分析

11

SCENE ANALYSIS

正文与潜台词

TEXT AND SUBTEXT

正如可以通过心理分析揭示性格结构一样，可以通过类似的探究揭示场景的内心生活。如果我们提出正确的问题，阅读中快速浏览并隐藏其缺陷的场景会以超慢动作停下来，打开并揭示其秘密。

Just as a personality structure can be disclosed through psychoanalysis, the shape of a scene’s inner life can be uncovered through a similar inquiry. If we ask the right questions, a scene that speeds past in the reading and hides its flaws brakes into ultra-slow motion, opens up, and reveals its secrets.

如果你觉得一个场景很精彩，就不要去修改它。但通常情况下，初稿会显得平淡无奇或显得牵强。然后我们就会倾向于一遍又一遍地重写对话，希望通过解释演讲内容，我们可以让它变得生动……直到我们走进死胡同。因为问题不在于场景的活动，而在于它的动作；不在于角色表面上的说话或行为，而在于他们面具后面的行为。节拍构建了场景，而设计不当的场景的缺陷就在于这些行为交流。要找出一个场景失败的原因，必须将整体分解成各个部分。因此，分析从将场景的文本与其潜台词分开开始。

If you feel a scene plays, don’t fix what works. But often a first draft falls flat or seems forced. Our tendency then is to rewrite dialogue over and over, hoping that by paraphrasing speeches we can bring it to life… until we hit a dead end. For the problem won’t be in the scene’s activity but in its action; not in how characters are talking or behaving on the surface, but in what they’re doing behind their masks. Beats build scenes, and the flaws of an ill-designed scene are in these exchanges of behavior. To find out why a scene fails, the whole must be broken into its parts. An analysis begins, therefore, by separating the scene’s text from its subtext.

文字是艺术作品的感官表面。在电影中，文字是屏幕上的图像以及对话、音乐和音效的配乐。我们看到的。我们听到的。人们说的。人们做的。潜台词是表面之下的生活——已知和未知的思想和感受，隐藏在行为之下。

Text means the sensory surface of a work of art. In film it’s the images onscreen and the soundtrack of dialogue, music, and sound effects. What we see. What we hear. What people say. What people do. Subtext is the life under that surface—thoughts and feelings both known and unknown, hidden by behavior.

一切都不是表面上看起来的那样。这一原则要求编剧时刻意识到生活的虚伪，认识到一切都至少存在于两个层面，因此，他必须写出同时存在的二元性：首先，他必须创造对生命感官表面的文字描述，视觉和声音，活动和谈话。其次，他必须创造有意识和无意识的欲望、行动和反应、冲动和本我、遗传和经验命令的内心世界。现实如此，小说亦然：他必须用活生生的面具掩盖真相，即人物言行背后的真实思想和感受。

Nothing is what it seems. This principle calls for the screen-writer’s constant awareness of the duplicity of life, his recognition that everything exists on at least two levels, and that, therefore, he must write a simultaneous duality: First, he must create a verbal description of the sensory surface of life, sight and sound, activity and talk. Second, he must create the inner world of conscious and unconscious desire, action and reaction, impulse and id, genetic and experiential imperatives. As in reality, so in fiction: He must veil the truth with a living mask, the actual thoughts and feelings of characters behind their saying and doing.

好莱坞有句老话：“如果一场戏是关于什么的，那你就倒霉了。”它的意思是“直截了当地”写作，在对话和活动中，人物最深层的思想和感受通过人物的言行来表达——将潜台词直接写进文本中。

An old Hollywood expression goes: “If the scene is about what the scene is about, you’re in deep shit.” It means writing “on the nose,” writing dialogue and activity in which a character’s deepest thoughts and feelings are expressed by what the character says and does—writing the subtext directly into the text.

例如，写下这句话：两个相貌俊美的人坐在烛光桌旁，烛光映照着水晶酒杯和恋人水汪汪的眼睛。微风吹动窗帘。背景中播放着肖邦的夜曲。恋人越过桌子，握住手，渴望地看着对方的眼睛，说：“我爱你，我爱你”……而且是真心实意的。这是一个无法表演的场景，会像路上的老鼠一样消失。

Writing this, for example: Two attractive people sit opposite each other at a candlelit table, the light glinting off the crystal wine-glasses and the dewy eyes of the lovers. Soft breezes billow the curtains. A Chopin nocturne plays in the background. The lovers reach across the table, touch hands, look longingly in each others’ eyes, say, “I love you, I love you”… and actually mean it. This is an unactable scene and will die like a rat in the road.

演员不是模仿手势和口语的木偶。他们是艺术家，用潜台词而不是文本中的素材进行创作。演员从内到外，从未说出来，甚至是无意识的想法和感受到行为的表面，将角色演绎得栩栩如生。演员会说和做场景需要的任何事情，但他们在内心生活中找到创作的源泉。上面的场景无法表演，因为它没有内心生活，没有潜台词。它无法表演，因为没有什么可表演的。

Actors are not marionettes to mime gestures and mouth words. They’re artists who create with material from the subtext, not the text. An actor brings a character to life from the inside out, from unspoken, even unconscious thoughts and feelings out to a surface of behavior. The actors will say and do whatever the scene requires, but they find their sources for creation in the inner life. The scene above is unactable because it has no inner life, no subtext. It’s unactable because there’s nothing to act.

当我们回想自己看电影的经历时，我们会意识到，我们一生都在见证潜台词现象。屏幕不是不透明的，而是透明的。当我们抬头看着屏幕时，我们难道不会觉得我们正在读心术和感受吗？我们经常对自己说：“我知道那个角色真正在想什么、感受什么。我比她自己更了解她内心的想法，我比和她交谈的那个男人更了解，因为他忙于自己的计划。”

When we reflect on our filmgoing, we realize we’ve witnessed the phenomenon of subtext all our lives. The screen isn’t opaque but transparent. When we look up at the screen, don’t we have the impression that we’re reading minds and feelings? We constantly say to ourselves, “I know what that character’s really thinking and feeling. I know what’s going on inside her better than she does, and I know it better than the guy she’s talking to because he’s busy with his own agenda.”

在生活中，我们的目光往往停留在表面。我们被自己的需求、冲突和白日梦所占据，以至于我们很少能够退后一步，冷静地观察其他人内心的想法。偶尔，我们会把咖啡店角落里的一对情侣框起来，创造一个电影时刻，透过他们的笑容看到他们内心的无聊，透过他们眼中的痛苦看到他们对彼此的希望。但这种情况很少发生，也只持续一瞬间。然而，在故事的仪式中，我们不断地透过人物的面孔和活动看到未说出口的、未被察觉的深处。

In life our eyes tend to stop at the surface. We’re so consumed by our own needs, conflicts, and daydreams that we rarely manage to take a step back and coolly observe what’s going on inside other human beings. Occasionally we put a frame around a couple in the corner of a coffee shop and create a movie moment as we look through their smiles to the boredom beneath or through the pain in their eyes to the hope they have for each other. But rarely and only for a moment. In the ritual of story, however, we continuously see through the faces and activities of characters to depths of the unspoken, the unaware.

这就是为什么我们要去找讲故事的人，他是引导我们超越表象到达真相的向导……在各个层面，不只是片刻，而是走到终点。讲故事的人给我们带来生活所拒绝的乐趣，让我们享受坐在故事的黑暗仪式中的乐趣，透过生活的表象，看到所说和所做的背后的感受和思想的本质。

This is why we go to the storyteller, the guide who takes us beyond what seems to what is… at all levels and not for a mere moment but to the end of the line. The storyteller gives us the pleasure that life denies, the pleasure of sitting in the dark ritual of story, looking through the face of life to the heart of what is felt and thought beneath what’s said and done.

那么，我们该如何写一场爱情戏呢？让两个人换车胎。让这场戏成为一本关于如何修理轮胎的虚拟教科书。让所有的对话和动作都围绕着千斤顶、扳手、轮毂盖和螺母：“能帮我一下吗？”“小心点。”“别弄脏了。”“让我……哎呀。”演员们会演绎这场戏的真实动作，所以要留出空间让他们完全从内心深处把浪漫演绎得活灵活现。当他们的目光相遇，火花四溅时，我们就会知道发生了什么，因为那是演员们未说出口的想法和情感。当我们看透表面时，我们会带着会心的微笑向后靠：“看看发生了什么。他们不只是在换车胎。他认为她很性感，她也知道。男孩遇到了女孩。”

How then might we write a love scene? Let two people change the tire on a car. Let the scene be a virtual textbook on how to fix a flat. Let all dialogue and action be about jack, wrench, hubcap, and lug nuts: “Hand me that, would ya?” “Watch out.” “Don’t get dirty.” “Let me… whoops.” The actors will interpret the real action of the scene, so leave room for them to bring romance to life wholly from the inside. As their eyes meet and sparks fly, we’ll know what’s happening because it’s in the unspoken thoughts and emotions of the actors. As we see through the surface, we’ll lean back with a knowing smile: “Look what happened. They’re not just changing the tire on a car. He thinks she’s hot and she knows it. Boy has met girl.”

换句话说，要像生活中发生的事情一样去写。因为如果我们把那个烛光场景交给优秀的演员，他们会嗅到谎言，拒绝表演，然后走开，直到场景被剪掉或重写为可表演的潜台词。如果演员缺乏要求重写的能力，那么他们会这样做：他们会在场景中加入潜台词，无论它是否与故事有关。优秀的演员不会在没有潜台词的情况下站在镜头前。

In other words, write as these things happen in life. For if we give that candlelit scene to fine actors, they’ll smell the lie, refuse to act it, and walk off until the scene is cut or rewritten with an actable subtext. If the cast lacks the clout to demand a rewrite, then they’ll do this: They will put a subtext in the scene whether or not it has anything to do with the story. Good actors will not step in front of a camera without their subtext.

例如，一个被迫拍摄烛光场景的演员可能会这样攻击：“这些人为什么要特意去创造这个电影场景？为什么烛光、轻柔的音乐和飘扬的窗帘？他们为什么不像正常人一样拿着意大利面去电视机前？这种关系出了什么问题？ ”因为这不就是生活吗？蜡烛什么时候熄灭？当一切都好的时候？不。当一切都好的时候，我们像正常人一样拿着意大利面去电视机前。所以从这个洞察出发，演员会创造出潜台词。现在，我们一边看，一边想：“他说他爱她，也许他真的爱她，但是你看，他害怕失去她。他很绝望。”或者另一个潜台词：“他说他爱她，但是你看，他在给她制造坏消息。他正准备离开。”

For example, an actor forced to do the candlelit scene might attack it like this: “Why have these people gone out of their way to create this movie scene? What’s with the candlelight, soft music, billowing curtains? Why don’t they just take their pasta to the TV set like normal people? What’s wrong with this relationship?” Because isn’t that life? When do the candles come out? When everything’s fine? No. When everything’s fine we take our pasta to the TV set like normal people. So from that insight the actor will create a subtext. Now as we watch, we think: “He says he loves her and maybe he does, but look, he’s scared he’s losing her. He’s desperate.” Or from another subtext: “He says he loves her, but look, he’s setting her up for bad news. He’s getting ready to walk out.”

这场戏并不是关于表面上的内容。而是关于其他事情。而正是那些其他的事情——试图重新赢得她的爱或让她为分手而心软——才会让这场戏成功。总会有一个潜台词，一个与文本形成对比或矛盾的内心生活。鉴于此，演员将创作出一部多层次的作品，让我们透过文本看到生命的眼睛、声音和手势背后震动的真相。

The scene is not about what the scene seems to be about. It’s about something else. And it’s that something else—trying to regain her affection or softening her up for the breakup—that will make the scene work. There’s always a subtext, an inner life that contrasts with or contradicts the text. Given this, the actor will create a multilayered work that allows us to see through the text to the truth that vibrates behind the eyes, voice, and gestures of life.

这条原则并不意味着人们不真诚。我们都戴着公众面具，这是常识。我们说和做我们认为应该做的事，而我们的想法和感受却完全不同。我们必须这样做。我们意识到我们不能到处说和做我们真正想和感受的事情。如果我们都这样做，生活就会变成疯人院。事实上，这就是你知道你在和一个疯子说话的方式。疯子是那些可怜的人，他们失去了内心的交流，所以他们允许自己说出和做他们正在想和感受的事情，这就是他们疯的原因。

This principle does not mean that people are insincere. It’s a commonsense recognition that we all wear a public mask. We say and do what we feel we should, while we think and feel something else altogether. As we must. We realize we can’t go around saying and doing what we’re actually thinking and feeling. If we all did that, life would be a lunatic asylum. Indeed, that’s how you know you’re talking to a lunatic. Lunatics are those poor souls who have lost their inner communication and so they allow themselves to say and do exactly what they are thinking and feeling and that’s why they’re mad.

事实上，任何人，即使是精神病患者，都几乎不可能完全表达内心的想法。无论我们多么希望表达我们最深切的感受，它们都躲避着我们。我们从来没有完全表达真相，因为事实上我们很少知道真相。考虑一下我们迫切想要表达我们最真实的想法和感受的情况——心理分析：一个病人躺在沙发上，倾诉他的心声。希望被理解。没有任何限制。没有什么亲密的亲密关系是不能透露的。当他把可怕的想法和欲望撕到表面时，分析师做了什么？静静地点头并做笔记。那些笔记里有什么？什么没有被说出，秘密，病人痛苦的忏悔背后隐藏着无意识的真相。一切都不是表面上看到的。没有潜台词的文字。

In truth, it’s virtually impossible for anyone, even the insane, to fully express what’s going on inside. No matter how much we wish to manifest our deepest feelings, they elude us. We never fully express the truth, for in fact we rarely know it. Consider the situation in which we are desperate to express our truest thoughts and feelings—psychoanalysis: A patient lies on a couch, pouring his heart out. Wanting to be understood. No holds barred. No intimacy too private to reveal. And as he rips terrible thoughts and desires to the surface, what does the analyst do? Quietly nods and takes notes. And what’s in those notes? What is not being said, the secret, unconscious truths that lie behind the patient’s gut-wrenching confession. Nothing is what is seems. No text without a subtext.

这并不意味着我们不能写出充满力量的对话，让绝望的人试图说出真相。这只是意味着最激情的时刻必须隐藏更深的层次。

Nor does this mean that we can’t write powerful dialogue in which desperate people try to tell the truth. It simply means that the most passionate moments must conceal an even deeper level.

唐人街：伊芙琳·穆尔雷大喊：“她是我的妹妹和女儿。我父亲和我……”但她没有说的是：“请帮帮我。”她痛苦的忏悔实际上是在请求帮助。潜台词：“我没有杀死我的丈夫；我的父亲杀了……为了占有我的孩子。如果你逮捕我，他会带走她。请帮帮我。”在下一个节拍中，吉蒂斯说：“我们必须把你赶出城。”一个不合逻辑的回答却完全合情合理。潜台词：“我明白了你告诉我的一切。我现在知道是你父亲干的。我爱你，我会冒着生命危险去救你和你的孩子。然后我会去追那个混蛋。”所有这些都是在场景的背后，给我们真实的行为，没有虚假的“直截了​​当”的对话，更重要的是，没有剥夺观众洞察的乐趣。

CHINATOWN: Evelyn Mulwray cries out: “She’s my sister and my daughter. My father and I…” But what she doesn’t say is: “Please help me.” Her anguished confession is in fact a plea for help. Subtext: “I didn’t kill my husband; my father did… to possess my child. If you arrest me, he’ll take her. Please help me.” In the next beat Gittes says, “We’ll have to get you out of town.” An illogical reply that makes perfect sense. Subtext: “I’ve understood everything you’ve told me. I now know your father did it. I love you and I’m going to risk my life to save you and your child. Then I’m going after the bastard.” All this is underneath the scene, giving us truthful behavior without phony “on the nose” dialogue, and what’s more, without robbing the audience of the pleasure of insight.

星球大战：当达斯·维德向卢克提供机会与他一起管理宇宙，带来“秩序”时，卢克的反应是试图自杀。这同样不是一个合乎逻辑的反应，但却是完全合理的，因为卢克和观众都读懂了达斯·维德的潜台词：“带来秩序”背后是未明言的暗示“……奴役数十亿人。”当卢克试图自杀时，我们读到了一个英雄的潜台词：“我宁愿死也不愿加入你的邪恶事业。”

STAR WARS: When Darth Vader offers Luke the chance to join him in running the universe, bringing “order to things,” Luke’s reaction is to attempt suicide. Again not a logical reaction, but one that makes perfect sense, for both Luke and the audience read Darth Vader’s subtext: Behind “bring order to things” is the unspoken implication “… and enslave billions.” When Luke attempts to kill himself, we read a heroic subtext: “I’ll die before I’d join your evil enterprise.”

角色可能会说或做任何你能想象到的事情。但因为任何人都不可能说出或表现出完全的真相，因为至少总有一个潜意识的维度，所以作家必须加入潜台词。当观众感觉到潜台词时，场景就开始了。

Characters may say and do anything you can imagine. But because it’s impossible for any human being to tell or act the complete truth, because at the very least there’s always an unconscious dimension, the writer must layer in a subtext. And when the audience senses that subtext, the scene plays.

这一原则也适用于第一人称小说、戏剧独白以及直接面对镜头或画外音的叙述。因为如果人物私下与我们交谈，这并不意味着他们知道真相或有能力说出真相。

This principle also extends to the first-person novel, theatrical soliloquy, and direct-to-camera or voice-over narration. For if characters talk privately to us, that doesn’t mean for a moment that they know the truth or are capable of telling it.

安妮·霍尔：当艾维·辛格（伍迪·艾伦饰）直接向观众“坦白”他的恐惧和不足时，他也撒谎、掩饰、哄骗、夸大和合理化，所有这些都以一种他自欺欺人地努力赢得我们的支持，并说服自己他的心是善良的。

ANNIE HALL: When Alvy Singer (Woody Allen) speaks directly to the audience “confessing” his fears and inadequacies, he also lies, dissembles, cajoles, exaggerates, and rationalizes, all in a self-deceived effort to win us over and convince himself his heart’s in the right place.

即使角色独自一人，潜台词也会出现。因为如果没有其他人在看着我们，我们就会看着我们。我们戴着面具来隐藏真实的自我。

Subtext is present even when a character is alone. For if no one else is watching us, we are. We wear masks to hide our true selves from ourselves.

不仅个人戴口罩，机构也一样，并聘请公关专家来确保口罩不脱落。帕迪·查耶夫斯基的讽刺作品《医院》直指这一事实的核心。医院工作人员都穿着白色衣服，表现得专业、有爱心、科学。但如果你曾在医疗机构工作过，你就会知道贪婪、自负和一丝疯狂是无形的。如果你想死，就去医院。

Not only do individuals wear masks, but institutions do as well and hire public relations experts to keep them in place. Paddy Chayefsky’s satire HOSPITAL cuts to the core of that truth. Hospital staffs all wear white and act as if professional, caring, and scientific. But if you’ve ever worked inside a medical institution, you know that greed and ego and a touch of madness are invisibly there. If you want to die, go to a hospital.

生命永恒的二重性即使对于无生命体也是如此。在罗伯特罗森改编的梅尔维尔的《比利巴德》中，一艘战舰在夜晚的热带海域休息。无数的星星在头顶闪烁，在漆黑平静的海面上倒映出壮丽的景色。一轮低垂的满月将光芒从地平线拖到船头。柔软的船帆在暖风中颤动。残忍的军械长克拉加特 (罗伯特瑞安饰) 正在值班。比利 (特伦斯斯坦普饰) 睡不着，于是他走到甲板上，和克拉加特一起站在船舷边，赞叹今天的夜晚多么美丽。克拉加特回答说：“是的，比利，是的，但请记住，在那闪闪发光的表面之下是一个滑行的怪物的世界。”就连大自然也戴着面具。

The constant duality of life is true even for the inanimate. In Robert Rossen’s adaptation of Melville’s BILLY BUDD a man-o-war rests in tropical waters at night. Uncountable stars gleam above, all magnificently reflected in a black, calm sea. A low, full moon trails its light from the horizon to the ship’s prow. The limp sails tremble in the warm breezes. The cruel master-at-arms, Claggart (Robert Ryan) is holding watch. Billy (Terence Stamp) can’t sleep, so he comes out on deck, stands at the gunnels with Claggart, and remarks on what a beautiful evening it is. Claggart answers, “Yes, Billy, yes, but remember, beneath that glittering surface is a universe of gliding monsters.” Even Mother Nature wears her masks.

场景分析技术

THE TECHNIQUE OF SCENE ANALYSIS

要分析一个场景，你必须在文本和潜台词两个层面剖析其行为模式。经过适当的检查，其缺陷就会变得一目了然。下面是一个旨在让场景泄露其秘密的五步流程。

To analyze a scene you must slice into its pattern of behaviors at the levels of both text and subtext. Once properly examined, its flaws become vividly clear. Below is a five-step process designed to make a scene give up its secrets.

第一步：定义冲突

Step One: Define Conflict

首先要问，谁推动了这一场景，激发了这一场景，并让它发生？任何角色或力量都可能推动这一场景，即使是无生命的物体或自然行为。然后研究这个角色的文本和潜台词或强迫，并问：他（或它）想要什么？欲望永远是关键。用不定式表达这种欲望（或用演员的习语来说：场景目标）：例如，“做这个……”或“得到那个……”

First ask, who drives the scene, motivates it, and makes it happen? Any character or force might drive a scene, even an inanimate object or act of nature. Then look into both the text and subtext of this character or force, and ask: What does he (or it) want? Desire is always the key. Phrase this desire (or in the actor’s idiom: scene objective) as an infinitive: such as, “to do this…” or “to get that…”

接下来，纵观整个场景，问：哪些对抗力量阻碍了这种愿望？同样，这些力量可能来自任何层面或组合。确定对抗的来源后，问：对抗力量想要什么？这也最好用不定式来表达：“不要那样做……”或“为了得到这个……”如果场景写得很好，当你比较表达双方愿望的短语集时，你会发现它们是直接冲突，而不是间接冲突。

Next, look across the scene and ask: What forces of antagonism block this desire? Again, these forces may come from any level or combination. After identifying the source of antagonism, ask: What do the forces of antagonism want? This too is best expressed as an infinitive: “Not to do that…” or “To get this instead…” If the scene is well written, when you compare the set of phrases expressing the desires from each side, you’ll see that they’re in direct conflict—not tangential.

第二步：记录开仓价值

Step Two: Note Opening Value

确定场景中所涉及的价值，并在场景开始时注意其正面或负面的倾向。例如：“自由。主角处于负面，是他自己执着野心的囚徒。”或者：“信仰。主角处于正面，他相信上帝会让他摆脱这种境地。”

Identify the value at stake in the scene and note its charge, positive or negative, at the opening of the scene. Such as: “Freedom. The protagonist is at the negative, a prisoner of his own obsessive ambition.” Or: “Faith. The protagonist is at the positive, he trusts in God to get him out of this situation.”

第三步：将场景分解成节拍

Step Three: Break the Scene into Beats

节拍是角色行为中动作/反应的交换。仔细观察场景中的第一个动作，从两个层面进行：从外表看角色似乎在做什么，更重要的是，透过表面看他实际上在做什么。用主动动名词短语来命名这个潜台词动作，例如“乞求”。尝试找到不仅表示动作而且触动角色感情的短语。例如，“恳求”表明角色的行为带有一种正式感，而“跪在她脚下”则传达出一种绝望的奴性。

A beat is an exchange of action/reaction in character behavior. Look carefully at the scene’s first action on two levels: outwardly, in terms of what the character seems to be doing, and, more important, look beneath the surface to what he is actually doing. Name this subtextural action with an active gerund phrase, such as “Begging.” Try to find phrases that not only indicate action but touch the feelings of the character. “Pleading” for example, suggests a character acting with a sense of formality, whereas “Groveling at her feet” conveys a desperate servility.

潜台词中表达动作的短语并不是从字面上描述人物的活动，而是更深入地用情感内涵来命名人物的本质动作。

The phrases that express the action in the subtext do not describe character activity in literal terms; they go deeper to name the character’s essential action with emotive connotations.

现在看看整个场景，看看这个动作引起了什么反应，并用主动动名词短语描述这种反应。例如，“无视请求。”

Now look across the scene to see what reaction that action brought, and describe that reaction with an active gerund phrase. For example, “Ignoring the plea.”

这种动作和反应的交换是一个节拍。只要它继续，角色 A 就会“跪倒在她脚下”，而角色 B 则会“无视恳求”，这是一个节拍。即使他们的交流重复多次，它仍然是同一个节拍。直到行为明显改变，才会出现新的节拍。

This exchange of action and reaction is a beat. As long as it continues, Character A is “Groveling at her feet” but Character B is “Ignoring the plea,” it’s one beat. Even if their exchange repeats a number of times, it’s still one and the same beat. A new beat doesn’t occur until behavior clearly changes.

例如，如果角色 A 的卑躬屈膝变为“威胁离开她”，而角色 B 的无视则变为“嘲笑威胁”，那么场景的第二个节拍就是“威胁/嘲笑”，直到 A 和 B 的行为第三次改变。然后，分析继续贯穿整个场景，将其解析为节拍。

If, for example, Character A’s groveling changed to “Threatening to leave her” and in reaction Character B’s ignoring changed to “Laughing at the threat,” then the scene’s second beat is “Threatening/Laughing” until A and B’s behavior changes for a third time. The analysis then continues through the scene, parsing it into its beats.

第四步：记录收盘价并与开盘价进行比较

Step Four: Note Closing Value and Compare with Opening Value

在场景结束时，检查角色处境的价值状态，并用积极/消极的术语描述它。将此注释与第二步中的注释进行比较。如果两个注释相同，则它们之间的活动为无事件。什么都没有改变，因此什么也没有发生。可能已经向观众传达了说明，但场景是平淡的。另一方面，如果价值发生了变化，那么场景就发生了转变。

At the end of the scene, examine the value-charged condition of the character’s situation and describe it in positive/negative terms. Compare this note to the one made in Step Two. If the two notations are the same, the activity between them is a nonevent. Nothing has changed, therefore nothing has happened. Exposition may have been passed to the audience, but the scene is flat. If, on the other hand, the value has undergone change, then the scene has turned.

第五步：调查节拍并找到转折点

Step Five: Survey Beats and Locate Turning Point

从开场节拍开始，回顾描述角色动作的动名词短语。当你将动作/反应追溯到场景结束时，应该会出现一种形状或模式。在精心设计的场景中，即使是看似杂乱无章的行为也会有弧线和目的。事实上，在这样的场景中，正是它们的精心设计让节拍感觉随机。在弧线内找到期望和结果之间出现重大差距的时刻，将场景转向其改变的最终价值。这个确切的时刻就是转折点。

Start from the opening beat and review the gerund phrases describing the actions of the characters. As you trace action/reaction to the end of the scene, a shape or pattern should emerge. In a well-designed scene, even behaviors that seem helter-skelter will have an arc and a purpose. In fact, in such scenes, it’s their careful design that makes the beats feel random. Within the arc locate the moment when the major gap opens between expectation and result, turning the scene to its changed end values. This precise moment is the Turning Point.

以下两个场景的设计分析说明了这种技术。

An analysis of the design of the following two scenes illustrates this technique.

卡萨布兰卡

CASABLANCA

《卡萨布兰卡》的中幕高潮是在时间和地点的统一下上演的，强调个人冲突并通过口头表达其主要动作。

Casablanca’s Mid-Act Climax is played within a unity of time and place that puts emphasis on personal conflict and expresses its primary action verbally.

概要

SYNOPSIS

1940 年，反法西斯自由战士里克·布莱恩和挪威侨民伊尔莎·伦德在巴黎相遇。他们坠入爱河，开始了一段恋情。他向她求婚，但她避而不答。里克上了盖世太保的逮捕名单。纳粹入侵前夕，这对恋人同意在火车站见面，一起逃离这座城市。但伊尔莎没有出现。相反，她寄了一张纸条说她爱里克，但再也不会见到他了。

Rick Blaine, an antifascist freedom fighter, and Ilsa Lund, a Norwegian expatriate, meet in Paris in 1940. They fall in love and begin an affair. He asks her to marry him, but she avoids an answer. Rick is on the Gestapo arrest list. On the eve of the Nazi invasion the lovers agree to meet at the train station and escape the city together. But Ilsa doesn’t show. Instead, she sends a note saying she loves Rick but will never see him again.

一年后，里克在卡萨布兰卡经营一家咖啡馆。他变得孤僻、坚定中立，不参与任何个人和政治事务。正如他所说，“我不会为任何人冒险。”他喝得太多，感觉好像自己已经杀死了以前的自己。然后伊尔莎挽着著名反抗军领袖维克多·拉兹洛的手走了进来。这对恋人再次相遇。在鸡尾酒聊天的背后，他们的激情显而易见。伊尔莎和拉兹洛一起离开，但里克坐在黑暗的咖啡馆里彻夜喝酒，等待着。

A year later, Rick runs a cafe in Casablanca. He’s become an isolate, determinedly neutral, uninvolved in all matters personal and political. As he says, “I stick my neck out for no man.” He drinks too much and feels as if he has killed his former self. Then Ilsa walks in on the arm of Victor Laszlo, a renowned resistance leader. The lovers meet again. Behind their cocktail chat their passion is palpable. Ilsa leaves with Laszlo, but Rick sits in the dark cafe drinking through the night, waiting.

午夜过后几个小时，她再次出现。此时里克非常伤感，而且同样醉醺醺的。伊尔莎小心翼翼地告诉他，她钦佩但并不爱拉兹洛。然后，在她告诉他她爱他之前，里克在醉酒的痛苦中，轻视了她的故事，将其与妓院里的故事进行比较。他带着扭曲的微笑盯着她，雪上加霜：“告诉我。你为了谁离开我？是拉兹洛吗？还是中间还有其他人？或者你不是那种会说出来的人？”这句诽谤的话暗示她是个妓女，他醉醺醺地哭了起来，把她赶出了门。

Hours after midnight she reappears. By now Rick is very maudlin and equally drunk. Ilsa tells him guardedly that she admires but doesn’t love Laszlo. Then, before she can tell him that she loves him, Rick, in drunken bitterness, belittles her story by comparing it to one told in a brothel. Staring at her with a twisted smile he adds insult to injury: “Tell me. Who’d you leave me for? Was it Laszlo? Or were there others in between? Or aren’t you the kind that tells?” This slur, implying she’s a whore, sends her out the door as he collapses in drunken tears.

中幕高潮

THE MID-ACT CLIMAX

第二天，伊尔莎和拉兹洛去寻找黑市出境签证。当他试图在一家咖啡馆做交易时，伊尔莎在街边的亚麻布摊上等着。里克看到她独自一人，便走了过去。

The next day Ilsa and Laszlo go in search of black market exit visas. While he tries to make a deal in a cafe, she waits at a linen stall on the street. Seeing her alone, Rick approaches.

第一步：定义冲突

Step One: Define Conflict

里克是这场戏的始作俑者，也是推动者。尽管里克内心很纠结，因为自从伊尔莎在巴黎抛弃他之后，他一直承受着痛苦，看到伊尔莎和另一个男人在一起，他又忍不住愤怒，但他的愿望很明确：“赢回伊尔莎。”他的敌意来源也同样明确：伊尔莎。伊尔莎的感情非常复杂，被内疚、悔恨和责任感等复杂的情绪所笼罩。她深爱着里克，如果可以的话，她会回到他身边；但出于只有她自己知道的原因，她不能。伊尔莎被夹在无法调和的需求之间，她的愿望可以表述为：“让她和里克的恋情留在过去，继续她的生活。”尽管内心纠结，但他们的愿望却截然相反。

Rick initiates and drives the scene. Despite inner conflict over the pain he has suffered since she abandoned him in Paris, and the anger he suppresses at seeing her with another man, Rick’s desire is clear: “To win Ilsa back.” His source of antagonism is equally clear: Ilsa. Her feelings are very complex and clouded by mixed emotions of guilt, regret, and duty. She loves Rick passionately and would go back to him if she could; but for reasons only she knows, she can’t. Caught between irreconcilable needs, Ilsa’s desire can be phrased as “To keep her affair with Rick in the past and move on with her life.” Although entangled with inner conflicts, their desires are in direct opposition.

第二步：记录开仓价值

Step Two: Note Opening Value

爱情主宰着整个场景。在他们最后一幕中，里克的侮辱行为让价值变得消极，但价值却偏向积极，因为观众和里克都看到了一线希望。在之前的场景中，伊尔莎被称为“伊尔莎·伦德小姐”，是与拉兹洛一起旅行的单身女性。里克想改变这种现状。

Love governs the scene. Rick’s insulting behavior in their last scene turned the value toward the negative, yet it leans to the positive because the audience and Rick see a ray of hope. In previous scenes Ilsa has been addressed as “Miss Ilsa Lund,” a single woman traveling with Laszlo. Rick wants to change that.

第三步：将场景分解成节拍

Step Three: Break the Scene into Beats

节拍 # 1

BEAT # 1

外部集市—亚麻布摊

EXT. BAZAAR—LINEN STALL

阿拉伯小贩摊位的招牌上写着“ LINGERIE”。他给伊尔莎看了一张蕾丝床单。

The sign over the Arab Vendor’s stall reads LINGERIE. He shows Ilsa a lace bed sheet.

卖方的行为：出售。

Vendor’s action: SELLING.

阿拉伯

ARAB

你不会找到宝藏

You’ll not find a treasure

就像整个摩洛哥一样，

like this in all Morocco,

小姐。

Mademoiselle.

就在这时，瑞克走到了她身后。

Just then, Rick walks up behind her.

瑞克的动作：接近她。

Rick’s action: APPROACHING HER.

伊尔莎不用看就能感觉到他的存在。她假装对蕾丝很感兴趣。

Without looking Ilsa senses his prescence. She feigns interest in the lace.

伊尔莎的反应：不理他。

Ilsa’s reaction: IGNORING HIM.

卖主举着一个牌子，上面写着“700法郎”。

The Vendor holds up a sign reading 700 FRANCS.

阿拉伯

ARAB

只有七百法郎。

Only seven hundred francs.

节奏 #2

BEAT #2

里克

RICK

你被骗了。

You’re being cheated.

瑞克的行动：保护她。

Rick’s action: PROTECTING HER.

伊尔莎花了几秒钟才平复心情。她看了一眼里克，然后礼貌地转向卖主。

Ilsa takes a second to compose herself. She glances at Rick, then with polite formality turns to the Vendor.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

没关系，谢谢你。

It doesn’t matter, thank you.

伊尔莎的反应：拒绝瑞克的求爱。

Ilsa’s reaction: REJECTING RICK’S ADVANCE.

为了让伊尔莎离开拉兹洛，里​​克的首要任务是打破僵局——鉴于他们上一幕中的相互指责和愤怒情绪，这绝非易事。他的警告似乎侮辱了阿拉伯小贩，她并不生气，但在潜台词中，它暗示了更多：她和拉兹洛的关系。

To win Ilsa away from Lazlo, Rick’s first task is to break the ice—no easy task given the recriminations and angry emotions of their last scene. His warning seems to insult the Arab Vendor, who takes no offense, but in the subtext it hints at more: her relationship with Lazlo.

节奏 #3

BEAT #3

阿拉伯

ARAB

啊……这位女士是我的朋友

Ah… the lady is a friend

Rick 的朋友？对于 Rick 的朋友，我们

of Rick’s? For friends of Rick we

有小幅折扣。七

have a small discount. Seven

一百法郎，我说过吗？

hundred francs, did I say?

（举起新的标牌）

(holding up a new sign)

你可以花两百美元买下它。

You can have it for two hundred.

里克

RICK

抱歉，我当时身体状况不佳

I’m sorry I was in no condition

接待来访者

to receive visitors when

你昨晚来拜访我了。

you called on me last night.

里克的行动：道歉。

Rick’s action: APOLOGIZING.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

没关系。

It doesn’t matter.

伊尔莎的反应：再次拒绝他。

Ilsa’s reaction: REJECTING HIM AGAIN.

阿拉伯

ARAB

啊！对于特别的朋友

Ah! For special friends of

Rick 我们有特别的

Rick’s we have a special

折扣。

discount.

他用第三个标志替换了第二个标志，上面写着“100法郎”。

He replaces the second sign with a third, reading 100 FRANCS.

第一节中里克的防御动作很自然，第二节中的道歉则更加困难和罕见。他用过度的礼节来掩饰自己的尴尬。伊尔莎无动于衷。

Rick’s protective action of the first beat comes naturally; the apology in the second beat is more difficult and rare. He masks his embarassment by using an excessive formality to make light of it. Ilsa is unmoved.

节奏 #4

BEAT #4

里克

RICK

你的故事让我有点

Your story left me a little

困惑。或许是

confused. Or maybe it was

波旁威士忌。

the bourbon.

里克的行动：找借口。

Rick’s action: EXCUSE MAKING.

阿拉伯

ARAB

我有一些桌布，一些

I have some tablecloths, some

餐巾……

napkins…

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

谢谢，我真的没有

Thank you, I’m really not

感兴趣的。

interested.

伊尔莎的反应：第四次拒绝里克。

Ilsa’s reaction: REJECTING RICK FOR THE FOURTH TIME.

阿拉伯

ARAB

（匆忙退场）

(exiting hurriedly)

请稍等片刻……

Only one moment…please…

阿拉伯小贩以多种方式丰富了场景。他以喜剧的语气开场，与黑暗的结局形成对比；他卖蕾丝，这增加了婚礼的内涵和内衣的性感；然而，最重要的是，他试图把里克卖给伊尔莎。小贩的第一句话就宣称里克是宝藏。为了展示里克的力量，小贩放下了他的价格为“Rick 的朋友”。然后，听到昨晚发生的事情后，摊主又降价为“Rick 的特别朋友”。

The Arab vendor enriches the scene in a number of ways. He opens it in a comic tone to counterpoint a dark ending; he sells lace which adds connotations of weddings and the sexuality of lingerie; most importantly, however, he tries to sell Rick to Ilsa. The vendor’s first line declares Rick a treasure. To demonstrate the power of Rick, the vendor drops his price for “friends of Rick’s.” Then, hearing something about last night, the vendor cuts it even more for “special friends of Rick’s.”

随后，里克第二次提到了他的酗酒问题，他试图让这件事为他的侮辱行为负责。伊尔莎什么都听不进去，但她站在那里等着，可以肯定她不是在等着买蕾丝。

This is followed by Rick’s second reference to his drinking, as he tries to make this take the blame for his insulting behavior. Ilsa will hear none of it, and yet she stands and waits and it’s safe to assume she isn’t waiting to buy lace.

节奏 #5

BEAT #5

她假装检查蕾丝制品，周围一片沉默。

A small silence as she pretends to examine the lace goods.

里克

RICK

你为什么回来？

Why’d you come back? To

告诉我你为什么跑出去

tell me why you ran out on

我在火车站吗？

me at the railway station?

瑞克的行动：获得机会。

Rick’s action: GETTING HIS FOOT IN THE DOOR.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

（悄悄）

(quietly)

是的。

Yes.

伊尔莎的反应：把门打开一条缝。

Ilsa’s reaction: OPENING THE DOOR A CRACK.

在连续四次听到“不”之后，里克希望她对任何事情都说“是”。于是他问了一个自带答案的问题。她平静的“是”打开了大门——也许这仍是锁链，但表明她愿意交谈。

After hearing no four times in a row, Rick wants her to say yes to anything. So he asks a question that supplies its own answer. Her quiet yes opens the door—keeping the chain on, perhaps, but indicating she’s willing to talk.

节奏 #6

BEAT #6

里克

RICK

好吧，你现在可以告诉我了。我

Well, you can tell me now. I’m

相当清醒。

reasonably sober.

里克的动作：跪下。

Rick’s action: GETTING DOWN ON HIS KNEES.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

我想我不会，里克。

I don’t think I will, Rick.

伊尔莎的反应：要求更多。

Ilsa’s reaction: ASKING FOR MORE.

沉默寡言的里克第三次因酗酒而自责。以他硬汉的作风，这是在乞讨，而且很管用。伊尔莎表示反对，以一种温和、礼貌的方式反对他，但仍继续装出买蕾丝的样子。用她的潜台词来解释：“这种乞讨方式很好。能不能再让我听听？”

The taciturn Rick insults himself over his drinking for the third time. In his tough guy manner, this is begging, and it works. Ilsa demurs, opposing him in a mild, polite way, yet continuing her lace-buying guise. To paraphrase her subtext: “That begging was nice for a change. Could I hear a little more, please?”

节奏 #7

BEAT #7

里克

RICK

为什么不呢？毕竟我

Why not? After all, I was

被困在火车票里。

stuck with the railroad ticket.

我认为我有权知道。

I think I’m entitled to know.

里克的行为：让她感到内疚。

Rick’s action: GUILT-TRIPPING HER.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

昨晚我看到了

Last night I saw what has

发生在你身上的事。瑞克

happened to you. The Rick I

在巴黎我就知道

knew in Paris, I could tell

他会理解的——但是

him. He’d understand—but

看着我的瑞克

the Rick who looked at me

怀着如此的仇恨……

with such hatred…

伊尔莎的反应：让他再次感到内疚。

Ilsa’s reaction: GUILT-TRIPPING HIM BACK.

这两个人之间有关系。每个人都觉得自己是受害方，而且都非常了解对方的敏感，因此他们很容易互相伤害。

These two people have a relationship. Each feels like the injured party, and each knows the sensitivity of the other so well that they hurt each other with ease.

节奏 #8

BEAT #8

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

（转身看着 Rick）

(turning to look at Rick)

我将离开卡萨布兰卡

I’ll be leaving Casablanca

很快。我们再也不会见面了

soon. We’ll never see each

彼此。我们非常清楚

other again. We knew very

彼此很少了解的时候

little about each other when

我们在巴黎相爱。如果我们

we were in love in Paris. If we

就这样吧，也许我们会

leave it that way, maybe we’ll

记得那些日子——不

remember those days—not

卡萨布兰卡——不是昨晚——

Casablanca—not last night—

伊尔莎的行动：说再见。

Ilsa’s action: SAYING GOODBYE.

瑞克只是盯着她。

Rick simply stares at her.

里克的反应：拒绝做出反应。

Rick’s reaction: REFUSING TO REACT.

潜台词中，伊尔莎善良、宽容的文字是明确的告别。无论她多么彬彬有礼，无论她的语言多么暗示她对里克的爱，这句话都是告别：“我们做朋友吧，让我们记住美好的时光，忘记不好的。”

In the subtext, Ilsa’s kind, forgiving prose is a clear goodbye. No matter how well-mannered, no matter how much her language implies her love for Rick, this is the kiss-off: “Let’s be friends, let’s remember the good times, and forget the bad.”

里克不会接受这一切。他拒绝做出反应；因为忽略某人的行为当然是一种反应。相反，他开始了下一个节拍。

Rick will have none of this. He reacts by refusing to react; for ignoring someone’s action is, of course, a reaction. Instead he starts the next beat.

节奏 #9

BEAT #9

里克

RICK

（声音低沉而强烈）

(voice low and intense)

你是否抛弃了我

Did you run out on me

因为你受不了？

because you couldn’t take it?

因为你知道那是什么

Because you knew what it

就像躲避

would be like, hiding from the

警察逃跑了

police, running away all the

时间？

time?

瑞克的行为：称她为懦夫。

Rick’s action: CALLING HER A COWARD.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

你可以相信如果你

You can believe that if you

想要。

want to.

伊尔莎的反应：骂他傻瓜。

Ilsa’s reaction: CALLING HIM A FOOL.

里克花了一年时间才弄清楚她为何离开他，他猜测她是个懦夫。然而，她每天都和拉兹洛一起冒险，所以她用冷酷的讽刺回敬他，暗示道：“我不在乎你怎么想；傻瓜才会相信这种胡说八道；如果你想加入他们，就也相信吧。”

Rick’s had a year to figure out why she left him, and his best guess is that she was a coward. She, however, dares death with Laszlo every day, and so she insults him in return with a cool sarcasm that implies: “I don’t care what you think; fools believe such nonsense; if you want to join them, believe it too.”

节奏 #10

BEAT #10

里克

RICK

好吧，我不会逃跑

Well, I’m not running away

我已经安定下来了——

anymore. I’m settled now—

确实比酒吧要好，但是

above a saloon, it’s true—but

走上一段楼梯。我会

walk up a flight. I’ll be

期待你。

expecting you.

里克的行为：对她进行性挑逗。

Rick’s action: SEXUALLY PROPOSITIONING HER.

伊尔莎垂下眼睛，转身背对着里克，宽边帽檐遮住了她的脸。

Ilsa drops her eyes and turns away from Rick, her face shaded by the wide brim of her hat.

伊尔莎的反应：隐藏她的反应。

Ilsa’s reaction: HIDING HER REACTION.

尽管伊尔莎否认，但他感觉到她的感情偏向了另一边。他清楚地记得他们在巴黎的性生活，也见过冷漠、冷漠的拉兹洛。所以他冒险在街上向她求爱。再次，成功了。伊尔莎也记得，她把脸红藏在帽檐下。有那么一刻，里克觉得她触手可及，但他还是忍不住说错话。

Despite her denials, he senses that her feelings lean the other way. He well remembers their sex life in Paris, and has seen the cold, aloof Laszlo. So he takes a chance and propositions her on the street. Again, it works. Ilsa too remembers, and hides her blush under her hat brim. For a moment Rick feels she’s within reach, but he can’t resist sticking his foot in his mouth.

节奏 #11

BEAT #11

里克

RICK

尽管如此，有一天你会

All the same, some day you’ll

对拉兹洛撒谎——你就会在那里。

lie to Laszlo—you’ll be there.

里克的行为：骂她是妓女。

Rick’s action: CALLING HER A WHORE.

伊利诺伊大学圣塔芭芭拉分校

ILSA

不，里克。你看，维克多

No, Rick. You see, Victor

拉兹洛是我的丈夫。

Laszlo is my husband.

并且是…

And was…

暂停，冷静地）……

pause, coolly)…

即使我认识你

even when I knew you in

巴黎。

Paris.

伊尔莎的反应：用这个消息打击他。

Ilsa’s reaction: CRUSHING HIM WITH THE NEWS.

伊尔莎镇定自若地走开了，留下震惊不已的里克目瞪口呆地看着她。

With dignity and poise, Ilsa walks away, leaving the stunned Rick to stare after her.

里克无法抑制伊尔莎抛弃里克所带来的痛苦。就像在他们之前场景的高潮中一样，他用性侮辱性的话反击，暗示她会背叛拉兹洛，回到他的床上。伊尔莎第二次被称为荡妇，她拿出她最硬的东西，用尽全力打了里克。然而，请注意，这只是半真半假；她没有补充说她认为她的丈夫是死了。相反，她留下了一个可怕的暗示：她是一个已婚女人，在巴黎利用了里克，当丈夫回来时，她抛弃了他。因此，她的爱从来都不是真实的。我们从潜台词中知道事实恰恰相反，但里克却伤心欲绝。

Rick can’t contain the pain caused by Ilsa’s abandonment. As in the climax of their previous scene, he strikes out with a sexual slur, implying that she’ll betray Laszlo to come back to his bed. Called a slut for a second time, Ilsa reaches back for the hardest thing she has, and strikes Rick with it as hard as she can. Notice, however, that this is a half-truth; she doesn’t add that she thought her husband was dead. Instead, she leaves a terrible implication in her wake: She was a married woman who used Rick in Paris, then walked out on him when her husband came back. Therefore, her love was never real. We know from the subtext that the opposite is the truth, but Rick is devastated.

第四步：记录收盘价并与开盘价进行比较

Step Four: Note Closing Value and Compare with Opening Value

主线情节从充满希望的积极面突然转变为消极面，其黑暗程度超出了里克的想象。伊尔莎不仅明确表示她现在不爱他，还暗示她从未爱过他。她的秘密婚姻使他们在巴黎的恋情变成了一场骗局，里克也成了戴绿帽的人。

The Central Plot turns sharply from a hopeful positive to a negative at a darker depth than Rick could have imagined. For not only does Ilsa make it clear she doesn’t love him now; she implies she never did. Her secret marriage turns their Paris romance into a sham and Rick into a cuckold.

第五步：调查节拍并找到转折点

Step Five: Survey the Beats and Locate the Turning Point

  1. 接近她/忽视他

  2. Approaching Her/Ignoring Him

  3. 保护她/拒绝他（和阿拉伯人）

  4. Protecting Her/Rejecting Him (and Arab)

  5. 道歉/拒绝他

  6. Apologizing/Rejecting Him

  7. 找借口/拒绝他（和阿拉伯人）

  8. Excuse Making/Rejecting Him (and Arab)
