  9. 踏入门槛/打开大门

  10. Getting His Foot in the Door/Opening the Door

  11. 跪下/要求更多

  12. Getting Down on His Knees/Asking for More

  13. 让她愧疚 / 让他愧疚

  14. Guilt-Tripping Her/Guilt-Tripping Him

  15. 说再见/拒绝反应

  16. Saying Goodbye/Refusing to React

  17. 称她为懦夫/称他为傻瓜

  18. Calling Her a Coward/Calling Him a Fool

  19. 向她提出性要求/隐藏她的反应

  20. Sexually Propositioning Her/Hiding Her Reaction

  21. 骂她贱人/毁了他的希望

  22. Calling Her a Slut/Destroying His Hope

动作/反应模式构建了快速的节拍。每次交流都超过前一次的节拍，让他们的爱情面临越来越大的风险，需要越来越多的意志力和能力来采取痛苦甚至残忍的行动，但同时又要保持冷静的控制。

The action/reaction pattern builds a rapid progression of beats. Each exchange tops the previous beat, placing their love in greater and greater risk, demanding more and more willpower and capacity to take painful, even cruel actions, but at the same time remain in cool control.

间隙在第十一拍中间打开，在启示上伊尔莎嫁给了拉兹洛，而她与里克有染。直到此刻，里克仍希望赢得她的芳心，但随着这一转折点的到来，他的希望破灭了。

The gap opens in the middle of the eleventh beat, on the revelation that Ilsa was married to Laszlo while having an affair with Rick. Until this moment, Rick has hopes of winning her over, but with this Turning Point his hope is shattered.

透过玻璃看黑暗

THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY

与《卡萨布兰卡》中静止的对话二重唱相比，《透过黑暗的玻璃》中卡琳/上帝情节的高潮随着时间的轻微延伸而从一个地方转移到另一个地方，涉及四个角色，锚定在内心冲突的层面，并通过身体传达其主要动作。

In contrast to the stationary dialogue duet in CASABLANCA, the Climax of the Karin/God plot in THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY shifts from place to place with slight ellipses of time, involves four characters, anchors itself at the level of inner conflict, and conveys its primary action physically.

概要

SYNOPSIS

伯格曼为这部电影设计了一个由六个相互关联的故事组成的多重情节。最有张力的是卡琳和她的“上帝”之间的冲突。她患有妄想性精神分裂症。在神志清醒的一段时间里，她出院与家人在波罗的海岛上的小屋里度过短暂的假期。当她努力保持理智时，她身边都是软弱、陷入困境的男人，他们向她寻求支持。

For this film Bergman designed a Multiplot of six interconnected stories. The most powerful is the conflict between Karin and her “God.” She suffers from delusional schizophrenia. During a period of lucidity, she’s released from a hospital to join her family for a brief holiday at their cottage on an island in the Baltic. While she struggles to hold on to her sanity, she’s surrounded by weak, troubled men who turn to her for support.

卡琳的父亲大卫外表善良，但内心压抑。他是一位受欢迎的小说家，但因缺乏评论界的认可而备受困扰。他更喜欢在安全的距离内观察生活，而不是为了艺术而牺牲生活。卡琳希望父亲快乐，并祈祷他取得艺术上的成功。

David, Karin’s father, is outwardly kind but emotionally repressed. He’s a popular novelist but hounded by his lack of critical recognition. He prefers to observe life at a safe distance before cannibalizing it for his art. Karin wants her father to be happy and prays for his artistic success.

卡琳的丈夫马丁是一名医生。她渴望得到他的理解和认可，但他却像对待自己的病人一样对她百般呵护，不断缠着她索要性爱。

Karin’s husband, Martin, is an MD. She craves his understanding and approval; instead, he patronizes her like one of his patients and pesters her for sex.

卡琳的哥哥米纳斯是她唯一真正的密友。她向他吐露心声，告诉他自己可怕的妄想背后的秘密，但他因青春期的性欲和与父亲的疏远而苦恼不已，没有给她多少安慰。相反，卡琳感觉到他的恐惧，于是安慰了米纳斯。

Karin’s brother, Minus, is her only true intimate. She confides in him, telling him the secrets of her terrifying delusions, but he’s so troubled with adolescent sexuality and estrangement from his father that he gives her little consolation. Instead, Karin, sensing his fears, offers Minus comfort.

很快，卡琳的敏锐感觉（甚至可能是心灵感应）就被幻觉所取代。她听到阁楼墙后传来声音，告诉她上帝将会出现。她害怕地转向马丁，但他却以婚姻中缺乏性生活为由羞辱她。当她找到父亲时，他像对待孩子一样温和地打发她。独自一人的卡琳偷看了父亲的日记，发现他对她唯一的兴趣就是作为下一部小说的人物研究。她试图告诉哥哥上帝降临的奇迹，但米纳斯对他的渴望感到困惑和折磨，他无法理解。突然间，卡琳的疯狂转向了性。她以野性的强度将哥哥拖入乱伦。

Soon Karin’s acute sensitivity (perhaps even psychic awareness) gives way to hallucination. She hears voices from behind an attic wall, telling her that God will appear. Scared, she turns to Martin, but he humiliates her over the lack of sex in their marriage. When she seeks out her father, he gently dismisses her like a child. Alone, Karin sneaks a look at her father’s diary and discovers that his only interest in her is as a character study for his next novel. She tries to tell her brother about the coming miracle of God’s visitation, but Minus is so confused and tormented by his cravings that he doesn’t understand. Suddenly, Karin’s madness takes a sexual turn. With feral intensity, she drags her brother down into incest.

当大卫发现发生了什么事时，他更多的是出于自怜，而不是对孩子的关心。令人惊讶的是，卡琳对他表示同情，而且知道他只是对她感兴趣，把她当作故事素材，这让她的父亲了解了她的病情。马丁打断了他的话，说他必须把卡琳送回精神病院。他叫了一辆救护车，开始收拾行李。

When David discovers what has happened, he’s moved more by self-pity than by concern for his children. Amazingly, Karin sympathizes with him, and knowing that he’s only interested in her as story material, gives her father insights into her illness. Martin interrupts, declaring that he must take Karin back to the mental hospital. He calls for an ambulance and starts to pack.

第一步：定义冲突

Step One: Define Conflict

卡琳主导着整个场景。她相信自己的声音，迫切希望看到上帝，这不仅是为了她自己的需要，也是为了她的男人们。她想让他们顿悟，也许是为了赢得认可，但更重要的是帮助他们陷入困境的生活。她的敌意有两个来源：首先是她的丈夫。马丁对她有性吸引力，也同情她，但他再也无法忍受她的疯狂，所以他想把她从她的“上帝”身边带走，把她安全地送回医院。第二个，也是更强大的，是她自己。虽然她希望瞥见天堂，但她的潜意识却等着给她一个地狱的景象。

Karin drives the scene. She believes in her voices and desperately hopes to see God, not only for her own needs but for her men. She wants to give them her epiphany, perhaps to win acceptance, but more importantly to help their troubled lives. Her sources of antagonism are two: first, her husband. Martin is drawn to her sexually and pities her, but he can no longer cope with her madness, so he wants to take her away from her “God” and put her safely back in the hospital. The second, and more powerful, is herself. While she hopes to have a glimpse of heaven, her subconscious waits to give her a vision of hell.

第二步：记录开仓价值

Step Two: Note Opening Value

希望以一种奇怪的方式充满了场景的开头。卡琳是电影中最有同理心的角色。我们希望她见到上帝的愿望能够实现。即使这是一个疯狂的幻想，它也会给一个饱受折磨的女人。此外，她在电影早期经历的许多精神体验让我们怀疑她可能不是在产生幻觉。我们希望发生一件超自然事件；卡琳战胜了她周围那些以自我为中心的男人。

Hope, in a strange way, fills the opening of the scene. Karin is the most empathetic character in the film. We want her desire to see God to be fulfilled. Even if it’s a mad fantasy, it would give joy to a tormented woman. Furthermore, her many psychic experiences earlier in the film have led us to suspect that she may not be hallucinating. We hold out hope for a supernatural event; Karin’s triumph over the self-centered men around her.

第三步：将场景分解成节拍

Step Three: Break the Scene into Beats

节奏 #1

BEAT #1

室内图：小屋卧室——白天

INT. COTTAGE BEDROOM—DAY

卡琳和马丁收拾行李准备上救护车。马丁翻遍了五斗橱，想找一件衬衫。卡琳费力地拖着塞得满满的行李箱，思绪似乎飘到了很远的地方。

Karin and Martin pack for the ambulance. Martin rummages through a chest of drawers, searching for a shirt. Karin’s thoughts seem far away as she struggles with an overstuffed suitcase.

卡琳

KARIN

你的衬衫已洗但尚未熨烫。

Your shirts are washed but not ironed.

卡琳的行动：计划逃跑。

Karin’s action: PLANNING HER ESCAPE.

马丁

MARTIN

无论如何，我在城里有衬衫。

I’ve got shirts in town anyway.

马丁的反应：隐瞒他的罪行。

Martin’s reaction: CONCEALING HIS GUILT.

卡琳

KARIN

请帮我结案。

Help me shut the case, please.

马丁费力地打开盖子，但一双鞋子挡住了门闩。他把鞋子拿出来，看了看。

Martin wrestles with the lid, but a pair of shoes keeps the latch from catching. He takes them out and looks at them.

马丁

MARTIN

这是我的鞋子。我可以把它们留在这里。

It’s my shoes. I can leave them here.

卡琳

KARIN

为什么不穿这些而把那些留着呢？

Why not wear these and leave those?

马丁

MARTIN

（表示对

(indicating the pair

他穿着）

he is wearing)

这些必须加以修补。

These have to be mended.

他把鞋子扔到地上，匆忙穿上夹克。卡琳慢慢关上行李箱盖。

He drops the shoes on the floor and hurriedly puts on his jacket. Karin slowly closes the suitcase lid.

这个节拍几乎是喜剧性的。卡琳穿好衣服收拾好行李，但马丁却像一个需要妈妈的男孩一样，手忙脚乱地走来走去。卡琳是一名正在接受电击治疗的精神病患者，但她仍然务实而沉着；马丁是一名医生，不知道该穿哪双鞋。在文本中，卡琳似乎在收拾行李，但在潜台词中，她正在计划下一步行动。他被自己的内疚感所困扰，没有看到她外表的平静背后隐藏着一个在阁楼上追求“奇迹”的阴谋。

This beat is almost comic. Karin’s dressed and packed, but Martin, like a boy needing a mother, fumbles around. She’s a psychiatric patient returning to electric shock treatments, yet remains practical and composed; he’s a doctor flustered over which shoes to wear. On the text Karin seems to be packing, but in the subtext she’s planning her next move. He’s so distracted by his guilty conscience, he doesn’t see that her outward calm conceals a mind scheming to pursue her “miracle” in the attic.

节奏 #2

BEAT #2

卡琳静静地、若有所思地抚摸着行李箱。然后：

Karin fingers the suitcase, quietly and thoughtfully. Then:

卡琳

KARIN

你有头痛药吗？

Have you a headache pill?

卡琳的行动：逃向她的“上帝”。

Karin’s action: ESCAPING TO HER “GOD.”

马丁

MARTIN

（环顾四周

(looking around the

房间）

room)

棕色的箱子在哪儿？

Where’s the brown case?

马丁的反应：帮助她。

Martin’s reaction: HELPING HER.

卡琳

KARIN

在厨房。

In the kitchen.

马丁

MARTIN

（回想）

(remembering)

是的，确实如此。

Yes, so it is.

马丁冲进

Martin rushes into the

内部厨房——相同

INT. KITCHEN—SAME

他在桌子上找到了他的药箱。他拿出一些药丸，倒了一杯水，然后轻手轻脚地走过

and finds his medical case on the table. He takes out some pills, fills a glass with water, then pads through the

内部主厅——相同

INT. MAIN HALL—SAME

回到

back to the

卧室——相同

INT. BEDROOM—SAME

马丁一进门，就发现卡琳已经走了。马丁放下水和药丸，冲回房间。

As he enters, a quick glance tells him that Karin’s gone. Martin puts down the water and pills and rushes back into the

内部主厅——相同

INT. MAIN HALL—SAME

正在找她。

looking for her.

卡琳比马丁更敏锐，但她如此轻易地摆脱了他，这体现了马丁的自我中心主义。他知道不能让精神分裂症患者独自一人，但他对把她送回医院感到内疚，因此他尽一切可能取悦她。他的关怀态度不是针对她的痛苦，而是针对他自己的痛苦。

Karin is more perceptive than Martin, but it’s a measure of his self-absorption that she gives him the slip so easily. He knows schizophrenics can’t be left alone, but his guilt over taking her back to the hospital has him doing everything possible to please her. His caring attitude isn’t about her suffering but his.

节奏 #3

BEAT #3

他看了一眼外面，然后跑向

He glances outside, then runs to

大卫的卧室——同样

INT. DAVID’S BEDROOM—SAME

然后打开门，让站在窗边的大卫大吃一惊。

and opens the door, surprising David at the window.

马丁

MARTIN

看到卡琳了吗？

Seen Karin?

马丁的行动：寻找卡琳。

Martin’s action: SEARCHING FOR KARIN.

大卫

DAVID

不。

No.

大卫的反应：帮助他寻找。

David’s reaction: HELPING HIM SEARCH.

马丁慌张地离开后，大卫跟着他走进了

As Martin leaves in a panic, David follows out into the

内部主厅——相同

INT. MAIN HALL—SAME

他和马丁交换了不确定的眼神。

where he and Martin exchange uncertain glances.

节奏 #4

BEAT #4

然后他们突然听到楼上传来卡琳的低语声。

Then suddenly they hear Karin’s voice in WHISPERS… upstairs.

卡琳的动作：祈祷。

Karin’s action: PRAYING.

大卫爬楼梯时，马丁准备了镇静剂。

Martin prepares a sedative while David climbs the stairs.

大卫的反应：冲向她。

David’s reaction: RUSHING TO HER.

马丁的反应：准备重新抓捕她。

Martin’s reaction: PREPARING TO RECAPTURE HER.

上厅

UPPER HALL

卡琳的低语声越来越大。

Karin’s WHISPERS grow louder.

卡琳

KARIN

（重复这句话）

(repeating the phrase)

是啊，我明白了，我明白了……

Yes, I see, I see…

卡琳的幻觉满足了这些人的愿望。对马丁来说，这是扮演医生的机会；对大卫来说，这是观察女儿病情最严重程度的机会。

Karin’s hallucination gives these men what they want. For Martin, the chance to play doctor; for David, the chance to observe his daughter’s illness at its most dramatic.

节奏 #5

BEAT #5

David 悄悄地走到一个未使用的

David quietly steps to an unused

阁楼房间——相同

INT. ATTIC ROOM—SAME

并将门打开几英寸来向内窥视。

and opens the door a few inches to peer inside.

David 的观点

DAVID’S POV

透过半开的门，卡琳站在房间中间，盯着墙，墙上的壁橱门紧闭着。她的声音庄重而虔诚，几乎是在吟诵这些话。

through the half-opened door of Karin standing in the middle of the room, staring at a wall with a closed closet door. Her voice is formal and prayerlike as she nearly chants the words.

卡琳

KARIN

（对着墙说话）

(talking to the wall)

是的，我完全明白。

Yes, I quite see.

卡琳的行动：为她的顿悟做准备。

Karin’s action: PREPARING FOR HER EPIPHANY.

关于大卫

ON DAVID

他注视着女儿，被她所创造的场景迷住了。

staring at his daughter, transfixed by the scene she’s creating.

卡琳（画外音）

KARIN (OFFSCREEN)

我知道这时间不会太长。

I know it won’t be long now.

大卫的反应：观察卡琳的疯狂。

David’s reaction: OBSERVING KARIN’S MADNESS.

马丁背着医疗包，和大卫一起走到门口。他怒视着卡琳，看着她和她想象中的倾听者说话。

Martin, carrying his medical bag, joins David at the door. He glares at the sight of Karin talking to her imaginary listener.

卡琳（配音）

KARIN (OS)

知道这一点很好。但是

It’s good to know that. But

我们很乐意等待。

we’ve been happy to wait.

马丁的反应：克制自己的情绪。

Martin’s reaction: FIGHTING HIS EMOTIONS.

卡琳在破裂的墙纸后面的声音面前祈祷，但她很清楚人们在努力寻找她，她父亲此刻警惕的目光，以及她丈夫压抑的愤怒。

Karin supplicates before the voices behind the cracked wallpaper, but she’s been well aware of the efforts to find her and of the now watchful eyes of her father, the suppressed anger of her husband.

节奏 #6

BEAT #6

马丁匆匆走进房间，来到卡琳身边。卡琳正焦急地把珠子绕在脖子上，虔诚地盯着墙壁和壁橱门。

Martin hurries into the room and over to Karin, who anxiously twists the beads around her neck and stares fixedly, reverently, at the wall and closet door.

马丁的行动：阻止她的幻觉。

Martin’s action: STOPPING HER HALLUCINATION.

卡琳

KARIN

（对马丁说）

(to Martin)

安静地走吧！他们说他会

Walk quietly! They say he’ll

很快就到了。我们必须

be here very soon. We must

做好准备。

be ready.

卡琳的反应：保护她的视力。

Karin’s reaction: PROTECTING HER VISION.

节奏 #7

BEAT #7

马丁

MARTIN

卡琳，我们要进城。

Karin, we’re going to town.

马丁的动作：把她拉走。

Martin’s action: PULLING HER AWAY.

卡琳

KARIN

我现在不能离开。

I can’t leave now.

卡琳的反应：坚持自己的立场。

Karin’s reaction: STANDING HER GROUND.

节奏 #8

BEAT #8

马丁

MARTIN

你错了，卡琳。

You’re wrong, Karin.

（看着关闭的门）

(looking at the closed door)

那里什么也没有发生。

Nothing is happening in there.

（抓住她的肩膀）

(taking her shoulders)

没有上帝会从门进来。

No God will come through the door.

马丁的行动：否认上帝的存在。

Martin’s action: DENYING THE EXISTENCE OF HER GOD.

卡琳

KARIN

他随时都会来。

He’ll come at any moment.

我必须在这里。

And I must be here.

卡琳的反应：捍卫她的信仰。

Karin’s reaction: DEFENDING HER FAITH.

马丁

MARTIN

卡琳，事实并非如此。

Karin, it’s not so.

节奏 #9

BEAT #9

卡琳

KARIN

不要这么大声！如果你不能

Not so loud! If you can’t be

靜默，走吧。

quiet, go.

卡琳的行动：命令马丁离开。

Karin’s action: ORDERING MARTIN AWAY.

马丁

MARTIN

跟我来。

Come with me.

卡琳

KARIN

你一定要把它弄坏吗？别再管我了。

Must you spoil it? Leave me alone.

大卫在门口注视着，卡琳从马丁身边走开，马丁则走到椅子上坐下，擦眼镜。

As David watches from the door, Karin pulls away from Martin, who withdraws to a chair, sits down, and cleans his glasses.

马丁的反应：撤退。

Martin’s reaction: RETREATING.

卡琳的实力确实比马丁强。马丁无法与卡琳的强大意志相抗衡，于是他放弃并撤退了。

Karin is simply stronger than Martin. Unable to match her powerful will, he gives up and withdraws.

节奏 #10

BEAT #10

卡琳面朝墙壁跪下，双手合十祈祷。

Karin kneels to face the wall and clasps her hands in prayer.

卡琳

KARIN

马丁，亲爱的，原谅我

Martin, dearest, forgive me

因为我太生气了。但不能

for being so cross. But can’t

你跪在我旁边吗？

you kneel down beside me?

你坐着的样子真滑稽

You look so funny sitting

我知道你不知道

there. I know you don’t

相信，但为了我的缘故。

believe, but for my sake.

卡琳的行动：将马丁吸引到她的仪式中。

Karin’s action: DRAWING MARTIN INTO HER RITUAL.

马丁的眼眶里噙满了泪水，他回到她身边，跪了下来，仿佛陷入了无助的痛苦之中。

Tears well up in Martin’s eyes, as in helpless anguish, he comes back to her and kneels.

马丁的反应：向她投降。

Martin’s reaction: SURRENDERING TO HER.

大卫一直在门口注视着。

All the while David watches from the doorway.

卡琳希望上帝的到来能带来完美的结果，所以她把不信教的马丁也带进了她奇怪的仪式中。

Karin wants everything to be perfect for the arrival of her God, so she brings the unbelieving Martin into her strange ritual.

节奏 #11

BEAT #11

马丁抓住卡琳的肩膀，把自己埋在她的颈窝里，用泪流满面的脸蹭着她的皮肤。

Martin takes Karin by the shoulders and buries himself in the crook of her neck, rubbing his tearful face against her skin.

马丁

MARTIN

卡琳，亲爱的，亲爱的，

Karin, dearest, dearest,

亲爱的。

dearest.

马丁的动作：爱抚她。

Martin’s action: CARESSING HER.

卡琳感到很厌恶。她把他的手掰开，猛地抽了回去。

Karin is repulsed. She pries his hand off and yanks away.

卡琳的反应：与他抗争。

Karin’s reaction: FIGHTING HIM OFF.

面对她的疯狂，马丁无能为力，他本能地试图引诱她摆脱狂躁，但他的爱抚却失败了。

Helpless in the face of her madness, Martin instinctively tries to seduce her out of her mania, but his caresses fail miserably.

节奏 #12

BEAT #12

卡琳双手合十在胸前祈祷。

Karin folds her hands in front of her in prayer.

卡琳的行动：用尽全力祈祷。

Karin’s action: PRAYING WITH ALL HER POWER.

突然，一声震耳欲聋的吼叫响彻整个房间。卡琳的目光顺着墙壁移向衣柜。

Suddenly an ear-splitting ROAR fills the room. Karin’s eyes shift along the wall to the closet.

“上帝”的反应：宣布“上帝”的到来。

“God’s” reaction: ANNOUNCING “GOD’S” ARRIVAL.

节奏 #13

BEAT #13

壁橱门似乎自动打开了。

The closet door swings open, seemingly of its own accord.

“上帝”的行动：向卡琳显现。

“God’s” action: APPEARING TO KARIN.

卡琳恭敬地站着，对着似乎从空衣柜里冒出来的某个东西微笑。

Karin stands respectfully and smiles at something that seems to be emerging from the empty closet.

卡琳的反应：接受她的“上帝”。

Karin’s reaction: RECEIVING HER “GOD.”

窗外，一架救护直升机从天而降。

Outside the window, an ambulance helicopter descends from the sky.

在背景中，大卫专注地注视着这一场景。

In the background, David eyes the scene intently.

门是如何、为何会自动打开的？也许是直升机的震动，但这并不是一个令人满意的解释。纯属巧合，就在卡琳祈求奇迹发生时，门和直升机联手为她带来了奇迹。然而，令人惊讶的是，这一行动似乎并不做作。用荣格的话来说，伯格曼创造了一个同步性事件：围绕巨大情感中心，有意义的巧合融合在一起。通过让我们听到卡琳的声音，通过向我们展示她对自然的敏锐感受，通过戏剧化地表现她对奇迹的迫切渴望，我们开始期待超自然现象。卡琳的宗教热情如此高涨，以至于它创造了一个同步事件，让我们瞥见了现实之外的东西。

How and why does the door open by itself? Vibrations from the helicopter perhaps, but that’s not a satisfactory explanation. By pure coincidence, just as Karin prays for a miracle, door and helicopter join forces to give it to her. Yet, amazingly, the action doesn’t seem contrived. For Bergman’s created, in Jungian terms, an event of Synchronicity: the fusion of meaningful coincidence around a center of tremendous emotion. By allowing us to hear Karin’s voices, by showing us her acute sensitivity to nature, and by dramatizing her burning need for a miracle, we come to expect the supernatural. Karin’s religious passion is at such a fever pitch that it creates a synchronous event that gives us a glimpse of something beyond the real.

节奏 #14

BEAT #14

卡琳盯着壁橱，看到一些令人吃惊的东西后，她的脸僵住了。

Karin stares into the closet; her face freezes as she sees something startling.

卡琳的“上帝”的行为：攻击她。

Karin’s “God’s” action: ATTACKING HER.

突然，她惊恐地尖叫起来，就像被追赶一样，跑过房间，把自己塞进一个角落，举起腿和胳膊来保护自己。

Suddenly, she screams in terror, and as if being pursued, runs across the room, jamming herself into a corner, bringing her legs and arms up to protect herself.

卡琳的反应：与她的“上帝”抗争。

Karin’s reaction: FIGHTING OFF HER “GOD.”

节奏 #15

BEAT #15

马丁抓住了她。

Martin grabs her.

马丁的行动：约束她。

Martin’s action: RESTRAINING HER.

她推开他，逃到另一个角落。

She pushes him off and flees to another corner.

卡琳的反应：逃离马丁。

Karin’s reaction: ESCAPING MARTIN.

节奏 #16

BEAT #16

仿佛有什么东西爬上了她的身体，她用拳头抵住自己的腹股沟，然后疯狂地向看不见的袭击者挥舞手臂。

As if something were crawling up her body, she presses her fists into her groin, then flails wildly at an unseen assailant.

“上帝”的行为：试图强奸卡琳。

“God’s” action: TRYING TO RAPE KARIN.

卡琳的反应：与“上帝”的强奸作斗争。

Karin’s reaction: BATTLING “GOD’S” RAPE.

现在大卫加入马丁并试图抱住她。

Now David joins Martin and tries to hold her.

大卫的反应：帮忙抱住她。

David’s reaction: HELPING HOLD HER.

节奏 #17

BEAT #17

但她挣脱了，冲出门，跑进了

But she breaks away and rushes out of the door into the

楼上大厅——同样

INT. UPSTAIRS HALL—SAME

然后下楼梯。

and down the stairs.

卡琳的行动：逃跑。

Karin’s action: FLEEING.

楼梯上——同样

INT. ON THE STAIRS—SAME

突然，Minus 出现在底部。

Suddenly, Minus appears at the bottom.

米纳斯挡住了她的去路。卡琳停下脚步，盯着她的哥哥。

Minus blocks her way. Karin stops and stares at her brother.

Minus 的反应：困住她。

Minus’s reaction: TRAPPING HER.

节奏 #18

BEAT #18

大卫抓住她，把她拉到楼梯上。马丁拿着注射器赶来。卡琳像被困的动物一样奋力挣扎。

David grabs her and pulls her down onto the stairs. Martin arrives with a syringe. Karin fights like a trapped animal.

马丁和大卫的行动：给她注射镇静剂。

Martin’s and David’s action: SEDATING HER.

马丁

MARTIN

抱住她的腿。

Hold her legs.

当马丁努力给她注射时，她在他们怀里挣扎。

She thrashes in their arms as Martin struggles to give her an injection.

卡琳的反应：疯狂抵抗针头。

Karin’s reaction: WILDLY RESISTING THE NEEDLE.

节奏 #19

BEAT #19

她靠在父亲身上，目不转睛地看着哥哥焦虑的脸。

She leans against her father and looks steadily into the anxious face of her brother.

镇静剂的作用：使她平静下来。

The sedative’s action: CALMING HER.

凯伦的反应：向毒品屈服。

Karen’s reaction: SURRENDERING TO THE DRUG.

大卫和马丁的反应：让自己冷静下来。

David’s and Martin’s reaction: CALMING THEMSELVES.

Minus 的反应：尝试去理解。

Minus’s reaction: TRYING TO UNDERSTAND.

节奏 #20

BEAT #20

卡琳

KARIN

我突然害怕起来。

I was suddenly afraid.

卡琳的行动：警告减号。

Karin’s action: WARNING MINUS.

三个人的反应都是：静静地聆听。

All three men’s reaction: LISTENING QUIETLY.

卡琳

KARIN

（慢慢解释

(slowly explaining

给她哥哥

to her brother)

门开了。但神

The door opened. But the god

出来的是一只蜘蛛。

that came out was a spider.

他向我走来，我

He came towards me and I

看到他的脸。那是一种可怕的，

saw his face. It was a horrible,

面无表情。他爬了

stony face. He crawled

并试图强迫自己

up me and tried to force himself

进入我。但我捍卫

into me. But I defended

我自己。整个过程中我看到

myself. The whole time I saw

他的眼睛。他的眼睛平静而

his eyes. They were calm and

冷。因为他不能强迫他的

cold. As he couldn’t force his

他爬上来

way into me, he climbed up

到我的胸前，到我的脸上

onto my breast, onto my face

然后爬上了墙。

and went up the wall.

（长时间观察

(a long look into

减去眼睛）

Minus’s eyes)

我看见了上帝。

I have seen God.

尽管蜘蛛神强奸是她潜意识中产生的幻觉，但回到现实后，她对幻觉却报以讽刺的敬意。她向三名男子讲述了她可怕的发现，但主要是向米纳斯讲述了一个警示故事，警告她的兄弟祈祷不会得到回应。

Although the spider-god rape is a delusion thrown up from her subconscious, once back in reality she treats the hallucination with ironic respect. She offers her terrifying discovery to all three men, but primarily to Minus as a cautionary tale, warning her brother that prayers will not be answered.

第四步：记录收盘价并与开盘价进行比较

Step Four: Note Closing Value and Compare with Opening Value

卡琳与蜘蛛神的相遇让场景从希望变成了绝望。她祈求顿悟，并将这个“奇迹”交给了父亲，因为她知道，由于父亲缺乏真实情感，他渴望用他人的生活经历来填满他的小说。她向丈夫表达了信心，但他的反应仅限于性行为和医学姿态。她的“奇迹”随后爆发成一场噩梦，她对上帝的信任也破灭了。

Karin’s encounter with the spider-god turns the scene from hope to hopelessness. She prays for an epiphany and gives this “miracle” to her father, knowing that because of his own incapacity for authentic emotion, he’s hungry for the life experiences of others to fill the pages of his novels. She offers faith to her husband, but his responses are limited to sexual gestures and medical posturing. Her “miracle” then explodes into a nightmare and her trust in God is shattered.

在最后一幕中，卡琳将自己那怪诞的幻象作为警告告诉了哥哥，但与这一幕戏剧性地展现的压倒性绝望相比，这最后的举动显得微不足道。我们感到，小说家和医生在整部电影中所做的那样，将爱情理智化，在我们本性中难以理解的力量面前显得十分软弱。

In the final beat, Karin gives her grotesque vision to her brother as a warning, but this last gesture is slight, compared to the scene’s dramatization of overwhelming despair. We’re left with the feeling that intellectualizing love, as the novelist and doctor do throughout the film, is pitifully weak in the face of the incomprehensible forces that inhabit our natures.

第五步：调查节拍并找到转折点

Step Five: Survey the Beats and Locate the Turning Point

  1. 策划她的逃跑/隐瞒他的罪行

  2. Planning Her Escape/Concealing His Guilt

  3. 逃离她的“上帝”/帮助她

  4. Escaping Her “God”/Helping Her

  5. 寻找卡琳/帮助他寻找

  6. Searching for Karin/Helping Him Search

  7. 祈祷/冲向她并准备重新俘获她

  8. Praying/Rushing to Her and Preparing to Recapture Her

  9. 为她的顿悟做准备/观察她的疯狂并与他的情绪作斗争。

  10. Preparing for Her Epiphany/Observing Her Madness and Fighting His Emotions.

  11. 阻止她的幻觉/保护她的梦想

  12. Stopping Her Hallucination/Protecting Her Dream

  13. 拉开她/坚持她的立场

  14. Pulling Her Away/Standing Her Ground

  15. 否认上帝的存在/捍卫她的信仰

  16. Denying the Existence of God/Defending Her Faith

  17. 命令马丁离开/撤退

  18. Ordering Martin Away/Retreating

  19. 吸引马丁参与她的仪式/向她投降

  20. Drawing Martin to Her Ritual/Surrendering to Her

  21. 爱抚她/击退他

  22. Caressing Her/Fighting Him Off

  23. 全力祈祷/宣告“神”的到来

  24. Praying with All Her Power/Announcing “God’s” Arrival

  25. 向卡琳显现/接受她的“神”

  26. Appearing to Karin/Receiving Her “God”

  27. 攻击卡琳/击退她的“神”

  28. Attacking Karin/Fighting Off Her “God”

  29. 束缚她/逃离马丁

  30. Restraining Her/Escaping Martin

  31. 试图强奸卡琳/与“上帝”对抗

  32. Trying to Rape Karin/Battling “God”

  33. 逃跑/诱捕她

  34. Fleeing/Trapping Her

  35. 给她注射镇静剂/拒绝针头

  36. Sedating Her/Resisting the Needle

  37. 让她平静下来/让自己平静下来并尝试理解

  38. Calming Her/Calming Themselves and Trying to Understand

  39. 警告减/静静聆听

  40. Warning Minus/Listening Quietly

节拍开始时很轻松，几乎有点滑稽，然后迅速发展。每次动作/反应都超过前一次的交流，要求所有角色做出更多努力，尤其是要求卡琳有越来越多的意志力来克服她可怕的幻觉。当卡琳对上帝的期望导致幻觉蜘蛛的性攻击时，节拍 #13 和 #14 之间出现了差距。与《卡萨布兰卡》中扭转场景的启示不同，这一高潮的转折点以行动为中心——在这种情况下，是主角潜意识采取的令人震惊的行动。

Beats begin lightly, almost comically, then progress rapidly. Each action/reaction tops the previous exchange, demanding more from all the characters, and, in particular, demanding more and more willpower from Karin to survive her horrifying visions. The gap opens between Beats #13 and #14 when Karin’s expectation of God results in a sexual attack by a hallucinatory spider. Unlike the revelation that turns the scene from CASABLANCA, the Turning Point of this Climax pivots on action—in this case, an action of appalling power taken by the protagonist’s subconscious mind.

这些精彩的场景被用来展示分析技巧。尽管它们在冲突程度和行动质量上有所不同，但它们的基本形式是相同的。它们中近乎完美的东西在其他价值较低的场景中可能会有缺陷。写得不好的场景可能缺乏冲突，因为欲望没有对立，可能反其道而行，因为它们重复或循环，可能不平衡，因为它们的转折点来得太早或太晚，或者缺乏可信度，因为对话和动作“一针见血”。但是，对有问题的场景进行分析，根据场景目标测试节拍，改变行为以适应欲望或欲望适应行为，将导致重写，使场景栩栩如生。

These superb scenes have been used to demonstrate the technique of analysis. Although they differ in levels of conflict and quality of actions, they share the same essential form. What is virtually perfect in them would be flawed in others of lesser worth. Ill-written scenes may lack conflict because desires are not opposed, may be antiprogressive because they’re repetitious or circular, lopsided because their Turning Points come too early or too late, or lacking credibility because dialogue and action are “on the nose.” But an analysis of a problematic scene that tests beats against scene objectives, altering behavior to fit desire or desire to fit behavior, will lead to a rewrite that brings the scene to life.

12

组成

12

COMPOSITION

构图意味着对场景进行排序和链接。就像作曲家选择音符和和弦一样，我们通过选择要包含的内容、要排除的内容、在什么之前和之后放置什么来塑造进程。这项任务可能令人痛苦，因为当我们了解我们的主题时，每个故事的可能性似乎都活灵活现，并朝着不同的方向发展。灾难性的诱惑是以某种方式将它们全部包括进来。幸运的是，为了指导我们的努力，艺术已经发展出构图的准则：统一性和多样性、步调、节奏和节拍、社会和个人进步、象征和讽刺的提升，以及过渡原则。

Composition means the ordering and linking of scenes. Like a composer choosing notes and chords, we shape progressions by selecting what to include, to exclude, to put before and after what. The task can be harrowing, for as we come to know our subject, every story possibility seems alive and squirming in a different direction. The disastrous temptation is to somehow include them all. Fortunately, to guide our efforts the art has evolved canons of composition: Unity and Variety, Pacing, Rhythm and Tempo, Social and Personal Progression, Symbolic and Ironic Ascension, and the Principle of Transition.

统一与多样性

UNITY AND VARIETY

故事，即使表达的是混乱，也必须统一。这句话，从任何情节中得出，都应该合乎逻辑：“由于激励事件，高潮必须发生。 ”《大白鲨》：“因为鲨鱼杀死了一名游泳者，警长必须杀死鲨鱼。”《克莱默对克莱默》：“因为克莱默的妻子离开了他和她的孩子，所以只有丈夫和妻子才能最终解决监护权问题。”我们应该感觉到激励事件和故事高潮之间的因果关系。激励事件是故事最深刻的原因，因此，最终效果，即故事高潮，应该是不可避免的。将它们结合在一起的粘合剂是主干，即主角恢复生活平衡的强烈愿望。

A story, even when expressing chaos, must be unified. This sentence, drawn from any plot, should be logical: “Because of the Inciting Incident, the Climax had to happen.” JAWS: “Because the shark killed a swimmer, the sheriff had to destroy the shark.” KRAMER VS. KRAMER: “Because Kramer’s wife left him and her child, only husband and wife could finally settle custody.” We should sense a causal lock between Inciting Incident and Story Climax. The Inciting Incident is the story’s most profound cause, and, therefore, the final effect, the Story Climax, should seem inevitable. The cement that binds them is the Spine, the protagonist’s deep desire to restore the balance of life.

统一性至关重要，但还不够。在统一性中，我们必须引入尽可能多的多样性。例如，《卡萨布兰卡》它不仅是有史以来最受欢迎的电影之一，也是最多样化的电影之一。这是一部精彩的爱情故事，但电影的一半以上是政治剧。其出色的动作场面与都市喜剧形成鲜明对比。它是一部音乐剧。十几首曲调贯穿始终，策略性地放置在一起，评论或设置事件、意义和情感。

Unity is critical, but not sufficient. Within this unity, we must induce as much variety as possible. CASABLANCA, for example, is not only one of the most loved films of all time, it’s also one of the most various. It’s a brilliant Love Story, but more than half the film is Political Drama. Its excellent action sequences are counter-pointed by urbane comedy. And it’s the next thing to a Musical. Over a dozen tunes, strategically placed throughout, comment on or set up event, meaning, emotion.

我们大多数人都无法做到如此多的变化，我们的故事也不需要如此，但我们不想一遍又一遍地重复同一个调子，这样每个场景听起来都一样。相反，我们在喜剧中寻找悲剧，在个人中寻找政治，在政治中寻找个人，在平凡中寻找非凡，在崇高中寻找琐碎。改变重复节奏的关键是研究。肤浅的知识会导致平淡、单调的讲述。有了作者的知识，我们可以准备一场快乐的盛宴。或者至少，增加幽默。

Most of us are not capable of this much variety, nor would our stories warrant it, but we don’t want to hit the same note over and over, so that every scene sounds like every other. Instead, we seek the tragic in the comic, the political in the personal, the personal driving the political, the extraordinary behind the usual, the trivial in the exalted. The key to varying a repetitious cadence is research. Superficial knowledge leads to a bland, monotonous telling. With authorial knowledge we can prepare a feast of pleasures. Or at the very least, add humor.

起搏

PACING

如果我们慢慢地加大压力，一幕一幕地增加一点紧张感，观众在故事结束前就会感到疲惫。观众会变得软弱无力，没有精力投入到故事的高潮中。因为故事是生活的隐喻，我们希望故事能让人感受到生活，有生活的节奏。这种节奏在两种相互矛盾的愿望之间跳动：一方面，我们渴望宁静、和谐、和平和放松，但日复一日地过得太多，我们就会变得无聊，需要治疗。因此，我们也渴望挑战、紧张、危险，甚至恐惧。但日复一日地过得太多，我们又会回到橡胶房。所以生活的节奏在这两个极端之间摇摆不定。

If we slowly turn the screw, increasing tension a little more, a little more, a little more, scene by scene by scene by scene, we wear the audience out long before the ending. It goes limp and has no energy to invest in the Story Climax. Because a story is a metaphor for life, we expect it to feel like life, to have the rhythm of life. This rhythm beats between two contradictory desires: On one hand, we desire serenity, harmony, peace, and relaxation, but too much of this day after day and we become bored to the point of ennui and need therapy. As a result, we also desire challenge, tension, danger, even fear. But too much of this day after day and again we end up in the rubber room. So the rhythm of life swings between these poles.

例如，一个典型日子的节奏是：你精力充沛地醒来，在清晨的镜子里凝视着自己，然后说：“今天我要做点什么。不，我是认真的。今天我一定要做点什么。”你开始“做点什么”，穿过错过的约会、未回的电话、毫无意义的差事和无休止的麻烦，直到你和朋友们共进午餐，聊天、喝葡萄酒，重新安置你的保持理智，放松身心，集中精力，这样你就可以出去与下午的恶魔作斗争，希望完成早上没有完成的所有事情——更多的未接电话，更多无用的任务，以及永远不够的时间。

The rhythm of a typical day, for example: You wake up full of energy, meet your gaze in the morning mirror, and say: “Today I’m going to get something done. No, I mean it for a change. Today I’m definitely getting something done.” Off you go to “get something done” through a minefield of missed appointments, unreturned calls, pointless errands, and unrelenting hassle until you take a welcome midday lunch with friends to chat, sip wine, relocate your sanity, relax and gather your energies so you can go off to do battle with the demons of the afternoon, hoping to get done all the things you didn’t get done in the morning—more missed calls, more useless tasks, and never, never enough time.

最后，你上了回家的高速公路，路上挤满了车，每辆车里只有一个人。你会拼车吗？不。工作了一天，你最不想做的就是和另外三个同事一起上车。你钻进车里，打开收音机，根据音乐进入正确的车道。如果是古典音乐，你就靠右；如果是流行音乐，你就靠中间；如果是摇滚乐，你就靠左。我们抱怨交通拥堵，但从不采取任何行动，因为事实上，我们暗自享受高峰时段；开车的时间是我们大多数人唯一独处的时间。你放松下来，抓紧需要抓紧的东西，在音乐中发出一声原始的尖叫。

Finally you hit the highway home, a road packed with cars with only one person in each. Do you car pool? No. After a hard day on the job, the last thing you want is to jump into a car with three other jerks from work. You escape into your car, snap on the radio, and get in the proper lane according to the music. If classical, you hug the right; if pop, down the middle of the road; if rock, head left. We moan about traffic but never do anything about it because, in truth, we secretly enjoy rush hour; drive-time is the only time most of us are ever alone. You relax, scratch what needs scratching, and add a primal scream to the music.

回家快速冲个澡，然后晚上出去寻找乐趣。什么乐趣？游乐园的游乐设施让你惊恐万分，电影让你遭受你一生中从未想要的情绪，单身酒吧和被拒绝的羞辱。疲惫不堪的你倒在床上，第二天黎明又开始这种节奏。

Home for a quick shower, then off into the night looking for fun. What’s fun? Amusement park rides that scare the life out of you, a film that makes you suffer emotions you’d never want in life, a singles bar and the humiliation of rejection. Weary, you fall into the rack and next dawn start this rhythm all over again.

这种紧张与放松的交替是生活的脉搏，是日子甚至岁月的节奏。在某些电影中，这种交替是明显的，在另一些电影中，这种交替是微妙的。《温柔的怜悯》将戏剧压力慢慢地提高，然后慢慢地降低，每个循环都慢慢地将整体紧张感提升到高潮；《亡命天涯》将紧张感塑造到尖锐的顶峰，然后短暂地减弱，然后加速到更高的高度。每部电影都以其自然的口音讲述故事，但绝不会以平淡、重复、被动的无事件或无情、沉重的动作来讲述。无论是大情节、小情节还是反情节，所有精彩的故事都随着生活的节奏而流动。

This alternation between tension and relaxation is the pulse of living, the rhythm of days, even years. In some films it’s salient, in others subtle. TENDER MERCIES eases dramatic pressure gently up, then gently down, each cycle slowly increasing the overall tension to Climax; THE FUGITIVE sculpts tension to sharp peaks, then ebbs briefly before accelerating higher still. Each film speaks in its natural accent, but never in flat, repetitious, passive non-events, or in unrelenting, bludgeoning action. Whether Archplot, Miniplot, or Antiplot, all fine stories flux with the rhythm of life.

我们使用幕结构从紧张的基础开始，然后逐个场景上升到第一幕的高潮。进入第二幕时，我们创作了一些场景来减少这种紧张感，切换到喜剧、浪漫，一种降低第一幕强度的对立情绪，以便观众可以喘口气，获得更多的能量。我们指导观众像长跑运动员一样移动，而不是以恒定的速度奔跑，而是加速、减速，然后再次加速，创造循环，让他达到极限。放慢节奏后，我们开始构建下一幕的进程，直到我们在强度和意义方面超越之前的高潮。我们一幕一幕地收紧和释放紧张感，直到最后的高潮让观众感到空虚，让他们情绪疲惫但又心满意足。然后是一个简短的结局场景，让他们回家前恢复体力。

We use our act structure to start at a base of tension, then rise scene by sequence to the Climax of Act One. As we enter Act Two, we compose scenes that reduce this tension, switching to comedy, romance, a counterpointing mood that lowers the Act One intensity so that the audience can catch its breath and reach for more energy. We coach the audience to move like a long-distance runner who, rather than loping at a constant pace, speeds, slows, then speeds again, creating cycles that allow him to reach the limit of his reserves. After retarding pace, we build the progressions of the following act until we top the previous Climax in intensity and meaning. Act by act, we tighten and release tension until the final Climax empties out the audience, leaving it emotionally exhausted but fulfilled. Then a brief Resolution scene to recuperate before going home.

这就像性爱一样。卧室艺术大师们会控制做爱的节奏。他们先让彼此进入一种令人愉悦的紧张状态，但还未达到高潮——我们在这两种情况下都使用同一个词——然后讲个笑话，变换姿势，再让彼此进入一种更紧张的状态，但还未达到高潮；然后吃个三明治，看电视，积蓄能量，然后达到越来越强烈的程度，做爱时紧张感不断增加，直到他们同时达到高潮，大地震动，他们看到色彩。优雅的讲故事者与我们做爱。他知道我们能够得到极大的释放……如果他能控制我们的节奏。

It’s just like sex. Masters of the bedroom arts pace their love-making. They begin by taking each other to a state of delicious tension short of—and we use the same word in both cases—climax, then tell a joke and shift positions before building each other to an even higher tension short of climax; then have a sandwich, watch TV, and gather energy to then reach greater and greater intensity, making love in cycles of rising tension until they finally climax simultaneously and the earth moves and they see colors. The gracious storyteller makes love to us. He knows we’re capable of a tremendous release… if he paces us to it.

节奏与节拍

RHYTHM AND TEMPO

节奏由场景的长度决定。我们在同一个时间和地点待多久？一部典型的两小时电影会演 40 到 60 个场景。这意味着，平均而言，一个场景持续两分半钟。但不是每个场景。相反，每一个一分钟的场景都会有一个四分钟的场景。每三十秒的场景都会有一个六分钟的场景。在格式正确的剧本中，一页等于一分钟的放映时间。因此，如果你在翻看剧本时发现一个两页的场景，后面跟着一个八页的场景、七页的场景、三页的场景、四页的场景、六页的场景、五页的场景、一页的场景、九页的场景——换句话说，如果剧本中场景的平均长度是五页，那么你的故事节奏就会像服用安定的邮政工人一样。

Rhythm is set by the length of scenes. How long are we in the same time and place? A typical two-hour feature plays forty to sixty scenes. This means, on average, a scene lasts two and a half minutes. But not every scene. Rather, for every one-minute scene there’s a four-minute scene. For every thirty-second scene, a six-minute scene. In a properly formatted screenplay a page equals a minute of screen time. Therefore, if as you turn through your script, you discover a two-page scene followed by an eight-page scene, a seven-page scene, three-page scene, four-page, six-page, five-page, one-page, nine-page—in other words, if the average length of scene in your script is five pages, your story will have the pace of a postal worker on Valium.

大多数导演的摄像机在两三分钟内就将一个场景中所有具有视觉表现力的东西都拍摄下来。如果一个场景持续更长时间，镜头就会变得多余。剪辑师会不断重复同样的定场镜头、同样的双人镜头、特写镜头。当镜头重复时，表现力就会消失；电影在视觉上变得乏味，观众会失去兴趣，视线会从屏幕上移开。如果这种情况发生得太多，你就会永远失去观众。平均场景长度为两到三分钟的时长是对电影本质以及观众对于连续富有表现力的时刻的渴望的反应。

Most directors’ cameras drink up whatever is visually expressive in one location within two or three minutes. If a scene goes on longer, shots become redundant. The editor keeps coming back to the same establishing shot, same two-shot, close-up. When shots repeat, expressivity drains away; the film becomes visually dull and the eye loses interest and wanders from the screen. Do this enough and you’ll lose the audience for good. The average scene length of two to three minutes is a reaction to the nature of cinema and the audience’s hunger for a stream of expressive moments.

当我们研究这一原则的众多例外时，它们只会证明这一点。《十二怒汉》在陪审团房间里拍摄了两天。本质上，它由两个五十分钟的场景组成，这些场景都发生在同一个地点，中间有一个短暂的休息时间，可以睡一晚。但因为它是根据一部戏剧改编的，导演西德尼·吕美特可以利用它的法国场景。

When we study the many exceptions to this principle, they only prove the point. TWELVE ANGRY MEN takes place over two days in a jury room. In essence, it consists of two fifty-minute scenes in one location, with a brief break for a night’s sleep. But because it’s based on a play, director Sidney Lumet could take advantage of its French Scenes.

在新古典主义时期（1750-1850 年），法国戏剧严格遵循“统一性”原则：一套将戏剧表演限制在一个基本动作或情节的惯例，该情节发生在一个地点，在演出的时间内。但法国人意识到，在这种时间和空间的统一性中，主要角色的出场或退场会彻底改变关系的动态，并实际上创造一个新的场景。例如，在花园场景中，年轻的恋人一起表演一场戏，然后她的母亲发现了他们。她的出场改变了人物关系，从而产生了一个新的场景。这三人有一个场景，然后年轻人退场。他的退场重新安排了母女之间的关系，以至于面具落下，新的场景开始了。

In the Neoclassical period (1750–1850) the French theatre strictly obeyed the Unities: A set of conventions that restricted a play’s performance to one basic action or plot, taking place in one location within the time it takes to perform. But the French realized that within this unity of time and space the entrance or exit of principal characters radically changes the dynamics of relationships and in effect creates a new scene. For example, in a garden setting young lovers play a scene together, then her mother discovers them. Her entrance so alters character relationships that it effects a new scene. This trio has a scene, then the young man exits. His exit so rearranges the relationship between mother and daughter that masks fall and a new scene begins.

吕美特了解法国场景的原理，于是将陪审团的房间分成了布景中的布景——饮水机、衣帽间、窗户、桌子的一端与另一端。在这些子场景中，他上演了法国场景：首先是陪审团成员 1 号和 2 号，然后 2 号退场，5 号和 7 号进场，切换到 6 号，切换到所有 12 人，切换到角落中的 5 人，等等。《十二怒汉》中的 80 多个法国场景构成了激动人心的节奏。

Understanding the principle of French scenes, Lumet broke the jury room into sets within the set—the drinking fountain, cloakroom, window, one end of the table versus the other. Within these sublocations, he staged French Scenes: First jury members #1 and #2, then #2 exits while #5 and #7 enter, CUT TO #6 alone, CUT TO all twelve, CUT TO five of them off in a corner, and so on. The over eighty French Scenes in TWELVE ANGRY MEN build an exciting rhythm.

《我与安德烈的晚餐》更加紧凑：一部两小时的电影，讲述两个角色的两小时晚餐，因此没有法国场景。然而，这部电影节奏感十足，因为它的节奏就像文学作品一样，通过用文字描绘听众的想象力来创造场景：波兰森林中的冒险，安德烈的朋友在一个奇怪的仪式中将他活埋，他在办公室遇到的同步现象。这些博学的叙述将教育情节包裹在教育情节中。当安德烈（安德烈·格雷戈里饰）讲述他不切实际的冒险经历时，精神上的发展，他如此不赞同朋友的人生观，以至于沃利（华莱士·肖恩饰）离开餐馆时已经变成了一个全新的人。

MY DINNER WITH ANDRE is even more contained: a two-hour film about a two-hour dinner with two characters and therefore no French Scenes. Yet the film pulses with rhythm because it’s paced with scenes created, as in literature, by painting word pictures on the imagination of the listener: the adventure in the Polish forest, Andre’s friends burying him alive in a bizarre ritual, the synchronistic phenomenon he encounters in his office. These erudite recountings wrap an Education Plot around an Education Plot. As Andre (Andre Gregory) relates his quixotic adventure toward spiritual development, he so cants his friend’s view of life that Wally (Wallace Shawn) leaves the restaurant a changed man.

节奏是指场景中对话、动作或两者结合的活动水平。例如，情侣枕边轻声交谈的节奏可能很慢；法庭上的争吵节奏很快。角色凝视窗外，面临人生重大决定的节奏可能很慢；暴乱的节奏很快。

Tempo is the level of activity within a scene via dialogue, action, or a combination. For example, lovers talking quietly from pillow to pillow may have low tempo; an argument in a courtroom, high tempo. A character staring out a window coming to a vital life decision may have low tempo; a riot, high tempo.

在一个讲述得好的故事中，场景和序列的进展会加快节奏。当我们走向高潮时，我们会利用节奏和节拍逐渐缩短场景，而场景中的活动会变得越来越轻快。就像音乐和舞蹈一样，故事是动态的。我们希望利用电影的感官力量将观众推向高潮，因为重大逆转的场景实际上通常很长、很慢而且很紧张。“高潮”并不意味着短暂而爆炸性；它意味着深刻的变化。这样的场景不容忽视。所以我们打开它们，让它们呼吸；我们放慢节奏，让观众屏住呼吸，想知道接下来会发生什么。

In a well-told story, the progression of scenes and sequences accelerates pace. As we head toward act climaxes, we take advantage of rhythm and tempo to progressively shorten scenes while the activity in them becomes more and more brisk. Like music and dance, story is kinetic. We want to use cinema’s sensory power to hurl the audience toward act climaxes because scenes of major reversal are, in fact, generally long, slow, and tense. “Climactic” doesn’t mean short and explosive; it means profound change. Such scenes are not to be skimmed over. So we open them and let them breathe; we retard pace while the audience holds its breath, wondering what’s going to happen next.

再次重申收益递减定律：我们停顿得越多，停顿的效果就越差。如果高潮之前的场景又长又慢，我们想要保持紧张感的大场景就会变得平淡无奇。因为我们把观众的精力都花在了次要的缓慢场景上，所以重要事件就被无视了。相反，我们必须通过缩短节奏和螺旋式节奏来“赢得停顿” ，这样当高潮到来时，我们就可以踩刹车，延长播放时间，保持紧张感。

Again, the Law of Diminishing Returns applies: The more often we pause, the less effective a pause is. If the scenes before a major Climax are long and slow, the big scene in which we want the tension to hold falls flat. Because we’ve dragged the energies of the audience through sluggish scenes of minor importance, events of great moment are greeted with a shrug. Instead, we must “earn the pause” by telescoping rhythm while spiraling tempo, so that when the Climax arrives, we can put the brakes on, stretch the playing time, and the tension holds.

当然，这种设计的问题在于它是一种陈词滥调。DW 格里菲斯 (DW Griffith) 是它的大师。无声时代的电影制作人知道，如果通过缩短场景和加快节奏来刺激节奏，那么像再次追逐坏人这样微不足道的事情也会让人感觉很棒。但是，除非一开始就有一些重要的东西，否则技巧不会成为陈词滥调。因此，我们不能因为无知或傲慢而忽视这一原则。如果我们在重大逆转之前延长和放慢场景，我们就会削弱我们的高潮。

The problem with this design, of course, is that it’s a cliché. D. W. Griffith mastered it. Filmmakers of the Silent Era knew that something as trivial as another chase to collar the bad guys can feel tremendous if pace is excited by making scenes ever shorter and tempo ever hasty. But techniques don’t become clichés unless they have something important going for them in the first place. We, therefore, cannot, out of ignorance or arrogance, ignore the principle. If we lengthen and slow scenes prior to a major reversal, we cripple our Climax.

节奏始于剧本。不管是否是陈词滥调，我们都必须控制节奏和节拍。它不需要对称地增加活动并缩短场景长度，但必须塑造进程。因为如果我们不这样做，电影剪辑师就会这样做。如果他为了修剪我们草率的作品而删掉了我们最喜欢的一些片段，我们只能怪自己。我们是编剧，不是小说的难民。电影是一种独特的艺术形式。编剧必须掌握电影的美学，并创作出为后来的艺术家铺平道路的剧本。

Pace begins in the screenplay. Cliché or not, we must control rhythm and tempo. It needn’t be a symmetrical swelling of activity and shaving of scene lengths, but progressions must be shaped. For if we don’t, the film editor will. And if to trim our sloppy work he cuts some of our favorite moments, we have no one to blame but ourselves. We’re screenwriters, not refugees from the novel. Cinema is a unique art form. The screenwriter must master the aesthetics of motion pictures and create a screenplay that prepares the way for the artists who follow.

表达进步

EXPRESSING PROGRESSION

当故事真正进展时，它需要越来越强大的人类能力，需要越来越强大的意志力，在人物生活中产生越来越大的变化，并使他们面临越来越大的危险。我们该如何表达这一点？观众如何感受到这种进展？有四种主要技巧。

When a story genuinely progresses it calls upon greater and greater human capacity, demands greater and greater willpower, generates greater and greater change in characters’ lives, and places them at greater and greater jeopardy. How are we to express this? How will the audience sense the progressions? There are four primary techniques.

社会进步

SOCIAL PROGRESSION

扩大人物行为对社会的影响。

Widen the impact of character actions into society.

让你的故事以亲密的方式开始，只涉及几个主要人物。但随着故事的推进，让他们的行为向外延伸到他们周围的世界，触动和改变越来越多人的生活。不要一下子全部发生。相反，通过进展逐渐传播影响。

Let your story begin intimately, involving only a few principal characters. But as the telling moves forward, allow their actions to ramify outward into the world around them, touching and changing the lives of more and more people. Not all at once. Rather, spread the effect gradually through the progressions.

孤星：两名男子在德克萨斯州一个废弃的步枪射击场寻找用过的子弹，发现了几十年前失踪的警长的遗骸。现场的证据让现任警长怀疑他的父亲可能是谋杀案的凶手。随着他的调查，故事向外传播到社会和时间，追溯到腐败和不公正的模式，这种模式影响并改变了三代德克萨斯人、墨西哥人和非洲裔美国人的生活——几乎是里约县的每一位公民。

LONE STAR: Two men searching for spent shells on a deserted rifle range in Texas uncover the skeletal remains of a sheriff who vanished decades before. Evidence at the scene leads the current sheriff to suspect that his own father may have committed the murder. As he investigates, the story spreads outward into society and back through time, tracing a pattern of corruption and injustice that has touched and changed the lives of three generations of Texan-, Mexican- and African Americans—virtually every citizen in Rio County.

黑衣人：一位农民与一位逃亡外星人在寻找一颗稀有宝石时偶然相遇，而这场邂逅逐渐蔓延开来，危及到所有的创造物。

MEN IN BLACK: A chance encounter between a farmer and a fugitive alien searching for a rare gem slowly ramifies outward to jeopardize all of creation.

这种从个人问题开始，然后向外延伸到世界，从而建立强大发展的原则解释了为什么某些职业在主角中占比过高。这就是为什么我们倾向于讲述律师、医生、战士、政治家、科学家的故事——这些人因职业而在社会中占据重要地位，如果他们的私人生活出了问题，作家就可以将情节扩展到社会。

This principle of starting with intimate problems that ramify outward into the world to build powerful progressions explains why certain professions are overrepresented in the roles of protagonists. This is why we tend to tell stories about lawyers, doctors, warriors, politicians, scientists—people so positioned in society by profession that if something goes haywire in their private lives, the writer can expand the action into society.

想象一下这样一个故事的开头：一天早上，美国总统起床刮胡子，当他盯着镜子时，他产生了幻觉，看到了世界各地的假想敌。他没有告诉任何人，但很快他的妻子就意识到他疯了。他的亲密同事也一样。他们聚在一起，决定既然他只剩六个月的任期了，为什么现在要破坏一切？他们会为他掩饰。但我们知道他“手握按钮”，而一个处于这种位置的疯子可能会把我们这个麻烦不断的世界变成普遍的地狱。

Imagine a story that begins like this: The President of the United States gets up one morning to shave and as he stares in the mirror, he hallucinates about imaginary enemies around the globe. He tells no one, but soon his wife realizes he’s gone mad. His close associates too. They gather and decide that since he has only six months left in office, why spoil things now? They’ll cover up for him. But we know he has “his finger on the button” and a madman in this position could turn our troubled world into universal hell.

个人进步

PERSONAL PROGRESSION

将行动深深地融入人物的亲密关系和内心生活中。

Drive actions deeply into the intimate relationships and inner lives of the characters.

如果设定的逻辑不允许您进行广泛的探索，那么您必须进行深入探索。从需要平衡但似乎相对可解决的个人或内心冲突开始。然后，随着故事的进展，从情感、心理、身体、道德等方面深入挖掘故事，直至揭露隐藏在公众面具背后的黑暗秘密和不为人知的真相。

If the logic of your setting doesn’t allow you to go wide, then you must go deep. Start with a personal or inner conflict that demands balancing, yet seems relatively solvable. Then, as the work progresses, hammer the story downward—emotionally, psychologically, physically, morally—to the dark secrets, the unspoken truths that hide behind a public mask.

《普通人》的故事情节仅限于家人、朋友和医生。母子之间的紧张关系似乎可以通过沟通和爱来解决，但后来却演变成痛苦。当父亲逐渐意识到他必须在儿子的理智和家庭的团结之间做出选择时，故事将孩子逼到了自杀的边缘，母亲透露她对自己孩子的憎恨，以及丈夫失去深爱的妻子。

ORDINARY PEOPLE is confined to the family, a friend, and a doctor. From a tension between mother and son that seems solvable with communication and love, it descends to grievous pain. As the father slowly comes to realize he must choose between the sanity of his son and the unity of his family, the story drives the child to the brink of suicide, the mother to reveal her hatred of her own child, and the husband to lose a wife he deeply loves.

《唐人街》的设计巧妙地结合了两种手法，既有广度又有深度。一名私家侦探被雇来调查一名男子的通奸行为。然后，就像浮油一样，故事以不断扩大的圈子向外扩散，吞噬了市政厅、百万富翁阴谋家、圣费尔南多谷的农民，直到它感染了洛杉矶的所有公民。同时，它向内猛冲。吉蒂斯不断受到攻击：踢打腹股沟，打击头部，鼻子被打裂。穆尔雷被杀，父女之间的乱伦被揭露，直到主角的悲惨过去重演，引发了伊芙琳·穆尔雷的死亡，并将一个无辜的孩子扔到疯狂的父亲/祖父手中。

CHINATOWN is an elegant design that combines both techniques, reaching simultaneously wide and deep. A private eye is hired to investigate a man for adultery. Then, like an oil slick, the story moves outward in an ever-widening circle that engulfs city hall, millionaire conspirators, farmers of the San Fernando Valley, until it contaminates all the citizens of Los Angeles. At the same time it plunges inward. Gittes is under constant assault: kicks to the groin, blows to the head, his nose split open. Mulwray is killed, incest exposed between father and daughter until the protagonist’s tragic past repeats to trigger the death of Evelyn Mulwray and throw an innocent child into the hands of an insane father/grandfather.

象征性的升天

SYMBOLIC ASCENSION

构建故事意象的象征意义，从特殊到普遍、从具体到原型。

Build the symbolic charge of the story’s imagery from the particular to the universal, the specific to the archetypal.

一个讲述得好的好故事可以成就一部好电影。但是，一个讲述得好的好故事加上潜意识象征的力量，可以将故事提升到一个新的表现力水平，而最终的结果可能是一部伟大的电影。象征主义非常引人注目。就像我们梦中的图像一样，它侵入潜意识并深深触动我们——只要我们没有意识到它的存在。如果我们以一种粗暴的方式将图像标记为“象征性的”，它们的效果就会被破坏。但如果它们悄悄地、逐渐地、谦逊地融入到故事中，它们就会深深地打动我们。

A good story well told fosters a good film. But a good story well told with the added power of subliminal symbolism lifts the telling to the next level of expressivity, and the payoff may be a great film. Symbolism is very compelling. Like images in our dreams, it invades the unconscious mind and touches us deeply—as long as we’re unaware of its presence. If, in a heavy-handed way, we label images as “symbolic,” their effect is destroyed. But if they are slipped quietly, gradually, and unassumingly into the telling, they move us profoundly.

象征性进展的运作方式如下：从仅代表其本身的动作、地点和角色开始。但随着故事的进展，选择越来越有意义的图像，直到故事结束时，人物、场景和事件代表了普遍的思想。

Symbolic progression works in this way: start with actions, locations, and roles that represent only themselves. But as the story progresses, chose images that gather greater and greater meaning, until by the end of the telling characters, settings, and events stand for universal ideas.

《猎鹿人》介绍了宾夕法尼亚州喜欢打猎、喝啤酒和寻欢作乐的钢铁工人。他们就像普通人一样他们所居住的城镇。但随着事件的发展，布景、角色和动作变得越来越具有象征意义，从越南的老虎笼到西贡赌场中人们玩俄罗斯轮盘赌以赢钱的高度象征性场景，最终在山顶上发生危机。主角迈克尔（罗伯特·德尼罗饰）从工厂工人成长为战士，再到“猎人”，一个杀人的男人。

THE DEER HUNTER introduces steel workers in Pennsylvania who like to hunt, drink beer, and carouse. They’re as ordinary as the town they live in. But as events progress, sets, roles, and actions become more and more symbolically charged, building from the tiger cages in Vietnam to the highly symbolic scenes in a Saigon casino where men play Russian Roulette for money, culminating in a Crisis at the top of a mountain. The protagonist, Michael (Robert De Niro) progresses from factory worker to warrior to “The Hunter,” the man who kills.

影片的主旨是：当我们停止杀害其他生物时，我们便拯救了我们自己的人性。如果猎人流了足够多的血，迟早他会没有目标，于​​是将枪口对准自己。他要么像尼克（克里斯托弗·沃肯饰）一样自杀，要么更有可能是自杀，感觉不到任何感情，内心死寂。《危机》让身着猎人服装的迈克尔手持武器，登上山顶。在那里的悬崖上，猎物——一只雄伟的麋鹿从雾中走出来。一个典型的画面：猎人和猎物在山顶。为什么是在山顶？因为山顶是“伟大的事情发生”的地方。摩西不是在厨房里，而是在山顶上接受了《十诫》 。

The film’s Controlling Idea is: We save our own humanity when we stop killing other living beings. If the hunter spills enough blood, sooner or later he runs out of targets and turns the gun on himself. He either literally kills himself, as does Nick (Christopher Walken), or more likely, he kills himself in the sense that he stops feeling anything and falls dead inside. The Crisis sends Michael in his hunter’s garb, armed with a weapon, to a mountaintop. There, on a precipice, the prey, a magnificent elk, comes out of the mist. An archetypal image: hunter and prey at the top of a mountain. Why the top of a mountain? Because tops of mountains are places where “great things happen.” Moses is given the Ten Commandments, not in his kitchen, but at the top of a mountain.

《终结者》以不同的方向展开了象征性的发展，不是爬山，而是进入了迷宫。影片以普通人在普通场景中的形象为开场，讲述了洛杉矶快餐女服务员莎拉·康纳的故事。突然，终结者和瑞茜从 2029 年冲到了现在，在洛杉矶的街道上追赶莎拉，一个想杀死她，另一个想救她。

THE TERMINATOR takes symbolic progression in a different direction, not up the mountain but into the maze. Opening with step-down imagery of commonplace people in commonplace settings, it tells the story of Sarah Connor, a fast-food waitress in Los Angeles. Suddenly, the Terminator and Reese explode into the present from the year 2029, and pursue Sarah through the streets of L.A., one trying to kill her, the other to save her.

我们了解到，在未来，机器人会拥有自我意识，并试图消灭创造它们的人类。当人类残余在魅力非凡的约翰·康纳的领导下发动起义时，他们几乎成功了。他扭转了局势，对机器人发起了反抗，几乎将他们消灭殆尽。但机器人发明了一台时光机，并派遣一名刺客回到过去，在康纳出生前杀死了他的母亲，从而消灭了康纳，为机器人赢得了战争。康纳夺取了时光机，发现了计划，并派他的副官里斯回来杀死这个怪物，以免它杀死他的母亲。

We learn that in the future robots become self-aware and try to stamp out the human race that created them. They nearly succeed when the remnants of humanity are led in a revolt by the charismatic John Connor. He turns the tide against the robots and all but stamps them out, when the robots invent a time machine and send into the past an assassin to kill Connor’s mother before he’s born, thus eliminating Connor from existence and winning the war for the robots. Connor captures the time machine, discovers the plan, and sends back his lieutenant, Reese, to kill this monster before it kills his mother.

洛杉矶的街道密谋形成古老的迷宫原型。高速公路、小巷、死胡同和建筑走廊将人物扭曲和转变，直到他们一路深入迷宫错综复杂的中心。在那里，莎拉就像米诺斯迷宫中心的忒修斯与半人半牛的牛头怪战斗一样，面对半人半机器人的终结者。如果她战胜了恶魔，她就会像圣母玛利亚一样，生下人类的救世主约翰·康纳 (JC)，并抚养他带领人类在即将到来的大屠杀中得到解脱。莎拉从女服务员成长为女神，这部电影的象征性发展使它超越了几乎所有同类电影。

The streets of Los Angeles conspire into the ancient archetype of the labyrinth. Freeways, alleyways, cul-de-sacs, and corridors of buildings twist and turn the characters until they work their way down to its tangled heart. There Sarah, like Theseus at the center of the Minoan maze battling the half-man/half-bull Minotaur, confronts the half-man/half-robot Terminator. If she vanquishes the demon, she will, like the Virgin Mary, give birth to the savior of humanity, John Connor (JC), and raise him to lead humanity to deliverance in the coming holocaust. Sarah progresses from waitress to goddess, and the film’s symbolic progression lifts it above almost all others in its genre.

讽刺的崛起

IRONIC ASCENSION

以讽刺的方式推进进程。

Turn progression on irony.

用讽刺来推进故事的发展。讽刺是故事乐趣最微妙的表现，是那种“啊，生活就是这样”的美妙感觉。它以二元性看待生活；它玩弄我们矛盾的存在，意识到表象与事实之间的无底深渊。言语讽刺存在于词语与其含义之间的差异中——笑话的主要来源。但在故事中，讽刺在行动和结果之间发挥作用——故事能量的主要来源，在表象和现实之间发挥作用——真理和情感的主要来源。

Turn progression on irony. Irony is the subtlest manifestation of story pleasure, that delicious sense of “Ah, life is just like that.” It sees life in duality; it plays with our paradoxical existence, aware of the bottomless chasm between what seems and what is. Verbal irony is found in the discrepancy between words and their meanings—a primary source of jokes. But in story, irony plays between actions and results—the primary source of story energy, between appearance and reality—the primary source of truth and emotion.

讽刺感是一种宝贵的财富，是一把直击真相的利刃，但它不能直接使用。让一个角色在故事中漫不经心地说“多么讽刺！”对我们来说毫无益处。就像象征主义一样，指出讽刺会摧毁它。讽刺必须冷静、随意地释放，看似无辜地不知道它所产生的效果，并相信观众会理解。因为讽刺本质上是狡猾的，它无法被硬性定义，最好用例子来解释。下面是六个讽刺故事模式，每个模式都有一个示例。

An ironic sensibility is a precious asset, a razor to cut to the truth, but it can’t be used directly. It does us no good to have a character wander the story saying, “How ironic!” Like symbolism, to point at irony destroys it. Irony must be coolly, casually released with a seemingly innocent unawareness of the effect it’s creating and a faith that the audience will get it. Because irony is by nature slippery, it defies a hard and fast definition, and is best explained by example. Below are six ironic story patterns with an example for each.

1.他终于得到了他一直想要的东西……但是已经太晚了。

1. He gets at last what he’s always wanted… but too late to have it.

奥赛罗：摩尔人终于得到了他一直想要的东西，他的妻子对他忠诚，从未背叛他，与另一个男人在一起……但当他发现这一点时，已经太晚了，因为他刚刚杀了她。

OTHELLO: The Moor finally gets what he always wanted, a wife who is true to him and who never betrayed him with another man… but when he finds that out, it’s too late, because he just killed her.

2.他离自己的目标越来越远……最后才发现，事实上，他已经被引导到了目标附近。

2. He’s pushed further and further from his goal… only to discover that in fact he’s been led right to it.

冷酷无情：贪婪的商人萨姆（丹尼·德维托饰）从桑迪（海伦·斯莱特饰）那里窃取了一个创意，赚了一大笔钱，却没有付给她一分钱版税。桑迪的丈夫肯（祖奇·莱茵霍尔德饰）决定绑架萨姆的妻子芭芭拉（贝特·米德勒饰），并向她索要他认为妻子欠他的两百万美元。但当肯绑架芭芭拉时，他并不知道萨姆正要回家谋杀他泼辣又肥胖的妻子。肯打电话给萨姆索要数百万美元，但得意洋洋的萨姆拒绝了他。肯一直降价，直到一万美元，萨姆说：“哦，你为什么不杀了她，一了百了呢。”

RUTHLESS PEOPLE: The greedy businessman, Sam (Danny Devito), steals an idea from Sandy (Helen Slater) and makes a fortune without paying her a cent of royalties. Sandy’s husband, Ken (Judge Reinhold), decides to kidnap Sam’s wife, Barbara (Bette Midler), and ransom her for the two million dollars he feels his wife is owed. But when Ken abducts Barbara, he doesn’t know that Sam is coming home to murder his shrewish and overweight wife. Ken calls Sam demanding millions, but the gleeful Sam puts him off. Ken keeps lowering the price until at ten thousand dollars Sam says, “Oh, why don’t you just kill her and get it over with.”

与此同时，被关押在凯斯勒地下室的芭芭拉把她的监狱变成了水疗中心。她按照电视上的所有锻炼节目进行锻炼，桑迪是一位出色的天然食品厨师，因此，芭芭拉减掉的体重比她在美国最好的减肥农场减掉的体重还要多。因此，她爱她的绑架者。当他们告诉她，由于她的丈夫不会支付赎金，他们不得不放她走时，她转过身对他们说：“我会帮你们拿到钱的。”这是第一幕。

Meanwhile, Barbara, held captive in the Kessler basement, has turned her prison into a spa. She’s following all the exercise programs on TV, Sandy’s an excellent natural foods cook, and as a result, Barbara loses more weight than she ever did at the best fat farms in America. Consequently, she loves her kidnappers. And when they tell her they’ll have to let her go because her husband won’t pay the ransom, she turns to them and says, “I’ll get the money for ya.” That was Act One.

3.他扔掉了后来他发现对他的幸福不可缺少的东西。

3. He throws away what he later finds is indispensable to his happiness.

红磨坊：残疾艺术家图卢兹-罗特列克（何塞·费雷尔饰）爱上了美丽的苏珊娜（米丽亚姆·海耶姆饰），但他无法告诉她。苏珊娜以朋友的身份陪他游览巴黎。罗特列克确信，苏珊娜与他共度时光的唯一原因是，这让她有机会结识英俊的男人。在醉酒的愤怒中，他指责苏珊娜利用了他，并愤然离开了她的生活。

MOULIN ROUGE: The crippled artist Toulouse-Lautrec (Jose Ferrer) falls in love with the beautiful Suzanne (Myriamme Hayem) but can’t bring himself to tell her this. She accompanies him as a friend around Paris. Lautrec becomes convinced that the only reason she spends time with him is that it gives her the opportunity to meet handsome men. In a drunken rage he accuses her of using him and storms out of her life.

不久之后，他收到了苏珊娜的来信：“亲爱的图卢兹，我一直希望有一天你会爱我。现在我意识到你永远不会爱我。所以我接受了另一个男人的求爱。我不爱他，但他很善良，而且你知道我的情况很糟糕。再见。” 劳特雷克疯狂地寻找她，但她确实嫁给了别人。于是他酗酒而死。

Some time later he receives a letter from Suzanne: “Dear Toulouse, I always hoped that some day you might love me. Now I realize that you never will. So I have taken the offer of another man. I don’t love him, but he’s kind and as you know my situation is desperate. Adieu.” Lautrec frantically searches for her, but indeed she’s left to marry another. So he drinks himself to death.

4.为了达到目标，他会不知不觉地采取必要的精确步骤来引诱自己偏离目标。

4. To reach a goal he unwittingly takes the precise steps necessary to lead him away.

《窈窕淑女》：迈克尔（达斯汀·霍夫曼饰）是一名失业的演员，他的完美主义让纽约的每一位制片人都感到厌烦，他假扮女性出演了一部肥皂剧。在片场，他遇到了朱莉（杰西卡·兰格饰），并爱上了她。但他是一名才华横溢的演员，朱莉的父亲（查尔斯·德恩宁饰）想嫁给他，而朱莉怀疑他是女同性恋。

TOOTSIE: Michael (Dustin Hoffman), an out-of-work actor whose perfectionism has alienated every producer in New York, impersonates a woman and is cast in a soap opera. On the set he meets and falls in love with Julie (Jessica Lange). But he’s such a brilliant actor, her father (Charles Durning) wants to marry him while Julie suspects he’s a lesbian.

5.他为破坏某物而采取的行动恰好变成了该物所需要破坏的东西。

5. The action he takes to destroy something becomes exactly what are needed to be destroyed by it.

《雨》：宗教偏执者戴维森牧师（沃尔特·休斯顿饰）努力挽救妓女赛迪·汤普森（琼·克劳馥饰）的灵魂，但却对她产生了欲望，强奸了她，然后羞愧地自杀。

RAIN: The religious bigot Reverend Davidson (Walter Huston) battles to save the soul of the prostitute Sadie Thompson (Joan Crawford), but falls into lust for her, rapes her, then kills himself in shame.

6.他得到了某件他确信会让他痛苦的东西，并尽一切可能摆脱它……结果却发现这是幸福的礼物。

6. He comes into possession of something he’s certain will make him miserable, does everything possible to get rid of it… only to discover it’s the gift of happiness.

《育婴奇谭》：当疯狂的社交名媛苏珊（凯瑟琳·赫本饰）无意中偷走了天真而压抑的古生物学家大卫·赫胥黎博士（加里·格兰特饰）的汽车时，她喜欢她所看到的一切，并像胶水一样粘在他身上。他想尽一切办法摆脱她，但她挫败了他疯狂的逃避，主要是通过偷他的骨头，雷龙的“肋间锁骨”。（如果有“肋间锁骨”这种东西，它应该属于一种头部连在肩膀下方的生物。）苏珊的坚持得到了回报，她把大卫从一个僵硬的孩子变成了一个拥抱生活的成年人。

BRINGING UP BABY: When the madcap socialite Susan (Katharine Hepburn) inadvertently steals the car of the naive and repressed paleontologist Dr. David Huxley (Cary Grant), she likes what she sees and sticks to him like glue. He tries everything possible to get rid of her, but she foils his lunatic evasions, chiefly by stealing his bone, the “intercostal clavicle” of a brontosaurus. (If there were such a thing as an “intercostal clavicle,” it would belong to a creature with its head attached well below its shoulders.) Susan’s persistence pays off as she transforms David from fossilized child to life-embracing adult.

讽刺性发展的关键是确定性和精确性。就像《唐人街》、《苏利文游记》和许多其他精彩电影一样，这些故事的主角觉得自己肯定知道自己必须做什么，并有一个精确的计划如何去做。他们认为生活就是 A、B、C、D、E。这时，生活就会转过身来，踢你的屁股，然后咧嘴笑着说：“今天不行，我的朋友。今天是 E、D、C、B、A。对不起。”

The key to ironic progression is certainty and precision. Like CHINATOWN, SULLIVAN’S TRAVELS, and many other superb films, these are stories of protagonists who feel they know for certain what they must do and have a precise plan how to do it. They think life is A, B, C, D, E. That’s just when life likes to turn you around, kick you in the butt, and grin: “Not today, my friend. Today it’s E, D, C, B, A. Sorry.”

过渡原则

PRINCIPLE OF TRANSITION

缺乏进展感的故事往往会从一个场景跌跌撞撞地过渡到下一个场景。它几乎没有连续性，因为没有任何事件联系在一起。当我们设计上升动作循环时，我们必须同时让观众顺利地过渡。因此，在两个场景之间，我们需要第三个元素，即连接场景 A 尾部和场景 B 开头的纽带。通常，我们会在两个地方之一找到这个第三个元素：场景的共同点或对立点。

A story without a sense of progression tends to stumble from one scene to the next. It has little continuity because nothing links its events. As we design cycles of rising action, we must at the same time transition the audience smoothly through them. Between two scenes, therefore, we need a third element, the link that joins the tail of Scene A with the head of Scene B. Generally, we find this third element in one of two places: what the scenes have in common or what they have in opposition.

第三个要素是过渡的关键；两个场景的共同点或对位点。

The third element is the hinge for a transition; something held in common by two scenes or counterpointed between them.

例子：

Examples:

  1. 一种性格特征。共同点：从任性的孩子转变为幼稚的成年人。相反点：从笨拙的主角转变为优雅的反派。

  2. A characterization trait. In common: cut from a bratty child to a childish adult. In opposition: cut from awkward protagonist to elegant antagonist.

  3. 一种动作。共同点：从做爱的前戏到享受余韵。相反点：从喋喋不休到冷漠沉默。

  4. An action. In common: From the foreplay of lovemaking to savoring the afterglow. In opposition: From chatter to cold silence.

  5. 一个物体。共同点：从温室内部到林地外部。相反点：从刚果到南极洲。

  6. An object. In common: From greenhouse interior to woodland exterior. In opposition: From the Congo to Antarctica.

  7. 一个词。共同点：场景中重复的一句话。反对：从赞美到诅咒。

  8. A word. In common: A phrase repeated from scene to scene. In opposition: From compliment to curse.

  9. 光的一种性质。共同点：从黎明的阴影到日落的阴影。相反点：从蓝色到红色。

  10. A quality of light. In common: From shadows at dawn to shade at sunset. In opposition: From blue to red.

  11. 一种声音。共同点是：从海浪拍打海岸的声音到睡眠者呼吸的起伏。相反点是：从丝绸抚摸肌肤的声音到齿轮的磨擦声。

  12. A sound. In common: From waves lapping a shore to the rise and fall of a sleeper’s breath. In opposition: From silk caressing skin to the grinding of gears.

  13. 一个想法。共同点：从一个孩子的诞生到一个序曲。相反点：从一个画家的空白画布到一个垂死的老人。

  14. An idea. In common: From a child’s birth to an overture. In opposition: From a painter’s empty canvas to an old man dying.

经过一个世纪的电影制作，过渡的陈词滥调比比皆是。然而，我们不能放弃这项任务。对几乎任何两个场景进行富有想象力的研究都会发现其中的联系。

After a century of filmmaking, transition clichés abound. Yet we can’t put down the task. An imaginative study of almost any two scenes will find a link.

13

危机、高潮、解决

13

CRISIS, CLIMAX, RESOLUTION

危机

CRISIS

危机是五部曲中的第三个，意思是决定。人物每次开口说“这个”而不是“那个”时，都会做出自发的决定。在每个场景中，他们都会决定采取一种行动而不是另一种行动。但大写的危机是最终的决定。危机的中文表意文字有两个术语：危险/机会——“危险”表示此刻错误的决定将永远失去我们想要的东西；“机会”表示正确的选择将实现我们的愿望。

Crisis is the third of the five-part form. It means decision. Characters make spontaneous decisions each time they open this mouths to say “this” not “that.” In each scene they make a decision to take one action rather than another. But Crisis with a capital C is the ultimate decision. The Chinese ideogram for Crisis is two terms: Danger/Opportunity—“danger” in that the wrong decision at this moment will lose forever what we want; “opportunity” in that the right choice will achieve our desire.

主角的探索过程不断复杂化，直到他用尽了所有行动来实现自己的愿望，只剩下一个。现在他发现自己走到了尽头。他的下一个行动是最后一次。没有明天。没有第二次机会。这个危险的机会时刻是故事中最紧张的时刻，因为主角和观众都感觉到“结果会怎样？”这个问题将在下一个行动中得到解答。

The protagonist’s quest has carried him through the Progressive Complications until he’s exhausted all actions to achieve his desire, save one. He now finds himself at the end of the line. His next action is his last. No tomorrow. No second chance. This moment of dangerous opportunity is the point of greatest tension in the story as both protagonist and audience sense that the question “How will this turn out?” will be answered out of the next action.

危机是故事的必经场景。从激励事件开始，观众就越来越生动地期待着主人公将面对他一生中最集中、最强大的敌对力量的场景。可以说，这就是守护欲望对象的龙：无论是《大白鲨》中的字面龙，还是无意义的隐喻龙在《温柔的怜悯》中，观众充满期待和不确定性地面对危机。

The Crisis is the story’s Obligatory Scene. From the Inciting Incident on, the audience has been anticipating with growing vividness the scene in which the protagonist will be face to face with the most focused, powerful forces of antagonism in his existence. This is the dragon, so to speak, that guards the Object of Desire: be it the literal dragon of JAWS or the metaphorical dragon of meaning-lessness in TENDER MERCIES. The audience leans into the Crisis filled with expectation mingled with uncertainty.

危机必须是真正的困境——在不可调和的善与恶之间做出选择，还是两害相权取其轻，或者同时做出两害相权取其轻的选择，这会让主人公承受一生中最大的压力。

The Crisis must be true dilemma—a choice between irreconcilable goods, the lesser of two evils, or the two at once that places the protagonist under the maximum pressure of his life.

主人公面临着这样的困境，当他面对生命中最强大、最集中的对抗力量时，他必须做出决定，采取这样或那样的行动，作为最后的努力来实现他的欲望目标。

This dilemma confronts the protagonist who, when face-to-face with the most powerful and focused forces of antagonism in his life, must make a decision to take one action or another in a last effort to achieve his Object of Desire.

主人公在这里的选择让我们最深刻地看到了他深刻的性格，以及他人性的终极表达。

How the protagonist chooses here gives us the most penetrating view of his deep character, the ultimate expression of his humanity.

这一幕揭示了故事中最重要的价值。如果对哪个价值是核心有任何疑问，那么当主角做出危机决定时，主要价值就会凸显出来。

This scene reveals the story’s most important value. If there’s been any doubt about which value is central, as the protagonist makes the Crisis Decision, the primary value comes to the fore.

在危机时刻，主人公的意志力受到最严峻的考验。正如我们从生活中所知道的那样，做决定远比采取行动困难。我们经常尽可能地推迟做某件事，然后当我们最终做出决定并采取行动时，我们会惊讶于它相对容易。我们不禁想知道为什么我们害怕做这件事，直到我们意识到生活中的大多数行动都在我们的能力范围内，但做决定需要意志力。

At Crisis the protagonist’s willpower is most severely tested. As we know from life, decisions are far more difficult to make than actions are to take. We often put off doing something for as long as possible, then as we finally make the decision and step into the action, we’re surprised by its relative ease. We’re left to wonder why we dreaded doing it until we realize that most of life’s actions are within our reach, but decisions take willpower.

高潮中的危机

CRISIS WITHIN THE CLIMAX

主角选择采取的行动成为故事的最终事件，导致积极、消极或具有讽刺意味的积极/消极故事高潮。然而，如果在主角采取高潮行动时，我们再次拉开期望与结果之间的差距，如果我们能再一次将可能性与必然性分开，我们可能会创造出一个观众会终生珍藏的宏伟结局。因为围绕转折点构建的高潮是最令人满意的。

The action the protagonist chooses to take becomes the story’s consummate event, causing a positive, negative, or ironically positive/negative Story Climax. If, however, as the protagonist takes the climactic action, we once more pry apart the gap between expectation and result, if we can split probability from necessity just one more time, we may create a majestic ending the audience will treasure for a lifetime. For a Climax built around a Turning Point is the most satisfying of all.

我们让主角经历了一个又一个行动，直到他精疲力竭，认为自己终于了解了自己的世界，知道自己必须做最后的努力。他用尽了自己最后的意志力，选择了一个他认为能实现愿望的行动，但一如既往，他的世界不会配合他。现实分裂了，他必须即兴发挥。主角可能会得到他想要的，也可能不会，但不会是他期望的那样。

We’ve taken the protagonist through progressions that exhaust one action after another until he reaches the limit and thinks he finally understands his world and knows what he must do in a last effort. He draws on the dregs of his willpower, chooses an action he believes will achieve his desire, but, as always, his world won’t cooperate. Reality splits and he must improvise. The protagonist may or may not get what he wants, but it won’t be the way he expects.

将《星球大战》与《帝国反击战》进行比较：在《星球大战》危机中，卢克·天行者攻击了“死星”，这是一座像行星一样巨大的人造堡垒。但它尚未完全建成。球体的一侧有一个易受攻击的槽口。卢克不仅要攻击槽口，还要击中其中的一个易受攻击点。他是一名专业的战斗机飞行员，但试图击中这个点，但没有成功。当他通过电脑操纵他的飞机时，他听到了欧比旺·克诺比的声音：“用原力前进，用原力前进。”

Compare STAR WARS with THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK: At the Crisis of STAR WARS Luke Skywalker attacks the “Death Star,” a manmade fortress as huge as a planet. But it’s not fully constructed. A vulnerable slot lies open on one side of the sphere. Luke must not only attack into the slot, but hit a vulnerable spot within it. He’s an expert fighter pilot but tries without success to hit the spot. As he maneuvers his craft by computer, he hears the voice of Obi-Wan Kenobi: “Go with the Force, go with the Force.”

突然之间，两难境地出现了：电脑与神秘的“原力”之间的对立。他苦苦挣扎，然后把电脑推到一边，凭直觉飞​​进插槽，发射了一枚鱼雷，击中了目标。死星的毁灭是影片的高潮，是危机中的直接行动。

A sudden dilemma of irreconcilable goods: the computer versus the mysterious “Force.” He wrestles with the anguish of choice, then pushes his computer aside, flies by instinct into the slot, and fires a torpedo that hits the spot. The destruction of the Death Star climaxes the film, a straight action out of the Crisis.

相比之下，《帝国反击战》的高潮部分则以螺旋式上升结束：面对达斯·维达，卢克遭遇了勇气危机。两害相权取其轻：他可以攻击并杀死维达，也可以逃跑并保住性命。两害相权取其轻：他可以攻击维达并被杀死，也可以逃跑，使他成为懦夫并背叛朋友。卢克鼓起勇气，选择战斗。然而，当维达突然退后并说：“你不能杀我，卢克……我是你的父亲”时，卢克的现实支离破碎。一瞬间，他意识到了真相，现在必须做出另一个危机决定：是否要杀死他的父亲。

THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK, by contrast, corkscrews its Climax: Face to face with Darth Vader, Luke is met by a Crisis of courage. Irreconcilable goods: He could attack and kill Vader, or he could flee and save his life. The lesser of two evils: He could attack Vader and be killed, or he could flee, making him a coward and betraying his friends. Luke musters his courage and chooses to fight. However, when Vader suddenly steps back and says: “You can’t kill me, Luke… I’m your father,” Luke’s reality splinters. In a flash he realizes the truth and now must make yet another Crisis Decision: whether to kill his father.

卢克直面这个决定的痛苦，选择战斗。但维德砍断了他的手，卢克倒在甲板上。然而，事情还没有结束。维德宣布他希望卢克加入他的运动，为宇宙带来“秩序”。当卢克意识到他的父亲不想让他死，他给他提供了一份工作时，第二个缺口出现了。他必须做出第三个危机决定，两害相权取其轻两难境地：加入“黑暗势力”还是自杀？他做出了英勇的选择，随着这些差距的扩大，高潮带来了深刻的洞察力，将两部电影联系在一起。

Luke confronts the agony of this decision and chooses to fight. But Vader cuts off his hand and Luke drops to the deck. Still, it’s not over. Vader announces that he wants Luke to join his campaign to bring “order to things” in the universe. A second Gap opens as Luke realizes that his father doesn’t want him dead, he’s offering him a job. He must make a third Crisis Decision, a lesser-of-two-evils dilemma: to join the “dark side” or take his own life? He makes the heroic choice, and as these Gaps explode, the Climax delivers deep rushes of insight uniting two films.

危机的定位

Placement of the Crisis

危机的地点由高潮动作的长度决定。

The location of the Crisis is determined by the length of the climactic action.

危机的地点由高潮动作的长度决定。

The location of the Crisis is determined by the length of the climactic action.

一般来说，危机和高潮都发生在最后几分钟，并且发生在同一个场景中。

Generally, Crisis and Climax happen in the last minutes and in the same scene.

《末路狂花》：在危机时刻，女人们勇敢面对两难：监禁和死亡。她们对视一眼，做出了“勇敢地选择”的危机决定，选择自杀。她们立即开车冲进大峡谷——这是一个异常短暂的高潮，通过慢动作拍摄和定格悬在深渊上的汽车，延长了高潮。

THELMA & LOUISE: At Crisis the women brave the lesser of two evils: imprisonment versus death. They look at each other and make their Crisis Decision to “go for it,” a courageous choice to take their own lives. They immediately drive their car into the Grand Canyon—an unusually brief Climax elongated by filming it in slowmotion and freeze-framing on the car suspended over the abyss.

然而，在其他故事中，高潮会变成具有自身进展的扩展动作。因此，可以使用危机决策来转变倒数第二幕的高潮，让高潮动作填满整个最后一幕。

However, in other stories the Climax becomes an expansive action with its own progressions. As a result, it’s possible to use the Crisis Decision to turn the Penultimate Act Climax, filling all of the final act with climactic action.

《卡萨布兰卡》：里克一直追赶伊尔莎，直到第二幕高潮中她向他投降，他说他必须为所有人做出决定。在下一幕中，拉兹洛敦促里克重新加入反法西斯事业。这种不可调和的善恶困境将剧情转向里克无私的危机决定，即把伊尔莎还给拉兹洛，并让妻子和丈夫登上飞往美国的飞机，这是一个决定人物性格的选择，扭转了他对伊尔莎的有意识的渴望。《卡萨布兰卡》的第三幕是十五分钟的高潮动作，揭示了里克帮助这对夫妇逃跑的令人惊喜的计划。

CASABLANCA: Rick pursues Ilsa until she surrenders to him in the Act Two Climax, saying that he must make the decisions for everyone. In the next scene, Laszlo urges Rick to rejoin the antifascist cause. This irreconcilable-goods dilemma turns the act on Rick’s selfless Crisis Decision to return Ilsa to Laszlo and put wife and husband on the plane to America, a character-defining choice that reverses his conscious desire for Ilsa. The third act of CASABLANCA is fifteen minutes of climactic action that unravels Rick’s surprise-filled scheme to help the couple escape.

在较为罕见的例子中，危机决策紧随激励事件之后，并且整部影片成为高潮动作。

In rarer examples the Crisis Decision immediately follows the Inciting Incident and the entire film becomes climactic action.

詹姆斯·邦德：激励事件：邦德接到任务，追捕一名大反派。危机决策：邦德接受任务——这是正确/错误的选择，而不是真正的困境，因为他永远不会想到其他选择。从此时起，所有邦德电影都是对单一动作的精心演绎：追捕反派。邦德从未做出其他实质性决定，只是选择在追捕过程中使用哪些计谋。

JAMES BOND: Inciting Incident: Bond is offered the task of hunting down an arch-villain. Crisis Decision: Bond takes the assignment—a right/wrong choice and not a true dilemma, for it would never occur to him to choose otherwise. From this point on, all Bond films are an elaborate progression of a single action: the pursuit of the villain. Bond never makes another decision of substance, simply choices of which ploys to use in the pursuit.

《离开拉斯维加斯》也是同样的形式。诱发事件：主角被解雇，并收到一大笔遣散费。他立即做出了危机决定，去拉斯维加斯喝酒自尽。从这时起，影片开始随着主人公追随自己的欲望走向死亡，这成为了悲伤的进程。

LEAVING LAS VEGAS has the identical form. Inciting Incident: the protagonist is fired and given a sizable severance check. He immediately makes his Crisis Decision to go to Las Vegas and drink himself to death. From this point on the film becomes a sad progression toward death as he follows his desire.

感官世界：煽动事件：恋人在前十分钟内相遇，并决定抛弃社会和正常生活，过上沉迷于性的生活。剩下的一百分钟都用于性实验，最终导致死亡。

IN THE REALM OF THE SENSES: Inciting Incident: Lovers meet within the first ten minutes and decide to abandon society and normalcy for a life of sexual obsession. The remaining hundred minutes are devoted to sexual experimentations that eventually lead to death.

将危机置于激励事件之后的最大风险是重复。无论是高预算的动作重复模式的追逐/打斗、追逐/打斗，还是低预算的重复模式的喝酒/喝酒/喝酒或做爱/做爱/做爱，多样性和进展的问题都是惊人的。然而，掌握这项任务可能会产生辉煌，就像上面的例子一样。

The great risk of placing the Crisis on the heels of the Inciting Incident is repetitiousness. Whether it’s high-budget action repeating patterns of chase/fight, chase/fight, or low-budget repetitions of drinking/drinking/drinking or lovemaking/lovemaking/ lovemaking, the problems of variety and progression are staggering. Yet mastery of this task may produce brilliance, as it did in the examples above.

危机的设计

Design of the Crisis

尽管危机决策和高潮动作通常发生在故事讲述最后的同一地点，但危机决策发生在一个地点，而故事高潮发生在另一个场景中的情况也并不少见。

Although the Crisis Decision and climactic action usually take place in continuous time within the same location at the very end of the telling, it’s not uncommon for the Crisis decision to occur in one location, the Story Climax later in another setting.

《克莱默夫妇》中爱的价值在第二幕高潮时变成了负面，法官将监护权判给了克莱默的前妻。第三幕开始时，克莱默的律师陈述了情况：克莱默输了，但他可以上诉获胜。然而，要做到这一点，他必须让儿子站在证人席上，让孩子选择和谁一起生活。男孩可能会选择他的父亲，克莱默会赢。但把这么小的孩子放在公众面前，强迫他在母亲和父亲之间做出选择，会给他留下终生的心理创伤。自我需求与他人需求的双重困境另一方，自我的痛苦与他人的痛苦。克莱默抬起头说：“不，我不能那样做。”镜头切换到高潮：在中央公园散步，父亲向儿子解释他们分开生活后的生活会怎样，他泪流满面。

The value of love in KRAMER VS. KRAMER turns negative at the Act Two Climax as a judge awards custody to Kramer’s ex-wife. As Act Three opens Kramer’s lawyer lays out the situation: Kramer has lost, but he could win on appeal. To do so, however, he’ll have to put his son on the witness stand and make the child choose with whom he wants to live. The boy will probably choose his father, and Kramer will win. But to put a child at this tender age in public and force him to choose between his mother and his father will psychologically scar him for life. A double dilemma of the needs of self versus the needs of another, the suffering of the self versus the suffering of another. Kramer looked up and said, “No, I can’t do that.” Cut to the Climax: a walk in Central Park and a river of tears as the father explains to his son how their life will be now that they’ll live apart.

如果危机发生在一个地方，而高潮发生在另一个地方，我们必须将它们拼接起来，将它们融合在电影时间和空间中。如果我们不这样做，如果我们从危机切换到其他材料（例如一个次要情节），我们就会耗尽观众压抑的能量，让高潮变得虎头蛇尾。

If the Crisis takes place in one location and the Climax later in another, we must splice them together on a cut, fusing them in filmic time and space. If we do not, if we cut from the Crisis to other material—a subplot, for example—we drain the pent-up energy of the audience into an anticlimax.

危机决策必须是一个刻意静止的时刻。

The Crisis decision must be a deliberately static moment.

这是必看的场景。不要把它放在屏幕外，也不要略过它。观众希望与主角一起承受这种困境带来的痛苦。我们定格这一刻，因为最后一幕的节奏取决于它。情感势头已经积累到了这一步，但危机阻碍了它的流动。当主角做出这个决定时，观众倾身向前，想知道：“他要做什么？他要做什么？”紧张感不断积累，然后当主角做出行动选择时，压缩的能量爆发成高潮。

This is the Obligatory Scene. Do not put it offscreen, or skim over it. The audience wants to suffer with the protagonist through the pain of this dilemma. We freeze this moment because the rhythm of the last movement depends on it. An emotional momentum has built to this point, but the Crisis dams its flow. As the protagonist goes through this decision, the audience leans in, wondering: “What’s he going to do? What’s he going to do?” Tension builds and builds, then as the protagonist makes a choice of action, that compressed energy explodes into the Climax.

《末路狂花》：这场危机被巧妙地延缓了，因为女人们在“走”这个词上结结巴巴地说着。“我说，我们走吧。”“走？你说‘走’是什么意思？”“嗯……就走吧。”“你的意思是……走？”随着紧张气氛的加剧，她们犹豫不决，观众祈祷她们不会自杀，但同时又为她们的勇气而兴奋。当她们把车挂上档时，紧张的焦虑炸药爆炸，将影片推向高潮。

THELMA & LOUISE: This Crisis is masterfully delayed as the women stutter over the word “go.” “I say, let’s go.” “Go? What do you mean ‘go’?” “Well… just go.” “You mean… go?” They hesitate and hesitate as tension builds and the audience prays they won’t kill themselves but at the same time is thrilled by their courage. As they put the car in gear, the dynamite of compacted anxiety blasts into the Climax.

猎鹿人：迈克尔悄悄地来到山顶。但当猎物出现在眼前时，他停了下来。随着时间的流逝，紧张感逐渐增强，观众害怕杀死这头美丽的麋鹿。在这个危机时刻，主人公做出了一个决定，使他的性格发生了深刻的变化。他放下武器，从一个杀人犯变成了一个救人犯。这一惊人的逆转成为了倒数第二幕的高潮。观众压抑的同情心在故事的最后一幕中涌现出来，迈克尔现在赶回越南去拯救他朋友的生命，最后一幕充满了高潮迭起的动作。

THE DEER HUNTER: Michael stalks to the top of a mountain. But with his prey in his sights, he pauses. Tension builds and tightens as the moment extends and the audience dreads the killing of this beautiful elk. At this Crisis point the protagonist makes a decision that takes him through a profound change of character. He lowers his weapon and transforms within from a man who takes life to a man who saves life. This stunning reversal turns the Penultimate Act Climax. The pent-up compassion in the audience pours into the story’s last movement as Michael now rushes back to Vietnam to save his friend’s life, filling the final act with rising climactic action.

高潮

CLIMAX

故事高潮是五部分结构中的第四部分。这一高潮性大逆转不一定充满喧嚣和暴力。相反，它必须充满意义。如果我可以给全世界的电影制片人发一封电报，那将是这三个词：“意义产生情感。 ”不是金钱；不是性；不是特效；不是电影明星；不是华丽的摄影。

Story Climax is the fourth of the five-part structure. This crowning Major Reversal is not necessarily full of noise and violence. Rather, it must be full of meaning. If I could send a telegram to the film producers of the world, it would be these three words: “Meaning Produces Emotion.” Not money; not sex; not special effects; not movie stars; not lush photography.

意义：价值观从正面到负面或从负面到正面的革命，带有或不带有讽刺意味——价值观念的转变达到最大程度，是绝对的、不可逆转的。这种变化的意义打动了观众的心。

MEANING: A revolution in values from positive to negative or negative to positive with or without irony—a value swing at maximum charge that’s absolute and irreversible. The meaning of that change moves the heart of the audience.

促成这一改变的行动必须是“纯粹的”、清晰的、不言而喻的，不需要任何解释。用对话或叙述来阐述它是无聊且多余的。

The action that creates this change must be “pure,” clear, and self-evident, requiring no explanation. Dialogue or narration to spell out it out is boring and redundant.

这一行动必须符合故事的需要。它可能是灾难性的：在《荣耀》中达到高潮的壮丽战斗场景，也可能是表面上微不足道的：一个女人和丈夫安静地交谈后站起来，收拾行李，出门。在《普通人》的背景下，这一行动是压倒性的。在《危机》中，当丈夫拼命揭露家庭的痛苦秘密时，家庭之爱和团结的价值观向积极方向倾斜。但在《高潮》中，当他的妻子走出去时，它们就转向绝对的、不可逆转的消极方向。另一方面，如果她留下来，她对儿子的仇恨最终可能会让儿子自杀。因此，她的离开带有积极的对比，以痛苦但总体上消极的讽刺结束这部电影。

This action must be appropriate to the needs of the story. It may be catastrophic: The sublime battle sequence that climaxes GLORY, or outwardly trivial: A woman rises from a quiet talk with her husband, packs a suitcase, and goes out the door. That action, in the context of ORDINARY PEOPLE, is overwhelming. At Crisis, the values of family love and unity tip toward the positive as the husband desperately exposes his family’s bitter secret. But at Climax, the moment his wife walks out, they swing to an absolute, irreversible negative. If, on the other hand, she were to stay, her hatred of her son might finally drive the boy to suicide.
