教父：不仅科里昂家族腐败，其他黑手党家族，甚至警察和法官也腐败。这部电影中的每个人都是罪犯或与罪犯有关系。但科里昂家族有一个优点——忠诚。在其他黑帮家族中，匪徒们会在背后捅刀子。这使他们成为坏人。教父家族的忠诚使他们成为好人。当我们发现这种优点时，我们的情感就会向它靠拢，我们会发现自己对匪徒产生了同情。

THE GODFATHER: Not only is the Corleone family corrupt, but so too are the other mafia families, even the police and judges. Everyone in this film is a criminal or related to one. But the Corleones have one positive quality—loyalty. In other mob clans gangsters stab one another in the back. That makes them the bad bad guys. The loyalty of the Godfather’s family makes them the good bad guys. When we spot this positive quality, our emotions move toward it and we find ourselves in empathy with gangsters.

我们能把善良的中心带到多远？什么样的怪物会引起观众的同情？

How far can we take the Center of Good? With what kind of monsters will an audience empathize?

《白热化》：影片中的善良中心科迪·贾瑞特（詹姆斯·卡格尼饰）是一名变态杀手。但编剧巧妙地平衡了正能量和负能量，首先赋予贾瑞特迷人的品质，然后为他营造一个残酷宿命的世界：贾瑞特是一群意志薄弱的唯唯诺诺者，但他具有领导能力。他被一群平庸的笨蛋 FBI 小队追捕，而他机智而富有想象力。他的“最好朋友”是 FBI 的线人，而科迪的友谊是真诚的。影片中没有人对任何人表现出感情，除了科迪，他崇拜他的母亲。这种道德管理让观众产生同情，感觉“如果我必须过犯罪的生活，我想成为像科迪·贾瑞特那样的人。”

WHITE HEAT: Cody Jarrett (James Cagney), the film’s Center of Good, is a psychopathic killer. But the writers design a masterful balancing act of negative/positive energies by first giving Jarrett attractive qualities, then landscaping around him a grim, fatalistic world: His is a gang of weak-willed yes-men, but he has leadership capacities. He’s pursued by an FBI squad of lackluster dullards, whereas he’s witty and imaginative. His “best friend” is an FBI informant, while Cody’s friendship is genuine. No one shows affection for anyone in this film, except Cody, who adores his mother. This moral management draws the audience into empathy, feeling, “If I had to lead a life of crime, I’d want to be like Cody Jarrett.”

《守夜人》：在充满戏剧性倒叙的背景故事中，主角和恋人（德克·博加德和夏洛特·兰普林）是这样相遇的：他是纳粹死亡集中营的虐待狂指挥官，她是一个具有受虐倾向的青少年囚犯。他们在死亡集中营的激情恋情持续了数年。战争结束后，他们分道扬镳。影片于 1957 年开场，他们在维也纳一家酒店的大堂里对视。他现在是一名酒店门房，而她是与钢琴演奏家丈夫一起旅行的客人。一回到房间，她就告诉丈夫她病了，让他先去听音乐会，然后留下来继续与前情人的恋情。这对情侣是善良的中心。

THE NIGHT PORTER: In a Backstory of dramatized flashbacks, protagonists and lovers (Dirk Bogarde and Charlotte Rampling) met in this fashion: He was the sadistic commandant of a Nazi death camp, she a teenage prisoner of masochistic nature. Their passionate affair lasted for years inside the death camp. With the war’s end, they went their separate ways. The film opens in 1957 as they eye each other in the lobby of a Viennese hotel. He’s now a hotel porter, she a guest traveling with her concert pianist husband. Once up in their room she tells her husband she’s ill, sends him on ahead to his concert, then stays behind to resume her affair with her former lover. This couple is the Center of Good.

编剧兼导演莉莉安娜·卡瓦尼 (Liliana Cavani) 通过将这对恋人置于一群邪恶的党卫军军官的包围中，成功实现了这一壮举。躲藏起来。然后她点燃一支小蜡烛，照亮这个冰冷黑暗的世界：不管这对恋人是如何相遇的，不管他们激情的本质如何，从最深最真实的意义上讲，他们的爱是真实的。更重要的是，他们的爱经受了极限的考验。当党卫军军官告诉他们的朋友，他必须杀死这个女人，因为她可能会揭发他们时，他回答说：“不，她是我的宝贝，她是我的宝贝。”他会为他的爱人牺牲自己的生命，她也会为他牺牲生命。当他们在高潮时选择一起死去时，我们感到一种悲惨的失落。

Writer/director Liliana Cavani manages this feat by encircling the lovers with a depraved society of malevolent SS officers in hiding. Then she lights one little candle to blaze at the heart of this cold, dark world: Despite how the lovers met and the nature of their passion, in the deepest and truest sense, their love is real. What’s more, it’s tested to the limit. When SS officers tell their friend he must kill the woman because she may expose them, he replies, “No, she’s my baby, she’s my baby.” He’d sacrifice his life for his lover and she for him. We feel a tragic loss when at Climax they choose to die together.

《沉默的羔羊》：小说和剧本的作者将克拉丽斯（朱迪·福斯特饰）置于正面的焦点，但也围绕汉尼拔·莱克特（安东尼·霍普金斯饰）塑造了第二个善的中心，并让观众对两人都产生同情。首先，他们赋予莱克特医生令人钦佩和渴望的品质：巨大的智慧、敏锐的机智和讽刺感、绅士风度，最重要的是冷静。我们不禁想，生活在这样一个地狱般的世界里的人怎么能保持如此镇定和礼貌呢？

SILENCE OF THE LAMBS: The writers of novel and screenplay place Clarice (Jodie Foster) at the positive focal point, but also shape a second Center of Good around Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) and draw empathy to both. First, they assign Dr. Lecter admirable and desirable qualities: massive intelligence, a sharp wit and sense of irony, gentlemanly charm, and most importantly, calmness. How, we wondered, could someone who lives in such a hellish world remain so poised and polite?

接下来，为了与这些特质形成对比，编剧们将莱克特置于一个残酷、愤世嫉俗的社会中。监狱里的精神病医生是个虐待狂，喜欢出风头。他的看守都是傻瓜。就连想让莱克特帮忙解决一个令人困惑的案件的联邦调查局也对他撒谎，试图用卡罗莱纳岛上的露天监狱的虚假承诺来操纵他。很快我们就合理化了：“所以他吃人。还有更糟糕的事情。我一时想不出是什么，但是……”我们陷入了同情，沉思道：“如果我是一个食人精神病患者，我想成为像莱克特一样的人。”

Next, to counterpoint these qualities the writers surround Lecter with a brutish, cynical society. His prison psychiatrist is a sadist and publicity hound. His guards are dimwits. Even the FBI, which wants Lecter’s help on a baffling case, lies to him, trying to manipulate him with false promises of an open-air prison on a Carolina island. Soon we’re rationalizing: “So he eats people. There are worse things. Offhand I can’t think what, but….” We fall into empathy, musing, “If I were a cannibalistic psychopath, I’d want to be just like Lecter.”

神秘、悬疑、戏剧性讽刺

Mystery, Suspense, Dramatic Irony

好奇心和关注度创造了三种可能的方式将观众与故事联系起来：神秘、悬念和戏剧性讽刺。这些术语不应被误认为是流派；它们命名了故事/观众关系，这种关系因我们的兴趣不同而不同。

Curiosity and Concern create three possible ways to connect the audience to the story: Mystery, Suspense, and Dramatic Irony. These terms are not to be mistaken for genres; they name story/audience relationships that vary according to how we hold interest.

在悬疑片中，观众知道的比剧中角色还少。

In Mystery the audience knows less than the characters.

神秘意味着仅通过好奇心就能引起兴趣。我们创造但隐藏了说明性事实，尤其是背景故事。我们激发观众对这些过去事件的好奇心，用真相的暗示挑逗他们，然后用“转移注意力的线索”故意让他们蒙在鼓里，让他们相信或怀疑虚假的事实，而我们则隐藏真实的事实。

Mystery means gaining interest through curiosity alone. We create but then conceal expositional facts, particularly facts in the Backstory. We arouse the audience’s curiosity about these past events, tease it with hints of the truth, then deliberately keep it in the dark by misleading it with “red herrings,” so that it believes or suspects false facts while we hide the real facts.

“Red herrings” （红鲱鱼）有一个有趣的词源：当农民偷猎鹿和松鸡并带着战利品穿过中世纪的森林时，他们会拖着一条鱼（红鲱鱼）穿过小路，以迷惑庄园领主的猎犬。

“Red herrings” has an amusing etymology: As peasant poachers of deer and grouse made off with their booty through medieval forests, they would drag a fish, a red herring, across the trail to confuse the lord of the manor’s bloodhounds.

这种通过设置干扰线索和嫌疑犯、通过制造混乱和好奇心来引发猜谜游戏以引起人们兴趣的技巧，只取悦了一种类型的观众，那就是谋杀悬疑小说，该类型小说又包括两种子类型，即封闭式悬疑小说和开放式悬疑小说。

This technique of compelling interest by devising a guessing game of red herrings and suspects, of confusion and curiosity, pleases the audience of one and only one genre, the Murder Mystery, which has two subgenres, the Closed Mystery and the Open Mystery.

封闭式悬疑是阿加莎·克里斯蒂的写作风格，其中谋杀案发生在幕后故事中却不为人知。“谁干的？”的主要惯例是多个嫌疑人。作家必须发展出至少三个可能的凶手，不断误导观众怀疑错误的人，即转移注意力的线索，同时将真正的凶手身份隐瞒到高潮。

The Closed Mystery is the Agatha Christie form in which a murder is committed unseen in the Backstory. The primary convention of the “Who done it?” is multiple suspects. The writer must develop at least three possible killers to constantly mislead the audience to suspect the wrong person, the red herring, while withholding the identity of the real killer to Climax.

《未解之谜》是《神探可伦坡》的版本，观众亲眼目睹了谋杀的发生，因此知道是谁干的。故事变成了“他将如何抓住他？”，因为作者用多个线​​索代替了多个嫌疑人。谋杀一定是精心策划的、看似完美的犯罪，是一个涉及多个步骤和技术要素的复杂计划。但观众通常知道这些要素之一是致命的逻辑缺陷。当侦探到达现场时，他本能地知道是谁干的，仔细检查众多线索，寻找明显的缺陷，发现它，并与傲慢的完美犯罪者对峙，后者随后自发认罪。

The Open Mystery is the Columbo form in which the audience sees the murder committed and therefore knows who did it. The story becomes a “How will he catch him?” as the writer substitutes multiple clues for multiple suspects. The murder must be an elaborate and seemingly perfect crime, a complex scheme involving a number of steps and technical elements. But the audience knows by convention that one of these elements is a fatal flaw of logic. When the detective arrives on the scene he instinctively knows who did it, sifts through the many clues searching for the telltale flaw, discovers it, and confronts the arrogant perfect-crime-committer, who then spontaneously confesses.

在悬疑小说中，凶手和侦探早在高潮之前就知道了事实，但却只字未提。观众从后面追赶，试图弄清楚主要人物已经知道了什么。当然，如果我们能赢得比赛，我们会觉得自己是失败者。我们努力猜测谁是谁或如何，但我们希望作者的侦探大师就是这样。

In the Mystery form the killer and detective know the facts long before Climax but keep it to themselves. The audience runs from behind trying to figure out what the key characters already know. Of course, if we could win the race, we’d feel like losers. We try hard to guess the who or how, but we want the writer’s master detective to be just that.

这两种纯粹的设计可以混合或讽刺。《唐人街》一开始是封闭的，但在第二幕高潮时却变成了开放的。《非常嫌疑犯》戏仿了封闭的谜团。它一开始是“谁干的？”，但变成了“没人干的”……不管“它”是什么。

These two pure designs may be mixed or satirized. CHINA-TOWN starts Closed but then turns Open at the Act Two Climax. THE USUAL SUSPECTS parodies the Closed Mystery. It starts as a “Who done it?” but becomes a “Nobody done it”… whatever “it” may be.

在悬疑剧中，观众和角色知道相同的信息。

In Suspense the audience and characters know the same information.

悬疑结合了好奇心和担忧。90% 的电影（喜剧和戏剧）都以这种模式吸引观众的兴趣。然而，在悬疑中，好奇心不是关于事实而是关于结果。谋杀悬疑的结局总是确定的。虽然我们不知道凶手是谁或如何，但侦探会抓住凶手，故事会以“好”结尾。但悬疑故事的结局可能是“好”的，也可能是“坏”的，也可能是讽刺的。

Suspense combines both Curiosity and Concern. Ninety percent of all films, comedy and drama, compel interest in this mode. In Suspense, however, curiosity is not about fact but outcome. The outcome of a Murder Mystery is always certain. Although we don’t know who or how, the detective will catch the killer and the story will end “up.” But the Suspense story could end “up” or “down” or in irony.

人物和观众在故事讲述过程中并肩前行，分享相同的知识。当人物发现说明性事实时，观众也会发现。但没有人知道“结果会如何？”在这种关系中，我们会感到同情并认同主角，而在纯粹的悬疑故事中，我们的参与仅限于同情。侦探大师很有魅力，很讨人喜欢，但我们从不认同他们，因为他们太完美了，而且从未真正处于危险之中。谋杀悬疑就像棋盘游戏，是头脑的酷炫娱乐。

Characters and audience move shoulder to shoulder through the telling, sharing the same knowledge. As the characters discover expositional fact, the audience discovers it. But what no one knows is “How will this turn out?” In this relationship we feel empathy and identify with the protagonist, whereas in pure Mystery our involvement is limited to sympathy. Master detectives are charming and likable, but we never identify with them because they’re too perfect and never in real jeopardy. Murder Mysteries are like board games, cool entertainments for the mind.

在戏剧性讽刺中，观众比角色知道的更多。

In Dramatic Irony the audience knows more than the characters.

戏剧性反讽主要通过关注来引起人们的兴趣，消除了人们对事实和后果的好奇心。这类故事通常以结局开场，故意透露结果。当观众被赋予在事件发生前就知道事件的神一般的优越感时，他们的情感体验就会发生转变。在悬念中，对结果的焦虑和对主人公福祉的恐惧，在戏剧性反讽中变成了对角色发现我们已经知道的事情的那一刻的恐惧，以及对我们看到的正在走向灾难的人的同情。

Dramatic Irony creates interest primarily through concern alone, eliminating curiosity about fact and consequence. Such stories often open with the ending, deliberately giving away the outcome. When the audience is given the godlike superiority of knowing events before they happen, its emotional experience switches. What in Suspense would be anxiety about outcome and fear for the protagonist’s well-being, in Dramatic Irony becomes dread of the moment the character discovers what we already know and compassion for someone we see heading for disaster.

日落大道：第一个场景中，乔·吉利斯（威廉·霍尔登饰）的尸体面朝下漂浮在诺玛·戴斯蒙（格洛丽亚·斯旺森饰）的游泳池里。镜头移到泳池底部，仰视尸体，画外音中吉利斯沉思道，我们可能想知道他为什么会死在游泳池里，所以他会告诉我们。这部电影变成了一部长篇倒叙，戏剧化地展现了一位编剧为成功而奋斗的过程。当我们看到这个可怜的人走向我们已经知道的命运时，我们既同情又恐惧。我们意识到，吉利斯为摆脱富有的泼妇的魔爪和写出诚实的剧本所做的所有努力都将化为泡影，他最终会成为她游泳池里的一具尸体。

SUNSET BOULEVARD: In the first sequence the body of Joe Gillis (William Holden) floats facedown in Norma Desmond’s (Gloria Swanson) swimming pool. The camera goes to the bottom of the pool, looks up at the corpse, and in voice-over Gillis muses that we’re probably wondering how he ended up dead in a swimming pool, so he’ll tell us. The film becomes a feature-length flashback, dramatizing a screenwriter’s struggle for success. We’re moved to compassion and dread as we watch this poor man heading toward a fate we already know. We realize that all of Gillis’s efforts to escape the clutches of a wealthy harridan and write an honest screenplay will come to nothing and he’ll end up a corpse in her swimming pool.

背叛：以从头到尾的倒叙方式讲述故事的反情节手法是 1934 年菲利普·考夫曼和莫斯·哈特在他们的戏剧《快乐前行》中发明的。四十年后，哈罗德·品特利用这个想法将戏剧性反讽发挥到了极致。《背叛》是一部爱情故事，开场是昔日恋人杰瑞和艾玛（杰瑞米·艾恩斯和帕特丽夏·霍奇饰演）分手多年后第一次私下会面。在紧张的时刻，她承认她的丈夫“知道”，她的丈夫是杰瑞最好的朋友。随着电影的推进，闪回到分手的场景，然后是导致分手的事件，再往前追溯到浪漫的黄金时代，最后以男孩遇见女孩结束。当年轻恋人的眼睛闪烁着期待的光芒时，我们心中五味杂陈：我们希望他们能够拥有一段恋情，因为这段恋情很甜蜜，但我们也知道他们将遭受所有的辛酸和痛苦。

BETRAYAL: The Antiplot device of telling a story in reverse order from end to beginning was invented in 1934 by Phillip Kaufman and Moss Hart for their play Merrily We Roll Along. Forty years later Harold Pinter used this idea to exploit the ultimate use of Dramatic Irony. BETRAYAL is a Love Story that opens with former lovers, Jerry and Emma (Jeremy Irons and Patricia Hodge) meeting privately for the first time in the years since their breakup. In a tense moment she confesses that her husband “knows,” her husband being Jerry’s best friend. As the film proceeds it flashes back to scenes of the breakup, then follows with the events that brought about the breakup, back farther to cover the golden days of the romance, then ends on boy-meets-girl. As the eyes of the young lovers glitter with anticipation, we’re filled with mixed emotions: We want them to have their affair, for it was sweet, but we also know all the bitterness and pain they’ll suffer.

让观众处于戏剧性反讽的位置并不能消除所有的好奇心。向观众展示将要发生的事情的结果是让他们问：“这些角色是如何以及为什么会做我已经知道的事情的？”戏剧性反讽鼓励观众更深入地了解角色生活中的动机和因果力量。这就是为什么我们经常在第二次观看一部好电影时更喜欢它，或者至少会有不同的感受。我们不仅会表达出经常被低估的同情和恐惧情绪，而且摆脱了对事实和结果的好奇心，我们现在专注于内心生活、潜意识能量和社会的微妙运作。

Placing the audience in the position of Dramatic Irony does not eliminate all curiosity. The result of showing the audience what will happen is to cause them to ask, “How and why did these characters do what I already know they did? Dramatic Irony encourages the audience to look more deeply into the motivations and causal forces at work in the characters’ lives. This is why we often enjoy a fine film more, or at least differently, on second viewing. We not only flex the often underused emotions of compassion and dread, but freed from curiosity about facts and outcome, we now concentrate on inner lives, unconscious energies, and the subtle workings of society.

然而，大多数类型的电影既不适合纯粹的悬疑，也不适合纯粹的戏剧性反讽。相反，在悬疑关系中，作家们通过混合其他两种手法来丰富故事情节。在整体悬疑设计中，一些情节可能采用悬疑来增加对某些事实的好奇心，而另一些情节则可能转而采用戏剧性反讽来触动观众的内心。

However, the majority of genres do not lend themselves to either pure Mystery or pure Dramatic Irony. Instead, within the Suspense relationship writers enrich the telling by mixing the other two. In an overall Suspense design, some sequences may employ Mystery to increase curiosity about certain facts, others may switch to Dramatic Irony to touch the audience’s heart.

《卡萨布兰卡》：在第一幕的结尾，我们得知里克和伊尔莎在巴黎有过一段恋情，最后以分手告终。第二幕以巴黎的闪回开场。从戏剧性讽刺的角度来看，我们看到这对年轻的恋人走向悲剧，并对他们浪漫的纯真感到特别的温柔。我们深入地观察他们在一起的时刻，想知道为什么他们的爱情以心碎告终，当他们发现我们已经知道的事情时，他们会作何反应。

CASABLANCA: At the end of Act One we learn that Rick and Ilsa had an affair in Paris that ended in breakup. Act Two opens with a flashback to Paris. From the vantage of Dramatic Irony, we watch the young lovers head for tragedy and feel a special tenderness for their romantic innocence. We look deeply into their moments together, wondering why their love ended in heartbreak and how they’ll react when they discover what we already know.

后来，在第二幕的高潮中，伊尔莎回到了里克的怀抱，准备离开丈夫去找他。第三幕转向神秘，展示里克做出危机决定，但没有让我们知道他选择做什么。因为里克比我们知道的更多，所以好奇心被激起了：他会和伊尔莎私奔吗？当答案出现时，我们大吃一惊。

Later, at the climax of Act Two, Ilsa is back in Rick’s arms, ready to leave her husband for him. Act Three switches to Mystery by showing Rick make his Crisis decision but not letting us in on what he’s chosen to do. Because Rick knows more than we, curiosity is piqued: Will he run off with Ilsa? When the answer arrives, it hits us with a jolt.

假设你正在写一部关于一个变态斧头杀人犯和一个女侦探的惊悚小说，你准备写故事高潮。你把故事背景设置在一座老宅邸昏暗的走廊里。她知道凶手就在附近，于是她一边慢慢地穿过左右两边的门，一边按下枪上的保险，一直延伸到黑暗的远方。应该使用这三种策略中的哪一种？

Suppose you were working on a Thriller about a psychopathic axe murderer and a female detective, and you’re ready to write the Story Climax. You’ve set it in the dimly lit corridor of an old mansion. She knows the killer is near and clicks the safety off her gun as she moves slowly past doors left and right extending into the dark distance. Which of the three strategies to use?

神秘：向观众隐瞒反派所知的事实。

Mystery: Hide a fact known to the antagonist from the audience.

关上所有门，这样当她沿着走廊走时，观众的眼睛就会搜索屏幕，想知道，他在哪里？第一扇门后面？下一扇门？再下一扇？然后他冲破了……天花板发起攻击！

Close all the doors so that as she moves down the hall the audience’s eyes search the screen, wondering, Where is he? Behind the first door? The next door? The next? Then he attacks by crashing through… the ceiling!

悬念：给予观众和角色相同的信息。

Suspense: Give the audience and characters the same information.

走廊尽头有一扇半开的门，门后有一盏灯，在墙上投下了一个拿着斧头的男人的影子。她看到影子，停了下来。影子从墙上退了回去。镜头切换到：门后，一个男人，手里拿着斧头，在等待：他知道她在那儿，他她知道他在那里，因为他听到了她的脚步声停了下来。镜头切换到：她犹豫的走廊：她知道他在那里，她知道他知道她知道他在那里，因为她看到他的影子在动。我们知道她知道他知道，但没人知道事情会如何发展？她会杀了他吗？还是他会杀了她？

At the end of the hall a door is ajar with a light behind it casting a shadow on the wall of a man holding an axe. She sees the shadow and stops. The shadow retreats from the wall. CUT TO: Behind the door a man, axe in hand, waits: He knows that she’s there and he knows that she knows that he’s there because he heard her footsteps stop. CUT TO: The hallway where she hesitates: She knows that he’s there and she knows that he knows that she knows that he’s there because she saw his shadow move. We know that she knows that he knows, but what no one knows is how will this turn out? Will she kill him? Or will he kill her?

戏剧性讽刺：采用希区柯克最喜欢的手法，向主角隐瞒观众已知的事实。

Dramatic Irony: Employ Hitchcock’s favorite device and hide from the protagonist a fact known to the audience.

她慢慢地向大厅尽头一扇关闭的门走去。

She slowly edges toward a closed door at the end of the hall.

镜头切换到：门后，一名男子手持斧头等待着。镜头切换到：走廊，她越来越接近那扇关闭的门。观众知道她不知道的事情，情绪从焦虑转为恐惧：“别靠近那扇门！看在上帝的份上，别打开那扇门！他在门后！小心！”

CUT TO: Behind the door a man waits, axe in hand. CUT TO: The hallway as she moves closer and closer to the closed door. The audience, knowing what she doesn’t know, switches its emotions from anxiety to dread: “Don’t go near that door! For God’s sake, don’t open that door! He’s behind the door! Look out!”

她打开门......一片混乱。

She opens the door and… mayhem.

另一方面，如果她打开门，拥抱这个男人……

On the other hand, if she were to open the door and embrace the man….

持斧男子

MAN WITH AXE

     （摩擦疼痛

     (rubbing sore

   肌肉

   muscles)

亲爱的，我一直在切

Honey, I’ve been chopping

整个下午都是木头。

wood all afternoon.

晚饭准备好了吗？

Is dinner ready?

...这不是戏剧性讽刺，而是虚假的神秘和其愚蠢的表亲“廉价惊喜”。

… this would not be Dramatic Irony, but False Mystery and its dim-witted cousin, Cheap Surprise.

一定程度的观众好奇心是必不可少的。没有它，叙事驱动力就会停滞不前。这种技巧让你有能力隐藏事实或结果，以便让观众向前看并提出问题。如果合适，它让你有能力迷惑观众。但你不能滥用这种权力。如果这样，观众会感到沮丧，不再看电影。相反，要用诚实、有见地的答案来奖励电影观众的专注。不要用肮脏的伎俩，不要用廉价的惊喜，不要用虚假的神秘。

A certain amount of audience curiosity is essential. Without it, Narrative Drive grinds to a halt. The craft gives you the power to conceal fact or outcome in order to keep the audience looking ahead and asking questions. It gives you the power to mystify the audience, if that’s appropriate. But you must not abuse this power. If so, the audience, in frustration, will tune out. Instead, reward the filmgoer for his concentration with honest, insightful answers to his questions. No dirty tricks, no Cheap Surprise, no False Mystery.

虚假的神秘是一种伪造的好奇心，它是由人为隐瞒事实而引起的。本来可以也应该向观众提供的内容被保留下来，以期引起观众对冗长、不具戏剧性的段落的兴趣。

False Mystery is a counterfeit curiosity caused by the artificial concealment of fact. Exposition that could and should have been given to the audience is withheld in hope of holding interest over long, undramatized passages.

淡入：一架载满乘客的飞机的飞行员正在与雷暴搏斗。闪电击中机翼，飞机坠向山腰。镜头切换到：六个月前，30 分钟的闪回，详尽地描述了致命航班前乘客和机组人员的生活。这个挑逗或悬念是作者做出的蹩脚承诺：“大家别担心，如果你们能坚持看完这段无聊的剧情，我最终会回到令人兴奋的部分。”

FADE IN: The pilot of a crowded airliner battles an electrical storm. Lightning strikes the wing and the plane plunges toward a mountainside. CUT TO: Six months earlier, and a thirty-minute flashback that tediously details the lives of the passengers and crew leading up to the fatal flight. This tease or cliff-hanger is a lame promise made by the writer: “Don’t worry, folks, if you stick with me through this boring stretch, I’ll eventually get back to the exciting stuff.”

意外问题

THE PROBLEM OF SURPRISE

我们向讲故事的人祈祷：“请让故事精彩。让我体验从未有过的感受，领悟全新的真理。让我对从未觉得好笑的事情发笑。让我被从未触动过的东西感动。让我以全新的视角看待世界。阿门。”换句话说，观众祈求的是惊喜，是期望的逆转。

We go to the storyteller with a prayer: “Please, let it be good. Let it give me an experience I’ve never had, insights into a fresh truth. Let me laugh at something I’ve never thought funny. Let me be moved by something that’s never touched me before. Let me see the world in a new way. Amen.” In other words, the audience prays for surprise, the reversal of expectation.

当角色出现在屏幕上时，观众会对他们抱有期待，觉得“这”会发生，“那”会发生改变，A 小姐会得到钱，B 先生会得到女孩，C 太太会受苦。如果观众期待的事情发生了，或者更糟的是，如果事情按照观众期待的方式发生，观众就会非常不高兴。我们必须让他们感到惊讶。

As characters arrive onscreen, the audience surrounds them with expectations, feeling “this” will happen, “that” will change, Miss A will get the money, Mr. B will get the girl, Mrs. C will suffer. If what the audience expects to happen happens, or worse, if it happens the way the audience expects it to happen, this will be a very unhappy audience. We must surprise them.

有两种惊喜：廉价的和真实的。真正的惊喜源自突然发现预期与结果之间的差距。这种惊喜是“真实的”，因为它会催生出洞察力，揭示出隐藏在虚构世界表面之下的真相。

There are two kinds of surprise: cheap and true. True surprise springs from the sudden revelation of the Gap between expectation and result. This surprise is “true” because it’s followed by a rush of insight, the revelation of a truth hidden beneath the surface of the fictional world.

《廉价惊喜》利用了观众的脆弱性。当观众坐在黑暗中时，他们的情绪就掌握在讲故事的人手中。我们总是可以通过突然切换到观众意想不到的场景，或者远离观众期望继续的场景来震惊观众。通过突然莫名其妙地打断叙事流程，我们总能让人们震惊。但正如亚里士多德所抱怨的那样，“即将行动而没有​​行动是最糟糕的。它令人震惊却不具有悲剧性。”

Cheap Surprise takes advantage of the audience’s vulnerability. As it sits in the dark, the audience places its emotions in the storyteller’s hands. We can always shock filmgoers by smash cutting to something it doesn’t expect to see or away from something it expects to continue. By suddenly and inexplicably breaking the narrative flow we can always jolt people. But as Aristoltle complained, “To be about to act and not to act is the worst. It is shocking without being tragic.”

在某些类型中——恐怖、奇幻、惊悚——廉价惊喜是一种惯例，也是乐趣的一部分：英雄走在一条黑暗的小巷里。一只手从屏幕边缘伸出来抓住他的肩膀，英雄转过身——这是他最好的朋友。然而，在这些类型之外，廉价惊喜是一种粗制滥造的手段。

In certain genres—Horror, Fantasy, Thriller—cheap surprise is a convention and part of the fun: The hero walks down a dark alley. A hand shoots in from the edge of the screen and grabs his shoulder, the hero spins around—and it’s his best friend. Outside these genres, however, cheap surprise is a shoddy device.

我最喜欢的季节：一个女人（凯瑟琳·德纳芙饰）结婚了，但并不幸福。她占有欲极强的哥哥不断搅乱妹妹的婚姻，直到最后她确信自己无法与丈夫幸福，于是离开并搬去和哥哥同住。兄妹俩住在一间顶楼公寓里。一天，他回家时感到不安。他一进门，就看到窗户开着，窗帘飘扬。他急忙往下看。从他的视角，我们看到他的妹妹倒在下面远处的鹅卵石上，死了，周围是一滩血。镜头切换到：卧室，他的妹妹从午睡中醒来。

MY FAVORITE SEASON: A woman (Catherine Deneuve) is married but not happily. Her possessive brother agitates his sister’s marriage, until finally convinced she cannot be happy with her husband, she leaves and moves in with her brother. Brother and sister share a top-floor apartment. He comes home one day feeling uncertain qualms. As he enters, he sees a window open, curtains billowing. He rushes to look down. In his POV we see his sister smashed on the cobbles far below, dead, surrounded by a pool of blood. CUT TO: The bedroom and his sister waking up from a nap.

为什么在一部严肃的家庭剧中，导演会借助兄弟俩神经质的想象来制造恐怖的震撼画面？也许是因为前三十分钟实在太无聊了，所以他认为是时候用他在电影学校学到的技巧来给我们一记重击了。

Why, in a serious Domestic Drama, would a director resort to horrific shock images from the brother’s nervous imagination? Perhaps because the previous thirty minutes were so unbearably boring, he thought it was time to kick us in the shins with a trick he learned in film school.

巧合问题

THE PROBLEM OF COINCIDENCE

故事创造了意义。巧合似乎是我们的敌人，因为它是宇宙中事物随机、荒谬的碰撞，从定义上讲，它毫无意义。然而巧合是生活的一部分，往往是强有力的一部分，它撼动着生活，然后像它出现时一样荒谬地消失。因此，解决办法不是避免巧合，而是戏剧化地展现它如何毫无意义地进入生活，但随着时间的推移获得意义，随机性的反逻辑如何成为生活的逻辑。

Story creates meaning. Coincidence, then, would seem our enemy, for it is the random, absurd collisions of things in the universe and is, by definition, meaningless. And yet coincidence is a part of life, often a powerful part, rocking existence, then vanishing as absurdly as it arrived. The solution, therefore, is not to avoid coincidence, but to dramatize how it may enter life meaninglessly, but in time gain meaning, how the antilogic of randomness becomes the logic of life-as-lived.

首先，尽早引入巧合，以便有时间从中构建意义。

First, bring coincidence in early to allow time to build meaning out of it.

《大白鲨》的煽动事件：一条鲨鱼偶然吃掉了一名游泳者。但故事中鲨鱼并没有离开。它留下来，不断威胁无辜者，并积累了意义直到我们感觉到这只野兽是故意这样做的，而且，它还乐在其中。这就是邪恶的定义：伤害他人并从中获取快感。我们都会无意中伤害他人，但会立即后悔。但当有人故意试图伤害他人并从中获取快感时，那就是邪恶。鲨鱼于是成为大自然黑暗面的强大象征，它很想把我们整个吞掉，并在吞噬过程中大笑。

The Inciting Incident of JAWS: a shark, by random chance, eats a swimmer. But once in the story the shark doesn’t leave. It stays and gathers meaning as it continuously menaces the innocent until we get the feeling that the beast is doing it on purpose and, what’s more, enjoying it. Which is the definition of evil: Doing harm to others and taking pleasure in it. We all hurt people inadvertently but instantly regret it. But when someone purposely seeks to cause pain in others and takes pleasure from it, that’s evil. The shark then becomes a powerful icon for the dark side of nature that would love to swallow us whole and laugh while doing it.

因此，巧合不能突然出现在故事​​中，成为故事的转折点，然后突然出现。例如：埃里克拼命寻找他疏远的恋人劳拉，但她已经搬走了。徒劳无功地寻找后，他停下来喝啤酒。他旁边的凳子上坐着卖给劳拉新房子的房地产经纪人。他给了埃里克她的确切地址。埃里克道谢后离开，再也没有见过推销员。并不是说这种巧合不可能发生，而是它毫无意义。

Coincidence, therefore, must not pop into a story, turn a scene, then pop out. Example: Eric desperately seeks his estranged lover, Laura, but she’s moved. After searching in vain, he stops for a beer. On the stool next to him sits the real estate agent who sold Laura her new house. He gives Eric her exact address. Eric leaves with thanks and never sees the salesman again. Not that this coincidence couldn’t happen, but it’s pointless.

另一方面，假设销售员不记得地址，但记得劳拉当时买了一辆红色的意大利跑车。两个男人一起离开，在街上发现了她的玛莎拉蒂。现在他们都走到了她的门口。劳拉仍然对埃里克生气，她邀请他们进来，并与销售员调情以惹恼她的前情人。原本毫无意义的好运现在变成了对抗埃里克欲望的力量。这个三角关系可以在故事的其余部分有意义地建立起来。

On the other hand, suppose that the salesman can’t remember the address, but does recall that Laura bought a red Italian sports car at the same time. The two men leave together and spot her Maserati on the street. Now they both go up to her door. Still angry with Eric, Laura invites them in and flirts with the salesman to annoy her ex-lover. What was meaningless good luck now becomes a force of antagonism to Eric’s desire. This triangle could build meaningfully through the rest of the story.

经验法则是，在故事叙述的中间部分之后不要使用巧合。相反，要让故事更多地掌握在人物的手中。

As a rule of thumb do not use coincidence beyond the midpoint of the telling. Rather, put the story more and more into the hands of the characters.

第二，永远不要用巧合来改变结局。这是天降神兵，也是作家最大的罪过。

Second, never use coincidence to turn an ending. This is deus ex machina, the writer’s greatest sin.

Deus ex machina是一个拉丁语短语，取自希腊和罗马的古典戏剧，意为“来自机器的神”。从公元前500 年到公元500 年，戏剧在整个地中海地区蓬勃发展。在这几个世纪里，数百名剧作家为这些舞台写过剧本，但只有七位被人们记住，其余的都被遗忘了，主要是因为他们倾向于使用 deus ex machina 来摆脱故事难题。亚里士多德抱怨这种做法听起来很像好莱坞制片人的想法：“这些作家为什么想不出可行的结局？”

Deus ex machina is a Latin phrase taken from the classical theatres of Greece and Rome, meaning “god from machine.” From 500 B.C. to A.D. 500 theatre flourished throughout the Mediterranean. Over those centuries hundreds of playwrights wrote for these stages but only seven have been remembered, the rest mercifully forgotten, due primarily to their propensity to use deus ex machina to get out of story problems. Aristotle complained about this practice, sounding much like a Hollywood producer: “Why can’t these writers come up with endings that work?”

在这些声学效果极佳的露天剧场中，有些剧场可容纳一万人，马蹄形舞台的远端是一堵高墙。底部有门或拱门，供出入。但扮演神的演员会站在系着绳索和滑轮的平台上，从墙顶降到舞台上。这种“机器中的神”装置是神灵从奥林匹斯山下来又回到奥林匹斯山的视觉比喻。

In these superb, acoustically perfect amphitheatres, some seating up to ten thousand people, at the far end of a horseshoeshaped stage was a high wall. At the bottom were doors or arches for entrances and exits. But actors who portrayed gods would be lowered down to the stage from the top of the wall standing on a platform attached to ropes and pulley. This “god from machine” device was the visual analogy of the deities coming down from Mount Olympus and going back up to Mount Olympus.

故事高潮在两千五百年前和现在一样难演。但古代剧作家有办法。他们会编造一个故事，扭曲转折点，直到让观众坐立不安，然后，如果剧作家的创造力枯竭，他找不到真正的高潮，传统允许他通过把神拉上舞台，让阿波罗或雅典娜解决一切来避开这个问题。谁活着，谁死去，谁和谁结婚，谁永远被诅咒。他们一遍又一遍地这样做。

Story climaxes were as difficult twenty-five hundred years ago as now. But ancient playwrights had a way out. They would cook a story, twist Turning Points until they had the audience on the edge of their marble seats, then if the playwright’s creativity dried up and he was lost for a true Climax, convention allowed him to dodge the problem by cranking a god to the stage and letting an Apollo or Athena settle everything. Who lives, who dies, who marries who, who is damned for eternity. And they did this over and over.

两千五百年来，什么都没变。如今的作家们仍然在编造无法结束的故事。但他们不是用神来结束故事，而是利用“天意”——《飓风》中拯救恋人的飓风，《大象漫步》中解决三角恋的大象踩踏事件，《邮差总按两次铃》和《生命中不能承受之轻》的交通事故，以及《侏罗纪公园》中及时跳出来吞噬迅猛龙的霸王龙。

Nothing has changed in twenty-five hundred years. Writers today still cook up stories they can’t end. But instead of dropping a god in to get an ending, they use “acts of god”—the hurricane that saves the lovers in HURRICANE, the elephant stampede that resolves the love triangle in ELEPHANT WALK, the traffic accidents that end THE POSTMAN ALWAYS RINGS TWICE and THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING, the T-Rex that hops in just in time to devour the velociraptors in JURASSIC PARK.

机械降神不仅抹去了所有的意义和情感，而且是对观众的侮辱。我们每个人都知道，无论好坏，我们都必须做出选择并采取行动，来决定我们生活的意义。无论我们周围有多么不公正和混乱，没有人或任何巧合会来取代我们的责任。你可能会因为没有犯下的罪行而被关在牢房里度过余生。但每天早上你仍然必须起床，创造意义。我是要用力撞墙，还是要找到某种方式来度过有意义的一天？我们的生命最终掌握在我们自己手中。机械降神是一种侮辱，因为它是一个谎言。

Deus ex machina not only erases all meaning and emotion, it’s an insult to the audience. Each of us knows we must choose and act, for better or worse, to determine the meaning of our lives. No one and nothing coincidental will come along to take that responsibility from us, regardless of the injustices and chaos around us. You could be locked in a cell for the rest of your life for a crime you did not commit. But every morning you would still have to get up and make meaning. Do I bludgeon my brains against this wall or do I find some way to get through my days with value? Our lives are ultimately in our own hands. Deus ex machina is an insult because it is a lie.

唯一的例外是反结构电影，它们用巧合代替因果关系：《周末》、《选择我》、《天堂陌生人》和《下班后》以巧合开始，以巧合发展，以巧合结束。当巧合主宰故事时，它创造了一个新的相当重要的意义：生活是荒谬的。

The one exception is Antistructure films that substitute coincidence for causality: WEEKEND, CHOOSE ME, STRANGERS IN PARADISE, and AFTER HOURS begin by coincidence, progress by coincidence, end on coincidence. When coincidence rules story, it creates a new and rather significant meaning: Life is absurd.

喜剧的问题

THE PROBLEM OF COMEDY

喜剧作家常常觉得，在他们狂野的世界里，指导戏剧家的原则并不适用。但无论是冷酷讽刺还是疯狂闹剧，喜剧都只是另一种讲故事的形式。然而，也有重要的例外，这源于喜剧和悲剧人生观之间的深刻分歧。

Comedy writers often feel that in their wild world the principles that guide the dramatist don’t apply. But whether coolly satiric or madly farcical, comedy is simply another form of storytelling. There are, however, important exceptions that begin in the deep division between the comic and tragic visions of life.

剧作家崇尚人性，创作的作品大意是：在最糟糕的情况下，人类精神是伟大的。喜剧指出，在最好的情况下，人类也会找到某种方式把事情搞砸。

The dramatist admires humanity and creates works that say, in essence: Under the worst of circumstances the human spirit is magnificent. Comedy points out that in the best of circumstances human beings find some way to screw up.

当我们窥视喜剧愤世嫉俗的笑脸面具背后时，我们发现了一个失意的理想主义者。喜剧感性希望世界完美，但当它环顾四周时，却发现贪婪、腐败、疯狂。结果是一个愤怒和沮丧的艺术家。如果你对此表示怀疑，请一位喜剧作家来吃晚饭。好莱坞的每一位主人都犯过这样的错误：“让我们邀请一些喜剧作家来参加聚会吧！这会让事情变得明亮起来。”当然……直到救护人员到来。

When we peek behind the grinning mask of comic cynicism, we find a frustrated idealist. The comic sensibility wants the world to be perfect, but when it looks around, it finds greed, corruption, lunacy. The result is an angry and depressed artist. If you doubt that, ask one over for dinner. Every host in Hollywood has made that mistake: “Let’s invite some comedy writers to the party! That’ll brighten things up.” Sure… till the paramedics arrive.

然而，这些愤怒的理想主义者知道，如果他们向世界宣讲这个世界是多么的腐烂，没有人会听。但如果他们贬低高贵的人，贬低势利的人，如果他们揭露社会的暴政、愚蠢和贪婪，让人们发笑，那么也许事情会改变。或者平衡。所以上帝保佑喜剧作家。没有他们，生活会是什么样子？

These angry idealists, however, know that if they lecture the world about what a rotten place it is, no one will listen. But if they trivialize the exalted, pull the trousers down on snobbery, if they expose society for its tyranny, folly, and greed, and get people to laugh, then maybe things will change. Or balance. So God bless comedy writers. What would life be like without them?

喜剧是纯粹的：如果观众笑了，它就成功了；如果它不笑，它就失败了。讨论结束。这就是评论家讨厌喜剧的原因；没什么可说的。如果我认为《公民凯恩》是一部浮夸的炫目奇观，充斥着刻板的人物，被操纵性的故事情节扭曲，充斥着自相矛盾的弗洛伊德和皮兰德尔式的陈词滥调，由一个为了给世界留下深刻印象而大手大脚的炫耀者制造，我们可能会永远争吵不休，因为《公民凯恩》的观众都沉默了。但如果我说《一条叫旺达的鱼》不好笑，你会可怜我，走开。在喜剧中，笑声可以平息所有争论。

Comedy is pure: If the audience laughs, it works: if it doesn’t laugh, it doesn’t work. End of discussion. That’s why critics hate comedy; there’s nothing to say. If I were to argue that CITIZEN KANE is a bloated exercise in razzle-dazzle spectacle, populated by stereotypical characters, twisted with manipulative storytelling, stuffed full of self-contradictory Freudian and Pirandellian clichés, made by a heavy-handed showoff out to impress the world, we might bicker forever because the CITIZEN KANE audience is silent. But if I were to say A FISH CALLED WANDA is not funny, you’ll pity me and walk away. In comedy laughter settles all arguments.

剧作家着迷于内心世界、激情与罪恶、人类内心的疯狂与梦想。但喜剧作家却并非如此。他专注于社会生活——社会中的愚蠢、傲慢与野蛮。喜剧作家挑出他认为已经充满虚伪与愚蠢的特定制度，然后进行攻击。我们通常可以通过电影的标题发现受到攻击的社会制度。

The dramatist is fascinated by the inner life, the passions and sins, madness and dreams of the human heart. But not the comedy writer. He fixes on the social life—the idiocy, arrogance, and brutality in society. The comedy writer singles out a particular institution that he feels has become encrusted with hypocrisy and folly, then goes on the attack. Often we can spot the social institution under assault by noting the film’s title.

《统治阶级》攻击富人；《颠倒乾坤》、《歌剧之夜》、《我的男人戈弗雷》也是如此。《陆军野战医院》攻击军队，《大兵本杰明》和《条纹》也是如此。浪漫喜剧——《女友星期五》、《伊芙小姐》、《当哈利遇到莎莉》——讽刺了求爱制度。《电视网络》、《警察学校》、《动物屋》、《摇滚万岁》、《荣誉普里兹》、《制片人》、《奇爱博士》、《讨厌的习惯》和《无处不在的夏令营》分别攻击电视、学校、兄弟会、摇滚乐、黑手党、剧院、冷战政治、天主教会和夏令营。如果一种电影类型充斥着自负，那么它也会被嘲笑：《空前绝后满天飞》、《新科学怪人》、《白头神探》。曾经被称为风俗喜剧的电影现在变成了情景喜剧——对中产阶级行为的讽刺。

THE RULING CLASS attacks the rich; so too TRADING PLACES, A NIGHT AT THE OPERA, MY MAN GODFREY. M*A*S*H assaults the military, as do PRIVATE BENJAMIN and STRIPES. Romantic Comedies—HIS GIRL FRIDAY, THE LADY EVE, WHEN HARRY MET SALLY—satirize the institution of courtship. NETWORK, POLICE ACADEMY, ANIMAL HOUSE, THIS IS SPINAL TAP, PRIZZI’S HONOR, THE PRODUCERS, DR. STRANGELOVE, NASTY HABITS, and CAMP NOWHERE strike at television, school, fraternities, rock ‘n’ roll, the mafia, the theatre, Cold War politics, the Catholic Church, and summer camp, respectively. If a film genre grows thick with self-importance, it too is ripe for mockery: AIRPLANE, YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN, NAKED GUN. What was known as Comedy of Manners has become the sitcom—a satire of middle-class behavior.

当一个社会不能嘲笑和批评其制度时，它就无法欢笑。有史以来最短的书是德国幽默史，这种文化曾遭受过对权威的恐惧。喜剧本质上是一种愤怒的、反社会的艺术。因此，要解决喜剧性弱的问题，作家首先要问：我为什么生气？他找到了社会中让他热血沸腾并发起攻击的那个方面。

When a society cannot ridicule and criticize its institutions, it cannot laugh. The shortest book ever written would be the history of German humor, a culture that has suffered spells of paralyzing fear of authority. Comedy is at heart an angry, antisocial art. To solve the problem of weak comedy, therefore, the writer first asks: What am I angry about? He finds that aspect of society that heats his blood and goes on an assault.

漫画设计

Comic Design

在戏剧中，观众不断抓住未来，努力让自己坚持下去，想知道结果。但喜剧允许作家停止叙事驱动力，即观众向前投射的思维，并在讲述中插入一个没有故事目的的场景。它只是为了搞笑。

In drama the audience continuously grabs handfuls of the future, pulling themselves through, wanting to know the outcome. But Comedy allows the writer to halt Narrative Drive, the forward projecting mind of the audience, and interpolate into the telling a scene with no story purpose. It’s there just for the yucks.

恐怖小店：受虐狂患者（比尔·默里饰演）拜访了虐待狂牙医（史蒂夫·马丁饰演），他蜷缩在椅子上说：“我想做一个漫长而缓慢的根管治疗。”这很有趣，但与故事无关。如果删掉，没人会注意到。但应该删掉吗？当然不，这太搞笑了。一部电影能讲多少故事，能融入多少纯粹的喜剧？看看马克斯兄弟。一个尖锐的故事，加上激励事件、第一幕、第二幕和第三幕的高潮，总是将马克斯兄弟的电影联系在一起……总放映时间约为十分钟。其余八十分钟则被马克斯兄弟令人眼花缭乱的天才表演所占据。

LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS: Masochistic patient (Bill Murray) visits sadistic dentist (Steve Martin), and as he cuddles up in the chair, says: “I want a long, slow root canal.” It’s drop-dead funny but has nothing to do with the story. If cut, no one would notice. But should it be cut? Hell no, it’s hysterical. How little story can be told and how much pure comedy worked into a film? Watch the Marx Brothers. A sharp story, complete with Inciting Incident, first, second, and third act climaxes, always holds a Marx Brothers film together… for a total screentime of about ten minutes. The other eighty minutes are surrendered to the dizzying genius of Marx Brothers shtick.

喜剧更能容忍巧合而不是戏剧性，甚至可以允许天降神兵的结局……只要做到以下两点：首先，让观众感觉到喜剧主角遭受了巨大的痛苦。其次，他从不绝望，从不失去希望。在这种情况下，观众可能会想：“哦，见鬼，就让他来吧。”

Comedy tolerates more coincidence than drama, and may even allow a deus ex machina ending… if two things are done: First, the audience is made to feel that the comic protagonist has suffered enormously. Second, that he never despairs, never loses hope. Under these conditions the audience may think: “Oh, hell, give it to him.”

淘金热：在高潮中，小家伙（查理·卓别林饰）差点被冻死，因为一场暴风雪把他的小屋掀离地面，把它和卓别林吹到阿拉斯加，然后把他扔到金矿上。镜头切换到：他很有钱，打扮得漂漂亮亮，抽着雪茄，正准备返回美国。一个喜剧巧合让观众不禁想，“这家伙吃了自己的鞋子，差点被其他矿工吃掉，被灰熊吞食，被舞厅女孩拒绝——他一路走到了阿拉斯加。饶了他吧。”

THE GOLD RUSH: At Climax the Little Chap (Charlie Chaplin) is nearly frozen to death when a blizzard rips his cabin off the ground, blows it and Chaplin across Alaska, then drops him smack on a gold mine. CUT TO: He’s rich, dressed to the nines, smoking a cigar, heading back to the States. A comic coincidence that leaves the audience thinking, “This guy ate his shoes, was almost cannibalized by other miners, devoured by a grizzly bear, rejected by the dance hall girls—he walked all the way to Alaska. Give ’im a break.”

喜剧与戏剧的显著区别在于：两者都以惊喜和洞察力来转变场景，但在喜剧中，当差距被拉开时，惊喜会引来当晚的哄堂大笑。

The incisive difference between comedy and drama is this: Both turn scenes with surprise and insight, but in comedy, when the Gap cracks open, the surprise explodes the great belly laughs of the night.

一条叫旺达的鱼：阿奇把旺达带到了一个借来的爱巢。旺达在睡觉的阁楼上气喘吁吁地看着阿奇在房间里旋转，脱光衣服，吟诵着让她心潮澎湃的俄罗斯诗歌。他把内裤套在头上，宣布自己不再害怕尴尬……门开了，一家人走了进来。期望和结果之间存在致命差距。

A FISH CALLED WANDA: Archie takes Wanda to a borrowed love nest. Panting with anticipation, she watches from the sleeping loft as Archie pirouettes around the room, stripping buck naked, intoning Russian poetry that makes her writhe. He puts his underwear on his head and declares himself free of the fear of embarrassment… the door opens and in walks an entire family. A killer Gap between expectation and result.

简而言之，喜剧是一个有趣的故事，一个精心设计的滚动笑话。虽然机智可以让讲述变得轻松，但仅凭这一点并不能使其成为真正的喜剧。相反，机智往往会创造出混合体，例如喜剧片（《安妮霍尔》）或罪案片（《致命武器》）。当你让一个无辜的受害者坐下并向他讲述你的故事时，你知道你写了一部真正的喜剧。只需告诉他发生了什么，而不需要引用机智的对话或视觉噱头，他就会笑。每次你转换场景，他都会笑；再次转换，他又会笑；转换，笑，直到你讲述的最后他倒在地上。这就是喜剧。如果你讲述你的故事而人们不笑，那么你写的不是喜剧。你写的是……别的东西。

Simply put, a Comedy is a funny story, an elaborate rolling joke. While wit lightens a telling, it doesn’t alone make it a true Comedy. Rather, wit often creates hybrids such as the Dramedy (ANNIE HALL), or the Crimedy (LETHAL WEAPON). You know you’ve written a true comedy when you sit an innocent victim down and pitch your story. Just tell him what happens, without quoting witty dialogue or sight gags, and he laughs. Every time you turn the scene, he laughs; turn it again and he laughs again; turn, laugh, until by the end of the pitch you have him collapsed on the floor. That’s a Comedy. If you pitch your story and people don’t laugh, you’ve not written a Comedy. You’ve written… something else.

然而，解决办法并不是想出巧妙的台词或恶搞别人。当喜剧结构需要时，搞笑自然而然就会出现。相反，要集中精力于转折点。对于每个动作，首先问“那是什么反面？”，然后再进一步问“那有什么不寻常的？”，在喜剧惊喜中穿插空白——写一个有趣的故事。

The solution, however, is not found in trying to devise clever lines or pie in the face. Gags come naturally when the comic structure calls for them. Instead, concentrate on Turning Points. For each action first ask, “What’s the opposite of that?” then take it a step farther to “What’s off-the-wall from that?” Spring gaps of comic surprise—write a funny story.

观点问题

THE PROBLEM OF POINT OF VIEW

对于编剧来说，视点有两层含义。首先，我们偶尔会要求使用 POV 镜头。例如：

For the screenwriter Point of View has two meanings. First, we occasionally call for POV shots. For example:

内部餐厅——白天

INT. DINING ROOM—DAY

杰克一边喝咖啡，一边突然听到一阵刺耳的刹车声和一阵震动整座房子的撞击声。他冲到窗边。

Jack sips coffee, when suddenly he hears a SCREECH OF BRAKES and a CRASH that shakes the house. He rushes to the window.

杰克的观点

JACK’S POV

窗外：托尼的汽车撞在车库门上，他的儿子摇摇晃晃地穿过草坪，醉醺醺地咯咯笑着。

out the window: Tony’s car crumpled against the garage door and his son staggering across the lawn, giggling drunk.

杰克

ON JACK

一怒之下打开窗户。

throwing open the window in a rage.

而第二层含义则适用于作家的视角。每个场景是从什么视角写的？整个故事又是从什么视角讲述的？

The second meaning, however, applies to the writer’s vision. From what Point of View is each scene written? From what Point of View is the story as a whole told?

场景中的 POV

POV WITHIN A SCENE

每个故事都发生在特定的时间和地点，然而，当我们想象一个个场景时，我们会把自己置于空间的哪个位置来观察这些动作？这就是视角——我们用来描述角色行为、他们彼此之间以及与环境之间的互动的物理角度。我们如何选择视角，对读者对场景的反应以及导演稍后如何安排和拍摄有着巨大的影响。

Each story is set in a specific time and place, yet scene by scene, as we imagine events, where do we locate ourselves in space to view the action? This is Point of View—the physical angle we take in order to describe the behavior of our characters, their interaction with one another and the environment. How we make our choices of Point of View has enormous influence on how the reader reacts to the scene and how the director will later stage and shoot it.

我们可以想象自己处于某个动作的 360 度范围内，或处于动作的中心，从 360 个不同的角度向外看——动作上方、下方、全球任何地方。每个视点的选择都会对同理心和情感产生不同的影响。

We can imagine ourselves anywhere 360 degrees around an action or at the center of the action looking out in 360 different degrees—high above the action, below it, anywhere globally. Each choice of POV has a different effect on empathy and emotion.

例如，继续上面的父子场景，杰克把托尼叫到窗边，两人争吵起来。父亲要求知道为什么一个在医学院的儿子喝醉了，并得知大学已经开除了他。托尼心烦意乱地走开了。杰克跑过房子来到街上安慰他的儿子。

For example, continuing the father/son scene above, Jack calls Tony to the window and they argue. The father demands to know why a son in medical school is drunk and learns that the university has expelled him. Tony wanders off, distraught. Jack races through the house to the street and consoles his son.

这一幕中有四种截然不同的视角选择：第一，将杰克完全置于你的想象中心。跟着他从桌子走到窗户，看看他看到了什么以及他对此的反应。然后跟着他穿过房子走到街上，他追着托尼拥抱他。第二，对托尼做同样的事情。当他开车上街、穿过草坪、冲进车库门时，完全跟着他。当他从残骸中跌跌撞撞地走出来，在窗边面对他的父亲时，展示他的反应。带他走到街上，然后突然把他变成他的父亲跑上去拥抱他。第三，在杰克的 POV 和托尼的 POV 之间交替。第四，采取中立的 POV。想象他们，就像喜剧作家那样，从远处看，从侧面看。

There are four distinctively different POV choices in this scene: One, put Jack exclusively at the center of your imagination. Follow him from table to window, seeing what he sees and his reactions to it. Then move with him through the house to the street as he chases after Tony to embrace him. Two, do the same with Tony. Stay with him exclusively as he weaves his car up the street, across the lawn, and into the garage door. Show his reactions when he stumbles out of the wreck to confront his father at the window. Take him down the street, then suddenly turn him as his father runs up to hug him. Three, alternate between Jack’s POV and Tony’s POV. Four, take a neutral POV. Imagine them, as a comedy writer might, at a distance and in profile.

第一个鼓励我们同情杰克，第二个要求我们同情托尼，第三个让我们与他们两人都亲近，第四个让我们两者都不亲近，并促使我们嘲笑​​他们。

This first encourages us to empathize with Jack, the second asks empathy for Tony, the third draws us close to both, the fourth with neither and prompts us to laugh at them.

故事中的视角

POV WITHIN THE STORY

如果在一部故事片的两个小时里，你能让观众与一个角色建立起一种复杂而又令人深感满意的关系，让他们终生难忘，那么你所做的就比大多数电影都要多。因此，一般来说，从主人公的角度来设计整个故事，可以增强叙事效果——让自己适应主人公，让他成为你想象世界的中心，把整个故事一个事件一个事件地呈现给主人公。观众只有在主人公遇到事件时才会见证事件。显然，这是讲故事的更困难的方式。

If in the two hours of a feature film you can bring audience members to a complex and deeply satisfying relationship with just one character, an understanding and involvement they will carry for a lifetime, you have done far more than most films. Generally, therefore, it enhances the telling to style the whole story from the protagonist’s Point of View—to discipline yourself to the protagonist, make him the center of your imaginative universe, and bring the whole story, event by event, to the protagonist. The audience witnesses events only as the protagonist encounters them. This, clearly, is the far more difficult way to tell story.

最简单的方法是穿越时空，收集零碎信息以方便阐述，但这会使故事变得冗长，失去张力。就像有限的设定、类型惯例和主旨思想一样，从主人公独特的视角塑造故事是一门创造性学科。它考验想象力，要求你尽最大努力。结果是紧凑、流畅、令人难忘的角色和故事。

The easy way is to hopscotch through time and space, picking up bits and pieces to facilitate exposition, but this makes story sprawl and lose tension. Like limited setting, genre convention, and Controlling Idea, shaping a story from the exclusive Point of View of the protagonist is a creative discipline. It taxes the imagination and demands your very best work. The result is a tight, smooth, memorable character and story.

与角色相处的时间越长，就越有机会见证他的选择。结果是观众与角色之间的共鸣和情感投入度更高。

The more time spent with a character, the more opportunity to witness his choices. The result is more empathy and emotional involvement between audience and character.

适应问题

THE PROBLEM OF ADAPTATION

改编的幻想是，通过选择文学作品，简单地将其转变为剧本。这种情况几乎从来不会发生。为了理解改编的困难，我们再次审视故事的复杂性。

The conceit of adaptation is that the hard work of story can be avoided by optioning a literary work and simply shifting it into a screenplay. That is almost never the case. To grasp the difficulties of adaptation we look again at story complexity.

在二十世纪，我们有三种讲述故事的媒介：散文（小说、中篇小说、短篇小说）、戏剧（正剧、音乐剧、歌剧、哑剧、芭蕾舞）和银幕（电影和电视）。每种媒介都通过让人物在生活的三个层面上同时发生冲突来讲述复杂的故事；然而，每种媒介在其中一个层面上都具有独特的力量和内在的美感。

In the twentieth century we now have three media for telling story: prose (novel, novella, short story), theatre (legit, musical, opera, mime, ballet), and screen (film and television). Each medium tells complex stories by bringing characters into simultaneous conflict on all three levels of life; however, each has a distinctive power and innate beauty at one of these levels.

小说的独特优势和奇妙之处在于将内心冲突戏剧化。这是散文最擅长的，远胜于戏剧或电影。无论是第一人称还是第三人称，小说家都以微妙、密集和诗意的意象将思想和情感融入其中，将内心冲突的骚动和激情投射到读者的想象中。在小说中，个人以外的冲突通过描述、文字描绘人物与社会或环境的斗争来描绘，而个人冲突则通过对话来塑造。

The unique strength and wonder of the novel is the dramatization of inner conflict. This is what prose does best, far better than play or film. Whether in first- or third-person, the novelist slips inside thought and feeling with subtlety, density, and poetic imagery to project onto the reader’s imagination the turmoil and passions of inner conflict. In the novel extra-personal conflict is delineated through description, word pictures of characters struggling with society or environment, while personal conflict is shaped through dialogue.

戏剧的独特魅力在于将个人冲突戏剧化。这是戏剧最擅长的，远胜于小说或电影。一部伟大的戏剧几乎是纯粹的对话，也许 80% 是用来听的，只有 20% 是用来看的。非语言交流——手势、眼神、做爱、打斗——很重要，但总的来说，个人冲突通过对话发展，无论是好是坏。更重要的是，剧作家拥有编剧所没有的权限——他可以用人类从未说过的方式写对话。他可以写的不仅仅是诗意的对话，而且像莎士比亚、TS 艾略特和克里斯托弗·弗莱一样，用诗歌本身作为对话，将个人冲突的表现力提升到令人难以置信的高度。此外，他还有演员的现场声音来添加阴影和停顿的细微差别，使其更上一层楼。

The unique command and grace of the theatre is the dramatization of personal conflict. This is what the theatre does best, far better than novel or film. A great play is almost pure dialogue, perhaps 80 percent is for the ear, only 20 percent for the eye. Nonverbal communication—gestures, looks, lovemaking, fighting—is important, but, by and large, personal conflicts evolve for better or worse through talk. What’s more, the playwright has a license screenwriters do not—he may write dialogue in a way no human being has ever spoken. He may write, not just poetic dialogue, but, like Shakespeare, T. S. Eliot, and Christopher Frye, use poetry itself as dialogue, lifting the expressivity of personal conflict to incredible heights. In addition, he has the live voice of the actor to add nuances of shading and pause that take it even higher.

在戏剧中，内心冲突通过潜台词来戏剧化。当演员从内心深处把角色演绎出来时，观众就能透过言行看到角色内心的想法和感受。就像第一人称小说一样，戏剧可以让角色独白，与观众亲密交谈。然而，在直接对话中，角色不一定在说实话，或者即使真诚，也无法理解他的内心生活并说出全部真相。戏剧通过不言而喻的潜台词来戏剧化内心冲突的能力是充足的，但与小说相比，它是有限的。舞台也可以戏剧化个人之外的冲突，但它能容纳多少社会？有多少布景和道具环境？

In the theatre inner conflict is dramatized through subtext. As the actor brings the character to life from the inside, the audience sees through the sayings and doings to the thoughts and feelings underneath. Like a first-person novel, the theatre can send a character to the apron in soliloquy to speak intimately with the audience. In direct address, however, the character isn’t necessarily telling the truth, or if sincere, isn’t able to understand his inner life and tell the whole truth. The theatre’s power to dramatize inner conflict through unspoken subtext is ample but, compared to the novel, limited. The stage can also dramatize extra-personal conflicts, but how much of society can it hold? How much environment of sets and props?

电影的独特力量和辉煌之处在于戏剧化地展现个人之外的冲突，展现出人类在社会和环境中奋力生存的巨大而生动的形象。这是电影最擅长的，比戏剧或小说更好。如果我们从《银翼杀手》中抽出一个画面，并要求世界上最优秀的散文作家创作出与其作品相当的文字，他会一页一页地写满文字，却永远无法捕捉到它的精髓。而这只是观众体验中流淌的数千个复杂图像中的一个。

The unique power and splendor of the cinema is the dramatization of extra-personal conflict, huge and vivid images of human beings wrapped inside their society and environment, striving with life. This is what film does best, better than play or novel. If we were to take a single frame from BLADE RUNNER and ask the world’s finest prose stylist to create the verbal equivalent of that composition, he would fill page after page with words and never capture its essence. And that is only one of thousands of complex images flowing through the experience of an audience.

评论家经常抱怨追逐片段，好像这是一种新现象。无声电影时代的第一个伟大发现就是追逐，它让查理·卓别林和基斯通警察、成千上万的西部片、DW 格里菲斯的大部分电影、《宾虚》、《战舰波将金号》、《亚洲风暴》和美丽的《日出》栩栩如生。追逐是被社会追赶的人，在物质世界中挣扎着逃脱和生存。这是纯粹的个人冲突，纯粹的电影，是人们用相机和剪辑机最自然的事情。

Critics often complain about chase sequences, as if they were a new phenomenon. The first great discovery of the Silent Era was the chase, enlivening Charlie Chaplin and the Keystone Cops, thousands of Westerns, most of D. W. Griffith’s films, BEN HUR, THE BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN, STORM OVER ASIA, and the beautiful SUNRISE. The chase is a human being pursued by society, struggling through the physical world to escape and survive. It’s pure extra-personal conflict, pure cinema, the most natural thing to want to do with a camera and editing machine.

为了表达个人冲突，编剧必须使用直白的对话。当我们在银幕上使用戏剧语言时，观众的正确反应是：“人们不会这样说话。”除了莎士比亚电影的特殊情况外，编剧要求自然主义的对话。然而，电影在非语言交流方面获得了巨大的力量。通过特写镜头、灯光和角度的细微差别，手势和面部表情变得非常有说服力。尽管如此，编剧无法将个人冲突戏剧化到戏剧的诗意程度。

To express personal conflict the screenwriter must use plain-spoken dialogue. When we use theatrical language on screen the audience’s rightful reaction is: “People don’t talk like that.” Other than the special case of filmed Shakespeare, screenwriting demands naturalistic talk. Film, however, gains great power in nonverbal communication. With close-up, lighting, and nuances of angle, gestures and facial expressions become very eloquent. Nonetheless, the screenwriter cannot dramatize personal conflict to the poetic fullness of the theatre.

银幕上内心冲突的戏剧化完全是潜台词，因为镜头透过演员的面部看到演员内心的想法和感受。即使是《安妮霍尔》中直接面对镜头的个人叙述，或者《阿玛迪斯》中萨列里的忏悔，都是层层递进的潜台词。电影可以把内心世界表达得淋漓尽致，但却达不到小说的密度和复杂性。

The dramatization of inner conflict on screen is exclusively in the subtext as the camera looks through the face of the actor to thoughts and feelings within. Even the personal direct-to-camera narration in ANNIE HALL or Salieri’s confession in AMADEUS is layered with subtext. The inner life can be expressed impressively in film, but it cannot reach the density or complexity of a novel.

这就是现实情况。现在想象一下改编的问题。几十年来，人们花费了数亿美元购买文学作品的电影版权，然后把这些作品扔到编剧的怀里，他们读完后就跑开，冲向深夜大喊：“什么都没发生！整本书都在角色的脑袋里！”

That is the lay of the land. Now imagine the problems of adaptation. Over the decades hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent to option the film rights to literary works that are then tossed into the laps of screenwriters who read them and go running, screaming into the night, “Nothing’s happens! The whole book is in the character’s head!”

所以改编第一原则：小说越纯粹，戏剧越纯粹，电影越差劲。

Therefore, the first principle of adaptation: The purer the novel, the purer the play, the worse the film.

“文学的纯粹性”并不意味着文学成就。小说的纯粹性意味着讲述方式完全定位在内心冲突的层面，使用语言的复杂性来煽动、推进和达到故事的高潮，相对独立于个人、社会和环境力量：乔伊斯的《尤利西斯》。戏剧的纯粹性意味着讲述方式完全定位在个人冲突的层面，使用诗意的口语来煽动、推进和达到故事的高潮，相对独立于内心、社会和环境力量：艾略特的《鸡尾酒会》。

“Literary purity” does not mean literary achievement. Purity of novel means a telling located exclusively at the level of inner conflict, employing linguistic complexities to incite, advance, and climax story with relative independence of personal, social, and environmental forces: Joyce’s Ulysses. Purity of theatre means a telling located exclusively at the level of personal conflict, employing the spoken word in poetic excess to incite, advance, and climax story with relative independence of inner, social, and environmental forces: Eliot’s The Cocktail Party.

改编“纯”文学的尝试失败有两个原因：一是审美上的不可能。图像是前语言的；对于大师级小说家和剧作家的华丽语言中隐藏的冲突，不存在电影对等物甚至近似物。二是，当一个不太有天赋的人试图改编天才的作品时，哪种可能性更大？一个不太有天赋的人会上升到天才的水平，还是天才会被拖到改编者的水平？

Attempts to adapt “pure” literature fail for two reasons: One is aesthetic impossibility. Image is prelinguistic; no cinematic equivalences or even approximations exist for conflicts buried in the extravagant language of master novelists and playwrights. Two, when a lesser talent attempts to adapt genius, which is more likely? Will a lesser talent rise to the level of genius, or will genius be dragged down to the level of the adaptor?

世界的银幕上经常充斥着自命不凡的电影人，他们希望被视为费里尼或伯格曼的另一个人，但与费里尼和伯格曼不同，他们无法创作原创作品，因此他们手拿普鲁斯特或伍尔夫的作品，去同样自命不凡的资助机构，承诺将艺术带给大众。官僚们提供资金，政客们向选民祝贺他们将艺术带给大众，导演拿到薪水，电影在周末就消失了。

The world’s screens are frequently stained by pretentious filmmakers who wish to be regarded as another Fellini or Bergman, but unlike Fellini and Bergman cannot create original works, so they go to equally pretentious funding agencies with a copy of Proust or Woolf in hand, promising to bring art to the masses. The bureaucrats grant the money, politicians congratulate themselves to their constituents for bringing art to the masses, the director gets a paycheck, the film vanishes over a weekend.

如果你必须适应，那就从“纯”文学中走下来，寻找那些冲突分散在三个方面的故事。层次……重点放在个人之外。皮埃尔·布勒的《桂河大桥》不会与托马斯·曼和弗朗茨·卡夫卡一起在研究生研讨会上讲授，但这是一部优秀的作品，充满了由内心和个人冲突驱动的复杂人物，主要在个人之外的层面上进行戏剧化。因此，在我看来，卡尔·福尔曼的改编成为大卫·里恩最好的电影。

If you must adapt, come down a rung or two from “pure” literature and look for stories in which conflict is distributed on all three levels… with an emphasis at the extra-personal. Pierre Boulle’s The Bridge on the River Kwai won’t be taught alongside Thomas Mann and Franz Kafka in postgraduate seminars, but it’s an excellent work, populated with complex characters driven by inner and personal conflicts and dramatized primarily at extrapersonal level. Consequently, Carl Foreman’s adaptation became, in my judgment, David Lean’s finest film.

要改编，首先要反复阅读作品，但不要做笔记，直到你觉得融入了它的精神。在你与社会接触、读懂他们的表情、闻到他们的古龙水味道之前，不要做出选择或计划行动。就像你从头开始创作的故事一样，你必须获得神一般的知识，永远不要认为原作者已经完成了他的功课。完成后，将每个事件简化为一两句话的陈述，仅此而已。没有心理学，没有社会学。例如：“他走进屋子，以为会与妻子发生冲突，却发现一张纸条，告诉他妻子已经离开了他，去找另一个男人了。”

To adapt, first read the work over and over without taking notes until you feel infused with its spirit. Do not make choices or plan moves until you’ve rubbed shoulders with its society, read their faces, smelled their cologne. As with a story you’re creating from scratch, you must achieve a godlike knowledge and never assume that the original writer has done his homework. That done, reduce each event to a one- or two-sentence statement of what happens and no more. No psychology, no sociology. For example: “He walks into the house expecting a confrontation with his wife, but discovers a note telling him she’s left him for another man.”

完成后，通读事件并问自己：“这个故事讲得好吗？”然后做好准备，十有八九你会发现它讲得不好。仅仅因为一个作家把一部戏剧搬上舞台或把一部小说出版并不意味着他已经掌握了这门手艺。故事是我们所有人最难做的事情。许多小说家讲故事的能力很差，剧作家就更差了。或者你会发现它讲得很美，像钟表一样完美……但长达四百页，材料是电影的三倍，如果一个齿轮被拿掉，钟表就会停止报时。无论哪种情况，你的任务都不是改编，而是重新发明。

That done, read through the events and ask yourself, “Is this story well told?” Then brace yourself, for nine times out of ten you’ll discover it’s not. Just because a writer got a play to the stage or a novel into print doesn’t mean that he has mastered the craft. Story is the hardest thing we all do. Many novelists are weak storytellers, playwrights even weaker. Or you’ll discover that it’s beautifully told, a clockwork of perfection… but four hundred pages long, three times as much material as you can use for a film, and if a single cog is taken out, the clock stops telling time. In either case, your task will not be one of adaptation but of reinvention.

适应的第二个原则：愿意重新发明。

The second principle of adaptation: Be willing to reinvent.

用电影节奏讲述故事，同时保持原著的精神。重新创作：无论小说中事件的叙述顺序如何，都要按时间顺序从头到尾重新排列，就像传记一样。从这些开始，创建一个分步大纲，使用原著中有价值的设计，但可以自由地删减场景，并在必要时创建新场景。最重要的是，把精神的东西变成物质的东西。不要用不言自明的对话来填充人物的嘴巴，而是找到他们内心冲突的视觉表达。这是成功或失败取决于你。寻求一种既能表达原著精神又能保持电影节奏的设计，忽略批评者可能会说“但这部电影不像小说”的风险。

Tell the story in filmic rhythms while keeping the spirit of the original. To reinvent: No matter in what order the novel’s events were told, reorder them in time from first to last, as if they were biographies. From these create a step-outline, using, where valuable, designs from the original work, but feeling free to cut scenes and, if necessary, to create new ones. Most testing of all, turn what is mental into the physical. Don’t fill characters’ mouths with self-explanatory dialogue but find visual expression for their inner conflicts. This is where you’ll succeed or fail. Seek a design that expresses the spirit of the original yet stays within the rhythms of a film, ignoring the risk that critics may say, “But the film’s not like the novel.”

银幕美学通常要求对故事进行重新演绎，即使原作讲述得非常精彩，而且是一部故事片的规模。正如米洛斯·福尔曼在将《莫扎特传》从舞台剧改编成电影时告诉彼得·谢弗的：“你将不得不再生一个孩子。”结果，世界上现在有了同一个故事的两个优秀版本，每个版本都忠于其媒介。在为改编而苦苦挣扎时，请记住这一点：如果改编版本与原作大相径庭——《征服者佩利》、《危险关系》——但电影很精彩，评论家们就会沉默。但如果你对原作——《红字》、《虚荣的篝火》——进行大肆破坏，并且没有用同样优秀甚至更好的作品来代替它，那就躲开吧。

The aesthetics of the screen often demand reinvention of story, even when the original is superbly told and of feature-film size. As Milos Foreman told Peter Shaffer while adapting AMADEUS from stage to screen, “You’re going to have to give birth to your child a second time.” The result is that the world now has two excellent versions of the same story, each true to its medium. While struggling with an adaptation bear this in mind: If reinvention deviates radically from the original—PELLE THE CONQUEROR, DANGEROUS LIAISONS—but the film is excellent, critics fall silent. But if you butcher the original—THE SCARLET LETTER, THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES—and do not put a work as good or better in its place, duck.

要了解改编，可以研究露丝·普劳尔·贾布瓦拉的作品。在我看来，她是电影史上将小说改编成电影的最佳人选。她是出生在德国的波兰人，用英语写作。在重新塑造了自己的国籍后，她成为了电影改编大师。就像变色龙或催眠术师一样，她栖息在其他作家的色彩和精神中。阅读《四重奏》、《看得见风景的房间》、《波士顿人》，从每部小说中提取一个步骤大纲，然后一幕一幕地将你的作品与贾布瓦拉的作品进行比较。你会学到很多东西。请注意，她和导演詹姆斯·艾弗里将自己限制在社会小说家——让·里斯、EM·福斯特、亨利·詹姆斯——身上，因为他们知道主要的冲突将是超个人的，并且会吸引镜头。没有普鲁斯特，没有乔伊斯，没有卡夫卡。

To learn adaptation study the work of Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. She is, in my view, the finest adapter of novel to screen in film history. She’s a Pole born in Germany who writes in English. Having reinvented her nationality, she’s become the master reinventer for film. Like a chameleon or trance-medium, she inhabits the colors and spirit of other writers. Read Quartet, A Room with a View, The Bostonians, pull a step-outline from each novel, then scene by scene compare your work to Jhabvala. You’ll learn a lot. Notice that she and director James Ivory restrict themselves to the social novelists—Jean Rhys, E. M. Forster, Henry James—knowing that the primary conflicts will be extra-personal and camera attractive. No Proust, no Joyce, no Kafka.

尽管电影的自然表现力是超个人的，但它不应该限制我们。相反，伟大的电影制作人一直接受的挑战是从社会/环境冲突的图像开始，带领我们进入复杂的人际关系，从所说和所做的表面开始，引导我们感知内心生活、未说出口的、潜意识——逆流而上，在电影中实现剧作家和小说家最容易做到的事情。

Although the natural expressivity of cinema is extra-personal, it shouldn’t inhibit us. Rather, the challenge that great filmmakers have always accepted is to start with images of social/environmental conflict and lead us into the complexities of personal relationships, to begin on the surface of what’s said and done and guide us to a perception of the inner life, the unspoken, the unconscious—to swim upstream and achieve on film what the playwright and novelist do most easily.

同样，剧作家和小说家也一直明白，他们的挑战是在舞台上或纸上演绎电影所演绎的最好。福楼拜著名的电影风格早在电影出现之前就已形成。爱森斯坦说他通过阅读查尔斯·狄更斯的作品学会了剪辑电影。莎士比亚在时间和空间上的惊人流畅性表明了他对摄影机的渴望。伟大的讲故事者一直都知道“展示，而不是讲述”是终极的创作任务：以纯粹的戏剧性和视觉方式写作，展示自然人类行为的自然世界，表达生活的复杂性而不讲述。

By the same token, playwright and novelist have always understood that their challenge is to do on stage or page what film does best. Flaubert’s famous cinematic style was developed long before there was cinema. Eisenstein said he learned to cut film by reading Charles Dickens. Shakespeare’s stunning fluidity through time and space suggests an imagination hungry for a camera. Great storytellers have always known that “Show, don’t tell” is the ultimate creative task: to write in a purely dramatic and visual way, to show a natural world of natural human being behavior, to express the complexity of life without telling.

情节剧的问题

THE PROBLEM OF MELODRAMA

为了避免被指责“这个剧本太夸张了”，许多人避免写“大场面”，即充满激情、震撼人心的事件。相反，他们写一些极简主义的短篇故事，其中几乎没有任何情节发生，自以为很巧妙。这是愚蠢的。人类所做的任何事情本身都不是夸张的，人类有能力做任何事情。日报记录了从特蕾莎修女到萨达姆侯赛因的巨大自我牺牲和残忍、勇敢和懦弱、圣人和暴君的行为。你能想象到人类所做的一切，他们都已经做了，而且是以你无法想象的方式。这些都不是夸张的；这只是人性而已。

To avoid the accusation “This script is melodramatic,” many avoid writing “big scenes,” passionate, powerful events. Instead, they write minimalist sketches in which little if anything happens, thinking they’re subtle. This is folly. Nothing human beings do in and of itself is melodramatic, and human beings are capable of anything. Daily newspapers record acts of enormous self-sacrifice and cruelty, of daring and cowardliness, of saints and tyrants from Mother Teresa to Saddam Hussein. Anything you can imagine human beings doing, they have already done and in ways you cannot imagine. None of it is melodrama; it’s simply human.

情节剧不是过度表达的结果，而是动机不足的结果；不是写得太宏大，而是写得太缺乏欲望。事件的力量只能与其原因的总和一样大。如果我们不相信动机与行动相匹配，我们就会觉得一个场景是情节剧。从荷马到莎士比亚再到伯格曼，作家们都创造了没有人会称之为情节剧的爆炸性场景，因为他们知道如何激励角色。如果你能想象出高戏剧或喜剧，那就写吧，但要提升驱使你的角色的力量，使其等于或超过他们行动的极限，我们会拥抱你，因为你把我们带到了终点。

Melodrama is not the result of overexpression, but of under motivation; not writing too big, but writing with too little desire. The power of an event can only be as great as the sum total of its causes. We feel a scene is melodramatic if we cannot believe that motivation matches action. Writers from Homer to Shakespeare to Bergman have created explosive scenes no one would call melodrama because they knew how to motivate characters. If you can imagine high drama or comedy, write it, but lift the forces that drive your characters to equal or surpass the extremities of their actions and we’ll embrace you for taking us to the end of the line.

洞的问题

THE PROBLEM OF HOLES

“漏洞”是失去可信度的另一种方式。现在的故事不是缺乏动机，而是缺乏逻辑，缺少了动机链中的一环。因果关系。但就像巧合一样，漏洞也是生活的一部分。事情发生的原因往往无法解释。所以如果你写的是生活，你的叙述中可能会出现一两个漏洞。问题在于如何处理它。

A “hole” is another way to lose credibility. Rather than a lack of motivation, now the story lacks logic, a missing link in the chain of cause and effect. But like coincidence, holes are a part of life. Things often happen for reasons that cannot be explained. So if you’re writing about life, a hole or two may find its way into your telling. The problem is how to handle it.

如果你能建立不合逻辑的事件之间的联系并填补漏洞，那就这么做吧。然而，这种补救措施通常需要创建一个新的场景，而这个场景除了让周围的事物合乎逻辑之外没有任何目的，从而造成与漏洞一样令人讨厌的尴尬。

If you can forge a link between illogical events and close the hole, do so. This remedy, however, often requires the creation of a new scene that has no purpose other than making what’s around it logical, causing an awkwardness as annoying as the hole.

在这种情况下，你要问：他们会注意到吗？你知道这是一个逻辑上的跳跃，因为故事静止地放在你的桌子上，它的洞正盯着你。但在屏幕上，故事是随着时间流动的。当洞出现时，观众可能没有足够的信息来意识到刚刚发生的事情是不合逻辑的，或者它发生得太快，以至于没有被注意到。

In which case ask: Will they notice? You know it’s a jump in logic because the story sits still on your desk with its hole glaring up at you. But onscreen the story flows in time. As the hole arrives, the audience may not have sufficient information at that point to realize that what just happened isn’t logical or it may happen so quickly, it passes unnoticed.

唐人街：艾达·塞申斯（黛安·拉德饰）冒充伊芙琳·穆尔雷，雇佣 JJ 吉特斯调查霍利斯·穆尔雷的通奸行为。吉特斯发现疑似外遇后，真正的妻子带着律师出现并提起诉讼。吉特斯意识到有人想抓穆尔雷，但就在他伸出援手之前，穆尔雷被谋杀了。第二幕开始时，吉特斯接到艾达·塞申斯的电话，告诉他她不知道事情会导致谋杀，想让他知道她是无辜的。在这通电话中，她还给了吉特斯一个关于杀人动机的重要线索。然而，她的话是如此隐晦，他只是更加困惑。然而，后来，他将她的线索与他挖掘出的其他证据联系起来，认为自己知道是谁干的，为什么干的。

CHINATOWN: Ida Sessions (Diane Ladd) impersonates Evelyn Mulwray and hires J. J. Gittes to investigate Hollis Mulwray for adultery. After Gittes discovers what appears to be an affair, the real wife shows up with her lawyer and a lawsuit. Gittes realizes that someone is out to get Mulwray, but before he can help the man is murdered. Early in Act Two Gittes gets a phone call from Ida Sessions telling him that she had no idea that things would lead to murder and wants him to know she’s innocent. In this call she also gives Gittes a vital clue to the motivation for the killing. Her words, however, are so cryptic he’s only more confused. Later, however, he pieces her clue to other evidence he unearths and thinks he knows who did it and why.

在第三幕的开头，他发现艾达·塞申斯已经死了，并在她的钱包里发现了一张美国演员工会的名片。换句话说，艾达·塞申斯不可能知道她在电话里说了什么。她的线索是百万富翁商人和高级政府官员在全市范围内实施腐败的关键细节，他们永远不会告诉他们雇来冒充受害者妻子的女演员。但当她告诉吉特斯时，我们不知道艾达·塞申斯是谁，也不知道她知道什么或不知道什么。一个半小时后，当她被发现死亡时，我们没有看到漏洞，因为那时我们已经忘记了她说了什么。

Early in Act Three he finds Ida Sessions dead and in her wallet discovers a Screen Actors Guild card. In other words, Ida Sessions couldn’t possibly have known what she said over the phone. Her clue is a crucial detail of a citywide corruption run by millionaire businessmen and high government officials, something they would never have told the actress they hired to impersonate the victim’s wife. But when she tells Gittes, we have no idea who Ida Sessions is and what she could or could not know. When she’s found dead an hour and a half later, we don’t see the hole because by then we’ve forgotten what she said.

所以也许观众不会注意到。但也许会。然后呢？胆小的作家会试图用沙子盖住这些洞，希望观众不会注意到。其他作家勇敢地面对这个问题。他们把洞暴露给观众，然后否认它是一个洞。

So maybe the audience won’t notice. But maybe it will. Then what? Cowardly writers try to kick sand over such holes and hope the audience doesn’t notice. Other writers face this problem manfully. They expose the hole to the audience, then deny that it is a hole.

《卡萨布兰卡》：法拉利（西德尼·格林斯特里特饰）是终极资本家和骗子，除了钱什么都不做。然而，有一次法拉利帮助维克多·拉兹洛（保罗·亨雷德饰）找到了珍贵的通行证，却不求回报。这不符合他的性格，也不合逻辑。编剧知道这一点，于是给了法拉利这样一句台词：“我不知道我为什么要这么做，因为这不可能给我带来任何好处……”编剧没有掩盖这个漏洞，而是大胆地撒谎承认了这一点，说法拉利可能冲动地慷慨大方。观众知道我们经常会出于无法解释的原因做事。听到称赞，观众点点头，心想：“就连法拉利也不明白。好吧。继续拍电影吧。”

CASABLANCA: Ferrari (Sidney Greenstreet) is the ultimate capitalist and crook who never does anything except for money. Yet at one point Ferrari helps Victor Laszlo (Paul Henreid) find the precious letters of transit and wants nothing in return. That’s out of character, illogical. Knowing this, the writers gave Ferrari the line: “Why I’m doing this I don’t know because it can’t possibly profit me…” Rather than hiding the hole, the writers admitted it with the bold lie that Ferrari might be impulsively generous. The audience knows we often do things for reasons we can’t explain. Complimented, it nods, thinking, “Even Ferrari doesn’t get it. Fine. On with the film.”

终结者没有洞——它建在深渊之上：2029 年，机器人几乎消灭了人类，而人类的残余在约翰·康纳的带领下扭转了战争的局势。为了消灭敌人，机器人发明了一台时间机器，将终结者送回 1984 年，在约翰·康纳出生前杀死他的母亲。康纳夺取了他们的设备，并派一名年轻的军官里斯回去试图先摧毁终结者。他这样做是知道里斯不仅会救他的母亲，还会让她怀孕，因此他的副官就是他的父亲。什么？

THE TERMINATOR doesn’t have a hole—it’s built over an abyss: In 2029 robots have all but exterminated the human race, when the remnants of humanity, lead by John Connor, turn the tide of the war. To eliminate their enemy, the robots invent a time machine and send the Terminator back to 1984 to kill the mother of John Connor before he’s born. Connor captures their device and sends a young officer, Reese, back to try to destroy the Terminator first. He does this knowing that indeed Reese will not only save his mother but get her pregnant, and therefore his lieutenant is his father. What?

但詹姆斯·卡梅隆和盖尔·安妮·赫德理解叙事驱动力。他们知道，如果让两个来自未来的战士在洛杉矶街头爆炸，并让他们咆哮着追赶这个可怜的女人，观众就不会提出分析性的问题，他们可以一点一点地分析出他们的设置。但他们尊重观众的智力，也知道看完电影后，观众可能会边喝咖啡边想：“等一下……如果康纳知道瑞茜会……”等等，这些漏洞会吞噬观众的乐趣。所以他们写了这个结局场景。

But James Cameron and Gail Anne Hurd understand Narrative Drive. They knew that if they exploded two warriors from the future into the streets of Los Angeles and sent them roaring in pursuit of this poor woman, the audience wouldn’t be asking analytical questions, and bit by bit they could parse out their setup. But respecting the intelligence of the audience, they also knew that after the film over coffee the audience might think: “Wait a minute… if Connor knew Reese would…,” and so on, and the holes would swallow up the audience’s pleasure. So they wrote this resolution scene.

怀孕的莎拉·康纳前往墨西哥偏远山区，在那里生下儿子并抚养他，为他未来的任务做准备。在加油站，她向女儿口述回忆录她把尚未出生的英雄放到录音机里，然后说：“你知道，我的儿子，我不明白。如果你知道瑞茜将成为你的父亲……那为什么……？怎么做？这是否意味着这种情况会再次发生……一次又一次……？”然后她停顿了一下，说：“你知道，想到这件事你可能会发疯。”全世界的观众都想：“见鬼，她是对的。这并不重要。”他们高兴地把逻辑扔进了垃圾桶。

The pregnant Sarah Connor heads for the safety of remote mountains in Mexico, there to give birth and raise her son for his future mission. At a gas station she dictates memoirs to her unborn hero into a tape recorder and she says in effect: “You know, my son, I don’t get it. If you know that Reese will be your father… then why… ? How? And does that mean that this is going to happen again… and again… ?” Then she pauses and says, “You know, you could go crazy thinking about this.” And all over the world audiences thought: “Hell, she’s right. It’s not important.” With that they happily threw logic into the trash.

17

性格

17

CHARACTER

心灵蠕虫

THE MIND WORM

当我追溯自荷马以来二十八个世纪的故事演变时，我想省下一千年，从四世纪直接跳到文艺复兴时期，因为根据我本科历史课本上的内容，在黑暗时代，所有的思考都停止了，僧侣们在犹豫“有多少天使在针尖上跳舞？”这样的问题。带着怀疑的心情，我深入研究了一下，发现中世纪的知识分子生活实际上仍然蓬勃发展……但以诗意的密码进行。当这个比喻被破译时，研究人员发现，“有多少天使在针尖上跳舞？”不是形而上学，而是物理学。讨论的主题是原子结构：“多小才算小？”

As I traced the evolution of story through the twenty-eight centuries since Homer, I thought I’d save a thousand years and skip from the fourth century to the Renaissance because, according to my undergrad history text, during the Dark Ages all thinking stopped while monks dithered over such questions as “How many angels dance on the head of a pin?” Skeptical, I looked a little deeper and found that in fact intellectual life in the medieval epoch went on vigorously… but in poetic code. When the metaphor was deciphered, researchers discovered that “How many angels dance on the head of pin?” isn’t metaphysics, it’s physics. The topic under discussion is atomic structure: “How small is small?”

为了讨论心理学，中世纪学者们发明了另一种巧妙的构想：心灵蠕虫。假设一种生物有能力钻入大脑并完全了解一个人——梦想、恐惧、力量、弱点。假设这种心灵蠕虫还具有引发世界事件的能力。然后它可以创造一个与该人的独特天性相适应的特定事件，从而引发一场独一无二的冒险，一场迫使他发挥自己极限、活出最深刻和最充实生活的探索。无论是悲剧还是成就，这场探索都将完全揭示他的人性。

To discuss psychology, medieval scholarship devised another ingenious conceit: the Mind Worm. Suppose a creature had the power to burrow into the brain and come to know an individual completely—dreams, fears, strength, weakness. Suppose that this Mind Worm also had the power to cause events in the world. It could then create a specific happening geared to the unique nature of that person that would trigger a one-of-a-kind adventure, a quest that would force him to use himself to the limit, to live to his deepest and fullest. Whether a tragedy or fulfillment, this quest would reveal his humanity absolutely.

读到那段话，我不禁笑了起来，因为作者是个思维蠕虫。我们也会深入人物内心，发现他的方方面面，他的潜力，然后创建一个符合他独特天性的事件——激励事件。对于每个主角来说，情况都不同——一个主角可能找到了财富，另一个主角则失去了财富——但我们设计的事件符合角色，正是这个事件让他踏上了探索的旅程，达到了他存在的极限。就像心灵蠕虫一样，我们探索人性的本质，用诗意的密码表达出来。因为几个世纪过去了，我们内心什么都没有改变。正如威廉·福克纳所观察到的，人性是唯一不会过时的话题。

Reading that I had to smile, for the writer is a Mind Worm. We too burrow into a character to discover his aspects, his potential, then create an event geared to his unique nature—the Inciting Incident. For each protagonist it’s different—for one perhaps finding a fortune, for another losing a fortune—but we design the event to fit the character, the precise happening needed to send him on a quest that reaches the limits of his being. Like the Mind Worm, we explore the inscape of human nature, expressed in poetic code. For as centuries pass, nothing changes within us. As William Faulkner observed, human nature is the only subject that doesn’t date.

角色不是人类

Characters Are Not Human Beings

角色不是人，就像米洛的维纳斯不是真实的女人一样。角色是一件艺术品，是人性的隐喻。我们与角色的关系就像他们是真实的一样，但他们比现实更优越。他们的各个方面被设计得清晰可知；而我们的人类同胞则难以理解，甚至难以捉摸。我们对角色的了解比对朋友的了解要多，因为角色是永恒不变的，而人是会变的——就在我们以为我们了解他们的时候，其实我们并没有了解他们。事实上，我对《卡萨布兰卡》中的里克·布莱恩的了解比我自己还要多。里克永远是里克。我有点不确定。

A character is no more a human being than the Venus de Milo is a real woman. A character is a work of art, a metaphor for human nature. We relate to characters as if they were real, but they’re superior to reality. Their aspects are designed to be clear and knowable; whereas our fellow humans are difficult to understand, if not enigmatic. We know characters better than we know our friends because a character is eternal and unchanging, while people shift—just when we think we understand them, we don’t. In fact, I know Rick Blaine in CASABLANCA better than I know myself. Rick is always Rick. I’m a bit iffy.

角色设计始于两个主要方面的安排：性格塑造和真实性格。重复一遍：性格塑造是所有可观察到的品质的总和，是使角色独一无二的组合：外貌加上举止、说话和手势风格、性取向、年龄、智商、职业、个性、态度、价值观、居住地、生活方式。真实性格隐藏在面具后面。尽管有性格塑造，但这个人的内心是谁？忠诚还是不忠诚？诚实还是撒谎？有爱心还是残忍？勇敢还是懦弱？慷慨还是自私？任性还是软弱？

Character design begins with an arrangement of the two primary aspects: Characterization and True Character. To repeat: Characterization is the sum of all the observable qualities, a combination that makes the character unique: physical appearance coupled with mannerisms, style of speech and gesture, sexuality, age, IQ, occupation, personality, attitudes, values, where he lives, how he lives. True Character waits behind this mask. Despite his characterization, at heart who is this person? Loyal or disloyal? Honest or a liar? Loving or cruel? Courageous or cowardly? Generous or selfish? Willful or weak?

真正的性格只能通过困境中的选择来展现。一个人在压力下选择如何行动，就是他的性格——压力越大，性格的选择就越真实、越深刻。

TRUE CHARACTER can only be expressed through choice in dilemma. How the person chooses to act under pressure is who he is—the greater the pressure, the truer and deeper the choice to character.

真实性格的关键在于欲望。在生活中，如果我们感到压抑，最快的解脱方式就是问自己：“我想要什么？”，倾听诚实的回答，然后找到追求欲望的意志。问题仍然存在，但现在我们已经开始行动，有机会解决它们。生活中的真相也适用于小说。当我们清楚地了解一个角色的欲望时，他就会活灵活现——不仅是有意识的欲望，而且在复杂的角色中，还有潜意识的欲望。

The key to True Character is desire. In life, if we feel stifled, the fastest way to get unstuck is to ask, “What do I want?,” listen to the honest answer, then find the will to pursue that desire. Problems still remain, but now we’re in motion with the chance of solving them. What’s true of life is true of fiction. A character comes to life the moment we glimpse a clear understanding of his desire—not only the conscious, but in a complex role, the unconscious desire as well.

问：这个角色想要什么？现在？很快？总体上？有意？无意？有了清晰、真实的答案，你就能掌控这个角色。

Ask: What does this character want? Now? Soon? Overall? Knowingly? Unknowingly? With clear, true answers comes your command of the role.

欲望背后是动机。你的角色为什么想要他想要的东西？你对动机有自己的想法，但如果别人有不同的看法，也不要感到惊讶。一个朋友可能会觉得父母的教养塑造了你角色的欲望；另一个人可能认为这是我们的物质主义文化；另一个人可能责怪学校制度；还有一个人可能声称这是基因决定的；还有一个人认为他被魔鬼附身了。当代态度倾向于对行为进行单一解释，而不是更可能出现的复杂力量。

Behind desire is motivation. Why does your character want what he wants? You have your ideas about motive, but don’t be surprised if others see it differently. A friend may feel that parental upbringing shaped your character’s desires; someone else may think it’s our materialist culture; another may blame the school system; yet another may claim it’s in the genes; still another thinks he’s possessed by the devil. Contemporary attitudes tend to favor mono-explanations for behavior, rather than the complexity of forces that’s more likely the case.

不要将人物简化为案例研究（虐待儿童事件是当下流行的陈词滥调），因为事实上，任何人的行为都没有明确的解释。通常，作者越是将动机归结为具体原因，他在观众心目中就越贬低人物。相反，要仔细思考动机，但同时要对动机留下一些神秘感，也许有点不合理，让观众利用自己的生活经历在想象中强化你的人物。

Do not reduce characters to case studies (an episode of child abuse is the cliché in vogue at the moment), for in truth there are no definitive explanations for anyone’s behavior. Generally, the more the writer nails motivation to specific causes, the more he diminishes the character in the audience’s mind. Rather, think through to a solid understanding of motive, but at the same time leave some mystery around the whys, a touch of the irrational perhaps, room for the audience to use its own life experience to enhance your character in its imagination.

例如，在《李尔王》中，莎士比亚塑造了最复杂的反派之一埃德蒙。在一幕中，占星术的影响（又一个对行为的单一解释）被归咎于某人的不幸之后，埃德蒙转身自言自语并大笑道：“如果天空中最美丽的星星照耀着我的私生子，我本应是现在的样子。”埃德蒙做坏事纯粹是为了取乐。除此之外，还有什么重要的事情呢？正如亚里士多德所观察到的，为什么一个人会做坏事一旦我们看到他所做的事情，事情就没有什么意思了。性格就是他为采取什么行动而做出的选择。一旦事情做完，他做事的理由就开始变得无关紧要了。

In King Lear, for example, Shakespeare cast one of his most complex villains, Edmund. After a scene in which astrological influences, yet another mono-explanation of behavior, are blamed for someone’s misfortune, Edmund turns in soliloquy and laughs, “I should have been what I am had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardy.” Edmund does evil for the pure pleasure of it. Beyond that, what matters? As Aristotle observed, why a man does a thing is of little interest once we see the thing he does. A character is the choices he makes to take the actions he takes. Once the deed is done his reasons why begin to dissolve into irrelevancy.

观众会通过各种方式了解你的角色：外貌和背景能说明很多问题，但观众知道外表不是现实，人物塑造不是真正的人物。尽管如此，角色的面具是揭示真相的重要线索。

The audience comes to understand your character in a variety of ways: The physical image and setting say a lot, but the audience knows that appearance is not reality, characterization is not true character. Nonetheless, a character’s mask is an important clue to what may be revealed.

其他角色对某个角色的评价是一种暗示。我们知道，考虑到人们的动机，一个人对另一个人说的话可能是真的，也可能不是真的，但说这话的人是谁，这是值得了解的。一个角色对自己的评价可能是真的，也可能不是真的。我们听了，然后把它记在心里。

What other characters say about a character is a hint. We know that what one person says of another may or may not be true, given the axes people have to grind, but that it’s said and by whom is worth knowing. What a character says about himself may or may not be true. We listen, but then put it in our pockets.

事实上，那些自我认知清晰的人物，那些通过背诵自我解释的对话来让我们相信他们就是他们所说的那个人，不仅无聊而且虚伪。观众知道，人们很少，甚至从来没有理解过自己，即使他们理解了，他们也无法完整而诚实地自我解释。总是有一个潜台词。如果一个角色对自己的描述碰巧是真的，我们不知道那是真的，直到我们亲眼目睹他在压力下做出的选择。自我解释必须在行动中得到证实或反驳。在《卡萨布兰卡》中，当里克说“我不为任何人冒险”时，我们会想，“好吧，里克，现在还不行。”我们比里克更了解他自己，因为他确实错了；他会冒险很多次。

In fact, characters with lucid self-knowledge, those reciting self-explanatory dialogue meant to convince us that they are who they say they are, are not only boring but phony. The audience knows that people rarely, if ever, understand themselves, and if they do, they’re incapable of complete and honest self-explanation. There’s always a subtext. If, by chance, what a character says about himself is actually true, we don’t know it’s true until we witness his choices made under pressure. Self-explanation must be validated or contradicted in action. In CASABLANCA when Rick says, “I stick my neck out for no man,” we think, “Well, not yet, Rick, not yet.” We know Rick better than he knows himself, for indeed he’s wrong; he’ll stick his neck out many times.

角色维度

Character Dimension

“维度”是角色中最难理解的概念。当我还是一名演员时，导演们会坚持塑造“圆润、立体的角色”，我对此非常赞同，但当我问他们维度到底是什么，如何创造一个维度，更不用说三个维度时，他们会支支吾吾，嘟囔着说些排练之类的话，然后走开。

“Dimension” is the least understood concept in character.
