When I was an actor, directors would insist on “round, three-dimensional characters,” and I was all for that, but when I asked them what exactly is a dimension and how do I create one, let alone three, they’d waffle, mumble something about rehearsal, then stroll away.

几年前，一位制片人向我推荐了一部他认为“三维”的主角：“杰西刚从监狱出来，但在监狱里，他学习了金融知识和投资，所以他是股票、债券和证券方面的专家。他还会跳霹雳舞。他拥有空手道黑带，吹得一手好爵士萨克斯。”他的“杰西”像桌面一样平淡无奇——一堆性格特征都粘在名字上。用怪癖来装饰主角并不能打开他的性格并引起同情。相反，怪癖可能会让他封闭自己，让我们保持距离。

Some years ago a producer pitched me what he believed to be a “three-dimensional” protagonist in these terms: “Jessie just got out of prison, but while he was in the slammer he boned up on finance and investment, so he’s an expert on stocks, bonds, and securities. He can also break dance. He’s got a black belt in karate and plays a mean jazz saxophone.” His “Jessie” was as flat as a desktop—a cluster of traits stuck on a name. Decorating a protagonist with quirks does not open his character and draw empathy. Rather, eccentricities may close him off and keep us at a distance.

一个广受欢迎的学术信条认为，优秀的人物都有一个显著的特征。麦克白的野心经常被提及。有人声称，正是雄心壮志成就了麦克白的伟大。这个理论完全错误。如果麦克白只是野心勃勃，那这部戏就没戏了。他只需打败英国人，统治苏格兰即可。麦克白是一个出色的人物，因为他一方面有野心，另一方面又有罪疚感。从这种深刻的内心矛盾中，涌现出他的激情、他的复杂性和他的诗意。

A favorite academic tenet argues that, instead, fine characters are marked by one dominant trait. Macbeth’s ambition is frequently cited. Overweening ambition, it’s claimed, makes Macbeth great. This theory is dead wrong. If Macbeth were merely ambitious, there’d be no play. He’d simply defeat the English and rule Scotland. Macbeth is a brilliantly realized character because of the contradiction between his ambition on one hand and his guilt on the other. From this profound inner contradiction springs his passion, his complexity, his poetry.

维度意味着矛盾：要么是深层人物内部矛盾（充满负罪感的野心），要么是人物塑造与深层人物之间矛盾（迷人的小偷）。这些矛盾必须保持一致。在整部电影中把一个人描绘得非常好，然后在一个场景中让他踢了一只猫，这并不能增加维度。

Dimension means contradiction: either within deep character (guilt-ridden ambition) or between characterization and deep character (a charming thief). These contradictions must be consistent. It doesn’t add dimension to portray a guy as nice throughout a film, then in one scene have him kick a cat.

以哈姆雷特为例，他是有史以来最复杂的人物。哈姆雷特不是三维的，而是十维、十二维，几乎数不胜数。他似乎很神圣，直到他亵渎神明。对奥菲莉亚来说，他起初是慈爱温柔的，然后是冷酷无情的，甚至是虐待狂。他勇敢，然后懦弱。有时他冷静谨慎，然后冲动鲁莽，因为他会刺伤躲在窗帘后面却不知道是谁的人。哈姆雷特冷酷而富有同情心，骄傲而自怜，诙谐而悲伤，疲惫而充满活力，清醒而困惑，理智而疯狂。他是一种天真的世俗，一种世俗的纯真，几乎与我们能想象到的所有人类品质都存在着矛盾。

Consider Hamlet, the most complex character ever written. Hamlet isn’t three-dimensional, but ten, twelve, virtually uncountably dimensional. He seems spiritual until he’s blasphemous. To Ophelia he’s first loving and tender, then callous, even sadistic. He’s courageous, then cowardly. At times he’s cool and cautious, then impulsive and rash, as he stabs someone hiding behind a curtain without knowing who’s there. Hamlet is ruthless and compassionate, proud and self-pitying, witty and sad, weary and dynamic, lucid and confused, sane and mad. His is an innocent worldliness, a worldly innocence, a living contradiction of almost any human qualities we could imagine.

维度令人着迷；自然或行为中的矛盾吸引着观众的注意力。因此，主角必须是演员阵容中最立体的角色，才能让观众将同理心集中在主角身上。否则，善良的中心就会偏离中心；虚构的世界就会分崩离析；观众就会失去平衡。

Dimensions fascinate; contradictions in nature or behavior rivet the audience’s concentration. Therefore, the protagonist must be the most dimensional character in the cast to focus empathy on the star role. If not, the Center of Good decenters; the fictional universe flies apart; the audience loses balance.

《银翼杀手》：营销策略让观众对哈里森·福特饰演的里克·德卡德产生共鸣，但一旦走进影院，观众们就会被复制人罗伊·巴蒂（鲁格尔·哈尔饰演）的更大维度所吸引。随着善良的中心转向反派，观众的情感困惑削弱了他们的热情，本应大获成功的电影变成了一部邪典电影。

BLADE RUNNER: Marketing positioned the audience to empathize with Harrison Ford’s Rick Deckard, but once in the theatre, filmgoers were drawn to the greater dimensionality of the replicant Roy Batty (Rutger Hauer). As the Center of Good shifted to the antagonist, the audience’s emotional confusion diminished its enthusiasm, and what should have been a huge success became a cult film.

铸造设计

Cast Design

从本质上讲，主角创造了其他角色。故事中所有其他角色首先是因为他们与主角的关系，以及他们各自如何帮助勾勒出主角复杂性格的各个方面。想象一个角色就像一个太阳系，主角是太阳，配角是围绕太阳的行星，配角是围绕行星的卫星——所有这些都被中心恒星的引力牵引着绕着轨道运行，每个人都在拉动其他人性格的潮流。

In essence, the protagonist creates the rest of the cast. All other characters are in a story first and foremost because of the relationship they strike to the protagonist and the way each helps to delineate the dimensions of the protagonist’s complex nature. Imagine a cast as a kind of solar system with the protagonist as the sun, supporting roles as planets around the sun, bit players as satellites around the planets—all held in orbit by the gravitational pull of the star at the center, each pulling at the tides of the others’ natures.

想想这个假设的主角：他有趣而乐观，然后又郁郁寡欢、愤世嫉俗；他富有同情心，然后又残忍；他无所畏惧，然后又胆小怕事。这个四维角色需要他周围的演员来描绘他的矛盾，他可以在不同的时间和地点对这些角色采取不同的行动和反应。这些配角必须使他更加完整，这样他的复杂性才既一致又可信。

Consider this hypothetical protagonist: He’s amusing and optimistic, then morose and cynical; he’s compassionate, then cruel; fearless, then fearful. This four-dimensional role needs a cast around him to delineate his contradictions, characters toward whom he can act and react in different ways at different times and places. These supporting characters must round him out so that his complexity is both consistent and credible.

例如，角色 A 激起了主人公的悲伤和愤世嫉俗，而角色 B 则展现了他机智、充满希望的一面。角色 C 激发了他充满爱和勇气的情感，而角色 D 则迫使他先是畏缩不前，然后愤怒地反击。角色 A、B、C 和 D 的创作和设计取决于主人公的需求。他们之所以成为他们，主要是为了通过行动和反应，使主角的复杂性清晰可信。

Character A, for example, provokes the protagonist’s sadness and cynicism, while Character B brings out his witty, hopeful side. Character C inspires his loving and courageous emotions, while Character D forces him first to cower in fear, then to strike out in fury. The creation and design of characters A, B, C, and D is dictated by the needs of the protagonist. They are what they are principally to make clear and believable, through action and reaction, the complexity of the central role.

虽然配角必须从主角中缩减，但他们也可能很复杂。角色 A 可能是二维的：外表美丽而内心可爱/怪诞，因为压力下的选择揭示了冷酷、变异的欲望。甚至一个维度可以创造出一个出色的配角。B 角色可以像终结者一样，有一个单一而又迷人的矛盾：机器与人类。如果终结者只是一个机器人或一个来自未来的人，他可能就没什么意思了。但他是两者兼而有之，他的机器/人类维度造就了一个出色的反派。

Although supporting roles must be scaled back from the protagonist, they too may be complex. Character A could be two-dimensional: outwardly beautiful and loving/inwardly grotesque as choices under pressure reveal cold, mutated desires. Even one dimension can create an excellent supporting role. Character B could, like the Terminator, have a single yet fascinating contradiction: machine versus human. If the Terminator were merely a robot or a man from the future, he might not be interesting. But he’s both, and his machine/human dimension makes a superb villain.

人物所处的物质世界和社会世界，例如其职业或邻里，是人物塑造的一个方面。因此，可以通过简单的对比来创造维度：将一个传统的人物置于异国情调的背景中，或将一个陌生、神秘的人物置于一个普通、朴实的社会中，会立即引起人们的兴趣。

The physical and social world in which a character is found, his or her profession or neighborhood, for example, is an aspect of characterization. Dimension, therefore, can be created by a simple counterpoint: Placing a conventional personality against an exotic background, or a strange, mysterious individual within an ordinary, down-to-earth society immediately generates interest.

配角应该刻意画得平淡……但不要枯燥。赋予每个角色新鲜出炉的特质，让角色在演员出场的那一刻值得扮演，但仅此而已。

Bit parts should be drawn deliberately flat… but not dull. Give each a freshly observed trait that makes the role worth playing for the moment the actor’s onscreen, but no more.

例如，假设你的主角是第一次来纽约，当她走出肯尼迪机场时，她迫不及待地想第一次搭乘纽约出租车司机。如何塑造这个角色？你会让他成为一个头戴棒球帽的哲学怪人吗？我希望不是。在过去的六十年里，每次我们在纽约电影中乘坐出租车时，他都会出现，那个古怪的纽约出租车司机。

For example, suppose your protagonist is visiting New York City for the first time, and as she steps out of Kennedy Airport, she can’t wait for her first ride with a New York taxi driver. How to write that role? Do you make him a philosophizing eccentric with a baseball cap sideways on his head? I hope not. For the last six decades every time we get in a cab in a New York movie, there he is, the kooky New York cab driver.

也许你创造了银幕上第一位沉默寡言的纽约出租车司机。她试图开始谈论纽约洋基队、尼克斯队、市长办公室等话题，但他只是整理了一下领带，开车走了。她瘫倒在地，这是她在纽约的第一次失望。

Perhaps you create the screen’s first silent New York cab driver. She tries to start New York conversations about the Yankees, the Knicks, the mayor’s office, but he just straightens his tie and drives on. She slumps back, her first New York disappointment.

另一方面，出租车司机是所有出租车司机中的佼佼者：一个声音沙哑但非常乐于助人的怪人，他给了她一次大城市生存的权威教程——如何把钱包带系在胸前，把狼牙棒罐放在哪里。然后他载她去布朗克斯，收了她一百五十美元，告诉她她在曼哈顿。他一开始很乐于助人，后来变成了一个偷窃的老鼠——这是人物塑造和深刻人物之间的矛盾。现在我们会在电影里到处寻找这个家伙，因为我们知道编剧不会在他们不会再使用的角色上加维度。如果这个出租车司机至少再不出现一次，我们会很生气。不要让小角色比必要的更有趣，从而引起虚假的期待。

On the other hand, the cab driver to end all cab drivers: a gravel-voiced but wonderfully obliging oddball who gives her a definitive tutorial in big-city survival—how to wear her purse strap across her chest, where to keep her mace can. Then he drives her to the Bronx, charges her a hundred and fifty bucks and tells her she’s in Manhattan. He comes on helpful, turns into a thieving rat—a contradiction between characterization and deep character. Now we’ll be looking all over the film for this guy because we know that writers don’t put dimensions in characters they’re not going to use again. If this cabby doesn’t show up at least once more, we’ll be very annoyed. Don’t cause false anticipation by making bit parts more interesting than necessary.

演员们围绕着主角展开。配角的灵感来自主角，旨在勾勒出主角的复杂维度。次要角色不仅需要主角，还需要彼此，以展现他们的维度。由于三线角色（图中的 E 和 F）与主角或其他主角有场景，他们也有助于揭示维度。理想情况下，在每个场景中，每个角色都展现出标志着其他角色维度的品质，所有这些都由处于中心的主角的重量所支撑。

The cast orbits around the star, its protagonist. Supporting roles are inspired by the central character and designed to delineate his complex of dimensions. Secondary roles need not only the protagonists but also one another, to bring out their dimensions. As tertiary characters (E and F on the diagram) have scenes with the protagonist or other principals, they also help reveal dimensions. Ideally, in every scene each character brings out qualities that mark the dimensions of the others, all held in constellation by the weight of the protagonist at the center.

漫画人物

The Comic Character

所有角色都在与敌对势力对抗，追求欲望。但戏剧角色足够灵活，能够避开风险，意识到：“这可能会让我丧命。”喜剧角色却不是这样。喜剧角色的特点是盲目的痴迷。解决一个应该搞笑但实际上并不搞笑的角色的问题的第一步是找到他的狂热。

All characters pursue desire against forces of antagonism. But the dramatic character is flexible enough to step back from the risk and realize: “This could get me killed.” Not the comic character. The comic character is marked by a blind obsession. The first step to solving the problem of a character who should be funny but isn’t is to find his mania.

当阿里斯托芬的政治讽刺作品和米南德的滑稽爱情故事成为历史时，喜剧就退化为悲剧和史诗的粗俗的农民表亲。但随着文艺复兴的到来——从意大利的哥尔多尼到法国的莫里哀（跳过德国），再到莎士比亚、琼森、威彻利、康格里夫、谢里丹；通过萧伯纳、王尔德、考沃德、卓别林、艾伦，以及英国、爱尔兰和美国的才子——喜剧上升为当今闪亮的艺术——现代生活的救星。

When the political satires of Aristophanes and farcical romances of Menander passed into history, Comedy degenerated into the ribald, peasant cousin of Tragedy and Epic Poetry. But with the coming of the Renaissance—from Goldoni in Italy to Molière in France (skipping Germany) to Shakespeare, Jonson, Wycherley, Congreve, Sheridan; through Shaw, Wilde, Coward, Chaplin, Allen, the crackling wits of England, Ireland, and America—it ascended into the gleaming art of today—the saving grace of modern life.

当这些大师们完善他们的艺术时，他们就像所有工匠一样，谈论着本职工作，并意识到一个喜剧人物是通过给角色分配一种“幽默”来创造的，这是一种角色看不到的痴迷。莫里哀的职业生涯建立在写戏剧的基础上，讽刺主人公的痴迷——守财奴、想象中的病人、厌世者。几乎任何痴迷都可以。比如鞋子。伊梅尔达·马科斯是一个国际笑话，因为她不认为自己对鞋子有神经质的需求，据估计她有三千多双鞋子。虽然在纽约的税务审判中，她说只有一千两百双……而且没有一双合脚。她声称，这些都是鞋业公司的礼物，鞋业公司永远都买不准尺码。

As these masters perfected their art, like all craftsmen, they talked shop and came to realize that a comic character is created by assigning the role a “humour,” an obsession the character does not see. Molière’s career was built on writing plays ridiculing the protagonist’s fixation—The Miser, The Imaginary Invalid, The Misanthrope. Almost any obsession will do. Shoes, for example. Imelda Marcos is an international joke because she doesn’t see her neurotic need for shoes, by some estimates over three thousand pairs. Although in her tax trial here in New York she said it was only twelve hundred… and none fit. They’re gifts from shoe companies, she claimed, who never get the size right.

在《一家子》中，阿奇·邦克（卡罗尔·奥康纳饰）是一个盲目偏执的偏执狂。只要他没有意识到这一点，他就是一个傻瓜，我们会嘲笑他。但如果他转过身对某人说：“你知道，我是一个种族主义仇恨贩子”，喜剧就结束了。

In All in the Family Archie Bunker (Carroll O’Connor) was a blindly obsessed bigot. As long as he doesn’t see it, he’s a buffoon and we laugh at him. But if he were to turn to someone and say, “You know, I am a racist hate monger,” the comedy is over.

黑暗中的一枪：一名司机在本杰明·巴伦（乔治·桑德斯饰）的庄园里被谋杀。一个痴迷于成为世界上最完美侦探的人，克鲁索船长（彼得·塞勒斯饰）出现了，他认定巴伦是凶手，并在台球室与这位亿万富翁对峙。当克鲁索摆出证据时，他撕破了台球桌上的毛毡，摔碎了球杆，最后总结道：“……而你却在一场愤怒的仪式中杀死了他。”克鲁索转身离开，但走错了方向门。我们听到他撞到墙上的“砰”的一声。他退后几步，带着冷漠的蔑视说道：“愚蠢的建筑师。”

A SHOT IN THE DARK: A chauffeur is murdered on the estate of Benjamin Ballon (George Saunders). Enter a man obsessed with being the world’s most perfect detective, Captain Clouseau (Peter Sellers), who decides that Ballon did the deed and confronts the billionaire in the billiards room. As Clouseau lays out his evidence, he rips the felt on the pool table and smashes the cues, finally summing up with: “… and zen you killed him in a rit of fealous jage.” Clouseau turns to leave but walks around the wrong side of the door. We hear THUMP as he hits the wall. He steps back and with cool contempt, says, “Stupid architects.”

《一条叫旺达的鱼》：旺达（杰米·李·柯蒂斯饰）是一名犯罪大师，对说外语的男人十分着迷。奥托（凯文·克莱恩饰）是一名失败的中情局特工，他坚信自己是一名知识分子——尽管旺达指出，他犯了一些错误，比如认为伦敦地铁是一场政治运动。肯（迈克尔·帕林饰）对动物的喜爱是如此痴迷，以至于奥托通过吃掉他的金鱼来折磨他。阿奇·利奇（约翰·克里斯饰）对尴尬有着强烈的恐惧，他告诉我们，这种恐惧笼罩着整个英国民族。然而，在电影中途，阿奇意识到了自己的痴迷，一旦他意识到这一点，他就从喜剧主角变成了浪漫主角，从阿奇·利奇变成了“加里·格兰特”。（阿奇·利奇是加里·格兰特的真名。）

A FISH CALLED WANDA: Wanda (Jamie Lee Curtis), a master criminal, is obsessed with men who speak foreign languages. Otto (Kevin Kline), a failed CIA agent, is convinced he’s an intellectual—although, as Wanda points out, he makes mistakes such as thinking that the London Underground is a political movement. Ken (Michael Palin) is so obsessed with a love of animals that Otto tortures him by eating his goldfish. Archie Leach (John Cleese) has an obsessive fear of embarrassment, a fear, he tells us, that grips the whole English nation. Midway through the film, however, Archie realizes his obsession and once he sees it, he turns from comic protagonist to romantic lead, from Archie Leach to “Cary Grant.” (Archie Leach was Cary Grant’s real name.)

塑造银幕角色的三个技巧

Three Tips on Writing Characters for the Screen

1.给演员留有余地。

1. Leave room for the actor.

好莱坞有句古老的格言，要求编剧给每个演员提供最大限度的机会来发挥他们的创造力，而不要用对行为、手势细微差别和语调的不断描述来覆盖和填充整个页面：

This old Hollywood admonition asks the writer to provide each actor with the maximum opportunity to use his or her creativity; not to overwrite and pepper the page with constant description of behaviors, nuances of gesture, tones of voice:

鲍勃斜倚在讲台上，一条腿交叉在另一条腿上，一只手叉腰。他越过学生们的头顶，若有所思地扬起眉毛：

Bob leans on the lectern, crossing one leg over the other, one arm akimbo. He looks out over the heads of the students, arching an eyebrow thoughtfully:

鲍勃

BOB

      （冷漠地）

      (phlegmatically)

啦啦，啦啦，啦啦，啦啦

Blaa, blaa, blaa, blaa, blaa

演员对充斥着这种细节的剧本的反应是把它扔进垃圾桶，心想：“他们不需要演员，他们想要一个傀儡。”或者，如果演员接受了这个角色，他会拿起一支红铅笔，把所有的废话都从纸上划掉。上面的细节毫无意义。演员想知道：我想要什么？为什么我想要它？我该如何得到它？是什么阻止了我？后果是什么？演员从潜台词中将角色带入​​生活：欲望与对抗力量相遇。在镜头前他会说和做场景需要的事情，但角色塑造必须是他的工作，甚至比你的工作更重要。

An actor’s reaction to a script saturated with that kind of detail is to toss it in the trash, thinking, “They don’t want an actor, they want a puppet.” Or if the actor accepts the role, he’ll take a red pencil and scratch all that nonsense off the page. The details above are meaningless. An actor wants to know: What do I want? Why do I want it? How do I go about getting it? What stops me? What are the consequences? The actor brings a character to life from the subtext out: desire meeting forces of antagonism. On-camera he’ll say and do what the scene requires, but characterization must be his work as much as or more than yours.

我们必须记住，在剧院里，我们希望自己的作品能在国内外、现在和将来上演数百场甚至数千场，但在银幕上，每个角色只有一场演出，永远定格在电影中。编剧/演员的合作始于编剧不再梦想虚构的面孔，而是想象理想的演员阵容。如果一位编剧觉得某位演员是他理想的主角，并在写作时想象她，他就会不断想起，只需要一点点出色的演员就能创造出震撼人心的时刻，他就不会写出这样的作品：

We must remember that, unlike the theatre where we hope our work will be performed in hundreds, if not thousands of productions, here and abroad, now and into the future, on screen there will be only one production, only one performance of each character fixed on film forever. Writer/actor collaboration begins when the writer stops dreaming of a fictional face and instead imagines the ideal casting. If a writer feels that a particular actor would be his ideal protagonist and he envisions her while he writes, he’ll be constantly reminded of how little superb actors need to create powerful moments, and won’t write this:

芭芭拉

BARBARA

     （给杰克递了一杯杯子）

     (offering Jack a cup)

您要这杯

Would you like this cup of

咖啡吗，亲爱的？

coffee, darling?

观众看到这是一杯咖啡，这个手势表示“你想要这个吗？”，女演员则感觉“亲爱的……”女演员意识到少即是多，于是转向导演说：“拉里，我是不是得说‘亲爱的，你想要这杯咖啡吗？’我的意思是，我提供的是该死的杯子，对吧？我们可以把那句台词剪掉吗？”台词被剪掉，女演员默默地给一个男人递上一杯咖啡，让屏幕火上浇油，而编剧则怒不可遏，“他们毁了我的台词！”

The audience sees it’s a cup of coffee; the gesture says, “Would you like this?”; the actress is feeling “darling…” Sensing that less is more, the actress will turn to her director and say: “Larry, do I have to say ‘Would you like this cup of coffee, darling?’ I mean, I’m offering the damn cup, right? Could we just cut that line?” The line is cut, the actress sets the screen on fire silently offering a man a cup of coffee, while the screenwriter rages, “They’re butchering my dialogue!”

2.爱上你笔下的所有角色。

2. Fall in love with all your characters.

我们经常看到电影中有很多优秀的角色……除了一个，他很糟糕。我们想知道为什么，直到我们意识到编剧讨厌这个角色。他在轻视和侮辱这个角色抓住一切机会。我永远无法理解这一点。一个作家怎么会讨厌他自己的角色？这是他的孩子。他怎么会讨厌他赋予生命的东西？拥抱你创造的一切，尤其是坏人。他们和其他人一样值得爱。

We often see films with a cast of excellent characters… except one, who’s dreadful. We wonder why until we realize that the writer hates this character. He’s trivializing and insulting this role at every opportunity. And I’ll never understand this. How can a writer hate his own character? It’s his baby. How can he hate what he gave life? Embrace all your creations, especially the bad people. They deserve love like everyone else.

赫特和卡梅隆一定很爱他们的终结者。看看他们为他做的精彩事情：在汽车旅馆的房间里，他用一把 Exacto 刀修复了一只受伤的眼睛。他站在水槽边，把眼球从头上撬出来，扔进水里，用毛巾擦干血迹，戴上 Gargoyle 太阳镜遮住洞，然后照镜子，理顺乱糟糟的头发。震惊的观众想，“他刚刚把眼球从头上撬出来，还不在乎自己的长相。他太虚荣了！”

Hurt and Cameron must have loved their Terminator. Look at the wonderful things they did for him: In a motel room he repairs a damaged eye with an Exacto knife. Standing over a sink, he pries his eyeball out of his head, drops it in the water, mops up the blood with a towel, puts on Gargoyle sunglasses to hide the hole, then looks in the mirror and smooths down his tangled hair. The stunned audience thinks, “He just pried his eyeball out of his head and he gives a damn what he looks like. He’s got vanity!”

然后门响了。当他抬起头时，摄像机以他的视角拍摄，我们看到他的电脑屏幕叠加在门上。上面列出了对敲门人的回应：“走开”、“请稍后再来”、“滚开”、“滚开，混蛋”。他的光标上下移动，做出选择，最后停在“滚开，混蛋”上。一个有幽默感的机器人。现在这个怪物更加可怕了，因为正是这些时刻，我们不知道该对他抱有什么期望，因此只能想象最坏的情况。只有热爱自己角色的作家才能发现这样的时刻。

Then a knock at the door. As he looks up, the camera takes his POV and we see his computer screen super-imposed over the door. On it is a list of responses to someone knocking: “Go away,” “Please come back later,” “Fuck off,” “Fuck off, asshole.” His cursor goes up and down while he makes his choice and stops at “Fuck off, asshole.” A robot with a sense of humor. Now the monster’s all the more terrifying, for thanks to these moments we have no idea of what to expect from him, and therefore imagine the worst. Only writers who love their characters discover such moments.

关于反派的提示：如果你的角色图谋不轨，而你把自己置于他的角度，问自己，“如果我是他，在这种情况下，我会怎么做？”，你会尽一切可能摆脱这种局面。因此，你不会像个反派一样行事；你不会扭动你的胡子。反社会人格者是我们见过的最迷人的人——富有同情心的倾听者，他们似乎非常关心我们的问题，而这些问题却把我们引向地狱。

A hint about villains: If your character’s up to no good and you place yourself within his being, asking, “If I were he in this situation, what would I do?,” you’d do everything possible to get away with it. Therefore, you would not act like a villain; you would not twist your mustache. Sociopaths are the most charming folks we ever meet—sympathetic listeners who seem so deeply concerned about our problems while they lead us to hell.

一位采访者曾对李·马文说，他演反派三十年了，总是演坏人一定很可怕。马文笑了笑，“我？我不演坏人。我演那些挣扎度日的人，尽其所能地利用生活所赋予他们的东西。别人可能认为他们是坏人，但我从不演坏人。”这就是为什么马文可以成为一个出色的反派。他是一个对人性有着深刻理解的工匠：没有人认为他们是坏人。

An interviewer once remarked to Lee Marvin that he’d played villains for thirty years and how awful it must be always playing bad people. Marvin smiled, “Me? I don’t play bad people. I play people struggling to get through their day, doing the best they can with what life’s given them. Others may think they’re bad, but no, I never play bad people.” That’s why Marvin could be a superb villain. He was a craftsman with a deep understanding of human nature: No one thinks they’re bad.

如果你不能爱他们，就不要写他们。另一方面，不要让你对一个角色的同情或反感产生戏剧性或刻板印象。爱他们所有人，但不要失去你的清醒头脑。

If you can’t love them, don’t write them. On the other hand, permit neither your empathy nor antipathy for a character to produce melodrama or stereotype. Love them all without losing your clearheadedness.

3. 品格就是自我认知。

3. Character is self-knowledge.

我所了解的有关人性的一切都是从我自己身上学到的。

Everything I learned about human nature I learned from me.

—安东·契诃夫

—Anton Chekhov

我们在哪里找到我们的人物？部分是通过观察。作家们经常随身携带笔记本或袖珍录音机，在观察生活中的流逝时，收集零碎的东西，用随机材料填满文件柜。当它们枯燥无味时，他们会从中寻找灵感，激发想象力。

Where do we find our characters? Partly through observation. Writers often carry notepads or pocket tape recorders and as they watch life’s passing show, collect bits and pieces to fill file cabinets with random material. When they’re dry, they dip in for ideas to stir the imagination.

我们观察生活，但将生活直接照搬在纸上是错误的。很少有人像人物一样，在复杂性方面如此清晰，轮廓如此分明。相反，像弗兰肯斯坦博士一样，我们用发现的部分来塑造人物。作家将他妹妹的分析思维与朋友的喜剧智慧拼凑在一起，再加上猫的狡猾残忍和李尔王的盲目坚持。我们从任何地方借用人性的点点滴滴、原始的想象力和观察力，将它们组装成矛盾的维度，然后将它们塑造成我们称之为人物的生物。

We observe, but it’s a mistake to copy life directly to the page. Few individuals are as clear in their complexity and as well delineated as a character. Instead, like Dr. Frankenstein, we build characters out of parts found. A writer takes the analytical mind of his sister and pieces it together with the comic wit of a friend, adds to that the cunning cruelty of a cat and the blind persistence of King Lear. We borrow bits and pieces of humanity, raw chunks of imagination and observation from wherever they’re found, assemble them into dimensions of contradiction, then round them into the creatures we call characters.

观察是我们塑造人物的源泉，但对人物的深刻理解却来自别处。所有优秀人物塑造的根源都是自我认知。

Observation is our source of characterizations, but understanding of deep character is found in another place. The root of all fine character writing is self-knowledge.

人生的一个悲哀事实是，在这苦难的深渊中，我们真正了解的人只有一个，那就是我们自己。我们本质上永远都是孤独的。然而，尽管其他人仍然与我们相距甚远，不断变化，并且从确定的、最终的意义上不可知，尽管年龄、性别、背景和文化存在明显差异，尽管人们之间存在所有明显的差异，但事实是，我们所有人的相似之处远多于不同之处。我们都是人类。

One of the sad truths of life is that there’s only one person in this vale of tears that we ever really know, and that’s ourselves. We’re essentially and forever alone. Yet, although others remain at a distance, changing and unknowable in a definitive, final sense, and despite the obvious distinctions of age, sex, background, and culture, despite all the clear differences among people, the truth is we are all far more alike than we are different. We are all human.

我们都有相同的人生经历。我们每个人都在受苦和享受，梦想和希望用有价值的东西度过每一天。作为一名作家，你可以肯定，每个从街上向你走来的人，都有着与你相同的基本人性思想和感受，每个人都有自己的方式。这就是为什么当你问自己，“如果我是这个角色，在这种情况下，我会怎么做？”诚实的回答总是正确的。你会做人性中的事情。因此，你越是深入了解自己人性的奥秘，你就越能理解自己，你就越能理解他人。

We all share the same crucial human experiences. Each of us is suffering and enjoying, dreaming and hoping of getting through our days with something of value. As a writer, you can be certain that everyone coming down the street toward you, each in his own way, is having the same fundamental human thoughts and feelings that you are. This is why when you ask yourself, “If I were this character in these circumstances, what would I do?” the honest answer is always correct. You would do the human thing. Therefore, the more you penetrate the mysteries of your own humanity, the more you come to understand yourself, the more you are able to understand others.

当我们回顾从荷马到莎士比亚、狄更斯、奥斯汀、海明威、威廉姆斯、怀尔德、伯格曼、戈德曼和其他所有大师的想象中出现的一系列人物时——每个人物都令人着迷、独特、具有崇高的人性，而且人数众多——并意识到所有人物都诞生于同一个人性……这真是令人震惊。

When we survey the parade of characters that has marched out of the imaginations of storytellers from Homer to Shakespeare, Dickens, Austen, Hemingway, Williams, Wilder, Bergman, Goldman, and all other masters—each character fascinating, unique, sublimely human and so many, many of them—and realize that all were born of a single humanity… it’s astounding.

18

经文

18

THE TEXT

对话

DIALOGUE

设计故事和角色的所有创造力和劳动最终都必须在纸上实现。本章探讨文本、对话和描述，以及指导写作的技巧。除了文本之外，它还探讨了故事的诗学，即嵌入文字中的图像系统，最终形成丰富意义和情感的电影图像。

All the creativity and labor that goes into designing story and character must finally be realized on the page. This chapter looks at the text, at dialogue and description, and the craft that guides their writing. Beyond text, it examines the poetics of story, the Image Systems embedded in words that ultimately result in filmic images that enrich meaning and emotion.

对话不是交谈。

Dialogue is not conversation.

偷听任何咖啡店里的对话，你都会立刻意识到你永远不会把这些废话放到屏幕上。真正的对话充满了尴尬的停顿、糟糕的词汇选择和措辞、不连贯的推论、毫无意义的重复；它很少能提出观点或达成共识。但这没关系，因为对话不是为了提出观点或达成共识。这就是心理学家所说的“保持渠道畅通”。谈话是我们发展和改变人际关系的方式。

Eavesdrop on any coffee shop conversation and you’ll realize in a heartbeat you’d never put that slush onscreen. Real conversation is full of awkward pauses, poor word choices and phrasing, non sequiturs, pointless repetitions; it seldom makes a point or achieves closure. But that’s okay because conversation isn’t about making points or achieving closure. It’s what psychologists call “keeping the channel open.” Talk is how we develop and change relationships.

当两个朋友在街上相遇并谈论天气时，我们难道不知道他们的谈话不是关于天气的吗？他们在说什么？“我是你的朋友。让我们从忙碌的一天中抽出一分钟，站在这里，彼此确认我们确实是朋友。”他们可能会谈论体育、天气、购物……任何事情。但文字不是潜台词。所说和所做的并不是所想和所感。场景并不是它表面上所讲的内容。因此，银幕对话必须具有日常谈话的节奏，但内容要远远超出正常水平。

When two friends meet on the street and talk about the weather, don’t we know that theirs isn’t a conversation about the weather? What is being said? “I’m your friend. Let’s take a minute out of our busy day and stand here in each other’s presence and reaffirm that we are indeed friends.” They might talk about sports, weather, shopping… anything. But the text is not the subtext. What is said and done is not what is thought and felt. The scene is not about what it seems to be about. Screen dialogue, therefore, must have the swing of everyday talk but content well above normal.

首先，银幕对话需要简洁和经济。银幕对话必须用尽可能少的单词表达最多的信息。其次，它必须有方向。每句对话都必须在不断变化的行为中将场景的节奏转向一个方向或另一个方向，不能重复。第三，它应该有目的。每一句台词或每段对话都是围绕转折点构建和展开场景的设计步骤。所有这些精确性，但它必须听起来像谈话，使用非正式和自然的词汇，包括缩写、俚语，甚至必要时还有脏话。亚里士多德建议：“说话要像普通人，但要像智者一样思考。”

First, screen dialogue requires compression and economy. Screen dialogue must say the maximum in the fewest possible words. Second, it must have direction. Each exchange of dialogue must turn the beats of the scene in one direction or another across the changing behaviors, without repetition. Third, it should have purpose. Each line or exchange of dialogue executes a step in design that builds and arcs a scene around its Turning Point. All this precision, yet it must sound like talk, using an informal and natural vocabulary, complete with contractions, slang, and even, if necessary, profanity. “Speak as common people do,” Aristotle advised, “but think as wise men do.”

记住，电影不是小说；对话说完就消失了。如果演员说出口的瞬间观众没有抓住话柄，恼火的观众就会突然悄悄问：“他说了什么？”电影也不是戏剧。我们看电影；听戏剧。电影的美学 80% 是视觉的，20% 是听觉的。我们想要看，而不是听，因为我们的精力都集中在眼睛上，只能一半时间在听配乐。戏剧 80% 是听觉的，20% 是视觉的。我们的注意力集中在耳朵上，只能一半时间在看舞台。剧作家可以编造出复杂而华丽的对话 — — 但编剧不能。银幕对话要求句子简短、结构简单 — — 一般是从名词到动词到宾语，或者从名词到动词到补语，按照这个顺序。

Remember, film is not a novel; dialogue is spoken and gone. If words aren’t grasped the instant they leave the actor’s mouth, annoyed people suddenly whisper, “What did he say?” Nor is film theater. We watch a movie; we hear a play. The aesthetics of film are 80 percent visual, 20 percent auditory. We want to see, not hear as our energies go to our eyes, only half-listening to the soundtrack. Theatre is 80 percent auditory, 20 percent visual. Our concentration is directed through our ears, only half-looking at the stage. The playwright may spin elaborate and ornate dialogue—but not the screenwriter. Screen dialogue demands short, simply constructed sentences—generally, a movement from noun to verb to object or from noun to verb to complement in that order.

举例来说，不是：“查尔斯·威尔逊·埃文斯先生是位于曼哈顿第五大道 666 号大楼的数据公司的首席财务官，他六年前以优异成绩从哈佛商学院毕业，被提升到这一职位，今天被捕，当局指控他挪用公司养老金，并试图隐瞒损失，涉嫌欺诈。”而是要有文采：“你知道查理·埃文斯吗？他是数据公司的首席财务官？哈！被捕了。他把拳头伸进了收银机。哈佛毕业生知道如何偷窃并逃脱惩罚。”将同样的想法分解成一系列简短、结构简单、非正式的句子，观众一点一点地理解。

Not, for example: “Mr. Charles Wilson Evans, the chief financial officer at Data Corporation in the 666 building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, who was promoted to that position six years ago, having graduated magna cum laude from Harvard Business School, was arrested today, accused by the authorities of embezzlement from the company’s pension fund and fraud in his efforts to conceal the losses.” But with a polish: “You know Charlie Evans? CFO at Data Cop? Ha! Got busted. Had his fist in the till. Harvard grad out to know how to steal and get away with it.” The same ideas broken into a series of short, simply constructed, informally spoken sentences, and bit by bit the audience gets it.

我们都有相同的人生经历。我们每个人都在受苦和享受，梦想和希望用有价值的东西度过每一天。作为一名作家，你可以肯定，每个从街上向你走来的人，都有着与你相同的基本人性思想和感受，每个人都有自己的方式。这就是为什么当你问自己，“如果我是这个角色，在这种情况下，我会怎么做？”诚实的回答总是正确的。你会做人性中的事情。因此，你越是深入了解自己人性的奥秘，你就越能理解自己，你就越能理解他人。

We all share the same crucial human experiences. Each of us is suffering and enjoying, dreaming and hoping of getting through our days with something of value. As a writer, you can be certain that everyone coming down the street toward you, each in his own way, is having the same fundamental human thoughts and feelings that you are. This is why when you ask yourself, “If I were this character in these circumstances, what would I do?” the honest answer is always correct. You would do the human thing. Therefore, the more you penetrate the mysteries of your own humanity, the more you come to understand yourself, the more you are able to understand others.

当我们回顾从荷马到莎士比亚、狄更斯、奥斯汀、海明威、威廉姆斯、怀尔德、伯格曼、戈德曼和其他所有大师的想象中出现的一系列人物时——每个人物都令人着迷、独特、具有崇高的人性，而且人数众多——并意识到所有人物都诞生于同一个人性……这真是令人震惊。

When we survey the parade of characters that has marched out of the imaginations of storytellers from Homer to Shakespeare, Dickens, Austen, Hemingway, Williams, Wilder, Bergman, Goldman, and all other masters—each character fascinating, unique, sublimely human and so many, many of them—and realize that all were born of a single humanity… it’s astounding.

对话不需要完整的句子。我们并不总是费心使用名词或动词。通常，如上所述，我们会省略开头冠词或代词，用短语甚至咕哝声说话。

Dialogue doesn’t require complete sentences. We don’t always bother with a noun or a verb. Typically, as above, we drop the opening article or pronoun, speaking in phrases, even grunts.

大声朗读对话，或者最好对着录音机读，以避免绕口令或意外押韵和头韵，例如：“他们正在把车开到那边。” 永远不要写任何引起人们注意的对话，任何跳出纸面大喊“哦，我是多么聪明的台词啊！”的东西。一旦你认为你写的东西特别好、特别有文学性，就把它删掉。

Read your dialogue out loud or, better yet, into a tape recorder to avoid tongue twisters or accidental rhymes and alliterations such as: “They’re moving their car over there.” Never write anything that calls attentions to itself as dialogue, anything that jumps off the page and shouts: “Oh, what a clever line am I!” The moment you think you’ve written something that’s particularly fine and literary—cut it.

简短演講

Short Speeches

银幕对话的本质就是古希腊戏剧中所谓的stikomythia——快速交换简短的演讲。长篇演讲与电影美学背道而驰。从页面顶部到底部的一栏对话要求摄像机在演员的脸上停留一分钟。观察秒针在钟面上爬行整整六十秒，你会意识到一分钟是一段很长的时间。在十到十五秒内，观众的眼睛会吸收所有视觉表现，镜头变得多余。这就像一张卡住的唱片一遍又一遍地重复同一个音符。当眼睛感到无聊时，它会离开屏幕；当眼睛离开屏幕时，你就失去了观众。

The essence of screen dialogue is what was known in Classical Greek theatre as stikomythia—the rapid exchange of short speeches. Long speeches are antithetical with the aesthetics of cinema. A column of dialogue from top to bottom of a page asks the camera to dwell on an actor’s face for a talking minute. Watch a second hand crawl around the face of a clock for a full sixty seconds and you’ll realize that a minute is a long time. Within ten or fifteen seconds the audience’s eye absorbs everything visually expressive and the shot becomes redundant. It’s the same effect as a stuck record repeating the same note over and over. When the eye is bored, it leaves the screen; when it leaves the screen, you lose the audience.

文学界的雄心勃勃者常常对这个问题不屑一顾，认为剪辑师可以通过切换到听众的面部来打断长篇演讲。但这只会带来新的问题。现在演员在画外讲话，当我们将声音分离时，演员必须放慢速度并多表达，因为观众实际上是在读唇语。观众对所说内容的理解有 50% 来自于观察。当面部消失时，观众就停止了倾听。因此，画外的演讲者必须小心翼翼地吐出单词，希望观众不会错过。更重要的是，画外的声音会失去演讲者的潜台词。观众有听众的潜台词，但这可能不是他们感兴趣的。

The literary ambitious often shrug this problem off, thinking the editor can break up long speeches by cutting to the listening face. But this only introduces new problems. Now an actor is speaking offscreen, and when we disembody a voice, the actor must slow down and overarticulate because the audience, in effect, lip-reads. Fifty percent of its understanding of what is being said comes from watching it being said. When the face disappears it stops listening. So offscreen speakers must carefully spit out words in the hope the audience won’t miss them. What’s more, a voice offscreen loses the subtext of the speaker. The audience has the subtext of the listener, but that may not be what it’s interested in.

因此，在写长篇演讲时要非常谨慎。但是，如果你觉得一个角色说完所有对话而另一个角色保持沉默是符合当时的实际情况的，那就写长篇演讲吧，但在写长篇演讲时，请记住，生活中没有独白这种东西。生活就是对话、行动/反应。

Therefore, be very judicious about writing long speeches. If, however, you feel that it’s true to the moment for one character to carry all the dialogue while another remains silent, write the long speech, but as you do, remember that there’s no such thing in life as a monologue. Life is dialogue, action/reaction.

假设，作为一名演员，当另一个角色进入时，我有一段很长的台词，而我的第一句话就是“你让我久等了”，在看到观众对我第一句话的反应之前，我怎么知道接下来该说什么？如果另一个角色的反应是道歉，他会尴尬地低下头，这会让我的下一个动作和台词变得柔和。然而，如果另一个演员的反应是敌对的，比如他瞪了我一眼，那我的下一句台词可能会变得愤怒。在感觉到观众对他刚才的行为的反应之前，人们怎么能时时刻刻知道接下来该说什么或做什么呢？他不知道。生活总是行动/反应。没有独白。没有准备好的演讲。无论我们如何在脑海中排练重要时刻，都只是即兴表演。

If, as an actor, I have a long speech that begins when another character enters and my first line is “You’ve kept me waiting,” how do I know what to say next until I see the reaction to my first words? If the other character’s reaction is apologetic, his head goes down in embarrassment, that softens my next action and colors my lines accordingly. If, however, the other actor’s reaction is antagonistic, as he shoots me a dirty look, that may color my next lines with anger. How does anyone know from moment to moment what to say or do next until he senses the reaction to what he just did? He doesn’t know. Life is always action/reaction. No monologues. No prepared speeches. An improvisation no matter how we mentally rehearse our big moments.

因此，通过将长篇演讲分解为塑造演讲者行为的动作/反应模式，向我们展示你对电影美学的理解。用无声反应将演讲分割成片段，导致演讲者改变节奏，例如《AMADEUS》中萨列里向牧师忏悔的片段：

Therefore, show us that you understand film aesthetics by breaking long speeches into the patterns of action/reaction that shape the speaker’s behavior. Fragment the speech with silent reactions that cause the speaker to change the beat, such as this from AMADEUS as Salieri confesses to a priest:

萨列里

SALIERI

我唯一想做的就是唱歌

All I ever wanted was to sing

上帝给了我这个

to God. He gave me that

渴望。然后让我

longing. And then made me

哑巴。为什么？告诉我。

mute. Why? Tell me that.

神父扭过头去，感到痛苦和尴尬，于是萨列里用反问的方式回答了自己的问题：

The Priest looks away, pained and embarrassed, so Salieri answers his own question rhetorically:

萨列里

SALIERI

如果他不想让我表扬

If he didn’t want me to praise

他用音乐，为何植入

Him with music, why implant

欲望……就像欲望

the desire… like a lust in

我的身体，然后拒绝我

my body and then deny me

天赋？

the talent?

或者在对话中加上括号，也可以达到同样的效果，比如后面这个场景：

Or put parentheticals within dialogue for the same effect, such as this from later in the scene:

萨列里

SALIERI

你知道吗，我恋爱了

You understand, I was in love

和女孩……

with the girl…

（被自己的

(amused by his own

词语选择）

choice of words)

…或者至少是充满欲望。

… or at least in lust.

（看到牧师

(seeing the priest

低头看看

look down at a

在他的十字架上

crucifix held in his

圈数

lap)

但我向你发誓，我绝不会

But I swear to you, I never

碰了她一下。不。

laid a finger on her. No.

（牧师看起来

(as the priest looks

庄严、评判）

up, solemn, judgmental)

尽管如此，我还是无法忍受

All the same, I couldn’t bear

为别人着想

to think of anyone else

触摸她。

touching her.

（愤怒于

(angered at the

莫扎特的思想）

thought of Mozart)

最不重要的是……这个生物。

Least of all… the creature.

角色可以对自己、对自己的想法和情感做出反应，就像上面的萨列里一样。这也是场景动态的一部分。在页面上展示角色内部、角色之间、角色与物理世界之间的动作/反应模式，将观看电影的感觉投射到读者的想象中，让读者明白你的电影不是一部说话头的电影。

A character can react to himself, to his own thoughts and emotions, as does Salieri above. That too is part of the scene’s dynamics. Demonstrating on the page the action/reaction patterns within characters, between characters, between characters and the physical world projects the sensation of watching a film into the reader’s imagination and makes the reader understand that yours is not a film of talking heads.

悬念句

The Suspense Sentence

在写得不好的对话中，无用的单词，尤其是介词短语，会飘到句子的末尾。因此，意义处于中间某处，但观众必须听那些最后的空话，在那一两秒钟里，他们会感到无聊。更重要的是，银幕对面的演员想从那个意义中得到提示，但必须尴尬地等到句子结束。在生活中，我们互相打断，把对方句子中摇摆不定的尾巴剪掉，让日常对话变得毫无意义。这也是为什么在制作过程中演员和导演会重写对话的另一个原因，因为他们会修剪演讲以提升场景的活力，让提示节奏变得突出。

In ill-written dialogue useless words, especially prepositional phrases, float to the ends of sentences. Consequently, meaning sits somewhere in the middle, but the audience has to listen to those last empty words and for that second or two they’re bored. What’s more, the actor across the screen wants to take his cue from that meaning but has to wait awkwardly until the sentence is finished. In life, we cut each other off, slicing the wiggling tails off each other’s sentences, letting everyday conversation tumble. This is yet another reason why in production actors and directors rewrite dialogue, as they trim speeches to lift the scene’s energy and make the cueing rhythm pop.

优秀的电影对白往往形成周期句：“如果你不想让我做这件事，你为什么要给我那个……”看？枪？吻？周期句是“悬念句”。它的含义被推迟到最后一个词，迫使演员和观众都听完台词。再读一遍上面彼得·谢弗的精彩对白，你会发现几乎每一句台词都是一个悬念句。

Excellent film dialogue tends to shape itself into the periodic sentence: “If you didn’t want me to do it, why’d you give me that…” Look? Gun? Kiss? The periodic sentence is the “suspense sentence.” Its meaning is delayed until the very last word, forcing both actor and audience to listen to the end of the line. Read again Peter Shaffer’s superb dialogue above and note that virtually every single line is a suspense sentence.

沉默的剧本

The Silent Screenplay

写电影对白的最佳建议就是不要写。当你可以创造视觉表达时，就不要写一行对白。对每个场景的第一次攻击应该是：我怎么能用纯视觉的方式写这个场景，而不必求助于一行对白？遵守收益递减定律：你写的对白越多，对白的效果就越小。如果你写一段又一段的对白，把人物带进房间，让他们坐在椅子上，然后说啊说啊，那么优质对白的时刻就会被淹没在大量的文字中。但是如果你为眼睛而写，当对白出现时，它就会激发兴趣，因为观众渴望它。精简的对白，与主要视觉的东西形成鲜明对比，具有显著性和力量。

The best advice for writing film dialogue is don’t. Never write a line of dialogue when you can create a visual expression. The first attack on every scene should be: How could I write this in a purely visual way and not have to resort to a single line of dialogue? Obey the Law of Diminishing Returns: The more dialogue you write, the less effect dialogue has. If you write speech after speech, walking characters into rooms, sitting them in chairs and talking, talking, talking, moments of quality dialogue are buried under this avalanche of words. But if you write for the eye, when the dialogue comes, as it must, it sparks interest because the audience is hungry for it. Lean dialogue, in relief against what’s primarily visual, has salience and power.

沉默：埃斯特和安娜（英格丽德·图林和冈内尔·林德布洛姆饰）是一对姐妹，生活在一个充满女同性恋和虐待狂氛围的家庭里。关系。埃斯特患有严重的肺结核。安娜是双性恋，有一个私生子，喜欢折磨她的姐姐。他们正返回瑞典，电影发生在旅途中的一家酒店。伯格曼写了一个场景，安娜去酒店餐厅，让自己被服务员勾引，以便用下午的风流韵事激怒她的姐姐。“服务员勾引顾客”的场景……你会怎么写？

THE SILENCE: Ester and Anna (Ingrid Thulin and Gunnel Lindblom) are sisters living in a lesbian and rather sadomasochistic relationship. Ester is seriously ill with tuberculosis. Anna is bisexual, has an illegitimate child, and enjoys tormenting her older sister. They’re traveling home to Sweden, and the film takes place in a hotel during their journey. Bergman has written a scene in which Anna goes down to the hotel restaurant and allows herself to be seduced by a waiter in order to provoke her sister with this afternoon affair. The “waiter seduces the customer” scene… how would you write it?

服务员会打开菜单并推荐某些菜品吗？询问她是否住在酒店？是否远行？称赞她的穿着？询问她是否了解这座城市？提到他下班了，很想带她去观光？聊聊……

Does the waiter open a menu and recommend certain items? Ask her if she’s staying at the hotel? Traveling far? Compliment her on how she’s dressed? Ask her if she knows the city? Mention he’s getting off work and would love to show her the sights? Talk, talk…

伯格曼为我们呈现的是：侍者走到桌边，不小心把餐巾纸掉在地上。他弯腰捡起餐巾纸，慢慢地嗅着安娜，从头到脚闻着她的气味。安娜的反应是，长长地、缓慢地、几乎是神志恍惚地吸了一口气。镜头切换到：他们在酒店房间里。很完美，不是吗？情色、纯粹的视觉，没有一句话说出来，也不需要一句话。这就是剧本。

Here’s what Bergman gave us: The waiter walks to the table and accidentally on purpose drops the napkin on the floor. As he bends to pick it up, he slowly sniffs and smells Anna from head to crotch to foot. She, in reaction, draws a long, slow, almost delirious breath. CUT TO: They’re in a hotel room. Perfect, isn’t it? Erotic, purely visual, not a word said or necessary. That’s screenwriting.

阿尔弗雷德·希区柯克曾经说过：“当剧本写好，对话添加好后，我们就可以开始拍摄了。”

Alfred Hitchcock once remarked, “When the screenplay has been written and the dialogue has been added, we’re ready to shoot.”

图像是我们的第一选择，对话则是令人遗憾的第二选择。对话是我们添加到剧本的最后一层。别误会，我们都喜欢精彩的对话，但少即是多。当一部极富想象力的电影转向对话时，它会令人兴奋不已，令人赏心悦目。

Image is our first choice, dialogue the regretful second choice. Dialogue is the last layer we add to the screenplay. Make no mistake, we all love great dialogue, but less is more. When a highly imagistic film shifts to dialogue, it crackles with excitement and delights the ear.

描述

DESCRIPTION

将电影植入读者的头脑

Putting a Film in the Reader’s Head

可怜的编剧，因为他不能成为诗人。他不能使用隐喻和明喻、谐音和头韵、节奏和押韵、提喻和转喻、夸张和减数分裂，这些宏大的比喻。相反，他的作品必须包含文学的所有内容，但不能是文学作品。文学作品本身就是完整的。剧本等待着镜头。如果不是文学，那么编剧的野心是什么呢？以这样的方式进行描述，让读者在翻阅书页时，一部电影在想象中流淌。

Pity the poor screenwriter, for he cannot be a poet. He cannot use metaphor and simile, assonance and alliteration, rhythm and rhyme, synecdoche and metonymy, hyperbole and meiosis, the grand tropes. Instead, his work must contain all the substance of literature but not be literary. A literary work is finished and complete within itself. A screenplay waits for the camera. If not literature, what then is the screenwriter’s ambition? To describe in such a way that as the reader turns pages, a film flows through the imagination.

这并非易事。第一步是要准确识别我们描述的是什么——看屏幕的感觉。百分之九十的口头表达没有电影对应物。“他已经坐在那里很长时间了”是无法拍摄的。所以我们不断用这个问题来约束想象力：我在屏幕上看到了什么？然后只描述照片中的内容：也许“他掐灭了第十支香烟”，“他紧张地看了看手表”，或者“他打哈欠，试图保持清醒”来暗示等待了很长时间。

No small task. The first step is to recognize exactly what it is we describe—the sensation of looking at the screen. Ninety percent of all verbal expression has no filmic equivalent. “He’s been sitting there for a long time” can’t be photographed. So we constantly discipline the imagination with this question: What do I see on the screen? Then describe only what is photographic: Perhaps “He stubs out his tenth cigarette,” “He nervously glances at his watch,” or “He yawns, trying to stay awake” to suggest waiting a long time.

当下生动行动

Vivid Action in the Now

银幕的本体是一种不断生动运动的绝对现在时。我们用现在时编写剧本，因为与小说不同，电影处于现在的刀刃上——无论是倒叙还是向前，我们都会跳转到一个新的现在。而银幕则表达了无情的动作。即使是静态镜头也有一种活力，因为虽然图像可能不会移动，但观众的目光会不断在屏幕上移动，赋予静止的图像能量。而且，与生活不同，电影是生动的。偶尔，我们的日常生活可能会被建筑物反射的灯光、商店橱窗中的鲜花或人群中女人的脸打破。但是，在我们度过每一天时，我们更多的是沉浸在自己的思绪中而不是外面，一半看，一半听这个世界。然而，屏幕却可以连续几个小时生动活泼。

The ontology of the screen is an absolute present tense in constant vivid movement. We write screenplay in the present tense because, unlike the novel, film is on the knife edge of the now—whether we flash back or forward, we jump to a new now. And the screen expresses relentless action. Even static shots have a sense of alive-ness, because although the imagery may not move, the audience’s eye constantly travels the screen, giving stationary images energy. And, unlike life, film is vivid. Occasionally, our daily routine may be broken by light glinting off a building, flowers in a shop window, or a woman’s face in the crowd. But as we walk through our days we’re more inside our heads than out, half-seeing, half-hearing the world. The screen, however, is intensely vivid for hours on end.

页面上的生动性源自事物的名称。名词是物体的名称；动词是动作的名称。要写得生动，请避免使用带有形容词和副词的通用名词和动词，并寻找事物的名称：不是“木匠使用大钉子”，而是“木匠用锤子敲出一个钉子”。 “钉子”是通用名词，“大”是形容词。坚实的盎格鲁-撒克逊语“钉子”在读者脑海中形成生动的形象，“钉子”则模糊不清。有多大？

On the page vividness springs from the names of the things. Nouns are the names of objects; verbs the names of actions. To write vividly, avoid generic nouns and verbs with adjectives and adverbs attached and seek the name of the thing: Not “The carpenter uses a big nail,” but “The carpenter hammers a spike.” “Nail” is a generic noun, “big” an adjective. The solid, Anglo-Saxon “spike” pops a vivid image in the reader’s mind, “nail” a blur. How big?

动词也是如此。典型的非描述性台词是：“他开始慢慢地穿过房间。”电影中，一个人是如何“开始”穿过房间的？角色要么穿过房间，要么迈出一步，停止。而“慢慢地移动”呢？“慢慢地”是副词；“移动”是一个含糊、乏味的动词。相反，要说出动作：“他轻快地穿过房间。”“他（漫步、溜达、慢步走、闲逛、拖着自己、蹒跚、华尔兹、滑行、笨拙地走、踮着脚尖、爬行、懒散、拖着脚走、蹒跚、蹒跚、蹒跚、蹒跚、蹒跚、蹒跚、蹒跚、蹒跚、摸索、蹒跚）穿过房间。”所有动作都很慢，但每一个都生动活泼，与众不同。

The same applies to verbs. A typical line of nondescription: “He starts to move slowly across the room.” How does somebody “start” across a room on film? The character either crosses or takes a step and stops. And “move slowly”? “Slowly” is an adverb; “move” a vague, bland verb. Instead, name the action: “He pads across the room.” “He (ambles, strolls, moseys, saunters, drags himself, staggers, waltzes, glides, lumbers, tiptoes, creeps, slouches, shuffles, waddles, minces, trudges, teeters, lurches, gropes, hobbles) across the room.” All are slow but each vivid and distinctively different from the others.

从头到尾都省略“is”和“are”。屏幕上没有任何东西处于存在状态；故事生活是无休止的变化和形成的流动。不是：“小镇上方的山上有一所大房子。”“有”、“他们是”、“它是”、“他/她是”是任何英语句子中最弱的表达方式。什么是“大房子”？城堡？庄园？“山丘”？山脊？悬崖？“小镇”？十字路口？村庄？也许是：“一座宅邸守卫着村庄上方的岬角。”海明威式地避开拉丁语和抽象术语、形容词和副词，而倾向于使用最具体的主动动词和具体名词，即使是定场镜头也变得生动起来。精彩的电影描述需要想象力和词汇量。

Eliminate “is” and “are” throughout. Onscreen nothing is in a state of being; story life is an unending flux of change, of becoming. Not: “There is a big house on a hill above a small town.” “There is,” “They are,” “It is,” “He/She is” are the weakest possible ways into any English sentence. And what’s a “big house”? Chateau? Hacienda? A “hill”? Ridge? Bluff? A “small town”? Crossroads? Hamlet? Perhaps: “A mansion guards the headlands above the village.” With a Hemingwayesque shunning of Latinate and abstrate terms, of adjectives and adverbs, in favor of the most specific, active verbs and concrete nouns possible, even establishing shots come alive. Fine film description requires an imagination and a vocabulary.

消除所有无法通过此测试的隐喻和明喻：“我在屏幕上看到（或听到）什么？”正如米洛斯·福尔曼所观察到的，“在电影中，树就是树。”例如，“仿佛”是一个在屏幕上不存在的比喻。角色不会“仿佛”穿过一扇门。他穿过门——就是这样。隐喻“一座豪宅守卫......”和明喻“门像枪声一样关上......”通过了测试，因为可以从前景角度拍摄豪宅，给人的印象是它庇护或守卫着下面的村庄；关门的声音可以像枪声一样震耳欲聋。事实上，在《失踪》中，所有关门的音效都是用枪声完成的，以潜意识地增加紧张感，因为意识听到了关门的声音，但潜意识对枪声做出了反应。

Eliminate all metaphor and simile that cannot pass this test: “What do I see (or hear) onscreen?” As Milos Forman observed, “In film, a tree is a tree.” “As if,” for example, is a trope that doesn’t exist onscreen. A character doesn’t come through a door “as if.” He comes through the door—period. The metaphor “A mansion guards…” and simile “The door slams like a gunshot…” pass the test in that a mansion can be photographed from a foreground angle that gives the impression it shelters or guards a village below it; a door slam can crack the ear like a gunshot. In fact, in MISSING the sound effects of all door slams were done with gunshots to subliminally increase tension as the conscious mind hears a door slam but the unconscious reacts to a gunshot.

另一方面，欧洲剧本基金的投稿中也出现了这样的场景：“太阳落山，就像丛林中老虎的眼睛闭上了一样”，还有“道路蜿蜒曲折，沿着山坡蜿蜒前行，直到到达山边，然后消失在视野之外，最后冲向地平线。”这些都是导演陷阱，诱人却无法拍摄。虽然这些段落的欧洲作家缺乏编剧纪律，但他们却巧妙地试图表达；而美国作家出于愤世嫉俗和懒惰，经常诉诸讽刺：

These, on the other hand, were found in submissions to the European Script Fund: “The sun sets like a tiger’s eye closing in the jungle,” and, “The road twists and knifes and gouges its way up the hillside, struggling until it reaches the rim, then disappears out of sight before bursting onto the horizon.” They are director traps, seductive but unphotographable. Although the European writers of these passages lack screenwriting discipline, they are ingenuously trying to be expressive; whereas American writers, out of cynicism and laziness, often resort to sarcasm:

“本尼，三十多岁，是个身材矮小、肌肉发达的英国人，他有一种狂躁的神情，让人觉得他一生中至少咬过一次鸡头。”还有，“你猜对了。性爱场景来了。我会写，但我妈妈读了这些东西。”很有趣，但这些作家希望我们这么想，这样我们就不会注意到他们不会写或不会写。他们诉诸于用讽刺掩盖的直白的讲述，因为他们没有技巧、天赋或自尊来创造一个能演绎出最简单的想法的场景。

“BENNY, in his thirties, is a small, muscular Englishman with an air of mania that suggests that, at least once in his life, he’s bitten the head off a chicken.” And, “You guessed it. Here comes the sex scene. I’d write it, but my mother reads these things.” Amusing, but that’s what these writers want us to think so we don’t notice that they can’t or won’t write. They’ve resorted to bald telling masked by sarcasm because they haven’t the craft, talent, or pride to create a scene that acts out the simplest of ideas.

消除“我们看到的”和“我们听到的”。“我们”并不存在。一旦进入故事仪式，剧院可能空无一人，我们根本不关心。相反，“我们看到的”注入了剧组透过镜头观察的形象，打破了剧本读者对电影的看法。

Eliminate “we see” and “we hear.” “We” doesn’t exist. Once into the story ritual, the theatre could be empty for all we care. Instead, “We see” injects an image of the crew looking through the lens and shatters the script reader’s vision of the film.

删除所有摄影机和剪辑符号。就像演员忽略行为描述一样，导演嘲笑“移调焦点”、“摇镜头”、“紧密双镜头”以及所有其他从纸上指导电影的努力。如果你写“跟踪镜头”，读者是否看到电影在他的想象中流动？不。他现在看到电影正在制作中。删除“切换”、“突然切换”、“叠化”和其他过渡。读者认为所有角度的变化都是在切换时完成的。

Eliminate all camera and editing notations. In the same way actors ignore behavioral description, directors laugh at RACK FOCUS TO, PAN TO, TIGHT TWO SHOT ON, and all other efforts to direct the film from the page. If you write TRACK ON, does the reader see a film flowing through his imagination? No. He now sees a film being made. Delete CUT TO, SMASH CUT TO, LAP DISSOLVE TO, and other transitions. The reader assumes that all changes of angle are done on a cut.

当代剧本是一部主场景作品，只包括讲述故事绝对必要的角度，仅此而已。例如：

The contemporary screenplay is a Master Scene work that includes only those angles absolutely necessary to the telling of the story and no more. For example:

内部餐厅——白天

INT. DINING ROOM—DAY

杰克走了进来，把公文包扔在门边的古董椅子上。他注意到餐桌上放着一张纸条。他走过去，拿起纸条，撕开，读了起来。然后他把纸条揉成一团，跌坐在椅子上，双手抱头。

Jack enters, dropping his briefcase on the antique chair next to the door. He notices a note propped up on the dining room table. Strolling over, he picks up the note, tears it open, and reads. Then crumpling the note, he drops into a chair, head in hands.

如果观众知道前一个场景中纸条的内容，那么描述就停留在杰克读然后瘫倒在椅子上。但是，如果观众必须读出杰克的字条，否则就无法跟上故事情节，那么：

If the audience knows the contents of the note from a previous scene, then the description stays on Jack reading and slumping into a chair. If, however, it’s vital that the audience read the note with Jack or it wouldn’t be able follow the story, then:

内部餐厅——白天

INT. DINING ROOM—DAY

杰克走进来，把公文包扔在门边的古董椅子上。他注意到餐桌上放着一张纸条。他走过去，捡起纸条，撕开。

Jack enters, dropping his briefcase on the antique chair next to the door. He notices a note propped up on the dining room table. Strolling over, he picks it up and tears it open.

插入注释：

INSERT NOTE:

书法手写体写道：杰克，我收拾好行李离开了。不要试图联系我。我有律师。她会联系我的。芭芭拉

Calligraphic handwriting reads: Jack, I’ve packed and left. Do not try to contact me. I have a lawyer. She will be in touch. Barbara

现场

ON SCENE

杰克把纸条揉成一团，跌坐在椅子上，双手抱头。

Jack crumples the note and drops into a chair, head in hands.

另一个例子：如果当杰克双手抱头坐着时，他听到外面有一辆车驶来并匆忙驶向窗前，而让观众理解杰克那一刻所看到的东西至关重要，那么继续上面的内容：

Another example: If, as Jack sits, head in hands, he were to hear a car pull outside and hurry to a window, and it’s critical to audience comprehension that they see what Jack sees at that moment, then continuing from above:

现场

ON SCENE

杰克把纸条揉成一团，跌坐在椅子上，双手抱头。

Jack crumples the note and drops into a chair, head in hands.

突然，一辆车在外面停了下来。他赶紧跑到窗边。

Suddenly, a car PULLS UP outside. He hurries to the window.

杰克的观点

JACK’S POV

穿过窗帘来到路边。芭芭拉从旅行车里走出来，打开车门，拿出行李箱。

through the curtains to the curb. Barbara gets out of her station wagon, opens the hatch and takes out suitcases.

杰克

ON JACK

从窗边转过身，将芭芭拉的纸条扔到了房间的另一边。

turning from the window, hurling Barbara’s note across the room.

然而，如果观众认为那辆车停下是芭芭拉回到杰克身边，因为她之前已经做过两次了，而杰克愤怒的反应说明了一切，那么描述就会停留在杰克在餐厅的“主镜头”上。

If, however, the audience would assume that car pulling up is Barbara coming back to Jack because she’s done it twice before and Jack’s angry reaction says it all, then the description would stay on the Master Shot of Jack in the dining room.

然而，除了基本的故事叙述角度之外，主场景剧本还让编剧对电影的方向产生了很大的影响。编剧没有给角度贴标签，而是通过将单倍行距的段落分成描述单元来暗示这些角度，并用图像和语言巧妙地指示摄像机距离和构图。例如：

Beyond the essential storytelling angles, however, the Master Scene screenplay gives the writer a strong influence on the film’s direction. Instead of labeling angles, the writer suggests them by breaking single-spaced paragraphs into units of description with images and language subtly indicating camera distance and composition. For example:

内部餐厅——白天

INT. DINING ROOM—DAY

杰克走进来，环顾空荡荡的房间。他把公文包举过头顶，然后“砰”的一声掉在门边那把脆弱的古董椅子上。他侧耳倾听。一片寂静。

Jack enters and looks around the empty room. Lifting his briefcase above his head, he drops it with a THUMP on the fragile, antique chair next to the door. He listens. Silence.

他心满意足地慢慢走向厨房，但突然停了下来。

Pleased with himself, he ambles for the kitchen, when suddenly he’s brought up short.

餐桌上，插满玫瑰花的花瓶边上，靠着一张写着他名字的纸条。

A note with his name on it sits propped against the rose-filled vase on the dinning table.

他紧张地转动着结婚戒指。

Nervously he twists his wedding ring.

他深吸一口气，走过去，捡起纸条，撕开，阅读。

Taking a breath, he strolls over, picks up the note, tears it open, and reads.

上面的内容不是写成厚厚的单倍行距散文，而是用几行白色文字将其分成五个单元，这样就暗示了顺序：一个覆盖房间大部分的广角镜头、一个穿过房间的移动镜头、一个对纸条的特写、一个对杰克无名指的更紧密的特写、以及一个到桌子的中景跟踪镜头。

Rather than writing the above into a thick block of single spaced prose, lines of white split it into five units that suggest in order: A wide angle covering most of the room, a moving shot through the room, a close-up on the note, an even tighter close-up on Jack’s ring finger, and a medium follow-shot to the table.

公文包对芭芭拉古董椅子的侮辱和杰克紧张地摆弄结婚戒指的姿势表达了他感情的变化。演员和导演总是可以自由地即兴创作自己的新作品，但这些小段落引导读者的内心通过杰克和房间、杰克和他的情绪、杰克和他的妻子（如她的笔记中所代表的那样）之间的动作/反应模式。这就是场景的生命。现在导演和演员必须在这种模式的影响下捕捉它。他们的创作任务究竟会如何。与此同时，主场景技术的效果是可读性，可转化为观看电影的感觉。

The briefcase insult to Barbara’s antique chair and Jack’s nervous gesture with his wedding ring express his shifts of feeling. Actor and director are always free to improvise new business of their own, but the miniparagraphs lead the reader’s inner eye through a pattern of action/reaction between Jack and the room, Jack and his emotions, Jack and his wife as represented in her note. That’s the life of the scene. Now director and actor must capture it under the influence of this pattern. How exactly will be their creative tasks. In the meantime, the effect of the Master Scene technique is a readability that translates into the sensation of watching a film.

图像系统

IMAGE SYSTEMS

编剧也是诗人

The Screenwriter As Poet

“可怜可怜的编剧，他不能成为诗人”这句话其实并不正确。一旦编剧理解了故事诗学的本质及其在电影中的运作方式，电影就是诗人灵魂的绝佳媒介。

“Pity the poor screenwriter, for he cannot be a poet” is not in fact true. Film is a magnificent medium for the poet’s soul, once the screenwriter understands the nature of story poetics and its workings within a film.

诗意并不意味着美丽。那些让观众在看完令人失望的电影后喃喃自语“但拍得很漂亮”的装饰性画面并不诗意。《遮蔽的天空》：它的人性内容是干涸，绝望的无意义——曾经被称为存在主义危机，小说的沙漠背景是主角生活荒芜的隐喻。然而，这部电影散发着旅游机构游记明信片般的魅力，几乎感觉不到它内心的痛苦。如果主题很美，漂亮的图片就很合适：《音乐之声》。

Poetic does not mean pretty. Decorative images of the kind that send audiences out of disappointing films muttering “but it’s beautifully photographed” are not poetic. THE SHELTERING SKY: Its human content is aridity, a desperate meaninglessness—what was once called an existential crisis, and the novel’s desert setting was metaphor for the barrenness of the protagonists’ lives. The film, however, glowed with the postcard glamour of a tourist agency travelogue, and little or nothing of the suffering at its heart could be felt. Pretty pictures are appropriate if the subject is pretty: THE SOUND OF MUSIC.

相反，诗意意味着增强的表现力。无论故事的内容是美丽还是怪诞，是精神还是世俗，是宁静还是暴力，是田园还是城市，是史诗还是私密，它都需要充分表达。一个讲得好、导演得好、表演得好的好故事，也许一部好电影。除此之外，作品的诗意表达能力也得到了丰富和深化，或许可以拍成一部伟大的电影。

Rather, poetic means an enhanced expressivity. Whether a story’s content is beautiful or grotesque, spiritual or profane, quietistic or violent, pastoral or urban, epic or intimate, it wants full expression. A good story well told, well directed and acted, and perhaps a good film. All that plus an enrichment and deepening of the work’s expressivity through its poetics, and perhaps a great film.

首先，作为故事仪式中的观众，我们对每个图像（无论是视觉图像还是听觉图像）都会做出象征性的反应。我们本能地感觉到每个物体都被选中，以表达比其本身更多的意义，因此我们给每个外延添加了内涵。当一辆汽车驶入镜头时，我们的反应不是“车辆”这样的中性想法，而是赋予它内涵。我们会想，“嗯。奔驰……有钱。或者，“兰博基尼……愚蠢的富人。”“生锈的大众……艺术家。”“哈雷戴维森……危险。”“红色 Trans-Am……性别认同问题。”然后，讲故事的人根据观众的这种自然倾向进行创作。

To begin with, as audience in the ritual of story, we react to every image, visual or auditory, symbolically. We instinctively sense that each object has been selected to mean more than itself and so we add a connotation to every denotation. When an automobile pulls into a shot, our reaction is not a neutral thought such as “vehicle”; we give it a connotation. We think, “Huh. Mercedes… rich. Or, “Lamborghini… foolishly rich.” “Rusted-out Volkswagen… artist.” “Harley-Davidson… dangerous.” “Red Trans-Am… problems with sexual identity.” The storyteller then builds on this natural inclination in the audience.

将一个精彩的故事变成诗意作品的第一步是排除 90% 的现实。世界上绝大多数物体对于任何特定电影来说都有错误的含义。因此，必须将可能的图像范围严格缩小到具有适当含义的物体。

The first step in turning a well-told story into a poetic work is to exclude 90 percent of reality. The vast majority of objects in the world have the wrong connotations for any specific film. So the spectrum of possible imagery must be sharply narrowed to those objects with appropriate implications.

例如，在制作过程中，如果导演想在镜头中添加一个花瓶，这会引起一个小时的讨论，而且是一次至关重要的讨论。什么样的花瓶？什么时期的？什么形状？颜色？陶瓷、金属还是木头？里面有花吗？什么种类的？放在哪里？前景？中景？背景？镜头的左上方？右下方？对焦还是失焦？它有灯光吗？它被当作道具触摸了吗？因为这不仅仅是一个花瓶，它还是一个高度浓缩的象征性物体，与镜头中的其他每个物体以及整部电影的前后场景都产生共鸣。与所有艺术作品一样，电影是一个整体，其中每个物体都与其他每个图像或物体相关。

In production, for example, if a director wants a vase added to a shot, this prompts an hour’s discussion, and a critical one. What kind of vase? What period? What shape? Color? Ceramic, metal, wood? Are there flowers in it? What kind? Where located? Foreground? Mid-ground? Background? Upper left of the shot? Lower right? In or out of focus? Is it lit? Is it touched as a prop? Because this isn’t just a vase, it’s a highly charged, symbolic object resonating meaning to every other object in the shot and forward and backward through the film. Like all works of art, a film is a unity in which every object relates to every other image or object.

在限定的适合内容范围内，编剧为影片赋予一个或多个图像系统，因为影片通常会有多个。

Limited to what’s appropriate, the writer then empowers the film with an Image System, or systems, for there are often more than one.

图像系统是一种主题策略，是电影中嵌入的一类图像，从头到尾在视觉和声音中不断重复，具有持久性和很大的变化，但同样具有很大的微妙性，作为一种潜意识的交流，以增加审美情感的深度和复杂性。

An IMAGE SYSTEM is a strategy of motifs, a category of imagery embedded in the film that repeats in sight and sound from beginning to end with persistence and great variation, but with equally great subtlety, as a subliminal communication to increase the depth and complexity of aesthetic emotion.

“类别”是指从物理世界中抽取的足够广泛的主题，可以包含足够的多样性。例如，自然的维度——动物、季节、光明与黑暗——或人类文化的维度——建筑、机器、艺术。这个类别必须重复，因为一两个孤立的符号效果不大。但有组织的图像回归的力量是巨大的，因为多样性和重复性将图像系统推向观众的潜意识。然而，最重要的是，电影的诗意必须以虚拟的隐形方式处理，并有意识地不被认可。

“Category” means a subject drawn from the physical world that’s broad enough to contain sufficient variety. For example, a dimension of nature—animals, the seasons, light and dark—or a dimension of human culture—buildings, machines, art. This category must repeat because one or two isolated symbols have little effect. But the power of an organized return of images is immense, as variety and repetition drive the Image System to the seat of the audience’s unconscious. Yet, and most important, a film’s poetics must be handled with virtual invisibility and go consciously unrecognized.

图像系统通过两种方式创建，即外部图像或内部图像。外部图像将电影之外已经具有象征意义的类别引入电影，使其在电影中具有与电影之外相同的含义：例如，使用国旗（爱国主义和爱国的象征）来表示爱国主义和爱国主义。例如，在《洛奇 4》中，洛奇击败俄罗斯拳击手后，用一面巨大的美国国旗裹住自己。或者使用十字架（对上帝的爱和宗教情感的象征）来表示对上帝的爱和宗教情感；蜘蛛网表示陷阱；泪珠表示悲伤。我必须指出，外部图像是学生电影的标志。

An Image System is created one of two ways, via External or Internal Imagery. External Imagery takes a category that outside the film already has a symbolic meaning and brings it in to mean the same thing in the film it means outside the film: for example, to use the national flag—a symbol of patriotism and love of country—to mean patriotism, love of country. In ROCKY IV, for example, after Rocky defeats the Russian boxer, he wraps himself in a massive American flag. Or to use a crucifix, a symbol of love of God and religious feelings, to mean love of God, religious feelings; a spider’s web to mean entrapment; a teardrop to mean sadness. External Imagery, I must point out, is the hallmark of the student film.

内在意象指的是影片之外可能有或可能没有象征意义的类别，但它被带入影片之中，并赋予其仅适用于这部电影的全新意义。

Internal Imagery takes a category that outside the film may or may not have a symbolic meaning attached but brings it into the film to give it an entirely new meaning appropriate to this film and this film alone.

《恶魔》：1955 年，导演兼编剧亨利-乔治·克鲁佐将皮埃尔·布瓦洛的小说《不该入室的人》改编成电影。片中，克里斯蒂娜（薇拉·克鲁佐饰）是一位迷人的年轻女子，但她非常害羞、安静且敏感。她从小就患有心脏病，身体状况一直不太好。多年前，她继承了巴黎郊区一处令人印象深刻的庄园，现在被改造成一所寄宿学校。她和丈夫米歇尔（保罗·默里斯饰）一起经营这所学校，米歇尔是一个虐待狂、恶毒的混蛋，喜欢把妻子当成烂泥。他和学校的一位老师妮可（西蒙·西涅莱饰）有染，他对情妇和妻子一样恶毒和残忍。

LES DIABOLIQUE: In 1955 director/screenwriter Henri-Georges Clouzot adapted Pierre Boileau’s novel, Celle Qui N’etait Pas to the screen. In it Christina (Vera Clouzot) is an attractive young woman but very shy, quiet, and sensitive. She has suffered from a heart condition since childhood and is never in the best of health. Years before she inherited an impressive estate in the suburbs of Paris that has been turned into an exclusive boarding school. She runs this school with her husband, Michel (Paul Meurisse), a sadistic, abusive, malignant bastard who delights in treating his wife like dirt. He’s having an affair with one of the school’s teachers, Nicole (Simone Signoret), and he’s as vicious and cruel to his mistress as he is to his wife.

每个人都知道这件事。事实上，这两个女人已经成为最好的朋友，都在这个暴徒的压迫下受苦。在电影的开头，她们决定，摆脱困境的唯一办法就是杀死他。

Everybody knows about this affair. In fact, the two women have become best friends, both suffering under the heel of this brute. Early in the film they decide that the only way out of their problem is to kill him.

一天晚上，他们把米歇尔引诱到离学校很远的一个村庄的公寓里，在那里他们偷偷地在浴缸里灌满了水。他穿着三件套西装进来，傲慢地嘲弄和侮辱他的两个女人，而她们则把他灌得酩酊大醉，然后试图把他淹死在浴缸里。但他并没有醉到那种程度，这真是一场艰苦的斗争。恐惧差点杀死了可怜的妻子，但妮可冲进客厅，从咖啡桌上抓起一个陶瓷豹雕像。她把这个沉重的东西放在男人的胸口上。在雕像的重量和她自己的力量的帮助下，她设法把他按在水下足够长的时间，把他淹死。

One night they lure Michel to an apartment in a village well away from the school where they’ve secretly filled a bathtub full of water. He comes in, dressed in his three-piece suit, and arrogantly taunts and insults his two women while they get him as drunk as they possibly can, then try to drown him in the bathtub. But he’s not that drunk and it’s a hell of a struggle. The terror nearly kills the poor wife, but Nicole rushes into the living room and grabs a ceramic statue of a panther from the coffee table. She loads this heavy thing on the man’s chest. Between the weight of the statue and her own strength she manages to hold him down under the water long enough to drown him.

女人们用防水布裹住尸体，藏在一辆皮卡车的后面，半夜偷偷溜回校园。学校的游泳池整个冬天都没用过，水面上长满了一英寸厚的藻类。女人把尸体扔进去，它沉到水里看不见了。她们很快就回去了，等着第二天尸体浮上来被发现。但第二天来了又去，尸体却没有浮上来。几天过去了，尸体还是没有浮上来。

The women wrap the body in a tarp, hide it in the back of a pickup truck, and sneak back to the campus in the middle of the night. The school’s swimming pool hasn’t been used all winter; an inch of algae covers the water. The women dump the body in and it submerges out of sight. They quickly retire and wait for the next day when the body will float up and be discovered. But the next day comes and goes and the body does not float up. Days go by and the body will not float up.

最后，妮可故意不小心把车钥匙掉在了游泳池里，于是请一位高年级的学生帮她捡起来。这个孩子潜入浮渣中，不停地寻找。他浮出水面，大口吸气，然后再次潜入水中，不停地寻找。他浮出水面大口吸气，然后第三次潜入水中，不停地寻找。最后他浮出水面……带着车钥匙。

Finally, Nicole accidentally on purpose drops her car keys in the pool and asks one of the older students to retrieve them. The kid dives down under the scum and searches and searches and searches. He comes up, gulps some air, then goes down again and searches and searches and searches. He comes up to gulp air, then goes down a third time and searches and searches and searches. At last he surfaces… with the car keys.

然后，女人们决定是时候清理游泳池了。她们命令把游泳池里的水排干，站在游泳池边，看着浮渣不断往下流……流到排水沟里。但是没有尸体。那天下午，一辆干洗店的货车从巴黎开来，送来了那名男子死时穿的洗干净、熨烫好的西装。女人们冲到巴黎的干洗店，在那里她们发现了一张收据，上面写着一家寄宿公寓的地址。他们去了那里，跟门房交谈，门房说：“是的，是的，这里曾经住着一个人，但是……他今天早上搬走了。”

The women then decide it’s time to clean the swimming pool. They order the pool drained and stand at its edge, watching as the scum goes down and down and down and down… to the drain. But there is no body. That afternoon a dry cleaner’s van drives out from Paris to deliver the cleaned and pressed suit that the man died in. The women rush into Paris to the cleaners where they find a receipt, and on it is the address of a boardinghouse. They head there and talk to a concierge who says, “Yes, yes, there was a man living here but… he moved this morning.”

他们回到学校，更奇怪的事情发生了：米歇尔在学校的窗户里出现又消失。当他们看高年级毕业照时，他站在学生身后，稍微有点模糊。他们无法想象发生了什么。他是鬼吗？他溺水后不知怎么活了下来，然后对我们做了这样的事？是别人发现尸体的吗？是他们干的吗？

They go back to the school and even more bizarre things happen: Michel appears and disappears in the windows of the school. When they look at the senior class graduation photo, there he is standing behind the students, slightly out of focus. They can’t imagine what’s going on. Is he a ghost? Did he somehow survive the drowning and he’s doing this to us? Did someone else find the body? Are they doing this?

暑假来临，所有学生和老师都离开了。然后妮可自己也离开了。她收拾行李，说她再也受不了了，把可怜的妻子一个人丢下。

Summer vacation comes and all the students and teachers leave. Then Nicole herself departs. She packs her bags, saying she can’t take this anymore, abandoning the poor wife alone.

那天晚上，克里斯蒂娜睡不着觉，她坐在床上，完全清醒，心脏怦怦直跳。夜深人静时，她突然听到丈夫办公室里传来打字的声音。她慢慢站起来，手放在心上，沿着一条长长的走廊走去，但就在她触摸办公室门把手时，打字声停止了。

That evening Christina can’t sleep; she sits up in bed, wide awake, her heart pounding. Suddenly in the dead of night she hears the sound of typing coming from her husband’s office. She slowly gets up and edges down a long corridor, hand on her heart, but just as she touches the office doorknob, the typing stops.

她轻轻打开门，看到打字机旁边放着丈夫的手套……就像两只巨大的手。然后她听到了最可怕的声音：滴水声。现在她朝办公室外的浴室走去，心里很愤怒。她吱吱作响地打开浴室的门，看到他——仍然穿着三件套西装，泡在装满水的浴缸里，水龙头滴水。

She eases open the door and there, alongside the typewriter, are her husband’s gloves… like two huge hands. Then she hears the most terrifying sound imaginable: dripping water. Now she heads toward the bathroom off the office, her heart raging. She creaks open the bathroom door and there he is—still in his three-piece suit, submerged in a bathtub full of water, the faucet dripping.

尸体坐了起来，水从里面流出。它的眼睛睁开，但没有眼球。有人向她伸出手，她捂住胸口，心脏病发作，倒在地上死了。米歇尔把手伸到眼皮下面，取出白色塑料插件。妮可从衣柜里跳出来。他们拥抱在一起，低声说：“我们做到了！”

The body sits up, water cascades off. Its eyes open but there are no eyeballs. Hands reach out for her, she grabs her chest, has a fatal heart attack, and drops dead on the floor. Michel reaches under his eyelids and removes white plastic inserts. Nicole jumps out of a closet. They embrace and whisper, “We did it!”

《恶魔》的片头看起来就像是一幅灰色和黑色的抽象画。但突然间，随着片头的结束，一个卡车轮胎从屏幕底部溅到顶部，我们意识到我们一直在看泥坑的俯视视角。镜头转向一片雨景。从这一刻开始，Image System 的“水”就不断地、潜意识地重复。总是阴雨绵绵，雾蒙蒙的。窗户上的冷凝水滴滴答答地流到窗台上。晚餐时他们吃鱼。人物喝着葡萄酒和茶，而克里斯蒂娜则啜饮着她的心脏病药。当老师们讨论暑假时，他们谈到去法国南部“泡温泉”。游泳池、浴缸……这是有史以来最潮湿的电影之一。

The opening titles of LES DIABOLIQUE look as if they’re over an abstract painting of grays and blacks. But suddenly, as titles end, a truck tire splashes from bottom to top of the screen and we realize we’ve been looking at the top angle view of a mud puddle. The camera comes up on a rainy landscape. From this first moment on, Image System “water” is continually and subliminally repeated. It’s always drizzly and foggy. Condensation on windows runs in little drops to the sills. At dinner they eat fish. Characters drink wine and tea while Christina sips her heart medicine. When the teachers discuss summer vacation, they talk of going to the South of France to “take the waters.” Swimming pool, bathtubs… it’s one of the dampest films ever made.

在这部电影之外，水是一切积极事物的普遍象征：神圣、净化、女性——生命本身的原型。但克鲁佐却颠倒了这些价值观，直到水承担起死亡、恐怖和邪恶的力量，水龙头滴水的声音让观众从座位上站起来。

Outside this film water is a universal symbol of all things positive: sanctification, purification, the feminine—archetype for life itself. But Clouzot reverses these values until water takes on the power of death, terror, and evil, and the sound of a dripping faucet brings the audience up out of its seats.

《卡萨布兰卡》交织了三个图像系统。其主要主题营造出一种监禁感，因为卡萨布兰卡市变成了一座虚拟监狱。角色们低声说出他们的“逃跑”计划，就好像警察是狱警一样。机场塔台上的灯塔在街道上移动，就像探照灯扫描监狱大院一样，而窗帘、房间隔断、楼梯栏杆，甚至盆栽棕榈树的叶子都像监狱牢房的栅栏一样形成阴影。

CASABLANCA weaves three Image Systems. Its primary motifs create a sense of imprisonment as the city of Casablanca becomes a virtual penitentiary. Characters whisper their “escape” plans as if the police were prison guards. The beacon on the airport tower moves through the streets like a searchlight scanning a prison compound, while window blinds, room dividers, stair railings, even the leaves of potted palms create shadows like the bars of prison cells.

第二个系统建立了从特定到原型的进程。卡萨布兰卡起初是一个难民中心，后来变成了一个小型联合国，里面不仅有阿拉伯人和欧洲人，还有亚洲人和非洲人。里克和他的朋友山姆是我们遇到的唯一的美国人。反复出现的画面，包括人物与里克交谈的对话，仿佛他是一个国家，将里克与美国联系起来，直到他象征着美国本身，卡萨布兰卡象征着世界。就像 1941 年的美国一样，里克坚定地保持中立，不想再参与另一场世界大战。他投身战争，潜意识里祝贺美国终于站到了反抗暴政的一边。

The second system builds a progression from the particular to the archetypal. Casablanca starts as a refugee center but becomes a mini-United Nations filled with not only Arab and European faces but Asian and African ones as well. Rick and his friend Sam are the only Americans we meet. Repeated images, including dialogue in which characters speak to Rick as if he were a country, associate Rick to America until he comes to symbolize America itself and Casablanca the world. Like the United States in 1941 Rick is steadfastly neutral, wanting no part in yet another World War. His conversion to the fight subliminally congratulates America for finally taking sides against tyranny.

第三个系统是连接与分离。画面中的许多图像和构图用于将里克和伊尔莎联系起来，潜意识地暗示他们虽然分开，但他们属于彼此。与此相对的是一系列将伊尔莎和拉兹洛分开的图像和构图设计，给人一种相反的印象，即他们虽然在一起，但他们属于彼此。

The third system is one of linking and separating. A number of images and compositions within the frame are used to link Rick and Ilsa, making the subliminal point that although these two are apart, they belong together. The counterpoint to this is a series of images and compositional designs that separate Ilsa from Laszlo, giving the opposite impression that although these two are together, they belong apart.

《透过黑暗的玻璃》是一部多情节电影，有六条故事线——三条正面高潮献给父亲，三条负面结局献给女儿——采用正反两方面的设计，交织了不少于四个图像系统。父亲的故事以开放空间、光明、智慧和口头交流为标志；女儿的冲突则以封闭空间、黑暗、动物形象和性来表达。

THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY is a multiplot film with six story lines—three positive climaxes devoted to the father, three negative endings to his daughter—in a point/counterpoint design that interweaves no fewer than four Image Systems. The father’s stories are marked by open spaces, light, intellect, and verbal communication; the daughter’s conflicts are expressed in closed spaces, darkness, animal images, and sexuality.

《唐人街》也采用了四个系统，两个是外部意象，两个是内部意象。主要的内化系统是“盲视”或假视的主题：窗户、后视镜、眼镜，尤其是破损的眼镜、照相机、双筒望远镜、眼睛本身，甚至是死者睁开的、看不见东西的眼睛，所有这些都汇聚了巨大的力量，表明如果我们在世界上寻找邪恶，我们就找错了方向。邪恶就在这里。在我们心中。正如毛泽东曾经说过的，“历史是症状，我们是疾病。”

CHINATOWN also employs four systems, two of External Imagery, two of Internal Imagery. The primary internalized system is motifs of “blind seeing” or seeing falsely: Windows; rearview mirrors; eyeglasses, and particularly broken spectacles; cameras; binoculars; eyes themselves, and even the open, unseeing eyes of the dead, all gather tremendous forces to suggest that if we are looking for evil out in the world, we’re looking in the wrong direction. It is in here. In us. As Mao Tse-tung once said, “History is the symptom, we are the disease.”

第二个内化系统将政治腐败转化为社会凝聚力。虚假合同、颠覆法律和腐败行为成为维系社会和创造“进步”的因素。两个外在意象系统，水与干旱、性残忍与性爱，具有传统含义，但使用起来却非常有效。

The second internalized system takes political corruption and turns it into social cement. False contracts, subverted laws, and acts of corruption become that which hold society together and create “progress.” Two systems of External Imagery, water versus drought and sexual cruelty versus sexual love have conventional connotations but are used with a sharp-edged effectiveness.

《异形》上映时，《时代》杂志刊登了一篇长达十页的文章，其中有剧照和图画，提出了一个问题：好莱坞是否做得太过分了？因为这部电影采用了高度色情的图像系统，并包含三个生动的“强奸”场景。

When ALIEN was released Time magazine ran a ten-page article with stills and drawings asking the question: Has Hollywood gone too far? For this film incorporates a highly erotic Image System and contains three vivid “rape” scenes.

当盖尔·安妮·赫德和詹姆斯·卡梅隆拍摄续集《异形》时，他们不仅将类型从恐怖片转变为动作/冒险片，还将形象系统重新塑造为母亲角色，因为里普利成为了孩子纽特（凯莉·亨恩饰演）的代孕母亲，而纽特又是她破损娃娃的代孕母亲。两人面对的是宇宙中最可怕的“母亲”，即在子宫般的巢穴中产卵的巨大怪物女王。在对话中，里普利评论道：“怪物让你怀孕。”

When Gail Anne Hurd and James Cameron made the sequel, ALIENS, they not only switched genres from Horror to Action/Adventure, they reinvented the Image System to motherhood as Ripley becomes the surrogate mother of the child Newt (Carrie Henn), who in turn is the surrogate mother of her broken doll. The two are up against the most terrifying “mother” in the universe, the gigantic monster queen who lays her eggs in a womblike nest. In dialogue, Ripley remarks, “The monsters make you pregnant.”

AFTER HOURS 只致力于一个内在的理念，但具有丰富的多样性：艺术。但不是作为生活的装饰品。相反，艺术作为武器。曼哈顿苏豪区的艺术和艺术家不断袭击主角保罗（格里芬·邓恩饰），直到他被包裹在一件艺术品中并被契奇和冲偷走。

AFTER HOURS works on only one internalized refrain but with a rich variety: Art. But not as the ornament of life. Rather, art as a weapon. The art and artists of Manhattan’s Soho district constantly assault the protagonist, Paul (Griffin Dunne), until he’s encapsulated inside a work of art and stolen by Cheech and Chong.

回顾过去几十年，希区柯克的惊悚片将宗教与性爱的形象结合在一起，而约翰·福特的西部片则将荒野与文明对立起来。事实上，回顾几个世纪，我们会发现意象系统与故事本身一样古老。荷马为他的史诗创造了美丽的主题，埃斯库罗斯、索福克勒斯和欧里庇得斯也为他们的戏剧创造了美丽的主题。莎士比亚在他的每部作品中都融入了独特的意象系统，梅尔维尔、爱伦·坡、托尔斯泰、狄更斯、奥威尔、海明威、易卜生、契诃夫、萧伯纳、贝克特也是如此——所有伟大的小说家和剧作家都信奉这一原则。

Going back through the decades, Hitchcock’s Thrillers combine images of religiosity with sexuality, while John Ford’s Westerns counterpoint wilderness with civilization. In fact, traveling back through the centuries we realize that Image Systems are as old as story itself. Homer invented beautiful motifs for his epics, as did Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides for their plays. Shakespeare submerged a unique Image System into each of his works, as did Melville, Poe, Tolstoy, Dickens, Orwell, Hemingway, Ibsen, Chekhov, Shaw, Beckett—all great novelists and playwrights have embraced this principle.

究竟是谁发明了剧本创作？是小说家和剧作家来到好莱坞、伦敦、巴黎、柏林、东京和莫斯科等艺术发源地，为无声电影创作剧本。电影的第一批主要导演，如 DW 格里菲斯、爱森斯坦和穆尔瑙，都是在剧院里学徒；他们也意识到，就像一出好戏一样，电影可以通过重复潜意识的诗意而达到崇高的境界。

And who, after all, invented screenwriting? Novelists and playwrights who came to the cradles of our art in Hollywood, London, Paris, Berlin, Tokyo, and Moscow to write the scenarios of silent films. Film’s first major directors, such as D. W. Griffith, Eisenstein, and Murnau, did their apprenticeship in the theatre; they too realized that, like a fine play, a film can be taken to the sublime by the repetition of a subliminal poetics.

而形象系统必须是潜意识的。观众不应该意识到这一点。几年前，当我观看布努埃尔的《维莉黛安娜》时，我注意到布努埃尔引入了绳索形象系统：一个孩子跳绳，一个富人用绳子上吊，一个穷人用绳子当腰带。大约第五次绳子出现在屏幕上时，观众齐声喊道：“象征！”

And an Image System must be subliminal. The audience is not to be aware of it. Years ago as I watched Buñuel’s VIRIDIANA, I noticed that Buñuel had introduced an Image System of rope: A child jump ropes, a rich man hangs himself with a rope, a poor man uses rope as a belt. About the fifth time a piece of rope came on the screen the audience shouted in unison, “Symbol!”

只要象征主义能够绕过意识，进入潜意识，它的力量就比大多数人想象的还要强大。就像我们做梦时一样。象征主义的使用遵循与电影配乐相同的原则。声音不需要认知，所以音乐可以在我们无意识的情况下深深地影响我们。同样，只要我们不把它们看作象征，象征主义就会触动我们、感动我们。对一个象征的认识会把它变成一种中性的、智力上的好奇心，无能为力，几乎毫无意义。

Symbolism is powerful, more powerful than most realize, as long as it bypasses the conscious mind and slips into the unconscious. As it does while we dream. The use of symbolism follows the same principle as scoring a film. Sound doesn’t need cognition, so music can deeply affect us when we’re unconscious of it. In the same way, symbols touch us and move us—as long as we don’t recognize them as symbolic. Awareness of a symbol turns it into a neutral, intellectual curiosity, powerless and virtually meaningless.

那么，为什么这么多当代作家/导演要给自己的象征贴上标签呢？《电影》中对“象征”形象的笨拙处理翻拍的《惊魂角》、《吸血鬼德古拉》和《钢琴课》是三个最露骨的例子。我能想到两个可能的原因：首先，为了讨好那些自认为是知识分子的精英观众，他们以安全、冷静的距离观看，同时为电影后的咖啡馆批评仪式收集弹药。其次，为了影响（如果不是控制的话）评论家和他们写的评论。夸夸其谈的象征主义不需要天才，只需要因对荣格和德里达的误读而点燃的自负。这是一种贬低和腐蚀艺术的虚荣心。

Why, then, do so many contemporary writer/directors label their symbols? The hamhanded treatment of “symbolic” images in the remake of CAPE FEAR, BRAM STOKER’S DRACULA, and THE PIANO, to name three of the more barefaced examples. I can think of two likely reasons: First, to flatter the elite audience of self-perceived intellectuals that watches at a safe, unemotional distance while collecting ammunition for the postfilm ritual of cafe criticism. Second, to influence, if not control, critics and the reviews they write. Declamatory symbolism requires no genius, just egotism ignited by misreadings of Jung and Derrida. It is a vanity that demeans and corrupts the art.

有人认为电影的影像系统是导演的作品，只有导演才能创造它。我对此没有异议，因为最终导演要对电影中每个镜头的每一寸负责。只是……有多少在职导演理解我上面的解释？很少。也许当今世界上只有二十几个。只是最好的，而不幸的是，绝大多数人无法区分装饰性摄影和表现性摄影。

Some argue that the film’s Image System is the director’s work and that he or she alone should create it. And I’ve no argument with that, for ultimately the director is responsible for every square inch of every shot in the film. Except… how many working directors understand what I’ve explained above? Few. Perhaps two dozen in the world today. Just the very best, while, unfortunately, the vast majority cannot tell the difference between decorative and expressive photography.

我认为编剧应该开始构思电影的形象系统，导演和设计师完成它。编剧首先设想了所有形象的基础，即故事的物质和社会世界。通常，在写作时，我们会自发地发现我们已经开始了这项工作，形象模式已经融入了我们的描述和对话中。当我们意识到这一点时，我们会设计出各种变化，并悄悄地将它们融入故事中。如果形象系统没有自动出现，我们会发明一个。观众不会关心我们怎么做；他们只希望故事能成功。

I argue that the screenwriter should begin the film’s Image System and the director and designers finish it. It’s the writer who first envisions the ground of all imagery, the story’s physical and social world. Often, as we write, we discover that spontaneously we’ve already begun the work, that a pattern of imagery has found its way into our descriptions and dialogue. As we become aware of that, we devise variations and quietly embroider them into the story. If an Image System doesn’t arrive on its own, we invent one. The audience won’t care how we do it; it only wants the story to work.

标题

TITLES

电影片名是营销的核心，它“定位”观众，为接下来的体验做好准备。因此，编剧不能沉迷于文学性的、非片名的片名：例如，《遗嘱》实际上是一部关于核灾难后大屠杀的电影；《面目与微笑》描绘了靠救济金生活的凄凉生活。我最喜欢的非片名是《一刻一刻》。《一刻一刻》是我一直使用的暂定片名，直到我弄清楚片名是什么。

A film’s title is the marketing centerpiece that “positions” the audience, preparing it for the experience ahead. Screenwriters, therefore, cannot indulge in literary, nontitle titles: TESTAMENT, for example, is actually a film about postnuclear holocaust; LOOKS AND SMILES portrays desolate lives on welfare. My favorite nontitle tile is MOMENT BY MOMENT. MOMENT BY MOMENT is the working title I always use until I figure out the title.

标题意味着命名。一个有效的标题指向故事中确实存在的一些内容 — 角色、背景、主题或类型。最好的标题通常会同时命名两个或所有元素。

To title means to name. An effective title points to something solid that is actually in the story—character, setting, theme, or genre. The best titles often name two or all elements at once.
