《大白鲨》为一个角色命名，将故事背景设置在荒野，并为我们呈现了人与自然对抗的主题，属于动作/冒险类型。《克莱默夫妇》为两个角色命名，主题是离婚和家庭剧。《星球大战》讲述了一场银河战士的史诗冲突。《假面》暗示了一群心理有问题的角色和隐藏身份的主题。《甜蜜的生活》将我们置于城市富人的颓废环境中。《我最好朋友的婚礼》确立了角色、背景和浪漫喜剧。

JAWS names a character, sets the story in the wilds, and gives us the theme, man against nature, in the Action/Adventure genre. KRAMER VS. KRAMER names two characters, a divorce theme, and Domestic Drama. STAR WARS titles an epic conflict of galactic warriors. PERSONA suggests a cast of psychologically troubled characters and a theme of hidden identities. LA DOLCE VITA places us in a decadent setting among the urban rich. MY BEST FRIEND’S WEDDING establishes characters, setting, and Romantic Comedy.

当然，片名并不是唯一的营销考虑因素。正如传奇人物哈里·科恩 (Harry Cohn) 曾经说过的，“《MOGAMBO》是个糟糕的片名。克拉克·盖博和艾娃·加德纳主演的《MOGAMBO》是个很棒的片名。”

A title, of course, isn’t the only marketing consideration. As the legendary Harry Cohn once observed, “MOGAMBO is a terrible title. MOGAMBO, starring Clark Gable and Ava Gardner, is a great f… ing title.”

19

作家的方法

19

A WRITER’S METHOD

专业作家可能会或可能不会获得评论界的赞誉，但他们可以掌控手艺，发挥自己的才华，多年来不断提高自己的表现，并靠艺术谋生。苦苦挣扎的作家有时可能会创作出高质量的作品，但他每天都无法在自己想要的时间和方式上发挥自己的才华，故事的质量也没有进步，而且从他的努力中获得的收入很少，甚至没有。总的来说，成功者和苦苦挣扎者之间的区别在于他们相反的工作方法：由内而外与由外而内。

Professional writers may or may not receive critical acclaim, but they’re in control of the craft, have access to their talent, improve their performance over the years, and make a living from the art. A struggling writer may at times produce quality, but from day to day he cannot make his talent perform when and as he wants, doesn’t progress in quality from story to story, and receives little, if any, income from his efforts. On the whole, the difference between those who succeed and those who struggle is their opposed methods of work: inside out versus outside in.

从外向内写作

WRITING FROM THE OUTSIDE IN

苦苦挣扎的作家往往有这样的工作方式：他想出一个主意，思考一会儿，然后直接冲到键盘前：

The struggling writer tends to have a way of working that goes something like this: He dreams up an idea, noodles on it for a while, then rushes straight to the keyboard:

外景，房屋——白天

EXT. HOUSE—DAY

描述，描述，描述。角色 A 和 B 进入。

Description, description, description. Characters A and B enter.

人物A

CHARACTER A

对话，对话，对话。

Dialogue, dialogue, dialogue.

人物 B

CHARACTER B

对话，对话，对话。

Dialogue, dialogue, dialogue.

描述，描述，描述，描述，描述。

Description, description, description, description, description.

他想象、写作、写作、梦想，直到写到第 120 页才停下。然后他把复印件发给朋友们，然后他们就会做出反应：“哦，这很好，我喜欢车库里的那个场景，他们互相泼油漆，那好笑吗？当那个小孩晚上穿着睡衣下来时，多甜蜜啊！海滩上的场景太浪漫了，当汽车爆炸时，令人兴奋。但我不知道……结尾……中间……开头……有什么地方让我不太满意。”

He imagines and writes, writes and dreams until he reaches page 120 and stops. Then he hands out Xerox copies to friends and back come their reactions: “Oh, it’s nice, and I love that scene in the garage when they threw paint all over each other, was that funny or what? And when the little kid came down at night in his pajamas, how sweet! The scene on the beach was so romantic, and when the car blew up, exciting. But I don’t know… there’s something about the ending… and the middle… and the way it starts… that just doesn’t work for me.”

因此，这位苦苦挣扎的作家收集了朋友们的反应和自己的想法，并按照以下策略开始第二稿：“我怎样才能保留我喜欢的和其他人都喜欢的六个场景，并以某种方式将它们组合成一部可行的电影？”经过一番思考，他回到了键盘前：

So the struggling writer gathers friends’ reactions and his own thoughts to start the second draft with this strategy: “How can I keep the six scenes that I love and that everyone else loves and somehow pretzel this film through them in a way that’ll work?” With a little more thought he’s back at the keyboard:

室内——夜晚

INT. HOUSE—NIGHT

描述，描述，描述。角色 A 和 C 进入，而角色 B 则躲在一旁观看。

Description, description, description. Characters A and C enter while Character B watches from hiding.

人物A

CHARACTER A

对话，对话，对话。

Dialogue, dialogue, dialogue.

人物 C

CHARACTER C

对话，对话，对话。

Dialogue, dialogue, dialogue.

描述，描述，描述，描述，描述。

Description, description, description, description, description.

他想象、写作、写作、梦想，但与此同时，他像溺水者一样紧紧抓住他最喜欢的场景，直到另一端重写出来。他复印了副本并分发给朋友，然后收到反馈：“这很不一样，绝对不一样。但我很高兴你保留了车库里的那个场景，还有那个穿着睡衣的孩子和海滩上的车……很棒的场景。但是……那个结局、中间部分以及开头的方式还是有些让我不满意。”

He imagines and writes, writes and dreams, but all the while he clings like a drowning man to his favorite scenes until a rewrite comes out the other end. He makes copies and hands them out to friends and back come reactions: “It’s different, decidedly different. But I’m so glad you kept that scene in the garage and with the kid in his pajamas and the car on the beach… great scenes. But… there’s still something about that ending and the middle and the way it starts that just doesn’t work for me.”

然后，作家又写了第三稿、第四稿和第五稿，但过程总是一样的：他坚持自己最喜欢的场景，通过这些场景来扭曲新的叙述，希望找到一个可行的故事。最后，一年过去了，他筋疲力尽。他宣布剧本完美无缺，并把它交给经纪人，经纪人读起来毫无热情，但因为他是经纪人，所以他必须这么做。他也复印了剧本，寄给好莱坞，然后读者反馈：“写得非常好，对话简洁、可演，场景描述生动，对细节的关注很好，故事很烂。放弃它。”作家责怪好莱坞的庸俗品味，并准备下一个项目。

The writer then does a third draft and a fourth and a fifth but the process is always the same: He clings to his favorite scenes, twisting a new telling through them in hopes of finding a story that works. Finally a year’s gone by and he’s burned out. He declares the screenplay perfect and hands it to his agent, who reads it without enthusiasm, but because he’s an agent, he does what he must. He too makes copies, papers Hollywood, and back come reader reports: “Very nicely written, good crisp, actable dialogue, vivid scene description, fine attention to detail, the story sucks. PASS ON IT.” The writer blames the Philistine tastes of Hollywood and gears up for his next project.

从内而外的写作

WRITING FROM THE INSIDE OUT

成功的作家往往采用相反的过程。如果乐观地假设，一个剧本从最初的想法到最终的草稿可以在六个月内完成，那么这些作家通常会在这六个月中的前四个月里，在一叠三乘五的卡片上写作：每一幕一叠——三、四，也许更多。在这些卡片上，他们创建了故事的步骤大纲。

Successful writers tend to use the reverse process. If, hypothetically and optimistically, a screenplay can be written from first idea to last draft in six months, these writers typically spend the first four of those six months writing on stacks of three-by-five cards: a stack for each act—three, four, perhaps more. On these cards they create the story’s step-outline.

步骤大纲

Step-Outline

顾名思义，分步大纲就是按步骤讲述的故事。

As the term implies, a step-outline is the story told in steps.

作者使用一两句陈述，简单而清晰地描述每个场景中发生的事情，以及它如何构建和转折。例如：“他进来以为会发现她在家里，但却发现她的纸条上写着她永远离开了。”

Using one- or two-sentence statements, the writer simply and clearly describes what happens in each scene, how it builds and turns. For example: “He enters expecting to find her at home, but instead discovers her note saying she’s left for good.”

在每张卡片的背面，作者标明他认为这个场景至少目前满足了故事设计中的哪一步。哪些场景设置了激励事件？哪个是激励事件？第一幕高潮？也许是中幕高潮？第二幕？第三幕？第四幕？或者更多？他对主情节和次要情节都这样做。

On the back of each card the writer indicates what step in the design of the story he sees this scene fulfilling—at least for the moment. Which scenes set up the Inciting Incident? Which is the Inciting Incident? First Act Climax? Perhaps a Mid-Act Climax? Second Act? Third? Fourth? Or more? He does this for Central Plot and subplots alike.

他连续几个月只玩几叠卡片关键原因是：他想毁掉自己的作品。品味和经验告诉他，无论他多么有才华，他所写的一切中 90% 充其量也只是平庸之作。为了耐心地寻找品质，他必须创造远超其所能使用的材料，然后将其毁掉。他可能会用十几种不同的方式勾勒出一个场景，最后才将场景的想法从大纲中剔除。他可能会毁掉整个场景。一个对自己的才华充满信心的作家知道他可以创造的东西是无限的，因此，为了追求一个宝石级的故事，他会抛弃一切不如自己最好的作品。

He confines himself to a few stacks of cards for months on end for this critical reason: He wants to destroy his work. Taste and experience tell him that 90 percent of everything he writes, regardless of his genius, is mediocre at best. In his patient search for quality, he must create far more material than he can use, then destroy it. He may sketch a scene a dozen different ways before finally throwing the idea of the scene out of the outline. He may destroy sequences, whole acts. A writer secure in his talent knows there’s no limit to what he can create, and so he trashes everything less than his best on a quest for a gem-quality story.

然而，这个过程并不意味着作家不会写满纸页。日复一日，书桌边堆满了一大堆文件：但这些都是传记、虚构世界及其历史、主题符号、图像，甚至是词汇和习语的片段。各种各样的研究和想象填满了一个文件柜，而故事则被严格按照步骤大纲进行。

This process, however, doesn’t mean the writer isn’t filling pages. Day after day a huge stack grows on the side of the desk: but these are biographies, the fictional world and its history, thematic notations, images, even snippets of vocabulary and idiom. Research and imaginings of all kinds fill a file cabinet while the story is disciplined to the step-outline.

最后，经过几周或几个月，作家发现了他的故事高潮。有了这个，他可以根据需要，从头开始重新创作。最后，他有了一个故事。现在他去找朋友，但不是要求他们抽出一天时间——当我们想让一个认真的人读剧本时，我们就是这样要求的。相反，他倒了一杯咖啡，要求他们抽出十分钟时间。然后他开始讲述他的故事。

Finally, after weeks or months, the writer discovers his Story Climax. With that in hand, he reworks, as needed, backward from it. At last he has a story. Now he goes to friends, but not asking for a day out of their lives—which is what we ask when we want a conscientious person to read a screenplay. Instead he pours a cup of coffee and asks for ten minutes. Then he pitches his story.

作者从不向人们展示他的分步大纲，因为它是一种工具，除了作者本人以外，其他人都无法理解。相反，在这个关键阶段，他想要讲述或介绍他的故事，这样他就能看到它随着时间的推移而展开，看到它在另一个人的思想和感受上发挥作用。他想看着那个人的眼睛，看到故事在那里发生。所以他介绍并研究反应：我的朋友是否被我的激励事件吸引住了？倾听并倾身？还是他的眼睛在游移不定？我在构建和转变进展时是否抱着他？当我达到高潮时，我是否得到了我想要的那种强烈反应？

The writer never shows his step-outline to people because it’s a tool, too cryptic for anyone but the writer to follow. Instead, at this critical stage, he wants to tell or pitch his story so he can see it unfold in time, watch it play on the thoughts and feelings of another human being. He wants to look in that person’s eyes and see the story happen there. So he pitches and studies the reactions: Is my friend hooked by my Inciting Incident? Listening and leaning in? Or are his eyes wandering? Am I holding him as I build and turn the progressions? And when I hit the Climax, do I get a strong reaction of the kind I want?

任何从大纲开始向聪明、敏感的人推销的故事都必须能够吸引注意力，保持十分钟的兴趣，并通过将他带入有意义的情感体验来获得回报——就像我的《恶魔》推销吸引、留住和感动你一样。无论类型如何，如果一个故事不能在十分钟内奏效分钟，那么在 110 分钟内效果如何？规模变大后效果不会更好。十分钟的宣传中出现的所有问题在屏幕上看起来要糟糕十倍。

Any story pitched from its step-outline to an intelligent, sensitive person must be able to grab attention, hold interest for ten minutes, and pay it off by moving him to a meaningful, emotional experience—just as my LES DIABOLIQUE pitch hooked, held, and moved you. Regardless of genre, if a story can’t work in ten minutes, how will it work in 110 minutes? It won’t get better when it gets bigger. Everything that’s wrong with it in a ten-minute pitch is ten times worse onscreen.

除非大多数听众都热情响应，否则继续下去是没有意义的。“热情响应”并不意味着人们会跳起来亲吻你的双颊，而是他们会低声说“哇”，然后就沉默了。一件精美的艺术作品——音乐、舞蹈、绘画、故事——有能力让脑海中的喋喋不休安静下来，并将我们带到另一个境界。当一个故事，按照步骤大纲提出，如此强大以至于带来沉默——没有评论，没有批评，只有愉悦的表情——那是一件了不起的事情，时间太宝贵了，不能浪费在一个没有这种力量的故事上。现在，作家准备进入下一个阶段——处理。

Until a good majority of listeners respond with enthusiasm, there’s no point going forward. “With enthusiasm” doesn’t mean people leap up and kiss you on both cheeks, rather they whisper “Wow” and fall silent. A fine work of art—music, dance, painting, story—has the power to silence the chatter in the mind and lift us to another place. When a story, pitched from a step-outline, is so strong it brings silence—no comments, no criticism, just a look of pleasure—that’s a hell of a thing and time is too precious to waste on a story that hasn’t that power. Now the writer’s ready to move to the next stage—the treatment.

治疗

Treatment

为了“处理”分步大纲，作者将每个场景从一两句话扩展为一段或多段双倍行距、现在时、逐刻的描述：

To “treat” the step-outline, the writer expands each scene from its one or two sentences to a paragraph or more of double-spaced, present-tense, moment by moment description:

餐厅——白天杰克走进来，把公文包扔在门边的椅子上。他环顾四周。房间里空无一人。他叫了她的名字。没有人回应。他又叫了一次，声音越来越大。还是没有人回应。当他走到厨房时，他看到桌子上有一张纸条。他捡起它，读了起来。纸条上说她已经永远离开了他。他倒在椅子上，双手抱头，开始哭泣。

Dining Room—Day Jack walks in and tosses his briefcase on the chair next to the door. He looks around. The room is empty. He calls her name. Gets no answer. He calls it again, louder and louder. Still no answer. As he pads to the kitchen, he sees a note on the table. Picks it up, reads it. The note says that she has left him for good. He drops in the chair, head in hands, and starts to cry.

在治疗中，作者指出人物谈论的内容——例如“他想让她这样做，但她拒绝了”，但从不写对话。相反，他创造了潜台词——所说和所做的背后真实的想法和感受。我们可能认为我们知道人物的想法和感受，但我们不知道我们知道什么，直到我们把它写下来：

In treatment the writer indicates what characters talk about—“he wants her to do this, but she refuses,” for example—but never writes dialogue. Instead, he creates the subtext—the true thoughts and feelings underneath what is said and done. We may think we know what our characters are thinking and feeling, but we don’t know we know until we write it down:

餐厅——白天门开了，杰克靠在门框上，一天的工作失败而令人沮丧，他筋疲力尽。他看起来在房间里转了一圈，发现她不在，他真心希望她不在。他今天真的不想和她打交道。为了确保房子里只有他一个人，他叫了她的名字。没有人回答。他叫得越来越大声。还是没有人回答。太好了。他终于一个人了。他把公文包高高举起，砰的一声扔在她珍贵的齐本德尔椅上，就在门边。她讨厌他刮坏她的古董，但今天他一点也不在乎。

Dining Room—Day The door opens and Jack leans on the jamb, exhausted from a day of failed and frustrating work. He looks around the room, sees she’s not around, and hopes like hell she’s out. He really doesn’t want to have to deal with her today. To be sure he has the house to himself, he calls her name. Gets no answer. Calls out louder and louder. Still no answer. Good. He’s finally alone. He lifts his briefcase high in the air drops it with a thud onto her precious Chippendale chair next to the door. She hates him for scratching her antiques but today he doesn’t give a damn.

他饿了，就往厨房走去，但当他穿过房间时，他注意到餐桌上有一张纸条。这是她经常留下的那些该死的、令人讨厌的纸条之一，贴在浴室的镜子或冰箱上或任何地方。他恼怒地捡起它并撕开。读完它，他发现她已经永远离开了他。他的腿发软，跌坐在椅子上，心里打了个结。他把头埋在手里，开始哭泣。他对自己爆发的情绪感到惊讶，很高兴他还能感受到一些情感。但他的眼泪不是悲伤；而是堤坝决堤，因为这段关系终于结束了而感到如释重负。

Hungry, he heads for the kitchen, but as he crosses the room he notices a note on the dining-room table. It’s one of those damn, annoying notes that she’s always leaving around, taped to the bathroom mirror or the refrigerator or whatever. Irritated, he picks it up and tears it open. Reading it, he discovers that she’s left him for good. As his legs go weak, he drops into a chair, a knot twisting in his gut. His head falls into his hands and he starts to cry. He’s surprised by his outburst, pleased he can still feel some emotion. But his tears are not grief; they’re the dam breaking with relief that the relationship is finally over.

* * *

*  *  *

一部典型的剧本有四十到六十个场景，逐一描述​​所有动作，并辅以所有角色有意识和无意识的想法和感受的完整潜台词，将产生六十、八、九十或更多双倍行距的页面。在 20 世纪 30 年代到 50 年代的制片厂制度下，制片人要求编剧处理剧本时，剧本通常长达两百到三百页。制片厂编剧的策略是从一部更大的作品中提取剧本，这样就不会遗漏或忽略任何内容。

The forty to sixty scenes of a typical screenplay, treated to a moment by moment description of all action, underlaid with a full subtext of the conscious and unconscious thoughts and feelings of all characters, will produce sixty, eight, ninety, or more double-spaced pages. In the studio system from the 1930s to the 1950s when producers ordered treatments from writers, they were often two hundred to three hundred pages long. The strategy of studio writers was to extract the screenplay from a much larger work so nothing would be overlooked or unthought.

如今，娱乐界流传的十到十二页的“大纲”并非大纲，而是足够让读者理解故事情节的大纲。十页的大纲对于剧本来说远远不够。如今的作家可能不会再回到片厂体制下的庞大大纲，但当分步大纲扩展到六十到九十页的大纲时，创作成就也会相应增加。

The ten- or twelve-page “treatments” that pass around show business today are not treatments but outlines given enough words that a reader can follow the story. A ten-page outline is not nearly enough material for a screenplay. Today’s writers may not return to the vast treatments of the studio system, but when a step-outline is expanded to a treatment of sixty to ninety pages, creative achievement expands correspondingly.

在治疗阶段，我们不可避免地会发现我们设想在分步大纲中会以某种方式发挥作用，现在我们想改变。研究和想象永不停歇，因此角色和他们的世界仍在成长和发展，这促使我们修改许多场景。我们不会改变故事的整体设计，因为它每次我们提出时都有效。但在这个结构中，场景可能需要被删减、添加或重新排序。我们重新处理处理，直到每一个时刻都生动地活在文本和潜台词中。完成之后，作者才会转向剧本本身。

At the treatment stage, we inevitably discover that things we thought would work a certain way in the step-outline now want to change. Research and imagination never stop, and so the characters and their world are still growing and evolving, leading us to revise any number of scenes. We won’t change the overall design of the story because it worked every time we pitched it. But within that structure scenes may need to be cut, added, or reordered. We rework the treatment until every moment lives vividly, in text and subtext. That done, then and only then does the writer move to the screenplay itself.

剧本

SCREENPLAY

根据详尽的剧本编写剧本是一件乐事，通常每天可以完成五到十页。现在，我们将剧本描述转换为屏幕描述并添加对话。此时编写的对话总是我们写过的最好的对话。我们的角色嘴上贴着胶带很久了，他们迫不及待地想说话，与许多电影中所有角色都使用相同的词汇和风格说话不同，经过深入准备后编写的对话会创造出特定角色的声音。他们听起来并不都像彼此，也不都像作者。

Writing a screenplay from a thorough treatment is a joy and often runs at a clip of five to ten pages per day. We now convert treatment description to screen description and add dialogue. And dialogue written at this point is invariably the finest dialogue we’ve ever written. Our characters have had tape over their mouths for so long, they can’t wait to talk, and unlike so many films in which all characters speak with the same vocabulary and style, dialogue written after in-depth preparation creates character-specific voices. They don’t all sound like one another and they don’t all sound like the writer.

在初稿阶段，仍然需要进行修改和修订。当角色被允许说话时，你认为会以某种方式进行的场景现在需要改变方向。当你发现这样的错误时，它很少能通过简单地重写对话或行为来修复。相反，你必须回到剧本中，重新设计设置，然后也许超越有缺陷的场景，重新完成结局。在你完成最终稿之前，可能需要进行多次润色。你必须培养自己的判断力和品味，对自己糟糕的写作有敏锐的嗅觉，然后鼓起勇气，根除弱点，把它们变成优势。

At the first draft stage, changes and revisions will still be needed. When characters are allowed to speak, scenes in treatment you thought would work a certain way now want to alter direction. When you find such a fault, it can rarely be fixed with a simple rewrite of dialogue or behavior. Rather, you must go back into the treatment and rework the setups, then perhaps go beyond the faulty scene to redo the payoff. A number of polishes may be necessary until you reach the final draft. You must develop your judgment and taste, a nose for your own bad writing, then call upon a relentless courage to root out weaknesses and turn them into strengths.

如果你走捷径，直接从大纲开始写剧本，那么你的初稿实际上并不是剧本，而是一种替代处理——一种狭隘、未经探索、未经即兴发挥、薄如纸的处理。事件选择和故事设计必须自由发挥，以消耗你的想象力和知识。转折点必须想象、抛弃、重新想象，然后在文本和潜台词中展现出来。否则，你几乎没有希望实现卓越。现在，你想如何以及何时做到这一点？在治疗中还是在剧本中？两者都可能有效，但剧本往往是一个陷阱。明智的作家会尽可能推迟对话的写作，因为过早的对话写作会扼杀创造力。

If you shortcut the process and rush straight to screenplay from outline, the truth is that your first draft is not a screenplay, it’s a surrogate treatment—a narrow, unexplored, unimprovised, tissue-thin treatment. Event choice and story design must be given free rein to consume your imagination and knowledge. Turning Points must be imagined, discarded, and reimagined, then played out in text and subtext. Otherwise you have little hope of achieving excellence. Now, how and when do you want to do that? In treatment or screenplay? Either may work, but, more often than not, screenplay is a trap. The wise writer puts off the writing of dialogue for as long as possible because the premature writing of dialogue chokes creativity.

从外向内写作——写对话以寻找场景，写场景以寻找故事——是最缺乏创造性的方法。编剧习惯性地过分重视对话，因为这是我们写的唯一真正能传达给观众的文字。其他一切都由电影的画面决定。如果我们在知道会发生什么之前就把对话打出来，我们不可避免地会爱上我们的文字；我们不愿意玩弄和探索事件，不愿意发现我们的角色可能会变得多么迷人，因为这意味着要删掉我们无价的对话。所有的即兴创作都停止了，我们所谓的重写就是对演讲进行修补。

Writing from the outside in—writing dialogue in search of scenes, writing scenes in search of story—is the least creative method. Screenwriters habitually overvalue dialogue because they’re the only words we write that actually reach the audience. All else is assumed by the film’s images. If we type out dialogue before we know what happens, we inevitably fall in love with our words; we’re loath to play with and explore events, to discover how fascinating our characters might become, because it would mean cutting our priceless dialogue. All improvisation ceases and our so-called rewriting is tinkering with speeches.

更重要的是，过早地写对话是最慢的工作方式。它可能会让你绕圈子好几年，直到你最终意识到，并不是所有的孩子都能通过自己的言行举止登上大银幕；并不是每个想法都值得拍成电影。你想什么时候发现这一点？两年后还是两个月后？如果你先写对话，你将对这个事实视而不见，永远徘徊不前。如果你从内而外地写作，你会在大纲阶段意识到你无法让这个故事发挥作用。没有人喜欢它。事实上，你不喜欢它。所以你把它扔进抽屉里。也许几年后你会捡起它并解决这个问题，但现在你要继续你的下一个想法。

What’s more, the premature writing of dialogue is the slowest way to work. It may send you in circles for years before you finally realize that not all your children are going to walk and talk their way to the screen; not every idea is worth being a motion picture. When do you want to find that out? Two years from now or two months from now? If you write the dialogue first, you’ll be blind to this truth and wander forever. If you write from the inside out, you’ll realize in the outline stage that you can’t get the story to work. Nobody likes it when pitched. In truth, you don’t like it. So you toss it in the drawer. Maybe years from now you’ll pick it up and solve it, but for now you go on to your next idea.

当我向你们介绍这种方法时，我完全明白我们每个人都必须通过反复试验找到自己的方法，确实有些作家会走捷径跳过处理阶段，创作出高质量的剧本，事实上也有一些作家从外到内写得非常好。但我也想知道，如果他们付出更多的努力，他们可能会取得什么样的辉煌成就。因为由内而外的方法是一种既有纪律又自由的工作方式，旨在鼓励你创作出最好的作品。

As I offer this method to you, I’m fully aware that each of us, by trial and error, must find our own method, that indeed some writers short-cut the treatment stage and produce quality screenplays, and that in fact a few have written very well from the outside in. But I’m also left to wonder what brilliance they might have achieved had they taken greater pains. For the inside-out method is a way of working that’s both disciplined and free, designed to encourage your finest work.

消退

FADE OUT

你已经将《故事》创作到了最后一章，而这一步，让你的职业生涯走向了许多作家所害怕的方向。有些人担心意识到自己是如何写作会削弱他们的自发性，所以从不学习这门手艺。相反，他们步调一致地遵循无意识的习惯，认为这是本能。他们创造独特、充满力量和奇迹的作品的梦想很少实现，甚至从未实现过。他们度过了漫长而艰难的日子，因为无论怎样走，作家的道路从来都不是一帆风顺的，因为他们有天赋，他们的努力不时会赢得掌声，但在内心深处，他们知道他们只是在利用才华散步。这样的作家让我想起了我父亲喜欢背诵的一则寓言的主人公：

You have pursued Story to its final chapter, and, with this step, taken your career in a direction many writers fear. Some, dreading that awareness of how they do what they do would cripple their spontaneity, never study the craft. Instead, they march along in a lockstep of unconscious habit, thinking it’s instinct. Their dreams of creating unique works of power and wonder are seldom, if ever, realized. They put in long, tough days, for no matter how it’s taken, the writer’s road is never smooth, and because they have a gift, from time to time their efforts draw applause, but in their secret selves they know they’re just taking talent for a walk. Such writers remind me of the protagonist of a fable my father loved to recite:

一只千足虫在森林地表上方高处，沿着树枝漫步，它的上千对腿轻松地摆动着。树顶上的鸣禽俯视着它，被千足虫步伐的同步性所吸引。“这真是一个惊人的天赋，”鸣禽们叽叽喳喳地叫道。“你的肢体比我们能数的还多。你是怎么做到的？”千足虫生平第一次想到了这一点。“是的，”她想知道，“我该怎么做呢？”当她转过身去回头看时，她那竖起的腿突然撞在一起，像常春藤一样纠缠在一起。鸣禽们笑了，因为千足虫在慌乱中扭成一团，摔倒在地上。

High above the forest floor, a millipede strolled along the branch of a tree, her thousand pairs of legs swinging in an easy gait. From the tree top, song birds looked down, fascinated by the synchronization of the millipede’s stride. “That’s an amazing talent,” chirped the songbirds. “You have more limbs than we can count. How do you do it?” And for the first time in her life the millipede thought about this. “Yes,” she wondered, “how do I do what I do?” As she turned to look back, her bristling legs suddenly ran into one another and tangled like vines of ivy. The songbirds laughed as the millipede, in a panic of confusion, twisted herself into a knot and fell to the earth below.

你可能也感受到了这种恐慌。我知道，即使是最有经验的作家，在面对一连串的见解时也会不知所措。幸运的是，我父亲的寓言有第二幕：

You too may sense this panic. I know that when confronted with a rush of insights even the most experienced writer can be knocked off stride. Fortunately, my father’s fable had an Act Two:

在森林的地面上，千足虫意识到只是自尊心受到了伤害，于是它慢慢地、小心翼翼地、一肢一肢地解开了身体。它耐心而努力地研究、弯曲和测试着自己的肢体，直到它能够站立和行走。曾经的本能变成了知识。它意识到自己不必以过去缓慢、死记硬背的速度移动。它能够漫步、昂首阔步、腾跃，甚至奔跑和跳跃。然后，它前所未有地聆听着鸣禽的交响乐，让音乐触动它的心灵。现在，它已经完全掌控了成千上万条灵巧的腿，鼓起勇气，用自己的风格，跳着令人眼花缭乱的舞蹈，让她世界里的所有生物都感到惊讶。

On the forest floor, the millipede, realizing that only her pride was hurt, slowly, carefully, limb by limb, unraveled herself. With patience and hard work, she studied and flexed and tested her appendages, until she was able to stand and walk. What was once instinct became knowledge. She realized she didn’t have to move at her old, slow, rote pace. She could amble, strut, prance, even run and jump. Then, as never before, she listened to the symphony of the songbirds and let music touch her heart. Now in perfect command of thousands of talented legs, she gathered courage and, with a style of her own, danced and danced a dazzling dance that astonished all the creatures of her world.

每天写作，一行一行，一页一页，一小时一小时。把故事放在手边。用你从中学到的东西作为指导，直到掌握它的原则变得像你与生俱来的天赋一样自然。尽管害怕，也要这样做。因为最重要的是，除了想象力和技能之外，世界对你的要求是勇气，敢于冒着被拒绝、嘲笑和失败的风险。当你追寻有意义和美丽的故事时，要深思熟虑地学习，但要大胆地写作。然后，就像寓言中的英雄一样，你的舞蹈将让世界眼花缭乱。

Write every day, line by line, page by page, hour by hour. Keep Story at hand. Use what you learn from it as a guide, until command of its principles becomes as natural as the talent you were born with. Do this despite fear. For above all else, beyond imagination and skill, what the world asks of you is courage, courage to risk rejection, ridicule and failure. As you follow the quest for stories told with meaning and beauty, study thoughtfully but write boldly. Then, like the hero of the fable, your dance will dazzle the world.

推荐阅读

SUGGESTED READINGS

我的教育受益于数百本有关故事艺术的书籍和文章的作者。不过，下面是一份最有见地、最鼓舞人心的作品清单。

My education owes a debt to the writers of many hundreds of books and essays on the art of story. Below, however, is a shortlist of works that have been the most insightful, the most inspiring.

亚里士多德的《诗学》。斯蒂芬·哈利韦尔翻译并评论。教堂山：北卡罗来纳大学出版社，1986 年。

Aristotle’s Poetics. Translation and commentary by Stephen Halliwell. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1986.

Bjorkman，Stig，Torsten Manns 和 Jonas Sima。《伯格曼论伯格曼》。Paul Britten Austin 译。纽约：西蒙与舒斯特出版社，1973 年。

Bjorkman, Stig, Torsten Manns, and Jonas Sima. Bergman on Bergman. Translation by Paul Britten Austin. New York: Simon & Schuster, 1973.

布斯，韦恩·C。《小说的修辞学》。第二版。芝加哥：芝加哥大学出版社，1983 年。

Booth, Wayne C. The Rhetoric of Fiction. 2d ed. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1983.

伯克，肯尼斯。《文学形式哲学》。伯克利：加州大学出版社，1974 年。

Burke, Kenneth. The Philosophy of Literary Form. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1974.

伯内特，哈莉和惠特·伯内特。《小说作家手册》。纽约：巴诺书店，1979 年。

Burnett, Hallie, and Whit Burnett. The Fiction Writer’s Handbook. New York: Barnes & Noble, 1979.

坎贝尔，约瑟夫。《千面英雄》。第二版。新泽西州普林斯顿：普林斯顿大学出版社，1972 年。

Campbell, Joseph. The Hero with a Thousand Faces. 2d ed. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1972.

弗里德曼，诺曼。《小说的形式与意义》。雅典：佐治亚大学出版社，1975 年。

Friedman, Norman. Form and Meaning in Fiction. Athens: University of Georgia Press, 1975.

加德纳，约翰。《论成为一名小说家》。纽约：Harper & Row，1983 年。

Gardner, John. On Becoming a Novelist. New York: Harper & Row, 1983.

詹姆斯，亨利。《小说的艺术》。RP Blackmur 编辑。纽约：Scribner's，1932 年。

James, Henry. The Art of the Novel. Edited by R. P. Blackmur. New York: Scribner’s, 1932.

科斯特勒，亚瑟。《创造行为》。纽约：麦克米伦，1964 年。

Koestler, Arthur. The Act of Creation. New York: Macmillan, 1964.

Langer, Susanne K. 《感觉与形式》。纽约：麦克米伦，1977 年。

Langer, Susanne K. Feeling and Form. New York: Macmillan, 1977.

劳森，约翰·霍华德。《电影：创作过程》。纽约：Hill & Wang，1964 年。

Lawson, John Howard. Film: The Creative Process. New York: Hill & Wang, 1964.

劳森，约翰·霍华德。《剧本创作和电影剧本创作的理论与技巧》。纽约：GP Putnam's，1949 年。

Lawson, John Howard. The Theory and Technique of Playwriting and Screenwriting. New York: G.P. Putnam’s, 1949.

马梅特，大卫。《论电影导演》。纽约：维京出版社，1981 年。

Mamet, David. On Directing Film. New York: Viking Press, 1981.

Rowe，Kenneth T.写那部剧本。纽约：Funk & Wagnalls，1939 年，1968 年。

Rowe, Kenneth T. Write That Play. New York: Funk & Wagnalls, 1939, 1968.

Scholes, Robert 和 Robert Kellogg。《叙事的本质》。牛津：牛津大学出版社，1966 年。

Scholes, Robert, and Robert Kellogg. The Nature of Narrative. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1966.

电影作品

FILMOGRAPHY

意外的旅客（美国/1988）

THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST (US/1988)

剧本由弗兰克·加拉蒂、劳伦斯·卡斯丹撰写。

Screenplay by Frank Galati, Lawrence Kasdan.

改编自安妮·泰勒的小说。

Based on the novel by Anne Tyler.

ADAM 的 RIB（美国/1949）

ADAM’s RIB (US/1949)

作者为露丝·戈登 (Ruth Gordon) 和加森·卡宁 (Garson Kanin)。

Written by Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin.

沉迷于爱情（美国/1997）

ADDICTED TO LOVE (US/1997)

由罗伯特·戈登（Robert Gordon）撰写。

Written by Robert Gordon.

下班后（美国/1985）

AFTER HOURS (US/1985)

作者为约瑟夫·米尼翁 (Joseph Minion)。

Written by Joseph Minion.

满天飞（美国/1980）

AIRPLANE (US/1980)

由吉姆·亚伯拉罕斯 (Jim Abrahams)、大卫·扎克 (David Zucker)、杰瑞·扎克 (Jerry Zucker) 撰写。

Written by Jim Abrahams, David Zucker, Jerry Zucker.

爱丽丝不再住在这里 (美国/1974)

ALICE DOESN’T LIVE HERE ANYMORE (US/1974)

作者为罗伯特·盖切尔 (Robert Getchell)。

Written by Robert Getchell.

爱丽丝梦游仙境（美国/1951）

ALICE IN WONDERLAND (US/1951)

动画电影改编自刘易斯·卡罗尔的《爱丽丝梦游仙境》和《爱丽丝镜中奇遇记》。

Animated film based on The Adventures of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass by Lewis Carroll.

异形（美国/1979）

ALIEN (US/1979)

剧本由丹·欧班农 (Dan O'Bannon) 撰写。

Screenplay by Dan O’Bannon.

改编自丹·欧班农 (Dan O'Bannon)、罗纳德·舒塞特 (Ronald Shusett) 的故事。

Based on a story by Dan O’Bannon, Ronald Shusett.

异形（美国/1986）

ALIENS (US/1986)

剧本由詹姆斯·卡梅隆撰写。

Screenplay by James Cameron.

该片改编自詹姆斯·卡梅隆、大卫·吉勒、沃尔特·希尔的故事，以及丹·欧班农、罗纳德·舒塞特创作的人物。

Based on a story by James Cameron, David Giler, Walter Hill, and on characters created by Dan O’Bannon, Ronald Shusett.

活着（美国/1993）

ALIVE (US/1993)

剧本由约翰·帕特里克·尚利 (John Patrick Shanley) 编写。

Screenplay by John Patrick Shanley.

根据皮尔斯·保罗·里德 (Piers Paul Read) 的非小说类叙述改编。

Based on the nonfiction account by Piers Paul Read.

爵士乐 (美国/1979)

ALL THAT JAZZ (US/1979)

由罗伯特·艾伦·奥瑟 (Robert Alan Aurther)、鲍勃·福斯 (Bob Fosse) 撰写。

Written by Robert Alan Aurther, Bob Fosse.

阿玛迪斯（美国/1984）

AMADEUS (US/1984)

Screenplay by Peter Shaffer.

根据彼得·谢弗 (Peter Shaffer) 的原创舞台剧改编。

Based on the original stage play by Peter Shaffer.

受约瑟夫康拉德的中篇小说《黑暗之心》的启发。

Suggested by the novella Heart of Darkness by Joseph Conrad.

Based on the novel by Theodore Isaac Perry.

LES DIABOLIQUES (Fr/1954)

剧本由杰弗里·普莱斯 (Jeffrey Price)、彼得·S·西曼 (Peter S. Seaman) 撰写。

Screenplay by Jeffrey Price, Peter S. Seaman.

改编自加里·K·沃尔夫的小说《谁审查了兔子罗杰？》 。

Based on the novel Who Censored Roger Rabbit? by Gary K. Wolf.

绿野仙踪（美国/1939）

The WIZARD OF OZ (US/1939)

剧本由诺埃尔·兰利 (Noel Langley)、弗洛伦斯·赖尔森 (Florence Ryerson) 和埃德加·爱伦·伍尔夫 (Edgar Allen Woolf) 编写。

改编自 L. Frank Baum 的小说《绿野仙踪》

Based on the novel The Wonderful Wizard of Oz by L. Frank Baum.

黄色潜水艇（英国/1968）

THE YELLOW SUBMARINE (UK/1968)

剧本由李米诺夫 (Lee Minoff)、艾尔布罗达克斯 (Al Brodax)、杰克门德尔松 (Jack Mendelsohn) 和埃里希西格尔 (Erich Segal) 编写。

Screenplay by Lee Minoff, Al Brodax, Jack Mendelsohn, Erich Segal.

根据约翰·列侬和保罗·麦卡特尼的歌曲改编。

Based on the song by John Lennon and Paul McCartney.

零导引, 47

致谢

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

我要感谢我的妻子苏珊娜·柴尔兹 (Suzanne Childs)，感谢她对事实的敏感，感谢她敏锐的编辑眼光、省略多余文字的不懈努力、感谢她无误的逻辑、乐观、鼓舞人心……感谢她对我的爱。

For her sensitivity to the truth, for her unblinking editorial eye and omnivorous will to omit needless words, her unerring logic, optimism, inspiration … for her love, I thank my wife, Suzanne Childs.

作为精明帮凶的幸运伙伴，我愿意忍受粗糙的草稿、填补漏洞、打磨粗糙的边缘，并明智地指出事物并不总是意味着作者所认为的意思，我感谢杰西·莫尼、盖尔·麦克纳马拉和我的编辑安德鲁·阿尔巴尼斯。

As the lucky associate of astute accomplices willing to suffer rough drafts, close holes, sand ragged edges, and wisely point out that things don’t always mean what their author thinks they mean, I thank Jess Money, Gail McNamara, and my editor, Andrew Albanese.

如果不是我的经纪人的超凡时间安排，我可能会把这本书拖到下个世纪。谢谢你，黛布拉·罗德曼。

If it weren’t for my agent’s uncanny timing, I would have procrastinated this book into the next century. Thank you, Debra Rodman.

如果不是出版商的坚持，我可能会把经纪人的要求拖到下个世纪。谢谢你，朱迪思·里根。

If it weren’t for my publisher’s persistence, I would have procrastinated my agent’s promptings into the next century. Thank you, Judith Regan.

如果没有埃文斯学者基金会的支持和我在密歇根大学遇到的那些人才，我的人生将会黯然失色。我要感谢肯尼斯·罗、约翰·阿托斯、休·诺顿、克拉丽贝尔·贝尔德、唐纳德·霍尔，以及所有其他我已忘记名字的教授，但他们的精彩教诲让我的生活充满活力。

If it weren’t for the support of the Evans Scholars Foundation and the minds I met at the University of Michigan, my life would have been diminished. I offer my gratitude to Kenneth Rowe, John Arthos, Hugh Norton, Claribel Baird, Donald Hall, and all other professors whose names I’ve forgotten, but whose brilliant teachings have braced my days.

最后，最重要的是，我的学生们。多年来，我对故事艺术的理解不断加深，这在很大程度上要归功于你们提出的问题，这些问题既有洞察力又有实践性，它们让我更加深入地寻找答案。没有你们，这本书就不会存在。

Lastly, most importantly, my students. Over the years my understanding of the art of story has grown thanks, in great part, to the questions you’ve asked, questions both perceptive and practical, that have sent me further and deeper in search of answers. This book would not exist without you.

关于作者

About the Author

罗伯特·麦基经常在洛杉矶、纽约、伦敦和世界其他主要电影电视中心授课。如需了解离您最近的课程信息，请拨打免费电话 (888) 67-MCKEE (676-2533)。传真 (310) 318-3924，或访问他的网站 www.mckeestory.com。

Robert McKee lectures regularly in Los Angeles. New York, London, and other major film and television centers throughout the world. For information on the class nearest you, call toll free (888) 67-MCKEE (676-2533). fax (310) 318-3924, or visit his website at www.mckeestory.com.

访问 www.AuthorTracker.com 获取有关您最喜爱的 HarperCollins 作家的独家信息。

Visit www.AuthorTracker.com for exclusive information on your favorite HarperCollins author.
